The funding was co-led by Franklin Templeton and Peak6 Strategic Capital, with the goal of targeting new segments within financial services. Bambu's scalable software-as-a-service solutions enable companies to digitize savings and investing for clients, with over 15 financial institutions worldwide already using its technology. The funding round brings the company's employee count to 70 and marks its continued growth in the digital wealth space.

site_title: BP avoids sending tankers and crews through Strait of Hormuz
summary: BP is avoiding sending tankers and crews through the Strait of Hormuz due to heightened tensions between Iran and the UK. The British oil giant's CEO, Robert Dudley, stated that BP is "not sending British ships and crews" to the region after a BP tanker took shelter near Saudi Arabia earlier this month. The decision follows a British Royal Marines seizure of a vessel transporting Iranian crude in the Mediterranean.

site_title: Hyflux applies to again extend debt moratorium; still in talks with potential white knights
summary: Hyflux has applied to extend its debt moratorium for a further two months to August 2, as it continues to discuss potential investments with strategic investors and stakeholders. The company is in talks with Utico FZC, which could take an 88% stake in Hyflux for a S$400 million commitment. This deal, valued at up to S$535 million, aims to ensure Hyflux remains a going concern and grow its business. The court will hear the applications on August 2.

site_title: Thailand's tourism numbers to see modest recovery, supported by Chinese and Indian tourists
summary: Thailand's tourism sector is expected to see a modest recovery, driven by the return of Chinese tourists. Arrivals from mainland China increased 2.3% year-over-year in July 2019, following a decline in the previous year due to negative publicity and political uncertainty. The sector has been struggling, with a 10% average annual growth rate over the past five years. The recovery is seen as a positive sign, but the industry still faces challenges, including air pollution and a strong Thai baht.

site_title: Trump says will look to cut US defence budget in future
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to cut defense costs in future budgets, following a significant increase in military spending during his presidency. Trump stated that the US now has a "very strong military" and can "cut back" on spending. The Republican-controlled Senate is set to vote on a Trump-backed budget with $738 billion for defense spending, contributing to a near $1 trillion budget deficit. Trump's fellow Republicans have criticized the growing budget deficits, and he plans to address this in his potential second term agenda.

site_title: Further drop in housing loans but business lending, total loans rise in June: MAS data
summary: Singapore's housing loan segment declined 0.2% in June, with the segment experiencing its sixth straight month of decline, and the magnitude of the drop increasing from May. However, business lending rose 1.3% month on month and 3.8% year on year, offsetting the decline and resulting in an increase in total loans to S$687.08 billion. This was largely due to government measures implemented last year to cool the property market, and bookings for DBS's mortgage book increased by 60% compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: Nintendo misses profit estimates amid sluggish game lineup
summary: Nintendo reported a 10% decline in operating income to 27.4 billion yen in its fiscal first quarter, missing analyst estimates. The company's net sales increased to 172.1 billion yen, but its full-year profit and revenue outlooks remain unchanged. Despite a strong lineup of games, including new Zelda and Pokemon titles, and the upcoming release of the Switch Lite, Nintendo's shares declined as the company's profit estimates fell short. Analysts expect the Switch Lite and China market to boost sales, but the company's conservative forecast for the year remains below analyst expectations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open ahead of GDP figures
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.02% at the open on Wednesday ahead of the release of quarterly GDP figures. The Hang Seng Index dropped 286.09 points to 28,860.41. US-China trade talks in Shanghai also contributed to the decline. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, down 0.27% and 0.22% respectively.

site_title: Air France-KLM orders 60 new Airbus planes, plans A380 phase-out
summary: Air France-KLM has ordered 60 new Airbus A220-300 planes, valued at around $5.5 billion, to modernize its fleet and reduce operating costs and carbon emissions. The airline plans to phase out its 10 A380 superjumbos by 2022 due to high fuel consumption and emissions. The A220s will replace ageing short and medium-haul flights, reducing operating costs per seat by at least 10%. The move aims to streamline operations and compete with low-cost rivals.

site_title: CRCT posts Q2 DPU of 2.54 S cents on stronger rental growth from core malls
summary: CRCT posted a Q2 DPU of 2.54 S cents, down 3.8% from the year-ago DPU, driven by stronger rental growth from core malls. Gross revenue grew 1.9% to S$55.2 million, while net property income increased 11.5% to S$40.4 million. The Reit's gearing was 33.8%, below the regulatory limit of 45%.

site_title: South Korean cult leader jailed for beating followers
summary: A South Korean court has sentenced cult leader Shin Ok Ju to six years in jail for holding 400 followers captive in Fiji and subjecting them to violence and barbaric rituals. Shin, founder of the Grace Road Church, convinced her followers to move to Fiji in 2014, where they were allegedly beaten, tortured, and punished with "ground threshings" for attempting to leave the church. The court found Shin guilty of violence, child abuse, and fraud, with the judge stating "heavy punishment is inevitable against illegal acts carried out in the name of religion."

site_title: Tensions high as Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters face court
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong appeared in court Wednesday, charged with rioting, amidst ongoing unrest sparked by a government bid to introduce a law allowing extraditions to mainland China. The 44 charged face up to 10-year jail terms, triggering clashes between police and protesters. The southern Chinese city has endured over seven weeks of protests demanding deeper democratic reforms and an end to eroding freedoms. Protests continue, with protesters vowing to keep their campaign going until their core demands are met, including the resignation of the leader and an independent inquiry into police tactics.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.3% at 3,340.21
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,340.21 at 1:05pm on Wednesday, driven by investor risk-off sentiment ahead of the Federal Reserve's anticipated rate cut. US President Donald Trump's comments on trade kept expectations of progress between the US and China's economies at bay. The local banks were mixed, while property developers CapitaLand and City Developments gained ground.

site_title: Sony CEO demonstrates how to manage a shrinking tech icon
summary: Sony's shares rose 6.6% after the company reported a beat on first-quarter profit due to strong demand for image sensors and improved smartphone business profitability. Despite reducing its revenue forecast by 200 billion yen, the company's profit outlook for the year remained unchanged. CEO Kenichiro Yoshida, who played a key role in Sony's turnaround, demonstrated his ability to manage the company's shrinking tech icon. Investors showed optimism, despite declining PlayStation 4 game sales and television sales.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.02 points to 1,640.67. Volume was 57.19 million lots worth RM16.73 million. The market saw 87 gainers versus 77 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong's youth aren't as happy as Singapore's: poll
summary: Hong Kong's youth are less happy than their peers in Singapore, according to a survey by the City University of Hong Kong. The "Happiness Index" study found that Hong Kong residents rated their happiness levels at 6.80, compared to 7.48 for Singaporeans. Hong Kong's residents were also dissatisfied with their housing conditions and were the least pleased with their economic conditions. The survey's lead researcher warned that the protests and government inaction could lead to a rapid decline in happiness levels, potentially causing Hong Kong to fall behind Singapore.

site_title: Trade war keeps China's factories in reverse gear for 3rd straight month
summary: China's factory activity shrank for the third consecutive month in July, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.7, below the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. The weak manufacturing reading, fueled by US-China trade tensions, may fuel global recession concerns and prompt policymakers to ease measures. Factory output, however, showed a slight increase, while export orders continued to shrink for the 14th month. The country's economy remains sluggish, with business confidence and investment weighed down by the ongoing trade war.

site_title: Australia: Shares ease as banks, builders sag; New Zealand hits new peak
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% to 6,823.2, with banks and construction stocks leading losses after the benchmark closed at a record high. The drop was attributed to profit-taking and concerns over weaker earnings from cement manufacturer Adelaide Brighton. In contrast, New Zealand shares rose 0.4% to a record high of 10,916.50, driven by gains in the dairy firm a2 Milk Company. A trade threat from US President Donald Trump also cast a pall on Australian markets.

site_title: Air Canada lifts Q2 earnings despite 737 MAX grounding
summary: Air Canada reported Q2 earnings beating expectations, driven by higher travel volumes and rising business class income. Despite the grounding of its 24 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft following deadly crashes, profits were unaffected. This contrasts with other airlines that have taken major hits to earnings due to the MAX grounding. Air Canada's positive earnings are attributed to its ability to adapt to the crisis and capitalize on increased demand for air travel.

images.alt_text: Profits at Air Canada beat expectations in the second quarter thanks to higher travel volumes and rising business class income, the airline said Tuesday.

site_title: US-China big power rivalry set for Bangkok staging
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet with Chinese and Russian counterparts in Bangkok, where the US will assert its influence in the Asia-Pacific region amidst China's military expansion. The summit comes as tensions rise over the South China Sea and North Korea's nuclear program. Pompeo will emphasize the US's commitment to regional security and freedom of seas and skies, while China and Russia seek to counterbalance US moves. The meeting follows a joint China-Russia bomber patrol over airspace claimed by Tokyo and South Korea.

site_title: Aloysius Pang's death: Two SAF servicemen to be charged in military court
summary: Two Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) servicemen, Ivan Teo Gee Siang and Hubert Wah Yun Teng, have been charged in military court over the death of actor Aloysius Pang, who died on January 23 after being seriously injured during a live-firing exercise in New Zealand. Teo faces three charges, including disobedience of general orders and causing death by negligent act, while Wah faces two charges, including causing death by rash act and negligent act. Both servicemen have applied for pro bono legal services and have been granted bail of $5,000 each.

site_title: Sony CEO demonstrates how to manage a shrinking technology icon
summary: Sony's shares rose 6.6% after the company reported a first-quarter profit that beat estimates, driven by strong demand for image sensors and improved smartphone profitability. The Tokyo-based company reduced its revenue forecast due to declining PlayStation 4 game sales and TV sales, but kept its profit outlook unchanged. CEO Kenichiro Yoshida is boosting capital spending to 1.2 trillion yen through March 2021, fueled by investments in sensors. Analysts praise the image sensor business as a key contributor to Sony's positive sales and earnings results.

images.alt_text: Chief Executive Officer Kenichiro Yoshida is showing he knows how to manage a shrinking Sony Corp.

site_title: Thai baht expected to survive central bank's push to restrain it: forecasters
summary: Thailand's central bank took steps to curb the baht's surge, but forecasters predict it will recover in the medium term due to the country's solid economic fundamentals and a global easing cycle. The baht may drop 2% in the next couple of weeks but recover to around 31 by year-end, according to top forecasters. Moody's and Fitch Ratings boosted Thailand's credit ratings, complicating the central bank's efforts, while rate cuts by the Federal Reserve are expected to weaken the dollar and boost the baht's value.

site_title: Boris Johnson visits Northern Ireland, heart of Brexit battle
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited Northern Ireland, the heart of the Brexit battle, to meet with leaders and discuss the restoration of the power-sharing government. His vow to leave the EU with or without a deal has raised concerns that it could break up the UK. Johnson's talks with Northern Ireland's main parties aimed to address the collapse of the government in January 2017. Irish leaders warned that Johnson's stance risks destabilizing the region, while Johnson sought to reassure them of his commitment to maintaining the UK's unity.

site_title: Trump tweets threaten to disrupt US-China trade talks
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to disrupt US-China trade talks on Twitter, despite official negotiations set to begin in Shanghai. Trump claimed China was not buying US agricultural products, calling it "arrogance." Chinese officials met with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin for dinner, but tensions remain high. Analysts say Trump's tweets will do little to ease the tense relationship, and the meetings are seen as a positive step despite low expectations.

site_title: Big is beautiful in Malaysian stocks as foreign funds return
summary: Malaysia's stocks are expected to outperform smaller ones in the second half of the year, driven by foreign funds returning to the market. Despite a 3.6% decline in the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index, which tracks the largest 30 companies, investors predict a 10% gain for the benchmark gauge. Large firms are seen benefiting from clearer policy direction and a stabilizing economy, with over $3 billion leaving the nation since the election last year. Foreign funds have returned to buy $61.4 million in Malaysian stocks in July, a second straight month of inflow.

site_title: Indian coffee tycoon Siddhartha's body found: police
summary: Indian coffee tycoon V.G. Siddhartha's body was recovered from the Nethravathi river near Mangaluru in Karnataka state. He was missing since Monday night and his family was notified. Siddhartha, founder of Cafe Coffee Day, was traveling to Mangaluru when he went for a walk and failed to return. His disappearance had spooked investors, causing a 20% drop in shares. Speculation about his death included pressure from outstanding debts and a letter purportedly written by Siddhartha blaming a private equity partner and tax authorities for his demise.

site_title: Britain searches for post-Brexit trading opportunities in South-east Asia
summary: British Foreign Minister Dominic Raab is set to attend an Asean meeting in Bangkok to explore post-Brexit trading opportunities in South-east Asia. The region is already worth £36 billion to the UK in trade, and Raab aims to boost that trade to benefit UK businesses and consumers. The meeting comes as Britain prepares to leave the EU on October 31, despite concerns about disrupting trade with the bloc's largest trading partner. Raab seeks to strengthen diplomatic ties and secure new bilateral trade deals.

site_title: Singapore rich kids are ending up with penthouses as parents skirt taxes
summary: In Singapore, wealthy families are buying properties for their children to avoid taxes, taking advantage of the cooling measures introduced in 2018. The additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) of 12% for second homes and 15% for third homes has led to an increase in apartments being purchased for children. This trend is expected to continue as the market tests demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark in the third quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: A penthouse at Martin Place Residences off Kim Yam Road in River Valley. Data is scant but property agents say they've seen a noticeable up-tick in apartments being bought by wealthy families for their children since the property cooling measures came into effect in July 2018.

site_title: Philippines' Jollibee sets sights on Indonesia with Coffee Bean beachhead
summary: Philippines' Jollibee Foods Corp is expanding into Indonesia with its acquisition of US chain Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf for $100 million. The move aims to bring Jollibee's Chickenjoy fried chicken and sweet spaghetti restaurants to the country's 260 million population. Jollibee plans to turn Coffee Bean around to become profitable within 12-18 months and aims to generate 50% of sales from overseas within three to five years, with a goal of becoming one of the world's five biggest fast-food firms.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Wednesday's open after global markets fall; STI up 0.06% to 3,352.71
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.06% to 3,352.71 points at Wednesday's open, following a muted start. Key global markets, including Wall Street, fell after US President Donald Trump increased trade rhetoric against China. Banking stocks led gains, with DBS and UOB up, while OCBC and Frasers Logistics Trust fell. The STI outpaced losers 59 to 43, with 109.4 million securities worth S$480.4 million changing hands.

site_title: 'Disgruntled' Walmart employee shoots dead two co-workers
summary: A disgruntled Walmart employee shot and killed two coworkers and wounded a police officer at a store in Southaven, Mississippi, on Tuesday. The gunman, who had worked at the store for 25 years before being fired, was shot and wounded by a police officer. The incident was described as a "senseless violent act" by police chief Macon Moore. Walmart expressed its "heartbreak" over the loss of two valued employees, and the mayor called it an "isolated event."

images.alt_text: A disgruntled employee shot dead two co-workers and wounded a police officer at a Walmart store in the southern US state of Mississippi on Tuesday, officials said.

site_title: Federal Reserve opens 2-day meeting, rate cut expected
summary: The Federal Reserve opened a two-day policy meeting, expected to cut the US key lending rate for the first time in over a decade amid rising economic uncertainties. The rate cut, anticipated to be 25 basis points, would undo the December increase and address slowing global economy and trade uncertainty. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has signaled the bank is likely to lower rates due to economic uncertainties, including President Trump's trade wars with China and Europe.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit raises Q2 DPU by 2.6% on higher rent from Singapore hospitals
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 2.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.27 Singapore cents for the second quarter, driven by higher rent from Singapore hospitals and appreciation of the Japanese yen. Gross revenue and net property income grew 2.9% and 2.3%, respectively. The Reit's annualized distribution yield was 4.32%, up from 4.21% last year. The company's gearing was 36.9% as of June 30, and its CEO attributed the performance to the long-term outlook of the healthcare industry.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust raises S$258.1m via private placement
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) raised S$258.1 million through a private placement of 220 million units at S$1.173 per unit, drawing strong demand from investors. The issue price was at the top end of the price range and 1.2% discount to the adjusted VWAP. The private placement was approximately 3.2 times subscribed, exceeding expectations.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q2 net profit slumps 53%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 53% slump in Q2 net profits to 5.18 trillion won (S$6 billion), due to a weakening chip market and a trade row with Tokyo. Chip prices fell as global supply increased while demand weakened. Operating profits plummeted 56% to 6.6 trillion won, while sales dropped 4% to 56.13 trillion won. The company attributed the decline to a limited recovery in demand and increased marketing expenses. The chip market weakness is also expected to be affected by a dispute between South Korea and Japan.

site_title: US appeals court upholds ruling against Chinese banks in North Korea sanctions probe
summary: A US appeals court upheld a ruling by a US judge holding three Chinese banks in contempt for refusing to comply with subpoenas in a probe into North Korea sanctions violations. The judge ordered daily fines of $50,000 on each bank for non-compliance. The US Justice Department accused the banks of laundering millions of dollars for North Korea's Foreign Trade Bank. The Chinese government claimed it ordered the banks not to provide records, citing US "long arm jurisdiction." The ruling opens the way for heavy daily fines, potentially affecting Shanghai Pudong Development Bank's access to US dollar transactions.

site_title: For big banks, it's an endless fight with hackers
summary: Big banks, such as Capital One, face an ongoing battle against hackers, with thousands of cyberattacks attempted daily. In a recent incident, a software engineer breached Capital One's network, downloading sensitive data from over 100 million customers. Experts say simple mistakes, like leaving a window open, can be exploited by hackers. The company is expected to spend at least $100 million responding to the breach, and cybersecurity experts warn that the threat is a "full-fledged arms race" between hackers and financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Large financial companies have to thwart hundreds of thousands of cyberattacks every single day. Data thieves have to get lucky only once.

site_title: North Korea fires two ballistic missiles: South Korea
summary: North Korea fired two ballistic missiles on July 30, 2019, from the Wonsan area on the east coast, with the missiles flying approximately 250km. The launch comes days after a similar incident and contradicts a warning from the North to South Korea over planned joint military drills with the US. The UN Security Council has banned North Korea from ballistic missile launches, and US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said talks with the North are taking "a little bit longer" than expected to start.

site_title: Apple gets lift from services, offsetting iPhone weakness
summary: Apple reported stronger-than-expected results in the third quarter, driven by growth from services, which offset weak iPhone sales. Profit fell 13% to $10 billion, while revenues increased 1% to $53.8 billion. iPhone sales, which have weakened, were down 12% to $26 billion. Apple's services revenue rose to $11.5 billion, with sales of Mac computers, iPad tablets, and wearables increasing. The company expects revenue between $61 billion and $64 billion in the current quarter, with several new product launches planned for later this year.

site_title: Global airfares, hotel rates set for modest rise as economy slows in 2020: industry forecast
summary: Global airfares and hotel rates are expected to rise modestly in 2020 due to economic slowdown and escalating trade wars. Airfares will increase by 1.2% and hotel rates by 1.3% in US dollar terms, and 2.2% in local currencies. The forecast, from Carlson Wagonlit Travel and the Global Business Travel Association, attributes the rise to factors such as Brexit, oil supply shocks, and a growing likelihood of recession.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.86% or 187.04 points to 21,522.27. Investors were discouraged by US President Donald Trump's negative tweets on China, which continue trade talks between the two economies. The broader Topix index also declined 0.80% or 12.54 points to 1,563.04. The decline was attributed to concerns over the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: 'Amateur' Capital One hack stuns security community
summary: A 33-year-old former web engineer, Paige Thompson, was arrested and charged with stealing data from over 100 million credit card applications from Capital One, the 10th largest US bank. The breach, which affected 100 million US customers and 6 million Canadian customers, appeared to be an unsophisticated attack, raising questions about the security of the financial system and insider threats to cloud computing. Authorities say Thompson gained access to the data through a misconfiguration of the web application, not the underlying cloud-based infrastructure.

site_title: Europe: Shares crushed as Trump toughens stance on China
summary: Europe's main Stoxx 600 index plummeted 1.5% on Tuesday, its worst session since May, due to US President Donald Trump's tougher stance on China, which deepened the impact of a bruising trade war on global growth. Automakers and trade-sensitive stocks fell, while banks led declines due to growing interest rate expectations. The US Federal Reserve is set to conclude its monetary policy meeting on Wednesday, with investors awaiting a potential rate cut, which may lead to consolidation.

site_title: After US$6b M&A spree, insurer FWD eyes China foray ahead of potential IPO
summary: FWD, a US$6 billion insurer, is planning to expand into China ahead of a potential initial public offering (IPO). The company, controlled by Richard Li, has built a presence in several Asian markets and is seeking to bolster its non-life business in the region. FWD has applied for a licence to operate a majority-owned joint venture in China, which is forecast to account for 20% of global premium by 2029. The company's CEO, Huynh Thanh Phong, has stated that having a growth story in Asia, stability in Japan, and a strong base in Hong Kong will be compelling for an IPO.

images.alt_text: Fast-growing insurer FWD is seeking to launch operations in China ahead of a public offering and plans to bolster its non-life business in Asia, its chief executive said, as a potential shake-up looms in the region's insurance sector.

site_title: Oil rises on expectations of Federal Reserve rate cut, another US crude drawdown
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a two-week high on Tuesday, driven by expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut and a forecasted US crude inventory drawdown for a seventh consecutive week. Brent futures gained $1.01, or 1.6%, to settle at $64.72 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude gained $1.18, or 2.1%, to settle at $58.05. The Fed's potential rate cut and ongoing US-China trade talks boosted economic prospects, despite lingering concerns about oil demand.

site_title: Ex-Turks and Caicos premier loses bid to toss US$100m graft case
summary: A former Turks and Caicos premier, Michael Misick, has lost his bid to dismiss a US$100 million corruption case. Misick and nine co-defendants, including former cabinet ministers, were accused of selling government land to investors at discounted rates, pocketing the difference. The case, which began in 2015, was expected to last six months but has dragged on for years. The judge declared there was sufficient evidence for the defendants to answer, contradicting Misick's claims the case was politically motivated. The lengthy proceedings have cost the territory nearly US$100 million.

site_title: P&G posts strong sales but Gillette shaves quarterly profits
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) posted a 3.6% increase in sales to $17.1 billion in the latest quarter, driven by gains in four of five business segments. However, the company reported a $5.2 billion quarterly loss due to a $8 billion accounting charge related to the lower value of the Gillette shaving business. Despite this, P&G's share price jumped 4.1% following the results, which exceeded expectations excluding one-time items. The company attributes the loss to accounting rules and sees grooming as a viable long-term business.

site_title: Trump says working on free trade deal with Brazil
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to work on a free-trade agreement with Brazil, aiming to strengthen ties between the two largest economies in the western hemisphere. Trump praised Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, calling him the "Trump of Brazil," and stated that a bilateral agreement could be reached without tariffs. The two countries have a significant trade surplus, with the US exporting goods like agriculture and information services, and importing aircraft, fuels, and metals. A deal is expected to be negotiated during Bolsonaro's visit to the US next week.

site_title: HK protests taking growing toll on city's economy
summary: Hong Kong protests are taking a growing toll on the city's economy, with fresh train disruptions and increased violence affecting daily life. The unrest, now in its eighth week, has led to a decline in tourism, especially from mainland China, and a drop in sales for local businesses. Economists warn of a double-digit drop in sales in July and August, with some retailers expecting permanent long-term damage. The protests have also prompted Britain, Japan, Singapore, and others to issue travel alerts, further exacerbating the economic impact.

site_title: Building agility and resilience with digital risk management
summary: A digital risk management strategy is crucial for companies to prepare for cyberattacks, as they are increasingly likely to occur. Effective strategies involve collaborating with ethical hackers, adopting a holistic approach to risk management, and prioritizing risk exposure. Smaller organizations can build an effective strategy by reviewing existing processes, defining risk appetite, and investing in technology solutions to automate monitoring and management. A strong risk culture, digital access controls, and minimizing single points-of-failure are also essential for cyber resilience. Ultimately, organizations must be in control of their digital risks to protect themselves from costly cyber incidents.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Parkway Life Reit, Starhill Global Reit, CRCT, FHT, Japfa, Lian Beng, Tee Land
summary:
Key developments in Singapore stocks include:

Parkway Life Reit posted a 2.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.27 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by higher rent from Singapore properties and a Japan property acquisition. Starhill Global Reit's DPU decreased 0.9% to 1.1 Singapore cents, while CapitaLand Retail China Trust's DPU fell 3.8% to 2.54 Singapore cents. Frasers Hospitality Trust cut its distribution per stapled security (DPU) to 1.0086 Singapore cents due to earnings decline. Japfa's second-quarter net profit plummeted 83.1% to US$4.99 million due to a large fair-value loss. Lian Beng Group's fourth-quarter net profit dropped 74.3% year-on-year, while Tee Land's net loss widened to S$23.8 million for the 12 months.

site_title: Nintendo's Q1 net profit drops 46% on forex losses
summary: Nintendo's Q1 net profit dropped 46% to 16.6 billion yen due to exchange rate losses, but the company reported steady sales of its Switch gaming platform, with a 13.2% increase in hardware sales and a 25.9% increase in software sales. Nintendo maintains its full-year forecasts despite the decline, with a forecasted 7.2% decline in bottomline profit. The company also announced the release of a cheaper Switch Lite console in September.

site_title: Raffles United will not restore free float if trading is suspended
summary: Raffles United, a Singapore-based bearings and seals supplier, will not restore its free float if the Singapore Exchange (SGX) suspends trading in its shares. The company's public float fell below the 10% threshold, and it intends to take steps to delist after its exit offer closes on Aug 14. However, the SGX has not confirmed whether Raffles United's delisting bid will be approved, citing ambiguity over the "reasonable" exit offer.

site_title: Dollar stalls ahead of Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar showed little direction ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, which is expected to cut interest rates by 25 basis points for the first time since the financial crisis. The move is seen as a precautionary measure to protect the US economy from global uncertainties and trade pressures. The euro hovered near a 26-month low, while the pound plummeted to a new 28-month low due to concerns over a potential Brexit without a transition agreement. Markets will focus on the Fed's forward guidance for clarity on future rate cuts.

site_title: JTC launches Tampines site for tender; Tuas site up for application
summary: JTC launched two industrial sites in Singapore, one at Tampines for tender and another at Tuas for application, as part of the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The Tampines site has a 0.49 ha area and 2.5 gross plot ratio, with a tender closing on Sept 24. The Tuas site, a reserve list site, has a 0.47 ha area and 1.4 gross plot ratio, and is available for application. Both sites have a 20-year lease tenure and are zoned "B2" for heavier industrial use.

site_title: Investor engagement is paramount when buying into startups
summary: Investors are increasingly taking a chance on early-stage startups, with potential returns of five to 10 times more than later-stage investments. However, this comes with unique challenges, including identifying suitable companies and managing high attrition rates. To mitigate these challenges, investors must stay focused and disciplined, assessing a company's scalability and management adaptability. Prioritizing these key criteria can help investors navigate the risks and rewards of early-stage investments in startups.

site_title: Johnson is the new helmsman, but the country is still not out of the woods
summary: Boris Johnson aims to deliver Brexit by October 31, with a deal preferred, but is prepared for no-deal negotiations with EU nations. He's purging Theresa May's ministers and appointing a "war cabinet" to negotiate Brexit. Johnson's government is also making spending pledges to boost the economy and attract votes. However, critics question his credibility and ability to unite the UK's diverse regions, with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland having differing views on Brexit. Johnson is betting that the UK won't break up post-Brexit, despite the challenges ahead.

site_title: IndoAgri sinks deeper into the red with Q2 loss of 216.5b rupiah
summary: IndoAgri, a mainboard-listed agribusiness, reported a net loss of 216.54 billion rupiah (S$21 million) for the second quarter, driven by a 6.6% decline in revenue to 3.14 trillion rupiah. The plantation division saw a 19% plunge in revenue due to lower selling prices of palm products. The edible oils and fats division recorded higher sales volumes and profitability. The company expects ongoing US-China trade tensions to impact global trade flows and commodity prices.

site_title: Korngold's rarely heard opera hints at his future in Hollywood
summary: ERICH Wolfgang Korngold's rarely heard opera Das Wunder der Heliane made its belated American premiere at the Fisher Center for the Performing Arts in Annandale-on-Hudson, New York. The 1920s Viennese-style opera showcases experimental harmonies and salacious themes, characteristic of the post-Freudian era. The performance highlighted Korngold's contributions to high-period Viennese style, demonstrating his influence on future Hollywood work. The opera's belated premiere marked a significant event in the Bard SummerScape festival, offering a glimpse into Korngold's artistic evolution.

site_title: Citigroup to cut hundreds of trading jobs in bad sign for Wall Street
summary: Citigroup is set to cut hundreds of jobs in its trading division, with at least 100 positions in the equities unit, amid an industry-wide slump in revenue. The move is a sign of more permanent challenges facing Wall Street, with analysts warning of further staff reductions across banks. The decline in trading revenue is attributed to factors such as hedge fund outflows, new rules limiting lenders' ability to make principal bets, and technological advancements narrowing spreads in the market.

site_title: Upstart that led India's wireless revolution
summary: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Jio has successfully upended the Indian telecoms industry, displacing Vodafone Idea to become the country's top mobile operator by users with 331 million subscribers. Jio has led a wireless revolution with rock-bottom prices, making India's mobile data the cheapest globally. Ambani's next goal is to achieve dominance in fixed-line broadband penetration, aiming to connect at least 50 million households. The company's ambitions will likely transform it into a combination of US telecom operator AT&T and Jeff Bezos' Amazon, at a cost of nearly $40 billion.

site_title: Brave new world of 5G investing
summary: 5G technology is poised to revolutionize industries and economies, similar to the impact of electricity in the industrial revolution. The new network promises to be 10-15 times faster than broadband and eliminate latency, enabling applications such as self-driving cars, smart factories, and connected healthcare. Key benefits include instant responsiveness, exponential productivity gains, and accelerated commercial productivity gains. Investors must adapt their strategies to 5G to remain competitive, as it is expected to bring significant technological opportunities and disruptions.

site_title: New pilot scheme to help high-growth tech firms bring in EP talent
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) have launched a two-year pilot scheme called Tech@SG to help high-growth tech firms bring in skilled employees with Employment Pass (EP) applications facilitated. The program aims to support tech companies in sectors such as digital, medtech, and fintech, providing them with access to required business networks and talent. The initiative will connect firms with Singapore's innovation ecosystem and offer "manpower flexibilities" to facilitate the entry of core team members.

site_title: Why borrowing makes sense as a financial strategy
summary: The article discusses why borrowing can be a useful financial strategy for investors, particularly in a dovish monetary policy environment. Borrowing allows for flexibility, diversification, and leverage to boost returns, but comes with risks of amplified losses and interest payments. Smart leverage can be beneficial for wealthy investors, but pitfalls to avoid include taking on too much debt and failing to understand the risks. The article suggests that borrowing can be a useful tool for investors to tap into the benefits of risk assets, such as a rising global market.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as markets await Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday as the Federal Reserve prepared to announce its monetary policy decision, amid strong consumer data and President Trump's calls for a deep interest rate cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Consumer confidence rebounded strongly, but analysts said this could complicate the Fed's course. Individual companies like Capital One and Pfizer also saw significant declines, while Procter & Gamble led the Dow's gainers.

site_title: Major hunt for India's missing coffee king
summary: Indian police launched a major hunt for billionaire coffee tycoon VG Siddhartha, founder of Cafe Coffee Day, after he went missing on Monday night. Siddhartha, 60, was last seen walking across a bridge in Karnataka and his chauffeur alerted police when he didn't return. Police searched the Nethravathi river and his home, amid concerns for his safety. Siddhartha's empire came under pressure after tax authorities launched raids in 2017 and he was in talks to sell a stake to Coca Cola. His family has been in the coffee business for over 130 years.

site_title: Racism storm follows Trump to historic US settlement
summary: President Donald Trump sparked a racism storm after a speech in Jamestown, Virginia, where he marked the 400-year anniversary of the first English colony's legislative assembly. Trump denounced slavery, but was interrupted by a heckler accusing him of "hate." Black Virginia state lawmakers boycotted the event, calling Trump's rhetoric "racist and xenophobic." Trump has been accused of pushing racism through his comments on immigrants and non-white politicians. He denied hurting his approval ratings, claiming African-Americans have been calling the White House to thank him, but opinion polls show support among black voters is at an all-time low.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump denounced the "horrors" of slavery in a speech on Tuesday marking the birth of US democracy, but an interruption by a heckler accusing him of "hate" underlined how many Americans now see him as openly racist.

site_title: ST Telemedia marks 25 years with scholarships for disadvantaged Singapore students
summary: ST Telemedia launched three bond-free scholarships, valued up to S$4 million, to support Singaporean students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The scholarships, in partnership with Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy, Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, and Somerville College, Oxford, aim to provide access to quality education and equip students with knowledge of international affairs. The scholarships are STT's first university sponsorships and were established as a tribute to Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Rates softening, but firms not biting
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter-point at its end-July meeting, which may influence the Singapore capital market. Analysts believe the rates may stay "lower for longer," with DBS rates strategist Eugene Leow stating this as the key theme. Companies may instead restructure their debts rather than engage in corporate shopping sprees fueled by low interest rates.

site_title: A fulfilling investing journey
summary: Industry experts at a conference discuss the future of investing, ethics, and investor protection. They warn of a challenging economic outlook, with rising volatility, and stress the importance of companies taking responsibility for their actions and being transparent. The panel also emphasizes the need for investors to educate themselves, be aware of risks, and prioritize long-term goals over short-term gains. Experts advocate for a more proactive approach to ethics, including robust sales processes and increased transparency, to protect retail investors. Ultimately, they emphasize that investor protection is a shared responsibility, with everyone in the ecosystem playing a part.

site_title: Holistic investing: Do good and do well
summary: MAS MD Ravi Menon emphasizes the need for a holistic approach to investing, balancing financial returns, security in retirement, and environmental sustainability. He highlights the growth of private markets, wealth preservation in an ageing Asia, and climate change as key trends. Menon notes that Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on private markets, with its vibrant ecosystem and favorable regulatory environment. He also stresses the importance of climate-conscious investing, citing the need for enhanced disclosure and industry expertise to support sustainable finance.

site_title: Consumer spending and prices rise moderately in June
summary: US consumer spending and prices rose moderately in June, with a 0.3% gain in consumer spending and a 0.1% increase in the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index. This suggests slower economic growth and benign inflation, potentially leading to the US Federal Reserve cutting interest rates for the first time in a decade. The economy grew at a 2.1% rate last quarter, despite weak exports, business investment, and a slowdown in inventory accumulation.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mazda 3 Review
summary: The Money FM podcast recently released a review of the Mazda 3, highlighting its strengths and weaknesses. The Mazda 3 received praise for its agile handling, comfortable ride, and premium interior. However, some critics noted that the car's infotainment system can be slow and the rear seats are somewhat cramped. Overall, the Mazda 3 is considered a solid choice for those seeking a fun-to-drive and feature-packed compact car.

site_title: Singapore to stop LNG indices, sheds hope of being main price hub
summary: Singapore Exchange will stop producing and publishing its spot price indices for liquefied natural gas (LNG) after less than four years, due to low participation. The SGX LNG Index Group, also known as 'Sling', will cease publication until October 31, 2019, and futures and swaps related to the indices will be delisted. Despite efforts to establish Singapore as a main pricing hub, the city-state faces competition from established pricing agencies, with S&P Global Platts' Japan Korea Marker becoming the main benchmark for spot cargoes in Asia.

site_title: Still upbeat about Asia Pacific prospects
summary: UBS private bankers remain optimistic about Asia Pacific prospects despite the challenges of 2019. Clients are cautiously optimistic, with a focus on diversifying portfolios through investments in disruptive trends and stable income instruments. The Fed's changing views on interest rates are expected to benefit equity markets. While Asia Pacific economies have slowed, clients are hopeful for long-term growth and see opportunities in emerging markets such as China, India, and Vietnam. There is growing interest in sustainable investments, with UBS launching its first sustainable investing mandate and seeing significant client commitments. The outlook for the rest of 2019 is cautious, with a focus on prudent risk management and opportunities for growth.

site_title: Five Eyes not united over 5G issue
summary: The Five Eyes intelligence partnership, consisting of the US, UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, is facing challenges over the use of Chinese 5G telecommunications technology, specifically Huawei. While the US and Australia have banned Huawei, the UK has allowed a limited role, sparking concerns among US officials that it may limit intelligence sharing. Canada and New Zealand are also taking nuanced approaches, with Canada delaying a decision until after an election and New Zealand exploring a "third way" path. The issue highlights the evolving global landscape and the need for the alliance to balance its relationships with China and the US.

site_title: Asiana feels chill in air travel from frosty S Korea-Japan ties
summary: South Korea's Asiana Airlines plans to switch to smaller planes for some of its Japan routes starting in September due to declining demand amid worsening diplomatic and economic ties between the two countries. The airline will operate smaller aircraft on three routes to Osaka, Fukuoka, and Okinawa from Seoul. This decision follows Japan's tightening of export controls and a widespread boycott of Japanese products and services, including air travel. Other carriers, including Korean Air and budget airlines, have also suspended or reduced flights to Japan.

site_title: Growing interest in sustainable investing
summary: Growing interest in sustainable investing is increasing in Singapore and Asia, driven by institutional and individual investors seeking to generate high returns while also making a positive impact. BNP Paribas has anticipated this demand and offers a range of sustainable investment solutions, including ESG integration, responsible multi-sector investing, and impact investing. The bank's clients are increasingly seeking to integrate ESG criteria into their investment processes, with a measurable impact on financial performance. The use of ESG criteria is becoming more widespread, with investors such as Temasek fully integrating ESG analysis into its investment processes.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) Q3 FY2019 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 3.9% year-on-year to 1.73 cents, driven by weaker Australian dollar (AUD) and partially offset by new acquisitions. The AUD cash rate was lowered to 1% by the Reserve Bank of Australia, potentially lowering borrowing costs and facilitating acquisitions. FLT's ability to tap its sponsor's pipeline in Australia and Europe is seen as a key investment merit. Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit for Q1 FY2019 was flat at 4.005 cents, with occupancy falling 0.8 percentage points due to Australia's drag.

site_title: Capital One says hacker stole data of about 100 million people
summary: A hacker, identified as Paige Thompson, 33, stole data of approximately 100 million people from Capital One, a US bank, by hacking into a server holding customer information. Thompson, a former Amazon Web Services employee, gained access to the sensitive data through a misconfigured firewall. The breach included 140,000 Social Security numbers and 80,000 bank account numbers, and the information came from credit card applications dating back to 2005. Capital One stated it believes the information was unlikely to be used for fraud, and the company has fixed the configuration vulnerability.

site_title: Cleaning up Asia's polluted air
summary: China is a key player in addressing Asia's urban air pollution, with sufficient resources and nationwide policy coordination enabling it to set an example for the region. Despite efforts to regulate car ownership, emissions targets, and electrify urban bus systems, challenges persist, with northern Chinese cities missing pollution abatement targets and high-pollution events continuing to make global headlines. The World Health Organization estimates that seven million premature deaths per year are attributable to air pollution, with China suffering over one million premature deaths annually. China must balance environmental sustainability with economic growth, and real progress will be attainable only when the rule-of-law is upheld and society genuinely expects and demands improvements.

site_title: GAM Holding calls truce with Tim Haywood, appoints new CEO
summary: Swiss asset manager GAM Holding has called a truce with former star manager Tim Haywood after months of dispute over his sacking, agreeing to a ceasefire without pursuing the matter further. The company has also appointed BlackRock executive Peter Sanderson as its new CEO, effective September 1, aiming to simplify the business and focus on areas of expertise to restore investor confidence. GAM's shares rose 5% following the announcement, after losing three-quarters of its value in 2018 due to Haywood's dismissal.

site_title: Lufthansa's Q2 earnings add to Europe's aviation gloom as fare war bites
summary: Lufthansa's Q2 earnings fell 25% to 754 million euros due to a fare war and a stuttering global economy, adding to Europe's aviation gloom. Despite reduced full-year profit guidance, Lufthansa stands by its earnings goals and plans to reduce costs. Europe's biggest airline group joins Ryanair in clinging to earnings goals, citing a tough environment and falling fares. The airline warns that business trends could deteriorate further in the second half, with short-haul routes and routes between Asia and Europe being particularly weak.

site_title: Epicentre names special auditor in 'missing chairman' case
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has appointed Ernst & Young Advisory as its special auditor to investigate six matters, including the disappearance of chairman Lim Tiong Hian and allegedly missing funds. The special auditor will review corporate events, loans, and transactions, as well as Epicentre's cash flow and sale of a subsidiary. Trading in Epicentre's shares has been suspended since May 30. The company will make further announcements on the special auditor's findings and update shareholders on material developments.

site_title: Does regulation offer investors 'an appropriate degree of protection'?
summary: The article questions whether regulation offers investors an "appropriate degree of protection" in the financial system. The author reflects on the evolution of regulation, from the 1980s when the UK introduced investor protection measures, to the current state where regulation has become increasingly bureaucratic and burdensome. The author argues that regulation can be more of a hindrance than a help, citing the example of the "Know Your Customer" process, which has become overly complex and time-consuming. The author concludes that investors should accept that they are ultimately responsible for their own financial well-being, and that regulation may not be sufficient to provide the level of protection they need.

site_title: Indonesia declares state of emergency and fights fires in palm-growing hot spots as drought looms
summary: Indonesia has declared a state of emergency in several provinces due to widespread forest fires, with over 9,000 personnel deployed to combat the blazes. The fires, fueled by drought and illegal burning, have scorching 28,000 hectares of land and threaten the livelihoods of 48.5 million people. The government has warned of a risk to its rice crop and has deployed helicopters for water bombing. This is a repeat of the 2015 haze that affected South-east Asia, prompting President Joko Widodo to order a moratorium on new permits for palm oil cultivation.

site_title: Cooling measures fuel earnings angst for Tee Land
summary: Tee Land, a Singaporean real estate developer, reported a net loss of S$23.8 million for the 12 months to May 31, with revenue falling 7.9% year on year due to a tough market. The group sold 13 units at The Peak at a loss of S$1.3 million, and took a write-down on unsold units. Cooling measures implemented in 2018 have made shifting units tougher, and the company expects its overseas markets to be affected by local politics and currency movements. No dividend was recommended due to prudence.

site_title: Goodbye to energy shipping?
summary: Shipping's carbon-free future may lead to a decline in its importance to world trade. A report by Maritime Strategies International (MSI) found that global fossil fuel demand reductions could alter inter-regional commodity trade flows and shipping capacity. By 2050, oil demand would halve, coal consumption would fall by 80%, and natural gas demand would peak before declining. This shift could lead to stagnant or falling demand for tanker and bulk carrier services, with tanker demand expected to fall by 33% and bulk carrier demand by 14% from 2020 to 2035.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported mixed earnings results, with some experiencing significant declines. Rich Capital, a Catalist-listed construction company, received a refund for a S$1.75 million advance payment but continues to demand a refund for the balance. Far East Hospitality Trust cut distribution per stapled security by 9.9% due to declining net property income and gross revenue. Lian Beng Group's spin-off, SLB Development, saw a 29.9% increase in net profit despite a 79% fall in revenue. Japfa's second-quarter net profit dropped 83.1% due to a large fair-value loss.

site_title: The future of investing: A personal perspective
summary: A family portfolio manager reflects on the rapidly changing investment landscape, questioning the effectiveness of traditional long-term passive strategies. The increasing pace of technological disruption, fake news, and the emergence of new financial products and markets are making it challenging for investors to remain informed and make informed decisions. The author believes a more specific and proactive approach is necessary, while maintaining an understanding of the underlying businesses and avoiding complex products. Warren Buffett's success serves as an exception to the rule, but the author wonders if investors can learn from history and adapt to the changing environment.

site_title: Tougher ride ahead for S-E Asia's banks
summary: Morgan Stanley's Asian economics team warns of a tougher ride ahead for Southeast Asia's banks due to trade tensions and slowing GDP growth. The forecasted 5.6% annual growth rate for the region is the lowest since the Global Financial Crisis. Singapore banks are expected to face the largest earnings risk, with loan growth and net interest margins likely to decline. Indonesian banks, however, are expected to benefit from lower interest rates, which could stimulate loan and consumer loan growth. The team recommends investors favor more defensive banks in the region.

site_title: SembMarine shares tumble on warning of bigger loss in H2
summary: SembMarine's shares plummeted 4.9% after the company warned of a larger-than-expected net loss in the second half of 2019, projecting a full-year loss of S$74 million, similar to last year's loss. The shipbuilder and engineering group attributed the warning to insufficient new orders secured in the last few quarters, with a net order book of S$5.27 billion as of end-June. Despite a narrower second-quarter net loss of S$8.5 million, analysts expressed disappointment and downgraded their expectations for the company's earnings.

site_title: Uber cutting marketing staff to reduce costs
summary: Uber is cutting 400 jobs from its marketing team of over 1,200 workers to reduce costs and improve efficiency. The restructuring aims to make the company's brand message more consistent, following a bumpy stock market debut and a need for a clear narrative. Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi cited this as a factor in the decision, which also comes after a leadership shake-up in June. The company reported $3.1 billion in revenue in the first quarter but lost $1 billion.

site_title: PEs target Asean startups as they join VCs in funding landscape
summary: Private equity firms in South-east Asia are increasingly investing in startups due to the region's booming startup scene and record levels of dry powder. This trend is driven by the need to capture opportunities in the space, despite caution. Key players like GoTo shares are tipped for a rebound, and startups like Manus are accelerating their move to Singapore to stay competitive in the intensifying AI race. As a result, private equity firms are reevaluating business models to unlock deep tech innovation and capitalize on the growth potential of startups.

images.alt_text: A burgeoning startup scene coupled with record levels of dry powder are nudging some private equity (PE) firms in South-east Asia into the territory of cash-burning, rapid-growth companies.

site_title: Tesla needs even more than 'ludicrous' speed
summary: Tesla faces significant operating costs, with its auto gross profit margin dipping to 18.9% in the second quarter. The company needs to bring costs down faster to compensate for cheaper Model 3s, which account for a bigger proportion of sales. Tesla aims to achieve gross margins above 20% to cover expenses, but its "full self-driving" (FSD) upgrades and research and development spending may not be enough to achieve this goal, leading to downward revisions in earnings and revenue forecasts.

site_title: How low will the pound go? Nomura's Mr Brexit has some ideas
summary: London-based currency strategist Jordan Rochester at Nomura International Plc predicts the UK pound could slide to US$1.15 if the UK exits the EU without a deal, down from its current level of around US$1.22. With new Prime Minister Boris Johnson's tough stance on Brexit, Rochester puts the chances of a no-deal exit at about 30% and a deal at about 40%. His prolific output has made him the go-to expert for Brexit analysis, but his predictions have also included misses, such as a 2018 comeback trade for the pound.

site_title: Qingjian pays S$42.6m in Phoenix Road en bloc deal
summary: A 99-year leasehold apartment row on Phoenix Road near Bukit Panjang was sold en bloc to CNQC Realty (Treasure) for S$42.6 million, surpassing the owners' asking price of S$42 million. Each owner will receive estimated gross sale proceeds of S$1.08 million to S$1.44 million. The site, zoned for residential use, could be redeveloped into about 80 residential units. The sale is the second collective sale attempt for the property and follows a similar sale in District 9 earlier this year.

site_title: Investors turn defensive ahead of Fed cut
summary: Asian markets closed broadly higher ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected rate cut, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.1% to 3,350.54. Defensive stocks like Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and ST Engineering outperformed cyclicals, driven by growth uncertainties and lower interest rates. Retail investors shifted interest from local government bonds to higher-yielding plays, with purchases of Singapore Savings Bonds falling 60% in July. Other markets in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea also closed higher, with Australia's ASX 200 reaching an all-time high.

site_title: South Korea seeks US$350m trade sanctions against US
summary: South Korea is seeking US$350 million in trade sanctions against the US at the World Trade Organisation (WTO) due to US tariffs on steel pipes. The tariffs were imposed in 2014 to prevent South Korea from exporting the product at unfairly cheap prices. Despite a 2014 WTO ruling in South Korea's favor, the US failed to comply with the ruling, prompting South Korea to file for sanctions. The WTO has scheduled a hearing on the matter for August 9, and South Korea plans to impose tariffs on US goods, although the exact goods have not been announced.

site_title: The new and promising landscape of wealth management in Asia
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong continue to lead the global wealth management industry, driven by their robust regulatory frameworks, strong talent pools, and supportive local institutions. The region's young population and strong valuation uplift have fueled growth, with Asia expected to maintain its position as the fastest-growing region for wealth creation. Despite headwinds, Singapore and Hong Kong remain poised to capture growth in global offshore wealth management, with their combined aggregate growth rate in the past five years reaching double-digit growth. The industry is expected to continue consolidating, with smaller, boutique players thriving in the long term due to the importance of interpersonal relationships in wealth management.

images.alt_text: Clients will automatically be drawn to Singapore for its deep talent pool and access to expertise.

The combined aggregate growth rate in the past five years saw double digit growth and this is forecast to continue, which means Hong Kong and Singapore are poised to attain the world's number one and two respectively as global offshore wealth management hubs.

site_title: Ralph Lauren says North America sales to come under pressure
summary: Ralph Lauren Corp expects North America sales to decline due to a tough retail environment and weakness in foreign tourist spending, with shares down 4%. The company takes a more cautious view of the retail environment, citing volatile brick-and-mortar traffic, particularly from foreign tourists. Despite this, Q1 is still expected to be the strongest quarter of the year.

site_title: The changing face of philanthropy
summary: Philanthropy is evolving, shifting from cheque-giving to impact investing and venture philanthropy. Social enterprises, for-profit businesses with a social mission, are on the rise, addressing societal problems and offering potential for significant positive impact. Industry experts emphasize the importance of mentorship, bridging social enterprises with wealth clients, and aligning values and objectives. A win-win scenario can be achieved, generating financial and societal returns. As the younger generation drives change, traditional businesses are recognizing the need to embed social impact principles into their operations, with many joining the global B Corp community.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit raises Q4 DPU
summary: Starhill Global Reit has announced a 0.9% increase in its Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.1 Singapore cents, despite a 0.4% decline in net property income to S$39.9 million. Gross revenue rose 0.4% to S$51.9 million, while distributable income decreased 1.7% to S$24.9 million. The Reit's full-year DPU fell to 4.48 Singapore cents, down from 4.55 cents the previous year. Occupancy rate stood at 96.3%, with a weighted average lease expiry of 9.4 years.

site_title: CDLHT's Q2 DPS falls 3.3% on weaker showing from Singapore, Maldives hotels
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 3.3% decline in its total distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.07 Singapore cents for the second quarter, driven by weaker performances from Singapore and Maldives hotels. Gross revenue fell 0.5% to S$47.5 million, while net property income (NPI) edged up 0.5% to S$33.8 million. The decline was largely offset by better performance from certain hotels and inorganic contributions. For the half-year, NPI fell 5.4% to S$67.5 million, while total distribution declined 3.5% to S$50.4 million.

site_title: BP profit outstrips forecasts, buoyed by higher oil output
summary: BP reported a stronger-than-expected profit in the second quarter, driven by increased oil and gas production despite weaker crude prices and refining profit. The result beat forecasts and follows a steady recovery for the company since 2014. BP's shares rose as a result. In contrast, Total and Equinor reported sharp earnings drops.

site_title: Aspion's ex-directors countersue Top Glove over RM1.37b deal, breach of employment
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove maker, is being countersued by Aspion's former directors, Low Chin Guan and Wong Chin Toh, over the RM1.37 billion buyout deal. The duo alleges Top Glove's claims of loss and damages are "hypothetical" and "fictitious" and were made in bad faith to renege on an estimated RM650 million earn-out provision for a new breakthrough glove range. Top Glove had removed Low as managing director and adviser, and Wong as director, from Aspion. The case is ongoing with no certain outcome, and the trial dates have been postponed due to a recused judge.

site_title: Global policy adjusts to the surprising effects of trade wars
summary: Global trade wars have taken an unexpected turn, with China's economy performing relatively well despite US tariffs. Contrary to expectations, Chinese growth has stabilized, and domestic demand has responded to fiscal and monetary stimulus. In contrast, advanced economies such as Germany have been hit hard by the demand shock, leading to recession risks in Europe. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank are considering dovish monetary policies to counteract the economic downturn, with the ECB explicitly calling for fiscal support to boost the region's economy.

site_title: Japfa Q2 profit drops by 83.1% on fair value loss and higher sales costs
summary: Japfa's second-quarter net profit dropped 83.1% to US$4.99 million due to a large fair-value loss for biological assets and higher sales costs. Revenue improved 8.2% to US$975 million, driven by increased animal feed sales and a stronger dairy segment. However, the company attributed the losses to external factors such as cyclicality and African swine fever outbreaks in Vietnam. Japfa warned of potential short-term hits to profitability in Myanmar and China, but expects growing animal protein consumption in emerging markets to drive medium- to long-term growth.

site_title: ARA H-Trust's maiden DPS beats forecast
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust's maiden report showed a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.36 US cents, beating forecast by 3.2%. Lower property expenses and borrowing costs outweighed softer gross revenue, with net property income 0.4% higher than projected. The trust attributed lower-than-expected gross revenue to temporary factors, including new hotel supply and bad weather. Despite this, the trust's gearing remains at 31.9% and its managers expect distributable income to be in line with its IPO forecast.

site_title: Wing Tai chairman sells Nassim Road bungalow property for S$230 million
summary: Wing Tai Holdings chairman Cheng Wai Keung and his wife Helen sold their 33 Nassim Road bungalow in Singapore for S$230 million, setting a record for the highest price paid for a Good Class Bungalow in the area. The property, with a land area of 84,543 sq ft, sold at S$2,721 per square foot, surpassing previous records. The buyer, SG Casa Pte Ltd, is a trustee and fiduciary services firm.

site_title: CapitaLand-ParkCity condo project in KL more than 70% sold
summary: CapitaLand's joint venture with ParkCity Group has sold over 70% of units in the Park Regent condominium project in Kuala Lumpur, with 505 units sold at an average price of RM1,100 (S$365) per square foot. Malaysians comprise 80% of buyers, and the project is scheduled for completion in 2023. The condominium features well-designed homes, excellent location, and community amenities, with strong sales interest both locally and internationally, according to CapitaLand's CEO Ronald Tay.

site_title: Ascott Reit's DPU up 8% on robust performance, lower finance costs and one-off gain
summary: Ascott Reit posted an 8% rise in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.98 Singapore cents, driven by robust portfolio performance, lower finance costs, and a one-off exchange gain. Net income before changes in fair value rose 36% to S$50.4 million, and distribution to unitholders grew 8% to S$43.1 million. The trust's UK properties, particularly London, saw improved figures due to strong demand and several one-off events. Ascott Reit remains positive on Australia and other markets, with plans for further acquisitions and expansion.

site_title: Malaysia could replace Indonesia as top palm oil supplier to India
summary: Malaysia is poised to replace Indonesia as the top palm oil supplier to India in 2019, with refined palm oil shipments from Malaysia increasing by 50% in the first half of the year due to a 5% lower import duty difference between refined and crude palm oil. India's palm oil imports from Malaysia rose to 2.59 million tonnes, while Indonesia's share fell below Malaysia's for the first time. Indian refiners are struggling to operate due to the surge in refined palm oil imports, urging the government to raise import tax on refined palm oil to 45%.

site_title: Lian Beng Q4 profit down by 74.3% on lower revenue, lack of one-off gain
summary: Lian Beng Group's fourth-quarter net profit plummeted 74.3% to S$14.5 million, mainly due to lower revenue and a lack of one-off gains. The construction segment showed improvement, with revenue from external customers rising 67.1% to S$291.7 million for the full year. Meanwhile, spin-off SLB Development posted a higher net profit of 29.9% to S$1.48 million, despite a 79% drop in revenue. The companies are cautious on land bank replenishment and regional opportunities.

site_title: SoftBank to pump second Vision Fund with proceeds from first: source
summary: SoftBank plans to use proceeds from its first Vision Fund to bankroll its second, a $38 billion commitment, demonstrating confidence in its huge tech bets. The second fund, totaling $108 billion, will be supported by SoftBank itself and existing investors, with some new investors including Microsoft and Kazakhstan's sovereign wealth fund. SoftBank aims to return capital during the 12-year lifespan of the fund, reducing the need for debt.

site_title: Make your investments sustainable
summary: Sustainable investing is gaining momentum globally, with over $30 trillion in assets under management considering environmental, social, and governance factors. The amount of sustainable assets has increased by 200% since 2010 and 35% in two years from 2016. Three-quarters of US asset managers now offer sustainable investing strategies, and 93% of the world's 250 largest companies provide corporate responsibility reporting. Investors can start by defining their values and objectives, then translating them into actionable decisions, and finally constructing a sustainable portfolio through various asset classes, including traditional and private investments.

site_title: Prime US Reit's IPO structured to minimise risks amid uncertainty
summary: Prime US Reit's initial public offering (IPO) was structured to minimize risks amid uncertainty following dismal results from Eagle Hospitality Trust's public offer. The company's sponsor and entities related to its manager had to increase their stakes to fill the placement tranche, while the bankers chose a concurrent offering structure to allocate units between retail and institutional tranches. The public offer was oversubscribed, with the Reit ultimately selling 40.9 million units. Despite initial concerns about institutional demand, Prime US Reit's stock price has remained stable, trading at US$0.895, above its IPO price of US$0.88.

site_title: Trump says he wants 'a large cut' from US Fed
summary: US President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve to significantly cut interest rates, calling for a "large cut," amid a slowing global economy. Markets expect a 25-basis-point rate cut, undoing the December increase. However, Trump's request for a deeper cut of 50 basis points or more is seen as unlikely. The Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has signaled a potential rate cut due to economic uncertainties, including Trump's trade wars. The US economy is experiencing its 11th year of expansion, with steady job growth and low unemployment, making a rate cut a contentious issue.

site_title: Allied Tech says it will heed wait-and-see advice on missing escrow funds
summary: Allied Technologies, a Catalist-listed company, will wait for the results of an audit by PwC before taking action to recover S$33 million in missing escrow funds handled by scandal-hit law firm JLC Advisors. The company cited the need to avoid unnecessary costs and the ongoing investigations by the police force's Commercial Affairs Department. Allied Tech has already taken steps to recover the funds, including making a police report and filing a complaint with the Law Society, but has been unable to put money in a new escrow account as instructed by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: UK's Johnson promises Irish PM no physical border checks
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar that there would be no physical border checks between the two countries after Brexit. Johnson repeated that the current "backstop" plan, which keeps the border open, was unacceptable. He reiterated the UK's commitment to the Belfast Agreement and vowed not to put physical checks or infrastructure on the border. However, EU leaders have refused to renegotiate the deal, and Varadkar said alternative arrangements, such as electronic checks, are being explored. The two leaders agreed to maintain a close working relationship and discuss the restoration of the devolved government in Northern Ireland.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.14% to 28,146.50. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.39% and 0.45% respectively. Investors are watching US-China trade talks, but the market remains positive.

site_title: Saudi allows two firms to test computerised investment advice
summary: Saudi Arabia's capital market regulator approved two firms, Wahed Capital and Haseed Investing Co, to test computerized investment advice as part of a fintech initiative. The approvals follow the Saudi central bank's launch of a blockchain payment settlement initiative. The regulator will allow clients to receive automated investment advice through online platforms, and the companies will also offer discretionary investment management. This move aims to encourage the use of financial technology in the Arab world's largest economy, positioning Saudi financial centers as regional fintech powerhouses.

site_title: US consumer spending, prices rise moderately
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.3% in June, driven by a 0.4% increase in spending on goods and a 0.3% rise in services, offsetting a decline in motor vehicle purchases. The data, combined with slower economic growth, suggests the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates for the first time in a decade. Consumer prices, as measured by the personal consumption expenditures price index, edged up 0.1% in June, with the core PCE price index rising 0.2% for the third straight month, undershooting the Fed's 2% target.

site_title: Singapore shares squeeze out 0.1% gain on Tuesday ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Tuesday with a 0.1% gain, reaching 3,350.54 points. The market was influenced by investor adjustments ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate decision on Wednesday. Defensive stocks like Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and ST Engineering saw increased activity, while local banks were mixed. Trading volume was 1.17 billion securities, with total turnover at S$1.1 billion, 4% above the daily average.

site_title: Trump warns China not to wait on trade deal as talks resume
summary: US President Donald Trump warned China against waiting to complete a trade deal, citing China's failure to meet its commitments. Trump tweeted that China is "doing very badly" and has not started buying US agricultural products, which is a condition of the deal. He also suggested that China should wait until after the 2020 US presidential election, implying that a tougher deal would be made if he wins. Trump stated that the US has the upper hand in negotiations, saying "we have all the cards, our past leaders never got it!"

site_title: Wing Tai chairman, wife, sell Nassim GCB site for record S$230m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings chairman Cheng Wai Keung and his wife sold a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) site in Nassim, Singapore for a record S$230 million, or S$2,721 per sq ft. The 84,543 sq ft plot can be redeveloped into five bungalows. The sale price surpasses the previous record of S$105.3 million, set in 2018, and is among the highest achieved in a GCB Area in terms of psf on land area.

images.alt_text: The sprawling freehold plot of 84,543 sq ft in the Nassim area can be redeveloped into five Good Class Bungalows.

site_title: CapitaLand, ParkCity condo project in Kuala Lumpur over 70% sold
