summary: CapitaLand's joint-venture freehold residential development, Park Regent in Kuala Lumpur, has sold over 70% of its 505 units, with more than 353 units sold at an average price of RM1,100 per square foot. Malaysians made up 80% of buyers, and the development is scheduled for completion in 2023. The project features well-designed homes, excellent location, and community amenities, with CapitaLand expressing confidence in continued strong sales interest both locally and internationally.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit bumps up Q4 DPU by 0.9% to 1.1 S cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.9% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.1 Singapore cents, despite a 0.4% decline in net property income. The Reit's full-year DPU fell to 4.48 Singapore cents, down 1.7% from the previous year. Gross revenue and distributable income also decreased, while occupancy stood at 96.3% and gearing was 36.1%. The Reit attributed the decline to higher operating expenses and lower contributions from the Singapore retail portfolio.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust cuts Q3 DPS by 10.2% to 1.0086 S cents on softness Down Under
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 10.2% year-on-year decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.0086 Singapore cents for the third quarter, citing weakness in its Australian assets. Net property income fell 11% to S$25.4 million, with gross revenue losing 8.4% to S$35 million. The decline was attributed to softness in the Down Under market.

site_title: Why we should fear easy money
summary: The Federal Reserve is poised to cut interest rates for the first time since the global financial crisis, but experts warn that this could hasten a collapse in financial markets, leading to an economic downturn and falling prices. The widespread deflation of the 1930s and Japan's experience have given the word a uniquely bad name, and easy money has increased inequality, fueled by record bull runs in financial markets and benefited large corporations at the expense of small companies and startups. The Fed's decision could set the stage for a debt-fuelled market collapse, raising the risk of a global recession.

site_title: Commerzbank arm sells 71 Robinson Rd to Sun Venture unit for S$655m
summary: Commerzbank's Singapore arm has sold its 71 Robinson Road office block to SV Robinson, a Sun Venture unit, for S$655 million. The sale price translates to around S$2,756 per square foot based on a net lettable area of 237,644 sq ft. The property, which has a remaining lease term of nearly 74 years, was previously owned by Commerzbank since 2008 and features blue-chip tenants including CommerzBank, Visa, and WeWork. The sale reflects a positive outlook for the Singapore office investment market, with top bids close to the asking price.

images.alt_text: 71 Robinson Road - at the corner of Robinson Road and McCallum Street - is a 13-storey building with around 22,000 sq m of office space, along with two storeys of parking.

site_title: US urges Germany to 'help secure' Strait of Hormuz
summary: The US has urged Germany to join efforts to secure the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic oil shipping lane, amid escalating tensions between Washington and Iran. This comes after Britain ordered its navy to escort UK-flagged ships in the area following Iranian soldiers seizing a tanker. The US, France, and the UK are seeking to combat Iranian aggression and secure the waterway.

site_title: SBI Offshore opens escrow accounts, asks to resume trading
summary: CATALIST-LISTED SBI Offshore has opened escrow accounts with CIMB Bank in Malaysia and Singapore, totaling US$15.2 million, to demonstrate its financial stability and meet Singapore Exchange requirements. The company, which was suspended from trading in March 2019 due to being deemed a cash company, will apply to lift the suspension. If approved, SBI Offshore will resume trading, or the funds can be released if the company goes bankrupt or is delisted.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit record high on red hot iron ore prices
summary: Australian shares hit a record high on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 6,845.1, driven by higher iron ore prices and gains from mining companies BHP Group and Rio Tinto Ltd. The benchmark index added 0.3% to close at a record peak, despite economic uncertainties. The Australian mining sector has gained nearly 27% this year, outperforming other sectors. However, some analysts, such as Lazard Asset Management, have expressed concerns about the market's pricing and potential bubble in growth stocks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets wavered at the start of trade on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.2% to 7,702.15 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index declined 0.2% and Paris erased 0.1%. This marked a contrasting day to the previous session, where London's FTSE 100 rose 0.4%. The eurozone's markets reacted to the uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and a potential extension of stocks rally.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets wavered at the start of trade on Tuesday, with London ahead but eurozone counterparts nudging into negative territory.

site_title: Tee Land almost trebles its losses for FY2019, sinks S$23.8 million into the red
summary: Tee Land, a Singapore-listed developer, reported a widening net loss of S$23.8 million for FY2019, nearly tripling its previous year's loss of S$8.69 million. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue from projects in Malaysia and the absence of contributions from two other projects. Despite excluding non-cash items, Tee Land would have recorded a pre-tax profit of S$400,000. The company warned of a cautious approach to acquiring new land sites and investing, citing a challenging Singapore residential market and potential delays in project completion.

site_title: Dubai ruler's wife applies for UK forced marriage protection order
summary: Princess Haya al-Hussein, wife of Dubai's 70-year-old Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al-Maktoum, has applied for a forced marriage protection order in a London court. The order, along with wardship of their children and a non-molestation order, aims to protect her from forced marriage or psychological abuse. The couple is in a legal battle over their children's welfare, with Sheikh Mohammed seeking the return of the children to Dubai. A two-day preliminary hearing is set to continue on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Princess Haya al-Hussein, 45, a wife of 70-year-old United Arab Emirates Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al-Maktoum, has applied for the order, as well as wardship of their children and for a non-molestation order relating to herself, the High Court heard.

site_title: Crown Resorts to be probed by Australian law-enforcement agency
summary: Australia's Attorney-General Christian Porter has referred Crown Resorts to the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity over alleged links to Asian money-laundering gangs and efforts to fast-track visa applications by high-roller gamblers. Reports suggest Crown used junket operators with ties to drug traffickers to bring Chinese gamblers to its casinos, and an Asian crime syndicate laundered money through its Melbourne-based casinos. The move follows weekend media reports and comes as Crown shares fell 3.9% in response to the allegations.

images.alt_text: An Australian law enforcement agency will assess Crown Resorts' alleged links to Asian money-laundering gangs and the company's reported efforts to fast-track visa applications by high-roller gamblers.

site_title: 71 Robinson Road office block sold for S$655m to investment firm SV Robinson
summary: Commerz Real sold its 71 Robinson Road office block to investment firm SV Robinson for S$655 million. The 15-storey building, which has a net lettable area of 237,644 square feet, features bluechip tenants such as CommerzBank, Visa, and WeWork. The sale comes after weeks of reported interest from Sun Venture, with SV Robinson's open-ended real estate fund hausInvest securing the property through an open-ended sale. The building has nearly 74 years' remaining lease and is considered a high-quality Grade A specification.

site_title: 'We may lose Christmas': escalating Hong Kong protests taking bigger toll on shops, economy
summary: Hong Kong's protests are taking a significant toll on the city's economy, with economists warning of a potential double-digit drop in sales in July and August. The protests, which began eight weeks ago, have led to widespread closures of shops and bank branches, and a decline in tourism, particularly from mainland China. Luxury brands such as Richemont and Swatch have already reported declines in sales, and some retailers are warning of permanent damage. The protests are also affecting business confidence, with Fitch Ratings raising concerns about policy paralysis and erosion of the rule of law.

site_title: Epicentre names Ernst & Young as special auditor
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a Catalist-listed company facing a judicial management hearing, appointed Ernst & Young Advisory as its special auditor to probe six matters, including the disappearance of chairman Lim Tiong Hian and allegedly uncontactable loans. The special auditor will carry out digital forensic procedures and review company transactions. Trading in Epicentre's shares has been suspended since May 30, and the company will update shareholders on key findings. The board will also review Epicentre Pte Ltd's sale and a proposed share placement.

site_title: Asiana Airlines to switch to smaller planes for some Japan routes
summary: Asiana Airlines plans to switch to smaller planes for some Japan routes starting September due to declining demand amid South Korea-Japan tensions. The airline does not plan to discontinue any Japan routes, but is monitoring the situation. This move aims to reduce costs amid the worsening diplomatic and economic row between the two countries.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters disrupt train services, cause commuter chaos
summary: Hundreds of Hong Kong protesters blocked train services during the early morning rush hour on July 30, causing commuter chaos. The protests, which started three months ago as a reaction to an extradition bill, have now morphed into a wider backlash against the city's government and Beijing. The disruptions have forced hundreds to seek alternative transport, with some trains delayed and others having no service. The protests are part of Hong Kong's worst political crisis in decades, with China urging the protesters to stop targeting the rail network that serves five million people daily.

site_title: Citic Envirotech tells bourse that it believes hazardous waste treatment can drive revenue growth
summary: Citic Envirotech, a Singapore-based environmental engineering group, expects hazardous waste treatment to drive revenue growth. The company's hazardous waste treatment segment is expected to contribute positively to revenue, driven by government initiatives for sustainable waste management. This is a key departure from its traditional revenue sources, which include membrane system sales and engineering contracts. The company's treatment revenue added 0.5% to S$56 million in the second quarter, while engineering revenue fell 29.8% to S$79 million.

site_title: Australia: Stock market reaches all-time high
summary: The Australian stock market reached a new record high, with the ASX200 index climbing to 6,874 points, surpassing its previous peak in 2007. The All Ordinaries index also hit a record high last week, reaching 6,862.4 points. The steady climb is attributed to lower interest rates and the re-election of the conservative government, boosting shares. The market has been on a steady rise since January, with no signs of slowing down.

site_title: China anti-graft body probes high-level Xinjiang official
summary: China's anti-graft agency is investigating Enwaer Tursun, a high-level official in the Xinjiang region, on charges of "serious violations of discipline and law", a euphemism for corruption. Tursun, an ethnic Uighur, worked as deputy secretary-general of the region's People's Congress until his investigation began. This is the latest official to fall under suspicion in President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has ensnared many officials in Xinjiang. Tursun's case follows that of former chairman Nur Bekri, who pleaded guilty to accepting $11.5 million in bribes.

site_title: Raffles United says will not restore free float if trading is suspended
summary: Raffles United, a bearings and seals supplier, has stated it will not restore its free float if the Singapore Exchange (SGX) suspends trading in its shares. The company's public float fell below the 10% threshold last week and it intends to delist after the August 14 offer closes. However, the SGX's decision on the delisting bid is uncertain, with the offeror's IFA stating that the exit offer is "not reasonable from a financial point of view." If the delisting is not allowed, Raffles United's shares will remain suspended.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks bounce back; Fed in focus
summary: South Korea's stocks rebounded 0.45% on Tuesday, recouping some losses from the previous day, amid ongoing tensions with Japan. The US Federal Reserve is set to meet, with expectations of a 25 basis point interest rate cut. Japan is preparing to remove South Korea from its "white list" status, further exacerbating the economic spat. Foreigners invested $119.25 million in South Korean shares, while local stocks, particularly underwear makers, surged due to a growing boycott of Japanese clothing brands.

site_title: Tycoon who founded Starbucks's Indian rival missing since Monday
summary: V. G. Siddhartha, the founder of Coffee Day Enterprises, India's rival to Starbucks, has gone missing since Monday evening after going for a walk. Siddhartha, who holds a 32.75% stake in the company, was last seen by his driver, who reported him missing when he failed to return after an hour. Police are investigating his disappearance.

site_title: Rich Capital receives S$1.75m of S$2m advance payment guarantee from associate
summary: Rich Capital received S$1.75 million from associate company Rich-Link Construction (RLC) as an advance payment guarantee for PT Oxley Karya Indo Batam's (OKIB) development project in Batam, Indonesia. The payment renders the guarantee unnecessary, and Rich Capital will continue to demand the remaining S$250,000. The development follows a trading halt of Rich Capital's shares since June 27, amid concerns over conflicts of interest and a going concern issue raised by auditors.

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.06% to 3,344.50
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.06% lower at 3,344.50, amid anticipation of a potential Federal Reserve rate cut this week. The index was influenced by corporate results, including a narrower second-quarter net loss for Sembcorp Marine. Banking stocks also declined, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank down 0.7% and 0.1%, respectively. Gainers included Sheng Siong Group, which posted a higher second-quarter net profit.

site_title: Space@Tampines launched for sale with guide price of S$170m to S$190m
summary: Space@Tampines, a 7-storey e-commerce and logistics development, has been launched for sale via an expression of interest exercise with a guide price of S$170m to S$190m. The development, by Oxley Holdings and Lian Beng Group, features 24 showroom units, a food court, and 59 warehousing units on a 417,645 sq ft site. Zoned for Business-2 development, it offers a total gross floor area of 709,263 sq ft. The sale is expected to test demand for Singapore's prime projects above S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Tuesday for public holiday
summary: Malaysian financial markets are closed on Tuesday, July 30 for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Wednesday, July 31.

site_title: Pilot scheme to facilitate high-potential tech firms' Employment Pass applications
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) have launched a pilot programme, Tech@SG, to facilitate Employment Pass applications for high-potential tech firms. The two-year programme aims to help tech companies grow in Singapore and expand in the region by providing access to business networks and talent. It targets companies in growth areas such as digital, medtech, biotech, and fintech, and will facilitate the entry of core team members with skills in frontier technologies. The programme is expected to create opportunities for Singaporeans to work with globally competitive teams.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.43% on Tuesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 21,709.31. Investors bought on dips due to expectations of a potential interest rate cut, despite the Bank of Japan maintaining its ultra-easy monetary policy. Major companies such as Toyota and Nintendo saw gains, while Sony's earnings fell short of expectations. US jobs data is also expected to influence global markets, with traders waiting for clues on the health of the world's largest economy.

site_title: Indonesia returns containers of waste to France, Hong Kong
summary: Indonesia has returned seven shipping containers of illegally imported waste to France and Hong Kong, marking the latest effort by a Southeast Asian nation to send back rubbish to their places of origin. The containers, loaded with garbage, plastic waste, and hazardous materials, were found to be in violation of import rules. The move follows similar efforts by other countries in the region to address the issue of plastic waste and environmental pollution.

site_title: Paints startup gush raises S$3m from property group CDL
summary: Singapore-based startup GUSH has secured S$3 million in funding from City Developments Limited (CDL) for its pre-Series A round. GUSH produces sustainable paints and advanced building materials, which have been used in over 600 residential and 60 commercial projects in Singapore and the region. The funding will be used for research and development and expansion into new markets, particularly in countries affected by air pollution. GUSH's flagship product purifies the air, eliminates bacteria, and promotes healthier indoor environments, aligning with CDL's focus on leveraging strategic partnerships and innovations to cater to evolving lifestyle needs.

site_title: Southeast Asian beauty buyers turning to influencers over celebrities for guidance
summary: Southeast Asian beauty buyers are shifting their focus from celebrities to social media influencers for beauty guidance, with 80% of respondents citing influencers' impact on buying decisions. According to Meltwater's study, for every $1.30 spent on beauty influencers, brands receive an average return of $11.80. Influencers on Instagram are preferred, particularly in Indonesia, where usage doubled to over 44 million in 2017. Brands should focus on immersive experiences, personalized content, and leveraging data to identify relevant influencers, according to Meltwater's regional director, Mimrah Mahmood.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by a weaker yen and investors buying on dips. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.60% to 21,745.75, while the Topix index gained 0.50% to 1,576.41.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, propped up by a weaker yen and investors buying on dips.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,351.97, up 0.17% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday with a 0.17% gain, reaching 3,351.97, amid muted market activity. The Straits Times Index saw 166 advancers and 154 decliners, with 622.7 million securities worth S$496.6 million changing hands. Notable movers included Thai Beverage, which rose 2.41%, and CapitaLand Commercial Trust, which gained 0.48%.

site_title: Singapore to stop 'Sling' LNG indices, sheds hopes of main price hub
summary: Singapore Exchange to stop producing and publishing its spot price indices - Sling - for liquefied natural gas (LNG), less than four years after their launch. The decision comes due to low participation and will be discontinued by October 31. Despite efforts to develop Singapore as a price hub, the city-state's hopes of becoming Asia's main pricing hub have been dashed, with the Baltic Exchange's LNG freight indices gaining prominence instead.

site_title: US woman charged in massive Capital One data breach
summary: A 33-year-old tech engineer, Paige Thompson, has been arrested and charged with stealing sensitive data from millions of credit card applications at Capital One, one of the largest financial services companies in the US. The data breach occurred between March and July 2019 and affected approximately 100 million US individuals and 6 million in Canada, with no credit card account numbers or log-in credentials compromised. Thompson faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted of computer fraud.

site_title: 17 killed as Pakistani army plane crashes into residential area
summary: Seventeen people were killed when a Pakistani military plane crashed into a residential area in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, early Tuesday. The plane, on a routine training mission, crashed into a poor village near an upscale neighborhood, causing a fireball and injuries. Twelve people were injured, and rescue officials extinguished the fire and moved the injured to a hospital. The incident marks the latest disaster to hit Pakistan's aviation sector, following previous crashes that killed over 40 people.

images.alt_text: Seventeen people were killed when a small military plane crashed into a residential area in the Pakistani city of Rawalpindi early Tuesday, officials told AFP, in the latest disaster to hit the country's troubled aviation sector.

site_title: Phoenix Road property sold en bloc above asking price at S$42.6m
summary: A row of apartments and shops on Phoenix Road near Bukit Panjang has been sold en bloc for S$42.6 million, above the owners' asking price of S$42 million. The buyer, CNQC Realty (Treasure), a subsidiary of Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group, will redevelop the site to offer about 80 residential units. The property, with a 99-year leasehold tenure, is zoned for residential use and is located near the Phoenix LRT station and several amenities.

site_title: Citi to cut hundreds of trading jobs in bad sign for Wall Street
summary: Citigroup plans to cut hundreds of jobs in its trading division, including at least 100 in its equities unit, as the bank struggles with an industrywide slump in revenue this year. This move comes as global banks face challenges from hedge fund outflows, new rules limiting lenders' ability to make principal bets, and technological advancements narrowing spreads in the market. The cuts are a sign that executives are worried about more permanent challenges, with analysts predicting further staff reductions across banks.

site_title: Asia: Markets up ahead of US-China trade talks
summary: Asia markets rose modestly on Tuesday ahead of US-China trade talks, with investors doubtful of major breakthroughs. Hong Kong and Shanghai rose 0.5% and 0.8% respectively, while Tokyo and Sydney also gained ground. The Bank of Japan announced a status quo decision, and US Federal Reserve policymakers will meet later to consider an interest rate cut. Market optimism over central bank easing boosted oil futures, but the pound slipped against the dollar due to firming Brexit expectations.

site_title: BOJ leaves policy unchanged ahead of expected Federal Reserve rate cut
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy unchanged ahead of the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate cut, as most economists had anticipated. The BOJ left its yield curve-control programme and asset purchases unchanged, and its interest rate pledge remained unchanged. The decision reflects hopes that the Fed and European Central Bank's stimulus may already be factored into the yen's exchange rate, reducing the need for additional easing by the BOJ.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.17% at the open on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 46.59 points to 28,059.82. Investors continue to monitor US-China trade talks. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.18% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.06%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks follows a 0.4% increase in the STI on Thursday.

site_title: SembMarine Q2 loss narrows to S$8.5m
summary: SembMarine, a Singapore-based rig builder, posted a narrower Q2 net loss of S$8.5 million, down from S$55.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 55.1% to S$731.3 million, mainly due to lower revenue recognition from rigs and floaters. The company's repairs and upgrades segment saw revenue rise 13% to S$142.4 million. SembMarine expects losses for the second half to be higher than the first half, with full-year losses projected to be similar to last year's losses.

site_title: Hot stock: Delong up 15.8% to S$6.96 after CEO revives S$7/share cash offer
summary: Delong shares surged 15.8% to S$6.96 on Tuesday after CEO Ding Liguo revived his S$7 per share cash offer to take the company private through Best Grace Holdings. The offer represents a 9.5% premium over Delong's 12-month volume-weighted average share price. The Securities Industry Council previously censured law firm Shook Lin & Bok and financial adviser PrimePartners Corporate Finance for their roles in a failed privatisation attempt in 2018. The offeror obtained an SIC waiver to re-introduce the offer at the original price.

images.alt_text: As at 3.35pm, the counter was trading at S$6.96, up S$0.95, with some 2.2 million shares traded - making it one of the most actively traded stocks by value for the day.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q2 DPS falls 9.9% to 0.91 S cent on lower hotel revenue
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported a 9.9% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 0.91 Singapore cent for its Q2, down from 1.01 cents a year ago, due to a 7.4% decline in income available for distribution. Net property income decreased 2.4% to S$25.1 million, while finance costs increased 10.3% due to higher interest rates. The trust's enlarged base and lower hotel revenue contributed to the decline.

site_title: SGX extends deadline for KOP to hold AGM, release Q1 results
summary: KOP Limited, a Catalist-listed property developer, has secured the Singapore Exchange's approval to extend its fiscal 2019 annual general meeting (AGM) deadline to August 30 and to release its first quarter financial results by September 30. The extension was granted due to additional time required by the company and its auditors to justify and assess the impact of adopting new accounting standards.

site_title: Ascott Reit posts 8% higher Q2 DPU at 1.98 S cents
summary: Ascott Reit reported an 8% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.98 Singapore cents for the second quarter, driven by stronger portfolio performance, lower finance costs, and a one-off realised exchange gain. Net income before changes in fair value rose 36% to S$50.4 million. The trust also announced its proposed combination with Ascendas Hospitality Trust, expected to be completed by the end of this year, which is expected to deliver higher stable income.

site_title: Three arrested over Brazil airport gold theft
summary: Brazilian police have arrested three individuals in connection with the theft of an estimated $30 million worth of gold from Sao Paulo's international airport. The gold, intended for New York and Zurich, was stolen by armed men impersonating federal police. One of the detained individuals worked at the airport and claimed he cooperated with the robbers after his family was kidnapped. The gold remains missing, and the investigation continues.

site_title: ANZ Singapore named IFA for Ascott Reit, A-HTrust merger
summary: ANZ Singapore has been appointed as the independent financial adviser (IFA) for Ascott Residence Trust's proposed merger with Ascendas Hospitality Trust. The merger, valued at S$1.24 billion, will see each A-HTrust unit swapped for 5.43 Singapore cents in cash and 0.7942 new Ascott Reit-BT units. The transaction is subject to unitholders' approval and is expected to be completed by the end of this year. ANZ will advise the Reit's trustee, audit committee, and independent directors on whether the merger is on normal commercial terms and not prejudicial to minority unitholders.

site_title: China launches low-tax pilot schemes to support SMEs: Xinhua
summary: China has launched a low-tax pilot scheme to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in urban areas, allocating 2 billion yuan (S$398 million) over three years. The scheme aims to reduce tax and fees for SMEs, helping them access financing. The move comes as traditional banks rely more on asset security and fewer on complex risk assessments, making it harder for smaller firms to secure funds. The pilot schemes will cover 60 cities and are overseen by multiple government ministries.

site_title: Deliveroo Singapore revenue for 2018 up 69% to S$44.5m
summary: Deliveroo Singapore reported a 69% increase in revenue to S$44.5 million for 2018, driven by a S$20.7 million investment from its headquarters. The company expanded its rider and restaurant partners, reaching 6,300 riders and 4,500 partners by the end of 2018. Deliveroo also opened its Editions site with 10 kitchens and a 40-seater dine-in space in March 2019. The company's global sales more than doubled to £277 million as of Dec 31, 2017. Deliveroo's growth in Singapore reaffirms its investment in the market.

site_title: US airport security finds 'souvenir' missile launcher in checked bag
summary: US transport security officers confiscated a missile launcher from a checked bag at Baltimore/Washington International airport, finding it in a bag brought back from Kuwait as a souvenir. The launcher, a Griffin missile, was not a live device and was confiscated by the TSA, with the man, a Texas resident and active military personnel, allowed to catch his flight. The incident highlights the TSA's strict policies on military weapons in luggage.

site_title: Ramaphosa is 'last hope' for South Africa, Chinese diplomat says
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa is seen as the "last hope" for the country's economy by Chinese diplomat Lin Songtian. China has pledged more than $55 billion in investment, but projects have lacked feasibility studies and policies have not secured favorable conditions for Chinese investors. To attract more investment, South Africa needs to upgrade its infrastructure, including its railway network and power grid, and implement an investment law. The country's heavily indebted state-owned utility, Eskom, also needs to improve its management and operations.

site_title: Qualcomm seeks closer ties with China's Tencent in mobile gaming
summary: Qualcomm has partnered with China's Tencent Holdings to work on mobile gaming devices using Snapdragon chips. The cooperation aims to develop augmented and virtual reality technology and improve mobile gaming experiences with faster data speeds. This partnership is crucial for Qualcomm as it seeks to solidify its position in the 5G market, where Tencent is a major player in online gaming. The tie-up highlights the importance of China to Qualcomm's business, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: UK plays Brexit hardball, pound tumbles
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has warned that the Brexit divorce is "dead" unless the European Union renegotiates, prompting a 28-month low in the pound's value. Johnson said the UK would leave the EU on October 31 with or without a deal, despite warnings from investors that a no-deal Brexit would have significant economic consequences. The pound dropped to a 28-month low, and investors are scrambling for protection against currency swings around the exit date.

site_title: Japan factory output slumps in June as trade war bites
summary: Japan's factory output fell 3.6% in June, exceeding market expectations, amid slowing global growth and the US-China trade war. This data follows a 2.0% rise in May and is part of a trend suggesting the country's export-reliant economy is being impacted. The Bank of Japan is set to review the impact of overseas risks on its economy, which is expected to sustain a moderate recovery. Despite this, manufacturers forecast a 2.7% rise in July and 0.6% in August, citing solid domestic demand.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq retreat from records as markets await Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve's highly anticipated meeting, where a rate cut is expected for the first time in a decade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively. The Fed's decision is expected to shape market expectations for future interest rate cuts, with some analysts debating whether the central bank will need to deliver more stimulus this year.

site_title: CDLHT posts 3.3% fall in Q2 DPS on weaker showing from Singapore, Maldives hotels
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 3.3% decline in total distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.07 Singapore cents for Q2, down from 2.14 cents last year. Gross revenue also fell 0.5% to S$47.5 million. The decline was attributed to weaker performances from Singapore and Maldives hotels.

site_title: Google builds gesture controls into new Pixel phone
summary: Google is building gesture controls and face recognition into its upcoming Pixel 4 smartphone, powered by its motion-sensing radar called "Soli." The Pixel 4 is expected to debut in October, featuring capabilities such as skipping songs, snoozing alarms, and silencing calls with hand gestures, and automatic unlocking with facial recognition. Soli data is kept on smartphones and not shared with other Google services. This technology marks a "next step" in Google's vision for seamless computing power.

images.alt_text: Google on Monday revealed that it is building gesture controls and face recognition into a next-generation Pixel smartphone as it looks to fuel early enthusiasm for its upcoming flagship handset.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch higher on UK merger action
summary: European stocks rose on Monday, driven by a 15.3% surge in London Stock Exchange Group shares after a reported US$27 billion merger deal, and a 22.7% jump in Just Eat shares following a Takeaway.com acquisition. The FTSE 100 reached an 11-month high, while defensive plays dominated other major markets ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy decision.

site_title: Political pressure complicates Federal Reserve's expected rate cut
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to cut interest rates for the first time in a decade to boost the US economy, amid a slowdown. However, President Donald Trump's constant criticism of the Fed has complicated the decision, with Trump claiming the EU and China will lower interest rates and outpace the US. Despite low unemployment and inflation, the Fed aims to inoculate the US economy from a global slowdown. A rate cut is seen as a certainty, with many economists predicting additional cuts this year and as many as three by early 2020.

site_title: Cuba expands Internet access, but at a price
summary: Cuba has expanded internet access to all homes, but at a high cost, with Wi-Fi available for $1 per hour. The government aims to control the flow of information, citing the need to educate citizens on responsible internet use. Only a small percentage of Cubans can access the global internet, and critical websites are frequently blocked. The government closely monitors internet activity, viewing it as an "instrument for the defence of the revolution".

site_title: JTC launches Tampines site for tender; Tuas site up for application
summary: JTC launched two industrial sites, one at Tampines for tender and another at Tuas for application, as part of the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The Tampines site, available for tender, has a 0.49-hectare site area and a gross plot ratio of 2.5. The Tuas site, released under the reserve list, has a 0.47-hectare site area and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. Both sites have a 20-year lease tenure and are zoned "B2" for heavier industrial use. Tender for the Tampines site closes on September 24.

images.alt_text: The site at Tampines North Drive 5, which is available for tender, is the first of four confirmed list sites for the second half of the 2019 IGLS programme.
The Tuas South Link 3 plot has a site area of 0.47 hectare and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. It is the fourth of six reserve list sites for the second half of the 2019 IGLS programme

site_title: ARA US Hospitality Trust posts maiden DPS of 1.36 US cents, 3.8% above forecast
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust posted its maiden distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.36 US cents, 3.8% above forecast, for the period from May 9 to June 30. The trust's distributable income exceeded expectations due to higher net property income and lower borrowing costs, reaching US$7.7 million. ARA H-Trust made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at 87.5 US cents per stapled security, slightly below its IPO price of 88 US cents.

site_title: Elite club that rules diamond world is showing cracks
summary: De Beers, the world's most exclusive diamond trading company, is facing cracks in its elite club system. The company's sightholders, who purchase diamonds at discounted rates, are struggling to make money due to shrinking profit margins. The built-in discount has been reduced to as little as 0.1% or even higher, forcing some sightholders to sell at a loss. The industry is also facing stagnant high-end jewelry sales and financing challenges, with banks abandoning the sector due to frauds and bad loans.

site_title: M+S confirms S$1.58 billion Duo sale to Allianz-Gaw team-up
summary: M+S Pte Ltd is selling the office and retail areas of Duo in Singapore's Ophir-Rochor precinct for S$1.575 billion, or S$2,570 per square foot. The sale includes Duo Tower with 570,000 sq ft of office space and Duo Galleria with 56,000 sq ft of retail space. The Andaz Singapore luxury hotel will remain in M+S's hands. The deal marks a significant milestone for Gaw Capital Partners, which is partnering with Allianz Real Estate on the transaction.

site_title: Oil edges up on prospect of US interest rate cut
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as investors anticipated a potential US interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, overshadowing concerns over US-China trade talks and slowing global economic growth. Brent crude gained 25 cents to $63.71 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 67 cents to $56.87 a barrel. The expected rate cut and supply risks, including tensions in the Strait of Hormuz, supported crude prices. However, US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about the rate cut, saying it would not be enough.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Monday as the prospect of an expected interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve overshadowed pessimism over US-China trade talks and worries about slower global economic growth.

site_title: China-US trade talks to restart after G-20 tariff truce
summary: US and Chinese negotiators meet in Shanghai to restart trade talks, with both sides downplaying expectations of an imminent deal. The negotiations come after a G-20 tariff truce and amid ongoing civil unrest in Hong Kong and lingering tensions between the two nations. US trade representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin lead the US side, while Chinese Vice Premier Liu He and Commerce Minister Zhong Shan will represent China. Expectations are low, with both sides hinting at "modest concessions" and a focus on rebuilding trust.

site_title: Regulator raps Delong chairman, advisers over buyout debacle
summary: A Singapore regulator has censured Delong Holdings chairman Ding Liguo and his advisers over a failed buyout bid. The Securities Industry Council (SIC) found Delong breached the Takeover Code due to a six-month price reference period, but ruled no compensation was necessary due to limited impact. Law firm Shook Lin & Bok and financial adviser PrimePartners Corporate Finance were also censured for their roles in the debacle. Delong has relaunched its offer at the original price of S$7 a share, with Stirling Coleman Capital replacing PrimePartners Corporate Finance.

site_title: Americans' views on tech firms turn sharply negative: poll
summary: Americans' views on major technology firms have taken a sharp turn negative over the past four years, with 50% of people seeing them as having a positive impact, down from 71% in 2015. The percentage of those who feel tech firms have a negative effect nearly doubled to 33%. Both Democrats and Republicans have a less favorable view, but Republicans are more negative. The shift comes amid growing criticism of Big Tech firms and calls for a breakup of dominant firms, with the US Justice Department investigating potential anti-competitive actions.

site_title: Investment in Britain's residential property up 150% despite Brexit
summary: Investment in Britain's residential property rose 150% in 2018, reaching 6.8 billion euros, driven by London's 2 billion euros in investment volume. This surge made London the fourth-largest European city for multi-family investment. The market's popularity stems from stable cash flow and a shortage of supply in top-tier cities. However, uncertainty around Brexit may impact the UK's residential sector in the long term, with some foreign investors becoming more cautious due to the lack of progress with Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, CDLHT, Ascendas Reit, Mapletree NAC Trust, Far East H-Trust, SembMarine
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on July 30, 2019, include Singapore Airlines (SIA) with a 0.62% gain after announcing a deal to swap Airbus A320neos orders for newer A321neos. CDL Hospitality Trusts fell 3.3% after posting a lower distribution per stapled security. Ascendas Reit rose 0.7% despite an enlarged unit base. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust increased its first-quarter distribution per unit 3.7%. Far East Hospitality Trust dropped 9.9% after posting a lower distribution per stapled security. Sembcorp Marine narrowed its second-quarter net loss to S$8.5 million. Sheng Siong increased its net profit 7.4% after opening 13 new stores. ASL Marine rose 6.52% after disposing of an inactive subsidiary in China.

site_title: Ex-teacher who created app is India's newest billionaire
summary: Byju Raveendran, a 37-year-old former classroom teacher, has become India's newest billionaire after his education app Think & Learn Pvt. secured a $150 million funding deal, valuing the company at $5.7 billion. The app, Byju's, will team up with Walt Disney Co to offer Disney characters to teach mathematics and English to students in the US by early 2020. This deal solidifies India's growing wealth creation, with online learning expected to more than double to $5.7 billion by 2020, according to the government-backed India Brand Equity Foundation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Clearbridge Health plans to raise S$11.29 million through subscription agreements for placement shares at S$0.141 apiece. Two mainboard-listed companies, Boardroom and Memtech Intl, have asked for trading suspensions after privatisation offers closed past the 90% delisting threshold. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust will pay out a 3.7% increase in first-quarter distribution, with net property income up 10.7% to S$85 million. Yorkshine Holdings lost an appeal against forced delisting, and Scoot will lease 10 Airbus A321neo planes and buy six more.

site_title: A platform for youths to inspire and be inspired
summary: Singapore's "imagin.Asia 2019 - Game On!" event showcased the country's rising music and dance talents, alongside counterparts from Asia, at Far East Square. The event featured 20-plus performers, including Sugar Rush Crew and Stylo Mylo dance groups, and aspiring musicians from Singapore and the region. The theme, inspired by popular arcade games, aimed to inspire and foster friendships among young artists across borders. The event was organized by The RICE Company Limited and conceptualized by Global Cultural Alliance and local electronic music artist Evan Low, promoting creative exchange and understanding.

images.alt_text: Performers at the imagin.Asia concert held at The Pavilion @ Far East Square last Saturday. Among them were Singapore dance groups Sugar Rush Crew and Stylo Mylo, whose members are from The Little Arts Academy and 10 Square Youth, which are beneficiaries of The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Ryanair clings to profit goal amid Max grounding, price war
summary: Ryanair maintained its full-year profit goal despite a European fare war and Boeing's 737 Max grounding, which hurt first-quarter profits. The airline's net income fell 21% to €243 million in the first quarter, but revenue rose 11% due to passenger numbers. Ryanair's costs excluding fuel rose 4% due to pilot pay increases and staff hiring. The airline expects to meet fiscal 2019 targets, with a focus on ancillary sales, but faces challenges from Brexit uncertainty and a 6% forecast drop in first-half fares.

images.alt_text: Ryanair says it has been forced to drop prices in the UK to stimulate demand amid uncertainty over how the split from the European Union will play out.

site_title: Raffles Medical's Q2 profit falls 15.6% on startup costs for Chongqing hospital
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 15.6% drop in Q2 net profit to S$14.3 million due to startup costs at its Chongqing hospital. Revenue grew 5.6% to S$127 million, driven by increased contributions from healthcare services and hospital services divisions. Gestation losses at the Chongqing hospital contributed to the net profit drop, but the group expects to remain profitable for the year.

site_title: DBS confident in fending off digital challengers
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, is "relatively confident" in its ability to fend off digital bank challengers due to its advanced digital capabilities and headstart. CEO Piyush Gupta warned that new players must compete on a profitable basis, avoiding distorted pricing and monopolistic behavior. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has announced plans to issue up to five digital bank licenses, with DBS expected to hold its ground against competitors, who will likely target underserved segments in markets where incumbent banks have not digitalized.

site_title: Trump deepens war of words with leftist black leaders
summary: US President Donald Trump escalated his war of words with prominent black and minority left-leaning leaders, branding African-American civil rights activist Al Sharpton a "con man" and criticizing Baltimore, a majority black city, as "rat and rodent infested." Trump rejected accusations of racism, claiming he has a "particular venom for blacks and people of color," while Sharpton called Trump's comments "venomous" and said he "makes trouble for bigots." The feud comes ahead of the 2020 presidential election, where Trump aims to frame Democratic opponents as the real extremists.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump brushed off accusations of racism Monday to step up his war of words with prominent black and minority left-leaning leaders, branding his latest target a "con man."

site_title: Singapore is ready with 'package' to help businesses, workers in sudden downturn: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced Singapore has prepared a package to support businesses and workers in case of a global economic downturn, citing the recent slowdown and trade tensions between China and the US. He emphasized the need for preparedness while hoping for the best, and stated that Singapore is not expecting a full-year recession. Heng also discussed regional cooperation, including the importance of maintaining peace and stability in the South China Sea and working together with ASEAN nations to achieve win-win outcomes.

site_title: Is this the house that Jack Ma is building in Singapore?
summary: A two-storey bungalow with a basement and swimming pool in Singapore's Victoria Park Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area is reportedly being developed by an entity linked to Alibaba Group Holding chairman and co-founder Jack Ma. The project is one of several high-end residential developments in Singapore by Alibaba-affiliated entities, expanding the group's presence in the country's luxury real estate market.

site_title: Convincing the older generation that the startup model works
summary: A Singaporean startup, Glife, is working to revolutionize the agricultural supply chain by overlaying technology, aiming to make fresh produce more accessible to consumers. The company, founded by CEO Justin Chou, initially faced resistance from his supportive parents, but they eventually came around to the idea of turning Glife into the "Grab of food."

site_title: Why firms should embrace the cloud now
summary: The Asia-Pacific region has become a global leader in next-generation technologies, with digital transformation initiatives driving business growth. Companies are embracing cloud computing for its agility, cost savings, and flexibility, but face challenges such as regulatory hurdles, data sovereignty, and cybersecurity threats. To overcome these challenges, organizations must develop a clear cloud strategy, invest in technology and skills, and select vendors with robust security measures. Despite growing cyber risks, the benefits of cloud computing are undeniable, and vigilance in defending data assets is essential for long-term success.

site_title: ONE Championship makes entry into Esports arena
summary: ONE Championship, a mixed martial arts organization, has entered the Esports space with its first planned events for the 2019-2020 season. The company will host a hybrid MMA-martial arts Esports event in Tokyo and Southeast Asian Dota 2 competitions. ONE Esports aims to leverage its experience in highlighting martial artists' hard work to promote Esports athletes. The organization plans to host its own Dota 2 Invitationals with a prize pool of US$500,000 and a commemoration for ONE Championship's 100th event.

site_title: EC drops equivalence status; Singapore credit agencies can still access EU, says MAS
summary: The European Commission (EC) has dropped equivalence status for Singapore credit agencies, but they can still access the EU market through the endorsement regime, which requires EU-based credit agencies to approve their ratings. Singapore remains among markets assessed by the ESMA to meet endorsement status rules. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) confirmed that Singapore credit agencies' ratings can be recognized in Europe if endorsed by European counterparts.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Putting action behind dreams
summary: The Money FM podcast "Putting action behind dreams" discussed the importance of turning aspirations into tangible actions. Key takeaways include the need to set realistic goals, prioritize tasks, and create a schedule to achieve them. The podcast also highlighted the significance of taking action, rather than just having dreams. By putting action behind their dreams, individuals can increase their chances of success and make progress towards their objectives. The episode aimed to inspire listeners to take concrete steps towards turning their aspirations into reality.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro, MONEY FM 89.3 presenter; Trevor Xie, founder & director of Children's Wishing Well; Ho Lee Yen, chief customer & marketing officer, AIA Singapore

site_title: Maybe banks really aren't worried about Brexit
summary: Bankers appear to be preparing for a potential Brexit, with Bank of America setting up a new Paris office and Deutsche Bank executive receiving a multimillion-euro bonus. However, surprisingly, the volume of business conducted by banks in the UK has not decreased significantly, indicating that the UK's financial preeminence remains intact. This suggests that banks may not be as concerned about the Brexit's impact on their operations as initially thought.

site_title: Singapore must 'step up' to global rivalry for talent: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore needs to step up its efforts to attract global talent in the face of rival markets offering fast-track visa schemes. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of securing access to highly skilled talent, both local and non-local, to support strong and dynamic companies. A fast-track visa scheme, particularly for the tech sector, could help Singapore react to emerging tech trends more quickly, but all sectors lacking relevant skills should also be supported.

site_title: JPTT secures PetroChina as anchor customer
summary: JURONG Port Tank Terminals (JPTT) has secured a major anchor customer, PetroChina, taking up 100% of its Phase 1 tank capacity. The terminal, a joint venture with Oiltanking, offers 252,000 cubic metres of clean petroleum storage capacity and will strengthen Jurong Island's storage infrastructure, enabling customers to benefit from cost savings and faster product transfers. JPTT is expected to handle about 7 million tonnes of clean petroleum products annually and solidifies Singapore's position as Asia's regional petrochemical hub.

images.alt_text: (From left) GM of JPTT Loh Wei; CEO of JP Ooi Boon Hoe; chairman of JP Ng Chee Keong; Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat; chairman of JTC Tan Chong Meng; CEO of JTC Ng Lang; CEO of Oiltanking Coenraad Huebner; and GM of Oiltanking Stanley Teo.

site_title: Offerors cannot rely on loss of public float alone to delist a stock: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified that exit offers for general offers must be both fair and reasonable, not just when a company's public float falls below 10%. This applies to both voluntary and compulsory delistings. If an issuer's free float falls below 10%, it must receive acceptances from at least 75% of independent shareholders to delist. However, delistings following a compulsory acquisition are not required to be fair and reasonable.

site_title: Watten Estate Condominium up for sale with S$536m reserve price
summary: The Watten Estate Condominium in Singapore is up for collective sale on July 30 with a reserve price of S$536 million. The site can be redeveloped into 242 modern resort homes with an average size of 1,270 sq ft, and is located within one kilometre of several schools and a MRT station. The land rate translates to S$1,738 psf ppr, making it "attractively priced" according to the marketing agent, Huttons. The public tender closes on October 18.

site_title: Grab to invest US$2b in Indonesia over a period of 5 years
summary: Grab commits to investing US$2 billion in Indonesia over 5 years through its partnership with SoftBank, aiming to develop a next-generation transportation network and fund the transformation of critical services such as healthcare. The investment will also support the digitization of services and infrastructure in Indonesia, with plans to release affordable e-healthcare services within 3 months. Grab will also establish a second headquarters in Jakarta, providing employment opportunities and upskilling tech talent in Indonesia.

site_title: Tarantino's new movie opens with US$40m, Lion King still tops
summary: Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood opened with a career-best $40 million at the North American box office, including a record-breaking $16.8 million on its opening day. Despite this, Disney's The Lion King still holds the top spot. The film marks a win for original content and showcases Tarantino's success in the industry, solidifying his position as a prominent filmmaker.

images.alt_text: Brad Pitt (left) and Leonardo DiCaprio in Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.

site_title: Japan says GDP growth could slow to 0.9% on weakening global demand
summary: Japan's government reduced its economic growth forecast for the fiscal year ending in March 2020 to 0.9% due to weaker exports, primarily caused by the US-China trade war. This downgrade is nearly twice as low as private-sector projections, which expect 0.5% growth. The government attributed the slowdown to declining exports, but also noted robust corporate investment and private spending would offset this decline. The forecast is lower than the government's previous estimate of 1.3% growth for the same period.

site_title: Polish artist's labour of devotion in Cairo church
summary: Polish artist Mario Dybich, 51, has spent over 23 years carving about 70 sculptures in the rock-hewn St Simon Monastery in Cairo, Egypt, inspired by biblical stories. The project began in the 1990s after he met the monastery's priest, who asked him to "turn the mountain into an open Bible." Mario, who has no prior sculpting experience, has become a fixture at the monastery, creating works that tell spiritual stories and giving the complex an ancient look. His labor of devotion has made the monastery a masterpiece, attracting thousands of visitors each week.

site_title: Violent unrest in Hong Kong won't be tolerated: China
summary: China has reaffirmed its support for Hong Kong's government and police, warning that violent protests won't be tolerated. The comments came after a chaotic weekend of unrest, with China's top diplomat saying the movement's actions have undermined Hong Kong's prosperity and stability. China's President Xi Jinping has maintained backing for Carrie Lam, and officials doubled down on their support, despite opposition lawmakers accusing the government of shifting blame.

site_title: Will US-UK ties now bloom or wither?
summary: US-UK ties may experience a shift following the election of Boris Johnson as British Prime Minister, who has been a proponent of Brexit. Johnson's pragmatic approach to politics and his desire to form a free-trade area agreement with the US aligns with President Trump's views. However, the two governments disagree on major geo-strategic issues, such as the nuclear deal with Iran. The outcome of Brexit and the US-UK relationship's future remains uncertain, with some speculating that the Special Relationship may be rekindled, while others see it as a nationalist backlash against the neo-liberal agenda.

images.alt_text: Someone did a mashup using images of UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and US President Donald Trump to produce a poster of 'Boris Borump'. These have gone up around east London.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q1 DPU edges up to 4.005 cents
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 6.3% year-over-year increase in Q1 total amount available for distribution to S$124.7 million. Gross revenue rose 6.1% to S$229.7 million, driven by new acquisitions in the UK and Australia. Net property income grew 11.5% to S$177.5 million, excluding land rent excluded from property operating expenses. The Reit's portfolio weighted average lease to expiry is 4.1 years, with 91.1% occupancy and average positive rental reversion of 2.7%.

site_title: Which way now for the EU?
summary: The European Union is poised for a leadership change this autumn, with Ursula von der Leyen as the new European Commission president, Christine Lagarde at the European Central Bank, and Charles Michel as European Council president. The EU's new leaders are urged to strengthen Europe's strategic sovereignty by pooling resources and policy coordination, but this would be insufficient in a G-2 world dominated by the US and China. Instead, the EU should aim for a rules-based global order, uphold human rights, and promote cooperation with all actors. A stronger, more integrated Europe could compete with the US and China, but this requires overcoming challenges such as unanimity among member states and avoiding a transactional approach to global politics.

site_title: Singapore to host over 50 countries at signing of namesake treaty
summary: Representatives from over 50 countries, including the US and China, will gather in Singapore on August 7 to sign the Singapore Convention on Mediation, a UN treaty on mediation. The convention aims to establish a framework for countries to recognize and enforce mediation agreements. About 25 countries have confirmed their participation, with the US and China among the signatories. The signing is seen as a significant milestone for international cooperation on mediation. The treaty was adopted by the UN General Assembly in December 2018.

site_title: Singapore well-positioned to build a sustainable, smart-energy future
summary: Singapore is poised to build a sustainable, smart-energy future due to a combination of demand and supply factors. The country's energy system is well-orchestrated, with a government that has a clear understanding of top-level architecture and design. Digital technologies, such as AI and IoT, can make energy systems more intelligent, efficient, and sustainable. Singapore's reliance on imported fuels and small, compact energy system heighten the need for optimization and efficiency. The country is well-positioned to exploit its solar potential, and its government has committed to a 100% cleaner energy public bus fleet by 2040.

site_title: Waterloo Street apartment site up for sale with S$145m asking price
summary: A 27-unit apartment development, Min Yuan, in Singapore's Waterloo Street area is up for sale with an asking price of S$145 million. The site, which spans 14,629 sq ft, is zoned for "residential with commercial at first storey" use and can be redeveloped into a hotel building. Comparable land prices in the area range from S$2,550 to S$2,720 psf ppr. The sale presents a "timely opportunity" for buyers to capitalize on the government's Draft Master Plan 2019, with the redeveloped hotel enjoying a panoramic view of the CBD skyline.

images.alt_text: Min Yuan is a 27-unit residential development with commercial on its first storey.

site_title: Smoky tea baked in clay: tandoori chai heats up Pakistan
summary: In Islamabad, a street vendor, Sanaullah, serves "tandoori chai" - a unique milk tea experience where tea is baked in clay pots at high temperatures, creating a smoky flavor. The drink has gained popularity, with the Tandoori Chai Company expanding to a second branch in Lahore. Pakistan is one of the top tea-consuming countries globally, with 73% of tea drinkers consuming at least two cups a day. The traditional method has become a niche product, but its unique taste and atmosphere have attracted customers.

site_title: Evergrande plans to bring EV charging technology closer to home
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese property developer, has established a joint venture with State Grid Corp of China to develop smart car charging technology. The goal is to make electric vehicle charging more affordable and convenient for customers, addressing the issue that public charging stations in China are scarce and expensive. The venture aims to enable users to charge their cars at home overnight and sell excess energy back to the grid, reducing costs. Similar partnerships have been signed with other major real-estate firms, and the technology is expected to start being produced in June.

site_title: DBS sees slower growth in H2 amid low rates
summary: DBS Group expects slower growth in the second half of the year due to a "global synchronised slowdown." Despite this, the bank reported a 20% year-on-year increase in net profit of S$1.6 billion in the second quarter, beating analyst estimates. Chief executive Piyush Gupta attributed the growth to one-time items. The bank's growth shift is attributed to a global economic slowdown, which may impact its H2 performance.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff salvoes from the Trump administration. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. In other news, an Indonesian employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and Singapore's GDP data is set to be released, leading to a 5-day rally in local stocks. Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: Air France to place big order for A220 jets: French weekly
summary: Air France plans to order 50-70 Canadian-made Airbus A220 medium-haul jetliners as part of a fleet revamp, according to France's Journal du Dimanche. The order, expected to be announced Tuesday, will not include A320neo jets and is aimed at reducing costs and competing with low-cost rivals. The A220, assembled in Quebec, can carry 100-150 passengers and has a range of over 6,000 kilometers. The value of the deal has not been disclosed, and Air France has declined to comment.

site_title: BM Mobility suspends trading after auditors flag going concern issues
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-listed electric transport group, has suspended trading after its independent auditors flagged "going concern" issues, citing a net loss of 13.4 million yuan and 13.1 million yuan in net cash used in operating activities. The auditor expressed material uncertainties that may cast significant doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. Management has prepared a cash flow projection showing sufficient working capital for the next 12 months, but the company's financial performance is uncertain.

site_title: Paring down debt pile top of mind for honestbee's new CEO
summary: honestbee's new CEO, Ong Lay Ann, aims to restructure the struggling grocery delivery startup's debt and attract strategic partners to turn the business around. Paring down debt is his immediate priority, with a focus on resolving the capital structure issues that led to a large number of creditors. Ong is open to working with a consortium of white knights and partners to rebuild the company, and has not ruled out investing in the business himself. He plans to refocus the company on its brick-and-mortar store, Habitat, and potentially revive halted markets, including Indonesia, where he has family connections.

site_title: Japan's Abe unlikely to meet South Korea's Moon at UN in Sept
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is unlikely to meet South Korean President Moon Jae-in at the UN General Assembly in September due to strained ties over World War-II era forced labor and other issues. Abe will also skip meetings with Moon at upcoming Association of Southeast Asian Nations and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation gatherings unless Seoul takes constructive steps. Relations between the two Asian neighbors are at their lowest ebb since they normalized ties in 1965, amid boycotts of Japanese goods and services.

site_title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell likes the economy hot
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed his intention to sustain the economic expansion, aiming to benefit underserved communities, including African-American families and rural white people. He noted that job improvements have reached "communities at the edge of the workforce," emphasizing the need to continue this process for a couple of years. This approach is a departure from his predecessors' focus on inflation control.

site_title: Verstappen writes off his own chance of title success
summary: Max Verstappen has ruled out his chances of winning the driver's championship despite his second consecutive victory for Red Bull in the German Grand Prix. Verstappen, 21, acknowledged Mercedes and Lewis Hamilton, who lead the standings by 63 points, as favorites to secure both titles. Verstappen stated that closing the gap is unlikely, showing he has conceded the championship battle.

site_title: Stamford Land and chairman buy London office-and-retail building
summary: Stamford Land Corporation, a luxury-hotel operator, has acquired a 60% stake in a London office-and-retail property for £156m. Ow Global, owned by Stamford Land's executive chairman C K Ow, bought the remaining 40% for £104m, totaling £260m. The deal marks Stamford Land's entry into the UK market.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's self-driving shuttle at NUS to start taking passengers
summary: ComfortDelGro's self-driving shuttle service, NUSmart, will start taking passengers at the National University of Singapore campus on Tuesday. The shuttle, supplied by France's EasyMile, is similar to those operating in Gardens by the Bay since 2015. The service has been testing since May.

site_title: Asian markets start the week lower
summary: Asian markets started the week lower due to weak sentiment from escalating protests in Hong Kong and low expectations from upcoming US-China trade talks. Stocks fell in Singapore, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea, but Australia bucked the trend with a 0.5% gain. Investors are awaiting the US Federal Reserve's rate cut decision, but rate cut hopes had little impact on market sentiment. Despite this, Singapore's Straits Times Index ended the day down 0.5% at 3,346.39.

site_title: CapitaLand secures 95% retail take-up for Chongqing mega-mall project
summary: CapitaLand has secured a 95% retail leasing rate for its mega-mall project, Raffles City Chongqing, ahead of its September opening. The 235,000 sq m five-storey mall will feature over 400 brands, including Adidas, GAP, and Old Navy, and offer personalized customer experiences with augmented reality interaction and navigation. The project, spanning 1.12 million sq m, is part of a larger mega-structure in Chongqing, China, and is expected to boost domestic consumption with rising disposable incomes.

site_title: US: Wall St eases from record highs as Fed meeting looms
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, easing from record highs ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened 0.21 points lower at 27,192.24, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline comes as investors await the Fed's stance on interest rates and trade concerns.

site_title: SGX is prescient in seeing its future in futures
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has restructured its organization, its second under CEO Loh Boon Chye, to adapt to changing market realities. The stock exchange is shifting its focus from traditional share trading to futures trading, which it believes will be more sustainable and profitable. This move comes amid a decline in IPO activity worldwide, driven by geopolitical tensions, trade issues, and Brexit. Other exchanges, such as the London Stock Exchange, are also transitioning to data products to increase revenue. SGX's new strategy aims to capitalize on the growing demand for futures trading and derivatives clearing.

site_title: British PM Johnson: We need a new trade deal with EU
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that a new trade deal with the European Union is possible and expressed desire for a grand new partnership, including cooperation on defense, security, and culture. He ruled out another referendum on Scottish independence, citing a previous promise to the people. Johnson emphasized the need for a new free trade deal to take back control of tariffs and regulations.

site_title: Why Mike Pence's star is on the rise
summary: Mike Pence's influence is growing within the Trump administration as he assumes key roles in promoting the US-Mexico-Canada trade treaty and international economic policy. Pence has helped calm tensions and foster cooperation with foreign leaders, showcasing his ability to diffuse the president's polarizing rhetoric. With Trump's age and potential health concerns, Pence's influence may expand, and he may even be considered a potential successor. Historically, sitting vice-presidents have had success in running for the presidency, with two having been elected, and Pence's domestic and international reputation could propel him to the top job in the future.

site_title: Sheng Siong raises interim dividend on higher Q2 profit
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singapore supermarket group, reported a 7.4% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$18.4 million for the second quarter, driven by higher revenue and improved gross margin. Revenue rose 11.8% to S$238.2 million, and an interim dividend of 1.75 cents per share was declared. The company attributed the growth to new store openings and a sales mix shift towards fresh produce. However, it warned of stiff competition in the industry and potential dampened local consumer demand due to the economic outlook.

site_title: How the might of monetary policy doves can prevail in Turkey's markets
summary: Turkey's central bank governor cut interest rates by a record 425 basis points, defying expectations of a sell-off in the markets. The lira rallied, bucking emerging markets' rout, and Turkish bonds saw a surge in yields. Investors piled on bets for further rate cuts, with yields on two-year notes breaking below 17% for the first time since May 2018. The central bank's move is seen as a positive for short-dated Turkish bonds, but the market remains sensitive to inflation data and future monetary policy.

site_title: US Democratic presidential candidates should state foreign policy stance
summary: US Democratic presidential candidates have yet to present a coherent foreign policy stance, despite a growing economy favoring incumbent President Trump. Despite criticizing Trump's policies, many candidates have failed to explain how their diplomatic and national security policies would differ. Notable exceptions include Senator Bernie Sanders, who opposes US military intervention, and Senator Elizabeth Warren, who echoes his positions. Key questions remain unanswered, including how Democratic candidates plan to exit Afghanistan, address Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela, and deal with China in trade and tech supremacy.

site_title: JPMorgan hiring in Germany amid private banking push
summary: JPMorgan Chase is expanding its private banking operations in Germany, aiming to capture a larger share of the country's private-banking market. The company is hiring more staff, with a focus on women, to cater to wealthy clients with liquid assets of at least €100 million. This move comes as German clients increasingly invest internationally, and JPMorgan seeks to provide a third pillar of advice to complement their existing relationships with local and Swiss lenders. The company views private banking as a competitive market, with other foreign banks, such as BNP Paribas and Rothschild & Co, also pushing into Germany.

site_title: EU signals tighter financial market access after Brexit
summary: The European Union has signaled tighter financial market access for the UK after Brexit, stating that equivalence does not automatically grant access even if a country's rules are equivalent to the EU's. The EU's executive European Commission will require more detailed assessments for "high-impact" third countries, including the UK, and may withdraw equivalence status with 30 days' notice. This move is seen as a step back from previous agreements and could make it less attractive for the UK to seek equivalence for its financial markets.

site_title: ASL Marine to sell loss-making Chinese shipyard unit for 35 million yuan
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED ASL Marine has agreed to sell its loss-making Chinese shipyard unit, Jiangmen Hongda Shipyard, to Guangdong Sanhe Pile for 35 million yuan (S$6.96 million) in cash. The sale, part of an asset rationalisation plan, aims to raise working capital and streamline the company's structure. The subsidiary, which has not done business since 2017, retains only land and buildings as assets, contributing 7.8% to ASL's net loss in the nine months to March 31. The sale is expected to yield a gain of about S$8.9 million.

site_title: JPMorgan, UBS among five banks facing US$1 billion forex-rigging suit
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co and UBS Group AG are among five banks being sued over allegations of foreign-exchange rigging in a class-action lawsuit seeking over £1 billion (S$1.68 billion). The lawsuit centres on market manipulation between 2007 and 2013, with traders allegedly colluding on foreign-exchange trading strategies. The European Commission previously fined the banks a total of 1.07 billion euros, with UBS escaping a fine for being the first to report the collusion. The lawsuit could take three to five years and may result in payouts for thousands of institutional investors.

site_title: EU court rules sites must warn about Facebook 'like' button
summary: The European Court of Justice ruled that online retailers must warn web users that they send personal data to Facebook through the "like" button. The court found that the transmission occurs without user awareness, regardless of membership in the social network or clicking on the "Like" button. Users should be warned and asked to consent to data collection, although retailers are not responsible for what Facebook does with the data. The decision aims to enhance consumer protection and provide transparency on data collection.

images.alt_text: According to a European Court of Justice ruling, a site that embeds the Facebook "like" icon and link on its pages also sends user data to the US web giant.

site_title: A boost to mediation, and Singapore as a premier dispute resolution destination
summary: The UN Convention on International Settlement Agreements Resulting from Mediation, known as the Singapore Convention, will be open for signatures on August 7, 2019, in Singapore, marking the city-state's commitment to cross-border investments and dispute resolution. The Convention aims to provide an internationally uniform framework for recognizing and enforcing mediated settlement agreements, elevating mediation's importance globally and offering an attractive option for businesses in resolving international commercial disputes. Singapore is expected to be one of the first signatories, cementing its position as a premier dispute resolution destination in Asia.

images.alt_text: If the dispute resolution process can be simplified, streamlined and made uniform across borders, the reduced costs required to resolve disputes would create a robust and more attractive business climate.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Suntec Reit's Q2 FY2019 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 4.6% year-on-year to 2.361 cents, but DPU from operations rose 1.4% yoy to 2.129 cents. The company proposed acquisitions of two high-quality assets in Sydney and Adelaide with initial net property income (NPI) yields of 5.5% and 8%, respectively. AEM Holdings raised its revenue guidance for FY2019 to S$265-280 million, driven by increased orders for HDMT test handlers. The analyst firm maintains a buy rating for AEM Holdings, with a target price of S$1.40.

site_title: Porsche's battery-powered Taycan on track to zoom past 911
summary: Porsche's battery-powered Taycan is on track to surpass the iconic 911 sports car in sales, with nearly 30,000 deposits already received.
