The company aims to produce 40,000 Taycans annually, driven by strong demand and plans to expand production capacity. The Taycan, priced at around $90,000, could redefine Porsche's brand image for the next generation and pose a challenge to Tesla's Model S. With a range of 500 kilometers on a single charge, Porsche is also investing in fast charging infrastructure to support the car's adoption.

site_title: Britain hosts 'Five Eyes' security alliance ministers for cyber talks
summary: Britain hosted a meeting of senior security ministers from the US-led 'Five Eyes' alliance to discuss tackling cyber threats, including political hacking and child pornography. British interior minister Priti Patel led the talks, focusing on emerging threats and new technologies. Industry roundtable discussions with Facebook, Google, and Microsoft were planned to address online child sexual exploitation and abuse. The meeting marked a shift in cooperation, with Facebook attending and Google and Microsoft participating after declining invitations last year. The Five Eyes alliance aims to enhance national security and child protection efforts.

site_title: Pfizer is to merge off-patent drug unit with Mylan
summary: Pfizer has agreed to merge its off-patent drug unit, Upjohn, with Mylan in an all-stock deal, creating a potential powerhouse in the market for medicines without patent protections. The combined business is expected to have $19-20 billion in annual sales and $1 billion in annual cost savings by 2023. The deal aims to regain leverage for generic drugmakers amid increasing pressure from pharmacies and wholesalers. Pfizer will spin off Upjohn and combine it with Mylan, with Michael Goettler taking over as CEO and Robert Coury becoming executive chairman.

site_title: More meat-loving indians mean chicken-feed imports are surging
summary: India's growing population and rising disposable incomes are driving the country's increasing demand for non-vegetarian food, leading to a surge in chicken-feed imports. The country is set to import a record 1 million tons of corn for chicken feed, mainly from Myanmar and Ukraine, in the upcoming year. This is due to India's own corn production being below demand, with the country expected to export just 500,000 tons this season, marking a significant shift from being a net exporter.

site_title: Temasek-Khazanah JV confirms S$1.58 billion Duo sale
summary: M+S Pte Ltd, a joint venture between Malaysia and Singapore, has sold the office and retail areas of the Duo complex in Singapore's Ophir-Rochor precinct for S$1.575 billion. The sale includes Duo Tower, with 570,000 sq ft of office space, and Duo Galleria, with 56,000 sq ft of retail space. The sale price is S$2,570 per square foot of net lettable area. The deal marks a significant divestment by Khazanah Nasional, the national joint venture, and is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Epicentre gets hearing date for creditor's judicial management application
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a Catalist-listed Apple reseller, has a hearing date set for August 2 for a creditor's judicial management application. The application, filed by Goh Chee Hong, claims a loan-related sum of S$3 million. The company faces a slew of other creditors, including former directors, and has previously reported discrepancies in loan agreements. Trading in Epicentre's shares has been suspended since May 30, and the company plans to have auditors probe past transactions involving its chairman and acting CEO, Kenneth Lim.

site_title: Grab to invest US$2 billion in Indonesia through SoftBank capital over next five years
summary: Grab has committed to investing US$2 billion in Indonesia over five years through a partnership with SoftBank, aiming to develop digital infrastructure and create a next-generation transportation network for cities. The investment will also transform how critical services, such as healthcare, are delivered in the country. The partnership was announced after a meeting between Indonesian President Joko Widodo and SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son.

site_title: Malaysian police chief says tough to combat drugs with addicts on force
summary: Malaysia's police chief, Abdul Hamid Bador, stated that combating drug abuse is challenging due to the presence of addicts within the force. The country has seen a record amount of crystal meth seizures, with many coming from neighboring Myanmar. The number of addicts is doubling, including police officers, who are being taken off duty after being arrested for possession. Malaysia is considering dropping penalties for small quantities of drugs intended for personal use, with the current fines and jail time in place. The issue remains a significant problem for the country's anti-drug efforts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 5.27 points to 1,642.69. The index saw a significant decline in volume, with 2.6 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 581 to 303.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% on Monday on weak regional sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% on Monday, down 17.4 points, due to weak regional sentiment caused by escalating protests in Hong Kong, low expectations for US-China trade talks, and growth prospects. The US Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting had little effect on markets. Trading volume was 1.3 billion securities, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank reporting lower shares, while City Developments Limited rose 1.3%.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust Q1 DPU up by 3.7% to 1.95 S cents
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's first-quarter distribution per unit increased by 3.7% to 1.95 Singapore cents, driven by a 10.7% rise in net property income to S$85 million. Gross revenue rose 11.1% to S$104.9 million, primarily due to higher rental income from its Chinese assets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down after more protests
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 1.03% on Monday amid investor caution ahead of US-China trade talks and civil unrest in the financial hub. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,106.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.12% to 2,941.01. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.10% to 1,574.95. The decline follows recent protests and heightened uncertainty in the region.

site_title: Singapore must step up to global competition for talent: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore must step up its efforts to attract global talent, particularly in STEM fields, to remain competitive with other markets offering fast-track visa schemes. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of having access to highly skilled talent to drive strong and dynamic companies. The government's talent strategy includes cultivating and growing the local talent pool through training and upskilling, as well as strengthening its fundamentals and connections with the world.

site_title: New British PM waits for EU to move on Brexit
summary: New British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is waiting for EU leaders to agree to renegotiate the Brexit deal before meeting them, as the government prepares for a "no deal" Brexit on October 31. Johnson wants to change the exit terms struck by his predecessor Theresa May but insists on leaving the EU without an agreement if necessary. The EU has refused to reopen the withdrawal agreement, and opposition among MPs is focused on the "backstop" arrangement intended to keep the border open between Northern Ireland and the EU.

images.alt_text: New British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is waiting for EU leaders to agree to renegotiate their Brexit deal before he meets them, his spokeswoman said Monday, as the government stepped up "no deal" planning.

site_title: A Fed interest rate cut is in the bag. What then?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to lower borrowing costs for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis, with a quarter-percentage-point interest rate cut. However, the decision's implications and potential future rate cuts remain uncertain due to differing opinions among Fed officials on the reasons for the cut and the state of the economy. The Fed's policy statement and press conference will provide clarity on the decision, but economists and traders expect a more limited series of rate cuts. The decision may also be influenced by global economic trends and the European Central Bank's expected rate cut in September.

site_title: Singapore credit ratings can still be used in the EU, says MAS
summary: Singapore's credit ratings can still be used in the EU, despite the European Commission (EC) no longer considering them equivalent. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that Singapore-based credit agencies' ratings can be endorsed by their counterparts in the EU, allowing them to be used within the EU. This is due to the endorsement regime, which was confirmed by the EC, and the MAS has noted that Singapore credit agencies meet the relevant endorsement provisions or have equally stringent internal requirements.

site_title: Europe's Search for next IMF chief narrowed to three hopefuls
summary: The search for the next International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief has narrowed to three European candidates ahead of a Sept 6 deadline. The candidates are former Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem, World Bank Chief Executive Kristalina Georgieva, and Bank of Finland Governor Olli Rehn. The IMF's application process opens July 29 and closes on the deadline, with the board aiming to complete the process by Oct 4. This comes after Christine Lagarde's resignation to lead the European Central Bank, a position traditionally held by a European, amid a world economy at its weakest since the financial crisis.

site_title: Boardroom, Memtech suspend trading after close of privatisation offers
summary: Two Singapore-listed companies, Boardroom Limited and Memtech, suspended trading of their shares after closing voluntary conditional cash offers for privatization. Boardroom's offeror, Salacca, failed to acquire enough shares to force a compulsory buyout, while Memtech's controlling shareholders closed their offer. Both companies will remain listed on the Singapore Exchange as they have at least 10% public shares. The delisting plans will provide the offerors with greater control and management flexibility.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts higher Q2 profit
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket group, reported a 7.4% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$18.42 million for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by 11.8% revenue growth to S$238.16 million. The group also declared an interim dividend of 1.75 cents per share. Despite a strong performance, Sheng Siong warned of stiff competition in the supermarket industry and potential dents in local consumer demand due to the economic outlook.

site_title: SIA's Scoot changes Airbus order, will add 16 A321neos to fleet
summary: Scoot, a budget airline owned by Singapore Airlines, is replacing part of its Airbus A320neo order with newer A321neos, adding 16 planes to its fleet starting from end-2020. The move aims to meet Scoot's double-digit growth plan and is expected to yield fuel cost savings of 12% compared to the A320neo. The changes come as Scoot faces operational disruptions and financial challenges, including a full-year operating loss of S$15 million in 2019.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as Heineken disappoints; Fed in focus
summary: European shares opened lower on Monday, weighed down by Heineken's 5.6% decline after missing earnings estimates. Ryanair also reported a slump in profit. In contrast, London Stock Exchange Group surged 11% after discussing a potential $27 billion deal to buy Refinitiv. Sanofi raised its 2019 outlook, and data showed slowing US economic growth solidifying expectations for a 25 basis point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. London's FTSE was the only major gainer, driven by deal talks and a weak British pound.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: honestbee has appointed Ong Lay Ann as its new CEO, replacing co-founder Jonathan Low, effective July 15. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by the US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Other news includes Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth, Citigroup's MSCI target, and the Thai court's decision on Thaksin's daughter's suspension as PM.

site_title: Watten Estate Condominium in Bukit Timah goes en bloc with S$536m reserve price
summary: The Watten Estate Condominium in Bukit Timah, a 104-unit freehold development, will go on collective sale on July 30 with a reserve price of S$536 million. The site can be redeveloped into 242 modern resort homes, averaging 1,270 sq ft, with a land rate of S$1,738 psf ppr. The sale is considered "attractively priced" after factoring in additional buyer's stamp duty. The public tender closes on Oct 18.

site_title: ONE Championship makes opening moves in e-sports arena
summary: ONE Championship, a mixed martial arts organization, is expanding into the e-sports space with its first planned events for the 2019-2020 season. The venture, led by Carlos Alimurung, will feature hybrid martial-arts and e-sports events, including Dota 2 competitions and a martial-arts fan fest. ONE aims to leverage its experience in highlighting martial artists' hard work and training to promote e-sports competitors, with a focus on celebrating inspirational stories and heroes. The organization plans to host events in Tokyo, Singapore, and Jakarta.

site_title: MUFG Bank appoints IT, banking veteran Goh Sok Kim to drive digital transformation
summary: MUFG Bank appointed Goh Sok Kim, a veteran IT and banking executive, as managing director and deputy head of its systems office for Asia (ASO) in Singapore. Kim brings 30 years of experience to the role, having previously led global and regional technology programs at Citibank. She will drive digital transformation and technological innovation in South-east Asia, South Asia, East Asia, and Oceania, aiming to leapfrog peers in terms of innovation and reinvent business practices.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slide to 2-month low on trade worries, weak earnings
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 1.78% to a 2-month low on Monday, amid growing concerns over a trade rift with Japan and weak global demand. The KOSPI index closed at 2,029.40 points, while the junior KOSDAQ index fell 4%. Analysts attributed the decline to Japanese export restrictions and weak corporate earnings, with chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix taking a hit. The US-China trade talks, set to take place in Shanghai, are expected to be uncertain, adding to the downward pressure on the market.

site_title: Securities watchdog censures advisers in failed 2018 Delong buy-out; CEO revives cash offer
summary: Delong Holdings' CEO Ding Liguo revived a privatization bid after the Securities Industry Council censured an aborted 2018 buy-out attempt for breaching Singapore's takeover code. Ding's new offer is a voluntary conditional cash offer of SGD 7 per share, valuing the steelmaker at SGD 771.3 million. The offeror and its concert parties hold an 81.48% interest in the company. The move comes after a failed attempt in 2018, when Ding's offer was rejected due to regulatory concerns.

site_title: Agri-food tech firm Nutrition Technologies raises US$8.5m in Series A round
summary: Nutrition Technologies, an agri-food tech firm, has secured US$8.5 million in Series A funding from a consortium of investors, including Openspace Ventures and Seeds Capital. The funds will be used to set up a commercial-scale insect protein facility in South-east Asia, capable of producing 18,000 tonnes of insect-based feed ingredients annually. The facility will manufacture the company's flagship Hi.Protein insectmeal product, with a focus on sustainable and affordable production. The investment aims to support the company's manufacturing expansion plans in the region.

site_title: Completed condo prices drop 0.7% in June after two months of gains: NUS Index
summary: Singapore's completed condo prices dropped 0.7% in June, after two months of gains, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI). This decline was observed in both central and non-central regions, with shoebox units experiencing the largest drop of 0.9%. Year-to-date, overall prices fell 0.7%, while prices of larger apartments dropped 0.5-0.7% and shoebox units fell 1.9-2.5%.

site_title: Australia: Shares end near record high on tech gains
summary: Australian shares closed near a record high on Monday, driven by tech stocks, which rose 0.5% to 6,825.80, 3 points shy of the benchmark's highest ever close. Tech stocks, including Afterpay and Nearmap, hit new highs following strong US results. The US Federal Reserve's potential policy easing cycle later this week also supported risk-sentiment. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand rose 0.4% to near an all-time high.

site_title: honestbee names Ong Lay Ann CEO; co-founder Jonathan Low quits
summary: honestbee appoints Ong Lay Ann as its new CEO, replacing LG scion Brian Koo, effective July 15. Ong, a non-executive director of ISDN Holdings, will receive a mix of cash and equity compensation. He aims to turn the company around and is open to working with investors to secure funding. Ong's appointment comes after the departure of co-founder Jonathan Low, who resigned on July 11. Honestbee has been facing financial difficulties, halting operations in several markets and suspending services.

site_title: Britain is turbo-charging no-deal Brexit preparations: foreign minister
summary: Britain is accelerating its preparations for a no-deal Brexit, with Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab stating the country will be ready to leave the EU on October 31 with or without a deal. The government has dismissed the possibility of EU renegotiation of the Brexit deal, instead focusing on "turbo-charging" preparations. Despite opposition from lawmakers, including Oliver Letwin, who said it's unclear if Parliament can prevent a no-deal exit, the UK is moving forward with its plans.

site_title: Hospitality startup RedDoorz raises US$45m in Series B funds
summary: Hospitality startup RedDoorz has raised US$45 million in Series B funds led by Qiming Venture Partners, Jungle Ventures, and MNC Group. The funds will be used to pursue growth strategies and increase its lead in South-east Asia's hospitality segment. RedDoorz operates over 1,200 budget hotels and properties across 80 cities in Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, and aims to achieve one million occupied room nights per month by year-end.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with eyes on earnings, trade
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.19% to 21,616.80, amid caution ahead of corporate earnings season and US-China trade talks. Investors are watching earnings reports and the Bank of Japan's policy board meeting, while a wait-and-see attitude prevails. Chinese shares fell, weighing on the Japanese market, and bluechip exporters were broadly lower, with Honda and Tokyo Electron closing down. The dollar fetched 108.60 yen in Asian trade.

site_title: China warns Hong Kong unrest goes 'far beyond' peaceful protest
summary: China warned that Hong Kong's unrest has "gone far beyond" peaceful protest, with chaotic weekend clashes and arrests, amid a leaderless, unpredictable movement. China's top agency condemned "evil and criminal acts" and supported the police force, but the decision to address foreign media in Beijing signals growing concern. The unrest has shaken business confidence, with a survey of the American Chamber of Commerce finding deepening perception that Hong Kong is a "riskier place" to do business. China's statements appear to relieve market anxiety, but opposition lawmakers say the agency did little to resolve the crisis, which they attribute to the city's inability to elect its own leaders.

images.alt_text: China warned that Hong Kong's unrest had gone "far beyond" peaceful protest, after a chaotic weekend of tear gas and clashes illustrated the government's struggle to quell a leaderless, unpredictable and widespread movement.

site_title: Stamford Land, chairman buy London office, retail building for £260m
summary: Stamford Land Corporation has acquired a 60% stake in a 60,000 sq ft London office and retail property for £260m, partnering with Ow Global, owned by Stamford Land chairman CK Ow, for the remaining 40%. The building, 8 Finsbury Circus, is fully let with a weighted average lease term of 14 years. The acquisition is in line with Stamford Land's strategy to seek new investments in developed countries and is not expected to impact its financial performance for the current year.

site_title: Number of suicides committed by teenage boys hits record high
summary: The number of teenage boys committing suicide in Singapore reached a record high in 2018, with 19 cases reported, the highest since 1991. The total number of suicides also rose to 397, a 36% increase from 2017. The Samaritans of Singapore attributed the rise to increased awareness of feelings of loneliness and helplessness among youths. The organization cited societal stereotypes that discourage men from seeking help as a significant barrier, with male teenagers making up only 30% of incoming helpline calls.

images.alt_text: The number of teenage boys taking their own lives reached a record high last year.

site_title: SLA deputy chairman reappointed, 2 new board members added
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law reappointed Yeoh Oon Jin as SLA deputy chairman, along with six other members, who will take effect on August 1. Two new members, Eric Sandosham and Angeline Poh, will also join the board. Outgoing members will complete their terms on July 31. SLA chairman Lim Sim Seng will continue to serve, along with other existing board members.

site_title: AmCham urges Hong Kong action to quell growing business concerns
summary: The American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong urged the government to take action to address growing business concerns, calling for an internationally credible independent inquiry into the protest movement and withdrawal of the suspended extradition bill. The chamber's president, Tara Joseph, stated that the government must show clear leadership to restore business confidence and the city's international reputation. The call comes amid ongoing protests for the eighth-straight weekend, with some overseas customers expressing concerns about Hong Kong's safety and business environment.

site_title: China's yuan suddenly retreats the most in three weeks
summary: China's yuan suddenly dropped 0.21% to 6.8948 USD, its largest decline in three weeks, amid loose yuan liquidity in Hong Kong and investors waiting for developments in the US-China trade dispute. The People's Bank of China's response to expected Federal Reserve interest rate cuts later this week is also being closely watched. This move marks a reversal from the yuan's recent subdued trading, with tiny moves becoming increasingly significant.

site_title: Hong Kong protests knock investor confidence in city's shares
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.7% on Monday, their worst drop in six weeks, due to prolonged protests affecting the local economy. Developers and MTR Corp. were among the biggest decliners, with losses of 3% and 2.9%, respectively. Despite a 12% year-to-date gain, investors are concerned about the impact of protests on retail landlords and global luxury retailers. With an eighth straight week of protests, local shoppers are staying away, and overseas visitors are canceling trips, eroding investor confidence in the city's shares.

site_title: Taiwan seen still growing in Q2 despite global tech slowdown
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow at 1.8% in the second quarter, similar to the first quarter, despite a slowing global tech slowdown and concerns over the US-China trade war. The country's export orders contracted for the eighth straight month in June, and chipmaker TSMC reported a 7.6% drop in profit due to sluggish demand. However, TSMC remains optimistic about demand for 5G chips, suggesting that Taiwan's economy may be more resilient than expected.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.7% at 3,341.22
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,341.22 at the start of the afternoon session, amid concerns over US Federal Reserve rate cuts and trade talks. Stocks in Asia-Pacific declined, except for Australia, which rose 0.5%. Market experts expect little progress from trade talks and the civil unrest in Hong Kong is affecting the overall risk equation. Volume on the Singapore bourse reached 677.1 million securities traded, with decliners outpacing advancers 193 to 138.

site_title: Signing of UN mediation treaty named after Singapore to see over 50 nations gather in city-state
summary: Representatives from over 50 countries, including the US and China, will gather in Singapore on Aug 7 to sign the UN Convention on International Settlement Agreements Resulting from Mediation, also known as the Singapore Convention on Mediation. The treaty aims to provide cross-border enforcement for mediated settlement agreements, enhancing the negotiation process. About 25 countries have indicated they will sign the treaty, with it coming into force six months after governments sign and ratify it. The signing ceremony is part of Singapore Convention Week, a series of events starting on Aug 6-8.

site_title: Ryanair expects average fares to fall 6% in key summer season
summary: Ryanair expects average summer fares to fall 6% due to overcapacity in Germany and Brexit fears. The airline retains its profit forecast for the year to March 31, 2020, at 750-950 million euros. Ryanair's shares have almost halved in value in two years, and the company now expects to receive only 30 Boeing 737 MAX jets by the summer season. The airline's chief financial officer says it is open to talks with pilots in the UK and Ireland amid concerns about industrial action.

site_title: Gold rises as markets brace for Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,423.49 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, where a rate cut is expected. Market participants anticipate a 25-basis-point cut, with only a small chance of a 50-basis-point move. US economic growth slowed less than expected, making a larger rate cut less likely. US-China trade talks are shifting to Shanghai, with low expectations for a breakthrough.

site_title: BM Mobility suspends trading after independent auditor flags going concern issues
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-listed electric transport group, has suspended trading of its shares and warrants following an independent auditor's warning that material uncertainties may cast doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The auditor noted significant losses, cash flow issues, and a deficit in shareholders' funds, prompting the suspension request. The company has assured that it will evaluate strategies to improve its financial performance and meet its obligations, but the decision has raised concerns among investors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.13% and the Topix index down 0.09%. Investors remained cautious amid corporate earnings season, despite a rally on Wall Street. The market shrugged off recent positive news, including a 5-day rally in Singapore and a mandatory offer for PSC shares.

site_title: China Evergrande plans to bring EV charging technology into the home
summary: China Evergrande Group has established a joint venture with State Grid Corp of China to develop smart car-charging technology, aiming to bring EV charging into homes in China. The technology, which includes vehicle-to-grid technology and smart-charging plugs, will allow users to charge their cars at home when electricity rates are cheaper and sell excess energy back to the grid. This initiative aims to reduce the high costs of public EV charging in China, with the goal of making electric vehicles more affordable and increasing adoption.

site_title: Waterloo Street apartment site up for sale with S$145m asking price
summary: A 27-unit residential apartment development, Min Yuan, with a commercial space on its first floor, is up for sale in Singapore with an asking price of S$145 million. The 999-year leasehold site spans 14,629 sq ft and can be redeveloped into a hotel building with a plot ratio of 4.2. Comparable land prices in the area range from S$2,550 to S$2,720 psf ppr. The sale presents a "timely opportunity" for buyers to capitalize on the government's Draft Master Plan 2019, with the redeveloped hotel expected to enjoy unblocked views of the CBD skyline.

site_title: 4 largest Singapore office Reits averaged 2.07 S cents DPU for April-June: SGX
summary: The four largest Singapore-listed office real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) posted an average distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.07 Singapore cents for the quarter ended June, down 0.3% from the year-ago period. Suntec Reit reported the highest DPU of 2.36 cents, while MCT posted the highest year-on-year growth in DPU. The four trusts averaged a 7.9% year-on-year fall in net property income to S$63.5 million, with leverage ratios ranging from 33.1% to 38.4%.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.09% to 3,360.83
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.09% to 3,360.83 on Monday, weighed down by cautious investor sentiment amid corporate earnings season and anticipation of a US interest rate cut. Losers outnumbered gainers 60 to 51, with DBS Group Holdings rising 0.45% despite a 17% net profit increase. Other banking stocks, such as OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank, declined.

site_title: YouTube needs 'new set of rules and laws': executive
summary: YouTube's number two executive, Neal Mohan, calls for a "new set of rules and laws" to combat racism, hate speech, and disinformation on the platform. The company aims to adapt and limit negative content, following increasing public pressure and scrutiny from governments. YouTube has already banned videos promoting racism and Holocaust denial, and Mohan emphasizes the platform's responsibility to ensure user safety. The process of updating policies and enforcement regimes is complex, with Mohan warning against rapid solutions and the need for consultation with experts.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as trade talks, Fed in focus
summary: Asian stocks started the week mixed, with Japan and South Korea dipping and Australia rising, ahead of US-China trade talks resuming and the Federal Reserve's first interest-rate cut in a decade. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes hit fresh records Friday on technology shares, while Treasuries and the US dollar were little changed. Investors will monitor the trade talks and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's press conference for any signs of a breakthrough or rate hike.

site_title: The elite club that rules the diamond world is starting to crack
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond miner, is facing challenges in maintaining its exclusive buyer network, known as "sightholders." The company's system, which guarantees a steady supply of gems at discounted rates, has seen profit margins shrink for buyers, forcing some to sell at a loss. High-end jewelry sales are stagnant, and financing for diamond trading companies is dwindling due to bank abandonment. De Beers has loosened rules for sightholders and reduced prices, but analysts predict a perfect storm of oversupply and low demand, making it difficult for the industry to recover.

images.alt_text: It's one of the world's most exclusive clubs, known over the years as the Syndicate, the Central Selling Organization and the Diamond Trading Company.

site_title: Jurong Port Tank Terminal secures PetroChina as anchor tenant
summary: Singapore's Jurong Port Tank Terminal has secured PetroChina as its anchor tenant, leasing all 252,000 cubic meters of phase 1 capacity. PetroChina will use the majority of the tanks for gasoline storage and chemical components. The terminal aims to reach 550,000 cubic meters of storage capacity when fully operational. This deal marks a significant milestone for JPTT, which started partial operations in April.

site_title: Goldman says Asia's trade slump is showing signs of bottoming
summary: Goldman Sachs analysts say Asia's export slump appears to be bottoming out, with a rebound in exports to the US from Taiwan, Vietnam, and India offsetting declines in shipments from China. The company expects supportive measures from governments and central banks to aid the trade recovery, despite potential escalation in US-China trade tensions. The Federal Reserve is set to cut interest rates for the first time in a decade, which could mitigate potential damages. However, a prolonged downturn could make the current downcycle the longest since the 1990s if trade tensions escalate beyond baseline expectations.

images.alt_text: That's according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc economists who highlight a substantial pick up in exports to the US from Asian economies including Taiwan, Vietnam and India that's effectively cancelling out the fall in shipments from China.

site_title: Australian PM Morrison takes lead in first poll since shock win
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative government leads Labor 53-47 in the two-party preferred measure, according to a major opinion poll. The survey, conducted among 1,601 voters, shows Morrison's Liberal-National coalition secure in power after securing a third consecutive term. The poll's results come after the government passed $158 billion in tax cuts, boosting Morrison's popularity. However, some observers caution against placing too much faith in Australian opinion polls, citing past failures to predict the May election outcome.

site_title: Jack Ma's 2 trillion yuan loan machine is changing Chinese banking
summary: Jack Ma's online bank, MYbank, is revolutionizing Chinese banking by lending 2 trillion yuan to nearly 16 million small businesses using real-time payments data and a risk-management system. The loan process takes just three minutes, with a default rate of about 1%. MYbank's technology is changing how banks interact with small businesses, which account for 60% of China's economic growth. The use of Big Data and artificial-intelligence technology is becoming increasingly common in Chinese lending, with the country becoming a world leader in its use.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma's online bank is leading a quiet revolution in the way China lends to small businesses, taking aim at a credit bottleneck that has held back Asia's largest economy for decades.

site_title: Investment in UK residential property up 150% despite Brexit
summary: UK residential property investment surged 150% to €6.8 billion in 2018, driven by London's nearly doubling investment volume to €2 billion. The UK capital became the fourth-largest European city for multifamily investment, behind Berlin, Copenhagen, and Paris. Investment in European multifamily properties rose 40% to €56 billion, with stable cash flow and limited supply in top-tier cities. However, Brexit uncertainty may impact future growth, with foreign investors becoming more cautious, according to JLL's Simon Scott.

site_title: EU to strip 5 countries, including Singapore, of some market access rights, says FT
summary: The European Commission has decided to strip 5 countries, including Singapore, of some market access rights due to inadequate regulation of credit ratings agencies. The countries, which also include Canada, Brazil, Argentina, and Australia, will lose their equivalence provisions, making it harder for European banks to rely on the ratings. This decision sets a precedent for monitoring adherence and is the first time such rights have been withdrawn, except for temporary permissions for Switzerland.

site_title: Oil falls after "constructive" talks on Iran's nuclear deal
summary: Oil prices fell after Iran described emergency talks on a nuclear deal as "constructive", easing Middle East tensions. Brent crude futures rose 0.4% to $63.23 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.2% to $56.08 a barrel. Despite the constructive talks, unresolved issues remain, and Iran will continue to reduce nuclear commitments if European countries fail to salvage the pact. Tensions remain high around the Strait of Hormuz, with Iran refusing to release a seized tanker. The US is working on a maritime security initiative in the Gulf.

site_title: China to brief on Hong Kong unrest after weekend of protests
summary: China's top office for Hong Kong affairs plans a briefing on the city's unrest after a weekend of protests, with police deploying tear gas and rubber bullets to clear thousands of demonstrators. At least 49 people were arrested, and the protests have sustained momentum for a protracted fight against embattled Chief Executive Carrie Lam and her supporters in Beijing. The movement has drawn comparisons with France's Yellow Vests movement, and fears of fatalities and further economic disruption have grown, with Hong Kong's reputation as a stable environment for business under threat.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index remained unchanged at 1647.96, with 85.3 million lots traded worth RM42.7 million. Gainers outpaced losers 115 to 66.

site_title: SIAEC's innovations come from the ground up
summary: SIA Engineering Co (SIAEC) is trialing innovative prototypes to improve productivity, leveraging employee ideas and experience. The company's innovation group is decentralizing its function to operating divisions, aiming to increase outreach and closeness to real operations. Staff-initiated ideas include a brake heat extraction system, a driving simulator, and a QR code technology for recording engine component numbers. SIAEC plans to continue implementing employee-led innovations, with a focus on automation and technology to stay competitive in the aviation industry.

site_title: Ex-national golfer Vincent Khua leads Car Times to the top of the table
summary: Vincent Khua leads his team, Car Times, to the top of the Business Times Corporate Golf League table with a total of 224 points after the second leg of the six-leg series. Khua contributed the maximum 40 points with a score of 71, and his team's best performance was 115 points. Team Citi shares the lead with 224 points. Audi Sport dropped to third with 221 points after the event's presenting sponsor, Jeff Mannering, made his farewell appearance.

site_title: DBS Q2 profit up 17% to S$1.6b; to pay out dividend of 30 S cents per share
summary: DBS Group Holding reported a 17% increase in its second-quarter net profit before one-time items to S$1.60 billion, driven by higher total income and sustained business momentum. The bank also declared a 30 Singapore cents per share dividend. Total income rose 16% to S$3.71 billion, led by loan growth, net interest margin progression, and higher fee income. Annualized earnings per share increased to S$2.47, up from S$2.12 a year ago.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q2 profit drops 15.6% on startup costs for Chongqing hospital
summary: Raffles Medical Group posted a 15.6% drop in Q2 net profit to S$14.2 million due to startup costs at its Chongqing hospital. Revenue grew 5.6% to S$127 million, driven by increased contributions from healthcare services and hospital services. Gestation losses at the Chongqing hospital contributed to the drop, but the group expects to remain profitable in 2019.

site_title: US teen wins US$3m at video game tournament Fortnite World Cup
summary: American teenager Kyle Giersdorf, 16, won $3 million at the Fortnite World Cup in New York, taking the top prize in a tournament with a total of $30 million in prize money. Giersdorf, competing under the name "Bugha", secured 59 points, beating his nearest competitor by 26 points. The Fortnite World Cup's popularity has contributed to the growing e-sports industry, with global revenues expected to reach $1.1 billion in 2019, up 27% from last year.

site_title: Fed poised to cut rates for first time since financial crisis, ending an era
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates for the first time since 2008, aiming to maintain a record economic expansion. The move, likely to be small, comes as the economy shows signs of slowing, including slumping manufacturing gauges and business investment. The Fed aims to keep the economy from petering out, but a rate cut signals the current expansion may be the best it gets. The move is driven by precaution, not politics, and is intended to address growing uncertainty and scars from the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: US dollar near 2-month top after US GDP boosts yield appeal
summary: The US dollar held near a two-month high against a basket of currencies after better-than-expected US GDP data boosted its yield attraction. The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates for the first time in over a decade, but the move is seen as a pre-emptive measure to protect the economy from global uncertainties. The US dollar index stood at 97.968, while the euro and yen were relatively unchanged. Market expectations suggest the Fed will cut interest rates by 25 basis points, leaving the US dollar with the highest interest rates among major currencies.

site_title: OCBC in sweet spot as SMEs go regional and digital
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 30% increase in cash management revenue in Q1, driven by its large share of primary bank accounts holding SMEs' operating accounts in Singapore. The bank's PayNow Corporate service has seen over 40% of main company registration numbers tied to an OCBC account, facilitating real-time fund transfers. OCBC's head of global transaction banking sees the bank in a "sweet spot" to capitalize on regionalization trends and digital payments, with plans to offer data analytics and expand its services.

site_title: Clearbridge Health to raise S$11.3m from share placement
summary: Clearbridge Health, a CATALIST-LISTED company, plans to raise S$11.34 million through a share placement of 80.5 million shares at S$0.141 apiece. The funds will be used for expansion via mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures, and investment in Asia, as well as general working capital purposes. The placement represents a 9.96% discount to its volume-weighted average price. The company's CEO, Jeremy Yee, stated that the funds will enhance the company's financial capabilities to grow its healthcare assets and presence across Asia.

site_title: Fed plan to cut interest rates may imperil the economy
summary: The Federal Reserve's plan to cut interest rates may have unintended consequences, particularly for individual and institutional investors who are forced into buying stocks due to low returns on safe investments. Ultra-low interest rates pose dangers to investors, retirees, and pension funds, potentially leading to a catastrophic cut in Social Security payments and exacerbating economic instability. Experts argue that a rate cut may not solve the economy's slowdown, which is largely caused by trade wars and uncertainties, and may even worsen the situation.

site_title: SAC Capital expands into fund management
summary: SAC Capital has launched SAC Investment Management (SACIM), a fund management firm to provide funding for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) at pre-listing and pre-trade sale stages. The firm aims to raise S$20 million in committed capital, with ambitions to hit S$50 million. SACIM will hold 75% of the capital, followed by a Japanese investor and SACIM's CEO. The move expands SAC Capital's private equity business, which complements its investment banking services. SACIM will focus on investing in mature, profitable companies with clear exit strategies, and has plans to launch more funds and expand into new markets.

site_title: Ratcliffe tapped to replace Coats as US spy chief
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he will nominate Representative John Ratcliffe, a Texas Republican, to replace Dan Coats as the US spy chief, effective August 15. Ratcliffe, a former US attorney and congressman, defended Trump during a congressional hearing and has clashed with Trump over assessments involving Russia, Iran, and North Korea. Trump thanked Coats for his service but will name an acting director shortly, marking the second time Trump has parted ways with a former Republican senator in his administration.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Sunday he would nominate Representative John Ratcliffe (pictured), a Texas Republican who strongly defended him at a recent congressional hearing, to replace Dan Coats as the US spy chief.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, CapitaLand, UIC, SIA Engg, Raffles Medical, iFast, HC Surgical
summary: DBS Group reported a 17% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$1.6 billion, with earnings per share rising to S$2.47. CapitaLand achieved a 95% leasing rate for its Raffles City Chongqing retail component ahead of its September opening. DBS shares closed at S$26.88, while CapitaLand shares were not mentioned.

site_title: 'War cabinet' to deliver Brexit by Oct 31, even if result is no-deal
summary: The UK government, under Prime Minister Boris Johnson, has established a "war cabinet" to deliver Brexit by October 31, regardless of the outcome. The cabinet, led by Michael Gove, will work on the assumption that the EU will not strike a fresh agreement. The government is preparing for a no-deal Brexit, with Chancellor Sajid Javid announcing significant extra funding to prepare for the scenario. The UK's economic future outside the EU's single market and customs union is uncertain, with polls showing a "Boris bounce" in support for the Conservative Party.

site_title: CapitaLand secures 95% retail take-up for Chongqing mega project
summary: CapitaLand has secured 95% retail take-up for its Chongqing mega project, Raffles City Chongqing, ahead of its September opening. The five-storey mall boasts a gross floor area of 235,000 sq m and will house over 400 brands, including Adidas, GAP, and Haidilao hotpot. The mall's experiential retail and lifestyle offerings will inject vibrancy into Chongqing's retail scene, with a focus on personalized customer experiences and leveraging analytics to optimize retailer offerings. The project is part of a larger 1.12 million sq m mega-structure in Chongqing, with a total development cost of 24 billion yuan.

site_title: Lower expectations on US-China talks: experts
summary: US trade negotiators return to China for fresh talks in Shanghai, but experts warn a breakthrough is unlikely due to differing expectations and a lack of progress since negotiations collapsed in May. The talks come after a G20 agreement to cease hostilities, but US demands for China to curb technology theft and provide a level playing field remain a major hurdle. Despite a positive tone from US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, experts expect follow-up talks in the US and a long and challenging negotiation process.

site_title: US judge sets July 29 hearing in Trump lawsuit over tax returns
summary: US District Judge Carl Nichols has scheduled a July 29 hearing in President Donald Trump's lawsuit against the House Ways and Means Committee, seeking to block the committee's access to his New York state tax returns. Trump's lawyers argue that the New York law granting the committee access to the president's state tax returns violates his constitutional rights. The law was enacted to retaliate against Trump, and the committee has sought Trump's federal returns to shed light on his business dealings. A hearing will resolve an "emergency" lawsuit filed by Trump's personal lawyers last week.

images.alt_text: A US judge will hear arguments on July 29 in President Donald Trump's lawsuit seeking to block a House of Representatives committee from obtaining his New York state tax returns, according to a court filing issued Sunday.

site_title: Hedge funds chasing 400% return show risk in China's wild market
summary: Chinese hedge funds are chasing high returns, often at the risk of failure, with many top performers ending up in the scrap heap. The "curse of the champion" refers to the phenomenon where top-performing funds lose their momentum and are shut down by regulators. In 2018, Guangdong Chaokin Investment Co's bet on just two stocks paid off, but the firm's peers have not been as lucky, with over 300 private fund-management firms cancelled for being "out of touch" or failing to submit required legal opinions. Regulators are taking notice, citing the high risk of one-way bets on stocks in the market.

site_title: US, China move trade talks to Shanghai amid deal pessimism
summary: US and Chinese trade negotiators meet in Shanghai for two-day talks amid low expectations for progress, following a G20 truce last month. The talks aim to detail "goodwill" gestures, such as Chinese purchases of US farm commodities and US permission for Huawei to resume some sales to China. However, both sides are far apart on key issues, including US complaints about Chinese state subsidies and forced technology transfers. President Trump suggests China may wait until after the 2020 election to sign a trade deal, while Chinese officials demand the removal of all US tariffs.

images.alt_text: US and Chinese trade negotiators shift to Shanghai this week for their first in-person talks since a G20 truce last month, a change of scenery for two sides struggling to resolve deep differences on how to end a year-long trade war.

site_title: Asean offers silver lining for logistics players as global trade slows
summary: US-China trade tensions are rerouting global trade to South-East Asia, with the region emerging as a key investment target for logistics players. Despite a slight contraction in global trade, the "big six" countries of Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines are leading the growth, while Vietnam is gaining pace. Multilateral trade agreements and bilateral free trade agreements are driving trade growth within the region. India and Bangladesh are also experiencing booming manufacturing sectors, and high-tech markets like South Korea and Japan are well-positioned to benefit from emerging technologies. Logistics firms such as DHL, UPS, and YCH are investing in the region, with plans to expand their footprint in Asia over the next few years.

site_title: Cloudiest Tokyo summer in 129 years hurts retailers
summary: Tokyo has experienced its cloudiest summer in 129 years, with only 44 daylight hours in July, leading to a significant drop in sales for retailers. Shimamura Co. reported an 18% decline in same-store sales, while Right On Co. and Nitori Holdings Co. saw 5.9% and 5.6% drops, respectively. The prolonged rainy season has hurt demand for summer clothing and furniture, with some retailers attributing the decline to customers staying home on weekends. Analysts predict weaker monthly sales for retailers in the coming week.

site_title: Vietnam detains 380 Chinese people in illegal online gambling bust
summary: Vietnam's police detained over 380 Chinese individuals accused of running the country's largest-ever underground online gambling ring. The operation, which took place in Haiphong City, targeted online platforms for Chinese gamblers, with estimated transactions of 3 billion yuan (S$600 million). The individuals, aged 18-24, were found operating in over 100 rooms, with police confiscating 2,000 smartphones and 530 computers. This is the largest-ever online gambling ring in Vietnam, with the previous record being held by a Vietnamese court's recent conviction of two senior police officials.

site_title: Dow recession signals not straightforward
summary: The Dow Jones index is experiencing a recession signal, but its relevance is being questioned. According to the Dow Theory, the Transportation index should confirm the trend of the Industrial index. However, the Transportation index has made significant lower highs, but a bullish pennant formation suggests it may be breaking higher. The confirmation signals have not been established, and a potential reversal is possible at 20,000. The Dow Theory has successfully predicted most downturns in the past, but the current situation may not be as straightforward as previous recessions.

site_title: Bond traders eye Johnson, Brexit as BOE decision takes back seat
summary: UK bond traders are focusing on Brexit uncertainty and Prime Minister Boris Johnson's deadlock with the EU, overshadowing the Bank of England's policy announcement next week. Gilts, UK government bonds, are expected to rally for a third monthly gain, driven by the risk of a no-deal Brexit and positive yields compared to German and French debt. The Bank of England is unlikely to raise interest rates to curb inflation, instead allowing the market to dictate gilt yields, which could edge close to 0.50% if a no-deal Brexit occurs.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How working in his family business prepared Glife's CEO for the future
summary: Singapore agri-tech firm Glife has raised S$1.6 million in seed capital to bring farm food directly to consumers. CEO Justin Chou, who co-founded Glife, credits his experience working in his family business for preparing him for the future. Chou emphasized the adoption of technology in the agri-tech industry, highlighting Glife's innovative approach to farm-to-fork solutions. The funding will support Glife's expansion and technology development, marking a significant step towards its goal of revolutionizing the local food industry.

site_title: You call that a burger? A food fight over names
summary: A battle is brewing over the labeling of plant-based food products, with meat producers attempting to pass legislation to prohibit the use of terms like "burger" and "steak" to describe meat alternatives. Alternative meat-makers, including Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat, are pushing back with lawsuits in multiple states, arguing that such laws violate consumer rights and confuse consumers. Proponents of the legislation claim that the terms are being misused, but vegans and vegetarians argue that the word "meat" can refer to any food product, regardless of its source.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Tokopedia bets on logistics, AI for Indonesia growth
summary: Tokopedia, Indonesia's e-commerce unicorn backed by SoftBank's Vision Fund, is investing in logistics companies and using AI to predict buying behavior to speed delivery and reduce shipping costs. The company aims to lift one-day delivery rates to 95% and cut costs for merchants, with plans to create a "super-ecosystem" offering services such as lending and payment. Tokopedia expects e-commerce sales to reach $53 billion by 2025, driven by Indonesia's growing online population of 260 million.

images.alt_text: Tokopedia founder and chief executive William Tanuwijaya also said the firm is in final talks to invest in an agritech startup that works with farmers and has been buying stakes in smaller marketplaces offering everything from wedding services to secondhand phones.

site_title: Piermont Grand EC sells 375 of 820 units on launch weekend
summary: Piermont Grand EC, Singapore's first executive condominium launched this year, sold 375 of its 820 units in its launch weekend, achieving a 46% sales rate. The project, developed by City Developments and TID, offers three- to five-bedroom units, with prices starting from S$888,000. Eligible second-time buyers accounted for 65% of the sold units, exceeding the 30% cap. The project's strong take-up rate and scenic waterfront location are seen as key factors in its success.

site_title: Temasek unit invests S$5m in HC Surgical
summary: Temasek Holdings unit Heliconia Capital has invested S$5 million in HC Surgical Specialists, a Catalist-listed medical services group, to support regional expansion. The investment is part of a three-year bond convertible into ordinary shares. HC Surgical plans to expand into ASEAN, particularly Vietnam, driven by growing demand for its endoscopic procedures. The investment aims to enhance the group's presence in the region, driven by ageing populations, chronic diseases, and rising affluence.

site_title: Audi's 'dirty tricks' exposed in emissions scandal
summary: Audi's luxury-car unit was involved in a deeper emissions cheating scheme than previously known, according to newly uncovered documents. The company installed software in engine computers to recognize official emissions tests, temporarily ramping up pollution controls to meet standards. Vehicles like the Audi Q7 SUV produced emissions far above legal limits. Audi engineers described the scheme as a "defeat device" or "cycle beating," and the company continued to sell vehicles with illegal software even after the scandal became public. Audi's actions were part of a broader Volkswagen emissions scandal, which has resulted in billions of dollars in fines and penalties.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market reveals a significant decline in rates. The Capesize market dropped 15% from $32,765 to $27,145, with West Australia to China rates falling from $11.145 to $9.77. Panamax rates also declined, with the Atlantic market experiencing a sharper correction. Supramax/Ultramax rates showed mixed fortunes, with the Baltic Supramax Index decreasing. The Handysize market calmed down, with the Baltic Handysize Index making gains overall. Tanker rates also decreased, with VLCC rates shedding a point to WS 42.5.

site_title: Tesla's days of splashy outside hires gives way to internal promotions
summary: Tesla is shifting its focus from external hires to internal promotions, with several high-profile executives leaving the company to be replaced by internal candidates. This trend is attributed to Elon Musk's demanding leadership style and the company's prioritization of talent development. Notable departures include J.B. Straubel, Deepak Ahuja, and Dane Butswinkas, who were replaced by internal candidates such as Drew Baglino, Zach Kirkhorn, and Jonathan Chang. This shift is seen as a cost-effective and efficient way to promote from within, reducing the risk of disenfranchising talented employees.

site_title: Fed policy, blue-chip earnings in focus after rocky week
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to announce a 25 basis point rate cut, sparking hopes of accommodative central bank policies and influencing global equity markets. The decision follows the Bank of Japan's decision on Tuesday and the Bank of England's decision on Thursday. Meanwhile, corporate earnings season is in full gear, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ending the week down 0.4% due to concerns over trade tensions and economic slowdown.

site_title: C$ steadies, after hitting 1-month low on better-than-expected US data
summary: The Canadian dollar stabilized against the US dollar after hitting a one-month low due to better-than-expected US data and the ruling out of currency intervention by the Trump administration. White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow stated that the US will not intervene in markets to lower the US dollar's value, alleviating concerns of currency manipulation. This news led to a slight recovery for the Canadian dollar.

site_title: StashAway raises US$12m led by Eight Roads Ventures
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based robo-advisor, has raised US$12 million in a Series B round led by Eight Roads Ventures. The funding will support regional expansion, product development, and improving its offerings to attract high net worth clients. With a total of US$20.4 million raised, the startup will drive growth in the Asia-Pacific region and enhance its financial education content. Currently, StashAway has over 80,000 users, primarily from the financial services, consulting, and technology industries.

site_title: Phishing attack on reporters probing Russia: ProtonMail
summary: Reporters investigating Russian military intelligence have been targeted by sophisticated phishing attacks on their encrypted ProtonMail accounts, with evidence suggesting Moscow's involvement. ProtonMail's CEO Andy Yen stated the attack was one of the best-run phishing attacks seen, and Bellingcat journalist Christo Grozev attributed it to Russia's GRU military intelligence unit. Multiple journalists have received phishing e-mails since April, and ProtonMail is conducting its own investigation, while Swiss authorities are being alerted. The Swiss Federal Police and MELANI have not yet launched an investigation, citing a lack of indication.

site_title: Where are the opportunities for fintechs in Indonesia?
summary: Fintech companies often choose Indonesia as a base due to its large potential for future customer growth, with 20% of all fintechs operating in the country. Indonesia's growing population, increasing GDP per head, and favorable demographic profile make it an attractive market for fintech firms. However, navigating the regulatory environment and gaining local acceptance are major challenges. Partnerships with commercial and non-commercial organizations can help overcome these challenges, providing access to market intelligence, technology exchanges, and referrals to potential customers.

site_title: Jack Ma's online loan machine is changing banking in China
summary: Jack Ma's online bank, MYbank, is revolutionizing small business lending in China by leveraging big data and AI technology. The bank has lent 2 trillion yuan to nearly 16 million small companies, with a default rate of about one percent. This approach is changing the way Chinese banks interact with companies that drive the nation's economic growth, and its success may have profound implications for China's US$13 trillion economy, which is facing its weakest growth pace since 1992.

site_title: Keeping the headcount up
summary: Singapore's declining birth rate poses a concern for the country's future, with a total fertility rate of 1.3, below the replacement rate of 2.1. Experts suggest a balanced approach, combining measures to encourage Singaporeans to start families, such as flexible work arrangements and pro-family initiatives, while also supplementing the population with immigrants who can integrate quickly. Immigration policies should be sectoral and focused on quality, not quantity, and tailored to address specific labor needs. Some propose extending family-friendly policies, such as longer paternity leave and housing adjustments, to accommodate diverse family arrangements.

site_title: HK economy and businesses hit by social unrest: Financial Secretary
summary: Hong Kong's economy and businesses are being severely impacted by the ongoing social unrest, with Financial Secretary Paul Chan warning of a rise in unemployment and potential countermeasures to stabilize the economy. The unrest, which began over proposed extradition legislation, has grown into a broader movement calling for Chief Executive Carrie Lam's resignation. The city's retail and catering industries have experienced a sharp decline in business, and the government is expected to report a preliminary second-quarter GDP drop on July 31. The situation is deteriorating, with clashes between protesters and police, and the government is preparing for a potential economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Protesters using umbrellas to protect themselves from tear gas during a protest near China's Liaison Office in Hong Kong; a number of stores in the neighbourhood were closed ahead of the tense standoff.

site_title: Strong earnings a threat to rate cut expectations
summary: US stocks rose last week, hitting record highs, amid strong housing and GDP data and better-than-expected earnings from companies like Google and McDonald's. The US Federal Reserve is set to cut interest rates by a quarter-percentage point on Wednesday, but investors are wary of a "plain vanilla" move, expecting more guidance on future rate cuts. Despite warnings of slowing Chinese demand, the rally is expected to continue, with strategists attributing the upward momentum to resumption of trade negotiations in Shanghai. The Fed's rate cut may be seen as an anticlimax, with investors looking for more signals on future rate moves.

site_title: Verstappen wins crazy German Grand Prix
summary: Max Verstappen of Red Bull won the chaotic German Grand Prix, despite Lewis Hamilton failing to score. Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari finished second, a surprising comeback from starting last. Daniil Kvyat of Toro Rosso secured third place. The win maintains Verstappen's lead over Hamilton in the championship standings, with Bottas' crash preventing a potential gap reduction.

site_title: Dish may find it difficult to serve up a nationwide wireless network
summary: DISH Network Corp. is poised to become a major wireless carrier after the US$26.5 billion merger of T-Mobile and Sprint was cleared by the Justice Department. The merger requires the companies to divest assets, which will potentially transform Dish into a major competitor. However, analysts say Dish faces long-shot odds of succeeding due to its lack of experience in the wireless industry. Despite this, Dish has a cache of prized assets, including a nationwide wireless network, which could give it a chance to succeed in the competitive market.

site_title: iFast Q2 net profit falls 16.5% on higher costs, continuing investments
summary: iFast Corporation, a Singapore-listed fintech firm, reported a 16.5% decline in Q2 net profit to S$2.45 million due to higher costs and investments in platform capabilities. Revenue dipped 0.9% to S$30.6 million, primarily affected by lower front-end commission income. Despite volatile market conditions, the company's assets under administration (AUA) grew 12.2% year-to-date to a record S$9.04 billion. iFast reiterated its interest in pursuing a digital bank license in Singapore, citing its potential strengths in the digital banking space.

site_title: LSE's bid for Refinitiv a sign of quest for data, global reach
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) is set to acquire Refinitiv in a $27 billion deal, marking a significant shift towards data products and global expansion for the exchange operator. This move follows a decade of consolidation efforts by exchanges to increase revenue and diversify their businesses. The deal will bring together LSE's and Refinitiv's data and information capabilities, making them more competitive and appealing to customers. The acquisition is expected to expand LSE's global footprint, increase earnings per share, and cut annual costs by over $350 million.

site_title: Regulation of global IT giants urged as alarm rises over oligopoly concerns
summary: The US Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission have launched investigations into Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon for alleged antitrust violations, amid concerns over oligopoly and the accumulation of customer information. The companies' acquisition of startups and dominance in the market could hinder future competition and innovation. Similar concerns have been raised by Japanese and European authorities, with efforts to develop a fair market environment through stricter screenings of acquisitions and regulations. The investigations come as public distrust in data protection grows, following high-profile cases of fake news and privacy violations.

site_title: Vibrant city or tourist magnet? Puerto Rico shows hidden cost of urban renewal
summary: In Puerto Rico's San Juan, urban renewal efforts have brought a vibrant hip neighborhood, but at a hidden cost. A group of residents transformed an abandoned house into a community center, only to see quality of life threatened by rising tourism and rents. The national government has highlighted tourism as an economic engine, but residents claim it's pushing out young people and low-income families, exacerbating the severe lack of affordable housing. Critics argue that tax incentives for tourism development have led to a surge in short-term rentals, displacing long-term residents.

site_title: Reliance Jio becomes India's top telecom services provider
summary: Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd has become India's top telecom services provider, surpassing Vodafone Idea Ltd with a subscriber base of 331.3 million as of June. The company's rapid growth has been fueled by significant spending of over $36 billion, leading to intense competition that has driven India's data tariffs to the lowest in the world. This growth comes ahead of the planned rollout of 5G networks in India next year, with most major carriers testing 5G networks.

site_title: ASA unit enters partnership agreement to make steel trailer wheels
summary: Advanced Systems Automation (ASA) announced a partnership agreement with Nakareg International Company, allowing Yumei Technology Sdn Bhd to manufacture steel trailer wheels. The project, valued at 6.16 million ringgit (S$2.04 million), will enhance Yumei's manufacturing capabilities and expand its customer base. ASA expects the project to have a minimal impact on its financials, with the cost funded mainly through bank loans, and no change in control or earnings per share. Further details will be announced as necessary.

site_title: FaceApp: A cautionary tale of betrayal
summary: The viral app FaceApp raised concerns over users' personal data after granting a "perpetual, irrevocable, nonexclusive, royalty-free, worldwide, fully-paid" license to photos through boilerplate agreements. Despite its age-advanced portraits and celebrity endorsements, the app's fine print revealed invasive data collection and analysis. Senator Chuck Schumer called for an FBI and FTC investigation, while a bill was introduced to require app stores to list software's country of origin. Experts say the issue highlights the underlying problem of companies' ability to collect and monetize user data without adequate oversight, despite the prevalence of similar practices in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Users of FaceApp agree to grant the company a licence to their photos that is "perpetual, irrevocable, non-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide, fully-paid", which is indeed quite expansive.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to start next phase of flour mill privatisation
summary: Saudi Arabia's state grain buyer SAGO will start the next phase of selling its flour mills, which has attracted interest from major agribusiness firms like Archer Daniels Midland Co and Bunge Ltd. This privatization is part of the kingdom's economy overhaul and marks one of its first major moves in this area. The sale is expected to bring in significant revenue for the government, with pre-qualified bidders set to perform due diligence and present financial offers.

site_title: Fit for the king? Thai monarchist's birthday haircut
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn's 67th birthday was marked by a devoted monarchist's unique haircut, with the phrase "Long Live the King" and the monarch's image on one side of his head. The haircut, which took over three hours to complete, has drawn praise from some royalists but criticism from others who view it as disrespectful. The king's popularity remains low, and special haircuts, like this one, are a regular feature for a strongly committed royalist barber.

site_title: Irish PM says no-deal Brexit could lead to united Ireland
summary: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar stated that a no-deal Brexit could lead to a united Ireland as more people in Northern Ireland may question the union with Britain. This comes after Boris Johnson announced the UK's top priority is leaving the EU without an agreement, particularly due to the Irish backstop, which prevents a hard border between Northern Ireland and EU member Ireland. The tension centers around the backstop, which Johnson considers unacceptable.

site_title: Aquaponics for all
summary: A Singaporean doctor, Dr. Lim Jia Yang, has received funding from the #OCBCCares Fund to expand his aquaponics project, which allows for sustainable and space-efficient farming of fish and plants. The project, which began three years ago, uses a symbiotic relationship between fish waste and plant nutrients to minimize water usage. The expanded project aims to supply fresh produce to local eateries and generate profits to fund operations. With the #OCBCCares Fund's support, Dr. Lim plans to build a miniature microfarm at a medical alumni complex, creating a sustainable food source and promoting environmental responsibility.

site_title: China needs new places to sell its mountain of stuff
summary: China is struggling to find new markets for its surplus goods due to its trade war with the US, its biggest overseas customer. The country has slowed its economic growth to its most sluggish pace in nearly three decades, with exports to the US plummeting 8.5% in the first half of this year. China is seeking new customers through a free-trade zone across the Asia-Pacific region and is also trying to lower trade barriers with Japan and South Korea. However, finding new markets for its vast amounts of manufactured goods may prove difficult, with no country willing to replace the US in running a close to $400 billion annual trade deficit in manufactured goods with China.

site_title: iFast Q2 net profit down 16.5% to S$2.45m
summary: iFast Corporation reported a net profit of S$2.45 million for Q2 2019, down 16.5% from the year-ago period. Revenue dipped 0.9% to S$30.6 million due to lower front-end commission income. Despite volatile market conditions, assets under administration grew 12.2% year-to-date. iFast reiterated its interest in pursuing a digital bank license in Singapore, citing its track record of running a profitable regulated business.

site_title: Russian opposition plans election protest despite crackdown
summary: Russian opposition plans to hold an unauthorized rally in Moscow on Saturday, despite a police crackdown, including the 30-day jailing of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny. The rally aims to demand free and fair polls for the September Moscow parliament election, amid worsening living standards and falling approval ratings for President Vladimir Putin. Despite authorities' efforts to suppress the opposition, nearly 11,000 people have indicated interest in attending the rally, with activists saying the country's future trajectory is at stake.

site_title: Trump, Johnson eye 'substantial' trade deal in first call
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he has spoken with new British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, discussing a "very substantial" trade deal. Trump predicted Johnson will be a great prime minister and expressed enthusiasm for a bilateral agreement post-Brexit, potentially three to four times larger than current trade. Johnson's Downing Street spokesperson confirmed both leaders' commitment to an ambitious free trade agreement and starting negotiations after the UK leaves the EU.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said Friday he had spoken by phone with new British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and that discussions on a "very substantial" trade deal were already underway.

site_title: Bank of England to hold rates as clouds gather over outlook
summary: The Bank of England is expected to maintain its benchmark interest rate at 0.75% as economic outlook worsens, with officials acknowledging a material decline since May. Economists predict a unanimous vote, citing a risk of a no-deal Brexit and a gloomy global outlook. Officials have scaled back rate-hike rhetoric, and investors are pricing in rate cuts. The decision comes with a falling pound, stronger wage growth, and inflation concerns, raising a potential dilemma between growth and prices.

images.alt_text: Bank of England (BOE) officials will probably keep policy on hold next week as they acknowledge that the economic outlook has worsened materially since May.

site_title: EC Piermont Grand sells 375 of 820 units in launch weekend
summary: City Developments (CDL) reported strong sales for Piermont Grand, its first executive condominium (EC) launch this year, with 375 of 820 units sold at an average price of S$1,080 per sq ft during the launch weekend. The 46% sales rate made it the best-selling EC launch this year, with eligible second-time buyers accounting for 65% of the sold units. The project, which offers three- to five-bedroom units, is set to be completed in 2023 and is located near two LRT stations and the Punggol MRT station.

site_title: Lucio Tan's Philippine Air to name president as revamp continues
summary: Philippine Airlines Inc is expected to name a new president on Monday, replacing Jaime Bautista, who quit last month. Gilbert Santa Maria, a former chief operating officer, is the top nominee, according to two people familiar with the matter. The airline's board of directors will meet on July 29 to make the decision. Lucio Tan, the airline's majority owner, confirmed Santa Maria's potential appointment but declined to elaborate. The move comes as the airline undergoes management changes and aims to cut costs by reducing flights to destinations with overcapacity.

site_title: London Stock Exchange in talks to buy Refinitiv for US$27b
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group Plc is in talks to acquire financial data analytics provider Refinitiv Holdings Ltd for US$27 billion, including debt. The deal would be financed with newly issued LSE shares, valuing Thomson Reuters at 15% of the combined company. Refinitiv's existing investors would own approximately 37% of the combined company, with less than 30% voting rights. The acquisition would significantly expand LSE's information services business, focusing on data and technology as revenue drivers.

site_title: 'I'm just protecting athletes', insists China swim star Sun
summary: China's Olympic swimming champion Sun Yang has defended himself against doping allegations, stating he's "protecting all athletes" after rivals accused him of violating doping rules. A leaked report alleged Sun smashed blood vials with a hammer after being visited by testers, but FINA cleared him to compete. Sun claims he was unfairly targeted and that the testers were not properly accredited. He will appeal the decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport in September, saying he has "all the evidence" to prove his innocence.

site_title: Privacy group files legal challenge to Facebook's US$5b FTC settlement
summary: A public interest research group, the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC), is challenging the Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) $5 billion settlement with Facebook, citing it as an unjustified victory for the tech giant. EPIC argues that the proposed deal fails to ensure consumer privacy and grants Facebook immunity from thousands of outstanding consumer complaints. The group is seeking a hearing to review the fairness of the settlement and consider consumer complaints.
