site_title: Hong Kong protest anger targets symbols of Beijing's rule
summary: Hong Kong's anti-government protests have shifted their focus from local leaders to symbols of Beijing's rule, with protesters targeting the city's Liaison Office and chanting slogans that echo a pro-independence activist's campaign. The protests, now in their seventh week, are fueled by frustration over Beijing's increased footprint in the city, including the influx of mainlanders and the erosion of cultural identity. Many young protesters feel colonized by Beijing, and tensions are deepening with the city's leadership and mainlanders.

site_title: 8 killed in quake, aftershocks in Philippines, 60 injured
summary: An earthquake and aftershocks struck the Batanes islands in the Philippines, killing eight people and injuring 60. A magnitude 5.4 quake was followed by two aftershocks, one of 5.9 magnitude, causing damage to traditional stone homes and new constructions. The national disaster agency is sending medical and rescue teams to the affected area, while the military is deploying an aircraft to send supplies and evacuate injured people. The Philippines is prone to frequent earthquakes due to its location on the Pacific Ring of Fire.

site_title: Hong Kong police fire tear gas at protesters in residential area
summary: Hong Kong police clashed with protesters in the residential area of Sai Ying Pun, firing tear gas after demonstrators vandalized the Chinese government's liaison office. Thousands marched through the city, chanting slogans and calling for universal suffrage and the resignation of Chief Executive Carrie Lam. The unrest, which began over a bill allowing extradition to the mainland, has put pressure on China to find a solution, with the city's reputation as a stable business environment taking a hit. The situation remains volatile, with police and protesters at odds over the use of force and the right to demonstrate.

site_title: Johnson forms 'war' Cabinet as no-deal prospect rises: Times
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson formed a "war Cabinet" of six senior ministers to prepare for a no-deal Brexit on October 31, amid rising concerns of a potential exit without an agreement. Johnson's most senior aide, Dominic Cummings, stated that Brexit will happen "by any means necessary," and the government is preparing to suspend Parliament or hold an election to block a no-deal Brexit. The government is also adding extra border control forces and launching a large public information campaign to prepare for departure from the EU.

site_title: China's industrial profits fall in June, add to fears of slowdown
summary: China's industrial profits declined 3.1% in June from a year earlier, adding to concerns about a manufacturing slowdown due to the trade war. The second-quarter economic growth slowed to a near 30-year low. Profits in the auto, oil processing, and steel sectors declined, while the construction material and machinery industries helped cushion the fall. The data also showed a 2.4% drop in first-half profits and a rise in liabilities, highlighting the economic challenges facing the country. US-China trade talks are set to resume on Tuesday, amid worries about deflation and potential stimulus measures.

site_title: Mexican government unveils winners for new oil refinery work
summary: Mexico's government has unveiled the winners of contracts to build and develop a new oil refinery in Dos Bocas, a southern port, with a total value of $8 billion. The refinery, set to be completed by 2022, will process 340,000 barrels per day of Maya heavy crude. Samsung Engineering and KBR won two blocks of work, while Fluor Enterprises and ICA Fluor won a block for the coking plant. The project is part of President Lopez Obrador's plan to make Mexico more self-sufficient and wean it off gasoline imports, despite concerns from financial analysts that it may not be economically viable.

site_title: Atletico humble Real Madrid 7-3 in friendly
summary: Atletico Madrid humbled La Liga rivals Real Madrid 7-3 in a pre-season friendly at MetLife Stadium. Diego Costa scored four goals, including a hat-trick by halftime, before being sent off in the 63rd minute. The match saw several injuries, including Luka Jovic and Marco Asensio, and a testy shoving match that led to multiple red cards. Despite the loss, Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane acknowledged his team's poor performance and vowed to focus on what went wrong.

site_title: Apple will face tariffs on components imported from China: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that Apple will face tariffs on components imported from China, despite the company's request for exemptions. Trump urged Apple to shift production to the US, stating that the company will not receive tariff wavers for Mac Pro parts made in China. Apple CEO Tim Cook was praised by Trump, who expressed optimism that the company will announce plans to build a plant in Texas, potentially alleviating tensions.

site_title: T-Mobile-Sprint merger approved by US justice department, clearing major hurdle
summary: The US Justice Department has approved the merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, the third and fourth-largest wireless carriers in the US, clearing a major hurdle for the $26 billion deal. The merger, which would create a company with over 100 million customers, requires the approval of the FCC and has been supported by FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, who signaled his support after the companies committed to investing in rural broadband and 5G technology. However, the deal could still face opposition from several states and a lawsuit brought by attorneys general, who claim it could harm consumers by leaving them with higher cellphone bills.

site_title: US Democrat calls for 'good faith' talks with USTR on USMCA trade deal
summary: US Representative Richard Neal, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, called for "good faith" negotiations with the Trump administration on the US-Mexico-Canada trade agreement, which Democrats have concerns about. A working group of nine lawmakers met with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, making "substantial progress" and presenting proposals to address concerns over labor, environmental issues, and access to medicine. The deal must be ratified by lawmakers in all three countries, with Mexico already having ratified it. Officials say the deal could move forward in September after the August recess.

site_title: Private home prices up 1.5% in Q2; 2019 could end in positive territory

site_title: Why there are no quick fixes for blotchy skin

There are no quick fixes for melasma, as it is a chronic condition that requires ongoing management and treatment. Effective treatments include sun protection, topical creams or serums, and laser or light therapy, often in combination with other treatments. Regular follow-up with a doctor is crucial to produce sustained lightening effects and minimize recurrence of the condition.

images.alt_text: Patients with melasma on their cheeks. Optimal management of difficult cases usually includes combination therapy where a topical treatment inhibits melanin production while a laser procedure accelerates melanin removal.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters rally at airport to 'educate' visitors
summary: Hundreds of Hong Kong protesters, including flight attendants, held a rally at the city's airport to "educate" visitors about the ongoing protests. The rally aimed to counter mainland China's portrayal of the protests as violent and foreign-funded. Protesters displayed satirical safety announcements and "Tourist Warning" signs, highlighting police violence and pro-government attacks. The rally is part of efforts to keep up pressure on pro-Beijing leaders and push for democratic reforms.

site_title: What is left in the central bank toolbox
summary: Central banks have limited room to cut interest rates, particularly in economies with negative interest rates, as seen in the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan. To support employment and inflation, central banks may turn to unconventional policy tools, such as quantitative easing (QE), which has been used in the past to lower rates to -5% in 2009. With interest rates already at record lows, central banks are exploring alternative options to stimulate the economy, including QE, to address the challenges posed by low growth and low inflation.

site_title: Gold loses some shine as investors await FOMC meeting
summary: Gold prices eased off gains amid strong US jobs data and profit-booking before the July 30-31 FOMC meeting. Smaller rate cut expectations boosted the US dollar, while investors await a potential 25bps rate reduction. Global PMIs and US trade policies remain supportive of safe haven assets. Key technical levels include US$1,400.00 (support) and US$1,452.00 (month-highs), with potential resistance at US$1,482.00. Investors expect a dovish pivot by global central banks and a potential rally in gold prices ahead of the FOMC meeting.

site_title: Japan police raid arson suspect's residence
summary: Japanese police raided the residence of Shinji Aoba, the main suspect in a deadly arson attack that killed 34 people at an anime firm in Kyoto on July 18. Aoba, who is in serious condition with burns, claimed the company stole an idea from his novel, but no link has been found. The case is being treated as arson and murder, with police searching for clues on the motive and method of the crime. Most of the victims were employees of the anime studio, with people continuing to lay flowers and offer prayers at the scene.

images.alt_text: Japanese police on Friday raided the home of the main suspect in a deadly arson attack that killed 34 people at an anime firm in Kyoto, media reports said.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks finish week lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished lower on Friday, erasing the week's gains, after US equities slipped overnight on disappointing earnings reports. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.69% to 28,397.74, down 0.30% for the week. This comes after a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a rise in Asian shares, despite new US trade threats.

site_title: Singapore shares drop on Friday, down 0.4% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,363.76, down 0.5% from Thursday's close, resulting in a 0.4% weekly loss. The drop followed the European Central Bank's decision to keep interest rates unchanged and a mixed earnings session on Wall Street. Asian markets, except China's Shanghai Composite Index, experienced broad losses on Friday.

site_title: Reits (July 27-28, 2019)
summary: REITs experienced fluctuations in July 2019, with US mortgage rates climbing after five straight weeks of declines. The Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record, with further increases predicted. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and New World sold China property assets following a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy.

site_title: Two institutes start course to help SMEs go global
summary: Singapore's International Trading Institute at Singapore Management University (ITI@SMU) and Ngee Ann Polytechnic launched the Internationalisation Skills (iSkills) Talent Development Programme to help SMEs grow globally. The 6-month course costs S$7,900 to S$16,000 and offers grants. The program aims to equip employees with key skills needed for international expansion, enabling SMEs to tap into new markets and increase their global presence.

site_title: Emerging-market assets fall after ECB fails to act
summary: Emerging-market assets declined on Friday, ending the week lower, following ECB chief Mario Draghi's toned-down expectations of aggressive monetary-policy easing. The ECB held interest rates steady, but Draghi's upbeat comments on the global economy disappointed investors. Emerging-market currencies fell, with the South African rand down 0.6%, while Turkey's lira rose 0.3% following a rate cut. The focus now shifts to the US Federal Reserve's meeting next week, expected to cut interest rates by at least a quarter of a point.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q2 DPU falls 4.6% as Suntec S'pore revenue drops 17%
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 4.6% drop in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.361 Singapore cents for Q2, down from 2.474 cents in the same period last year. Net property income (NPI) fell 7.2% to S$56.4 million, primarily due to a sinking fund contribution for office upgrades. This had no impact on distributable income. The decline in revenue is attributed to a 17% drop in Suntec Singapore revenue.

site_title: Australian watchdog calls for controls on Facebook, Google
summary: Australia's competition watchdog recommended tighter controls on Facebook and Google, including measures to ease their dominance in online advertising and increase transparency. The watchdog's 23 recommendations include regulating personal data use and imposing sanctions for misuse. The Australian government will consider the report's findings and propose regulation by the end of the year. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg welcomed the report, stating that the companies need to be held accountable for their activities and that the world has never seen such large amounts of personal data collected by just two companies.

site_title: After Mueller show, Democrats likely no closer to impeachment
summary: Former special counsel Robert Mueller's testimony to Congress has not moved Democrats closer to impeaching President Donald Trump, despite the damning evidence presented. Mueller's flat answers and refusal to provide new information have dashed hopes of a viral moment or bombshell soundbites. Democrats now acknowledge that the 2020 election is the best way to remove Trump from office, with House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff stating that impeachment is "unquestionably the only way he gets removed."

site_title: Swiber asks again for more time to propose a return to trading
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore and marine group, has applied for a third extension to propose a return to trading, pushing the deadline to December 31. The company, under judicial management, is awaiting certainty on a US$200 million bailout injection and a related power project in Vietnam. A restructuring deal with creditors, which included a May vote, must also be finalized. Trading in Swiber shares has been suspended since 2016. The company is seeking clarification from the Singapore Exchange on "certain issues" before assessing the impact of the planned deals and restructuring.

site_title: Alibaba unveils first chip as China eyes tech dominance
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has unveiled its first chip, the Xuantie 910 processor, which uses an open-source design called RISC-V. The move is part of China's efforts to reduce its dependence on foreign chips and compete with global tech giants. Alibaba's chip-making subsidiary, T-head or Pingtouge, is backed by the company's expansion into artificial intelligence and IoT technology. The new processor supports connected devices and AI applications, and Alibaba may license it to generate revenue. China's chip industry is gaining momentum, with Huawei and other companies also developing alternatives to foreign software and hardware.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q1 net profit up 2.7% to S$41.6m on lower expenses
summary: SIA Engineering Group reported a 2.7% increase in Q1 net profit to S$41.6m, driven by higher operating profit and lower expenses. Revenue remained flat at S$258.1m. Operating profit rose 74% to S$18m, with a 3% reduction in expenditure. The company attributed the improvement to transformation initiatives and technology adoption. Despite the positive results, the operating environment remains challenging, and no dividend was recommended.

site_title: Lime drops Singapore sandbox licence as it 're-prioritises' growth plans
summary: Lime, a US-based e-scooter and e-bike rental firm, has withdrawn its application for a sandbox licence to operate in Singapore, citing a "re-prioritisation" of growth plans. Despite maintaining its corporate team in Singapore, the move comes after the Land Transport Authority (LTA) pushed back its decision to issue PMD-sharing licenses until the third quarter, citing safety concerns. Lime's Asia-Pacific footprint spans Australia, New Zealand, and Singapore, and the company has expressed its commitment to the region, but no plans for the Singapore outpost have been disclosed.

site_title: European stocks steady at open
summary: European stocks remained steady at the start of trade on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% at 7,503.82 points. In the eurozone, Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also added 0.2% and remained flat, respectively. The steady market trend is attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks are also under focus.

site_title: UIC Q2 net profit soars 268% to S$409.3m on fair-value gains
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) reported a net profit of S$409.3 million in Q2 2019, a 268% increase from the same period last year, driven by a S$135 million fair-value gain on investment properties. Revenue rose 20% to S$218.7 million, and property trading revenue increased 27%. Earnings per share (EPS) excluding fair-value gains was 18.5 Singapore cents, up from 4.3 Singapore cents last year. UIC shares rose 0.68% to close at S$2.95.

site_title: Tritech snags new investors for loss-making China unit in 42.3m yuan deal
summary: Tritech Group has secured a 42.3 million yuan (S$8.39 million) deal with new investors Qingdao Ocean Group and Rongtai Construction to sell its loss-making Tritech Environmental arm and four China-based subsidiaries. The deal involves a 40% stake for Qingdao Ocean Group and 20% for Rongtai Construction. The sale is expected to improve Tritech's financial position, with the proceeds representing an unlocking of the investment in the water and environmental business. The plan is to transform Tritech Environmental into a leading water treatment player in China within three to five years.

site_title: FLT raises Q3 DPU by 3.4% to 1.82 Australian cents
summary: FRASERS Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported a 3.4% year-on-year increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.82 Australian cents. Net property income rose 24.4% to A$48.9 million, while revenue increased 21.6% to A$60 million. FLT's 81 properties have a weighted average lease expiry of 6.27 years and occupancy of 99.5% as of end-June. The trust's gearing stood at 35.4%. FLT plans to acquire 12 freehold logistics assets in Germany and Australia.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower as Draghi remarks dim rate-cut hopes
summary: South Korean stocks declined on Friday as European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi's remarks dampened expectations of interest rate cuts by major central banks. The KOSPI index fell 0.40% to 2,066.26 points, while the Korean won and benchmark bond yield also dropped. Draghi signaled the ECB's intention to explore monetary easing but left interest rates unchanged, and expressed a more upbeat view of the economy than expected. The won and bond yield declined, while foreign investors bought 58.3 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Fortune Reit H1 DPU dips 0.8% to 26.13 HK cents
summary: Fortune Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported a 0.8% drop in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 26.13 Hong Kong cents, attributed to a 0.4% decline in revenue due to the sale of a mall and renovation works. Net property income remained flat year-over-year, while distributable income increased 0.1%. Occupancy rose to 97.4% and gearing decreased to 20.5%. Despite economic slowdowns, the manager expects Fortune Malls to be resilient due to non-discretionary spending.

site_title: Rich Capital asks for AGM extension on Batam project woes
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Catalist-listed real estate firm, has asked the Singapore Exchange to extend its annual general meeting (AGM) deadline to October 31 due to a dispute with its Indonesian joint-venture partner. The company must hold its AGM by July 31, but the extension is needed to resolve the issue. The board cited the ongoing dispute as the reason for the delay.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares slip as ECB puts off rate cut
summary: Australian shares declined 0.4% on Friday due to financials and tech stocks, following the European Central Bank's decision to hold interest rates steady. The focus shifts to the US Federal Reserve's rate decision on July 30-31, with investors concerned about a potential cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,793.40, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.83%. Mining stocks rose, led by BHP Group and Rio Tinto, despite a weak week for the sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's industrial output shrank 6.9% in June, marking the fourth straight month of decline. The unemployment rate for Singaporeans edged up to 3.3% in Q2, amid trade tensions and global uncertainties. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% on Friday, closing at 3,363.76. The European Central Bank unexpectedly kept interest rates unchanged, dampening sentiment. The general offer to privatise Raffles United was deemed "not fair and not reasonable" by the independent financial adviser.

site_title: Singapore hotel room rates to rise by 2% in 2020: report
summary: Singapore hotel room rates are expected to rise by 2% in 2020, driven by significant investments in the travel market, including the expansion of Changi Airport and Resorts World Sentosa. This increase is forecasted to offset a decline in international visitors due to a less optimistic global economic outlook. Other markets in the Asia-Pacific, such as Bangalore and Tokyo, are also expected to see significant increases in hotel room rates. Despite global economic challenges, the number of people traveling for business and leisure continues to grow.

site_title: Offer for Raffles United 'not fair and not reasonable': IFA
summary: The independent financial adviser for Raffles United's independent directors has stated that the offer to privatise the company is "not fair and not reasonable". Despite this, Raffles United has fallen below 10% ownership control, with offeror Raffles Infinity taking control of 91.16% of shares. The IFA's comments come after the offeror had already gained significant control of the company.

site_title: Two Hong Kong police officers cleared in 2014 beating of protester
summary: Hong Kong's appeal court overturned the conviction of two police officers and reduced the sentence of five others over the 2014 beating of a pro-democracy protester, Ken Tsang. The ruling comes amid intense public anger towards the police force over its handling of recent protests. The two officers were cleared due to a lack of identification in video footage, while the other five received reduced sentences ranging from 15 to 18 months, with one sentence deemed "manifestly excessive". The verdict is seen as a blow to the police force's reputation.

site_title: Bets off for Macau gaming stocks as VIPs feel trade war crunch
summary: Macau gaming stocks are experiencing a downturn due to the ongoing US-China trade war's impact on China's high rollers, a key source of revenue for the region. Despite record foot traffic, gaming revenue has slumped, and shares have fallen. Las Vegas Sands Corp and SJM Holdings Ltd have seen their shares decline after reporting disappointing results. The industry group has seen a 15% gain in the UBS Macau Gaming Basket, but the odds are now stacked against Macau's gaming stocks.

site_title: Singapore private home prices up 1.5% in Q2; rents rise 1.3%: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 1.5% in Q2, driven by non-landed properties in the core central region and rest of the central region. Rents increased 1.3% and vacancy rates edged up to 6.4%. The increase is attributed to higher launch prices of new homes and interest from overseas buyers, particularly in the high-end segment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to profit-taking, ending a three-day winning streak. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.45% to 21,658.15, while the Topix index lost 0.40% to 1,571.52. This comes after US stocks retreated from record highs. The decline snapped a rally in regional markets, which had been driven by optimism over economic growth and trade talks.

site_title: Nearly 30% more HDB resale flats sold in Q2 as prices dip for 4th straight quarter
summary: The number of Housing Board (HDB) resale flats sold in Q2 2019 increased by nearly 30% compared to the same period last year, with 6,276 transactions recorded. This is the first increase in sales volume since July 2018, attributed to policy changes allowing buyers to use their Central Provident Fund (CPF) and get bigger housing loans. Resale prices also dipped 0.2% for the fourth consecutive quarter, with the highest median price for a five-room flat in Toa Payoh at S$839,000.

images.alt_text: The number of Housing Board (HDB) resale flats that changed hands in the second quarter of 2019 grew nearly 30 per cent as compared with the first three months of the year, latest public housing figures show.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, snapping a three-day winning streak, due to profit-taking. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.25% to 21,703.11 and the Topix index dropped 0.28% to 1,573.40. The decline follows US stocks retreating from record highs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 8.62 points to 1,647.96. The index saw 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with 511 losers outnumbering 369 gainers.

site_title: Delong Q2 net profit slides 38% despite higher hot rolled coil sales
summary: Delong, a mainboard-listed steelmaker, reported a 38.1% decline in net profit to 299.6 million yuan (S$59.6 million) for the second quarter, despite higher hot rolled coil sales. Revenue fell 8.1% year-on-year, while administrative expenses increased 29.7% and finance costs more than doubled. The company attributed a delay in its Indonesian steel project to a shortage of skilled labor and construction disruptions. Net asset value per share decreased to 59.27 yuan, while no dividend was recommended for the period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.66% and the Shanghai Composite Index 0.32% lower. The decline followed US equities' overnight drop due to disappointing earnings reports. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.30%. The decline is attributed to US market uncertainty, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Epicentre to dismiss uncontactable chairman, conduct investigative audit
summary: Epicentre Holdings plans to terminate the employment of its uncontactable chairman, Kenneth Lim Tiong Hian, and engage an audit firm to investigate past transactions involving him and his associates. The company also plans to implement "hard measures on spending" and make two police reports on loan agreements with two creditors. The audit will review the validity of each claim or debt and report directly to the Singapore Exchange Regulation. Trading in Epicentre's shares has been suspended since May 30.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,354.07, down 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 3,354.07 on Friday, tracking Asia market declines due to bearish outlook on Fed rate cut hopes. Losers outnumbered gainers 183 to 128, with banks, real estate, and technology stocks among the weakest performers. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with Singtel's ex-dividend also contributing to the drop.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares retreat as ECB holds rates steady
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Friday, wiping out three consecutive gains, as investors reacted to the European Central Bank's decision to hold interest rates steady until September. Tech stocks and financials led the decline, with the financials sub-index losing 0.6%. The focus now shifts to the US Federal Reserve's policy committee meeting next week, with expectations of a rate cut.

site_title: Modest rate rises for Asean hotels in 2020: report
summary: Hotel room rates in key Asean cities are expected to rise by 2% in 2020, according to the Hotel Monitor report by American Express Global Business Travel. The cities of Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, Kuala Lumpur, and Singapore are predicted to see this modest increase, comparable to some other Asia-Pacific cities. Despite rapid growth in hotel capacity, sustained demand in these economies means rates will rise. Thailand expects a record 41.1 million visitors in 2019, while Vietnam and Malaysia are expected to maintain solid occupancy levels and room rates in 2020.

images.alt_text: Resorts World Sentosa, an integrated resort in Singapore.

site_title: China accuses FedEx of 'holding up' Huawei parcels
summary: China accused FedEx of "holding up" the delivery of over 100 Huawei packages, contradicting FedEx's claim of misrouting a "small number" of packages. A Chinese government probe found FedEx had also violated regulations. This incident comes amid a trade war between China and the US, with China threatening to create its own blacklist of "unreliable" companies and individuals. The US and Chinese officials will resume trade talks next week in Shanghai.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.84 points to 1,653.74. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 41.29 million lots traded worth RM45.78 million. Losers outperformed gainers 85 to 75.

site_title: SoftBank announces US$108b Vision Fund 2
summary: SoftBank has announced its second Vision Fund, aiming to raise a total of $108 billion with a $38 billion initial commitment from the company. The fund, set to be launched every two to three years, will focus on cutting-edge technologies like AI and autonomous driving. Apple, Microsoft, and Japanese finance companies are expected to contribute capital. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son plans to maintain his leading role as a technology investor, following the success of the first $100 billion fund, which has earned 62% returns after 71 investments.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for airport protests as countries including Singapore issue travel advisories
summary: Hong Kong is bracing for a demonstration at its airport, with protesters planning to gather at the arrival hall to reach foreigners visiting the city. Countries including Singapore have issued travel advisories, citing the potential for protests to turn violent. The demonstrations have escalated into violence in recent rallies, with clashes between protesters and police, and vandalism of Beijing's liaison office. Police have not given approval for the airport gathering, and organizers are considering alternative actions to circumvent police rules.

images.alt_text: In a bid to find new ways to spread their message, protesters are planning to gather at the arrival hall of Hong Kong International Airport in Lantau to reach foreigners visiting the city.

site_title: Mercurius starts PE fund for Indochina resort, leisure property investments
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment, a Catalist-listed firm, will launch a private equity fund focused on resort and leisure property investments in the Indochina region. The fund, to be led by Richard Tan Liat Chew, aims to capitalize on Thailand investment opportunities with Apex Development, a Thailand-listed real estate developer. This move comes after a joint-venture agreement between the two firms was updated on June 12.

site_title: Alibaba unveils its first chip as China pushes for independence
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has developed its first microchip, the Xuantie 910 processor, based on an open-source RISC-V design. This move comes as China pushes for independence in technology, particularly in semiconductors, amid trade tensions with the US. Alibaba's chip-making subsidiary, T-head or Pingtouge, may generate a new revenue stream and bolster its cloud services division. The company joins other Chinese corporations, such as Huawei, in reducing dependence on foreign chips, which China imports roughly three times more than it produces domestically.

site_title: Sino Grandness gets further 2-week extension to hold AGM, release Q1 results
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry, a Singapore-listed canned fruits and vegetables producer, has extended its annual general meeting (AGM) and first-quarter financial results release by two weeks. The AGM is now set for August 8, and Q1 results will be released by August 29. This follows a previous extension granted by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company had initially planned to hold the AGM and release Q1 results by July 24.

site_title: Singapore retail rents ease 1.5% q-o-q in Q2, vacancy rate drops to 7.7%: URA
summary: Singapore retail rents eased 1.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q2, with a vacancy rate of 7.7% at the end of the quarter, down from 8.7% in Q1. The URA reported a total supply of 320,000 square meters of retail space, while occupied space increased by 74,000 square meters in net lettable area. This led to a decline in the retail space stock and a decrease in vacancy rates.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble after disappointing US earnings
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday after disappointing US earnings and a bearish outlook on a potential Fed rate cut. Tesla and American Airlines suffered declines, while Amazon reported slower earnings growth. Investors are now wary of a less dovish Fed announcement, despite strong economic data. The Tokyo stock market dropped 0.5%, while Hong Kong and Shanghai fell 0.5% and 0.2%, respectively. The euro hit two-year lows before rallying after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust adds potential incremental rent in master lease agreements
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has amended its master lease agreements, adding a potential incremental rent stream to the real estate investment trust (Reit). Under the changes, the Reit will receive rental payments with a variable rent component tied to gross operating revenue and profit. This provides upside growth exposure and an additional rent stream from lessees in higher profit margin scenarios. The amendment has received unanimous approval from independent directors and does not prejudice stapled security holders. The trust's initial public offering (IPO) projections remain unchanged.

site_title: Japan could rule to remove South Korea from white list trade status as early as Aug 2: Kyodo
summary: Japan is preparing to remove South Korea from the white list status with minimum trade restrictions as early as August 2, according to a Kyodo news agency report. This move comes after Japan tightened curbs on exports to South Korea of high-tech materials. The removal would take effect 21 days after the announcement, and South Korea has protested the plan, saying it would undermine economic and security cooperation. Currently, 27 countries are on Japan's white list, including Germany, Britain, and the US.

site_title: Singapore factory output shrinks 6.9% in June, falling for 4th straight month
summary: Singapore's industrial output declined 6.9% in June, marking the fourth consecutive month of year-on-year decline. The biomedical manufacturing sector cushioned the fall, with overall manufacturing output rising 1.2% month-over-month. The electronics sector, once a driver of growth, saw output plummet 18.8% in June. General manufacturing and biomedical manufacturing posted the strongest performances, with general manufacturing output rising 10.8% and biomedical manufacturing output up 5%. Economists expect a slight upward revision in second-quarter GDP growth and a potential technical recession in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Singapore's industrial output fell 6.9 per cent in June, deepening from May's 2 per cent fall and marking the fourth straight month of year-on-year decline, according to preliminary estimates from the Singapore Economic Development Board on Friday.

site_title: Google, Alphabet sees fresh growth amid antitrust woes
summary: Google parent Alphabet reported stronger-than-expected quarterly results, with profits tripling to $9.9 billion and revenues increasing 19% to $38.9 billion. The company's stock price surged 9% in after-hours trade, easing concerns about slowing growth. Alphabet's strong results come as it faces antitrust scrutiny in the US, where regulators are reviewing online platforms over competition concerns. CEO Sundar Pichai acknowledged the scrutiny but expressed confidence in addressing concerns and engaging constructively.

site_title: Credit Suisse appoints Deutsche Bank banker as new Australia head
summary: Credit Suisse appointed Richard Gibb, head of corporate finance in Asia Pacific at Deutsche Bank, as the new head of its Australian operations, effective October. Gibb's departure from Deutsche Bank comes amid a global restructuring that will reduce headcount by 18,000. He will lead the Swiss bank's business in Australia, including investment banking, capital markets, and private banking.

site_title: Jobless rate for Singaporeans edges up to 3.3% in Q2 with employers more cautious in hiring
summary: Singapore's jobless rate for Singaporeans rose to 3.3% in Q2, up from 3.2% in March, amid trade tensions and global uncertainties. Employment growth slowed, with total employment growing by 4,000, lower than the previous quarter. Retrenchments dipped to 2,300, down from 3,230 in the previous quarter. Employers are exercising caution in hiring, instead focusing on retaining existing workers. The overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 2.2%.

site_title: Gunmen steal 750kg of precious metals from Brazil airport
summary: Gunmen impersonating federal police stole nearly a ton of precious metals, including gold, from Sao Paulo's Guarulhos International Airport in Brazil. The thieves, who drove vehicles resembling federal police cars, made off with 750kg of metals en route to New York and Zurich without firing shots. The incident is under investigation.

site_title: Singapore office rents rise 1.3% q-o-q in Q2; vacancy rates fall to 11.5%: URA
summary: Singapore office rents rose 1.3% in Q2 compared to the previous quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This follows a 0.6% drop in Q1. The vacancy rate fell to 11.5% as of Q2. The total supply of office space in the pipeline remained steady at 732,000 square meters. The URA's office space price index increased 0.9% in Q2, slower than the 3.0% gain in the previous quarter.

site_title: Britons care more about climate change than Brexit, survey shows
summary: A majority of British adults, seven in 10, believe climate change will be a more important issue than Brexit in the future, according to a survey commissioned by Christian Aid. Two-thirds of respondents think Prime Minister Boris Johnson should prioritize climate change, with experts warning of the devastating effects of the climate emergency. The survey comes as the UK experiences a heatwave, highlighting the growing concern about climate change among Britons.

site_title: Climate records fall as Europe bakes in heatwave
summary: A severe heatwave gripped Europe, breaking records in Germany, France, Britain, and the Netherlands. Temperatures soared to 41.5°C in Germany, 42.6°C in Paris, and 38.1°C in Britain, with the southern Netherlands reaching 40.4°C. Climate specialists attributed the heatwaves to global warming, citing increased frequency and intensity due to greenhouse gas emissions. The heatwave led to disruptions in nuclear power, rail travel, and air conditioning usage, with health authorities warning vulnerable populations.

site_title: Funny People
summary: Singapore's only full-time female standup comedian, Sharul Channa, is hosting "Fresh + Raw," a showcase featuring standup wannabes she has been training. The event, part of TheatreWorks N.O.W. miniarts festival, will take place on July 26 and 27 at 10pm. The debutants will perform live in front of an audience, with Sharul hosting and providing feedback. The event aims to discover fresh and authentic comedy in Singapore. Tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: Mattel reports smaller loss on higher 'Barbie,' 'Toy Story 4' sales
summary: Mattel reported a smaller loss of $108 million in the second quarter, compared to a $240.9 million loss in the same period last year, due to sales growth in key franchises such as Barbie and Toy Story 4. Revenues rose 2% to $860.1 million, boosted by action figures and games linked to Toy Story 4. However, sales declined in certain divisions, including American Girl and Fisher-Price, due to a recall. Mattel aims to restore profitability and regain topline growth through a multi-year turnaround strategy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, MCT, Suntec Reit, Ascendas-iTrust, Sabana Reit, SingHaiyi
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments Friday, with several companies reporting key earnings updates. ST Engineering secured new contracts worth S$1.5 billion, while Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a 3.6% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit. However, Suntec Reit and Sabana Reit faced challenges, with Suntec Reit's DPU dropping 4.6% and Sabana Reit's DPU shrinking to 0.62 cents. Meanwhile, SingHaiyi Group reported a net loss of S$8.2 million, while Ascendas-iTrust posted a 28% jump in DPU.

site_title: Southwest won't fly 737 Max until 2020 as grounding hits airline earnings
summary: Southwest Airlines has abandoned its goal of flying the 737 Max aircraft until 2020 due to the ongoing grounding, which has impacted earnings. The airline's quarterly profits rose, but it took a $175 million hit from the crisis. American Airlines reported a 1.8% profit increase, despite a $400 million hit from the Max crisis. Both airlines expect to resume flights on the Max in 2020, with Southwest planning to resume flights on January 5 and American anticipating a November 2 return.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q2 DPU falls 4.6% to 2.361 S cents on lower convention revenue
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 4.6% drop in DPU to 2.361 S cents for Q2, down from 2.474 cents last year, due to lower convention revenue. Net property income decreased 7.2% to S$56.4 million, primarily due to a S$3.2 million sinking fund contribution. Gross revenue fell 2.3% to S$88.4 million, mainly due to a S$3.9 million drop in revenue from Suntec Singapore.

site_title: China, HK developers temper their bids in Singapore land tenders
summary: China and Hong Kong developers have tempered their bids in Singapore land tenders amid cooling measures and significant landbanks built up from en bloc deals. Despite remaining active players, they have had little success in state and private housing site tenders since the first half of last year. This shift is attributed to government efforts to curb property prices and control speculation.

site_title: Amazon pays a price for one-day delivery as profit growth slows
summary: Amazon reported profits below expectations, edging up 3.6% to $2.6 billion in the past quarter, amid investments in one-day delivery, which saw revenues rise 20% to $63.4 billion. Analysts attribute the costs to erosion of profits, citing competition from retailers like Walmart and Target. Despite this, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos said the move to one-day delivery is a necessary strategy to compete with brick-and-mortar stores. The company's cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services, saw revenue gains of 37%.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records, Tesla dives
summary: US stocks retreated from records on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dropping 0.5% each. Tesla's stock plummeted 13.6% after disappointing earnings, while American Airlines fell 8.4% after raising its Boeing 737 Max-related earnings estimate. Strong economic data may lead to a less dovish Federal Reserve announcement, causing investors to reassess their expectations. The Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 1.0% to its lowest level since July 11.

site_title: North Korea missiles launched under guidance of leader Kim: state media
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised the launch of two short-range missiles into the sea, described as a "solemn warning" to South Korean military officials. This was Pyongyang's first missile test since a meeting with US President Donald Trump last month. The launch was seen as a demonstration of the country's military capabilities. The test was conducted under Kim's "personal guidance," according to state news wire KCNA. The incident raised concerns about the region's stability and potential for escalation.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised the launch of "a new-type of tactical guided weapon" as a "solemn warning to South Korean military warmongers," state news wire KCNA said on Friday.

site_title: ECB puts inflation target in focus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced that its inflation target should not be viewed as a 2% cap, instead focusing on a "commitment to symmetry in the inflation aim." This move comes as the ECB struggles to address low inflation and a manufacturing recession in the eurozone. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that rates may be at present or lower levels until mid-2020, and the bank is considering restarting asset purchases to stimulate the economy. The decision aims to boost confidence and prop up the struggling economy.

site_title: Arsenal stars targeted by 'knife-wielding car-jackers'
summary: Arsenal footballers Sead Kolasinac and Mesut Ozil were targeted by knife-wielding car-jackers in north London. The attackers, on mopeds, brandished knives at Kolasinac, but he fought them off, and both players escaped unharmed. Police responded to reports of an attempted robbery and are investigating. No arrests have been made, and enquiries continue. This incident marks the latest in a series of attacks on footballers in London, following a similar incident in 2016 targeting former West Ham player Andy Carroll.

images.alt_text: Arsenal footballers Sead Kolasinac and Mesut Ozil fought off knife-wielding car-jackers in a terrifying ordeal in north London which was captured on video and circulated on social media.

site_title: Fund managers offload to retail investors in China's STAR Market
summary: Fund managers in China's STAR Market are offloading their holdings to retail investors, locking in profits amid volatile trade. The market, which debuted last week, has seen shares surge 520% due to frothy valuations and speculative investor community. Retail investors accounted for 90% of transactions, while institutional investors sold the majority of shares. Short-selling transactions dominate margin buying, with borrowing costs rising by 20% due to limited supply. Experts warn of a potential sharp selloff, but analysts see the market's volatility as a step towards long-term liberalization of China's stock markets.

site_title: Cloudstreet serves up a cloud of magic
summary: Cloudstreet, a new eatery in Singapore, offers accessible fine dining with a dream-like atmosphere inspired by chef Rishi Naleendra's imagination. The restaurant, named after an Australian novel, features whimsical and dark designs, including artwork, old-world furniture, and dramatic sketches. Naleendra's seven-course degustation menu combines his Sri Lankan heritage with modern Aussie flavors, with dishes such as Coffin Bay oyster with betel leaf and binchotan, and roasted baby lamb with Sri Lankan jackfruit curry. The restaurant's cooking engages on a personal level, with a sophisticated execution, and offers a unique dining experience.

site_title: Europe: Shares sink as Draghi disappoints rate-cut bulls
summary: European shares plummeted 0.5% on Thursday after the European Central Bank signaled monetary policy easing but failed to provide clarity on interest rate cuts. ECB chief Mario Draghi stated that the risk of a recession in the euro zone is "pretty low," and policymakers would wait for more data before taking action. Despite initial gains, investors were disappointed by the lack of concrete steps, leading to a decline in stocks, particularly in Germany, where shares fell 1.3%.

site_title: HK home prices weaken briefly after protests
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is expected to experience a short-term impact from recent protests, with prices forecast to fall 4% in the second half and rise 6% for the full year. Realtors attribute this to pent-up demand and a shortage of land, rather than the protests themselves. Despite a decline in tourism, housing prices are expected to continue rising, driven by expectations of lower interest rates and solid sales volumes for small to medium-sized properties. Overall, the protests are seen as having little impact on the property market.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday's open tracking Wall St retreat; STI down 0.62% to 3,360.22
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.62% to 3,360.22 points at the start of Friday, following a retreat in Wall Street shares amid the corporate earnings season. Losers outpaced gainers 73 to 59, with AEM gaining 2.63% and Golden Agri-Resources tumbling 3.23%. Suntec Reit and Sabana Reit also fell due to lower distribution per unit and second-quarter results. The decline came after Wall Street shares retreated from record highs in the US, with investors awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: Apple takes majority stake in Intel modem unit
summary: Apple agreed to pay $1 billion to acquire Intel's majority stake in its smartphone modem business, gaining more control over its supply chain. The deal will see 2,200 Intel employees join Apple and acquire intellectual property, equipment, and leases. The move aims to expedite Apple's development of future products and differentiate its offerings. Intel will focus on 5G network technology, retaining critical intellectual property and modem technology. This deal follows Apple's investments in its own mobile chips to reduce dependence on sector leader Qualcomm.

images.alt_text: Apple agreed Thursday to pay US$1 billion to acquire the majority of Intel's smartphone modem business, a move giving the iPhone maker more control over its supply chain.

site_title: Oil climbs on Iran tensions, US inventory decline
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by tensions between the West and Iran, a decline in US crude stockpiles, and a meeting between the US, Britain, and other nations to discuss protecting shipping in the Gulf. Brent crude futures rose 21 cents to $63.39 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 14 cents to $56.02 a barrel. The decline in US crude stocks, largely due to Tropical Storm Barry, also supported prices. However, lingering concerns about slowing economic growth limited gains, with global economic data weakness and the US-China trade war continuing to impact demand.

site_title: Home is where the cork is: UK designers present recyclable house
summary: A UK-based architecture firm has designed a 44-square-meter house made almost entirely of cork, which can be recycled at the end of its life. The house, called Cork House, features an open-plan living space and was assembled by hand using prefabricated cork blocks, engineered timber, and steel foundations. Built with cork's natural thermal properties in mind, the house remains warm and can be easily disassembled. The project aims to demonstrate sustainable architecture and has a "whole life carbon" of less than 15% of a standard British new-build house.

site_title: The slippery slope of good intentions
summary: A recent article discusses the concept of "doing well by doing good" and its potential pitfalls. Christiana Figueres, a climate change expert, argues that companies' good intentions can lead to a slippery slope, where the pursuit of profit compromises their values. The article highlights various business sections, including investing, finance, and lifestyle, but ultimately concludes that the phrase "doing well by doing good" can be misleading and may not always lead to positive outcomes.

site_title: Reformative Training
summary: Off Duty Pilates, a new Pilates studio, offers hybrid classes combining Reformer practice and TRX suspension training to achieve a strong and lean physique. The studio, led by co-founder Julie Jang, provides group classes with personal attention, ranging from basic to high-intensity sessions. A smaller studio with additional equipment, such as the Cadillac Trapeze Table, is reserved for private lessons. Off Duty Pilates is located at 5A, 6A Craig Road and can be found at offdutypilates.com.

site_title: InBev cheers profits as beer sales growth fizzes to five-year high
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev), the world's largest brewer, reported a 2.1% year-on-year increase in beer volumes in the April-June period, exceeding expectations. Revenue and profits rose due to price increases and consumers shifting to higher-priced beers. AB InBev's shares rose 4.3% after beating earnings expectations, with the company maintaining its full-year revenue and core profit growth estimates. Despite a 14% gain in the past week, shares are still 11% down year-on-year.

site_title: Why a 'no deal' Brexit remains very unlikely
summary: Boris Johnson's appointment as UK Prime Minister makes a "no deal" Brexit unlikely, according to experts. Johnson's leadership style and personal ambitions suggest an orderly Brexit with a transition period, rather than a sudden rupture. This could lead to economic activity comparable to the 2008 financial crisis, but a lengthy transition period would offset short-term damage, potentially leading to an economic resurgence in Britain and Europe. Johnson's cleverness and ability to mitigate risks make a "no deal" outcome less likely, with any Brexit outcome other than "no deal" now seen as a positive surprise.

site_title: Helping to start the day with breakfast
summary: Kellogg's is collaborating with the North East Community Development Council (CDC) in Singapore to provide over 48,000 serves of cereal to more than 500 children over a 12-month period. As part of its "Kellogg's Better Days" global commitment, the company aims to address hunger, food security, and climate change. The initiative, which focuses on nourishing people, feeding those in need, and promoting healthy eating habits, aims to create a healthier younger generation in Singapore. The partnership highlights Kellogg's commitment to philanthropy and conservation efforts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AIMS Apac Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.5 Singapore cents for its first quarter, unchanged from the previous year. Net property income grew 18.1% to S$22.9 million, driven by higher gross revenue and lower property operating expenses. Gross revenue rose 5.8% due to increased rental income from several properties. The company's adoption of FRS 116 contributed to the improved financial performance.

site_title: Sabana Reit cuts Q2 DPU by 24% as revenue, net property income fall
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 24.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for its second quarter, falling to 0.62 Singapore cents due to lower revenue and net property income. The Reit attributed the decline to a "challenging market" and lower occupancies at five properties. Despite this, the Reit secured three new leases and will begin an asset enhancement initiative at New Tech Park. DPU for the first half of the fiscal year fell 19.2% to 1.37 Singapore cents.

site_title: Britain's new PM sacks 17 ministers in 'night of the blonde knives'
summary: Britain's new Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, has sacked a record 17 ministers in a move dubbed "the night of the blonde knives" by the Sun. The cabinet includes several "remain" voters chosen to back Brexit by October 31, deal or no deal. The sacking has raised concerns about the UK's political temperature. Johnson's actions have also sparked speculation about his leadership and ability to manage the Brexit process. The move is seen as a significant shift in the UK's government, with many questioning the implications for the country's future.

site_title: US housing sector mired in weakness despite sales rebound
summary: US single-family home sales rebounded in June, but the market remains weak despite lower mortgage rates and a strong labour market. Sales for the prior three months were revised down, indicating a lack of momentum. The weak housing and manufacturing sectors are offsetting strong consumer spending, posing a threat to the longest US expansion in history.

site_title: Young Chefs
summary: Ding Dong, an Asian-centric eatery, is hosting a National Day collaboration dinner with ex-MasterChef Singapore finalists, featuring grown-up versions of childhood dishes. The dinner, on Aug 2-3, will be priced at S$100++. The chefs, Zander Ng, Genevieve Lee, and Aaron Wong, will present unique dishes such as a spicy mackerel paste, brined sous vide chicken, and crispy duck breast. The event is available for bookings at https://cho.pe/DingDongXMC.

site_title: A Home to Last a Lifetime
summary: A Singaporean couple, Remash and Raadthie Nair, transformed their 12-year-old corner terrace house in Upper Serangoon into a modern home with a seamless connection between the living room and car porch, glass barriers around the garden, and scratch-resistant flooring. The home was designed to be wheelchair-friendly, dog-friendly, and future-proof, with smart home features. The couple's vision was to create a space that would last a lifetime, with unique features such as a recessed copper-plated mosaic tile wall, a dry kitchen with outdoor terrace, and a spacious attic bedroom with a sitting area. The home, nicknamed "The Black Box House," was designed to be elegant and modern, with a focus on functionality and comfort.

site_title: ANZ faces suit over clients' fee levy case
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) filed a Federal Court civil action against ANZ Ltd, accusing the bank of knowingly breaking the law by charging customers fees to transfer money between accounts from 2003 to 2016. ASIC claims ANZ wrongfully took fees from over 440,000 retail customers and 18,000 business customers. The lawsuit seeks damages for the alleged fee levy.

site_title: The Rise of Co-Working
summary: Co-working spaces are expanding rapidly in Singapore, catering to a wider audience beyond tech start-ups. Major players like WeWork and Spaces are increasing their presence, with new locations and larger spaces. A survey by IWG found 83% of people prefer flexible working conditions, and 28% value work location over holiday allowance. New co-working spaces are emerging, offering tailored options for entrepreneurs, SMEs, and larger companies. Examples include GATHER, a feminine-designed space with private suites, and csuites, a corporate-focused space with natural light and real plants. Other spaces, like Trehaus and Core Collective, offer childcare services and wellness facilities, respectively. The rise of co-working is changing the work culture, with a focus on flexibility, work-life balance, and collaboration.

site_title: Clariant's JV talks with SABIC collapse
summary: Swiss chemicals maker Clariant has canceled joint venture talks with Saudi Basic Industries (SABIC) due to current market conditions. The talks, which aimed to combine Clariant's additives and specialty masterbatches businesses with SABIC's specialty chemicals operation, have been put on hold. Clariant will now sell its specialty masterbatches business and other assets on the auction block, with proceeds going towards technology investments and shareholder returns. Analysts believe SABIC may soon make a takeover offer for Clariant, following CEO Ernesto Occhiello's sudden resignation.

site_title: Business equipment orders jump by most since early 2018
summary: US business equipment orders jumped 1.9% in June, the largest gain in over a year, as corporate investment regained momentum despite tariffs and global weakness. This increase in non-military capital goods orders, excluding aircraft, suggests a strong job market, with filings for unemployment benefits at a three-month low. The data contradicts expectations and may indicate a boost to economic growth.

images.alt_text: A proxy for business investment, non-military capital goods orders excluding aircraft jumped 1.9 per cent in June after a downwardly revised 0.3 per cent increase in the prior month.

site_title: The Kleptocrats - The 1MDB Saga Retold
summary: A documentary, "The Kleptocrats," revisits the US$3.5 billion 1MDB scandal in Malaysia, exposing the corruption involving former Prime Minister Najib Razak and financier Jho Low. The film features interviews with journalists, witnesses, and those implicated, including celebrities Leonardo DiCaprio and Martin Scorsese, who were connected to the scandal through Red Granite Pictures. The documentary showcases the extravagance and deceit behind the scandal, using text messages, documents, and videos to build a case against the perpetrators. The film offers a detailed look at the rot of corruption that went deep into Malaysian society.

site_title: Royal Couple
summary: Ralph Fiennes and Sophie Okonedo won Best Actor and Best Actress awards for their roles in the 2018 UK National Theatre production of Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra, which will be screened at the Esplanade on July 27. The production, directed by Simon Godwin, is part of a series that also includes the 2018 production of King Lear starring Ian McKellen and the 2014 show War Horse. The screenings are scheduled for July 27 and 28.

images.alt_text: Antony and Cleopatra and War Horse.

site_title: Ditching minimum trading price fixes one flaw, but long tail still a problem
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering ending its minimum trading price (MTP) rule after three years, citing its ineffectiveness as a quality-control tool. The MTP, which requires mainboard-listed companies to maintain a share price of at least 20 cents and a market value of at least S$40 million, has been criticized for punishing companies with good governance and business fundamentals. Removing the rule would address the long tail of poorly traded, low-value counters but would leave the problem of vulnerability to market manipulation unresolved. SGX Regulation plans a public consultation on the matter.

site_title: HK residents scouting for properties in Canada and UK
summary: Hong Kong residents are seeking properties in Canada and the UK amid ongoing protests, with realtors reporting a surge in interest. The interest is driven by falling house prices in both countries, with Canadian and British house prices decreasing. This has attracted investors from Hong Kong, who are looking for alternative options. Realtors in Vancouver and the UK are fielding a high volume of inquiries from Chinese agents seeking to buy or rent properties in these countries.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips at open as corporate earnings point to slowing growth
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 22.58 points, or 0.08%, to 27,247.39, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping. The decline was attributed to earnings reports indicating a slowing global economy. However, the European Central Bank's hint at future interest rate cuts limited losses.

site_title: The Cut Of Excellence
summary: Larry Jewelry, a Hong Kong-based diamond manufacturer and distributor, has strengthened its 30-year partnership with LAZARE Diamonds. The exclusive distributor of LAZARE Diamonds in Singapore and Indonesia, Larry Jewelry has expanded its customer base across all ages, with younger shoppers drawn to the brand's quality and recognition. The partnership aims to educate consumers about the value of quality diamonds, amidst challenges such as synthetic diamonds and limited budgets for marketing. To celebrate the anniversary, an exclusive Signature Ring has been designed, featuring a 13.68-carat LAZARE Diamond.

site_title: Asia markets post mostly moderate gains
summary: Asia markets posted moderate gains on Thursday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rising 12.82 points or 0.4% to close at 3,381.26. The gains were driven by a US session where earnings beat consensus estimates and weak manufacturing figures from the eurozone, which sparked hopes of a rate cut by the European Central Bank. The rally also saw gains in other Asia-Pacific markets, while South Korea bucked the trend with a lower close.

site_title: Nissan's pain worsens amid 99% earnings plunge, 12,500 job cuts
summary: Nissan Motor Co. reported a 99% earnings plunge, with a 12,500 job cut globally, exceeding the initial 4,800 job losses announced in May. The company's production capacity will be reduced by 10% by the end of 2022, and its product lineup will be reduced by at least 10% to improve competitiveness. The drastic measures come as the company struggles with an ageing product lineup, declining US and European vehicle sales, and a slide in revenue, which fell 13% to 2.37 trillion yen.

site_title: As consumer sector heats up, telcos gear for fiercer fight for business clients
summary: Singapore's consumer mobile market is becoming increasingly crowded, with established network operators considering turning to enterprise-related mobile business to fend off competition from mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs). Grid Mobile, a new entrant backed by Singtel and ST Telemedia, has joined the fray, targeting the same millennial consumer market as StarHub's Giga sub-brand. The surge of MVNOs may make business mobile subscriptions a safer haven for telcos, with a two-year lock-in period offering low churn rates. Established telcos such as M1, Singtel, and StarHub also have business mobile plans, and may consider acquiring or poaching employees to retain business clients.

site_title: China is winning the ideological battle with the US
summary: China is outpacing the US in the ideological battle, according to a recent experience of the author in China. Chinese Communist Party leader Xi Jinping has slowed market reforms and increased state intervention in the economy, rendering the US-style capitalist model less appealing. Economic growth has slowed, but the Chinese system remains unique. The author notes that China is gaining intellectual influence among Chinese students and scholars who once admired the US democratic model. The US should renew its democracy and reengage in leading the liberal order abroad to regain the upper hand in the ideological struggle with China.

site_title: Ex-Prudential agency manager sues insurer's ex-CEO, two agents
summary: Ex-Prudential agency manager Tay Peck Gek sues the insurer for up to S$2.5 billion, alleging the company poached 244 agents and agency leaders to join Aviva Financial Advisers. Tay claims this amounts to a breach of contract. The lawsuit also targets two former Prudential executives, including the company's ex-CEO. The High Court will hear the case, with the outcome yet to be determined.

site_title: US economic growth seen stumbling as trade weighs on business
summary: US economic growth is expected to slow down in the second quarter, with a 1.8% annualized growth rate, the slowest since 2017. Trade tensions, particularly the US-China tariff war, are partly to blame, with business investment declining for the first time in three years. Despite this, consumer spending remained robust, growing at a 4% pace, and jobs and wages continued to rise. The Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates by a quarter point, but the GDP report will provide more detail on the state of the economy to inform its decision-making.

site_title: The Heart Of Kueh
summary: Chef Damian D'Silva is on a mission to educate Singaporeans about traditional Eurasian desserts, including bolu koku and blueda. Bolu koku is a sweet cake with a crispy exterior, fluffy interior, and grated coconut, brandy, and spices. D'Silva aims to showcase the diversity of Eurasian cuisine, which often gets overlooked in favor of more well-known desserts like sugee cakes. By sharing these lesser-known treats, D'Silva hopes to preserve and promote Singapore's rich cultural heritage.

site_title: HK names Eddie Yue as new HKMA chief
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), has appointed Eddie Yue as its new chief executive, succeeding Norman Chan in September. Yue, 54, will oversee the city's HK$4 trillion exchange fund and the peg to the US dollar, a key aspect of maintaining Hong Kong's economic stability. The appointment comes amid intense protests against a proposed extradition bill and trade tensions. Yue is seen as a steady change in management, and his experience will be crucial in defending the currency peg and formulating banking policies.

site_title: Grim political arithmetic for Johnson as UK's PM
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a grim internal and external political arithmetic, mirroring those of his predecessor Theresa May. Johnson's weak and uncertain government faces constraints similar to those that plagued May, with his personal and political frailties exposed. A no-deal Brexit, threatened by Johnson's optimism, may soon come unstuck, with leading EU figures welcoming the prospect of working with him but underlining the near-zero manoeuvring room for changing the exit deal. Johnson's government may face a vote of confidence, potentially leading to a general election, which could result in significant economic uncertainty.

site_title: Scandal-hit Future Land to sell project interests worth up to 15b yuan
summary: China's Future Land Development Holdings plans to sell equity interests in projects worth up to 15 billion yuan to enhance cash flow. The move comes after the detention and arrest of ex-chairman Wang Zhenhua for child molestation, which led to a decline in the company's shares. Seazen Holdings, a subsidiary of Future Land, has already sold interests in 10 projects for 4.15 billion yuan, representing 13.6% of its net assets in 2018. The sales are expected to increase cash flow, improve asset and liability structure, and strengthen debt repayment abilities.

site_title: Euro at 2-month low as investors wait for ECB easing
summary: The euro fell to a two-month low against the US dollar, trading at $1.1128, as investors awaited the European Central Bank's rate decision. The decline was driven by a weaker-than-expected German Ifo index and expectations of possible monetary easing. Money markets price in a 50% chance of a 10 basis point interest rate cut, but analysts differ on the ECB's dovishness, with some expecting a rate cut in September. The Swiss franc surged to a two-year high against the euro, fueled by expectations of lower rates in the euro zone.

site_title: Malaysia restarts rail project with China after cost cut
summary: Malaysia has restarted the China-linked East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project after a cost reduction, with the price tag now set at RM44 billion (down from RM65.5 billion). The project, expected to be completed in 2026, aims to connect Peninsular Malaysia's eastern coast to states near Kuala Lumpur. The reduced cost is expected to save Malaysia RM12.6 billion in financing costs, with 85% of the project financed by China's Export-Import Bank. The project is seen as a boon for China's Belt and Road Initiative, while also bringing economic benefits to Malaysia.

site_title: Samsung to launch Galaxy Fold in September
summary: Samsung will launch its Galaxy Fold in September, after conducting final testing and modifications following its initial April postponement due to defects in the device's flexible screen. The company has redesigned the protective film and re-engineered the hinge to improve durability. The launch comes as Samsung competes with Chinese rivals Xiaomi and Huawei, who are also developing foldable phones. The Galaxy Fold's delay may impact Samsung's projected sales, but analysts believe the company has learned from its mistakes and is poised to take a lead in the emerging foldable market.

site_title: US business investment picking up; goods trade deficit narrows
summary: US business investment showed a 1.9% surge in June, with core capital goods orders increasing 1.9% year-over-year, suggesting a pickup in business spending on equipment. The goods trade deficit narrowed to $74.2 billion, with imports and exports declining, indicating the trade war between the US and China is hurting trade. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates next week, citing business investment and housing as areas of weakness in the economy.

site_title: NSL OilChem Waste Management opens S$40m wastewater treatment plant
summary: NSL OilChem Waste Management has opened a S$40 million wastewater treatment plant in Tuas, Singapore, capable of treating 1,000 cubic metres of industrial wastewater per day. The plant serves various industries, including petrochemical, pharmaceutical, and automotive. It is the company's second treatment plant, showcasing its commitment to state-of-the-art technology and addressing complex wastewater issues. The plant is one of the largest in Singapore, underscoring the company's capabilities.

site_title: Dave Lim, founder of TEDx Singapore
summary: Dave Lim, founder of TEDx Singapore, was inspired by TED Talks in the late 2000s and applied for the rights to organize TEDxSingapore within 24 hours of its launch in 2009. Since then, the event has featured over 200 speakers and talents, with 150,000 followers, and has grown to become a platform for sharing ideas and perspectives. Lim aims to make Singapore an ideas-driven society by showcasing diverse ideas and perspectives, and has curated events to discuss topics such as happiness and the future of Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Citic Envirotech (CEL) has had its share price downgraded to "hold" by DBS Equity Research due to execution risk and low earnings growth. The company's high adjusted net debt-equity ratio and recent earnings plunge of 80% are concerns. Mapletree Industrial Trust's (MIT) distribution per unit was in line with forecasts, but the trust's high valuations have led to a downgrade to "hold" by CGS-CIMB.

site_title: Learn how to flourish in the new digital economy
summary: Singapore's sgsme is hosting a networking event on August 16 to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) thrive in the digital economy. Lai Chang Wen, co-founder of Ninja Van, and Rachel Lim, co-founder of Love Bonito, will share their experiences and insights on how to succeed in the digital age. A white paper by Ovum, "Putting digital to work," will also be discussed, highlighting the top business challenges faced by SMEs, including keeping up with technology and dealing with competition.

site_title: French 'flying man' fails to cross Channel on jet-powered hoverboard
summary: French inventor Franky Zapata failed to cross the English Channel on a jet-powered hoverboard, missing a refuelling platform on a boat by just a few centimeters. He had been attempting to reach Dover from Sangatte, France, at a speed of up to 140 kph. The failure occurred on the 110th anniversary of the first powered flight between Britain and France, with Zapata unhurt. The team attributed the failure to the waves, not the wind, and Zapata had previously successfully completed the maneuver in heavier seas.

site_title: Apple suppliers see demand for new iPhones stabilising this year
summary: Apple's suppliers are planning to produce components for up to 75 million new iPhones in the second half of 2019, indicating steady demand for the company's most important product despite US-China trade tensions and a decline in the overall smartphone market. This signals stabilization after a year of uncertainty, with analysts estimating shipments of newly released iPhones will rise to 74-80 million in the second half. The planned production levels also suggest Foxconn Technology Group is hiring staff to secure a peak-period workforce, while Pegatron Corp and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co are also benefiting from the news.

site_title: Treasure Trove
summary: Winston Wong and his daughter Rebecca have opened Singapore's first flatted factory store, "By My Old School", featuring vintage finds. The store, located in a converted factory, offers a wide range of nostalgic items such as nautical equipment, family portraits, and tools used by Singapore's past industries. The store caters to collectors, particularly the older crowd, who appreciate the nostalgic connection. The Wongs also rent out items for production companies and nostalgia-themed weddings, making the store a unique treasure trove for Singaporeans to connect with their past.

images.alt_text: By My Old School is a vintage trove.
Left: A vintage provision shop set up. Right: A film projector that is rented out for display.
Left: Some collectors buy old family portraits. Right: Old coffeecups and milk tins.

site_title: Game of Thrones inspired scotch lifts Diageo sales
summary: Diageo, the world's largest spirits company, reported higher annual profit driven by growth across all markets and the popularity of its "Game of Thrones" inspired scotch. The company's operating profit rose 10% to £4 billion, with Asia-Pacific sales up 9% and net sales up 5.8%. Scotch sales, a quarter of Diageo's net sales, increased 6% due to the success of "White Walker by Johnnie Walker", while the company approved plans to return up to £4.5 billion to shareholders over 2020-2022.

site_title: Corporate governance is a shared responsibility. It's not just on auditors
summary: Corporate governance is a shared responsibility among multiple stakeholders, including the board, management, audit committee, and internal and external auditors. While auditors play a crucial role in ensuring the accuracy of financial statements, they are not the sole guardians of public interest. The Companies Act requires the board to produce true and fair financial statements and maintain internal controls, with the competency of the CFO and finance team being crucial. The audit committee assists the board in fulfilling its oversight responsibilities, and the auditor seeks to obtain reasonable assurance that financial statements are free from material misstatement.

site_title: Eating disorder hiding in plain sight
summary: A growing concern among dietitians is orthorexia nervosa, a little-known eating disorder characterized by an obsession with health, wellness, and clean eating, driven by Western cultural influences. Coined in 1998, it is not yet an official diagnosis in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5).
