As the wellness culture amplifies every new diet and fitness trend, social media platforms showcase filtered bodies, fueling the perception of "clean eating" as a desirable and attainable goal. Experts warn of the potential for orthorexia nervosa, citing rising cases among clinicians.

images.alt_text: Orthorexia would seem to be a condition uniquely suited to our times, when fats, carbs and processed food are demonised.

site_title: SingHaiyi posts net loss of S$8.2m, 84% slump in revenue for Q1
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a net loss of S$8.2 million for Q1, with revenue plummeting 84% to S$4.2 million due to lower revenue from its completed private condominium project City Suites. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue recognition. No dividend was declared, and shares ended at S$0.095, up 2.15% before the results were announced.

site_title: MCT posts 3.6% rise in Q1 DPU on higher gross revenue, NPI
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 3.6% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.31 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended June 30, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income (NPI). Gross revenue rose 3.3% to S$112.13 million, while NPI increased 2.8% to S$88.35 million. The trust's VivoCity mall saw 5.2% and 4.2% growth in gross revenue and NPI, respectively, driven by higher rental income and asset enhancement initiatives. The portfolio's aggregate leverage ratio stood at 33.1% as of June 30.

site_title: Sicily's white wines - rich and salty, racy and refreshing
summary: Sicily's white wines, made from the carricante grape, are gaining attention for their distinctive salty flavor and high acidity, setting them apart from other Italian whites. Grown in the foothills of Mount Etna, these wines are influenced by the volcanic soils and constant winds from the Mediterranean. With a recommended percentage of carricante grapes, ranging from 60% to 100%, the best wines showcase the grape's unique character. Notable producers include Federico Curtaz, Le Vigne di Eli, and Benanti, offering a range of styles and prices, from affordable to premium.

images.alt_text: Sicily's whites are not conventional, fruity whites. They offer none of the tropical flavourssometimes associated with New World chardonnays, none of the peach and apricot of German rieslings, not even the tart twang of sauvignon blancs.

site_title: Healthcare firm Halodoc raises about US$100m in Series B, B+ rounds
summary: Healthcare startup Halodoc has raised approximately US$100 million in a Series B+ round, led by strategic investors including the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Allianz X, and Prudential. The funding will support the expansion of Halodoc's mobile platform, creating more awareness in other Indonesian cities and improving product development. The platform, which serves around 7 million patients per month, aims to simplify healthcare in Indonesia and improve access to affordable and reliable services.

site_title: Cycle & Carriage Singapore enters car-leasing business, partners Gojek
summary: Cycle & Carriage Singapore has entered the car-leasing business through Cycle & Carriage Leasing, a new unit wholly owned by parent company Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C). The new unit will lease car fleets to corporate clients and ride-sharing players, partnering with ride-hailing operator Gojek. The fleet will offer various leasing options, including daily rentals and long-term rentals of up to three years, with brands including Kia and Mitsubishi. This marks Cycle & Carriage's move into the mobility space and reflects the company's drive to stay competitive in the automotive industry.

site_title: Singtel bundles insurance into mobile services for foreign workers
summary: Singtel is bundling NTUC Income-provided insurance coverage into its prepaid and remittance app services for foreign workers in Singapore. The telco absorbs the insurance premiums as an acquisition cost, aiming to increase market share. The insurance payouts are relatively small, with S$5,000 for permanent disability or accidental death and S$20 per day for hospitalization. Customers can receive coverage by remitting money using the Dash app, topping up a prepaid card, or purchasing a data plan, with coverage periods ranging from 30 days.

site_title: Singapore medical device market growth cut to 8.4% for 2018-2023: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's medical device market is projected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 8.4% from 2018 to 2023, down from a previous estimate of 9.1%, with a valued market of S$1.3 billion in 2023. Weaker global economic momentum and US-China trade tensions will impact exports, but increased government spending and new trade agreements will support imports and sector growth. The industry will be driven by an ageing population, high-quality healthcare, and a well-developed medical tourism industry.

site_title: Singtel offers insurance cover in prepaid, remittance app services
summary: Singtel will bundle NTUC Income insurance coverage into its prepaid phone and remittance services, targeting 40% of its 60% foreign worker customer base. The telco absorbs insurance premiums as acquisition cost, aiming to increase cross-platform subscriptions and market share. The insurance coverage supplements mandatory medical insurance, with payouts of up to S$25,000 for permanent disability or accidental death. Singtel plans to leverage its scale and digitalisation to offer more insurance products in the coming months, making coverage more accessible and affordable.

site_title: Jaguar owner Tata Motors has fourth loss in five quarters as hurdles mount
summary: Tata Motors, owner of Jaguar Land Rover, reported its fourth consecutive loss in five quarters, with a loss of 37 billion rupees (S$733.22 million) for the three months ended June 30. The company attributed the loss to slumping demand in China and the shift towards cleaner fuels, particularly affecting Jaguar Land Rover. The company expects growth from Chinese business, but a hard Brexit could further impact the UK's auto industry. Tata Motors is exploring strategic options for Jaguar Land Rover, including a potential stake sale.

site_title: External factors cast long shadow over industrial property rentals
summary: The Singapore industrial property market remained stable in Q2 2019, with a 0.1% uptick in JTC's rental index. However, analysts attribute this to caution due to external factors, including US-China trade tensions and a dimmed economic outlook. Analysts predict a 2% drop in overall industrial property rental index this year and next, with the warehouse segment being particularly exposed to weakening trade performance. The occupancy rate remained flat, while transaction volumes increased by 24% in Q2.

site_title: Falcon Energy Group files for 6-month moratorium
summary: Falcon Energy Group, an offshore and marine company, has filed applications for a 6-month moratorium in the High Court as part of a court-supervised process to reorganize their liabilities. The moratorium, which started on July 25, prevents legal proceedings against the company and its subsidiary Asetanian Marine during this period. Shares of Falcon Energy have been suspended since January due to financial issues. The company has engaged law and financial advisers to facilitate the process, which aims to restructure their liabilities.

site_title: The Sex Appeal Of Glass
summary: Netflix's reality contest Blown Away, a glass-blowing competition, has unexpectedly charmed audiences with its unique blend of technical expertise and artistic expression. The show, featuring 10 contestants competing for a $60,000 prize and a residency at the Corning Museum, highlights the intricate process of creating glassware under time constraints. With a cast of shy and talented artists, the show focuses on the integrity of the work rather than drama or competition, making it a refreshing watch in the age of fast-paced reality TV.

site_title: LY Corp unit receives court summons over mezzanine floor collapse
summary: LY Corp subsidiary LY Furniture Sdn Bhd has received a court summons over the November 2019 collapse of a mezzanine floor at one of its Johor factories, resulting in an employee's death. The summons charges LY Furniture with failing to provide a safe mezzanine floor under the Occupational Safety and Health Act 1994. The company is scheduled to appear in court on August 18.

site_title: More reach, more punch
summary: Chatri Sityodtong, CEO of Singapore-based mixed-martial arts organization One Championship, aims to surpass the NFL in reach and popularity. He believes that prioritizing profit over growth would have hindered the success of companies like Amazon and Tesla. Sityodtong advocates for a "go-big-or-go-home" mentality, which has driven One Championship's rapid growth and success.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust Q2 DPU falls 6.9% on sales drop, expenses hit
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 6.9% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.321 Singapore cents in Q2, due to lower net property income (NPI) of 5.4% to S$20.5 million. This was attributed to lower rental income and higher property expenses from lease structure changes. Gross revenue also fell 7.4% to S$27.8 million. The trust will pay the Q2 distribution on Aug 28.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$600m in China's Didi, new joint venture
summary: Toyota is investing US$600 million in Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-hailing giant, and a new joint venture. The partnership will expand collaboration between Toyota and Didi in China, with Toyota also partnering with Guangzhou Automobile Group Co Ltd. The new joint venture aims to enhance mobility services in the country.

site_title: Rubicon claim against KrisEnergy ruled valid by High Court
summary: A High Court in England has ruled in favor of Rubicon Vantage International, finding it made a compliant demand under a guarantee from KrisEnergy regarding a $1.8 million debt. The ruling comes after Rubicon sought a declaration from the court. KrisEnergy plans to pursue available options, while also facing a notice of arbitration from Northern Gulf Petroleum Pte Ltd, related to a joint exploration project. The company's shares declined 5.26% following the announcement.

site_title: Europeans stall on IMF Nomination as Draghi rules himself out
summary: European countries are unable to agree on the next head of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) by Friday, with the French considering abolishing the 65-year-old age limit to widen the candidate pool. Christine Lagarde is leaving the European Central Bank to take over as ECB head, and a decision on her replacement is likely next week. Potential candidates include Jeroen Dijsselbloem, Nadia Calvino, and Olli Rehn, but France is reportedly pushing for Mario Draghi, despite him ruling himself out.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q1 DPU rises 28% to S$0.0205
summary: Ascendas India Trust posted a 28% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0205 for the first quarter ended June 30, driven by a 13% rise in net property income (NPI) to S$37.8m and a 29% increase in income available for distribution to S$23.7m.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q2 DPU falls 24.4%, to start AEI for New Tech Park
summary: Sabana Reit's Q2 DPU fell 24.4% to 0.62 Singapore cents due to a one-time absence of cost recovery and lower revenue, resulting in a 24.1% decline in Q2 income available for distribution to S$6.6 million. The challenging market also led to a 24.4% decrease in net property income. Payment is due August 29, and books will close on August 2.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel expanded its VIA mobile payment alliance to Japan through its partnership with Netstars. BlackRock ceased to be a substantial shareholder of Venture Corp after a related entity reduced its holdings. A poll found Singaporeans are 6th most vacation-deprived globally, with 77% willing to take a pay cut for an extra day off. The Singapore stock market is expected to see continued delistings this year, with two companies delisting on average per month. The STI gained 0.4% following a positive US earnings session.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust Q1 DPU up 3.6% to 2.31 S cents
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a 3.6% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.31 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended June 30. Gross revenue edged up 3.3% to S$112.13 million, driven by higher contributions from VivoCity and office/business park assets. The trust's committed occupancy stood at 98.9% as of June 30, with manageable lease expiries expected to support its portfolio's resilience.

site_title: Tritech requests trading halt pending announcement
summary: Tritech Group, a CATALIST-listed engineering firm, has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The company recently completed a share placement to raise S$1 million, with S$950,000 for working capital. Tritech's shares were trading at three Singapore cents before the halt, down 0.1 cent or 3.2% from the previous day's close. The exact nature of the announcement is not specified.

site_title: Japan may soon gain a powerful trade weapon against South Korea
summary: Japan is set to remove South Korea from its "white list" of trusted export destinations, potentially restricting exports of hundreds of items to the country, including critical components for semiconductors and display manufacturing. The move is a response to South Korea's alleged failure to properly manage sensitive materials, a claim denied by Seoul. The decision could harm South Korea's tech sector and affect 97% of Japanese imports, but economists predict a short-term impact. Japan's government is assessing public comments on the matter, with a decision expected in August.

site_title: BlackRock ceases to be substantial shareholder of Venture Corp
summary: BlackRock has ceased to be a substantial shareholder of Venture Corporation after PNC Financial Services Group reduced its holdings in the electronics manufacturing services provider. PNC disposed of 525,500 shares on July 22, reducing its shareholding to 4.98%. This move followed a one-day increase in PNC's stake to 5.16% on July 19. As a result, BlackRock's indirect control of PNC through its substantial minority equity interest in BlackRock has also ended, removing it as a substantial shareholder of Venture Corp.

site_title: Volkswagen bucks the trend in crowd of struggling carmakers
summary: Volkswagen reported a second-quarter operating profit that beat expectations, bucking the trend of struggling carmakers. The company's strong model lineup, particularly sport utility vehicles, helped offset declining vehicle sales and negative currency effects. Volkswagen's CFO stated that the second half of the year will be "potentially difficult" due to a weaker market environment. Despite this, the company reiterated its operating return on sales target at the lower end of a 6.5-7.5% range, and its CFO mentioned that sharing components across nameplates, or MQB technology, is saving costs.

site_title: ECB charts path for new stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) signaled a potential new stimulus package and rate cuts to boost the sluggish euro zone economy, citing growing fears over US-led protectionism, Brexit, and emerging market weakness. The ECB left rates at zero and hinted at further cuts, with officials exploring options including new net asset purchases. The move comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where rates are expected to be cut for the first time in a decade.

site_title: ST Engineering bags S$1.5b in new aerospace, electronics contracts
summary: ST Engineering secured new contracts worth S$1.5 billion in its aerospace and electronics sectors for the second quarter of 2019. The aerospace sector secured contracts worth S$809 million, including a multi-year agreement for Boeing 717s and engine maintenance agreements. The electronics sector secured contracts worth S$702 million for smart mobility, satellite communications, and IoT applications. The company also received a US$95 million contract from the US Army for a unified simulation platform. These contracts are expected to have no material impact on the company's earnings.

site_title: Singtel expands its VIA mobile payment alliance to Japan
summary: Singtel has expanded its VIA mobile payment alliance to Japan, partnering with Netstars to introduce QR code payments at Haneda Airport International Terminal and other popular tourist destinations. The alliance now connects telco and non-telco mobile wallets across borders, allowing tourists from Singapore and Thailand to use their local mobile wallets for payments in Japan. More merchants, including convenience stores, restaurants, and department stores, will be added in the coming year, growing the alliance to represent 40 million mobile-wallet users and 2.1 million merchants across five countries.

site_title: AB InBev beats expectations as beer sales growth hits 5-year high
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev), the world's largest brewer, reported a 2.1% year-on-year increase in beer volumes in the second quarter, its fastest pace in over five years. Revenue and profits rose due to price increases and higher-priced beers. The company expects strong revenue and core profit growth this year, despite being weighed down by debt. AB InBev aims to reduce its net debt to EBITDA ratio to below 4 by the end of 2020, with a long-term goal of a multiple of around 2.

site_title: Nissan quarterly net profit plunges, 12,500 job cuts planned
summary: Nissan announced a 12,500 job cut plan as it struggles with weak sales and the arrest of former CEO Carlos Ghosn. The company's quarterly net profit plummeted, and it plans to reduce global production capacity by 10% by 2022. The job cuts and production reductions aim to optimize operations and address financial challenges.

site_title: Jollibee risks indigestion with US coffee deal
summary: Jollibee Foods is acquiring California-based retailer The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf for $350 million, expanding its presence to 1,189 stores in Southeast Asia and aiming to boost its coffee business. However, the deal may be a misstep, as the company is struggling to compete with Starbucks and other entrenched rivals, and has lost money in the past. The acquisition is expected to put further financial strain on Jollibee, which is already losing money in its battle with Starbucks.

site_title: Moody's buys climate data firm, signaling new scrutiny of climate risks
summary: Moody's Corp has purchased a controlling stake in Four Twenty Seven, a California-based firm that measures climate change risks, signaling increased scrutiny of climate-related creditworthiness. The data firm tracks hazards like extreme rainfall and sea level rise, covering 2,000 companies and 196 countries. Moody's aims to better understand and mitigate climate risks, with the purchase allowing for more precise reviews of climate-related risks. This move reflects the growing importance of climate risks in credit analysis, potentially impacting governments and companies worldwide.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.4% following positive Wall St earnings session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 12.82 points or 0.4% to close at 3,381.26 on Thursday, following a positive US earnings session. The Asian market trend was driven by weak eurozone manufacturing figures, which boosted hopes of a European Central Bank rate cut. Financials and real estate investment trusts (Reits) were among the main gainers, with Mapletree Industrial Trust units closing 0.9% higher. Despite a sluggish South Korean economy, most markets in the region ended with gains, with the exception of South Korea.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q1 DPU rises 28% to 2.05 S cents
summary: Ascendas India Trust posted a 28% jump in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first quarter, rising to 2.05 Singapore cents. Net property income increased 13% to S$37.8 million, while income available for distribution rose 29% to S$23.7 million. The improved performance was driven by incremental income from leased-out properties, including aVance Pune and the Anchor building at International Tech Park Bangalore. The trust's portfolio occupancy remains at 99%, with a weighted average lease expiry of 4.3 years.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end higher as tech lends support
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.3% to 28,594.30, led by tech firms following a US-China trade rally. The Hang Seng IT index climbed 1.6%, with Tencent ending up 1.9% at a two-month high. Top gainers included CSPC Pharmaceutical Group Ltd and China Merchants Bank Co Ltd. The yuan weakened 0.03% to 6.8751 per US dollar, as top US and Chinese negotiators meet next week to revive trade talks.

site_title: Speculation of ECB rate move lifts European stocks
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trade on Thursday as market players speculated on a possible move on interest rates by the European Central Bank (ECB). The Paris CAC 40 index added 0.6% to 5,637.06 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 0.2% to 12,550.73. The ECB will discuss easing monetary conditions to kick-start sluggish growth and inflation at its policy-setting meeting. Expectations of a possible rate cut have been heightened by recent ECB statements.

site_title: 3 in 10 CFOs, treasurers in Asia-Pacific leading digital transformation: DBS poll
summary: A DBS Bank survey of 1,304 CFOs and corporate treasurers in the Asia-Pacific region found that 29.5% believe it's their responsibility to push the digital strategy agenda, while 43.6% think technology colleagues should lead digital transformation. Only 11.3% attribute it to CEOs. The survey also revealed that nearly half of respondents partner with business units to execute digital transformation and that Singapore companies are more digitally ready, with 41% having a clearly defined digital strategy.

site_title: Cycle & Carriage Singapore enters car leasing business, partners Gojek
summary: Cycle & Carriage Singapore has entered the car leasing business through a new unit, Cycle & Carriage Leasing, in partnership with Gojek. The new unit will offer various leasing options, including daily rentals and long-term car rentals of up to three years. The fleet will consist mainly of Kia and Mitsubishi brands, with other car makes available for more options. This move reflects the group's drive to stay competitive in the automotive industry and marks its entry into the mobility space through a partnership with an on-demand ride-hailing operator.

site_title: Australia shares climb towards record high on rate cut hopes; NZ up
summary: Australian shares climbed towards a record high, up 0.6% or 41.3 points to 6,818.0, driven by hopes of global interest rate cuts and strong performances in financials and healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index narrowly missed its record high of 6,851.50 set in November 2007. Disappointing manufacturing surveys from Europe and the US solidified expectations of European Central Bank and US Federal Reserve rate cuts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher supported by tech rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.22% or 48.98 points at 21,756.55. The rally was driven by US tech sector gains and strong corporate earnings from Japanese chip-related firms. The Topix index also rose 0.18% or 2.76 points to 1,577.85. Analysts attributed the boost to fresh records in the S&P and Nasdaq and chip-related shares being heavily bought.

site_title: Aussie PM vows quick work on UK trade deal
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has vowed to work quickly on a trade deal with the UK, with a potential agreement echoing the Australia-EU trade deal under negotiation. Morrison congratulated Boris Johnson, the new British Prime Minister, and expressed a commitment to maintaining a strong relationship between the two countries. The deal may be influenced by the UK's future trade relationship with Europe, and Morrison hopes to meet Johnson at the G-7 summit next month.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,377.13, up 0.26% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.26% to 3,377.13, driven by gains in P5 Capital Holdings, Golden Agri-Resources, and DBS Group Holdings. Banking stocks also edged up. However, shares of Citic Envirotech and Cache Logistics Trust declined due to downgrades and lower-than-expected earnings. The market's rally continues ahead of GDP data, with other Asian markets also posting minor gains.

site_title: Rents, prices of Singapore industrial space remained stable in Q2: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space prices and rentals remained stable in Q2, with a 0.1% dip in the price index and a 0.1% increase in the rental index. Occupancy rates remained flat, but increased 0.6% year-on-year to 89.3%. About 170 units of uncompleted industrial space are available for sale, totaling 112,000 sq m. An estimated 0.9 million sq m of industrial space will be completed in 2019, with 1.7 million sq m expected in 2020, meeting the average annual supply and demand of 1.3 million sq m over the past three years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slightly higher on Thursday at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.18% to 28,575.49, following a lacklustre day on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also showed minimal changes. The gains come as investors continue to track earnings reports and await updates on US-EU trade talks and the Federal Reserve's split views on interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.17 points to 1,656.58, with a trading volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM2 billion. Losers beat gainers 500 to 301 on Thursday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip on downbeat quarterly earnings
summary: South Korean stocks declined on Thursday, with the Kospi index falling 0.38% to 2,074.49, as tepid corporate earnings and a murky outlook from a major chemical firm deflated sentiment. Chip giants SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics rose after the company announced plans to cut investment and production to support a modest rebound in chip demand. Despite a technical recession in the second quarter, the economy is expected to need further stimulus to stoke demand.

site_title: Alibaba Cloud, SACEOS ink MOU to team up in AI, big data, cloud tech
summary: Alibaba Cloud and the Singapore Association of Convention & Exhibition Organisers & Suppliers (SACEOS) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to collaborate on artificial intelligence, big data, and cloud technologies. The partnership aims to provide training and collaboration opportunities in these fields, with Singapore seeking to maintain its edge as a top Asian destination in the MICE and hospitality industry. This move aims to support the growth of AI and cloud technologies in Singapore and promote innovation in the region.

site_title: Libra Group calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: Libra Group requested a trading halt pending an announcement, with its counter closing at 5.1 Singapore cents on Wednesday, down 0.6 cent from the previous day. The company recently reconstituted its board following the resignation of Gn Jong Yuh Gwendolyn and appointed Goh Keng Haw as an independent director to take over her duties.

site_title: Tunnelling starts on Circle Line's final stage, existing line to be upgraded
summary: Tunnelling work for the Circle Line 6 (CCL6) has started in Singapore, marking the final stage of the orbital Circle Line. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is upgrading the existing line, with 66% of earth retaining and stabilising structure works completed. The LTA is also procuring 12 new trains from Alstom to support the expanded network. The CCL is expected to open in 2025, with system enhancements to be implemented to prepare for the new trains and stations. The upgrades include improved signalling, power supply, and communications systems.

site_title: China's Wanda Sports cuts US IPO size, lowers price range
summary: Wanda Sports Group Co Ltd, a unit of Dalian Wanda Group, has cut the size of its US IPO to up to $308 million from $500 million, lowering the price range to $9-$11 per ADS. This follows China's largest live-streaming platform DouYu International Holdings Ltd pricing its $775 million IPO at the bottom of its range last week. The company plans to use IPO proceeds to repay debt and fund strategic investments. Wanda Sports reported a 31% drop in profit in 2018 and a loss in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Asia: Markets tempered by US-China doubts
summary: Asian markets were tempered on Thursday due to doubts over the US-China trade meeting, despite a surge in US stocks the previous day. The release of a Chinese defense white paper accusing the US of undermining global stability has softened hopes of a resolution. Investors are also wary of a slump in manufacturing activity, which could spill over into the services sector. Central banks are expected to point to rate cuts, with the European Central Bank likely to announce a rate cut in September.

site_title: Growth in Singapore medical device market cut to 8.4% for 2018-2023: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's medical device market is projected to grow at a 8.4% compound annual rate from 2018 to 2023, down from 9.1%, with an industry value of S$1.3 billion in 2023. The growth is driven by an ageing population, high-quality healthcare, and government support, but is limited by a small population and high competition. Medical device imports are expected to increase due to government spending, while exports face headwinds due to the global economic slowdown, but will benefit from new trade agreements.

site_title: Facebook firm in its quest to launch Libra cryptocurrency
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reaffirmed the company's commitment to launching Libra cryptocurrency, despite criticism and government pushback. Switzerland's FINMA has pledged to oversee the Geneva-based Libra Association, which is expected to debut next year. The move comes after Facebook unveiled plans for Libra in June, sparking concerns over the digital currency's unintended consequences.

site_title: Billionaire owners' public spat weighs on IndiGo's future
summary: Billionaire co-founders of Indian budget airline IndiGo, Rakesh Mr Gangwal and Rahul Bhatia, are in a public dispute over corporate-governance transgressions, with Gangwal seeking to curb Bhatia's powers. The disagreement threatens to derail the airline's future, despite its recent record profit. Analysts see risks in a prolonged dispute, including a drawn-out legal battle, loss of market share, dilution of the brand, and potential impact on Airbus orders. The dispute may also affect IndiGo's plans to add capacity on overseas routes, as rival airlines capitalize on the uncertainty.

site_title: ANZ says watchdog plans to take it to court for wrongful fee charges
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) said Australia's corporate regulator, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), plans to take the lender to court for wrongful fee charges. ASIC is seeking penalties for 1.3 million occasions where fees were applied, related to periodical payments before February 2016. ANZ denies any deliberate wrongdoing and will vigorously defend itself in court. This comes amid increased scrutiny of banks following the Royal Commission, which exposed compliance and governance failures in the financial sector.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on prospects for global rate cuts; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a 12-year high, driven by expectations of global interest rate cuts. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 6,800.20, with financial stocks gaining 0.9% to their highest since March 2018. Lower US rates are expected to alleviate pressure on Australian banks, which have been concerned about their margins. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.59% as investors anticipate rate cuts in the country.

site_title: Citi hires JPMorgan asset management executive for Asia equities business
summary: Citi has hired Curt Engler, a senior executive from JPMorgan's asset management business, as the Asia Pacific head of equities execution services. Based in Hong Kong, Engler will oversee Citi's cash equities business in 12 Asian markets, focusing on client relationships, technology, and governance. Engler joins Citi after overseeing US$250 billion in assets under management at JPMorgan Asset Management.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1% to 3,372.29
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,372.29 on Thursday, following Wall Street's gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, while the Dow retreated due to Boeing's disappointing earnings. The market is awaiting GDP data, and investors are optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open modestly higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened marginally higher on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.03% or 7.27 points at 21,716.84. The easy money policy by central bankers encouraged risk-on sentiment, as investors closely watched earnings reports. The broader Topix index was also up 0.06% or 1.00 points at 1,576.09.

site_title: Australia's central bank governor says 'reasonable' to expect lower rates for longer
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe stated it's "reasonable" to expect an extended period of low interest rates, citing a potential need for additional policy stimulus if demand growth disappoints. The RBA has reduced interest rates twice since June to a record low 1% to revive growth and inflation. Lowe emphasized the RBA's commitment to achieving an average inflation rate of 2-3% and ruled out contemplating higher interest rates until inflation returns to the target range. The RBA's inflation target remains unchanged despite recent criticism.

site_title: Singaporeans 6th most vacation-deprived globally, will take pay cut for holiday: poll
summary: Singaporeans are the 6th most vacation-deprived globally, with nearly two-thirds of full-time workers feeling they don't get enough time off work. 77% would take a pay cut for an extra day off, and 63% felt they didn't get enough vacation time in 2018. The country's sentiments of vacation deprivation grew 6% from 2017, with 39% citing inability to take time off as the main reason. The survey also found that 70% of employees took at least one mental health day, and 30% felt their supervisors expected them to be constantly available.

site_title: SK Hynix warns of chip supply disruption on Japan's export curbs
summary: SK Hynix, a key Apple supplier, warns of potential chip supply disruption due to escalating trade tensions between South Korea and Japan. The company is diversifying its vendors and minimizing input of restricted materials, amid a global memory chip market recovery. SK Hynix cuts DRAM output capacity and investment for next year, citing weak chip prices and a 89% drop in quarterly operating profit. Japan's export curbs on chipmaking materials are expected to hurt global supply chains, prompting South Korean officials to meet with US tech industry groups.

site_title: Brazil hopes US$11.2b stimulus spurs economy
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro announced a plan to inject US$11.2 billion into the country's slowing economy through a stimulus package, aiming to help 63 million workers with debts and overdue bills. The plan includes allowing workers to withdraw up to 500 reais from a severance fund and releasing cash from a social security fund. The stimulus is expected to add 2.5 percentage points to GDP per capita over 10 years and create three million jobs, but some critics have questioned the small amount of money offered.

site_title: AA Reit posts flat Q1 DPU at 2.5 Singapore cents
summary: AIMS APAC Reit (AA Reit) posted a flat Q1 DPU of 2.5 Singapore cents, unchanged from the year-ago period. Net property income grew 18.1% to S$22.9 million, driven by higher gross revenue and lower property operating expenses. Gross revenue rose 5.8% to S$30.6 million, with rental contributions from new properties contributing to the increase. Distributions to unitholders edged up 1.4% to S$17.4 million.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Citic Envirotech to 'hold' following earnings slump
summary: DBS Equity Research downgraded Citic Envirotech to 'hold' with a target price of S$0.34 due to a 66% drop in net profit to S$14.7 million for the second quarter. The company's revenue shrank 30.3% to S$202.8 million, mainly attributed to a decline in the engineering business and membrane system sales. Analyst Patricia Yeung noted execution risk as the main reason for earnings disappointment, but cited upside potential if construction progress is sustained and more project wins are secured.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust posts 6.9% drop in Q2 DPU to 1.321 S cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 6.9% drop in Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.321 Singapore cents, down from 1.419 cents in the year-ago period. Net property income fell 5.4% to S$20.5 million due to lower revenue and higher property expenses from lease conversions. Gross revenue shrank 7.4% to S$27.8 million. The trust will pay Q2 distribution on Aug 28, with a half-year DPU of 2.834 Singapore cents, down 3.1% from the previous period.

site_title: Tesla needs more time to turn profit; founding engineer steps down
summary: Tesla missed financial targets in the second quarter, with a quarterly loss deeper than expected and narrower margins. The company pushed back its profit timeline, now expecting to break even in the current quarter and reach profitability in the fourth quarter of 2019. Founding engineer JB Straubel stepped down as chief technology officer, while Elon Musk focuses on containing costs and investing in major initiatives. Tesla's strong deliveries in the quarter were not enough to offset revenue and profit concerns, with shares falling 11.5% after hours.

site_title: Federal Reserve expected to cut rates for first time in a decade this month: Poll
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates for the first time in over a decade, with 95% of economists predicting a 25 basis point cut in the federal funds rate to 2.00-2.25% at the July 30-31 meeting. The decision comes amid rising economic risks from the US-China trade war and concerns about slowing growth and weak inflation pressure. The expected rate cut is seen as a response to market expectations and a shift in the Fed's stance from tightening to easing, with economists predicting another cut later in the year and potentially three rate cuts this year.

site_title: Anti-Johnson London protesters converge on Westminster
summary: Thousands of protesters gathered in central London to demonstrate against British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, converging on Downing Street and disrupting cabinet members. The "fck Boris" rally, organized by progressive groups, featured DJ decks, music, and speeches criticizing Johnson's policies. Attendees, holding anti-Johnson placards, claimed up to 10,000 people attended the protest, with speakers including Momentum and Labour Party officials, warning of Johnson's dangers for communities, society, and the world.

site_title: Samsung to launch Galaxy Fold in Sept after screen problems
summary: Samsung's Galaxy Fold, its first foldable smartphone, will launch in September after being delayed due to screen problems. The company has made improvements to the nearly $2,000 phone, including strengthening hinges, and is conducting final tests. The rollout has been hampered by defects in samples reported in April, but Samsung is still in talks with mobile carriers to finalize details. Chinese rival Huawei's Mate X folding phone is also expected to launch in September, signaling Samsung's highly anticipated device may revive flagging smartphone sales.

site_title: DP World's Dubai ports hit by Iran woes, rivalry
summary: DP World's Dubai ports saw a decline in cargo volumes for the fifth consecutive quarter, with US sanctions against Iran and competition from Abu Dhabi's Khalifa Port contributing to the drop. US President Donald Trump's sanctions in November and the expansion of Khalifa Port's capacity, set to double in 2019, have eroded Jebel Ali's market share. The UAE's embargo on Qatar also continues to impact Dubai's ports, according to industry consultant Drewry.

site_title: China's first AI fund learned from the country's best traders
summary: China's first AI fund, Zheshang Fund Management Co, is set to launch next month, using 300 investment models to analyze over 3,000 Chinese stocks. The fund learned from the nation's best traders and analysts, with an initial return of 26.4% between September and June. Despite mixed results globally, experts believe AI strategies will gain traction in the long run, and the fund's diversification and risk-adjusted performance may appeal to retail investors. The launch marks a significant step in China's push into AI-driven investing.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records but Dow drops on Boeing, Caterpillar
summary: US stocks ended the day at records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq surging 0.5% and 0.9% respectively, while the Dow Jones shed 0.3%. Boeing and Caterpillar fell after disappointing earnings, but analysts say expectations of an interest rate cut next week outweighed concerns, with investors taking a wait-and-see view of a government antitrust probe into tech giants.

site_title: Boeing reports biggest-ever loss as 737 Max grounding drags on
summary: Boeing reported its largest-ever loss of $2.9 billion in the second quarter due to the ongoing 737 Max crisis, which has been grounded since March following two deadly crashes. The company warned it may temporarily halt production if the grounding is extended, citing a complex regulatory process. Boeing has set aside $9.8 billion to compensate airlines and has not updated its full-year profit forecast. The crisis has also had a ripple effect on the US economy, with manufacturing output and exports impacted.

site_title: South Korea Q2 GDP bounces as public spending offsets private sector drag
summary: South Korea's economy grew 1.1% in the second quarter, beating forecasts, thanks to increased government spending. The private sector's contribution to GDP was negative, with companies slashing investment due to uncertainty. The Bank of Korea cut interest rates earlier than expected and trimmed its 2019 growth forecast to 2.2%. Merchandise exports returned to growth, but remain uncertain due to Japan's export curbs. Analysts have downgraded their forecasts for 2019 growth, with some predicting growth below 2%.

site_title: Legal penalties dent Facebook profit; revenue, user base grows
summary: Facebook reported a 49% drop in profit to $2.6 billion in the second quarter, primarily due to a $2 billion settlement with US regulators over privacy and data protection. Despite this, revenue increased 28% to $16.9 billion, beating market expectations. The company's monthly user base grew 8% to 2.41 billion, and shares rose slightly after-hours. Facebook's total user base, including Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger, reached 2.7 billion. The company's employee count grew 31% to 39,651, and it continues to invest in security, privacy, and content moderation.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Wednesday reported that its profit in the recently ended quarter plummeted due to costs of a US privacy settlement in a quarterly update that was largely better than expected.

site_title: Hong Kong to name Eddie Yue as next monetary authority chief: report
summary: Hong Kong's Monetary Authority will name Eddie Yue as its next chief executive, succeeding Norman Chan, who retires at the end of September. Yue, a 54-year-old deputy at the central bank, will oversee the city's HK$4 trillion exchange fund and defend the peg to the dollar. The appointment is seen as crucial amid the city's political crisis and underpins stability since 1983. Yue, an advocate of the exchange fund's growth portfolio, will be among the world's best-paid central bankers with a focus on defending the currency peg.

site_title: Delistings on SGX expected to continue in H2 even at higher prices: analysts
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to continue seeing delistings in the second half of 2019, with analysts predicting an average of two companies per month. The trend is driven by persistently low valuations and the shift in power to minority shareholders. Delistings may occur at higher prices, but not beyond what's affordable, according to analysts. Several companies, including SIA Engineering, Unusual, Fu Yu Corp, Frencken Group, and The Hour Glass, are considered ripe for potential delistings due to their low valuations and attractive valuations.

images.alt_text: Singapore's stock market has seen on average two companies a month on track to relinquish their listing status this year. This trend may not be reversing anytime soon.

site_title: First Sponsor Q2 earnings up 24.7% to S$15.1m
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 24.7% increase in net profit to S$15.1 million for the second quarter, driven by increased revenue from property sales and hotel operations. Revenue rose 80.1% to S$79.4 million, with property sales more than quintupled to S$42.2 million and hotel operations revenue increasing 34.4% to S$16.0 million. An interim cash dividend of 1.1 Singapore cents per share has been declared.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPH Trust, First Sponsor, AA Reit, CLT, Citic Envirotech, Sunpower
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Singapore stocks saw mixed developments on Thursday, with Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reporting a 1.4% dip in revenue and First Sponsor Group posting a 24.7% rise in net profit. Aims Apac Reit maintained its distribution per unit, while Cache Logistics Trust saw a 6.9% decline. Citic Envirotech's net profit plummeted 66% due to revenue shrinkage. Sunpower Group announced plans to acquire a 90% stake in a Chinese thermal power plant. Meanwhile, Libra Group requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tesla shares plunge as it reports big Q2 loss
summary: Tesla shares plummeted 10% to $238.39 after the electric carmaker reported a Q2 loss of $408 million, or $1.12 per share, exceeding analyst forecasts. Despite record car deliveries, the company's disappointing earnings led to the share price drop. The loss is attributed to increased production costs and a decline in revenue. The Q2 loss marks a significant setback for Tesla, which has been struggling to achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: Tesla shares plunged on Wednesday as the electric carmaker reported a bigger-than-expected loss despite notching record car deliveries.

site_title: Oil falls 1% despite large US stockpile decline
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures dropping to $63.18 a barrel and US WTI crude futures falling to $55.88 a barrel. Despite a large decline in US crude stockpiles, investors' concerns about slowing global economic growth and weakening oil demand kept prices down. The market structure of contango, where the front-month contract trades at a discount to the second-month contract, also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat ahead of ECB meet; earnings a mixed bag
summary: European shares ended at a two-week high, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.05% ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday. Gains were offset by a 0.7% decline in the FTSE 100 due to miners' losses. Chipmakers, such as Texas Instruments and European chipmakers ASM International, ASM International, Infineon Technologies, and Siltronic, gained between 2.3% and 6.5%. The ECB's signal on support for growth and the US Federal Reserve's response will be closely watched.

site_title: Abandoned Siberian factory could cause Chernobyl-style disaster, warns official
summary: A Russian state official has warned that an abandoned chemicals factory in Siberia poses a significant environmental risk, comparable to the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident. The Usolyekhimprom plant, which produced chlorine and other chemicals, has been abandoned due to bankruptcy in 2017 but still contains toxic substances, including oil waste that could flow into the Angara river. If not addressed, the situation could lead to a major ecological disaster, prompting the official to call for urgent action to prevent an "ecological Chernobyl."

site_title: British PM Johnson overhauls cabinet with Brexit hardliners
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has overhauled his cabinet with Brexit hardliners, replacing most top ministers in an effort to secure a new divorce deal with the EU or leave without one by October 31. Johnson, who has pledged to break the political deadlock, has named Brexit supporters to key positions, including Dominic Raab as foreign minister and Priti Patel as interior minister. However, EU leaders warn they will not renegotiate the existing agreement, and opposition from within the Conservative party and parliament is expected, raising concerns about the viability of a "no-deal" exit.

site_title: Counting down to 2020, Singapore's ocean tankers tests IMO-compliant fuel
summary: Singapore's Ocean Tankers is testing IMO-compliant fuel for its supertanker Pu Tuo San, ahead of stricter marine fuel rules starting January 1, 2020. The new rules prohibit ships from using fuels containing more than 0.5% sulphur, affecting over 50,000 merchant ships globally. Ocean Tankers plans to convert its fleet to burn very low-sulphur fuel oil, with its first vessel to test the new fuel type already loaded with 1,000 tonnes of VLSFO. The company is taking steps to ensure compatibility and stability of the new fuel.

images.alt_text: Off the coast of Singapore, the world's largest ship refuelling centre, a bunker barge sidled next to the supertanker Pu Tuo San to fill the giant vessel with a new type of fuel that will meet global standards that start up in January.

site_title: Titanic explorer to search for Amelia Earhart's plane
summary: Robert Ballard, the explorer who found the Titanic, is planning to search for Amelia Earhart's plane in the Pacific Ocean. Ballard will lead a National Geographic expedition on the research vessel E/V Nautilus, starting from Samoa on August 7. The team will use sonar and remotely operated vehicles to map the ocean floor and search for the Lockheed Electra. The expedition aims to answer the question of what happened to Earhart and navigator Fred Noonan, who vanished in 1937 while attempting a round-the-world flight. The documentary will air on October 20.

site_title: EU urges reforms against flow of dirty money
summary: The European Commission has urged EU reforms to combat dirty money, citing major shortcomings in handling money laundering. A review of 10 cases found banks often failed to comply with anti-money laundering requirements, while watchdogs in member states failed to address shortfalls. The EU estimates that dirty money flows could total over $304 billion annually. The Commission suggests making anti-money laundering rules directly binding on member states and improving banking supervision, and calls for the creation of a fully-fledged EU supervisory agency.

site_title: China steps up investments in automotive industry
summary: China is increasing its investments in the automotive industry, with state-backed Beijing Automotive Group Co (BAIC) purchasing a 5% stake in Daimler AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz. This marks the latest in a series of major transactions, with more than half of the past 11 major deals between Chinese companies and non-Chinese firms occurring in the past two years. The move highlights China's growing role as an investor in the industry, following a period of increased activity in the sector.

site_title: With finger on trigger, ECB aims at more stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to ease policy further, potentially cutting interest rates or restarting a bond-buying program, to boost confidence amid economic uncertainty. ECB President Mario Draghi will likely unveil revamped interest rate guidance, signaling a rate cut and extended low interest rates. The decision comes amid weak economic data and a steady flow of bad news, but policymakers may wait for staff projections in September before making a move, as the deadline for Draghi's tenure approaches.

site_title: Johnson promises Brexit withdrawal deal
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised to achieve a withdrawal deal with Brexit, aiming to end economic uncertainty and "energise" domestic reforms. Johnson, who has a paper-thin majority, plans to make the threat of "no deal" a serious possibility to encourage European Union leaders to compromise. The sticking point in the current withdrawal deal is the Irish backstop insurance deal, which Brexiteers voted against. Johnson's government will face a hostile parliament, including "remain" supporting Conservative MPs, and will need to balance competing demands to deliver Brexit and promote economic growth.

site_title: Top challenges confronting new British leader Boris Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson takes power amidst Brexit uncertainty, the Iran crisis, and economic uncertainty. Brexit remains a pressing issue, with Johnson vowing to renegotiate the divorce deal, but facing opposition from MPs who oppose a no-deal departure. The Iran crisis is heightened due to the seizure of a UK-flagged ship in the Strait of Hormuz, while global economic growth forecasts slow due to Brexit uncertainty and rising trade tensions. Johnson's government faces potential challenges, including a vote of no confidence in Parliament, if he attempts to force through a disorderly Brexit in October.

site_title: North Korea fires 'short range' projectile: US official
summary: North Korea fired a short-range projectile, according to a US official, ahead of US-South Korean military exercises scheduled for next month. The launch was reportedly carried out without warning, and its timing raises concerns about the planned resumption of denuclearization talks between the US and North Korea. The incident comes amid heightened tensions between the US and North Korea, with the US-South Korean exercises seen as a provocation by Pyongyang.

site_title: Changing the way we work and how we view our jobs
summary: Co-working spaces have evolved from no-frills youth-oriented spaces to smart, designer-driven suites with full concierge services, catering to various corporate and family needs. The proliferation of co-working premises has led to a new work culture, with industry-specific spaces emerging for health and fitness-related businesses. According to Dave Lim, the founder of TEDx Singapore, generating conversation and ideas is crucial for Singapore's development, reflecting the shift towards a more flexible and collaborative work environment. This transformation is changing the way we view our jobs and the way we work.

site_title: Euro falls to 2-month low against US dollar
summary: The euro dropped to a two-month low against the US dollar, influenced by weak economic data and speculation about the European Central Bank's potential monetary policy easing. Money markets predict a 54% chance of a 10 basis point rate cut at Thursday's ECB meeting. This move is seen as a response to weak economic data and the bank's efforts to stimulate the economy.

site_title: China's current interest rates at appropriate level: PBOC head
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang said interest rates are at an appropriate level, citing moderate inflation and a need to tackle deflationary risks. Policymakers remain satisfied with the targeted stimulus approach, despite the economy slowing. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will consider a reform to the rate framework, replacing the benchmark lending rate with the Loan Prime Rate, to lower borrowing costs. The PBOC has offered cheap liquidity to the economy, but analysts believe further action is needed to stabilize the economy.

site_title: HPH Trust's Q2 performance hit by global trade tensions
summary: HPH Trust reported a 1.4% drop in revenue and a 20% decrease in net profit to HK$136.5m in its Q2, due to global trade tensions and uncertainties. The trust's management remains cautious about future cargo trends, citing weak outbound cargoes to the US and expected volatility in the second half. The company recommended a distribution rate of 6 HK cents per unit, down from 8.52 HK cents last year.

site_title: Insurtech will improve, not kill, the advisory model
summary: Insurtech is transforming the insurance industry, offering one-click shopping, same-day delivery, and greater personalization. While it may reduce barriers to entry for new disruptors, it's unlikely to kill the advisory model. In fact, digitalization can enhance the role of agents by providing them with tools to efficiently compile complex information and streamline the process. Insurers can adapt by offering a complete omni-channel experience, including easy evaluation methods and direct connections to agents for final purchase decisions. By embracing digital disruption, insurers can meet customers' growing expectations and drive growth.

site_title: At US$437,500, Nike running shoes smash auction record for sneakers
summary: A pair of 1972 Nike running shoes, known as the Nike Moon Shoe, sold for a record-breaking $437,500 at a Sotheby's auction in New York, surpassing the previous record of $190,373 for a pair of signed Converse shoes. The shoes were designed by Bill Bowerman for the 1972 Olympics trials and were the top lot in the first-ever sneaker auction at Sotheby's. The buyer was not immediately known, while 99 other pairs of rare sneakers were bought privately for $850,000 by Canadian car collector Miles Nadal.

site_title: 4G leaders have to grow the trust built by predecessors: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for the 4th generation of Singapore's ruling party leaders to build on the trust established by predecessors, particularly Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. He warned that trust cannot be inherited and must be grown through constructive politics, problem-solving, and community engagement. Heng encouraged PAP activists to give back to society, strengthen communication, and team up with others to promote unity and nation-building.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng notes that the PAP has to keep and grow the people's trust by implementing policies with the longer-term interests of Singaporeans at heart.

site_title: ANZ names Shahaney as head of South-east Asia, India, Middle East
summary: ANZ promotes Vishnu Shahaney to head of South-east Asia, India, and the Middle East, effective August. Shahaney, current president director of PT Bank ANZ Indonesia, will be based in Singapore and report to Farhan Faruqui, group executive of international. The move aims to capitalize on regional growth opportunities, with Singapore remaining a key hub for multinational companies in Asean. ANZ expects Shahaney's experience and customer networks to bring significant value to the bank's business and customers in the region.

site_title: Nissan to cut over 10,000 jobs worldwide, say reports
summary: Nissan plans to cut over 10,000 jobs worldwide, following its previous 4,800 job cuts announced in May, as the company struggles to recover from the arrest of former CEO Carlos Ghosn and declining sales in the US and Europe. The job cuts are likely to affect factories in South America and other low-profit regions. Nissan's net profit fell to a near-decade low in May, with the company forecasting an even worse outlook for the current fiscal year. The decision reflects the firm's struggles in the wake of Ghosn's arrest and a difficult business environment.

site_title: NZ's foreign buyer ban hits house prices in Queenstown
summary: New Zealand's ban on foreign property buyers has led to a decline in house prices in Queenstown, a popular winter resort town. The ban, introduced last October, has reduced demand by a "massive chunk," causing prices to drop 0.1% annually and 2.2% over the past three months. Despite this, the median price remains high at NZ$1.17 million. The ban is part of the government's effort to make housing more affordable for its citizens, but it's unlikely to suppress national prices amid a shortage of new building, continued immigration, and record-low interest rates.

site_title: River Valley hotel plot offers CapLand-CDL integration potential with Liang Court
summary: A site in River Valley Road has been allocated for a hotel development that will be integrated with the Fort Canning MRT Station. This comes as CapitaLand and City Developments Ltd (CDL) recently gained full control of the Liang Court complex, which includes the Somerset Liang Court serviced residence and the Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay hotel. The integration of the hotel with the MRT station is seen as a strategic move, capitalizing on the duo's recent acquisition of the Liang Court complex.

site_title: Singapore's Generation Z won't be mall rats
summary: Singapore's malls, particularly those catering to suburban middle-class consumers, are showing resilience in the face of global online shopping trends. Despite a 0.9% decline in sales, CapitaLand Mall Trust reported a 4% increase in rents on new leases signed or old ones renewed. This is attributed to the success of malls on Singapore's western industrial side, which attract tenants with lower expectations for storefronts. However, the long-term impact of Generation Z's preference for online shopping remains uncertain, with the US-China trade war taking a toll on the city's economy.

site_title: Citic Envirotech Q2 profits dive 66% on falling revenues
summary: Citic Envirotech reported a 66% decline in Q2 net profit to S$14.7 million, primarily due to a 30% decrease in engineering business and 44.7% decrease in membrane system sales. Revenue dropped 30.3% to S$202.8 million. Despite a gloomy macroeconomic environment, the company remains optimistic about China's environmental mandates and expects its hazardous waste treatment capabilities to drive revenue growth. No dividend was declared for the period.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AA Group identified the mysterious shareholder that sold its stake to Haitong International Financial Products after receiving information from the company on July 15. The shareholder was not named, but the matter has been referred to the Monetary Authority of Singapore for investigation. Raffles United Holdings shares were accepted by Teo Xian-Hui Amanda Marie, allowing Raffles Infinity Holdings to consolidate its holdings to 91.06% of Raffles United's total issued shares. Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trusts also changed their financial year-end to December 31 to align with its holding company's change.

site_title: Creditor goes to court to place Epicentre under judicial management
summary: A creditor, Goh Chee Hong, has filed an application with the Singapore High Court to place Epicentre Holdings under judicial management, citing a S$3 million debt. This follows a statutory demand filed by Goh on May 21. Other creditors, including ELush T3 and Kenneth Lim, have also filed demands. The company has instructed its lawyer to review the application and take legal advice. Trading in Epicentre's shares has been suspended since May 30.

site_title: Amazon moves into real estate by teaming up with Realogy
summary: Amazon has partnered with Realogy, the largest US residential real estate broker, to launch the TurnKey programme, allowing homebuyers to connect with Realogy agents through an Amazon portal. Buyers can earn a bundle of Amazon benefits worth up to $5,000, including smart home devices and services, upon closing. The deal gives Amazon a foothold in the real estate market and provides a lifeline for Realogy, which has seen its stock sink 65% this year. TurnKey will launch with 3,000 participating agents in 15 markets, offering a lead-generation programme similar to Zillow's Premier Agent Program.

site_title: Skills Framework for Design to help firms, workers across sectors
summary: Singapore has launched the Skills Framework for Design, a government publication outlining required skills and salary information for design-related job roles across various sectors. The framework covers 25 job roles and 66 skills, including user experience design, business model innovation, and content development. The initiative aims to guide workers and employers in hiring and training for design roles, and to encourage adoption by firms outside the creative design sector. The framework is part of Singapore's industry transformation map and is expected to help the country tackle its greatest future challenges.

site_title: Oil up as industry report shows hefty drop in US stockpiles
summary: Oil prices rose for a fourth consecutive day after the US reported a 10.96 million barrel drop in crude inventories, exceeding forecasts. The International Monetary Fund cut its global growth forecasts, citing policy missteps on trade and Brexit. Despite rising tensions in the Middle East, demand remains shaky, and no imminent breakthrough is expected from high-level trade talks between the US and China. Oil futures gained 0.9% in New York, with West Texas Intermediate rising 21 cents to $56.98 a barrel.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a slight dip in occupancy rates to 97.6% in Q1 FY2020 due to the expiry of a single-user asset in Singapore. However, the Reit saw higher take-rates from China, particularly from JD.com space, and a strong rental reversion of 1.8% from Hong Kong, Vietnam, and China. Analysts at BS Group Research and GS-CIMB retain their buy calls, with target prices at S$1.85 and S$0.61, respectively, citing the Reit's resilient operating metrics and potential for accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Asia phoenix will rise from decoupling of US
summary: The US decoupling from China's economy is forcing investors to reassess their bets, but experts believe a less integrated world dominated by regional trading blocs may not necessarily lead to slower growth. Instead, it could mark a shift towards genuine domestic stories and unique business models in Asia, particularly in China's domestic-led consumption sectors. Regionalisation is seen as a key opportunity, with Asia's GDP growth rates outpacing the US. Experts predict that the US will gradually reduce its linkages with the rest of the world, creating opportunities for Asian countries to shine.

site_title: ISOTeam to buy construction management firms for S$24m
summary: ISOTeam, a CATALIST-listed construction management firm, will acquire Coney International's stake in Pure Group for S$24 million in cash and shares. The deal will expand ISOTeam's capabilities and leverage Pure Group's networks for growth opportunities. The acquisition will boost ISOTeam's overseas expansion, with a presence in Singapore, Myanmar, and Malaysia, and Pure Group's presence in Singapore, the Philippines, China, Malaysia, and Thailand. The conditional sale and purchase agreement can be terminated within 21 business days if certain conditions are not met.

site_title: Cracks in home building sector rattle Australia's economy
summary: Australia's construction sector is experiencing a slowdown, with home building approvals plummeting to six-year lows in May. The decline is affecting the entire supply chain, including land releases, timber sales, and labor hire firms. Layoffs are becoming common, with architects and engineers also feeling the impact. The slowdown is weighing on the economy, which is already growing at its slowest in a decade. The central bank is concerned about the impact on labor market strength and inflation, and interest rates are expected to remain low to stimulate growth.

site_title: US home sales tumble as prices surge to record high
summary: US existing home sales dropped 1.7% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million units, missing expectations. The median existing house price reached a record high of $285,700, up 4.3% from last year. A persistent shortage of properties and rising prices limited home sales, particularly in the entry-level segment. Economists forecast the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates next week to address the slowdown in economic activity.

site_title: Singapore has what it takes to be a fintech hub
summary: Singapore has the potential to be a leading fintech hub, driven by its business-friendly environment, smart infrastructure, and progressive regulations. The country's capital markets volumes lag behind global peers, but initiatives such as the Monetary Authority of Singapore's eFX plans and fintech support programs aim to address this. With digital technology reducing trading costs and increasing access to information, Singapore is well-positioned to thrive in the new technology-driven environment, particularly in attracting specialist technology talent.

site_title: Biopharma revenues have built-in expirations
summary: Biopharma companies face significant challenges due to patent expirations and biosimilars. As patent expirations and biosimilars threaten revenues, scientists must produce expensive, new drugs to maintain revenue growth. With the average cost of bringing a new drug to market increasing to $2.17 billion in 2018, biopharma companies need to innovate and develop new treatments to stay competitive. To address this, companies are adopting collaborative clinical trials, machine learning, and R&D productivity to stay ahead of biosimilars.

site_title: Which Boris Johnson will the new UK PM prove to be?
summary: Boris Johnson has been elected as the UK's new Prime Minister, defeating Jeremy Hunt by 92,153 votes. Johnson's leadership is expected to be tested on two key questions: his ability to deliver Brexit by October 31 and his ability to unite the country. The new PM's character and policies are expected to be revealed as he takes office, with some warning that his "Boris" persona from the campaign trail may not align with his moderate, One Nation approach. Johnson's government faces a challenge to secure a working majority and may face an early general election if Parliament blocks a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: India considers more sugar export subsidies to cut reserves
summary: India is considering additional sugar export subsidies to boost exports and support struggling mills. The government may reimburse exporters for ocean freight and marketing expenses, in addition to existing subsidies for local transport costs and arrears to growers. The measures would comply with World Trade Organization rules. This move comes amid criticism from Brazil and Australia that India's existing subsidies are keeping global prices low and hurting their farmers.

site_title: Working towards a double bottom line
summary: DBS Bank, a Singaporean bank, aims to achieve a "double bottom line" by balancing profit and social responsibility. The bank's approach prioritizes long-term value creation, considering both economic and social outcomes. DBS supports social enterprises through grants, capacity-building programs, and bespoke mentoring. The bank also integrates sustainability principles into its lending activities, providing S$2.4 billion in sustainable financing in 2018. DBS's focus on social responsibility is driven by its guiding ethos, which emphasizes responsibility to society and the environment.

site_title: Market dips 0.1% as growth worries linger
summary: The Singapore stock market closed 0.1% lower at 3,368.44, with the Straits Times Index losing 4.69 points. Losers outpaced gainers, with 223 stocks declining and 194 rising. Market analysts attributed the decline to lingering growth worries despite renewed US-China trade talks, citing the International Monetary Fund's downgraded global growth forecasts.

site_title: Coca-Cola shares bubble up on higher profits
summary: Coca-Cola's second-quarter net income surged 12.6% to US$2.6 billion, driven by robust sales of mini cans in North America. The company increased its profit and revenue targets for the year, citing gains in North America that offset the impact of a strong dollar in overseas markets. The move to sell smaller packages helped reduce the negative impact of consumers rejecting sugary drinks.

site_title: Jollibee in US$350m deal to buy Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf
summary: Jollibee Foods Corp has agreed to spend $350 million to acquire Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf, expanding its global sales by 14% and store network by over a quarter. The acquisition, Jollibee's largest to date, will boost international contributions to 36% of total sales. However, analysts have expressed concerns that the deal may be earnings dilutive, citing Coffee Bean's 2018 loss of 12% of Jollibee's profit. The acquisition is expected to add to Jollibee's global presence and expand its market capitalization.

site_title: China's soybean crushers in no rush to buy from US despite Beijing tariff offer
summary: China's soybean crushers are unlikely to buy large quantities of US soybeans despite a potential exemption from 25% tariffs, as they grapple with poor margins and doubts about Sino-US trade relations. A plan to boost imports was announced, but US soybeans won't be competitive with Brazilian supplies until October, making immediate orders unlikely. China has commitments to buy 20 million tonnes, but the country's demand for soybeans has decreased due to African Swine Fever, and purchases will likely be tied to US policy adjustments, such as lifting sanctions on Huawei Technologies.

site_title: NOVI Health fights chronic diseases person by person, behaviour by behaviour
summary: NOVI Health, a Singapore-based healthtech startup, aims to prevent, manage, or reverse chronic conditions through a holistic approach combining technology, data, and personalized care. Founded by three senior healthcare professionals, the startup offers a physical clinic and a health app, NOVIFY, which provides patients with data insights, customized recommendations, and goal-setting tools. NOVI charges a subscription fee and has partnered with insurers and healthcare providers to offer customized solutions. The startup plans to grow its business-to-business segment and is open to external funding from investors who appreciate its sustainable and impact-driven approach.

site_title: Aston Martin shares plunge 24% on cut in vehicle sales forecast
summary: Aston Martin shares plummeted 24% after the luxury sports car manufacturer reduced its full-year sales forecast by as much as 14%, citing intensifying weakness in key markets. The company now expects 6,300 wholesale deliveries, down from a previous forecast of 7,100-7,300 vehicles. This is the largest decline in Aston Martin's shares since listing in October, with the company joining other manufacturers dialing back expectations due to worsening demand.

site_title: On the right track to improve health of the market
summary: Singapore Exchange's proposed scrapping of the minimum trading price (MTP) for mainboard-listed companies is seen as a positive move to boost market confidence. In 2015, a group of 1,200 stockbrokers signed a letter to Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, recommending the MTP policy's withdrawal due to its potential to sap market sentiment and liquidity. Although the call went unheeded, the proposed scrapping is now being considered, which could lead to improved market health.

site_title: Decentralised Finance in a centralised world
summary: Decentralized Finance (DeFi) is poised to revolutionize the financial sector by automating payments and loans, disrupting the centralized model and reducing costs. DeFi uses blockchain technologies to enable peer-to-peer transactions, reducing intermediaries and increasing efficiency. With low transaction costs and quick finalization, DeFi has the potential to improve micropayments, microloans, and monetization strategies. DeFi lending platforms also offer lower interest rates and reduced counterparty risks, making financial services more accessible, especially in developing markets. However, technical complexity and regulatory uncertainty pose challenges to widespread adoption.

site_title: Yoma Q1 loss widens to US$13.3m on lower real estate revenue, higher finance expenses
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-focused company, reported a net loss of US$13.3 million for its Q1, widening from a US$5.6 million loss last year. Revenue decreased 11.5% to US$18.6 million due to lower real estate development revenues and higher finance expenses. The loss was attributed to a decline in real estate development revenues and increased finance costs.

site_title: Gala event to raise S$600,000 for persons with disabilities and the arts
summary: A fundraising gala, "The Blue Charity Gala", will be held on August 30 at Resorts World Sentosa to raise S$600,000 for persons with disabilities and youth with a passion for the arts. The event, organized by The RICE Company Limited and local charity SPD, will feature performances by the Singapore Police Force Band, Adelyn Koh, and Robert Fernando. Tables are priced at S$5,000, S$10,000, and S$25,000, with donations eligible for 250% tax deduction. The funds will support SPD and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Standard Life, Lloyds settle £104 billion fund dispute
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc and Standard Life Aberdeen Plc have settled a £104 billion fund dispute, with Lloyds paying £140 million in cash as compensation. The assets remaining under management will stay until at least April 2022, comprising £30 billion of passively managed portfolios and £5 billion in real estate funds. The settlement follows an arbitration panel ruling in Standard Life's favour in March, which Lloyds maintained despite. The agreement was a legacy of Aberdeen's acquisition of Scottish Widows Investment Partnership from Lloyds in 2014.

site_title: Joko Widodo courts Softbank, Saudi prince in pursuit of investment
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is courting foreign investment, securing deals with companies like Inpex Corp., Toyota Motor Corp., and SoftBank Group Corp. amid a landslide election win. The government aims to attract $10 billion in investments during a state visit by Abu Dhabi's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, with projects worth $91 billion on the table. To boost investment, Widodo is cutting corporate taxes, easing labor laws, and offering infrastructure projects, including a $412 billion spending plan over five years.

site_title: US increases price for investors seeking green card
summary: The US has increased the price for investors seeking a green card in exchange for a major financial investment.
