site_title: Australia: Shares jump on rising chance of Federal Reserve cuts; New Zealand touches record
summary: Australian shares surged 0.8% on Friday, reaching a 6-week high, after US Federal Reserve comments confirmed a potential rate cut late this month. New Zealand's benchmark index also touched a record high. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,698.9, with heavyweight financials and mining sectors leading the gains. The Fed's dovish remarks boosted gold prices, sending Australian miners to their highest levels in nearly eight years.

site_title: Singapore returning S$50.3m seized in 1MDB probe to Malaysia: Police
summary: Singapore is returning approximately S$50.3 million to Malaysia in connection with the 1MDB financial scandal. The money was seized by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department as part of the probe into the scandal, which contributed to the downfall of Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak. The return of the funds has been approved by the courts, with part of the money already transferred to Malaysia and the rest being processed by the banks.

site_title: Merkel says Brexit can be postponed, hopes for Irish border fix
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said the UK can be given more time to leave the EU if needed, but the Brexit divorce agreement and Irish border backstop cannot be renegotiated. The EU is willing to rewrite a non-binding statement on future trade ties, which could make the backstop obsolete. Merkel's comments come as the UK's next prime minister seeks a more favorable Brexit deal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, rising 0.43% to 28,585.15, following two days of losses. The gains were driven by hopes of a deep interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve later this month. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, adding 0.29% and 0.37% respectively. The move was seen as a positive response to fresh market expectations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, recouping losses from the previous day, after a solid performance on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.44% to 21,137.84, while the Topix index rose 0.27% to 1,538.37. This follows a strong showing on US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Prime US Reit units 1.2 times subscribed ahead of Friday debut, potentially netting it US$346.2m
summary: Prime US Reit, a US office Reit, has received 1.2 times the number of units it originally offered, netting approximately US$346.2 million at US$0.88 per unit. The Reit will debut on the Singapore Exchange mainboard on Friday, with applications exceeding the 335.2 million units offered. The Reit's manager attributed the oversubscription to "market conditions stabilizing" after a long delay from earlier attempts.

site_title: Efforts to develop workforce for digital economy must include workers from all sectors: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized the need for an inclusive approach to develop a workforce for the digital economy, involving workers from all sectors. Over 74,000 training places have been taken up or committed to since the launch of the TechSkills Accelerator in 2016. The government is working with non-ICT trade associations to reach out to workers in manufacturing, accounting, and legal sectors. Iswaran commended companies that support workers' skills and create inspiring cultures, citing examples of companies like ThoughtWorks, M-DAQ, and Web Imp as models for workplace excellence.

site_title: Swine fever sends China's pork prices, imports soaring
summary: China's pork prices and imports have soared due to African swine fever, with over 1.1 million pigs killed or culled. The virus has spread to neighboring countries and is affecting the country's massive pig-farming industry. China is ramping up imports, with shipments from the EU and Brazil increasing, and prices could rise by up to 40% in the next six months. Authorities have implemented strict controls, but experts warn the worst is yet to come, with production and consumption expected to fall.

site_title: China urges citizens to cut consumption of oils, sugar and salt
summary: China is urging citizens to reduce their consumption of edible oils, sugar, and salt as part of a nationwide campaign to minimize health risks. The country aims to limit daily oil intake to 25-30 grams per adult by 2030 and daily salt intake to less than 5 grams per person. Additionally, sugar consumption is targeted to be less than 25 grams per day. The campaign, launched by the State Council, aims to reduce the nation's reliance on unhealthy diets and mitigate health issues such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.21% to 3,368.14
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.21% to 3,368.14 on Friday, driven by stronger US shares and gains in banking stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 48, with AEM Holdings and United Overseas Bank rising 2.7% and 0.5%, respectively. European stocks closed lower, while Asian markets followed Wall Street's lead, with Tokyo shares up 0.44% and the Nikkei 225 index at 21,137.84.

site_title: Prime US Reit makes SGX debut at US$0.865, down 1.7% from offer price
summary: Prime US Reit debuted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at US$0.865 per unit, down 1.7% from its initial offer price of US$0.88. The Reit received 1.2 times the original offer of 335.2 million units. Its initial portfolio includes 11 office properties in the US, and its manager expressed confidence in the market's confidence in the Reit's stable and resilient portfolio. This is the third US office Reit to list on SGX this year, raising US$612 million, and brings the total number of SGX-listed Reits to 45.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on fresh hopes for steep Federal Reserve rate cut
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday after a top Federal Reserve official suggested the central bank may unveil a deep interest rate cut at the end of the month, with Tokyo and Hong Kong leading the gains. The remarks by Vice Chairman John Williams provided insight into the Fed's thinking, putting probabilities of multiple rate cuts higher. Despite concerns about the global economy, the rally was driven by bets on lower rates and a softer US dollar, with oil prices also rising. Analysts, however, warn that the moves may not be enough to support markets, citing the ongoing trade war and economic slowdown.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Changi South former tenant to pay S$2.99m in lease settlement
summary: Sabana Reit's former tenant, Adviva Distribution, is paying S$2.99 million to settle a lease termination at its Changi South Street 2 property. The lease was brought forward to July 18 from December 12 due to a mutual agreement. Sabana Reit does not expect the settlement to impact its distribution per unit for the current financial year. The former tenant had previously paid S$2.15 million to settle outstanding rental arrears and late payment charges.

site_title: Great Barrier Reef agency breaks with Australia government in climate warning
summary: The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has broken with the Australian government, calling for "strongest and fastest possible action" against climate change to save the reef. The agency's study found an urgent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions is needed to protect the reef, which has suffered from back-to-back coral bleaching in 2016 and 2017 due to rising sea temperatures linked to climate change. The reef is a UN-listed World Heritage site, and the agency's warning highlights the need for global action to mitigate the impact of climate change on the reef's future.

site_title: Europe: ECB report eases earnings pain for stocks
summary: European stocks ended lower on Thursday, despite a Bloomberg report suggesting the European Central Bank may adjust its inflation goal, potentially easing monetary policy. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.2%, with technology shares dropping 1.5% after SAP reported a 21% fall in quarterly operating profit. Global markets have been recovering from a May correction, but earnings worries and some stronger economic numbers have weakened sentiment.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon up 0.48% on day as Asia markets rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Friday afternoon up 0.48% to 3,377.10, tracking regional gains. Asian markets rallied after a top Fed official's comments hinted at a deep interest rate cut at the end of the month. Advancers outnumbered decliners 192 to 145, with AEM and Genting Singapore leading gains, while SATS tumbled 5.8% due to a weaker global economy. Banking stocks made gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 1.1-1.3%.

site_title: Taiwan June export orders seen dropping for 8th straight month: poll
summary: Taiwan's export orders are expected to decline for the eighth consecutive month in June, according to a Reuters poll, with a median forecast of a 0.83% drop from last year. This follows May's 5.8% decline and April's 3.7% drop. Soft global electronic demand continues to hurt the island's economy, which relies heavily on exports.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's export orders likely declined for an eighth straight month in June, a Reuters poll showed, as soft global electronic demand continued to hurt the export-reliant island's economy.

site_title: GS Holdings flags 'significantly higher' H1 profit from receipt of China service fees
summary: GS Holdings expects to report a "significantly higher" net profit for the first half of 2019, primarily due to service fees from 14 branding and operation agreements in China, totaling 50 million yuan (S$9.86 million). The company's subsidiary, Wish Hospitality Holdings, entered into the agreements, generating a net amount of 25.7 million yuan after local taxes. This marks a notable improvement from the company's net loss of S$3.55 million in FY2018.

site_title: Icahn launches proxy fight after stalled talks with Occidental CEO
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn launched a proxy fight against Occidental Petroleum, seeking control of four board seats after stalled talks with CEO Vicki Hollub failed to reach an agreement. Icahn owns 4.4% of Occidental shares and opposes the company's $38 billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum, calling it "misguided and hugely overpriced." Icahn's proxy solicitation, which includes four candidates, could force a special meeting of shareholders as early as September or October, potentially influencing the pace and direction of billions of dollars in asset sales resulting from the acquisition.

site_title: US Navy says American sailor missing in Arabian Sea
summary: The US Navy is searching for a missing US sailor who went overboard from the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier in the Arabian Sea. The sailor's identity has not been released. A joint search operation involving ships from Spain, Pakistan, and the US is underway. The incident occurred amid tensions in the region, with Iran detaining a foreign tanker and its crew for allegedly smuggling fuel. The US is seeking to form an international coalition to escort merchant ships through the Gulf, where much of the world's crude oil travels.

site_title: Machine-meshed super-humans remain stuff of fantasy
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink startup claims to have enabled a monkey to control a computer with its brain, but experts say the technology is still in its infancy and far from the futuristic scenario depicted in "The Matrix" films. Neuralink aims to develop a brain-computer interface to cure diseases and enhance human cognition, but experts highlight significant challenges, including the complexity of the brain, the need for long-term testing, and the risk of triggering the body's defenses. Musk's goal is to make the technology as easy to use as laser eye surgery, but experts caution that achieving true symbiosis with artificial intelligence may be a long-term goal.

site_title: Profit soars for Microsoft fueled by cloud, business services
summary: Microsoft reported a 49% increase in net income to $13.2 billion and a 12% increase in revenue to $33.7 billion in its fiscal fourth quarter, exceeding expectations. The company's business services, including cloud computing, drove growth, while Xbox gaming revenue declined 10%. Microsoft's market value surpassed $1 trillion, with analysts praising the company's "strongest commercial quarter ever" and "firing on all cylinders."

site_title: Japan inflation hits 2-year low as BOJ faces pressure to act
summary: Japan's inflation rate hit a 2-year low in June, falling to 0.6% from a year earlier, according to data from the internal affairs ministry. This decline adds pressure on the Bank of Japan to increase monetary stimulus to achieve its 2% inflation target. The Bank of Japan's arsenal is largely depleted, making it challenging to respond to the sluggish prices. Experts attribute the decline to factors such as lower mobile phone service charges, free preschool education, and the Federal Reserve's dovish turn, which has strengthened the yen and reduced import costs.

site_title: Pain from Hong Kong protests spreads as luxury brands get hit
summary: Luxury brands in Hong Kong are feeling the impact of the ongoing protests, with jewelry and cosmetics sales declining by single to double digits. Swiss luxury-goods maker Richemont reported a blow to local sales, while LVMH and Kering SA are set to report first-half earnings next week, potentially revealing the extent of the disruption. The unrest has also affected tourist arrivals, with 350,000 mainland Chinese tourists expected to stay away this year, and flight bookings from Asia falling 5.4% in June. The impact comes at an inopportune time for retailers already facing headwinds from the trade war and global recession.

site_title: Huationg Global settles trademark-infringement lawsuit out of court
summary: HUATIONG Global has settled a trademark-infringement lawsuit with a group of similarly-named but unrelated companies out of court. The lawsuit, filed in January 2018, was related to trademarks registered in the name of HG and its subsidiaries. The plaintiff group alleged HG and its subsidiaries made "certain groundless threats" and defamed them, causing damages. The settlement does not expect to impact HG's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials see prudence of acting early to sustain growth
summary: Federal Reserve officials, including Vice-Chairman Richard Clarida and New York Fed chief John Williams, have expressed the need to act quickly to sustain US economic growth. They suggested that the central bank could cut interest rates by as much as half a percentage point at its July 30-31 policy meeting, citing concerns over softening global economic data and disinflationary pressures. The remarks have bolstered bets for a rate cut, with US money markets pricing in 35 basis points of easing. However, not all Fed officials are on board, with Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic expressing skepticism about lowering rates.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker in plea talks to avoid US trial over 1MDB charges
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, is in plea talks to avoid a US trial on charges related to 1MDB. Ng faces allegations of violating American anti-bribery laws and conspiring to launder money embezzled from Malaysia's state investment fund. Approximately 640,000 documents have been prepared for discovery, but talks have been slowed due to concerns about sensitive material. Ng pleaded not guilty and is charged with crimes carrying a maximum sentence of decades in prison, with a preliminary trial date set for May 11, 2020.

site_title: Japan summons South Korea envoy in escalating row over wartime forced labour
summary: Japan summoned South Korea's ambassador over forced labor compensation, escalating tensions between the two nations. A South Korean man set himself on fire outside the Japanese Embassy in Seoul, sparking a tragic turn in the dispute. Japan's export controls on high-tech materials have threatened the global supply of microchips and smartphone displays. South Korea's Trade Ministry urged Japan to hold serious talks by July 24, calling for the withdrawal of export curbs, but Japan declined to receive the statement. The dispute has soured relations between the US's closest Asian allies, with the US caught in the middle.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SATS, Aims Apac Reit, Sabana Reit, GS Holdings, Metech
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Several Singaporean companies reported earnings or made announcements that may impact their shares. Keppel Corporation's net profit dropped 38.4% to S$153.4 million due to absent en bloc sales gains, while SATS' first-quarter net profit fell 14.4% to S$54.7 million. Aims Apac Reit secured a 10-year master lease for a 268,000 sq ft property. Sabana Reit received a S$2.99 million settlement from a former tenant, while GS Holdings expects higher net profit for the first half. Metech International halted trading pending an announcement. Shares of these companies changed on Thursday before the results were released.

site_title: Southwest Airlines again pushes back 737 Max return date
summary: Southwest Airlines has pushed back its target date for returning the Boeing 737 Max to service to November 2, citing uncertainty about regulatory approval. The domestic carrier had previously revised its schedule to remove the Max through October 1 to ensure reliability and stability. The Boeing 737 Max fleet has been grounded since mid-March following two deadly crashes that killed 346 people. This is the second time Southwest has pushed back its return date, as regulators continue to review the safety of the aircraft.

site_title: PES refinery expected to shut remaining units as crude dwindles: sources
summary: The Philadelphia Energy Solutions (PES) refinery, the oldest and largest on the US East Coast, is expected to shut its remaining units on Monday due to dwindling crude supplies. The refinery is weighing the economics of running more crude to keep units active. This move comes as the US East Coast faces a shortage of crude, with the PES refinery being a key player in the region's energy market.

site_title: Defence questions witness' loss estimate from Prudential agents' mass defection
summary: Defence lawyers questioned expert estimates of future profits Prudential Assurance Co Singapore would forego due to 244 agents' defection to rival insurer Aviva in 2016. Expert witness Larry Rubin projected $300m in losses over 10 years or $2.5b if agents stayed on indefinitely. Defence lawyers challenged these estimates, citing a 2017 report showing Prudential recorded underwriting losses in 2015 and 2016, and questioning how these losses squared with Rubin's estimated profitability.

site_title: Boeing says Q2 earnings hit by US$4.9b in costs on 737 Max
summary: Boeing reported Q2 earnings hit by $4.9 billion in costs due to the 737 Max grounding, affecting profits and production. The grounding, following two crashes, has been in place since mid-March, with the company estimating the planes will return to service early in the fourth quarter. Boeing's CEO stated the company remains focused on safely returning the 737 Max to service, acknowledging significant headwinds and financial challenges.

images.alt_text: Boeing announced on Thursday that second-quarter earnings would be dented by US$4.9 billion in one-time costs to compensate airlines for disruptions due to the grounding of the 737 Max aircraft.

site_title: Court documents tie Trump, Hicks to 2016 hush money payoffs
summary: Court documents link President Donald Trump and former aide Hope Hicks to $130,000 hush money payments to adult film actress Stormy Daniels in 2016. The FBI investigation into the payments, which was closed, suggests Trump and Hicks were involved in arranging the payment. Documents show eight calls between Trump, Hicks, and former lawyer Michael Cohen, as well as text messages, in October 2016. The payments were found to be an illegal campaign contribution aimed at helping Trump win the election. A New York judge ruled the investigation closed, making it unlikely that Trump or Hicks will be punished.

site_title: SGX-backed CapBridge partners Hana Financial to extend reach in S Korea
summary: CapBridge, a private capital platform backed by the Singapore Exchange, has partnered with Hana Financial Investment to expand in South Korea. The tie-up will allow Hana Financial to offer companies and investors more access to private markets through CapBridge's platform. The goal is to make it more convenient for unlisted companies in South Korea to attract overseas investments. Qualified investors will also have access to more foreign private investment opportunities, and Hana Financial aims to create a global investment platform model.

images.alt_text: Lee Jin-kook, (left), with Johnson Chen. While CapBridge's private capital platform handles primary capital raising activities, its affiliate, 1exchange, facilities the trading of private equities.

site_title: Tom Cruise shocks Comic-Con with new Top Gun footage
summary: Tom Cruise surprised the audience at Comic-Con with the world-first trailer for "Top Gun: Maverick," describing it as a "love letter to aviation." The sequel to the 1986 action film has been in the works for many years, and Cruise acknowledged the anticipation from fans. The trailer was unveiled in Hall H, and Cruise expressed his gratitude to those who have supported him in pursuing another "Top Gun" film.

images.alt_text: Tom Cruise swooped into San Diego Comic-Con on Thursday to unveil the world-first trailer for "Top Gun: Maverick," which he described as a "love letter to aviation."

site_title: Central banks should 'act quickly' during 'distress': Federal Reserve's Williams
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice Chairman John Williams advises central banks to act quickly during economic distress, even when interest rates are already low. This stance suggests the Fed may cut interest rates later this month to address a potential economic slowdown. Williams' comments, seen as a sign of preparedness for rate cuts, led to a positive close for the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The remarks also reflect concerns that central banks may not have enough firepower to respond to slowing growth, especially with interest rates already low in major economies.

site_title: SGX to propose scrapping rule on minimum trading price: sources
summary: SGX plans to scrap its minimum trading price (MTP) rule for Mainboard-listed companies, seeking public feedback on the proposal. The rule, introduced in 2016, requires companies to maintain a six-month volume-weighted average share price of 20 Singapore cents and a six-month average daily market capitalisation of at least S$40 million to avoid delisting. The move aims to address the risk of low-priced securities being susceptible to market manipulation and could potentially avert the delisting of up to 54 companies in June 2020.

site_title: Boris Johnson kicks up a stink with Brexit fish tale
summary: Boris Johnson sparked controversy by claiming EU red tape increased the cost of smoking kippers, a British delicacy. However, the EU Commission disputed his claim, stating that the sale of processed fish products like kippers is not covered by EU hygiene legislation. The Isle of Man, where the kippers are produced, has its own laws, which are based on UK and EU regulations. Johnson's claim was labeled "fake news" by EU officials and critics.

site_title: Oil falls about 2.5% as US Gulf production returns
summary: Oil prices fell about 2.5% on Thursday, weighed down by weakness in US equities markets and expectations of rising crude output in the Gulf of Mexico following a hurricane. US Gulf production is set to return, and economic concerns further depressed prices. Brent crude futures settled at $61.93 a barrel, down $1.73.

site_title: Asia's untapped markets for AI-based song analysis is music to Musiio's ears
summary: Musiio, a music technology startup, is poised to capitalize on the untapped Asian market for AI-based song analysis. Founded by music industry veterans Hazel Savage and Aron Pettersson, the company has raised S$1.2 million in seed funding and is leveraging Singapore's strong infrastructure to access markets in South-east Asia, China, and India. Musiio's machine learning-powered engine can analyze music files and assign tags, offering a scalable solution for large music portfolios. The startup plans to focus on the business-to-business (B2B) market initially, with potential expansion into consumer-facing models in the future.

site_title: Indonesia's Astra bets on Gojek as car sales dive
summary: Indonesia's Astra International, the country's largest automobile distributor, has launched a joint venture with ride-hailing firm Gojek to provide cars to the company. The move aims to boost Astra's market dominance despite a decline in car sales. Astra has invested $250 million in Gojek and has contributed $100 million to the ride-hailing firm's $3 billion fundraising round. The partnership, called "GoFleet," will help Gojek compete with rival Grab in Indonesia.

site_title: Indonesia pledges more rate cuts as it moves to spur growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 5.75% for the first time in almost two years. This move aims to support the country's growth, shifting focus from inflation control. The decision was in line with most economists' forecasts. The central bank has pledged more easing measures to come, indicating its commitment to stimulating the economy.

site_title: US destroys Iranian drone in Strait of Hormuz: Trump
summary: The US military shot down an Iranian drone in the Strait of Hormuz on Thursday, with President Donald Trump stating that the drone was "threatening the safety of the ship and the ship's crew." The USS Boxer took defensive action, destroying the drone immediately. This incident comes amid mounting tensions between the US and Iran, with the US having imposed sanctions on Iran. Trump called on other nations to condemn Iran's actions and protect their ships in the region.

site_title: Arnie 'addicted' to Terminator as original Sarah Connor returns for sequel
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger will reprise his role in the upcoming "Terminator: Dark Fate" due to his "addiction" to the franchise. Linda Hamilton, who originated the role of Sarah Connor, returns after careful consideration, citing her life experience as enriching the character. The film, directed by Tim Miller, will ignore alternate timelines and follow Sarah Connor as she deals with the consequences of destroying the shadowy Cyberdyne system. James Cameron, producer and director of the original two films, confirmed Schwarzenegger's return and Eddie Furlong's reprisal of John Connor.

site_title: Italy's warring coalition parties warn of government collapse
summary: Italy's coalition government is at risk of collapse after the League and 5-Star Movement leaders exchanged recriminations over the European Commission presidency election. The League voted against German candidate Ursula von der Leyen, while 5-Star supported her, leading Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio to warn of a lack of trust. League leader Matteo Salvini accused 5-Star of betraying voters and threatened to quit the government if no progress is made. Italy's markets appear calm, with bond yields at their lowest level in almost three years, but political instability remains a concern.

site_title: Beauty World Plaza's second en bloc try ends with no takers
summary: Beauty World Plaza's second en bloc attempt at S$165 million failed to attract buyers, moving into a 10-week private treaty period. The 24,817 sq ft mixed-use development, located in Upper Bukit Timah, has in-principle approval for redevelopment to serviced apartments. Several new developments will be built in the area, including an integrated transport hub and a one-stop facility. The owners are keeping the reserve price at S$165 million, with the land rate at S$2,189 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: BMW names new boss as it looks to speed up electric transition
summary: BMW has named Oliver Zipse as its new CEO, replacing Harald Krueger in August. Zipse will accelerate the German auto giant's transition to electric cars, a move seen as a response to criticism of Krueger's leadership. Krueger, who had stated he would not seek another term, had been criticized for not steering the company quickly enough towards electric technology. Zipse's appointment aims to speed up BMW's electric transition, marking a significant shift in the company's strategy.

site_title: Japan's June exports fall 6.7% for 7th straight decline
summary: Japan's exports fell 6.7% in June for the seventh consecutive month, pressured by Sino-US trade frictions and slowing China growth. This decline, along with a three-year low in Japanese manufacturers' business confidence, has raised concerns about the country's export-led economy. The Bank of Japan is expected to roll out more stimulus, joining the US Federal Reserve in signaling additional monetary stimulus amid deteriorating global conditions. The ongoing US-China trade negotiations and heightened global uncertainty also weigh on corporate spending.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit completes 80.3m euro purchase of 3 French office properties
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has completed the acquisition of three freehold office properties in Greater Paris for 80.3 million euros, bringing the total cost of its French acquisitions to 246.9 million euros. The properties, valued at 23,066 sq m, are located in the Ivry-sur-Seine office district and have a 4.7-year weighted average lease expiry. The acquisition was funded through a mix of new shares and a private placement, with 71.4 million euros used to partially fund the purchase.

site_title: Investor offers S$48m convertible loan to TT International instead of assets buy
summary: TT International, a mainboard-listed company, has accepted a S$48 million convertible loan from Celestial Palace instead of buying assets. The loan will fund a new restructuring scheme, allowing the company to resolve unsustainable liabilities and restructure its balance sheet. The scheme excludes the company's 51% subsidiary Big Box Singapore, which has been voluntarily liquidated. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since 2017, and the new scheme is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

site_title: UBS unveils 3rd edition of Future of Finance Challenge contest in Singapore
summary: UBS has launched its third edition of the Future of Finance Challenge competition in Singapore, inviting innovators and fintechs to address challenges in transforming banks and the future of finance. Ten participants per region will be selected to attend in-person regional finals, with the opportunity to present ideas and solutions globally, win cash prizes, and receive coaching from UBS experts. The competition deadline is August 15, 2019, with a focus on topics such as technology enablement, smart risk management, and tokenized assets.

site_title: The Zen Life
summary: A Singaporean couple, who have been married for three years and have visited Japan four times, incorporated Japanese aesthetics into their newly purchased home. Unlike other homeowners who prefer a hotel look, they chose a unique design inspired by Japan. The couple, who work in advertising technology and chemistry, decided to create a space that reflects their love for Japan.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher after dovish Fed comments
summary: US stocks ended higher on Thursday after a top Federal Reserve official's dovish comments shifted attention from mixed earnings. New York Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams said central banks should "act quickly" to address economic weakness, boosting expectations of a potential interest rate cut later this month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 27,222.97, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. Despite a strong consumer sector, vulnerability in the manufacturing sector and mixed earnings reports weighed on some stocks, including Netflix's 10.3% decline.

site_title: How to make innovation work
summary: Business leaders can improve innovation processes by establishing a programme, corporate venture fund, or open innovation ecosystem that empowers diverse thinkers. Implementing effective screening processes, such as the Stage-Gate approach, can help convert ideas into successful innovations. Leveraging external sources, like crowdsourcing and partnerships, can also drive innovation. Examples of successful innovation processes include Lego's open innovation ecosystem and Oxfam's Future Shapers initiative, which engage diverse stakeholders and facilitate idea generation. By enhancing innovation value chains, companies can create a culture of innovation and capture new value, ultimately driving growth and competitiveness.

site_title: China Energy to expand ultra-low emission coal-fired power: official
summary: China Energy Group, the country's largest power generator, plans to add over 6 GW of ultra-low emission coal-fired capacity this year and 5 GW next year. The company aims to gradually shut down small and polluting units and replace them with efficient ones. China Energy will also launch another carbon capture and storage (CCS) project in northwest China next year. The move is part of the country's efforts to reduce pollution and tackle global warming, with China aiming to peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and raise non-fossil fuel energy share to 20% by 2030.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Triyards Marine Services has been ordered to wind up by the court, following an application by creditor Tractors Singapore. The liquidators, Joshua James Taylor and Yit Chee Wah, were appointed to oversee the winding-up process. The move comes after Tractors Singapore filed the application on October 3, 2018, and Triyards Marine Services had also received statutory demands from Taiwanese lender CTBC Bank and a supplier. The company had previously received US$14.6 million in statutory demands.

site_title: Fostering a shared sense of purpose
summary: A Good Space, a community of social changemakers, organized the second edition of A Good Day, an event that brought people together to expand perspectives on diverse social issues. Activities included expressing relationships with death through art, learning about food waste, and playing games to deepen empathy towards specific groups. The event aimed to foster a shared sense of purpose among participants, promoting social change and community engagement.

site_title: A Great Way to Fly
summary: This article highlights eight travel essentials that frequent travelers swear by, including lightweight luggage, a belt bag, travel-friendly suit, travel wallets, sweatpants, smart sneakers, aromatherapy blends, and oversized scarves. Brands such as Rimowa, Ermenegildo Zegna, Aspinal, and Hermès offer durable and stylish options that cater to different needs and preferences. These items are designed to make traveling more convenient, comfortable, and stylish, allowing jet-setters to focus on their next adventure.

site_title: Orangutan numbers drop 30% in M'sian palm oil estate forests: WWF
summary: Orangutan populations in Malaysian oil palm estate forests have declined by up to 30% in 15 years, with 650 individuals lost in protected areas between 2002 and 2017. Despite this, the overall population of around 11,000 orangutans in Sabah remains stable. WWF attributes the decline to the monoculture nature of oil palm plantations, which do not support species dependent on forest environments like orangutans.

site_title: COE supply for Aug-Oct to shrink significantly
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply for the August-October quota period will shrink by 16.5% to 4,904 a month, due to a record number of motorists extending the lifespan of their old cars this year. This is the smallest supply in the past decade, making it challenging for vehicle buyers.

site_title: SATS Q1 net slips 14.4% on macro headwinds
summary: SATS, a Singapore airport and food services provider, reported a 14.4% decline in first-quarter net profit to S$54.7 million due to weaker global economic conditions. Revenue rose 5.8% to S$465.1 million, driven by growth in gateway services and food solutions segments. Cargo volume fell 1.6% due to global trade uncertainties. Despite this, the company aims to strengthen its market leadership through network expansion and digitalization.

site_title: Beach Party
summary: Sentosa GrillFest returns with 27 establishments serving over 130 food and drink options, including a 3m-tall tepee BBQ pit and a GrillFest Gelato Bomb. The event, held over four weekends from July 19 to August 12, features exclusive drinks and activities like movie screenings by the beach. To reduce single-use plastics, guests are encouraged to bring reusable utensils and containers. Payments will be made via credit and EZ-Link cards, and the event promotes a zero-waste future.

site_title: Special Feature: Hotels of Substance
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group, a Singapore-listed hotel chain, has been recognized as "Best Regional Hotel Chain" and owns or manages over 40 hotels across 25 cities. The company prioritizes sincerity and authentic experiences, offering unique features such as Local Experiences and human-centric design. New properties, including Pan Pacific London and Pan Pacific Orchard, are set to open in 2020 and 2021, respectively. The group is committed to environmental sustainability, aiming to eliminate single-use plastics by the end of 2019 and becoming the world's first zero-waste hotel in 2021.

site_title: Truckmaker Volvo lifts market forecast amid higher deliveries
summary: Volvo, the world's second-largest truckmaker, raised its market forecasts for North America and Europe due to higher truck and construction equipment deliveries, beating profit estimates. The company partnered with Samsung to develop battery packs for its electric trucks. Volvo expects truck demand in Europe to be flat this year, a reversal of its previous forecast of a 6% decline, while North America is expected to see a 5% increase. The company will adapt production to a potential market slowdown in the second half of the year.

site_title: Clash Of The Football Titans
summary: Premier League giants Manchester United, Tottenham Hotspur, Juventus, and Inter Milan will participate in the International Champions Cup in Singapore this weekend. United and Inter will face off in a sold-out match on July 20, while Spurs will take on Juventus on July 21. This marks the return of top-tier football to the National Stadium, last hosting the event in 2017 when Inter won the tournament. Fans can book tickets online at www.sportshub.com.sg.

site_title: Asia markets dip on growth concerns
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing down 0.11% at 3,361.05. Weak earnings from CSX Corp and the Bank of Korea's interest rate cut weighed on sentiment. US President Donald Trump's remarks on US-China trade talks also raised concerns about global economic growth. However, some stocks, such as Tee International and AEM Holdings, saw gains, with AEM Holdings surging 5.77% after an upgrade to "add" by CGS-CIMB research.

site_title: 2019 Audi Q3 review: A long Q is building
summary: The second-generation Audi Q3 has been redesigned to offer a more mature and spacious experience, with a 4.5-meter length and increased interior room for rear passengers. The Q3 now features a 12.3-inch virtual instrument display, a 10.1-inch touchscreen, and a familiar Audi design language. The model tested has a 1.5-liter turbocharged engine, delivering neutral handling and chassis behavior. Despite feeling underpowered on the autobahn, the Q3 is efficient and competent, making it suitable for Singapore's roads. The Q3 is priced at S$168,800 with COE.

site_title: New Mazda 3 review: A sculptural sedan
summary: The Mazda 3 Sedan has been reviewed, praising its sleek and elegant design, along with its smooth driving experience. The sedan offers more boot space and a longer length, making it ideal for practical buyers. The 1.5-litre engine variant with a mild hybrid system provides a fuel efficiency of 5.5L/100km. The car's extensive driver and assistance systems, available on the Elegance pack, make it stand out in its class, offering features like lane departure prevention and automatic following. The Sedan is available in Singapore, priced at S$103,688 with COE, offering solid value despite being pricier than the hatchback.

site_title: Pharrell Williams' manga mania
summary: Pharrell Williams has curated an exhibition at the Guimet Museum in Paris, "A Call To Action", featuring vibrant and chaotic manga-style artwork by Japanese visual artist Mr. The exhibition, which took five years to create, imagines a post-apocalyptic world led by young children who have taken up arms against the failures of adults, including climate change and gun regulation. Williams, a collector of Mr's work, sees the exhibition as a call to action for the young generation to make better decisions. The exhibition marks Williams' second collaboration with Mr, who has worked with the singer on various projects in the past.

site_title: Frenzy over SembMarine shares fizzles out day after near 8% gain
summary: SembMarine shares fell 1.3% to S$1.49 after a brief surge of 7.86% on Wednesday due to unusual trading activity. The company denied knowledge of undisclosed information that may have caused the unusual price movements, citing possible media reports and rating updates from stock broking firms. SembMarine is currently under investigation in Brazil for bribery, but the company maintains it is in compliance with listing rules and will issue announcements if material contracts are secured.

site_title: China's tech giants use Internet to deliver smart health services
summary: China's tech giants, including Ping An, Alibaba, and Tencent, are building advanced health ecosystems to meet the growing demand for healthcare services. The industry is expected to reach $1.6 trillion in revenues by 2020, driven by rising incomes and life expectancies. However, the healthcare system faces challenges such as an aging population, chronic diseases, and a lack of primary care. Tech giants are addressing these issues through online consultations, AI-assisted screening and diagnosis, and telemedicine, which can reduce waiting times and costs. The Ping An Good Doctor portal, for example, connects patients with medical service providers and payers, and employs over 1,000 medical experts and 5,000 external doctors.

images.alt_text: Alibaba has an AI diagnostic system called DoctorYou, which assists doctors in their diagnosis and decision-making. It also operates an AI-assisted processing system called ET Medical Brain.

site_title: 33 people die in arson attack on studio in Japan
summary: Thirty-three people died and 36 were injured in an arson attack on a Japanese animation studio in Kyoto, Japan, on Thursday. The suspect, a 41-year-old man, shouted "die" as he doused the building with fuel. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called the incident "too appalling for words" and offered condolences to the victims' families. It was Japan's worst mass killing since a 2001 arson attack, and the studio produces popular series such as Sound! Euphonium. The suspect was injured and being treated in hospital, and police arrested him.

images.alt_text: Smoke billowing from the building's charred windows. Police arrested a 41-year-old man who had shouted "die" as he poured what appeared to be petrol around the three-storey Kyoto Animation building shortly after 10 am.

site_title: Sunny outlook for US economy despite shade thrown by trade
summary: The US economy showed a "modest" growth rate despite concerns over trade-related uncertainty, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report. Employment continued to expand, with tight labor markets and employers boosting wages to $15 an hour to compete for entry-level workers. However, businesses reported difficulties securing and renewing work visas and adapting to supply chain and tariff issues linked to a weakened global economy and Trump administration policies. The Fed is expected to reduce interest rates at its upcoming meeting, with some officials questioning whether a rate cut is needed.

site_title: Takashi Murakami, Artist
summary: Takashi Murakami's art exhibition at STPI in Singapore drew hundreds of fans, many of whom waited in line as early as 6am. The exhibition, which featured merchandise including a $1,800 giant stuffed toy, sold out in under an hour, with fans becoming emotional upon learning of the toy's unavailability. This frenzy is reminiscent of the 2017 Yayoi Kusama exhibition, with no reported incidents of tears. The exhibition marked a rare instance of Murakami being mobbed, despite his international renown and commercial success.

site_title: Helpful words that demystify wine appreciation
summary: A wine expert argues that overly specific descriptions of wine can be confusing and fail to capture the essence of the beverage. Instead, he advocates for general characterizations, such as a wine being energetic, tense, or plush, to convey its overall impression. Key terms, including energetic, tense, plush, lean, structure, tannins, linearity, length, depth, focus, power, precision, life, sweetness, savoury, and mineral, are defined to provide a framework for describing wine. These terms aim to capture the complexity and nuance of wine, rather than relying on technical jargon.

site_title: Indie Sounds
summary: The Observatory is set to return with a special two-day event, BlackKajiXtra - Nusasonic, on July 20 and 21 at The Substation. The experimental music series, conceived by the band themselves and local distro Ujikaji, will feature performances and panel discussions. The Observatory's new lineup, led by drummer Cheryl Ong, will explore wordless territories and atonalism with influences from post-punk to free improv and experimental electronics. Tickets are available through Peatix.

site_title: Twinkle Stars
summary: The Singapore International Jewelry Expo is set to run from July 18 to 21 at the Marina Bay Sands Expo & Convention Centre. Over 230 exhibitors from 26 countries will showcase over $150 million worth of jewelry, priced from $300 to $3 million. Highlights include a $3 million ring featuring a 27-carat diamond and a two-gem necklace combining a 26-carat sapphire and 12-carat emerald. The event is expected to attract designers, collectors, and fashion enthusiasts worldwide.

site_title: Dean & DeLuca battles to survive as sales fall
summary: Dean & DeLuca, a US-based gourmet grocer, is struggling to survive amidst stalling sales and a competitive landscape dominated by bigger rivals. The company has shut several US locations, leaving only four company-operated stores, and is facing financial difficulties, including unpaid supplier bills and a significant debt-to-equity ratio. Despite its success in Asia, the US operations are being reorganized to stem losses, and the company's owner has announced plans to inject capital to fix the business and pay obligations.

site_title: NTU, Rolls-Royce to deepen ties in Phase 2 of corporate lab
summary: Singapore's Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Rolls-Royce are set to deepen their ties in the second phase of their corporate lab, aiming to develop innovations in the aviation sector. The collaboration will focus on energy storage solutions for hybrid-electric aircraft, potentially reducing carbon emissions by 30%. This move aligns with the global aviation industry's goal of becoming more efficient and environmentally sustainable.

site_title: NY-listed 8x8 pays US$125m for Singapore-based Wavecell
summary: US-based cloud provider 8x8 has acquired Singapore-based communications platform-as-a-service provider Wavecell for approximately US$125 million in cash and stock. Wavecell, with over 500 enterprise customers in the Asia-Pacific region, offers SMS, chat apps, video interaction, and voice solutions to enhance customer experience. The acquisition provides 8x8 with an established technology platform and a high-growth revenue business to pursue CPaaS globally, expected to quicken 8x8's revenue growth and have minimal impact on its fiscal 2020 non-GAAP pre-tax loss.

site_title: Special Feature: The Art Of Travelling In Style
summary: Luxury guided holidays have evolved from traditional coach touring, offering discerning travelers a more refined and stress-free experience. Companies like Insight Vacations and Luxury Gold are experiencing a 15% rise in bookings, with travelers seeking premium experiences, safety, and security. Guided holidays now offer flexibility, VIP access, and dedicated concierges, catering to diverse traveler styles, including multi-generational families and solo travelers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported Q2 2019 results that met expectations. The company secured WeWork Singapore as a new tenant for its 21 Collyer Quay property, with a seven-year lease starting in early Q2 2021, lifting the overhang on the property. This comes as HSBC's lease expires in April 2020. The news was welcomed by analysts, who maintain their "SELL" rating with a target price of S$1.92.

site_title: Bank of Korea cuts interest rate as growth slows amid trade risks
summary: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate to 1.5% from 1.75%, citing slowing economic growth and inflation forecasts. The central bank now expects the economy to grow 2.2% this year, down from 2.5% in April. The rate cut reflects growing pressure as the nation's export-dependent economy slows and other central banks cut rates or signal they will soon. The US-China trade war, Japan's export controls, and China's economic slowdown have also contributed to the decision, with policymakers citing financial stability as a concern.

site_title: Australia's Lendlease bags Google project worth US$15b
summary: Australia's Lendlease Group secured a US$15 billion contract with Alphabet's Google to develop residential and retail space in Silicon Valley. The deal sent the builder's stock to its highest in over 8 months. This comes as Australian developers face a challenging domestic property market, characterized by a drop in building approvals and tighter consumer spending. The contract is a significant boon for Lendlease, providing much-needed revenue at a time of economic uncertainty.

site_title: Fashion for hire: Americans go for rental services
summary: US women are increasingly turning to clothing rental services, ditching the need to buy and store expensive, often-worn-only garments. The trend is expected to disrupt the traditional fashion industry. Companies like ThredUp and Rent the Runway are leading the way, offering affordable and stylish options for special occasions. As the sector grows, it's raising questions about the future of fast fashion and the environmental impact of frequent purchases.

site_title: 2019 Porsche 911 review: Iconoclast
summary: The 2019 Porsche 911 has undergone significant revamps, including a new engine, redesigned interior, and improved performance. Despite changes, the car's timeless design and familiar shape continue to appeal to traditional fans. The new 911 boasts 450 horsepower, a quicker steering rack, and improved handling. The interior offers enhanced comfort and amenities, while the exterior design maintains a recognizable and iconic look. The 992 model is available in two versions, Carrera S and Carrera 4S, both offering impressive performance and stability.

site_title: Japan-Korea spat spurs worries of 'never seen before' chip price spike
summary: A dispute between South Korea and Japan over chipmaking materials has led to a surge in memory chip prices, with prices rising 15% in just a week. The price jump has sparked fears of a "never seen before" chip price spike and supply disruption, with Japan's curbs on exports of key materials putting pressure on South Korea's dominant chipmakers, Samsung and SK Hynix. Industry sources warn that the ban could lead to a shortage of DRAM and NAND chips, benefiting companies like Micron and Western Digital, but potentially hurting Samsung and SK Hynix.

site_title: Gold is making a comeback to the world financial system
summary: Gold is making a comeback to the world financial system, with central banks and countries repatriating gold reserves, and China increasing its holdings to at least 8,000 tonnes. The US wants to maintain its fiat dollar system, but some US insiders, including former World Bank president Robert Zoellick, have called for a return to the gold standard. China's growing gold reserves and potential joint US-EU-China gold revaluation could lead to the largest monetary changes since the 1971 closure of the gold window, challenging the US dollar's dominance.

site_title: The challenge of upward mobility
summary: Young people face an uphill battle in upward mobility due to rapid asset inflation and a changing economy, challenging traditional assumptions of each generation being better off than the previous one. Entrepreneurs and experts share insights on navigating the market, utilizing big data, and avoiding data-related pitfalls. Meanwhile, a new interview with Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino and a look at male menopause are featured in the Health page. The article highlights the need for adaptability and new approaches to success in today's economy.

site_title: The Frequent Flyers
summary:
Four individuals, a financial advisor, a vice-president of marketing, an entrepreneur, and a CEO, share their passionate travel pursuits. 

Paul Grinberg, a 58-year-old financial advisor, is on a mission to dine at all top-rated restaurants globally, having traveled to five continents, 35 countries, and 138 cities. He has faced challenges, including a two-year wait for a reservation at Sushi Saito, but values the experiences.

Geraldine Dreiser, a vice-president of marketing, travels for leisure about eight times a year, seeking new cultures and destinations. Her memorable vacations include sailing in Komodo Island, chasing the Northern Lights, and hiking the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu.

Benjamin Goh, an entrepreneur, and his wife Cynthia travel to Europe every year, visiting factories and dining at Michelin-starred restaurants. They prioritize experiences over tourist attractions and have become friends with chefs from their favorite restaurants.

Beatrice Liu, the CEO of Oriental Remedies Group, fulfilled her childhood dream of a "white Christmas" in Europe in 2017. She enjoyed experiencing local Christmas markets and traditional Austrian culture, including a family-owned farm dinner in Bavaria.

site_title: Will the global debt bomb explode again in an era of low interest rates?
summary: The global debt has reached nearly 320% of world GDP, totaling US$246.5 trillion, and is a major concern for potential economic recession or worse. Borrowing has driven economic growth, but excessive borrowing can lead to default or spending reductions. Countries have varying debt tolerance levels, with the US showing a relatively high tolerance for borrowing. Low interest rates have helped sustain the global economy, but economists warn that the worst is yet to come, particularly with emerging market countries' debt nearing expiration and high debt levels at some firms.

site_title: Keppel Q2 profit drops 38.4% in absence of project en bloc sales
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 38.4% drop in net profit to S$153.4 million in Q2, primarily due to the absence of en bloc sales gains. Revenue rose 17.2% year-over-year to S$1.78 billion. The conglomerate declared an interim dividend of 8 Singapore cents per share, down from 10 cents previously. Despite this, the property division was the top earnings contributor, and the company's asset management business contributed 40% of net profit.

site_title: Can Bentley's 100th birthday present to itself ward off doom?
summary: Bentley celebrates its 100th anniversary with the unveiling of the EXP 100 GT, an experimental vehicle showcasing the brand's vision for luxury touring in 2035. The car features sustainable materials, including a 5,000-year-old material, organic waste textile, and recycled rice husks, highlighting the artisanal human element in bespoke coachwork. The EXP 100 GT also boasts autonomous driving capabilities, with a steering wheel and pedals to maintain a driver-focused experience. The car aims to redefine sustainability beyond environmental concerns, emphasizing human skill and provenance of materials.

images.alt_text: The EXP 100 GT is an experimental vehicle that straddles the luxurious world of its grand past, and a future full of disruptive tech that might not even have a place for private cars.

site_title: South-east Asia's meth gangs making US$60b a year: UN study
summary: A UN study found that South-east Asia's methamphetamine gangs are generating over $60 billion annually, with seizures of the drug tripling over the last five years. The majority of the meth originates from Myanmar's Northern Shan State and is laundered through casinos and smuggled to neighboring markets, including Australia and Japan. The report warns that this is fueling an addiction crisis and driving down street prices.

site_title: Malaysian police say political leader behind videos
summary: Malaysian police have identified a leader of a political party behind videos purporting to show a Cabinet minister, Tengku Azizan Abdul Zahrin, engaged in sex with another man. The minister is seen as a potential successor to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The police did not disclose the party or the leader's name. The allegations were made public on Thursday, July 18, 2019.

site_title: 2019 Honda Civic review: Rice to the occasion
summary: The 2019 Honda Civic review praises the car's driving experience, citing its taut chassis, ease of handling, and turbocharged engine providing brisk acceleration. The facelift brings minor cosmetic changes, but the most significant upgrade is the addition of physical buttons for infotainment and climate control. The Civic is considered a top choice for those who prioritize driving pleasure, but its price tag of S$121,999 puts it in competition with other models like the Volkswagen Golf and Mazda 6. A more affordable 1.6-litre option is recommended for those seeking value and simplicity.

images.alt_text: The Civic 1.5 Turbo sails through corners effortlessly thanks to its engine. It may only be 1.5 litres in displacement, but turbocharging gives it a meaty 173 horsepower and 220 Newton-metres of torque.

site_title: Dollar falls for a second day on US rate cut bets
summary: The US dollar fell for a second day against its rivals, losing 0.1% to 97.09 against a basket of its peers, as investors expect a potential 25-50 basis point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve next week. Despite this, the euro remains hemmed in a narrow trading range around the US$1.12 level, awaiting a potential European Central Bank response. Other currencies, such as the Australian dollar, rose following a solid jobs report.

site_title: Chefs' Top Tables
summary: Several prominent chefs share their favorite dining spots around the world. Tristin Farmer, executive chef of Zén, praises Parisian restaurants like Septime and E.DEHILLERIN for their exceptional food and hospitality. Chef Rishi Naleendra, owner of Cheek Bistro and Cloudstreet, recommends dining at award-winning Royal Mail Hotel in Australia and SingleThread Farm in California. Chef Han Li Guang of Labyrinth raves about Nihonryori Ryugin in Tokyo for its emphasis on top-notch produce and traditional techniques. Meanwhile, Petrina Loh of Morsels enjoys Tokyo's Sushi Masa Ishibashi and Kyoto's Restaurant Kabi, while Cynthia Chua of Spa Esprit Group seeks out Le Suquet in France for its exceptional cuisine.

site_title: Does renewables pioneer Germany risk running out of power?
summary: Germany's shift away from nuclear and coal power, aimed at reducing carbon emissions, may pose a risk to the country's energy security. In the next three years, conventional energy capacity is expected to fall by a fifth, potentially leaving it short of peak power demand. Utilities and grid firms have expressed concerns about the reliability of renewable energy supply, storage, and network infrastructure, which could lead to power outages and economic losses.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit secures master tenant for Tuas property
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) secured a master tenant for its 3 Tuas Avenue 2 property, a global medical device company occupying approximately 268,000 square feet on a 10-year triple net lease basis. The lease provides an estimated initial net property income yield of 7.3%. The redevelopment project, originally projected for the second half of 2019, is now expected to be completed in the first half of 2020, with a revised estimated development cost of S$48.2 million.

site_title: India regulator proposes tighter disclosure for auditors
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) proposed tighter disclosure requirements for auditors of listed companies, following a series of high-profile resignations. The regulator aims to improve investor confidence and provide reliable information for financial decisions. Proposed guidelines include disclosing reasons for auditor resignation, audit committee views, and details of unobtained information. SEBI also recommends that auditors complete the audit of a financial year before resigning, and issue limited reviews or audit reports for incomplete audits. The proposals will be open for public comment by August 8.

site_title: Don't fight artificial intelligence, work with it instead
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a scholarship program for postgraduate students studying artificial intelligence in Singapore, aiming to harness the technology's potential for customer value and business scalability. Amid concerns about AI's darker future, such as job losses and lack of regulation, experts emphasize the technology's benefits in humanitarian research and its potential to alleviate laborious jobs. Instead of fearing AI, it's suggested that Singapore focus on defining its relationship with the technology, working alongside it to facilitate productivity and human empathy, and embracing its potential to solve humanity's greatest challenges.

site_title: US consumer comfort rises to fresh high amid robust job market
summary: US consumer comfort has reached an 18-year high, with the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index rising to 64.7 in the week ended July 14. This is due to a robust job market and equities, with unemployment near a half-century low and the S&P 500 index surpassing 3,000. Retail sales and factory output topped estimates in June, further supporting optimism about the US economy. The comfort index for buying climate and personal finances also reached record levels, with several demographic groups experiencing increased sentiment.

site_title: India queries Chinese app TikTok after call for ban by Hindu group
summary: India's IT ministry has asked Chinese video app TikTok to explain how it collects user data and promotes safe use of its platform, amid calls for a ban by a Hindu nationalist group. The group, linked to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party, alleges poor privacy protection by TikTok's developer, Beijing Bytedance Technology Co. The IT ministry has also asked for details on measures taken to prevent obscene content and create awareness among children and parents. TikTok plans to invest $1 billion in India over the next three years.

site_title: Japan has become 'developing country' in AI race: SoftBank
summary: Japan has become a "developing country" in the AI race, according to SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son. He stated that there are limited investment opportunities in Japan and that few Japanese companies can be considered global number one unicorns, unlike in the US, China, and India. With a limited pool of IT engineers, Japanese tech firms are looking overseas for talent, and SoftBank's Vision Fund has largely overlooked Japan in favor of these countries. Son urged Japan to "wake up" to this new reality and catch up in the AI field.

site_title: YuuZoo asks for its trading suspension to be lifted
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group, a Singapore-based social commerce player, has made a second request to have its share trading suspension lifted. The suspension was imposed 16 months ago due to concerns over the company's financial statements. YuuZoo claims it has provided all necessary information and can trade on a fair, orderly, and transparent basis. The company faces "major challenges" due to the suspension, including a massive project in China and significant financial losses.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Netflix plunges
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday as Netflix plummeted, kicking off earnings for the FAANG group on a sour note. The Dow Jones fell 0.10%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.19%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.41%. This marks a negative start to the earnings season for tech giants, with Netflix's decline leading the way.

site_title: Japan urges G7 to think beyond existing rules in dealing with Libra
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso urged G7 counterparts to reassess Facebook's Libra digital currency for new challenges beyond existing regulations, citing concerns over anti-money laundering and data security. Policymakers fear widespread adoption could upend the financial system. Despite concerns, there was no consensus on regulating Libra, but G7 members agreed it poses a problem for consumer data protection and monetary policy. The global economy is expected to recover by next year, according to the G7 assessment.

site_title: Regulators must begin to gauge challenges FB's Libra may raise
summary: Facebook's Libra digital coin has sparked concerns among regulators due to its potential to destabilize global currencies and upend the financial system. Despite its altruistic mission to provide access to financial services, lawmakers and experts have raised concerns over Libra's volatility, lack of proven solutions, and potential misuse. The US Federal Reserve, Treasury Secretary, and lawmakers have expressed serious concerns, and some are seeking to outlaw Libra. Regulators must begin to gauge the challenges Libra may raise, particularly in terms of anti-money laundering and systemic risk.

site_title: United pushes Boeing for '797' decision as Max crisis drags on
summary: United Airlines is pressuring Boeing to provide details on its proposed new jetliner, the "797," as the planemaker works to revive its 737 Max. The airline is considering replacing 130 older B-757 and 767 aircraft with a new model, but is waiting for clarity on Boeing's plans. Meanwhile, Airbus is rolling out its A321XLR, a longer-range version of its A321neo, which is gaining traction with airlines. United's decision on replacing its older planes is expected to be made soon, but the timeline for Boeing's new jetliner is uncertain.

site_title: Carlos Acosta's company makes Singapore debut
summary: Carlos Acosta's dance company, Acosta Danza, is set to make its Singapore debut at the 14th edition of the da:ns festival in October. Acosta, a renowned Cuban ballet dancer, will perform alongside Israeli dancer-choreographer Hofesh Shechter in a mixed bill of two duets and two group pieces. The festival also features a street dance programme with acts from Taiwan and Japan, as well as local dancers participating in the Sixteen da:ns Challenge. Other highlights include performances by Filipino choreographer Eisa Jocson, Austrian dance dramaturg Raimund Hoghe, and Southeast Asian artists Raka Maitra, Ming Poon, and Pichet Klunchun.

site_title: Paris orders schools near Notre-Dame cleaned over lead fears
summary: Paris authorities have ordered a deep clean at schools near Notre-Dame Cathedral due to lead contamination fears. A report by Mediapart found high levels of lead in schools and creches surrounding the cathedral, with one school showing 10 times the safe limit. The Paris health official said the risk is minimal, but environmental groups warned of potential health risks, including neurological defects and kidney problems, for children and pregnant women. The cleaning is aimed at reassuring residents, particularly children, about the risk of lead pollution.

site_title: Airbus closes in on Air France jetliner deal
summary: Airbus is close to a deal worth billions to sell A320neo-family and A220 aircraft to Air France. The deal could include 50-70 A220 jets and 40 A320neo jets to replace Air France's ageing fleet. Airbus declined comment on the deal, expected to be discussed at an Air France-KLM board meeting. Air France-KLM has not made a decision on the deal, but is pursuing a medium-haul fleet renewal.

site_title: Self-driving tech slams into wall of human behaviour
summary: Detroit and Silicon Valley had envisioned thousands of self-driving taxis in 2019, but progress has been slower and more costly than anticipated. Several carmakers and tech companies, including Ford and Volkswagen, are teaming up to tackle the challenge. Researchers attribute the delay to human behavior, citing unpredictable situations such as cyclists riding the wrong way down streets and street sweepers suddenly turning corners. Despite 80% of the technology needed to put self-driving cars into routine use developed, the remaining 20% will be difficult to solve, with companies like Waymo and GM now expecting to roll out thousands of self-driving cars in the future but with no clear timeline.

site_title: Singapore 'Fort Knox' maximum-security vault said to be up for sale
summary: Singapore's maximum-security vault, known as Le Freeport, is up for sale after its Swiss owner, Yves Bouvier, embroiled in a five-year legal battle with a Russian tycoon, Dmitry Rybolovlev, sells assets. The facility, which opened in 2010, has reported accumulated losses of $18.4 million and has cut rental rates to attract new tenants. A buyer would inherit a debt of $20 million to DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank. The vault, designed to store fine art, precious gems, and gold, has seen a decline in demand due to economic slowdown and China's clampdown on luxury spending.

images.alt_text: A file photo from 2010 of what was then the Singapore Freeport. Le Freeport, as it is now known, has been seeking a buyer since as far back as 2017 - so far without success.

site_title: South Korean political leaders vow to work together to resolve Japan dispute
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in and leaders of major political parties pledged to work together to resolve the ongoing dispute with Japan, which includes restrictions on high-tech materials and a wartime labor dispute. The leaders agreed to mitigate the economic impact of Japan's export curbs and strengthen South Korea's tech industries. They also warned Japan not to remove South Korea from its "white list" of countries with minimum trade restrictions. The meeting comes as tensions between the two neighbors escalate, with South Korea's approval ratings rising amid growing anti-Japan sentiment.

site_title: SGX-backed CapBridge partners Hana Financial to extend reach in South Korea
summary: CapBridge, a private capital platform backed by the Singapore Exchange, has partnered with Hana Financial Investment to expand in South Korea. The partnership aims to provide more access to private markets for unlisted companies and investors in the country, making it easier for them to attract overseas investments. Hana Financial will offer companies and investors in South Korea access to CapBridge's private capital ecosystem, while also creating a global investment platform model. The partnership reflects Hana Financial's intention to increase exchanges with overseas investors, resulting in more investment opportunities.

site_title: Volvo Cars defies slowing market to hit record sales
summary: Volvo Cars reported a record 340,286 car sales in the first half of the year, a 7.3% year-on-year jump, defying a slowing global auto market. Sales revenue rose 5.9% to 130 billion Swedish kronor. However, operating profit fell nearly 30% to 5.5 billion Swedish kronor due to increased pricing pressure and tariffs. Despite this, CEO Hakan Samuelsson noted the company's strong growth and implemented cost controls to mitigate the effects in the second half of the year.

site_title: Defence lawyers question estimated losses from departure of Prudential agents
summary: Defence lawyers for Peter Tan Shou Yi questioned expert estimates of Prudential Assurance Co Singapore's future profits lost due to 244 agent departures. They questioned the discrepancy between estimated losses (2015-2016) and future profitability estimates (made by Larry Rubin). This relates to a lawsuit by Prudential against Tan for allegedly instigating the defection of agents to rival Aviva. The defence lawyers aim to challenge Prudential's claims of compensation.

site_title: UK lawmakers back bid to hamper a no-deal Brexit
summary: British lawmakers have backed proposals to make it harder for the next prime minister to force through a no-deal Brexit by suspending parliament. The measures include requiring parliament to be sitting to consider Northern Irish affairs and fortnightly reports on progress towards re-establishing the executive. This could make it difficult for a future prime minister to bypass parliament, despite a plan to leave the EU on October 31. The Office for Budget Responsibility warned that a no-deal Brexit could compound a recession, with a 2% contraction expected by the end of 2020.

site_title: Classy omakase by female chef
summary: Chef Akane Eno's Ichigo Ichie, a weekly private dining concept at Sushi Kimura, offers a unique omakase experience. Eno, a female sushi chef, takes over the kitchen on Mondays, showcasing her skills and warm hospitality. The $250 ticket price yields a carefully crafted, complex menu featuring Edomae delights, including a prawn and tomato cocktail, shrimp stock, and Hokkaido abalone. Chef Eno's guiding principle is to cook what she likes to eat, resulting in a memorable dining experience. With its impeccable food and sincere demeanour, Ichigo Ichie is a must-visit for food lovers, and Eno's talent deserves a permanent space.

site_title: Dubai's big spenders tighten purse strings
summary: Dubai's luxury shopping scene is experiencing a downturn, with the city's affluent population reining in spending due to lower oil and property prices. The Gate Avenue mall, a symbol of Dubai's opulence, was largely empty at peak shopping time, marking a shift from its former status as a hub for high-end shoppers. This decline reflects a broader slowdown in the retail economy in the Middle East's leading shopping capital.

site_title: Netflix plunges most in a year after stumble on customer growth
summary: Netflix reported a significant drop in US customers, losing 130,000 subscribers, and slower growth overseas, missing forecasts by roughly half. The company blamed higher prices and a weak TV show lineup for the decline, but analysts say it's a temporary setback. Despite this, Netflix expects to add 7 million subscribers in the current quarter, driven by popular shows like "Stranger Things" and "Orange Is the New Black." The company's shares plummeted 11% to their lowest in a year, raising concerns about its ability to compete with emerging streaming services.

site_title: Britain's easyJet hires Ryanair's operations chief
summary: Britain's easyJet hires Ryanair's operations chief Peter Bellew as its new chief operating officer, effective immediately. Bellew is stepping down from Ryanair at the end of the year after previously serving as the airline's CEO from 2017. This move comes as easyJet reported quarterly trading in line with expectations.

site_title: Archaeologists find mosque from when Islam arrived in the holy land
summary: Archaeologists in Israel discovered the remains of a 7th-8th century mosque in the Bedouin town of Rahat, near the Negev desert. The Israel Antiquities Authority estimates it's one of the world's oldest rural mosques, predating larger mosques in Jerusalem and Mecca. The ancient mosque is believed to have been a local farmers' congregation, making it rare to find a house of prayer of this age. The discovery provides new insights into the early history of Islam in the holy land.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.60 points to 1,648.93. The market saw 2.8 billion lots traded worth RM1.8 billion, with 561 losers beating 287 gainers.

site_title: Malaysian police say political leader behind gay sex tape allegations
summary: Malaysian police have identified a leader of a political party as the person behind videos purporting to show Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali engaged in sex with another man. The videos, allegedly of Azmin, were widely distributed via WhatsApp and were described by police as a "nefarious plot" to end his career. The police did not identify the party or leader, but Azmin claimed they were a "wicked alliance" within his own party. The scandal has deepened rifts within the ruling coalition and raised concerns about a turbulent transition of power.

site_title: Spiritual Retreats
summary:

Several luxury wellness retreats offer unique experiences in various locations, including Indonesia, New Zealand, Japan, and Cambodia. Nihi Sumba in Indonesia features treehouses and ocean villas, while Aro-Ha in New Zealand offers week-long hiking and yoga programs. Hoshinoya Tokyo provides a digital detox in the city, while Six Senses in Cambodia offers LED therapy and sacred energy medicine sessions. Other retreats include Sense Spa in Laos and Yufuin Tamanoyu in Japan, offering traditional ryokan experiences.

site_title: US labour market still strong; mid-Atlantic factory activity rebounds
summary: The US labour market remains strong despite moderate increases in unemployment benefits applications, with initial claims rising 8,000 to 216,000 for the week ended July 13. Factory activity in the mid-Atlantic region rebounded sharply in July, offering hope for the struggling manufacturing sector. The four-week moving average of initial claims dipped to 218,750, suggesting steady job growth this month. Layoffs remain low, but concerns about a shortage of workers and the Trump administration's tougher stance on immigration could impede job growth.

site_title: Thirty feared killed in arson attack on Japanese animation studio
summary: Thirty people were feared dead in an arson attack on a Japanese animation studio in Kyoto, Japan, on Thursday. A 41-year-old man was arrested after dousing the building with fuel, shouting "die" as he did so.
