The dollar-denominated, physically deliverable contracts are traded on Singapore's Asia Pacific Exchange, offering longer trading hours than other exchanges. This development is seen as a challenge to Malaysia's long-dominant benchmark contract, which has traditionally controlled the palm oil futures market.

site_title: Best World gets SGX nod on expanded independent review
summary: Best World International has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX RegCo) to expand its independent review, which was initially ordered due to concerns over its sales in China under an export model from 2015 to 2018. The review will examine potential breaches of listing rules, internal control weaknesses, and corporate governance practices. Independent reviewer PwC will report its findings to SGX RegCo, and Best World will disclose key findings. Trading in the company's shares remains suspended until the investigation is completed.

site_title: Retail tranche for Prime US Reit IPO set at 40.9m units
summary: The manager of Prime US Reit has set aside 40.9 million units for public subscription in its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, exceeding the minimum offer size of 16.8 million units. Following strong demand, every valid application was successful, with successful applicants receiving their full allotment. Prime US Reit has an initial portfolio of 11 office properties with a total appraised value of US$1.2 billion, and trading is expected to start on the mainboard on July 19.

site_title: Higher chance of no-deal Brexit sends sterling to 27-mth low
summary: Sterling plummets to a 27-month low against the dollar, hitting a six-month low against the euro, amid the UK's Brexit uncertainty. The pound's weakness is fueled by the two candidates vying to become Britain's next prime minister, both taking a harder Brexit stance. This has led markets to price a higher risk of a no-deal Brexit, potentially forcing the Bank of England to cut interest rates. The pound's fall extends even after employment data showed a rise in average weekly earnings, but labor market strength is attributed to temporary hiring.

site_title: Singapore Shopping Centre on en bloc market with S$255m reserve price
summary: Singapore Shopping Centre puts itself on the collective sale market with a reserve price of S$255 million. The seven-storey retail and office development spans 2,449.8 sq m and is zoned for commercial use under DMP19 with a plot ratio of 4.2+. The area is expected to undergo rejuvenation with redevelopment plans for Park Mall and pedestrianisation of Orchard Road. This is the first collective sale of a residential development in 2019, with the buyer purchasing the five-unit Sophia View on Sophia Road for S$10 million.

site_title: Spider-Man tops US box office for second week
summary: Spider-Man: Far From Home holds the top spot at the US box office for a second consecutive week, earning an estimated $45.4 million. The film has now grossed $847 million worldwide. Toy Story 4 takes second place with $20.9 million, while debut films Crawl and Stuber round out the top three. Other debut films include a romantic comedy about a musician remembering the Beatles and Men in Black: International, which bring up the rear of the top 10.

site_title: Trump says he wants review of Google's ties to China
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to review Google's ties to China, following unsubstantiated claims by tech billionaire Peter Thiel that the company had worked with the Chinese government or military. Google denied these allegations, stating it does not work with the Chinese military and has limited business operations in China. Trump has previously criticized Google for its withdrawal from a Pentagon contract and has accused the company of "bias" against him and his supporters.

site_title: Irn-Bru maker AG Barr sinks on profit warning
summary: British soft drinks maker AG Barr warned of a 20% decline in profits this year due to higher prices and lower sales. The company's shares plummeted 33% to an eight-month low of 601 pence, citing challenges from the sugar tax and declining soda sales. AG Barr plans to launch new products but expects the impact to be felt until the second half of the year. The company's profit forecast was cut to £36 million from £46.6 million, with rival Britvic and Fevertree also experiencing lower shares.

site_title: Indon VAT on online products and services
summary: Indonesia is drafting new rules to impose Value-Added Tax (VAT) on online products and services provided by offshore companies, aiming to tap into the country's growing digital market. The tax authority sees VAT as a low-hanging fruit, but requires new implementation rules to apply it to digital transactions. The new rules would target e-commerce, content providers, and startups, with authorities looking to learn from Japan and Australia's experiences with digital taxes. The move is expected to generate significant revenue from the country's internet economy, which reached $27 billion last year and is projected to grow to $100 billion by 2025.

site_title: Lower rates might hurt the dollar but boost gold
summary: The price of gold has remained stable despite global turmoil, largely due to the strength of the dollar and stock market. However, some market strategists believe that lower interest rates could hurt the dollar and boost gold prices, potentially reaching $1,500 an ounce by the end of next year. Despite underperforming in recent years, gold mutual funds have shown some resilience, with the SPDR Gold Trust returning 1.77% over the last three years. Georgette Boele, a currency strategist, predicts a massive sell-off of the dollar could drive gold prices up, but warns that expectations of rate cuts are already factored into gold valuations.

site_title: Sembawang site put up for sale to pilot dementia-care village
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for a 30-year lease site in Sembawang, Singapore, to pilot a dementia-care village. The site, comprising 10 state bungalows on two plots of land, will be used to provide a safe and home-like environment for residents with dementia. Tenderers will submit concept proposals and prices separately, with the selected concept aligning with the vision for the dementia-care village, which aims to provide tailored services and programmes to create meaningful participation and social interactions among residents.

site_title: Oil market crisis looks averted - for now
summary: The oil market crisis appears to have been averted, at least temporarily, due to a shift in the type of crude being pumped out of the ground globally, which has reduced supplies of high-sulfur fuel oil. Refineries are now producing more middle-distillate fuels, and shipowners are increasingly using scrubbers to burn high-sulfur fuel oil without breaking the rules. However, demand for high-sulfur fuel oil is still expected to be high, and prices are expected to slump, with some analysts predicting a discount of up to $30 per barrel to Brent crude.

site_title: Nissan bets on new driverless sports car to heal image after Ghosn scandal
summary: Nissan unveiled a new version of its Skyline sports sedan, featuring its most advanced autonomous driving technology and design elements shared with the GT-R sports coupe. The car is part of Nissan's efforts to revive its business after a scandal and will be sold for between $45,000 and $52,000. The Skyline's hybrid version will include Nissan's ProPilot autonomous system, offering lane-changing and driver monitoring functions. The move comes as Nissan faces pressure to introduce new products and refresh core models, with CEO Hiroto Saikawa spending $440 million over three years on new products.

site_title: Data lull sees quiet day on Singapore bourse
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% higher at 3,360.03, driven by a rebound in real estate investment trusts (Reits) after six consecutive days of decline. Trading volume was 1.17 billion securities, with CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Keppel DC Reit among the top performers. Investors remain cautious ahead of US Fed comments and critical data releases, including US retail sales and industrial production numbers for June.

site_title: Memtech's proposed delisting gets SGX nod
summary: Memtech International has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to delist from the mainboard, subject to the completion of a compulsory acquisition by its controlling shareholders, the Chuang family. The delisting is deemed unnecessary as the offeror has control of over 90% of Memtech shares, allowing them to unilaterally determine the outcome of a delisting resolution. The offer price of S$1.35 per share represents a 23.9% premium over Memtech's last traded price.

site_title: Lagarde resigns as IMF chief, cites more clarity on ECB post
summary: Christine Lagarde, International Monetary Fund Managing Director, announced her resignation effective September 12, citing more clarity on her nomination to be European Central Bank President. Her resignation follows her nomination two weeks ago, which is subject to European Parliament approval. Lagarde's second five-year term at the IMF would have ended in July 2021, and her departure is expected to expedite the selection of her successor.

site_title: Gender diversity key to improving corporate governance
summary: A gender-balanced workforce is crucial for improving corporate governance and performance, according to research. Women's different sensibilities and perceptions can counterbalance prevailing attitudes and "group-think" tendencies, leading to richer debates and better decisions. Despite being under-represented on corporate boards, women are driving the growth of gender lens investing, which targets investments in companies that promote gender equality. Assets in gender-based investment vehicles have more than doubled to $4.65 billion, and investors are seeking gender parity and financial returns. Companies that prioritize gender equality are more likely to outperform their peers, as seen in RobecoSAM's Global Gender Equality Impact Equities Investment Strategy, which has consistently outperformed the benchmark since its inception.

site_title: ECB may mull over bank-bond buying
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may consider buying senior bank bonds, a move that could help banks weather a further rate cut, at its next policy meeting. Despite previous reluctance due to potential conflicts of interest, the ECB may pair a rate cut with purchases of senior bank debt to benefit lenders in weaker economies. This move could expand the universe of eligible notes and benefit banks with significant upcoming issuance needs. However, concerns over conflicts of interest, the erosion of the collateral principle, and potential disruptions to other ECB programs remain.

site_title: Big banks beat profit expectations but warning signs grow
summary: US big banks JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup reported strong earnings despite warning signs that lower interest rates may pressure their bottomlines. JPMorgan lowered its net interest income outlook, while Wells Fargo saw a decline in net interest margins. The banks' consumer business remained buoyant, offsetting weakness in other areas. Goldman Sachs, the least rate-sensitive of the three banks, performed well, with shares rising 1.3%. The Fed's potential interest rate cut in July is a concern, with investors worried it could impact bank margins.

site_title: HK retailers forecast sharp drop in sales as protests rock city
summary: Hong Kong retailers forecast a double-digit drop in sales for July and August due to ongoing protests, which have gripped the city for over a month. The protests, sparked by a proposed extradition bill, have led to violent clashes between protesters and police. The retail industry is concerned about the impact on Hong Kong's international image and expects a decline in mainland tourists. The Hong Kong Retail Management Association urges the government to resolve the dispute peacefully to mitigate the economic impact. Sales are expected to fall by double digits for the full year, contrary to initial forecasts of single-digit growth.

site_title: EU braces for no-deal Brexit or another delay under Boris Johnson
summary: The European Union is bracing for a no-deal Brexit or another delay if Boris Johnson becomes UK prime minister, pledging to renegotiate a deal the bloc says will not be reopened. EU leaders are concerned about the impact on the $18.7 trillion economy and are ramping up pressure on Ireland to prepare for a no-deal exit, which could disrupt financial markets and trade. The EU will not renegotiate the Brexit deal, and a no-deal Brexit could lead to recession, undermine euro zone growth, and weaken London's financial claim.

site_title: S Korea accuses Japan of 'lukewarm' stand on N Korea
summary: South Korea has accused Japan of a "lukewarm" stance on implementing UN sanctions against North Korea, amid a worsening dispute over labor compensation for South Koreans forced to work for Japanese occupiers during World War II. Japan restricted exports of high-tech materials to South Korea, citing "inadequate management" of sensitive items, but South Korea claims Japan is trying to avoid implementing sanctions. The dispute has strained relations between the two US allies, with a court case seeking to force Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to compensate South Korean forced laborers set to escalate tensions.

site_title: UK PM candidate Johnson could send lawmakers away to go for no-deal Brexit
summary: UK PM candidate Boris Johnson may send lawmakers home for up to two weeks in October to prevent them from blocking a no-deal Brexit on October 31. This plan, reportedly being considered by the Johnson campaign, would make lawmakers "unavailable" to stop the Brexit before the deadline. Johnson is also looking at scheduling a Queen's Speech in early November, which could further limit lawmakers' ability to block a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Prime US Reit sets public offer at 40.9m units, cites 'strong demand'
summary: Prime US Reit has set a public offer of approximately 40.9 million units, exceeding the minimum offer size of 16.76 million units, due to "strong demand" from retail investors. 2,708 valid applications for over 42.3 million units were received, with those applying for up to 100,000 units receiving full allotment. The Reit's units will trade on the mainboard starting July 19 at US$0.88 per unit, representing a 7.4% distribution yield in 2019.

site_title: India planning roadshows for Air India sale: sources
summary: India plans to invite expressions of interest to sell Air India Ltd by the end of August, aiming to complete the transaction this year. The government will conduct roadshows and meet prospective buyers before the expressions of interest are sought. Bidders will be able to view Air India's accounts and share purchase agreement, except for confidential portions. The process is expected to allow buyers to assess the airline's financials and operational readiness for sale.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Reit reported a Q2 FY 2019 earnings of 1.39 Singapore cents, in line with expectations. Property income declined 22.7% due to a high base from one-off income in Q2 FY2018. The Reit manager has extended debt maturity and managed interest costs, with S$105 million in capital gains available for distribution or share buyback. Analysts maintain positive views on the Reit's Singapore office portfolio and share price.

site_title: US retail sales increase solidly in boost to economy
summary: US retail sales increased 0.4% in June, beating expectations and indicating strong consumer spending. The strong gain in core retail sales, excluding autos and other volatile items, suggests an acceleration in consumer spending in the second quarter. This could help counteract weak business investment and support the economy. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates by 50 basis points at its July meeting, as signs of rising inflation and strong consumer spending suggest the central bank may instead act to protect the economy from risks such as the trade war with China.

site_title: N Korea warns US-South Korea drills will affect nuclear talks
summary: North Korea warned that US-South Korea military drills could impact nuclear talks between Pyongyang and Washington, potentially leading to a reconsideration of its moratorium on nuclear testing. The joint drills, scaled down to facilitate dialogue, were agreed upon after US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's historic meeting in June. The statement from Pyongyang was the first on the talks since their resumption, raising concerns about the impact of the drills on the negotiations.

site_title: Taiwan asks HK, China to help fight US$30m online love scams
summary: Taiwan has urged China and Hong Kong to cooperate in investigating a US$30 million online love scam that targeted Taiwanese victims, with over 500 people affected since January last year. Suspects based in China and Hong Kong used social media to lure victims into investing in fake financial companies, with losses totaling over US$30 million. Taiwanese authorities are seeking cooperation from Hong Kong and China police for a joint investigation, citing the need for continued efforts to combat cross-border fraud despite recent tensions between the three administrations.

site_title: Singapore Shopping Centre put on collective sale market for S$255m
summary: Singapore Shopping Centre has put itself on the collective sale market with a reserve price of S$255 million. The seven-storey retail and office development spans 2,449.8 sq m, zoned for commercial use. The area is expected to undergo rejuvenation with redevelopment plans, including pedestrianisation of Orchard Road and green space connections. The tender closes on September 9.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Shopping Centre, located opposite Dhoby Ghaut MRT, has put itself on the collective sale market with a reserve price of S$255 million.

site_title: Could Canada provide a Brexit breakthrough for the UK?
summary: Canada's landmark bilateral trade agreement with the EU, the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), could serve as a model for a potential UK-EU deal, but it comes with significant costs for the UK. A Canadian-style deal would allow the UK to leave the EU's Customs Union and Single Market, but it would also require the UK to establish new trade agreements with other countries, potentially leading to a "hard Brexit." The agreement does little to facilitate business sectors like financial services and does not eliminate border controls. While some Brexiteers argue that negotiating a Canadian-style deal would be relatively easy, the talks have been challenging, with a near-complete breakdown in 2016. The UK's current membership in the EU provides a unique position with access to the Single Market, budgetary rebates, and the ability to make its own trade agreements.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit posts Q2 DPU of 1.5 US cents
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.5 US cents in its Q2 2019, lower than forecasted 1.58 US cents, but higher than its actual Q2 2018 DPU. The company reported 23.4% higher income available for distribution and 29.3% higher gross revenue due to contributions from recent acquisitions. Net property income climbed 27.9% to US$18 million. Unitholders will receive their distributions on September 25, 2019.

site_title: Vodafone launches 5G in Germany, challenges Deutsche Telekom on price
summary: Vodafone launches 5G services in Germany, offering cheaper deals and reaching more cities than market leader Deutsche Telekom. The network will cover 25 cities, 25 municipalities, and 10 industrial parks by the end of this year, reaching 10 million users by 2020 and 20 million by 2021. Vodafone's 5G plans start at 14.99 euros per month, while Deutsche Telekom's unlimited plan costs 85 euros. Vodafone's goal is to "democratize" 5G, making it accessible to a wider range of consumers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble in early deals
summary: Europe's stock markets experienced minor fluctuations on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 7,535.57 points and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also increasing 0.1% to 12,400.64 points. The Paris CAC 40 remained flat at 5,576.78. The markets seemed to shrug off concerns, focusing on sectors like mining and healthcare.

site_title: Boeing Max crisis hits airline growth as Ryanair pares plans
summary: Ryanair Holdings Plc has scaled back growth plans for next summer due to the extended grounding of Boeing's 737 Max plane, citing a reduced fleet of 58 planes instead of 104 initially expected. The airline expects a 5 million passenger reduction and will cut its growth rate to 3% from 7%. Boeing's certification package for the Max is still uncertain, with a possible return to service in December. This decision highlights the significant fallout for airlines, which typically plan six months in advance, and may benefit earnings by easing excess seating and bolstering prices.

site_title: US manufacturing output climbs for second month in June
summary: US manufacturing output rose 0.4% in June, the second consecutive month, driven by a 2.9% increase in motor vehicle and parts production. This eased concerns about the US factory sector's strength in a slowing global economy. Despite recent gains, the manufacturing sector is down 2.2% for the second quarter, its largest quarterly decline since 2016. The sector's capacity utilization rate climbed to 75.9% in June, but overall capacity utilization remains 1.9% below its 1972-2018 average.

images.alt_text: US manufacturing output accelerated in June, climbing for the second straight month, thanks in large part to increased production of motor vehicles and parts.

site_title: IMF: Singapore's financial sector oversight among world's best, but 2019 growth outlook is weaker
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reaffirmed Singapore's financial sector oversight as "among the best globally" in its third financial sector assessment program (FSAP). The country's economic fundamentals are strong, and its policies are sound, with a resilient financial system and healthy buffers to withstand severe shocks. However, the IMF lowered its 2019 economic growth forecast for Singapore from 2.3% to 2% due to global trade tensions and a deceleration of global growth. The country's central bank forecasts growth between 1.5% and 2.5% this year.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reaffirmed Singapore's financial sector oversight to be "among the best globally", and described the country's economic fundamentals as strong, and its economic policies as sound.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.43 points to 1,668.94. The market saw 3.3 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 444 to 413.

site_title: Small District 9 condo sold in 2019's first residential collective sale
summary: A five-unit condo building in Singapore's District 9, Sophia View, was sold in June 2019 for an undisclosed price, with each unit valued at around S$2 million. The buyer, a private investor, plans to keep their options open and may redevelop the land or submit for change of use. This sale marks a rare transaction in Singapore's residential collective sale market, which has remained quiet despite recent tenders. The sale is seen as a sign of potential upside in the area, with the buyer taking a long-term view of the market.

site_title: Singapore Auditor-General flags lapses in procurement, contracts, IT controls in public sector
summary: The Auditor-General's Office of Singapore has flagged several lapses in the public sector, including weaknesses in IT controls, procurement, and contract management. The Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, Ministry of National Development, Ministry of Defence, and Ministry of Manpower were identified for lapses, including irregularities in contract approvals, procurement processes, and IT system security. The Ministry of Finance has responded by launching initiatives to address these issues, including producing a good practice guide and automating IT tasks.

site_title: French minister resigns in luxury dinners scandal
summary: French Environment Minister Francois de Rugy resigned after reports accused him of extravagant spending, including luxury dinners, sparking a "media lynching." He filed a defamation complaint against Mediapart, which published the accusations. President Emmanuel Macron asked Prime Minister Edouard Philippe for "full clarity" on the matter. De Rugy cited the pressure on his name as reason for his resignation, which he presented to Philippe.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly lower after mixed bank reports
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 9.84 points, or 0.04%, to 27,349.32, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opening lower. This decline came after mixed quarterly reports from JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Wells Fargo. The drop was attributed to the mixed bank reports, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

site_title: China says misleading to suggest it needs trade deal due to slowing economy
summary: China's Foreign Ministry denied the notion that Beijing needs a trade deal with the US due to slowing economic growth, stating its economy was "not bad". Following a tweet by US President Donald Trump, China's economic growth cooled to 6.2% in the second quarter, its weakest pace in at least 27 years. China's spokesman, Geng Shuang, said the US tariffs were having a "major effect" on China's economy, contradicting Trump's claim.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prudential sues former top agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi for up to S$2.5b over alleged poaching of 244 agents. Singapore's financial sector is deemed resilient with healthy buffers, according to the IMF. Weaknesses in public sector procurement and IT controls were flagged by the Auditor-General's Office. The Singapore Exchange approved Memtech International's proposed delisting. The Straits Times Index added 12.08 points, or 0.4%, to close at 3,360.03.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.4% in a ho-hum Tuesday session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to close at 3,360.03, driven by a rebound in real estate investment trusts (Reits) and modest gains in local banks. Trading volume was 1.17 billion securities, below the daily average in the first six months of 2019. The benchmark index had eight of its 30 components closing in the red, with Genting Singapore being the most traded stock. The market's cautious tone was attributed to the upcoming Fed speakers and critical US data releases.

site_title: Powell concession on too-tight Fed underlines shift towards cuts
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell conceded that monetary policy may have been tightened too much, citing an underestimated shift in the US economy. This admission suggests the central bank may cut interest rates this month and later in the year to prolong the expansion and test labor market slack. Powell's comments, made during congressional testimony, also imply that the Fed's previous estimates of the longer-run jobless rate and interest-rate level were overly optimistic. This shift in policy could benefit President Donald Trump, who has criticized the Fed for raising rates in 2018.

site_title: Pakistan reopens airspace to civil aviation after India standoff
summary: Pakistan reopened its airspace to civil aviation after a months-long standoff with India, allowing international airlines to resume flights. The decision, made on July 16, 2019, comes after Pakistan closed its airspace in February following an attack by a militant group in Indian-controlled Kashmir. The move brings relief to airlines, reducing flight time and fuel costs. India's ministry of civil aviation stated that there are no further restrictions on airspace in either country, following the lifting of restrictions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after long weekend
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Tuesday, July 16, 2019, following a three-day weekend, due to concerns over a strong yen erasing buying sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.69% to 21,535.25 and the Topix index dropped 0.48% to 1,568.74.

site_title: South Korea accuses Japan of "lukewarm" stand on NK sanctions
summary: South Korea has accused Japan of being "lukewarm" and passive in implementing UN sanctions against North Korea, amid deteriorating relations between the two countries. The dispute began when Japan restricted exports of high-tech materials to South Korea, threatening global supplies of memory chips and smartphones. South Korea's National Intelligence Service chief claimed Japan was not taking sufficient action to enforce sanctions, while Japan denied any wrongdoing. The tensions also reignited old wartime animosity, with South Koreans seeking compensation for forced labor during Japan's 1910-45 colonization.

site_title: Burberry sales grow on demand for designer Tisci's new looks
summary: Burberry's sales rose 4% in the first quarter, exceeding analyst predictions, driven by strong demand for designer Riccardo Tisci's new looks. Sales in mainland China rose in the mid-teens, despite economic slowdown, thanks to policies encouraging domestic spending. Tisci's designs made up over half of products in stores by the end of the quarter, boosting the brand's perception. The strong report could benefit the luxury sector amid concerns about Chinese demand.

site_title: Hong Kong retailers forecast drop in sales due to protests
summary: Hong Kong retailers forecast a double-digit drop in sales for July and August due to ongoing protests. The Hong Kong Retail Management Association also revised its full-year retail sales forecast to a double-digit fall. The association urges the government to resolve the dispute over a proposed extradition law peacefully. The protests have gripped the city for over a month, affecting consumer spending and retail sales.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Retail Management Association said on Tuesday its members expect sales for July and August to see a double-digit drop from a year earlier due to protests that have gripped the Chinese-ruled city for more than a month.

site_title: Malaysian MPs back lowering voting age to 18
summary: Malaysia's parliament voted in favor of lowering the voting age from 21 to 18, a change that would add millions of people to the electoral roll. The reform, championed by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, aims to give young people a voice in the country's democracy. The change still needs to be debated and passed in the senate before it can become law, and will allow 18-year-olds to stand for election and automatically register to vote. The move is expected to bring 7.8 million new voters to the electoral roll by 2023, increasing the total number of voters to 22.7 million.

site_title: Renault sees new model push as softening sales decline
summary: Renault reported a 6.7% decline in first-half vehicle sales to 1.94 million light vehicles in January-June, outpaced by a 7.1% global market contraction. The decline comes amid a global auto slowdown, with major markets in decline and trade barriers looming. Renault attributed the decline to a global slowdown, but said a new product offensive would help soften the blow in key markets. This announcement follows a 12.8% slump in deliveries by domestic rival PSA.

site_title: Fidelity promotes Tan Jenn-Hui to global stewardship and sustainable investing role
summary: Fidelity International has promoted Tan Jenn-Hui to global head of stewardship and sustainable investing, reporting to Paras Anand, head of asset management, Asia-Pacific. Tan, based in Singapore, will oversee Fidelity's ESG teams in Europe and Asia, providing external and internal leadership for sustainable investing activities globally. He previously held roles as head of capital markets and corporate governments for Asia-Pacific and head of legal counsel at Fidelity International, with 12 years of service.

site_title: Indonesia drafting rules to apply VAT on online products and services
summary: Indonesia is drafting new rules to impose value-added tax (VAT) on online products and services provided by offshore companies, targeting a bigger slice of revenue from the country's growing digital market. The move aims to increase tax revenue, with Indonesia's internet economy valued at US$27 billion in 2019 and expected to grow to US$100 billion by 2025. The new VAT rules would apply to e-commerce, content providers, and startups, and authorities are looking to learn from Japan and Australia's experiences with digital taxes.

site_title: Nissan bets on new driverless sports car to heal image after Ghosn scandal
summary: Nissan unveiled a new version of its Skyline sports sedan in Japan, featuring advanced autonomous driving technology and design elements shared with the GT-R sports coupe. The car, Nissan's first major product debut since the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn, aims to revive the company's business following a scandal and low operating profit. The Skyline, priced between $45,000 and $52,000, will offer connected services and lane-changing functions, with only around 200 units expected to be sold per month.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,352.51, up 0.14% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday with a 0.14% gain, reaching 3,352.51 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 177 to 143, with Asian Pay Television Trust and Sino Grandness being among the top gainers. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data releases, and despite US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: New tripartite initiative to help Singapore firms hire persons with disabilities
summary: A new tripartite initiative, "The Unlimited," has been launched in Singapore to promote inclusive hiring for persons with disabilities (PWDs). The initiative, led by United Overseas Bank (UOB), aims to connect Singapore companies with suitable candidates and facilitate the hiring process. The program will provide training and support for both employers and employees, as well as administer grants to eligible employers. The initiative follows a UOB survey showing that two-thirds of business leaders in Singapore would hire PWDs if given sufficient guidance on the hiring process.

site_title: Cocoa's Opec moment puts world market on track for boom and bust
summary: Ivory Coast and Ghana, the world's two largest cocoa producers, are introducing a $400 per metric ton premium to control the market and help farmers. The move aims to boost prices, but analysts warn it could lead to a boom-and-bust scenario, causing overproduction and lower futures prices. This could hurt demand, particularly in emerging markets, and benefit other cocoa-producing countries. The plan's success is uncertain, as it has failed in the past when Ivory Coast tried to control prices in 1987.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain ahead of rate decision, US data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.45% to 2,091.87 points ahead of US retail sales and industrial output data, and the Bank of Korea's rate decision. The won ticked up, and benchmark bond yields fell. Analysts expect the Bank of Korea to keep interest rates steady this week but cut them next month due to slowing economic growth. Foreigners were net buyers of 251.4 billion won worth of shares, and the won was quoted at 1,177.6 per dollar, up 0.2% from the previous day.

site_title: Dating guru Mathew Hussey thinks swiping makes men "flaky"
summary: Dating coach Matthew Hussey believes that online dating, particularly swiping, makes men "flaky" by creating a culture of disposability. He notes that men feel entitled to pursue multiple connections without investing in any one person, leading women to chase after them and overvalue their connections. Hussey advises women to focus on building a fulfilling life and not to invest too much in one person, as this can lead to emotional danger. He also emphasizes the importance of genuine connection and communication in relationships.

site_title: SBF launches joint platform with Vietnam counterpart to strengthen business ties
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and Vietnam Chamber of Commerce and Industry (VCCI) have launched the Vietnam-Singapore Business Council (VSBC) to strengthen business ties between the two countries. The council will facilitate networking opportunities and identify new business opportunities, while promoting economic growth. 17 Singapore companies, including CapitaLand and Grab, are part of the council. The VSBC aims to strengthen partnerships in five priority clusters, including urban development, energy, and manufacturing. The launch follows a five-day business mission to Vietnam, highlighting the growing bilateral trade and investments between the two countries.

site_title: Australian banks begin lowering mortgage stress test rates
summary: Australian banks Westpac and ANZ are lowering mortgage stress test rates, helping to stabilize house prices. The banks now use the lower of 2.5% or 5.75% test rate, down from 7.25%. This move, introduced by the prudential regulator APRA, aims to revive the country's sluggish economy. Borrowers applying for home loans with variable rates of 3.5% will now be tested on a 6% interest rate, allowing them to borrow up to 10% more. APRA's credit easing measure is expected to boost borrowing capacity for many new borrowers.

site_title: SME engineering firm Fong's to launch full smart factory in 3 to 5 years
summary: SME engineering firm Fong's plans to launch a full smart factory in 3-5 years, boosting revenue by 20% year-on-year. The facility will feature advanced robotics and IIoT capabilities, enabling around-the-clock production with minimal human intervention. This move is expected to set Fong's apart as one of only a few SMEs in Singapore to achieve this capability.

site_title: Oil steady as US resumes Gulf of Mexico output amid signs of further supply
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday as US Gulf of Mexico output resumed after Hurricane Barry, with Brent crude futures up 7 cents to $66.55 a barrel. US shale production is expected to rise to a record 8.55 million barrels per day in August, further undermining efforts by Russia and Saudi Arabia to reduce global oil inventories. Despite Opec+ agreeing to extend production cuts for nine months, the rising US supply and muted demand outlook are expected to impact the market.

site_title: E-cigs threaten up to 5% of Indonesian market for smokes: Report
summary: E-cigarettes are gaining popularity in Indonesia, threatening up to 5% of the country's cigarette market, particularly higher-end segments. US e-cigarette leader Juul has launched in Indonesia, while tobacco giant Philip Morris is also considering entering the market with its iQOS device. Maybank Kim Eng analysts predict that regular machine-rolled products will outperform, especially mid-priced brands, due to their value for money and stronger foothold outside big cities. However, initial device investment and maintenance costs may be a barrier to e-cigarette adoption.

site_title: IMF cuts forecast for Singapore's 2019 economic growth to 2%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has lowered its forecast for Singapore's 2019 economic growth to 2% from 2.3%, citing global trade tensions that have hit exports from the city-state. This is the lowest growth forecast for Singapore in a decade. The IMF expects growth to stabilize around 2.5% in the medium term, with risks to the outlook primarily stemming from external factors, including global financial conditions and trade tensions.

site_title: Gibraltar Crescent site put up for sale to pilot dementia care village
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for the sale of a site at Gibraltar Crescent to pilot a dementia care village. The site, with a 30-year lease, consists of two land plots and 10 state bungalows. The sale aims to create a safe, home-like environment for residents with dementia, providing tailored services and programmes to promote meaningful participation and social interactions. The tender closes on November 19, 2019, and URA will evaluate concept proposals based on suitability and price.

site_title: Tiong Seng makes JV its unit by buying remaining 56% stake for S$1
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings acquired the remaining 56% stake in joint-venture Geostr-RV for S$1, making it a wholly owned subsidiary. This move follows a restructuring agreement with Geostr Corporation. Geostr-RV, a manufacturer and distributor of precast tunnel segments, was previously a 56-44 joint venture between Tiong Seng and Geostr Corporation.

site_title: Belmont Road GCB to be auctioned in mortgagee sale with S$42m guide price
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at 80 Belmont Road, Singapore, with a land area of 27,000 square feet and floor area of 15,714 sq ft, will be auctioned on July 23 with a guide price of S$42 million (S$1,557 psf). The property features a two-storey freehold, with a range of amenities including a covered car porch, lift, swimming pool, playground, basketball court, and landscaped garden. The sale is a mortgagee sale to recover an outstanding debt, following the owner's default.

site_title: China's yuan internationalisation should be market-driven, will take time-regulator
summary: China's head of foreign exchange regulator Pan Gongsheng stated that the internationalization of the yuan currency should be market-driven and won't happen overnight. China will continue to encourage cross-border yuan use in trade and investment, ease foreign investor access to yuan markets, and develop offshore yuan financial products. The regulator will also provide liquidity support. This approach will help China achieve its goal of yuan internationalization without government intervention.

images.alt_text: China's policy of internationalising the use of its yuan currency should be market-driven and cannot be accomplished overnight, the head of its foreign exchange regulator said on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.08 points to 1,672.45. Gainers outpaced losers 107 to 54, with a total trading volume of 51.41 million lots worth RM23.86 million.

site_title: Iranian bread permanent guest at Kuwaiti tables
summary: Kuwait has adopted Iranian bread as a permanent guest at local tables, particularly in the popular Souq Al-Mubarakiya market. The bread is baked in traditional clay ovens at the Al-Walimah restaurant in downtown Kuwait City. The Iranian baker carefully shapes and bakes the dough to perfection, making it a staple at many Kuwaiti households. This cultural exchange has become an integral part of Kuwaiti dining, showcasing the country's appreciation for Iranian cuisine and traditions.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hold firm, domestic stimulus long priced in
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held firm against the US dollar, priced in for aggressive interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Domestic inflation figures came in as expected, supporting currency stability. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut rates again, and the Reserve Bank of Australia is ready to ease rates to support employment and economic growth, with rate cuts already priced in for early next year.

site_title: Australian state pledges US$420m to fix fire-prone building cladding
summary: Victoria, Australia pledged US$422 million to replace flammable building cladding following the 2017 Grenfell Tower blaze. The state will establish a new agency to disburse funds to building owners for replacing high-risk cladding, the first in Australia. This move comes after authorities worldwide grappled with the issue of cladding products that contributed to the London blaze. Other states in Australia are expected to follow Victoria's lead in addressing the problem.

site_title: Brazil plan to open gas sector seen luring Naturgy, Engie, others
summary: Brazil plans to overhaul its domestic natural gas market, requiring companies with a dominant position to sell their stakes in distributors. This move is expected to trigger privatizations, with international and domestic bidders, such as Naturgy, Engie, and Repsol, potentially interested in the segment. State-oil firm Petroleo Brasileiro SA may seek buyers for its stakes in 19 distributors. The process has the backing of the Finance and Mining and Energy ministries, with experts predicting a trend of gas distributors being sold into private hands.

site_title: 'Misogynist' Duterte slammed over Philippines anti-harassment law
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed a law against sexual harassment, but critics say his past misogynistic remarks and actions make implementation challenging. The law prohibits behavior such as catcalling, sexist slurs, and groping, with fines and prison sentences for offenders. Duterte has been accused of sexual harassment himself, including wolf-whistling at a journalist and kissing a woman onstage. Women's rights groups say his role as the "misogynist-in-chief" undermines the law's effectiveness, and implementation will be difficult. The law's author, Senator Risa Hontiveros, welcomes its passage but notes it's only as good as its implementation.

site_title: EV maker Tesla revamps prices in sales push
summary: Tesla has revised the prices of its Model 3, X, and S vehicles. The Model 3's starting price drops to $30,315, while the Model X's price increases to $75,315, and the Model S's price rises to $70,115. Prices include incentives and petrol savings of $9,875.

site_title: The 'Lady of the House' who was long entangled with Jeffrey Epstein
summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, the British socialite and former girlfriend of Jeffrey Epstein, was at the center of a scandal surrounding Epstein's alleged sex trafficking and abuse of girls. Maxwell, 57, helped manage Epstein's homes, facilitated his social relationships, and recruited masseuses to satisfy his appetite for massages. She has denied any wrongdoing, but has struck confidential settlements with two women who claim she participated in Epstein's abuse. Maxwell's ties to Epstein, including Prince Andrew, who was a frequent guest at his homes, have raised questions about her involvement in his alleged crimes.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as investors eye start of earnings season
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as investors awaited the start of corporate earnings season, with Tokyo's Nikkei down 0.7% and Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Sydney also posting losses. Despite a record-breaking lead on Wall Street, optimism was tempered by concerns over the US-China trade war and a global slowdown. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said top US and Chinese trade negotiators will hold phone talks this week, but no face-to-face talks have been scheduled. Profits are expected to be down from last year, with the effects of the US-China trade war weighing on Asia.

site_title: Prudential sues former top agency manager for up to S$2.5b over alleged poaching of 244 agents
summary: Prudential Assurance Company Singapore is suing former top agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi for up to S$2.5 billion over allegations that he poached 244 agents to join Aviva Singapore in 2016. Prudential claims Tan breached his contractual and fiduciary duties, using a "carrot and stick" approach to lure agents away. The lawsuit also targets Peter Tan Organisation (PTO) and its management. Tan denies the allegations, blaming Prudential's refusal to adopt a financial advisory model and his own agents' dissatisfaction with the insurer. The trial is set to run for 65 days.

site_title: Toyota's war with dealer over recalls cost it US$16m
summary: A California court jury ordered Toyota Motor Corp to pay $15.8 million to a dealer, Roger Hogan, who claimed the company retaliated against him for developing a safety-recall software that saved the automaker millions in repairs. Hogan's Autovation program was more efficient than Toyota's system, but the jury found Toyota didn't intend to deceive dealerships. Hogan's lawyers stated that the verdict sets a precedent for dealerships prioritizing safety. Toyota will consider its options after the verdict, which discounted $2.3 million from the original judgment.

site_title: Latest returned 1MDB loot includes 'King Kong' poster, Basquiat
summary: US producer Joey McFarland has agreed to return a haul of stolen 1MDB funds, including a vintage "King Kong" poster and a Jean-Michel Basquiat drawing. McFarland, co-founder of Red Granite Pictures, claimed he received the items as gifts from Low Taek Jho, the alleged mastermind behind the 1MDB heist. McFarland did not know the gifts were purchased with funds diverted from the Malaysian state fund. The items are part of a larger return of assets, with the total value of the haul yet to be disclosed.

site_title: China's H1 fixed-asset investment projects rise 81% y-o-y to 472b yuan
summary: China's fixed-asset investment projects rose 81% year-over-year to 472 billion yuan in the first half of 2019, driven by increased infrastructure spending to support a slowing economy. The National Development and Reform Commission approved 94 projects worth 471.5 billion yuan, a 211.2 billion yuan increase from the same period last year. This boost in infrastructure spending aims to stimulate economic growth and counteract a slowdown in China's economy.

site_title: Changing habits: China's pig farms clean up to beat swine fever
summary: China's pig farms are taking measures to combat African swine fever, which has killed millions of pigs. Biosecurity measures have been tightened, with increased sales of disinfectants and cleaning washes. Farmers are now disinfecting inside and outside pig barns every other day, up from once or twice a week. This change in attitude reflects a shift in the industry's approach to hygiene, driven by the need to prevent the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: A devastating outbreak of African swine fever that has killed millions of pigs in China is changing attitudes in a country where farm hygiene has often been seen as lax by international standards.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.18% and the Topix index falling 0.18%. Investors returned from a weekend and looked for fresh incentives, but no major news drove the decline. This marks a brief pause in the market's recent rally.

site_title: Nomura to pay US$25m over mortgage bond traders' lies
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc will repay US$25 million to settle allegations by the US Securities and Exchange Commission that its traders lied to clients about mortgage securities prices and ownership. The traders, including ex-managing director Ross Shapiro, engaged in misconduct from 2010 to 2014. Nomura will pay US$20.7 million to affected customers and US$4.2 million to CMBS clients, with an additional US$1.5 million in penalties. The settlement reflects Nomura's "substantial cooperation" with the SEC.

site_title: Over two-thirds of Asia-Pac firms lack understanding of blockchain solutions: EY poll
summary: A poll conducted by Ernst & Young (EY) in the Asia-Pacific region found that over two-thirds (68%) of companies lack understanding and education on blockchain solutions, citing trust as a key barrier to adoption. The majority of respondents (66%) also believe they need better knowledge of blockchain's possibilities, risks, and benefits before implementing it. Common misconceptions about blockchain include its "trust-less" nature and "unhackability," with 51% of respondents believing it is not hack-proof.

site_title: Protest begins against billion-dollar Southern Copper mining project in Peru
summary: Protesters in southern Peru blocked a highway to protest a $1.4 billion copper mining project by Southern Copper Corp, citing concerns over pollution and water supplies. The project, which has been delayed since 2011, has sparked deadly protests in the past. The protesters, led by the mayor of Cocachacra, are demanding the presence of President Martin Vizcarra and the cancellation of the project. The Peruvian government has offered to discuss the issue, but has yet to receive a response. The project's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.06% to 3,349.81
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.06% to 3,349.81 at Tuesday's open, driven by a stronger opening in the US and Europe markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 23, with heavy trading in Anchor Resources and Amplefield. Financials were mixed, with DBS Group Holdings down 0.1% and United Overseas Bank up 0.2%. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index grew 0.2%.

site_title: Australia: Shares unmoved by dovish central bank minutes, New Zealand eases
summary: Australia's shares remained flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dipping 0.07% to 6,648.70 points, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's dovish central bank minutes indicating a potential rate cut this year. The benchmark ended lower on Monday. The mining sector, driven by robust iron ore prices, saw gains, while financial and energy stocks were weighed down. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.2% to 10,646.42.

site_title: Rio Tinto hits cost blowout at Mongolia copper expansion
summary: Rio Tinto has reported a cost blowout of up to $1.9 billion and a potential 16-30 month delay at its Oyu Tolgoi copper mine in Mongolia, citing challenging geology. The project's capital cost is estimated at $6.5-7.2 billion, up from the original $5.3 billion. First production is now expected between May 2022 and June 2023, with the company reviewing the value of its investment.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, KTL Global, Tiong Seng, Keppel Reit, Keppel Infra Trust
summary: Suntec Reit expanded its presence in Australia with the acquisition of a freehold office building in Adelaide for A$148.3 million. KTL Global entered into one-year service agreements with three Chinese utility operators, with 25 million yuan (S$4.9 million) payable quarterly. These developments may impact trading of Suntec Reit and KTL Global shares.

site_title: Pine Capital appoints independent reviewer to look into allegations of lapses, conflict of interest
summary: Pine Capital Group has appointed KordaMentha as an independent reviewer to investigate allegations of potential conflict of interest and lapses in internal control. The allegations stem from the company's plans to buy a 51% stake in Silver Tree Hong Kong, as well as the departure of its CEO and chairman. The reviewer will review internal controls and make recommendations on potential breaches or non-compliance. The investigation is separate from a reprimand by the Monetary Authority of Singapore regarding the company's fund management firm, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management.

site_title: New Zealand PM 'utterly' disagrees with Trump tweets
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern strongly disagrees with US President Donald Trump's xenophobic tweets targeting four Democratic congresswomen of colour. Ardern praises New Zealand's diversity, stating that her parliament should reflect the country's multiculturalism. She joins international condemnation, including British Prime Minister Theresa May and Canadian leader Justin Trudeau, who have also criticized Trump's tweets. Ardern has previously highlighted her differences with Trump, including advising him to show sympathy to Muslim communities after the Christchurch mosque massacre.

site_title: Amazon workers strike as 'Prime' shopping frenzy hits
summary: Amazon workers in the US and Germany went on strike during Prime Day, a major two-day shopping event, to protest working conditions, job safety, and equal opportunity. The strike, which lasted about an hour, was part of an ongoing effort to pressure the company for concrete action on these issues. US Democratic presidential contenders Kamala Harris and Bernie Sanders expressed support for the strikers on Twitter, while Amazon defended its work conditions, citing its commitment to paying workers at least $15 hourly and providing benefits.

images.alt_text: Amazon workers walked out of a main distribution center in Minnesota on Monday, protesting for improved working conditions during the e-commerce titan's major "Prime" shopping event.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, building on four days of gains, as investors look ahead to the start of earnings season. The Hang Seng Index edged up 0.10% to 28,583.93, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.12%. This follows a record close on Wall Street, with investors tracking US stocks.

site_title: Singapore financial sector oversight 'among the best globally': IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reaffirmed Singapore's financial sector oversight as "among the best globally", praising the country's strong economic fundamentals and sound policies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) completed its third financial sector assessment program and found the sector to be resilient under severe adverse scenarios. MAS' crisis management and resolution regime has been strengthened, and its fintech regulation and supervision strike a good balance between innovation and stability. The IMF's assessment is based on Singapore's status as a systemically-important financial centre.

site_title: New Zealand inflation quickens in Q2, but rate cut views remain
summary: New Zealand's inflation accelerated to 0.6% in the second quarter, driven by higher fuel and housing costs. However, this growth did not deter market expectations of a rate cut this year to support the slowing economy. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) kept interest rates at a record low of 1.50% and warned of potential further cuts due to economic risks. Despite this, inflation remained within the RBNZ's 1-3% target range, and the New Zealand dollar remained unchanged.

site_title: Citigroup earnings climb on lower expenses
summary: Citigroup reported a 6.9% increase in second-quarter earnings to US$4.8 billion, driven by higher lending and lower expenses. The bank's revenues rose 1.6% to US$18.8 billion, despite a drop in investment banking revenues. Citigroup's expenses dropped, with lower employee compensation and technology investments. The results come as the US economy slows, with the Federal Reserve expected to lower interest rates. CEO Michael Corbat attributed the success to disciplined expense management and a strong strategy.

site_title: US: Stocks edge to records ahead of major earnings
summary: US stocks edged to fresh records on Monday as companies are expected to report a 3% drop in second-quarter profits, according to FactSet. Analysts say earnings growth has been elusive for the S&P 500 this year. Despite low expectations, stocks continued to rise, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. US-EU trade talks are also in focus.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks edged to fresh records on Monday at the start of a heavy week of earnings reports for which expectations are relatively low.

site_title: Atlantia, Delta picked to reboot ailing Alitalia
summary: Italy's state railway Ferrovie dello Stato (FS) has chosen Atlantia transport group and US airline Delta as partners to reboot struggling carrier Alitalia. The economy ministry will be the fourth main investor, following a business plan with the chosen partners. Atlantia will hold around 35% of the company, while Delta and the ministry will hold 15% each. The move aims to boost long-haul flights and cut unprofitable routes, with job cuts and wage cuts expected as part of the recovery plan.

site_title: Best World's finalised scope of expanded independent review gets SGX RegCo's green light
summary: Best World International has finalized the scope of its expanded independent review, approved by the Singapore Exchange (SGX RegCo), following a notice of compliance in May. The review will verify sales under the export model with primary import agent Changsha Best from 2015-2018, identify potential breaches of listing rules and internal control weaknesses, and make recommendations. The review aims to determine if sales were conducted on normal commercial terms and at arm's length basis. The findings will be reported directly to SGX RegCo and disclosed in an executive summary.

site_title: Investment firm Varde Partners appoints Singapore-based co-CEO
summary: Varde Partners appoints Ilfryn Carstairs as co-CEO, effective January 1, 2020, alongside current CEO George Hicks. Carstairs, based in Singapore, will also retain his role as global co-CIO and co-chairs the investment committee. This appointment is part of Varde's succession plan for a new generation of leaders, with Hicks transitioning to an executive chair role in 2022. Carstairs joined Varde Partners in 2006 and has been based in Singapore since 2017, playing a key role in building the firm's European and Asian businesses.

images.alt_text: Based in Singapore, Ilfryn Carstairs (left) will join George Hicks (right), co-founder and current sole CEO, at the helm as co-CEOs of Varde Partners.

site_title: London's mayor rejects billionaire's plan for towering tulip building
summary: London's mayor, Sadiq Khan, rejected a proposal to build a 305-meter tulip-shaped tower near the Gherkin skyscraper in the financial district, citing potential harm to the nearby Tower of London. The tower, designed by Foster + Partners, would offer panoramic views and gondola pods, but the mayor's office found issues with the project, including harm to the skyline, pedestrian areas, and cycle parking. The developer will now consider next steps, with the project's developer expressing disappointment over the decision. The project was set to begin construction in 2020 and finish in 2025.

site_title: Ikea closing only US furniture factory, cutting 300 jobs
summary: Ikea will close its only US factory in Danville, Virginia, cutting 300 jobs, as it's more cost-effective to produce products in Europe and import them due to high raw material costs. The factory, which opened in 2008, will close in December. Ikea will work with labor representatives and US agencies to provide job search assistance to affected employees. The decision aims to maintain competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Japan trade minister blasts South Korea for "mistaken" explanation after bilateral meeting
summary: Japanese trade minister Hiroshige Seko criticized South Korea for providing a "mistaken" explanation after a working-level meeting over Japan's export controls. The dispute could threaten global supplies of microchips and smartphone displays. Tokyo lodged a protest against Seoul, citing a broken agreement on disclosure of discussion details from the meeting. The feud deepened after the two sides contested accounts of the meeting, further straining bilateral relations.

site_title: Memtech's proposed delisting gets SGX nod; EGM not required
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has approved Memtech International's proposed delisting, subject to the completion of its controlling shareholders' compulsory acquisition. The company does not need to hold an EGM for shareholder approval, as SGX granted a waiver from listing rule 1307. The offeror, M-Universe Investments, has received valid acceptances for 90% of shares, allowing it to unilaterally determine the outcome of a delisting resolution. The proposed delisting values Memtech at S$189 million, a 23.9% premium over its last transacted price.

site_title: For US, tariffs on China do not cover the costs of Trump's trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump claims tariffs on China are generating billions of dollars for the US, but government figures show the revenue collected is not enough to cover the cost of the president's bailout for farmers or compensate hurt industries. The US collected $20.8 billion from tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods, but the gap between revenue and costs is growing. Trade talks with China have faltered, and the administration projects China is suffering more harm, but experts disagree, citing studies showing US consumers bear the cost of tariffs, particularly among the lowest earners.

site_title: Brazil's vice-president says no restrictions on Huawei
summary: Brazil's vice-president, Hamilton Mourao, announced that there will be no restrictions on Chinese company Huawei, despite US pressure to ban it due to security concerns. Mourao stated that Brazil's ties with China cannot be "disregarded" and that Huawei has been operating in the country for 10 years. The announcement comes as Brazil prepares to launch its 5G network, with an auction of spectrum expected to take place next year. This decision is seen as a departure from President Jair Bolsonaro's previous stance on China, and aims to balance relations with both the US and China during the ongoing trade war.

site_title: LVMH teams up with Stella McCartney
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury and fashion company, has partnered with Stella McCartney, a renowned designer known for her environmental credentials. The deal will see LVMH acquire a minority stake in McCartney's design house, allowing her to maintain majority ownership and creative direction. The partnership aims to accelerate worldwide development and will also see McCartney become a special adviser to LVMH's head on sustainable development policies. This move comes after McCartney ended her 17-year tie-up with Kering, a rival luxury group.

site_title: Trump weighs ousting commerce secretary Ross: report
summary: President Donald Trump is considering removing Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross amid the administration's failure to add a citizenship question to next year's census. Trump told aides he's considering firing Ross "as soon as this summer," citing Ross' role in the failed effort. Ross has faced public setbacks, including a refusal from the Office of Government Ethics to certify his financial disclosures. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin praised Ross, saying he's doing a good job, but the decision to remove him remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump is considering removing Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross after the administration failed to add a question on citizenship to next year's census, NBC news reported on Monday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks closes higher as upbeat China data boosts German shares
summary: European stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by strong Chinese data that boosted German shares and buoyed risk sentiment. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.4% as trade-sensitive sectors like automakers and basic resources companies topped gains. Data from China showed factory output and retail sales exceeded forecasts, and investors are optimistic about the European Central Bank's potential easing of monetary policy. Regional chipmakers and biotech firms also saw gains, while banking stocks ended flat.

site_title: Twitter revamps website in bid to mimic mobile app
summary: Twitter has rolled out an overhauled version of its website, making it faster, easier to navigate, and more personalized, similar to the mobile app. The revamped site features an "explore" section, live video, local "moments," and customizable dark mode themes. The move aims to increase engagement while managing abusive content. Twitter will shift from monthly active users to monetizable daily active users, with 134 million users in the most recent quarter. The update follows Twitter's efforts to keep pace with larger social networks like Facebook and Instagram.

site_title: KTL Global unit enters service pacts worth 25m yuan with 3 China utility operators
summary: KTL Global's 80%-owned subsidiary, Bluegas Private Limited, has entered into one-year service agreements with three Chinese utility operators worth 25 million yuan (S$4.9 million). The agreements, signed as part of a non-binding MOU, are expected to positively impact KTL Global's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. The deals were assigned to Bluegas by Shenzhen Green Leopard Medical Technology Co Ltd, and the operator that has already paid 7.5 million yuan as of June 30.

site_title: Worsening world hunger affects 821 million, says UN
summary: The United Nations reports that over 821 million people worldwide suffered from hunger in 2019, a rise for the third consecutive year, reversing decades of decline. Climate change and war are major contributors to the increase in malnutrition. The report warns that achieving zero hunger by 2030 is an "immense challenge" and that extremist groups are using hunger as a weapon to divide communities. To address the issue, a "structural transformation" is needed to include the poorest people in economic and social policies, and integrating food security and nutrition concerns into poverty reduction efforts.

site_title: Amazon staff stage strikes in Germany on big sale day
summary: Amazon employees in Germany staged a strike at seven locations on Prime Day, demanding better wages. Over 2,000 workers participated, citing low wages and lack of collective bargaining. The strike coincided with Amazon's announcement of creating 1,000 jobs in Poland. Despite the company's claims of fair wages, the Verdi labor union argues that Amazon's profits of 3.2 billion euros in the first quarter suggest money is available for better wages. The strike will continue on Tuesday, with workers calling for "no discounts on our incomes."

site_title: S&P reaffirms Deutsche Bank ratings after restructuring
summary: S&P Global Ratings reaffirmed Deutsche Bank's credit ratings, classifying its long-term debt at "BBB+" and short-term debt at "A-2," after the bank unveiled a restructuring plan to eliminate 18,000 jobs and exit equities sales and trading. The plan aims to shift focus towards Germany and Europe, but S&P notes a challenging economic environment in Europe and potential risks. The ratings agency may lower its rating in the next 12-24 months if Deutsche Bank fails to meet targets.

site_title: Facebook needs 'very high standard' for Libra coin: US Treasury
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that Facebook must meet a "very high standard" before moving forward with its Libra digital currency, citing concerns over money laundering and illicit activities. Regulators have expressed concerns about the global cryptocurrency, and Mnuchin emphasized the need for safeguards against its use for criminal activity. Facebook's Libra is expected to launch in the first half of 2020 and is designed to be backed by a basket of currency assets. The US Treasury welcomes "responsible innovations" but prioritizes maintaining the integrity of the financial system.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO sees no 'Greta effect' on passenger numbers
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated that the airline expects a 4% increase in passenger numbers this year, contradicting concerns that climate activist Greta Thunberg's public support might deter air travel. Despite discussions on climate change, bookings remain strong, with Swiss International Air Lines also showing growth. People want to fly, Spohr said, playing down the "Greta effect" on air travel demand.

site_title: Most working adults not financially ready for retirement
summary: Most working adults in Singapore are financially unprepared for retirement, with 3/4 not on track, and 1-in-3 saying they do not invest, viewing it as a form of gambling. The OCBC Financial Wellness Index survey found that 26 indicators show Singaporeans are making basic financial habits, but struggle with growing wealth through investments, financial emergencies, and retirement planning. Only half have enough savings to last six months, and 65% are not accumulating enough funds to maintain their lifestyle after retirement.

site_title: China's economy sputters with 6.2% growth in Q2
summary: China's economy experienced its slowest growth rate on record, with a 6.2% growth rate in Q2, down from 6.4% in the first quarter. The slowdown is attributed to the ongoing US-China trade war, with businesses remaining skeptical of a broader trade agreement. Chinese officials downplay the effects, but analysts warn of continued economic pressure, with some revising their forecast for 2019 growth to 6.3%. The economy is expected to slow further before picking up in 2020, with trade tensions potentially escalating again.

site_title: UK PM hopefuls slam Trump tweets, but refuse to call them racist
summary: UK Prime Minister hopefuls Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt condemned US President Donald Trump's xenophobic tweets as "totally offensive" and "totally unacceptable," but refused to call them racist during their debate before the July 23 announcement of the new leader. Johnson and Hunt emphasized the importance of UK-US relations, but also criticized Trump's comments as divisive and un-British. The debate highlights the challenges of navigating the relationship between free speech and offense in the face of divisive rhetoric.

site_title: Spackman to buy Korean film production firm for S$3.3m
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group, a Singaporean film producer and investor, plans to acquire South Korean film production company Simplex Films for S$3.3 million in new shares. The acquisition was announced in a bourse filing and is subject to regulatory approval. This move aims to expand Spackman's presence in the Asian film industry.

site_title: Home-price growth weakens in China as wider curbs kick in
summary: China's home-price growth weakened for the first time since February, as authorities widened curbs to slow a re-inflating market. New-home prices excluding government-subsidies rose 0.66% in June from May, down from a 0.71% gain in May. This marks the first decline in growth since February, indicating a slowdown in China's housing market.

site_title: Govt rolls out IT tools to boost security of sensitive data
summary: The Singapore government has rolled out IT tools to improve the management of citizens' sensitive data, following a spate of cyber and data security breaches. The Public Sector Data Security Review Committee has recommended 13 solutions, including digital tools to prevent accidental data breaches and protect confidential files with digital signatures. These measures aim to enhance the government's data protection and incident response capabilities, with a focus on process and people measures to address the increasing complexity of systems and threats.

site_title: EU holds crisis talks on Iran nuclear deal
summary: European foreign ministers held crisis talks in Brussels on Monday to discuss the Iran nuclear deal, amid concerns that the "small window" to save the accord is closing. Iran has breached the agreement, prompting the US to reimpose sanctions and hammering its economy. The EU is trying to prevent the deal's unravelling, seeing it as the best way to prevent Iran from acquiring atomic weapons. The EU is exploring a special trading mechanism, INSTEX, to enable businesses to deal with Iran without using the US dollar or financial system.

site_title: US-China trade officials to talk again 'this week': official
summary: US and Chinese trade officials are set to speak by telephone this week, marking the second call in two weeks between senior officials from Washington and Beijing. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed optimism about the thaw in trade negotiations. No face-to-face talks have been scheduled yet, but the principal-level call aims to continue discussions. The talks come as the US and China continue to navigate the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: US proposes barring big tech from financial services, digital currencies
summary: The US House Financial Services Committee has proposed a bill to bar big tech companies from functioning as financial institutions or issuing digital currencies, with a fine of $1 million per day for violations. The "Keep Big Tech Out Of Finance Act" would define large tech firms as those with $25 billion in annual revenue and prohibit them from creating digital assets with exchange, account, or value functions. The proposal comes amid growing scrutiny of tech companies' financial activities, including Facebook's Libra digital coin. Passage is unlikely due to Republican opposition and would need to pass the Senate.

site_title: Auto union vows to look closely at Ford-Volkswagen alliance
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) union has expressed concerns over Ford's alliance with Volkswagen, amid the company's contract negotiations with major American automakers. UAW President Gary Jones warned that the alliance may not be in the union's favor, given Volkswagen's past treatment of workers in Chattanooga, Tennessee. Despite this, Jones emphasized the union's focus on economic gains, particularly in sharing profits with workers. The UAW is also exploring opportunities in autonomous driving, with a potential role in Argo AI, which Volkswagen is investing in.

site_title: Singapore is 3rd in Asia-Pacific for nurturing women entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore ranks third in the Asia-Pacific for nurturing women entrepreneurs, behind Sydney and Melbourne, according to a study by Dell. The city scored well in talent and technology, but poorly in access to capital and a supportive market. Its ranking fell from eighth in 2017 to 21st in 2019 due to increased competition from other cities. Despite progress, Singapore still faces challenges such as gender parity pay and a lack of female board members, with the markets pillar ranking 25th globally.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International's subsidiary Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings (YKA) has received approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to list on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, pending regulatory approval. The planned listing will see around 10% of YKA shares listed, with proceeds used to fund capital expenditure in China. DBS Group Holdings is expected to record around 1% quarter-on-quarter loan expansion in Q2, driven by business loan growth and a rising Sibor.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US stocks opened lower on Jul 11, 2025, amid fresh tariffs on Canada by President Trump. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue with similar operating losses as H1. In Singapore, OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) signed an agreement to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Grab was downgraded to 'hold' by CGS Investment.
