site_title: Bitcoin drops more than 10% as scrutiny of cryptocurrencies grows
summary: Bitcoin fell over 10% to a two-week low, reaching $9,855, amid growing scrutiny of cryptocurrencies. Fears of a crackdown on digital coins, fueled by Facebook's planned Libra digital coin, have increased. US President Donald Trump's criticism and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's call for regulation have contributed to the decline. Regulators worldwide have expressed concerns over consumer protection, privacy, and systemic risks. Japanese authorities have also set up a working group to examine Libra's impact on monetary policy and financial regulation.

site_title: Boris and Donald can try building US-UK's 'special relationship'
summary: The UK government is considering a replacement for Ambassador to Washington Kim Darroch amid a row with US President Donald Trump over his critical comments about the UK. The leak of cables with negative comments about Trump has strained bilateral ties, which were already complicated by the UK's post-Brexit relationship. The US sees a potential trade deal as a cornerstone of a renewed "special relationship," but there are significant differences between the two countries, including Mr. Trump's "America First" agenda and the UK's desire to maintain close economic ties with China. The next UK prime minister will need to navigate these challenges to build a smooth relationship with Trump.

site_title: Sentosa Cove in need of a boost in profile
summary: Sentosa Cove, a waterfront housing district in Singapore, is in need of a profile boost due to a tough condo sales market and low prices. The area, once a prestigious integrated oceanfront marina, has seen a significant gap in condo prices compared to prime districts 9 and 10, widening from 4% in 2010 to 77% last year. Efforts to promote the area and attract high net worth buyers have been hindered by property cooling measures and a lack of overseas marketing. Potential catalysts for a revival include Resorts World Sentosa's expansion plans and upcoming developments, but a stronger boost may come from attracting investments to Singapore through targeted promotions.

site_title: Thai PM declares an end to military rule; resigns as army chief
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha formally resigned as head of the military government, marking the end of five years of military rule. He remains as PM with the support of pro-military parties and a military-appointed upper house. Prayuth cited success in areas like combating human trafficking and the rescue of the 12 boys from a flooded cave as reasons for the transition to democracy. The new civilian government, endorsed by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, will take power after a swearing-in ceremony on Tuesday, with its policies to be presented to Parliament next week.

site_title: AB InBev seeks Plan B after investors bail on 2019's biggest IPO
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, is seeking Plan B after investors bailed on its 2019 initial public offering in Hong Kong, leaving the company with a US$100 billion debt pile. The brewer needs to reduce debt and mollify shareholders while reinvigorating its business, which has lost its fizz. Options include eliminating overlapping functions, selling a minority stake in its Asian unit, or cutting marketing outlays. Standard & Poor's has a negative outlook on AB InBev's debt, citing the risk of further downgrades if the company fails to meet its debt reduction targets.

site_title: Oil prices down on dwindling storm impact, Chinese economic data
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% on Monday, settling at $66.48 a barrel for Brent crude and $59.58 a barrel for US crude, due to a short-lived impact from a tropical storm on US Gulf Coast production and refining. This contrasts with previous weekly gains, which were driven by cuts in US oil inventories and diplomatic tensions in the Middle East. The decline was also influenced by Chinese economic data, which dimmed the crude demand outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil prices sank about 1 per cent on Monday on signs that the impact of a tropical storm on US Gulf Coast production and refining would be short-lived, while Chinese economic data dimmed the crude demand outlook.

site_title: When presidents answered the White House door bell
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency may be nearing its end as the public grows increasingly frustrated with his actions. Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, has been releasing numerous policy proposals, including plans to reduce student debt and increase tax rates on large corporations. Warren's mantra of "I have a plan for that" has been met with skepticism, particularly from comedian Ashley Nicole Black. Meanwhile, Trump has been opening a new chapter in US foreign policy, and the global community is watching with interest as China prepares for an EU-China summit later this month.

images.alt_text: Mt Rushmore, featuring (from left) Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln, who had to tangle with the checks and balances asserted by the legislative and judicial branches of government.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott signs 26 new properties, debuts in 6 cities
summary: CapitaLand's Ascott has signed 26 new properties, mostly under management contracts, across 22 cities in 11 countries. The new properties will house 6,000 units, expanding the Ascott brand to six cities, including Atyrau in Kazakhstan and Yokohama in Japan. The move strengthens the Ascott's presence in 14 cities, including major markets like Australia, China, and Southeast Asia. The company aims to open over 40 properties with 8,500 units this year, targeting fee income of S$25 million annually.

site_title: America's cycle of disappointment
summary: A renowned economist and policy expert, Alice Rivlin, has passed away at 88, leaving behind a legacy of unfulfilled promises. Rivlin, known as "the queen of Washington's budget wonks," was a pioneer in her field, but her life's work exemplified the "cycle of disappointment" that pervades American politics. Despite creating and advocating for numerous policy solutions, poverty, racial tensions, and other problems persist, highlighting the failure of policy entrepreneurship to deliver meaningful change. The proliferation of think tanks and policy experts has created a system of "political congestion," where problems compete for attention, and solutions are often inadequate.

site_title: Phnom Penh poor uprooted as lakes are filled in
summary: In Phnom Penh, Cambodia, 15 of 25 lakes have been filled in, and others are partly filled or earmarked for reclamation, displacing poor families who rely on these water bodies for fishing and farming. The city's rapid expansion has led to the loss of wetlands, with nearly half of the country's wetlands disappearing in the last 15 years. Authorities claim reclamation is necessary for infrastructure, but critics argue it exacerbates environmental problems and ignores the needs of those living in poverty. The UN warns of increased flooding risk due to climate change, highlighting the need for long-term urban development planning.

site_title: Xiaomi revamps chip strategy with investment in semiconductor designer
summary: Xiaomi has invested approximately 6% in chip designer VeriSilicon Holdings Co Ltd, becoming its second-largest external shareholder. This move is part of Xiaomi's strategy to drive innovation in semiconductors, a sector the Chinese government aims to become more self-reliant in under its "Made in China 2025" initiative. The investment comes as Xiaomi seeks to overcome its struggles in the chip market, having launched a semiconductor division in 2014.

site_title: June new homes sales exceed launches amid holiday lull
summary: New homes sales in June exceeded launches, defying the typical post-holiday lull, according to recent data. US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of declines, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached another record, with more increases predicted. Additionally, Goldman Sachs acquired a large portfolio of hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and Singapore's Good Class Bungalow prices were discussed. Overall, these developments indicate a mixed market trend globally.

site_title: Asia markets mixed on latest China data
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session on Monday as investors reacted to China's latest economic data releases, which showed retail sales and industrial output beating expectations despite a slowdown in Q2 GDP to 6.2% yoy. Sentiment remains choppy due to ongoing US-China trade tensions and a global economic slowdown. China's consumer sector saw bright spots, with retail sales and June industrial output beating expectations.

site_title: Singapore construction sector may face long slowdown in medium term: Fitch
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to see a slowdown in growth in the medium term due to a poorer global economic outlook. The sector's growth is forecasted to weaken to 2.7% in 2020 and 0.5% in 2021 in real terms. However, the buildings sector, which accounts for 70% of the industry's value, is expected to grow at 3.2% this year and 2.3% in 2020, driven by the construction of major projects such as the North-South Corridor.

site_title: Further curbs on money lending to foreigners
summary: Singapore has further tightened caps on loans to foreigners, with measures taking effect immediately. Foreigners earning less than S$10,000 per annum can only borrow up to S$500 from licensed moneylenders, down from S$1,500. Licensed moneylenders will also face restrictions on the number of foreign borrowers and outstanding principal. The measures aim to reduce the proliferation of moneylending to vulnerable groups, with borrowers able to restructure debt through voluntary welfare organizations. The Credit Association of Singapore expects the supply restrictions to be "devastating" for the industry.

site_title: China-friendly Taiwan mayor beats Foxconn's Gou in opposition's presidential primary
summary: Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has nominated Kaohsiung Mayor Han Kuo-yu for the 2020 presidential election, beating Foxconn founder Terry Gou. Han, known for his pro-China views, won 44.8% of the vote, while Gou secured 27.7%. Han's nomination directly challenges President Tsai Ing-wen, who is seeking re-election. The election takes place amid heightened tensions with China, which considers Taiwan a wayward province. Han's victory could pose a threat to Tsai's bid for re-election, and may also impact Taipei city mayor Ko Wen-je's potential run as an independent candidate.

site_title: Over 40 new standards to be developed for new tech, business processes
summary: The Singapore Standards Council (SSC) will develop over 40 new standards for emerging technologies and business processes, including additive manufacturing and video analytics, to support economic transformation and innovation. The standards will be developed in collaboration with experts in these fields and will serve as guides for best practices in navigating disruptive technologies. Compliance with Singapore Standards will become mandatory when used by government bodies in regulations, and the SSC plans to increase its participation in international standard-setting bodies like the International Standards Organisation (ISO).

site_title: Amazon's July sales blitz could hurt competitors
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sale, which started on July 15, 2019, has grown to a record 250 retailers offering sales to compete with Prime Day. This "Black Friday in July" event may hurt competitors, with some analysts warning of cannibalization and decreased foot traffic. Retailers risk losing customers to Amazon's steep discounts, which may remove the incentive to return to stores later in the summer. Despite this, some chains are using July sales to promote back-to-school items, which may not cut into future sales.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust declares flat Q2 DPU of 0.93 cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cent for the second quarter of 2019, despite a 26.3% year-on-year increase in distributable cash flow. The trust's DCF rose to S$45.8 million from S$36.2 million, driven by contributions from Ixom HoldCo. Revenue and net profits also increased, with a 200% rise in revenue and a profit of S$15.96 million. The trust's gearing decreased to 34.2% after issuing subordinated perpetual securities.

site_title: Rise in Chinese buyer enquiries for Australian homes
summary: Chinese buyer enquiries for Australian homes rose 40% in the first quarter, marking the second consecutive year-on-year increase since 2016. This signals a possible revival of demand for Australia's property market, which has struggled. The trend is attributed to easing capital controls, a lower Aussie dollar, and stabilizing home prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low in an effort to revive growth and inflation. This increase in Chinese buyer enquiries is welcomed by policymakers, who are concerned about the economy's weakness.

site_title: Updating an old defence with modern tech
summary: Singapore-based company Willowmore has developed a keyless smart lock system to address security concerns in the telecommunications industry. The industrial-grade lock allows authorized staff and contractors to access sites remotely, track entries, and detect potential threats. The system uses stainless steel and wireless technology, making it robust enough for industrial use. Willowmore aims to expand its customer base, targeting companies with distributed assets, and plans to leverage data analytics to improve security and efficiency. The company has already gained recognition from the GSM Association and is conducting trials in Southeast Asia and other regions.

site_title: A$3.3b insurance sale likely off, says Australia's AMP
summary: AMP, an Australian wealth manager, is likely to cancel its A$3.3 billion sale of its life insurance unit to Resolution Life due to New Zealand's central bank intervention, which requires the buyer to create separate financial assets to protect policy holders. The cancellation is seen as a setback for AMP's recovery strategy and sends its shares tumbling. Analysts describe the probable cancellation as an accidental win for AMP, as the sale price was deemed too cheap. The move extends New Zealand's regulatory scrutiny of international companies, with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand having ordered major banks to increase their reserve capital.

site_title: America ratchets up cross-straits tensions with US$2.2b arms sale
summary: The US has approved a $2.2 billion arms sale to Taiwan, including 108 Abrams tanks and 250 Stinger missiles, amid rising tensions with China. Beijing has threatened to sanction US companies involved and has held military drills near the island. The Trump administration maintains the sale is for self-defense purposes and within the framework of the Three Communiques, governing US-China relations. This move comes as Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen's popularity has improved, and China's diplomatic and military pressure on Taipei has increased since her election in 2016.

site_title: Singapore's virtual banks offer homegrown AI a chance to shine
summary: Singapore's virtual banks are expected to be granted licenses later this year, marking the next chapter in the city-state's banking liberalization journey. This development is significant as it gives homegrown AI companies a chance to shine, as AI is increasingly being used in global banking operations. The best banks of the coming decade will have the best AI, and Singapore's homegrown AI companies are well-positioned to reap the rewards of a burgeoning virtual banking ecosystem. The government's push to build up its AI sector is expected to drive innovation and growth in the financial services industry.

site_title: Pictet bets on Asia expansion; aims to double team of bankers
summary: Pictet Wealth Management plans to double its team of bankers in Asia over the next few years as part of its growth strategy. The firm aims to expand its presence in North Asia, primarily from Hong Kong, and Southeast Asia, from Singapore. Pictet will leverage its asset management expertise and extend lending services to private clients, capitalizing on its recent wholesale bank licence in Singapore. The firm also plans to roll out an advisory solution in Asia, offering a range of investment advisory services. Globally, Pictet expects equities to perform sideways, with a cautious stance on valuations.

site_title: Suntec Reit acquires Adelaide office building
summary: Suntec Reit has acquired a 12-storey office building in Adelaide, South Australia for A$148.3 million, its first Australian property. The building, 55 Currie Street, has a 91.6% occupancy rate with key tenants including the Commonwealth Government and Allianz. The property has undergone refurbishments, including solar panels and end-of-trip facilities, and has a 4.5-star energy rating. The acquisition is expected to provide immediate distribution per unit accretion and income stability for unitholders.

site_title: SGX looking to curb big price swings during auction windows
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking feedback on introducing price collars and time extensions to curb extreme price swings during its auction process. The proposed controls aim to protect investors from large price fluctuations, particularly during the pre-open, mid-day, and closing auctions. Three options are being considered: a 30% price collar for pre-open auctions, a 10% price collar for mid-day and closing auctions, or extending the auction period by 4-5 minutes if the indicative opening price moves beyond a certain threshold. The consultation is open until August 15, with changes to be implemented if deemed feasible.

site_title: Smaller London home-price drop shows market is stabilising
summary: London's housing market appears to be stabilizing, with home prices falling 0.2% in July, the smallest drop in five years. This marks a contrast to previous months, where prices fell 0.6% on average. Low interest rates, record employment, and a short supply of homes are preventing a sharper decline. The average time to sell a property remains steady at 67 days, and the number of new sellers is down 18% from last year. Experts believe the market may be "bottoming out" and are waiting for a recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.92 points to 1,672.37 on Monday, driven by higher volume of 3 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 375.

site_title: UK's Hammond pledges to fight a no-deal Brexit from outside government
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond has announced he will not stay in his job when the next prime minister takes office, pledging to fight a no-deal Brexit. Hammond stated he would do everything possible to prevent the UK leaving the EU without a transition deal, despite his own party's majority voting against a no-deal Brexit earlier this year. Hammond's departure follows the expected change in leadership, which could impact the UK's Brexit stance.

site_title: Scouting for new tools, central banks look at Japan's yield controls
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are exploring Japan's "yield curve control" (YCC) program, a unique approach by the Bank of Japan to anchor long-term interest rates near zero. The unconventional program has drawn interest from global central bankers worried about a global economic downturn. The BOJ has received queries from several central banks, including the Fed, on how the program works. While the Fed has been able to raise interest rates relatively high since the 2007-2009 financial crisis, it is now considering lowering rates due to global weakness and low inflation.

site_title: Koh Brothers unit snags S$668.2m PUB job
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, a subsidiary of Catalist-listed Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, has secured a S$668.2 million contract from PUB to construct influent pumping stations at Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. This contract boosts the company's order book to over S$1 billion. The project is expected to be completed later this month.

site_title: China's property rules rife with reversals, twists and turns
summary: China's Communist government employs a range of policy levers to control the housing market, including restrictions on foreign buyers, loan-to-value limits, and land prices. The government can fine-tune the market to pop bubbles before they inflate, keeping the property industry afloat. China's unique approach, where all crucial issues are decided by the government, has led to successful control of home prices in major cities since 2016, but also resulted in past failures, such as a 50% surge in home prices after a down-payment cut in 2014.

site_title: Seoul: Japan's reports of N Korea sanctions breach a 'grave challenge'
summary: Japan's export curbs on sensitive materials to South Korea pose a "grave challenge" to Seoul, according to President Moon Jae-in. The curbs, in response to a court ruling ordering Japan to compensate South Koreans for wartime labor, have led to concerns about global supplies of microchips and smartphone displays. Japan has denied reports that hydrogen fluoride was shipped to North Korea, but Seoul claims it has been doing a better job in tracking illicit exports. The dispute has deepened tensions between the two countries, with Seoul calling the curbs "retaliatory" and seeking Tokyo's withdrawal.

site_title: Lower one-off income hits Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU
summary: Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU fell 2.1% to 1.39 Singapore cents due to lower one-off income from Ocean Financial Centre and Bugis Junction Towers. Revenue and net property income also declined. However, the Reit's committed occupancy reached 99.1% as of June 30, 2019, with average signing rent above the Grade A core CBD market average. The distribution will be paid on August 27, 2019.

site_title: Suntec Reit buys freehold Grade A office building in Adelaide for A$148.3m
summary: Suntec Reit has acquired a freehold Grade A office building in Adelaide, Australia for A$148.3 million, expanding its presence in the country. The 12-storey property has a 91.6% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.4 years. The vendor has agreed to provide a 27-month rent guarantee for the vacant spaces. This acquisition strengthens Suntec Reit's presence in Australia and provides a stable income stream through its existing tenants.

site_title: Five things businesses need to do to protect themselves against online security threats
summary:
Businesses must prioritize online security to protect against increasingly sophisticated cyber threats. Despite over half of organizations worldwide not prioritizing cybersecurity, IT departments can take five steps to ensure data safety: 

1. Ensure cloud and application vendors follow data security best practices.
2. Offer cybersecurity training to employees to prevent data breaches through simple tips.
3. Secure information in the cloud by restricting document sharing and specifying user access.
4. Focus on strong company passwords and employee credentials, using tools to generate and identify weak passwords.
5. Establish a protocol for managing passwords, including an online password manager and clear IT policy enforcement.

site_title: Expectations for dovish ECB cap euro gains
summary: The euro remained within its recent trading range against the dollar, capped by expectations of a dovish European Central Bank meeting next week. Investors expect the ECB to cut rates in September and March, and the Federal Reserve to cut rates in July and September. Despite high Treasury yields, the euro is expected to recover as the eurozone economy and expectations bottom out. The Australian dollar rose on stronger-than-expected Chinese economic data, while speculators added to their short positions against the euro.

images.alt_text: The euro remained within its recent trading range against the dollar on Monday, its progress capped by expectations for a dovish European Central Bank meeting next week and after investors turned more bearish on the currency.

site_title: Mind tricks help Djokovic outlast Federer in Wimbledon
summary: Novak Djokovic defeated Roger Federer in the longest singles final in Wimbledon's 133-year history, winning 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, 4-6, 13-12. The 5-hour match showcased a battle of artistry versus industry, with Djokovic's unyielding intensity and athleticism prevailing over Federer's beautiful strokes. Djokovic credited his mental stability and focus for his win, saying he tried to "switch off" from the crowd and be present on the court. The victory secured Djokovic's fifth Wimbledon crown and narrowed the Grand Slam gap between the "big three."

site_title: Maybank demands another S$33.6 million from Hyflux's unit, over hedging deal
summary: Maybank is demanding another S$33.6 million from Hyflux's unit Tuaspring, following the early termination of a hedging agreement. The demand is in addition to S$509.1 million and US$44.5 million previously sought by Maybank. Tuaspring's debt-ridden water treatment company Hyflux's debt moratorium ends on Aug 2, with National water agency PUB taking over the loss-making Tuaspring desalination plant.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.3% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 9.39 points, or 0.3%, to close at 3,347.95 on Monday, as investors reacted to Chinese data releases that largely met or beat expectations. Despite this, the market had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks. The decline was attributed to "every time we are faced with a major economic number, it comes as a huge sigh of relief," according to Vanguard markets managing partner Stephen Innes.

site_title: US airlines cancel thousands of flights as Boeing works on 737 Max problems
summary: US airlines American, United, and Southwest have cancelled thousands of flights due to Boeing's 737 Max technical problems, which have grounded the planes since March. The cancellations, affecting hundreds of flights daily, are expected to continue through November, with Boeing aiming to submit software updates for approval by September. The Federal Aviation Administration has declined to offer a firm timeline for lifting the grounding order, citing a thorough process. The 737 Max's Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System, which can override pilot controls, has been a major concern following two deadly crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia.

site_title: Pound is weakest ever at start of summer and worse may be coming
summary: The pound is at its weakest point in history at the start of summer, hitting a two-year low against the US dollar this month. Sterling has suffered record weekly losses against the euro and is expected to worsen in August due to risk-averse trading conditions and the upcoming change in UK leadership. A new prime minister is likely to be chosen, raising the prospect of a no-deal Brexit, and a divided Parliament on recess during the summer holiday. The pound may fall to 92 pence per euro by September or October, according to some strategists.

site_title: Vietnam factories buoyed by diversion from China: Report
summary: Vietnam's factories are benefiting from China's labor-intensive manufacturing shift, with greenfield investments in electronics production and capital inflows from South Korea and Japan. However, the report notes that industry value chains now rely more on research and development, innovation, and value-added services, requiring countries to alter their investment priorities and develop new skills to compete in a knowledge-intensive trade landscape. This shift is driven by Asian companies building shorter, more local supply chains and a more internally connected region.

site_title: Sports Direct delays results as House of Fraser deal backfires
summary: British retailer Sports Direct has delayed publishing its annual results due to difficulties integrating its purchase of House of Fraser stores and increased scrutiny of its accounts. Shares dropped 14% to a seven-month low, with the company citing "unbelievably bad" trading in December and "uncertainty" over the future performance of the acquired business. The delay is attributed to a review by Britain's accounting watchdog and increased complexity from its acquisition of video gaming retailer Game Digital.

site_title: Taking a long-term view
summary: Singapore's capital markets ecosystem faces threats from polarization, driven by technology and social fragmentation. This has led to uneven distribution of data, knowledge, and capital, eroding trust in the markets. Companies are struggling with financial difficulties, often due to tough business environments or aggressive decisions, rather than outright fraud. To address these challenges, financial education and literacy are crucial for investors, enabling them to diversify their portfolios and protect themselves. By taking charge of their investments, individuals can help strengthen the sustainability of the capital markets ecosystem.

site_title: BMW launches first of its kind subscription service here
summary: BMW has launched "Access by BMW," a subscription service allowing users to swap in and out of different BMW cars at leisure, starting at S$2,288 a month. The service includes insurance, maintenance, and road tax, and can be paused or cancelled at any time. With a fleet of 40-50 cars, Access by BMW targets tech-savvy millennials and frequent travelers, offering a hassle-free experience without the commitment of car ownership. The service is the first of its kind in Singapore, following a successful launch in Nashville, Tennessee in March.

images.alt_text: Ms Chandy personally pushed for the subscription service when she was posted here last July; she herself spent only one weekend in Singapore last month.

site_title: Oil trades near US$60 on storm disruption as glut concerns linger
summary: Oil prices rose 0.4% near $60 a barrel after a storm shut 73% of US Gulf of Mexico crude production. Despite lingering demand concerns, the US stockpile reduction and rising tensions in the Middle East contributed to the gain. However, Opec warned of a glut in 2020 and the IEA predicted a surprise increase in global inventories in the first half of this year, casting doubt on the longer-term outlook. Some producers are preparing to return workers to offshore platforms, but the impact of China's slowing economy and US-Iran tensions remains a concern.

site_title: India's diesel demand set for detour as drivers switch to petrol
summary: India's diesel demand growth is decoupling from the car market as motorists increasingly switch to petrol vehicles, mainly due to the diminishing price advantage of diesel over petrol. This shift is expected to reduce diesel demand growth, potentially leading to a glut of diesel in the region and putting pressure on refining profit margins. The decline in diesel's discount to petrol has seen sales of diesel-powered cars fall to a record low share of total sales, with commercial vehicles and government spending now expected to drive demand growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance despite China slowdown
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Monday despite China's weakest economic growth in nearly three decades, due to the US trade war. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indexes rose 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively. China's economy grew 6.2% in the second quarter, within forecast and the government's target range, with analysts attributing the slowdown to the US trade war.

site_title: Online fashion platform Zilingo appoints James Perry as chief financial officer
summary: Zilingo, an online fashion platform, has appointed James Perry as its first chief financial officer. Perry, a former Citigroup executive, brings over 20 years of experience in corporate finance, including overseeing clients raising funds over $150 billion. As Zilingo expands globally, Perry will join the management team to propel the business forward in terms of scalability and sustainability. Zilingo's CEO Ankiti Bose welcomed Perry's appointment, citing the company's innovative approach to the fashion industry.

site_title: Turkey marks third anniversary of failed coup
summary: Turkey marked the third anniversary of a failed coup attempt on July 15, 2016, with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan laying flowers at a monument for victims. Nearly 250 people were killed and over 2,000 injured in the attempt, which was met with widespread protests. Erdogan has faced growing tensions with the West, a weakened economy, and worsening relations with the US, while strengthening ties with Russia. The anniversary comes at a challenging time for Erdogan, with his party's loss in the Istanbul local election and ongoing arrests and trials of suspected coup plotters.

site_title: Knight Frank Singapore names Alan Tan head of agency arm
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed Alan Tan, a 20-year industry veteran, as head of its agency arm KF Property Network. Tan leads over 600 real estate salespersons and reports to Wendy Tang, group managing director.

site_title: Citigroup profit beats estimates on gains in consumer lending
summary: Citigroup reported a quarterly profit of $4.80 billion, beating analyst estimates, driven by gains in consumer lending and disciplined expense management. Total loans rose 3% to $689 billion, while deposits increased 5% to $1.05 trillion. Trading revenue declined 4% due to fixed-income trading and equities businesses. Net interest income rose 2%, and the bank's return on tangible common equity improved to 11.9%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking feedback on introducing volatility controls to protect investors from extreme price swings. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over US tariff announcements and the Asian garment industry is bracing for potential tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case. The UK economy shrank for the second month in a row, and ASEAN has downplayed the significance of Myanmar's upcoming election.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens at record highs as earnings season kicks off
summary: US stocks opened at record highs on Monday as corporate earnings kicked off, with Citigroup beating expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 32.66 points, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 4.03 points. Despite tariff uncertainty, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records. The positive start to earnings season is expected to continue, with investors optimistic about the market's performance.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust declares flat DPU of 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for the second quarter of 2019, despite a 26.3% increase in distributable cash flow (DCF) to S$45.8 million. The trust's revenue and net profits also increased, with a 2.5-fold rise in revenue to S$418 million and a swing from a loss to a profit of S$15.96 million. The trust's gearing decreased to 34.2% following an equity fund raising exercise and perpetual securities issuance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in positive territory, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.29% to 28,554.88, driven by speculation of fresh stimulus measures in China following data showing another slowdown in economic growth. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, with the latter rising 1.00%. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and came despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Lower one-off income hits Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU
summary: Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU decreased 2.1% to 1.39 Singapore cents due to lower one-off income from Ocean Financial Centre and Bugis Junction Towers. Lower property income and net property income were also attributed to a weaker Australian dollar. However, income from T Tower and 8 Exhibition Street partially offset the decline. Net property income fell 37.8% to S$26.9 million. The Reit manager committed leases of 272,900 sq ft, bringing portfolio occupancy to 99.1%.

site_title: DBS downgrades full-year Singapore growth forecast to 0.7%, OCBC lowers it to 0-1%
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at a slower pace than initially forecast, with DBS Group Research and OCBC Bank lowering their full-year growth predictions to 0.7% and 0-1% respectively. The downgrades come after disappointing second-quarter flash data, which showed a 0.1% year-on-year growth rate, the weakest in 10 years. Economists attribute the slowdown to weak global demand and external headwinds, including the US-China trade tensions and Middle East tensions. The government has stated that it does not expect a full-year recession, but the economic outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Gojek rides to come with inward-facing video cameras
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing company Gojek plans to install inward-facing video cameras in its cars, recording video and audio footage for seven days. The devices will be accessible only to the Land Transport Authority and police, and customers will be notified before their ride if a camera is installed. Passengers can cancel their ride if they do not wish to be recorded. The move aims to ensure "better safety and security for all users on the Gojek platform."

site_title: Symantec falls as deal talks with Broadcom are said to have stalled
summary: Symantec's proposed merger with Broadcom has stalled as discussions over a price of US$28.25 per share failed to reach an agreement. The deal, valued at approximately US$17.5 billion, would have seen Broadcom expand into the software business. Talks have halted, but could resume if both parties compromise on price or if Symantec faces pressure to re-engage. As a result, Symantec's shares fell 13% to US$22.29, while Broadcom's shares rose 2.4%.

site_title: SGX considers volatility controls for pre-open and pre-close trading
summary: SGX is considering introducing volatility controls to its securities trading auction process to protect investors from extreme price swings. The proposed controls, which could be implemented as early as next year, include price collars and time extensions for the pre-open, mid-day, and closing auctions. These measures aim to prevent extreme price movements, similar to the 83% drop in Jardine Matheson's pre-market trading in January. The consultation is open until August 15, and changes will be implemented if deemed feasible.

site_title: Indonesia posts smaller-than-expected US$200m trade surplus in June
summary: Indonesia posted a smaller-than-expected US$200 million trade surplus in June, contrary to a Reuters poll's prediction of a US$690 million surplus. Imports rose 2.80% to US$11.58 billion, while exports fell 8.98% to US$11.78 billion. Long holidays during Ramadan contributed to the weak foreign trade. This marks the second consecutive month of declining exports and imports, following softer global trade amid the US-China trade war.

images.alt_text: Indonesia recorded a narrower-than-expected trade surplus in June, as imports surprisingly rose, government data showed on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on worries over economy, Q2 earnings
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Monday due to concerns over the country's fragile economy and second-quarter corporate earnings. The Kospi index fell 0.2% to 2,082.48 points, snapping a three-session winning streak. Foreign investors bought 14.2 billion won worth of shares, while the won was flat against the US dollar. China's economic growth data, which showed a slowdown to 6.2% in the second quarter, had little impact on South Korean markets. Investors remain cautious ahead of key earnings releases from SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics.

site_title: Developers sell 821 private homes in June, 26% higher on year, down 14% from May: URA data
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 821 private homes in June, a 26% increase from the same period last year, but a 14% decrease from May. This marks a 25.5% increase from June 2018. In contrast, 670 private homes were launched last month, down from 1,394 units in May and 726 units in June last year.

site_title: Singapore is 3rd in Asia-Pac for nurturing women entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore ranks third in the Asia-Pacific for nurturing women entrepreneurs, behind Sydney and Melbourne, according to a study by Dell. The city's strengths lie in talent and technology, but its weaknesses are access to capital and a supportive market. The ranking fell from eighth in 2017 to 21st in 2019 due to increased competition. Despite progress in some areas, Singapore still faces challenges in providing women entrepreneurs with capital, mentors, and equal opportunities, with issues including a lack of female board members and accelerators, and gender parity pay.

site_title: Australia shares hit by financials, but miners help trim losses; NZ weaker
summary: Australian shares ended down 0.65% at 6,653 points, despite miners' gains driven by Chinese economic data. The mining sector rose 0.3% with Rio Tinto and BHP Group up 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively. Financial stocks, however, declined 0.8%, with AMP shedding nearly 16% to a record low. New Zealand shares fell 0.3% at 10,666.56, with Meridian Energy and Mercury New Zealand down 3.1% and 2%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon barely changed at 3.356.25
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Monday afternoon at 3.356.25, down 1.09 points or 0.03% from the previous day's close. China's Q2 GDP data, which fell within expectations, brought relief to market watchers, with Vanguard markets managing partner Stephen Innes stating that the data confirmed the market's view that China's economy is slowing. The STI was up 0.4% on Thursday, and local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, while Thai Beverage and Singapore Press Holdings fell.

site_title: Singapore appoints 3 new High Court judges and one international judge
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob appointed three new High Court judges, Judicial Commissioners Pang Khang Chau, Audrey Lim Yoon Cheng, and Ang Cheng Hock, effective August 1, and an international judge, Arjan Kumar Sikri, for the Singapore International Commercial Court until January 4, 2021. The appointments bring the Supreme Court's total judges to 23, including the Chief Justice and four Judges of Appeal.

site_title: Amazon Prime Day can cost competitors later on
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sale has grown significantly, with 250 retailers offering their own sales to compete with the event. This "Black Friday in July" has led to a record $447 billion in July sales in the US, surpassing December sales. The sale, which spans two days, offers major discounts on various products, further solidifying Amazon's influence on the retail calendar.

images.alt_text: Amazon had already revolutionized the way people read books, watch TV and shop online. And now it has succeeded in transforming the retail calendar.

site_title: Toxic employers face jail as South Korea tackles workplace bullying
summary: South Korea has implemented a revised labour law that will criminalise business owners who unfairly dismiss employees who have been harassed at work. The law, which comes into effect on Tuesday, will subject owners to three years imprisonment or a fine of up to 30 million won (S$34,000) for unfairly demoting or dismissing workers who allege harassment. The move is a response to widespread workplace bullying, with a recent government survey finding that two-thirds of workers had experienced harassment on the job.

site_title: Peter Thiel urges US probe of Google's 'seemingly treasonous' acts
summary: Peter Thiel, a Trump supporter and Google investor, accused Google of "seemingly treasonous" actions by collaborating with China and lapsing a US defense department contract. Thiel called for an FBI and CIA investigation into Google's AI research program and senior management, suggesting foreign intelligence agencies may be involved. Thiel praised Trump's trade efforts with China and criticized Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren's calls to break up tech giants like Google.

site_title: China's Xiaomi continues chip strategy revamp with investment in semiconductor designer
summary: China's Xiaomi has invested around 6% in semiconductor designer VeriSilicon Holdings Co Ltd, as part of its chip strategy revamp under the "Made in China 2025" initiative. This move aims to boost the country's self-reliance in semiconductors, a sector the government identifies as crucial for innovation. Xiaomi's chip division has struggled in the past, but the investment marks a significant step towards the company's ambitions in chip-making, which could potentially rival US leaders like Qualcomm.

site_title: Boeing's 737 Max may stay grounded until 2020, WSJ says
summary: Boeing's 737 Max may remain grounded until January 2020, according to the Wall Street Journal, citing unidentified sources within the FAA and pilot-union leaders. The plane's software issue, which surfaced after two crashes killed 346 people, requires an additional patch by Boeing. US airlines, including American Airlines and United Airlines, have adjusted their schedules to accommodate the Max's absence, which is expected to last until early 2020. A firm timeline has not been established, with the situation remaining "fluid."

site_title: Indonesia's plan to lower corporate tax rates to benefit most listed companies: Maybank Kim Eng
summary: Indonesia plans to lower corporate tax rates to 20% from 25%, a move expected to boost earnings of most listed companies. Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng say this will make Indonesia more competitive with neighboring countries. However, the government faces challenges, including parliamentary approval and revenue compensation, which may not be achieved until next year. The analysts suggest a potential VAT increase to 13% to compensate for potential losses, which could impact domestic economic activities and create a near-term shock to the economy.

site_title: Nike supplier pivots away from Vietnam after exiting China
summary: Eclat Textile, a Nike and Lululemon supplier, is pivoting away from Vietnam due to the escalating global trade war, particularly with the US imposing higher import duties on steel from Vietnam. The company is shifting its focus to setting up multiple, smaller regional manufacturing hubs in Southeast Asia, such as Indonesia and Cambodia, to diversify its production and mitigate risks. Eclat aims to invest $80 million in new facilities and expects to reduce its reliance on Vietnam, which now accounts for 50% of its garment production.

site_title: AB InBev seeks plan B after investors bail on year's biggest IPO
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, is facing a bind after its Hong Kong IPO failed, leaving it with a $100 billion debt pile. The company needs to find a new way to reduce debt and mollify shareholders, while reinvigorating a business that has lost its fizz. Options include cutting costs, revisiting an IPO, selling assets, or cutting the dividend. Standard & Poor's has a negative outlook on AB InBev's debt, citing potential further downgrades if debt reduction is not prioritized.

site_title: PUB awards Koh Brothers Eco unit and JV partner S$668.2m pumping stations project
summary: PUB has awarded a S$668.2 million contract to Koh Brothers Eco Engineering's unit and joint venture partner, China Harbour Engineering Company, for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System Phase 2 project at the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The project involves constructing five deep shafts with 26 large capacity pumps, expected to conclude by 2025. The DTSS Phase 2 project aims to boost Singapore's water sustainability through reclamation and recycling of water, with construction commencing in 2019.

site_title: China's first half pork output falls 5.5 per cent to 24.7m tonnes
summary: China's pork production decreased 5.5% in the first half of 2019 to 24.7 million tonnes, largely due to a severe outbreak of African swine fever. The herd size declined 15% to 347.6 million head, resulting in a 6.2% decrease in slaughtered hogs. This decline is the largest in six months, with total meat output falling 2.1% to 39 million tonnes.

site_title: Asia: Markets in retreat as China growth slows further
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday as China's economy expanded 6.2% in April-June, its weakest pace in nearly three decades. The data, in line with forecasts, highlights the impact of the US trade war on China's growth model. Investors await further monetary easing measures from the People's Bank of China and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut. Despite the decline, some markets, such as Manila and Jakarta, rose, while others, like Tokyo, were closed for a holiday.

site_title: One Pearl Bank condo draws 4,000 in turnout during weekend preview
summary: Over 4,000 people attended the public preview of One Pearl Bank, a 99-year leasehold condominium in Singapore, on July 13 and 14. The development, expected to be completed by 2023, features 774 units ranging from studios to penthouses. Bookings are set to open on July 20, with prices starting from S$970,000 for studios and over two-thirds of units priced below S$2 million. The sale price translates to a land price of S$1,515 per square foot, with an additional lease top-up premium of S$201.4 million.

site_title: 1 in 3 Singaporeans do not invest, most financially unprepared for retirement: OCBC survey
summary: About 1 in 3 Singaporeans do not invest, with 34% of investors failing to meet their investment targets, and 27% speculating excessively for quick gains. Most Singaporeans are financially unprepared for retirement, with 65% lacking sufficient funds to maintain their lifestyle. The sandwiched generation, who support both ageing parents and their own children, are particularly financially worried, with 63% concerned about not being able to spend comfortably. Singapore scored 63 out of 100 in the OCBC Financial Wellness Index, indicating room for improvement in financial health.

site_title: One dies, hundreds evacuate after 7.3 quake in Indonesia
summary: A 7.3-magnitude earthquake struck the remote Maluku islands in eastern Indonesia, killing at least one person and causing widespread destruction. Hundreds of people were evacuated to shelters after 160 houses collapsed in the South Halmahera district. Local officials have distributed logistics and food for the evacuees, while aftershocks continue to occur. The quake is the latest in a series of seismic activity in Indonesia, a country prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week with losses, falling 0.59% as investors await Chinese economic growth data. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,303.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Singapore shares little changed at Monday's open; STI down 0.08%
summary: Singapore shares ended Monday at 0.08% lower, at 3,354.59 points, following Friday's disappointing economic data. Despite this, Wall Street's record highs amid rate cut hopes helped curb losses. Key movers included AusGroup (up 11.5%), Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (up 0.7%), and DBS (up 0.4%). The market awaits China's GDP data release and Singapore's economic data, which showed the economy slowed more than expected in the second quarter.

site_title: Colombia puts some banana crops in quarantine on fungus concern
summary: Colombia has placed 150 hectares of banana crops in quarantine in the La Guajira department due to a suspected outbreak of the fusarium R4T fungus, a potentially devastating fungus known as Panama disease. The fungus can remain in the soil for up to 30 years and attacks the roots of banana plants. Colombia is one of the world's leading banana exporters, with 50,000 hectares of banana plantations generating 30,000 direct jobs and exporting over 100 million boxes of bananas worth $859 million in 2018. The quarantine is aimed at strengthening security measures and preventing further spread of the disease.

site_title: Foxconn billionare Gou won't vie for Taiwan's presidency after all
summary: Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang, has chosen firebrand mayor Han Kuo-yu as its presidential candidate, snubbing billionaire Foxconn owner Terry Gou. Han secured a weighted average of 44.8% support in a recent primary poll, while Gou received 27.7%. Han's pro-China views could raise tensions with ruling President Tsai Ing-wen, who is critical of Beijing. Han's victory sets him up as the main challenger to Tsai in January's presidential election, which is expected to be closely fought.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.14 points to 1,670.59. Volume was 95.17 million lots worth RM23.06 million, with 140 gainers surpassing 51 losers.

site_title: China's Sinopec sets up fuel oil unit in Sri Lanka
summary: China Petroleum and Chemical Corp, Sinopec Corp, has set up a fuel oil company in Sri Lanka, Fuel Oil Sri Lanka Co Ltd, to supply fuel to ships along the Indian Ocean. The move is part of China's Belt and Road Initiative infrastructure plan and takes advantage of the strategic location of Hambantota port. This investment comes as India and Oman signed a $3.85 billion deal to build a 200,000 barrel-per-day oil refinery near Hambantota port. Sinopec aims to supply low-sulphur bunker fuels meeting International Maritime Organization standards by 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Monday
summary: Tokyo's financial markets are closed on July 15 for a public holiday, resuming trading on July 16. Meanwhile, global markets continue to trend upwards, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty. Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, while Asia's stocks rally extended into Friday. The Asia region sees mining and healthcare sectors propelling shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Growing demand for hybrid of executive and team assistants in Singapore: Hays
summary: Demand for hybrid executive and team assistants in Singapore's job market is on the rise, driven by companies adopting flatter organizational structures and collaborative working. Recruitment firm Hays notes this shift has led to increased demand for assistants who can adapt to fast-paced environments and support teams. Employers are offering competitive packages, including flexible working arrangements and allowances, to attract capable assistants. The hybrid role may require senior-level EAs to adjust their mindset, as supporting a team is seen as a step forward in their careers.

site_title: Sprawl may eat vestige of Southern California's citrus empire
summary: A 12-acre orange grove in the San Fernando Valley, one of the last remaining in the area, is at the center of a dispute between its owners and community members over its future. The Los Angeles City Council is considering a proposal to give the site a historic designation to preserve at least part of the orchard. The grove, which was once a 100-acre ranch, is a symbol of the region's agricultural past and a nostalgic reminder of the area's transformation into suburban sprawl. The outcome of the proposal is uncertain, but preservation efforts aim to save the last vestige of the citrus industry in the area.

site_title: Home-price growth weakens in China as wider curbs kick in
summary: China's home-price growth weakened for the first time since February, with new-home prices increasing just 0.66% on average in June from May in 70 major cities. This follows a solid upswing in the previous three months, as authorities widened curbs to tamp down on a re-inflating market. The moderation aims to balance the need to keep housing prices under control while supporting a slowing economy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's US$697b wealth fund is hiring
summary: Abu Dhabi's US$697 billion wealth fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, plans to hire new positions in its fixed income and treasury department to boost active management of its portfolio. The fund's 20-year annual rate of return fell to 5.4% from 6.5% the previous year, prompting the move to scale up active investing. The fund aims to increase actively managed investments to 55% of its portfolio, up from 50% in 2018.

site_title: Hedge funds make record bearish cotton bet before prrices tumble
summary: Hedge funds made a record bearish bet on cotton futures just before prices tumbled to a three-year low of US$62.6 cents per pound. The market is suffering from a supply overhang due to high US inventories and tariffs from China. Despite slower global economic growth, demand remains low, and prices have fallen almost 30% in the past 12 months. The net-short position of investors expanded to 41,727 futures and options, the most bearish since 2006, as inventories are projected to reach a 12-year high in the 2019-2020 season.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, United Engineers, HMI, Spackman, SPH, Yoma, AusGroup
summary: Wilmar International and United Engineers received new developments. Wilmar's subsidiary Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings' application to list on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange was accepted by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, with Wilmar retaining majority control. United Engineers denied any involvement in a recent share sale that drew concerns from shareholder Oxley, stating the shares were sold to independent unrelated third parties.

site_title: Shell reports 'operational upset' at unit at Pulau Bukom refinery in Singapore
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's Pulau Bukom refinery and petrochemical complex experienced an operational upset on July 14, resulting in flaring at one of its units. The incident occurred at approximately 2pm and has been reported to the relevant authorities. No injuries were reported, and the rest of the site's operations remained unaffected. The cause of the upset is currently unknown, and an investigation is likely underway.

site_title: Boris Johnson would meet Trump to negotiate trade deal after becoming Prime Minister: The Times
summary: Boris Johnson, the UK's frontrunner to become prime minister, plans to meet US President Donald Trump within two months to negotiate a post-Brexit trade deal. Johnson's ally believes a trade deal with the US will encourage other countries to form agreements, giving the UK "a strong negotiating position." Johnson is ready to travel to the US as soon as possible to secure a limited agreement before the Brexit deadline of October 31.

site_title: China June industrial output up 6.3% y-o-y, beats forecasts, retail sales up 9.8%
summary: China's industrial output grew 6.3% in June from a year earlier, beating market expectations, while retail sales rose 9.8% in annual terms. The data follows a 17-year low in May and suggests the economy may be stabilizing despite the ongoing Sino-US trade war. Fixed-asset investments rose 5.8% for the first half of the year, exceeding forecasts. The positive numbers are a relief for policymakers, who are under pressure to address slowing growth and a potential global recession.

site_title: Singapore to develop over 40 new standards for new tech, business models
summary: Singapore aims to develop over 40 new standards for emerging technologies such as drones, additive manufacturing, and video analytics within the next year. The Singapore Standards Council (SSC) has already published 19 new standards in the past year, with plans to increase industry collaboration and participation. The standards are expected to support economic transformation and innovation, facilitating market access and driving interoperability. The country's standards program is voluntary but mandatory for government bodies in certain cases, and its development is crucial for shaping Singapore's future.

site_title: Glints raises US$6.8m in Series B funding to expand to Vietnam, Hong Kong
summary: Glints, a recruitment and career development platform based in South-east Asia, has raised US$6.8 million in an oversubscribed Series B funding round. The investment will be used to expand into Vietnam and Hong Kong markets and grow its product and engineering teams. Glints aims to automate recruitment processes, making them more efficient and cheaper for clients. The startup has seen six-time revenue growth in the past year and has clients including Go-Jek, AIA, and UOB Bank. The funding will help Glints meet the needs of both candidates and companies in Asia, with a focus on young jobseekers.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott signs 26 new properties, enters 6 new cities
summary: CapitaLand's lodging business unit The Ascott has signed 26 new properties, covering 6,000 units across 22 cities and 11 countries, with a majority under management contracts. The new properties will open in phases from 2019 to 2023, with Ascott entering six new cities, including Atyrau, Nairobi, and Hoi An. This move strengthens its presence in 14 cities and expands its select-service business hotel brand Citadines Connect to Bangkok and Malaysia.

site_title: South Korea imports no oil from Iran in June; H1 imports fall 37%
summary: South Korea imported no crude oil from Iran in June for the second consecutive month, following the end of US sanctions waivers. Iranian oil imports for the first half of the year dropped 36.9% compared to the same period last year. South Korea's crude oil imports fell 12.6% in June to 11.49 million tonnes, with the US becoming a significant supplier, nearly tripling imports to 1.09 million tonnes. This shift is part of South Korea's efforts to diversify its crude sources and replace Iranian oil.

site_title: Rouhani says Iran ready to talk to US if sanctions lifted
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said the country is ready to hold talks with the US if sanctions are lifted and the 2015 nuclear deal is reinstated. The US has signaled openness to negotiations, but Iran has made talks conditional on restoring oil exports. The European parties to the deal, France, Britain, and Germany, have called for dialogue to resume, but US President Donald Trump has announced plans to increase sanctions. Tensions between the US and Iran have escalated, with Tehran scaling back its commitments under the deal.

site_title: Hong Kong turmoil has millionaires eyeing other wealth havens like Singapore
summary: Hong Kong's turmoil has prompted millionaires to consider alternative wealth havens like Singapore, with private bankers reporting a surge in inquiries from investors seeking to move their assets out of the city. The unrest has reinforced concerns about Beijing's erosion of Hong Kong's judicial independence, with many wealthy individuals seeking reassurance of having an overseas bank account. Singapore's stable political environment, rapid air connections with China, and favorable asset management industry have made it an attractive destination for investors, with hundreds of leaflets explaining the process for booking assets in other jurisdictions being snapped up quickly.

images.alt_text: Private bankers are being flooded with inquiries from investors in Hong Kong who are worried about the long-term effects of the political crisis in the Chinese city.

site_title: Singapore's construction sector may face protracted slowdown in medium term: Fitch
summary: Singapore's construction sector may face a protracted slowdown in the medium term due to a global economic downturn, according to Fitch Solutions Macro Research. The sector's growth is expected to weaken to 2.7% in 2020 and 0.5% in 2021, despite a short-term growth of 3% in 2020, driven by a stronger buildings sector and infrastructure projects such as the North-South Corridor. A global recession and uncertainty in markets will dampen demand for commercial and industrial space, leading to a slowdown in the sector.

site_title: China H1 property investment slows, sales dip
summary: China's real estate investment slowed to 10.9% in the first half of the year, down from 11.2% in January-May, marking the slowest pace since 2018. This easing was largely due to a dip in property sales, which declined from a year-on-year increase of 8.1% in January-May to a decrease of 4.9% in the same period. Despite this, real estate investment remains a key driver of growth in China's economy, which is still experiencing a slowdown.

images.alt_text: Growth in China's real estate investment hit 10.9 per cent in the first six months of the year on an annual basis, easing from 11.2 per cent in January-May, official data showed on Monday.

site_title: Pernod Ricard takes 34% stake in Yoma whisky joint venture
summary: Pernod Ricard has acquired a 34% stake in Seagram MM Holdings, a joint venture between Yoma Strategic, Win Brothers, and Delta Capital Myanmar, to produce and distribute whisky in Myanmar. The deal was first announced in May 2018. Following the acquisition, Yoma Strategic now holds 19.8%, while Win Brothers and Delta Capital Myanmar hold 33% and 13.2%, respectively. Pernod Ricard will lead the management of production facilities, distribution network, and brand portfolio of Access Myanmar Distribution Company, which includes the High Class Whisky brand.

site_title: Officials seek answers after blackout in New York's Manhattan
summary: A five-hour blackout in Manhattan's New York City left 73,000 customers without power on Saturday. The blackout, which affected an area from West 30th to West 72nd Street, was caused by a transformer explosion at West 49th Street. Officials ruled out a surge in usage and cyber attack as factors, and said it would take time to determine the cause. Broadway theatres reopened after shows were canceled, and the city's electrical system is prepared to handle increased demand in air conditioning. No injuries or deaths were reported during the blackout.

images.alt_text: Government and utility officials were still searching for definite reasons on Sunday for a five-hour blackout in a large section of New York City's Manhattan borough that left 73,000 customers without power on Saturday.

site_title: Amazon workers in Germany to strike over pay, Verdi union says
summary: Amazon workers in Germany are set to strike over pay for at least two days starting Sunday night, coinciding with Prime Day. The Verdi union, which represents logistics workers, is demanding better pay and recognition of collective bargaining agreements. The strikes will affect seven Amazon sites across Germany, where workers are seeking a living wage despite the company's hefty discounts on Prime Day. Amazon has faced a long-running battle with unions in Germany over pay and conditions.

site_title: Italy business outlook improves sharply in Q2: survey
summary: Italy's business outlook has improved sharply in the second quarter, with confidence reaching a one-year high, according to a global survey by IHS Markit. The country's net balance of companies forecasting an increase in activity in the coming 12 months rose to +29%, the highest since June 2018. Manufacturers' confidence also improved, with a balance of +28, while service providers cited improved internal demand and better technology utilization as reasons for optimism. Despite political instability and global trade protectionism, the Italian economy has shown signs of improvement, with a 7-year low jobless rate and falling borrowing costs.

site_title: Spackman to buy Korean film production company for S$3.3m in shares
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group, a Catalist-listed film producer and investor, is acquiring 100% interest in South Korean film production company Simplex Films for S$3.3 million in new shares. The acquisition aims to expand Spackman's annual film production capacity and includes the distribution of Simplex's upcoming film "Jeesters: The Game Changers" in South Korea and overseas. The deal is part of Spackman's strategy to aggressively look for accretive acquisitions and share networks and resources with Simplex.

site_title: India postpones Moon mission launch over 'technical snag'
summary: India postponed the launch of its Chandrayaan-2 Moon mission due to a technical snag discovered 56 minutes and 24 seconds before the planned liftoff. The mission aimed to make India the fourth country to land a craft on the lunar surface, following Russia, the US, and China. Officials did not provide details on the issue or an estimated revised launch date. The launch was halted just under an hour before the planned 2:51am (2121 GMT Sunday) liftoff at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, India.

site_title: Algeria ex-industry minister detained in graft probe
summary: Algeria's former industry minister, Youcef Yousfi, has been placed in provisional detention on allegations of squandering public money and abuse of power. He is the latest in a series of prominent figures to be detained or questioned in connection with corruption since President Abdelaziz Bouteflika's resignation in April. Yousfi's detention comes amid ongoing protests demanding a complete overhaul of the government and the departure of Bouteflika-era figures before new presidential elections.

site_title: Australian economy stuck in sub-par growth, but to dodge recession: poll
summary: Australia's economy is forecasted to experience sub-par growth of 2.1% in 2019, down from previous predictions, but analysts expect it to avoid a recession. The Reserve Bank of Australia has cut interest rates twice, while tax handouts may help stabilize growth. However, risks remain, including a potential trade war with China and softening labor demand indicators. Despite this, analysts expect core inflation to remain low, and stimulus opportunities are available, with growth predicted to pick up to 2.5% in 2020 and 2.6% in 2021.

site_title: Rain, flooding follow Storm Barry as it spins north from New Orleans
summary: Storm Barry trudged through northwestern Louisiana, weakening to a tropical depression, but dropping up to 38cm of rain, causing life-threatening flood conditions along the Mississippi River. The storm made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane on Saturday and brought 7.6-12.7cm of additional rain, leading to dangerous flooding. New Orleans saw light rain, with some businesses open, and residents in low-lying areas received mandatory evacuation orders. The storm has shut in 73% of US crude oil production in the Gulf of Mexico, and tornadoes were possible across parts of southeastern Louisiana.

site_title: China Q2 GDP rises 6.2% y-o-y, slowest in at least 27 years
summary: China's Q2 GDP rose 6.2% year-over-year, the slowest pace in at least 27 years, due to a faltering trade war with the US. This marks a further decline from the first quarter's 6.4% growth, raising concerns about the need for policy support measures. Analysts had forecast the same 6.2% growth. The US-China trade war's impact on the world's second-largest economy is being closely watched, with fears of a global recession. China's policymakers face pressure to act to boost consumption and investment.

images.alt_text: China's economic growth slowed to 6.2 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier, the weakest pace in at least 27 years, as demand at home and abroad faltered amid an escalating trade war with the United States.

site_title: Trump under fire for 'racist' attack on US congresswomen
summary: US President Donald Trump sparked controversy with remarks aimed at four progressive Democratic congresswomen, telling them to "go back" to their countries of origin. The comments, branded "racist" and "xenophobic," targeted women of color, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar. Trump's remarks were met with fierce criticism from Democratic leaders and lawmakers, who accused him of perpetuating white nationalism and racism. The incident has reignited debate over Trump's views on immigration and race.

site_title: Smaller London home-price drop shows bottom near: Rightmove
summary: London house prices fell 0.2% in July, the smallest drop in five years, as sellers held back due to market stabilization. This is a lower drop than the average 0.6% decline for July over the past five years. The UK's decision to leave the EU has weighed on the market, but low interest rates and record employment are preventing a sharper decline. The average time to sell a property remained steady at 67 days, suggesting the market may be "bottoming out."

site_title: Top Thai bank sees digital platform driving surge in loans growth
summary: Siam Commercial Bank forecasts a surge in digital lending to retail customers, with credit card and personal loans expected to rise nearly eight-fold this year to at least 18 billion baht. The bank's online retail banking expansion has been driven by a $1 billion investment and partnerships with technology companies. Despite increasing domestic household debt, digital lending is seen as a key to growth for Thai banks, with online services offering cheaper fees and a wider target group.

site_title: Erdogan says Turkey will make serious interest rate cuts: broadcaster
summary: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan announced plans to make serious interest rate cuts, aiming to reduce inflation from over 15% to single digits by the end of the year. This follows the replacement of the central bank governor last week. Erdogan stated that the cuts will be significant and will lead to a reduction in inflation. Economists expect a 200 basis point rate cut at the next meeting on July 25, which could impact the country's struggling economy.

site_title: Desperate for next fix: South Africa in grip of heroin-based 'nyaope'
summary: South Africa is grappling with a heroin-based street drug called 'nyaope', which has led to widespread addiction. The drug's main ingredient is heroin, and users often sell items, such as helping others carry bags, to fund their next fix. Withdrawal symptoms can start within two hours, prompting users to work desperately to earn money. The issue has become a significant concern, with many individuals struggling to overcome the addiction. Authorities have yet to implement effective solutions to combat the growing problem.

site_title: E-wallet operators set sights on digital banking space
summary: E-wallet operators in Singapore are exploring the possibility of obtaining a digital bank license, which will allow them to offer a range of financial services to individuals and businesses. At least five e-wallet operators, including Liquid Group, Xfers, and MatchMove Pay, are considering applying for the license, which will be issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The digital bank license will require operators to meet capital requirements and adhere to risk management practices, but it will also provide opportunities for financial inclusion in emerging economies.

site_title: Benetton family firm Atlantia tipped to take Alitalia stake: reports
summary: Italy's Atlantia group, owned by the Benetton family, is set to take a 35% stake in struggling airline Alitalia, alongside three other investors, including the Italian state railway Ferrovie dello Stato (FS) and the Italian Treasury. The rescue plan, to be presented on Monday, aims to bring in new investors to reduce the airline's debt. Atlantia's offer, worth over 300 million euros, comes after the company has already injected money into Alitalia. The move is seen as a positive step for the airline's relaunch, with Italy's economic development minister welcoming the new investment.

site_title: Singapore startup FintruX Network launches financing platform
summary: FintruX Network, a Singapore startup, has launched a global financing platform called TruX, powered by blockchain technology. TruX creates a global business network to empower startups and SMEs to achieve growth and sustainability. The platform enables businesses to establish a dynamic credit reputation based on alternative credit data, facilitating credit terms and commercial loans. FintruX has raised over US$25 million in funding and has partnered with companies like ZWEEC Analytics, a winner of the Emerging Enterprise Award. The platform supports over 130 currencies and is available globally, addressing challenges faced by small business owners and SMEs.

site_title: Hamilton wins record sixth British GP, extends F1 lead
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured a record sixth British Grand Prix victory at Silverstone, extending his F1 lead. Hamilton finished 25 seconds ahead of teammate Valtteri Bottas, despite a favorable safety car intervention that allowed him a free pit stop. Hamilton now holds a 39-point advantage in the title race and has won seven times in 10 races this year, tying the British Grand Prix record with Jim Clark and Alain Prost.

site_title: Huawei planning major job cuts in US: WSJ
summary: Huawei is planning major job cuts at its US-based research and development arm, Futurewei Technologies, citing US sanctions and concerns about its ties to the Chinese government. The layoffs could affect hundreds of employees, with some Chinese employees given the option to return home. The move comes as the US administration has put Huawei on its entity list, restricting US companies from supplying technology to the Chinese firm. This is the latest development in the ongoing dispute between the US and Huawei over national security concerns.

site_title: Ex-owner of Russia's largest independent oil refinery arrested in Moscow
summary: Dmitry Mazurov, former owner of Russia's largest independent oil refinery, was arrested in Moscow on Saturday. He was a suspect in a criminal case and was taken into custody at Sheremetyevo airport. The arrest was made by the Investigative Committee. No further details were provided by Mazurov's company, New Stream group.

site_title: US proposes barring big tech companies from offering financial services, digital currencies
summary: The US House Financial Services Committee has proposed a bill that would bar big tech companies from offering financial services or issuing digital currencies. The bill, if passed, would impose a US$1 million daily fine for violating the rules. The proposal comes after Facebook's Libra digital coin sparked widespread objection. The bill is expected to face opposition from Republican members, making passage in the lower chamber uncertain. The move aims to address concerns about the risks and lack of regulation in the digital currency space.

site_title: James Murdoch makes largest deal yet with bet on VR
summary: James Murdoch has invested $20 million in virtual reality company Void LLC, taking a seat on the board.
