The investment is the largest in Murdoch's portfolio, joining Fidelity Management, Qualcomm Ventures, and Walt Disney Co. Void operates immersive entertainment experiences in 11 cities worldwide, and Murdoch prefers its technology over rival Dreamscape Immersive. Murdoch's investment is part of his Lupa Systems fund, which spans technology and entertainment.

site_title: Mystery surrounds Epstein's 'orgy island'
summary: Jeffrey Epstein's private island in the US Virgin Islands, dubbed "Orgy Island" and "Pedophile Island," has sparked mystery and speculation. The island, purchased by Epstein in 1998 for $7.95 million, was reportedly used to host young women, including models and guests of wealthy business figures and celebrities. A former employee recalled women sunbathing topless or nude, and extra security measures were taken to protect Epstein's personal life. The island's size and Epstein's fortune remain a subject of intrigue, with theories about his business dealings and tax benefits.

site_title: Bankruptcy among options that luxury retailer Barneys NY exploring
summary: US luxury department store operator Barneys New York Inc is exploring options, including a potential bankruptcy filing, to address high rents and changing consumer tastes. The nearly 100-year-old retailer is working with law firm Kirkland & Ellis LLP to prepare for a possible bankruptcy filing, which could come in the coming weeks. Barneys has 28 locations and operates upscale department stores, as well as restaurants, but is struggling to compete with e-commerce firms like Amazon.

site_title: Federer rues 'missed opportunity' to win ninth Wimbledon title
summary: Roger Federer expressed disappointment and frustration after losing to Novak Djokovic in the longest Wimbledon men's final at 5 hours and 57 minutes. Federer had two match points but failed to convert them, ultimately losing 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, 4-6, 13-12. He described the loss as a "missed opportunity" and said it was hard to tell if losing in straight sets would have been less bitter. Federer still holds the all-time Grand Slam record of 20 but said it was not the thing that motivated him as a player.

site_title: Mall clashes at latest Hong Kong anti-extradition march
summary: Hong Kong's anti-extradition protests turned violent at a shopping mall on Sunday, with riot police and protesters clashing in a night of fresh unrest. The clashes, which began after a rally in a nearby district, involved pepper spray, batons, and projectiles, resulting in at least one officer being knocked unconscious. The protests, which have lasted over a month, are calling for democratic reforms, universal suffrage, and an end to sliding freedoms in the semi-autonomous hub. The government has condemned the violence, while Beijing has thrown its full support behind the city's leader, Carrie Lam.

site_title: Alitalia rescue plan could see Delta boost its minority stake
summary: Italy's government is working on a rescue package for bankrupt Alitalia, which could see US carrier Delta Air Lines boost its stake in a new company from an initial minority holding. Delta may acquire more shares from state bodies Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane SpA and the Treasury or through a capital injection, potentially increasing its stake from 10-15% to 50%. The airline faces liquidation or de facto nationalization and a deadline for bids is set for Monday, with a group of investors submitting a binding offer.

site_title: PODCAST: ABCs of robo-powered wealth management (Money Hacks, Ep 49)
summary: In a recent podcast, "ABCs of robo-powered wealth management," experts discuss the benefits of dollar asset diversification, particularly for Asia. As countries seek to reduce dependence on the US dollar, asset managers are exploring alternative currencies and investing strategies. Meanwhile, low-profile property trusts are investing in data centers, and Jack Ma-backed Ant plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. The podcast also touches on the growing demand for ETFs in Asia and Europe, driven by retail investors, and the potential for productivity gains to unlock wealth creation.

site_title: Fusion energy startups see renewables leaving a gap in power market
summary: Fusion energy startups, including First Light Fusion Ltd, believe that while renewable energy growth is necessary, it may not be enough to combat climate change. A study commissioned by First Light concludes that new zero-carbon technologies are needed to avert catastrophic climate change, with the potential electricity shortfall needing to be filled by fusion energy. The study estimates that fusion could deliver power at $60 a megawatt-hour, making it a viable option to address the gap, with a potential addressable market of 460 gigawatts globally.

site_title: US-China trade tensions hit Panama Canal revenues
summary: US-China trade tensions have negatively impacted Panama Canal revenues, with cargo from the US to China declining this year. The decline is attributed to China cutting imports of American food and fuel. According to Panama Canal Authority CEO Jorge Luis Quijano, US cargo through the waterway has slumped. The trade tensions between the US and China are affecting global trade, highlighting the significant role of the Panama Canal in international commerce.

site_title: On song with an eagle, birdies and a 310m drive
summary: Lim Joo Seng won The FJ Player of The Round award in the 10th Business Times Corporate Golf League, scoring 41 stable points on the System 36 format at the Serapong course. He also won the Hugo Boss Longest Drive prize with a 310m drive on the par-five 450m third hole. AudiSport secured the top spot in the 20-team table with 112 points, propelled by Lim's performance. The second leg of the Corporate Golf League will take place on July 24 at Sembawang Country Club.

site_title: GuocoLand mounts drive to be leader in urban rejuvenation
summary: GuocoLand, a Singapore-based developer, is shifting its focus towards urban rejuvenation, considering new asset classes, business lines, and possibly a Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit). The company aims to build on its success in integrated developments, such as Guoco Midtown and Guoco Tower, which are set to be completed in 2022. GuocoLand's goal is to rejuvenate the Beach Road area, connecting various developments in the City Hall; Bugis and Marina Centre sub-markets, and to create a "definitive public space" for events. The company is also exploring a "core and flex" office leasing strategy, offering flexible space for tenants.

site_title: Von der Leyen's bid for EU top job hangs in the balance
summary: European Parliament members will decide on Tuesday whether to approve Ursula von der Leyen as the first female president of the European Commission. The outcome is uncertain, potentially leading to a stalemate. Von der Leyen's bid faces opposition, and a decision may delay business as usual in the European Union.

site_title: Huawei plans to cut jobs in its US R&D unit: report
summary: Huawei plans to cut hundreds of jobs at its US research-and-development subsidiary, Futurewei Technologies Inc, amid the ongoing US blacklisting. The move comes as the company struggles to maintain its US presence. The cuts affect employees in states including Texas, California, and Washington. This move is part of Huawei's broader efforts to mitigate the impact of US President Donald Trump's decision to blacklist the company, which threatens to disrupt the global rollout of fifth-generation technology.

site_title: 'High-rise' schools in the city?
summary: Guocoland Singapore is exploring innovative integrated developments, such as creating parks within high-rise buildings, like the 150,000 sq ft park at Guoco Tower in Tanjong Pagar district. The company aims to redefine what an integrated development looks like in the city.

site_title: Trump's favourite parts of US economy are also the weakest
summary: US President Donald Trump claims a renaissance in US factories, despite the sectors he has championed - coal mining, steel, aluminium, and auto manufacturing - being buffeted by market forces and changing technologies. Analysts say his punitive tariffs have actually hurt these industries, which have become the weakest links in the otherwise solid US economy. The sectors have been damaged by factors beyond his control, including weak foreign demand and a strong US dollar. Trump's policies have also led to bankruptcies, idling hundreds of workers, and declining production in these industries.

site_title: HK anti-extradition protesters take their rally to the suburbs
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters in Hong Kong, including young, elderly, and families, gathered in the suburbs on Sunday, driven by anger over the government's handling of an extradition bill that has revived fears of Beijing eroding freedoms in the former British colony. The protests, which have swelled to millions over the past month, demand the withdrawal of the bill and an end to perceived erosion of freedoms. Demonstrators, waving British and American flags, chanted "Carrie Lam go to hell" and called for an independent investigation into police brutality.

site_title: Junior miner, bullion-linked ETF on SGX rally on gold rush
summary: Singapore's Catalist-listed junior gold miner CNMC Goldmine Holdings has seen a surge in stock price, reaching a year's high, amid the gold rush driven by the US Federal Reserve's dovish posture and rising spot gold prices. The stock has generated a 29.2% total return for the year to July 11, while the SPDR Gold Shares ETF on the Singapore Exchange has doubled its June trading volume and recorded a 9.7% year-to-date return. Analysts attribute the gold rally to uncertainty over global economic growth and the possibility of the Fed's interest rate cut, which has led to a weakening US dollar and a spike in gold prices.

site_title: Potential rate cuts music to market bulls' ears
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell suggests a preemptive rate cut to extend the economic recovery, despite strong June jobs data. Powell's testimony indicates the Fed is taking out insurance against further economic deterioration, potentially leading to a 50-basis-point rate cut. Market bulls welcome the news, with the S&P 500 breaking through 3,000 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 27,000. However, some critics warn that rate cuts could cause imbalances and that the recession may still occur, leaving the Fed with limited ammunition.

site_title: Attenborough's documentaries inspired Lion King
summary: Disney's 3D Lion King remake was inspired by David Attenborough's natural world documentaries, with its creators taking safari tours to real-life locations for inspiration. The film's photo-realistic visuals and realistic animal faces were influenced by Attenborough's work, with composer Hans Zimmer citing his Planet Earth II series as an inspiration. Director Jon Favreau aimed to create the illusion of a naturalistic documentary, with animators relying on actual facial expressions and movements to match the dialogue recorded by voice actors.

site_title: How will a rising Asia lead the way?
summary: Asia is increasingly leading the way in global trade and economic growth, with emerging economies like China, India, and Vietnam developing new industrial capabilities and becoming less reliant on foreign imports. The region's share of top-performing firms has grown from 19% to 31% over the past two decades, and Asia is home to more than one-third of the world's unicorns. However, the report also highlights the need for investment in research and development, data, and artificial intelligence to remain competitive, as well as reskilling and upskilling for workers.

site_title: Lagarde as ECB chief 'could hasten currency devaluations'
summary: Economic analysts fear that Christine Lagarde's appointment as European Central Bank (ECB) chief will accelerate euro devaluation against the US dollar, yen, and other currencies. Her expected continuation of the "flush money" policy has caused negative short-term interest rates in Europe, leading to a 20% decline in the euro's value against the US dollar over the past four years. Analysts warn of potential backlash from the Trump administration, which could cause an economic downturn, and a "global currency war."

site_title: Want to profit from a trade war? There's an investment fund for that too
summary: An investment fund focused on profiting from a trade war has been created, catering to investors drawn to unique and emerging assets. Analysts note the trend of people investing in "wacky" and new funds, driven by the desire for novelty. This phenomenon is attributed to the allure of new and potentially lucrative opportunities, despite the lack of traditional investment options.

site_title: How can blockchain help create better public services?
summary: Blockchain technology can improve public services by increasing efficiency, trust, and transparency. In government operations, blockchain-based solutions can enable secure and transparent movement of assets, track spending and resources, and facilitate data sharing and security. Applications include public finance management, data sharing, and security, with examples in Southeast Asia such as Singapore's Project Ubin and the City of Vienna's blockchain hub. A supportive ecosystem of collaboration between the public and private sectors is necessary to unlock the full potential of blockchain in public services.

site_title: Focus will be on Chinese data, trade tensions this week
summary: US-China trade tensions will continue to influence market sentiment this week, with a focus on Chinese data and the second-quarter GDP release on Monday. US President Trump's latest tweet on July 11 also raised concerns about China's agricultural purchases. Investors will also be monitoring June retail sales, industrial production, unemployment data, and home prices in China, as well as non-oil domestic exports in Singapore. Central banks, including the Fed and Bank of Korea, are expected to keep rates unchanged, with some predicting rate cuts amid the global economic slowdown.

site_title: Positive moves to tackle shortage of Singapore MNCs
summary: Singapore is launching a 2.5-year program, Scale-up SG, to groom local high-growth enterprises into global powerhouses. The invite-only program targets promising SMEs with a good track record and ambition to become big. The initiative aims to address the shortage of globally competitive Singaporean MNCs, which is attributed to legacy issues, lack of talent, and a lack of ambition. The government is placing its bets on high-potentials through a targeted approach, with the goal of building a strong external wing for the Singapore economy.

site_title: Facebook's Libra faces scepticism from London fintech sector
summary: London's fintech industry expresses skepticism towards Facebook's planned virtual currency, Libra, with about two-thirds of experts raising their hand to express distrust. Concerns over governance and regulation, as well as privacy concerns, are major concerns. Regulators, including the Bank of England and the European Central Bank, have also raised eyebrows. While some believe Libra will force regulators to present clearer guidelines, others argue it's not a true cryptocurrency due to its centralization and lack of decentralization. The cryptocurrency community is divided on Libra's potential impact.

site_title: Hong Kong slaughterhouse may shut due to pig shortage
summary: A Hong Kong slaughterhouse may shut due to a pig shortage from China. The Tsuen Wan slaughterhouse's owners plan to convert the land into a columbarium, citing the lack of pigs. The government prioritizes increasing mainland China's fresh pork supply to Hong Kong, but no formal notice has been received.

site_title: BNP Paribas joins lenders shunning US private prison industry over Trump policies
summary: France's BNP Paribas joins other lenders in distancing itself from the US private prison industry due to controversy over Trump administration detention policies. The bank will no longer finance US private prison operators, but existing contracts remain unaffected. This decision follows similar moves by US banks such as SunTrust, Wells Fargo, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America. The private prison industry, which accounts for about two-thirds of those held by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement, has argued that the decisions are politically motivated.

site_title: Cuba takes first step in railways upgrade with China, Russia help
summary: Cuba has launched its first new train passenger cars in over four decades, marking the beginning of a major upgrade of its decrepit railway system with help from China and Russia. The 80 Chinese-made rail cars, which set off on their maiden journey on Saturday, are the first step in a plan to modernize the country's railways by 2030. The upgrade aims to improve efficiency and safety, with new cars offering air conditioning and better conditions for passengers. Cuba has also signed a deal with Russia worth almost $1 billion to modernize its railways.

site_title: Surge in Chinese buyer enquiries for Australian homes: Juwai.com
summary: Chinese buyer enquiries for Australian homes rose 40% in the first quarter, marking the second consecutive year-on-year increase since 2016, according to Juwai.com. This signals a possible revival of demand for Australia's beleaguered property market, particularly from Chinese investors. A weaker Aussie dollar and stabilisation in home prices could boost Chinese investments. However, the market still faces challenges, with home values down 8% and further weakness in the economy.

site_title: Subway, theatres close as blackout hits Manhattan
summary: A transformer explosion in Manhattan on Saturday caused a five-hour blackout affecting over 70,000 homes and businesses, including subways, stores, and Broadway theatres. The outage, which began at 6:47pm EDT, lasted until 11:47pm EDT and was the 42nd anniversary of a 1977 blackout that sparked rioting and looting. No deaths or injuries were reported, but the city's main utility, Consolidated Edison Inc, faced renewed calls to overhaul its network following the incident.

site_title: China plans to toughen emission checks on steel mills
summary: China plans to tighten emission assessments on steel mills, with the country's environment ministry set to bring in industrial associations to carry out assessments to prevent fraud. The move aims to reduce pollution from the steel industry, which remains a major contributor despite production restrictions and emission upgrades. The ministry will impose severe punishment on mills found to be deceiving on their emission levels, with the goal of achieving ultra-low emission standards by 2020 for over 60% of steel capacity.

site_title: Trump declines to set US uranium production quotas
summary: US President Donald Trump declined to issue uranium production quotas, instead ordering a 90-day review of the issue. The decision was welcomed by nuclear power generators, who fear curbs on fuel imports would boost costs. Trump disputed Commerce Department findings that imports threaten national security, but acknowledged the need for a deeper analysis. The review will consider national security implications and recommendations for domestic nuclear fuel production. The move may signal future White House intervention in energy policy issues ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Let's talk about gay penguins: Munich zoo joins Pride week
summary: The Munich zoo has joined Pride week with an unusual tour that explores same-sex love in the animal kingdom. The zoo's guides point out that many animal species, including giraffes, penguins, and lions, display homosexual behavior. Biologist Guenter Strauss notes that penguins, for example, conduct long-term homosexual relationships and are often bisexual, unlike humans who tend to have a fixed sexual orientation. The zoo aims to boost tolerance among humans and promote acceptance of LGBTQ+ rights, as attacks based on sexual orientation are still a problem in Germany.

site_title: 73 acquisitions and disposals filed while 14 companies conduct buybacks
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.7% from July 5 to 11, with 14 companies conducting share buybacks totaling S$11.1 million. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also increased, with 28 acquisitions and 6 disposals filed. Notable transactions include Full Day Ltd's acquisition of Cordlife Group shares, and First Sponsor Group chairman Calvin Ho Han Leong increasing his interest in the company to 45.38%. Other companies saw increases in stake ownership, including UOB-Kay Hian Holdings, Indofood Agri Resources, and JEP Holdings. The STI's 2019 total return is now 11.5%.

site_title: Dollar slides for 3rd day on US rate cut bets
summary: The US dollar declined for a third consecutive session, falling 0.1% against a basket of currencies to 97.004, due to expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Despite a slight increase in producer prices, analysts believe the Fed will cut rates this month, citing the core PCE price index's low inflation rate. The dollar's weakness is partly offset by other central banks' easing monetary policies, with the euro up 0.2% against the dollar to US$1.1271.

site_title: Magnitude 6.1 earthquake strikes north of Japan's Okinawa
summary: A magnitude 6.1 earthquake struck north of Japan's Okinawa islands on Saturday, at a depth of 257 km, approximately 346 km north of Naha, the capital of the prefecture. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties from the quake. The earthquake occurred far from populated areas, reducing the risk of injury or loss of life.

site_title: New Zealanders give up weapons after mosque killings
summary: New Zealanders participated in a nationwide gun buyback scheme, handing in 97 firearms and 94 parts and accessories in the first two hours. The initiative, following the Christchurch mosque attacks, aimed to remove semi-automatic weapons from circulation. Over 250 collections were planned nationwide, with 903 gun owners in the Canterbury area registering 1,415 firearms to be handed in. The government tightened gun laws immediately after the attacks, with the goal of removing the most dangerous weapons from circulation. The buyback scheme was deemed successful, with many participants expressing positive feedback.

site_title: Major Indian housing lender DHFL warns it may not survive as going concern
summary: Indian housing lender DHFL warns it may not survive as a going concern due to substantial financial stress, posting a Q4 net loss of 22.23 billion rupees, compared to a profit of 1.34 billion rupees in the same period last year. The company is undergoing financial stress, with minimal disbursements, and is exploring restructuring options, including discussions over the sale of its retail and wholesale portfolio. This comes amid a broader crisis in India's banking and shadow lending sectors, with concerns about bad debts and potential contagion risks.

site_title: In Paris, cars forced to make way for the two-wheel revolution
summary: In Paris, a mobility revolution is underway, with locals and tourists embracing app-based transportation alternatives to cars. Electric scooters, mono-wheels, and bikes are popular, and the city is pushing back against car dominance due to climate change concerns. The shift is driven by frequent heatwaves and peak pollution alerts, as Paris seeks to reduce its reliance on cars and mitigate its environmental impact.

site_title: BNP Paribas backs away from US private prison industry
summary: France's BNP Paribas has decided to stop financing US private prison operators, becoming the first foreign bank to distance itself from the sector amid controversy over Trump administration detention policies. The decision, made after pressure from concerns about detention centre conditions, does not affect existing contractual agreements. BNP Paribas joins several domestic US banks, including SunTrust, Wells Fargo, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America, which have also committed to phasing out lending to private prison companies.

site_title: US shale firms put up US$16.5m to build West Texas charter schools
summary: US shale firms have pledged $16.5 million to build charter schools in West Texas, where an influx of oil and gas workers is straining local services. The Permian Strategic Partnership, a consortium of 20 energy companies, aims to raise $100 million to address civic strains in the region. The initiative is the first of its kind by the group, which operates in the top US shale field, the Permian Basin.

site_title: 25 injured as quake rocks southern Philippines
summary: A 5.8-magnitude earthquake struck the northeast coast of Mindanao island in southern Philippines, injuring 25 people and causing damage to several homes, churches, and buildings. The quake, which occurred at 4:42am, was followed by seven aftershocks, with the impact felt in four neighboring towns. Damage included cracked walls, collapsed buildings, and broken glass and ceramics. The region is prone to seismic activity due to its location in the Pacific "Ring of Fire."

site_title: Crypto trailblazer says Facebook's Libra threatens to undo blockchain gains
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency, backed by cash and short-term securities, poses a threat to blockchain gains in privacy and user sovereignty, according to Ethereum co-founder Tan Teck Long. The US Congress is set to grill Libra head David Marcus next week. The digital asset's development has sparked concerns from politicians, including US President Donald Trump, and regulators, potentially undoing the progress made by blockchain pioneers.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson faces US criminal probe related to baby powder
summary: The US Justice Department is conducting a criminal probe into Johnson & Johnson (J&J) regarding potential lies about cancer risks associated with its talcum powder. A grand jury has been convened in Washington, focusing on documents related to known carcinogens in the products. J&J had previously disclosed receiving subpoenas from the Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission. The probe is part of ongoing baby powder litigation.

site_title: Thailand's biggest anti-junta party Pheu Thai elects new leader
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai Party, the country's largest opposition party, elected Sompong Amornvivat as its new leader, succeeding acting head Viroj Pao-in. The party vowed to scrutinize the government under the new leadership, aiming to keep the coalition government accountable. Sompong Amornvivat made the pledge during his first public statement as party leader, indicating a commitment to monitoring government activities closely.

site_title: Trump administration freezing fuel efficiency penalties
summary: The Trump administration has issued final rules to suspend a 2016 Obama-era regulation that more than doubled penalties for automakers failing to meet fuel efficiency requirements. The regulation, which was set to raise fines to $14 from $5.50 per 0.1 mile over the required standards, was met with resistance from the automotive industry, citing potential costs of $1 billion annually. The move is seen as a significant shift in the administration's stance on fuel efficiency, with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) stating that the final rule will reduce future burdens on industry and consumers.

site_title: Speaking for a good cause
summary: The Asia Professional Speakers Singapore (APSS) will host Raise Your Game 2019 on July 19 to raise funds for the School of the Arts (SOTA) Endowment Fund. The event will feature 12 keynote speeches, a live charity auction, and a panel discussion on the theme "Ideas in Action." Proceeds from ticket sales will support SOTA students from less privileged backgrounds, providing them with financial assistance, such as bursaries, scholarships, and allowances. The event aims to promote diversity and inclusiveness in the arts.

images.alt_text: Members of APSS Glenn van Zutphen (left) and Eugene Seah (right) conducting coaching sessions on delivering a professional keynote speech at SOTA during the school holidays.

site_title: US VP Pence visits overcrowded migrant camp, deplores 'crisis'
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence visited an overcrowded migrant camp in Texas, where he was met with deplorable conditions and allegations of "concentration camps". Pence visited the McAllen Border Station, where 384 men were held in a caged area with inadequate facilities, and later a migrant-processing facility in Donna, Texas, where he spoke with parents and children who said they were well taken care of. Pence blamed Democrats for the crisis and called for Congress to act, while the Trump administration disputes the detainees' accounts of the conditions, stating that they are allowed to brush their teeth once a day and have access to basic necessities.

site_title: Mexico faces headwinds to growth as oil production slows: Fitch
summary: Mexico's economic growth faces significant headwinds due to slowing oil production, with industrial output declining 3.1% in May from the previous year. Fitch Solutions Macro Research attributes this decline to underinvestment and mismanagement of Pemex. Despite increased funding for Pemex, production is expected to continue declining in the near term, limiting the impact of recent funding allocations. This slowdown in industrial output will likely hinder Mexico's economic growth over the coming quarters.

site_title: AB InBev pulls Budweiser listing, cancelling this year's biggest IPO
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, cancelled its planned initial public offering (IPO) of its Asia-Pacific unit, Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, in Hong Kong, which would have been the world's biggest IPO of 2019. The decision was made due to investors' unwillingness to accept the valuation multiple of the Budweiser Asia-Pacific business, which was expected to raise up to $9.8 billion. The IPO was also seen as a setback to the Hong Kong stock exchange, which had hoped to attract other high-profile international companies.

site_title: Eternally stinky city? Rome garbage crisis sparks health fears
summary: Rome's garbage crisis has sparked health fears due to overflowing landfills, rats, and disease-ridden waste. The city's chief physician has issued a "hygiene alert" and local prosecutors are investigating the refuse collection. Rome residents are launching a contest to find the most fetid dustbins, while others blame the mayor for the crisis. The city's high waste treatment costs and lack of infrastructure have contributed to the issue, with some residents dumping hazardous waste on the streets. Rome's mayor and regional president have assured the environment minister that the crisis will be resolved within 15 days.

site_title: Volkswagen zooms ahead in extension of alliance with Ford to electric, automated cars
summary: Volkswagen and Ford have agreed to a billion-dollar investment in joint development of electric and self-driving vehicles, deepening their global alliance. VW will invest $3.1 billion in Ford's Argo AI unit and $2.6 billion, while buying $500 million worth of Argo shares. The partnership aims to slash development and manufacturing costs, with VW expected to generate up to $20 billion in revenue from sharing its MEB electric vehicle architecture with Ford. The collaboration also includes Ford building an electric car in Europe starting in 2023 using VW's MEB platform.

site_title: French bank Societe Generale cutting jobs in London
summary: Societe Generale, a French bank, is cutting jobs in London, following similar job losses at rival Deutsche Bank. The bank's voluntary departure program will reduce positions over coming months, with 30 job losses in commodities already reported. This move adds to the city's job losses, which have been a concern for several months.

site_title: USD/SGD: Bullish momentum seen
summary: The USD/SGD currency pair is showing bullish momentum, with prices rebounding from a 50% recovery from its 2016 low. The pair is currently at a key support level, where a breakout to the upside is expected. A symmetrical triangle pattern is forming, indicating a non-directional bias, with the upper and lower bounds serving as possible points of resistance and support. The formation of this pattern suggests that a breakout could occur, potentially leading to further upward movement.

site_title: BlackRock is nearing a marijuana ETF as legal obstacles start to fade
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is "likely" to launch a cannabis-focused exchange-traded fund (ETF) as concerns about the legality of such strategies fade. This move could boost assets in marijuana ETFs to $5 billion over the next few years. The US regulator's request for third-party legal opinions has made it more acceptable for investors to dive into the industry. Other issuers, such as OBP Capital and Global X Management Co, are also planning to bring cannabis-themed ETFs to market, which could shake up the category.

site_title: Singer R Kelly charged in sex scheme of kidnapping and payoffs
summary: US federal prosecutors charged Grammy Award-winning singer R Kelly, 52, with kidnapping women and girls for sex, forcibly keeping them under his control for 20 years, and buying their silence. The racketeering and human trafficking scheme, run by Kelly and his employees, included strict rules requiring obedience and calling him "Daddy." Kelly faces five-count Brooklyn racketeering charges and 13-count Chicago indictment, including allegations of kidnapping, forced labor, and child exploitation. He has denied abuse allegations for decades and is set to appear before a federal magistrate in Chicago on Friday.

site_title: Japan sets up working group on impact of Facebook's Libra ahead of G7
summary: Japan sets up a working group to discuss the impact of Facebook's Libra digital coin on monetary policy and financial regulation ahead of a G7 finance leaders' gathering. The group, comprising the Bank of Japan, Ministry of Finance, and Financial Services Agency, will coordinate policies to address regulation, monetary policy, tax, and payments settlement. Japan aims to rally support to expand the task force into a bigger group of tax and financial regulators, given the wide range of policies affected by digital currencies. This comes as Facebook's Libra plan raises concerns among global regulators.

site_title: YouTube tries to get video stars off their advertising addiction
summary: YouTube has introduced new revenue streams to combat creators' reliance on advertising. The platform now offers Super Stickers, Channel Membership tiers, and expanded merchandise sales. These features aim to keep lucrative creators from switching to rival services. The move comes as 20,000 channels now earn more from Super Chat than ads. YouTube's goal is to provide creators with a "full gamut" of monetization options, addressing concerns over falling payouts. The changes were unveiled at VidCon, a conference for social media celebrities and fans.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of July 8-12, 2019. Key highlights include: 

- The Capesize market was driven by Brazilian iron ore shipments, with rates increasing due to volatile bunker costs.
- The Panamax market saw significant growth, with vessels being taken for two laden legs at $20,000 per trip.
- Supramax and Ultramax vessels remained in positive territory, with rates rising in the Atlantic basin and steady activity in the Indian Ocean.
- Handysize vessels saw improved activity in the Atlantic, while the Pacific basin eased.
- The VLCC market in the Middle East slipped due to tensions, while Suezmax and Aframax rates remained flat.
- The clean market for tankers saw rates decrease in the Middle East and Europe, while improving in the Asian market.

site_title: US markets regulator joins calls for speedy transition away from Libor
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has joined global watchdogs in calling for banks to end their use of the London interbank offering rate (Libor) by 2021, amid concerns of a significant impact on financial markets. The SEC urges banks to assess existing contracts and ensure new contracts use alternative benchmark reference rates, such as the Secured Overnight Financing Rate. The transition poses a material risk to market participants, and the SEC expects firms to disclose relevant risks and plan for the transition.

site_title: Childcare and dog health helped plump these funds' returns
summary: Two actively managed mutual funds, MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund and Davenport Equity Opportunities Fund, outperformed the S&P 500 in the second quarter, with returns of 9.12% and 8.83%, respectively. The funds focus on companies with strong earnings growth and cash flow, such as Bright Horizons Family Solutions and Zoetis. The managers take a patient approach, holding onto stocks for an average of 5 years, and avoid making frequent changes to their portfolios. In contrast, the Vanguard Financials Index Fund, a passively managed fund, returned 7.61% in the quarter due to the strong performance of the financial sector.

images.alt_text: The managers of Davenport Equity Opportunities Fund think that Zoetis, their animal-health holding, can benefit from "the humanisation of pets" - people treating their pets like members of their families.

site_title: US regulators approve US$5 billion Facebook settlement over privacy issues: source
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) approved a $5 billion settlement with Facebook over its handling of user data, following an investigation into the sharing of 87 million users' information with Cambridge Analytica. The settlement, the largest civil penalty ever paid to the agency, includes restrictions on Facebook's treatment of user privacy. Despite the penalty, investors cheered and lawmakers criticized the amount, calling it inadequate. The deal resolves a major regulatory headache for Facebook, but the company still faces potential antitrust probes and public criticism over its cryptocurrency plans and social media issues.

site_title: Cargill shuts animal-feed mills in China as fatal hog disease spreads
summary: Cargill has shut animal-feed mills in China due to the rapid spread of African swine fever, a fatal hog disease, which has killed over a million pigs and reduced demand for feed ingredients. The closures, which include three facilities representing a 150,000-tonne reduction in capacity, are expected to be permanent. Despite this, Cargill sees a bright future for its animal-nutrition business in China and is investing $65 million in a new facility. The outbreak has also led to reduced hog feed demand in China and a 14.7% drop in soybean imports.

site_title: Property speculators hope for investment paradise in south-west China
summary: Property investors are flocking to Xishuangbanna, a town in southwestern China, due to its relaxed market regulations and tropical climate. The town has seen a 40% surge in new home prices in June compared to the previous year, making it a hotspot for real estate investment. Developers such as Ping An Real Estate and Dalian Wanda Group have built luxury villas and apartments in the area, taking advantage of its location in the Belt and Road network. Investors are attracted to the town's affordable prices, lush landscapes, and potential for long-term appreciation.

site_title: Oil prices flat as tropical storm limits output, glut forecasts weigh
summary: Oil prices remained flat on Friday as US Gulf of Mexico crude output dropped by over half due to a tropical storm, but concerns over a global crude surplus limited gains. Brent crude futures rose 20 cents to $66.72 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1 cent to $60.21 a barrel. Despite a 4% gain this week, prices fell last week due to bearish market sentiment, partly due to Trump's tariff outlook.

site_title: Two critical aspects of an investment that are overlooked
summary: Investors often overlook two critical aspects of an investment: its crisis performance and liquidity profile. Evaluating an investment's historical and future returns, risk assessment, and crisis resilience can help identify fragile investments, such as equities and real estate, that may not recover in a crisis. On the other hand, anti-fragile investments, like insurance, can gain from stress and provide flexibility during crises. Investors should prioritize liquidity, recognizing that giving up liquidity for extended periods may require higher returns, and diversify to invest in top-tier funds to maximize returns.

site_title: US crackdown on immigrant families to start Sunday, Trump says
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a nationwide wave of arrests of immigrants facing deportation, targeting hundreds of families in 10 cities, starting over the weekend. The operation, intended to discourage Central American migrants, will focus on removing criminals and follow a delay. Critics warn that the advance notice could help targeted immigrants evade arrest, while immigration advocates and lawmakers urge caution. The plan comes amid a surge of mostly Central American families crossing the US-Mexico border, sparking concerns about children being separated from adults.

site_title: Shares of troubled China tech firm tumble
summary: China's Beijing Xinwei Technology Group Co shares plummeted 5% on Friday, the first trading day in over 900 days, after the company's value dropped 147.5 billion yuan (S$29.2 billion) since its record high in June 2015.

site_title: US fixed-mortgage rates end up back where they started after up-and-down week
summary: US fixed-mortgage rates ended the week at the same level as last week, with the 30-year fixed-rate average holding steady at 3.75% and the 15-year fixed-rate average rising to 3.22%. The rates were influenced by strong jobs data last week, which initially pushed rates higher, but were later pulled down by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony that the US economy is slowing, leading to a potential rate cut at the July 31 meeting.

site_title: Suicide car bomb targets hotel in Somali port city, two journalists confirmed dead
summary: A car bomb exploded at the Hotel Asasey in Somalia's port city of Kismayu, targeting local elders and lawmakers discussing an upcoming regional election. Two journalists, Mohamed Omar Sahal and Hodan Naleyeh, were confirmed dead. The militant Islamist group al Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack, saying its fighters battled into the hotel after the explosion. The death toll is expected to be high, with many people inside the hotel at the time of the attack.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AusGroup Limited's subsidiary AGC Industries secured a $30 million contract with Yara Pilbara Nitrates in Western Australia. Salacca Pte Ltd extended the deadline for its offer to acquire Boardroom Ltd's shares, with valid acceptances for 8.73% of shares. United Engineers denied involvement in sourcing end placees for its share sale, while Lung Kee (Bermuda) Holdings warned of a 40% decline in half-year profit due to the trade war's negative impact.

site_title: VW to invest in Ford-backed Argo AI at US$7b valuation
summary: Volkswagen (VW) will invest $2.6 billion in Ford-backed autonomous-car partner Argo AI at a $7 billion valuation, expanding an alliance formed earlier this year. The investment is a defensive move to compete with Alphabet's Waymo and General Motors' Cruise unit. VW and Ford will cooperate on electric vehicles, with VW to utilize Argo's technology and Ford expected to use VW's MEB electric platform for smaller models.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Real estate markets are experiencing increased activity. The US saw a rise in mortgage rates after five weeks of declines. In Singapore, the Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. In Asia, Goldman Sachs acquired Seoul hotel and retail assets, while New World sold China property assets. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. These developments indicate a robust real estate market.

site_title: Thomson Medical prices S$225m 3-year notes at 4.8% in maiden bond offering
summary: Thomson Medical Group priced its S$225 million 3-year senior notes at 4.8% in its maiden bond offering. The notes, set to be issued on July 18, will be available in denominations of S$250,000 and secured by a charge over an interest-service reserve account. The offering was two times oversubscribed, seen as a strong endorsement of the company's business strategy and growth prospects. Net proceeds will be used to refinance existing loan facilities and extend debt maturity profile.

site_title: China tightens curbs on property firms raising money offshore
summary: China has tightened restrictions on property firms raising money offshore to reduce potential financial risks. The National Development and Reform Commission requires real estate companies to replace medium- and long-term offshore debt maturing in the next year with new offshore bond issues. Companies must also contain foreign debt risks by holding a "reasonable position" in their foreign exchange reserves and improve information disclosure. This move aims to prevent risks from the offshore bond market and promote the stable development of the real estate market.

site_title: Europe: Swiss stocks keep a lid on European shares as pharma drag lingers
summary: European shares ended flat on Friday, breaking a five-week winning streak, as drugmakers underperformed due to US government pressure on high prices. Swiss stocks declined over 1% and European auto stocks recovered 1% despite Daimler's warning of a second-quarter loss. Chemicals made gains, while technology and semiconductor stocks were impacted by earnings deluge. The pan-European STOXX 600 index is expected to report 0.8% earnings growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Rolls-Royce, A*Star pump extra S$8m into joint lab
summary: Rolls-Royce has invested an additional S$8 million in its joint lab with Singapore's Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) and Singapore Aero Engine Services (SAESL), bringing the total investment to S$69 million over five years. The funds will support a sixth workstream focused on advanced maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) technologies for high-value engine components. This investment aims to develop technology solutions for problem statements from Rolls-Royce and SAESL, with the goal of commercializing the technologies in Rolls-Royce's facilities.

site_title: No consensus on whether immediate pain relief is needed
summary: Singapore's economy ground to a halt in the second quarter with 0.1% year-on-year growth, increasing the likelihood of a recession. Analysts expect monetary easing at the October MAS meeting to support the economy, while leaders emphasize long-term economic transformation plans. The government has reaffirmed its strategy to help companies and workers adapt to new realities, rather than artificially boosting demand. Despite a slowdown, officials believe the economy has strong fundamentals and sound strategies, with some suggesting potential targeted stimulus measures to boost investment and R&D activity.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits fresh records as rate cut hopes lift investor spirits
summary: Wall Street's main indices closed at fresh records on Friday, with the S&P 500 surpassing 3,000 for the first time. Investors became increasingly optimistic about a potential interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, following Chairman Jerome Powell's comments that "crosscurrents" of risk increased the economic outlook. The week ended on a strong note, with the Dow and Nasdaq also reaching new highs, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japanese firm loses 3.5b yen in cryptocurrency hack
summary: A Tokyo-based cryptocurrency exchange, Remixpoint, has halted services after losing 3.5 billion yen (S$43.9 million) in a cryptocurrency hack. The hack, discovered overnight, involved the disappearance of various digital currencies from its management. Remixpoint attributed the loss to a hack, although the exact cause is unclear. The incident is the latest in a series of cryptocurrency hacks, highlighting the vulnerabilities of the digital currency market.

site_title: JPMorgan's US$50b fund halves EM holdings on trade war risk
summary: JPMorgan's Global Income Fund has halved its emerging-market (EM) holdings to 3% due to concerns over the US-China trade war's impact on Asia. The fund, managing $50 billion, has shifted focus to European corporate junk bonds and Treasuries. Co-manager Eric Bernbaum warns of ongoing uncertainty and structural issues in the region, despite a potential US interest-rate cut. The fund expects the Fed to cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point in July, but sees Asia's economies still struggling with the trade war's effects.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit is recommended to buy with a target price of US$0.88, citing its strong portfolio in key US growth markets and undervalued yield of about 8%. Frasers Commercial Trust is downgraded to hold, with its share price potentially range-bound due to Google's increased occupancy and limited valuation support.

site_title: The Peak marks its 35th year with special edition featuring young pioneers
summary: The Peak magazine celebrates its 35th year with a special edition featuring 20 young pioneers shaping the future in various fields, including lifestyle, technology, and finance. The individuals profiled, such as Zac Toh and Bernise Ang, are leading innovators in their respective sectors, using technology and artificial intelligence to create sustainable solutions. The gala event at the Shangri-la Hotel Singapore marked the occasion, attended by over 300 guests from Singapore's business community, who recognized the impact of these individuals on shaping the future.

site_title: Brave new world of lasers and robots driving ENT surgery
summary: Advances in lasers and robots have significantly reduced disfigurement in ENT surgery, enabling precise treatment of benign and malignant conditions. The development of specialized technologies has led to a reduction in collateral injury and improved quality of life. Lasers, such as the CO2 laser, have been used to treat tumors, skin conditions, and stones in the salivary ducts. Robotic systems, like the da Vinci Surgical System and Medrobotics Flex, provide surgeons with access to the upper aerodigestive tract, allowing for minimally invasive procedures with improved outcomes and reduced recovery time.

site_title: Today's leadership challenge: hardwiring people development to the bottom line
summary: A Deliberately Developmental Organization (DDO) culture is key to facing the future, according to experts. A DDO embeds a growth culture that allows employees to continuously evolve and flourish, maximizing their performance potential. This approach, advocated by Robert Kegan and Lisa Lahey, involves shifting from a reactive, socialized structure of mind to a self-authoring, creative, and self-transforming structure. By combining care and candor, businesses can drive results through flawless execution of strategies built around the organization's culture. This approach prioritizes people development, recognizing that work is not just a job, but a space for growth and self-improvement.

site_title: Gold strengthens over dovish testimony by Fed chief
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's dovish testimony bolstered gold prices as traders maintain bets for a quarter-basis point cut at the next FOMC meeting. The Fed chief spoke of subdued economic momentum, citing muted US manufacturing and inflation levels. Rising market risks and looming US dollar weakness have contributed to gold's significant price increase. Investors should expect a 25bps cut in the US Federal Funds Rate, with gold prices expected to stay above key technical levels of $1,400 and $1,380, potentially reaching $1,483.

site_title: Apple pays the price to stay at the bleeding edge
summary: Apple is reportedly paying up to $1 billion to keep its devices at the leading edge, with a significant portion of that amount going to Japan Display Inc, a key screen provider. The company is also set to pay up to $1 trillion to Samsung Electronics Co for its OLED displays, a significant increase from previous purchases. This move is seen as a response to Apple's desire to maintain technological leadership in the premium smartphone market, as global brands struggle to innovate.

site_title: On turning 60 and starting afresh
summary: A 60-year-old woman reflects on her life at this milestone age, feeling that she's starting anew after reaching a career and financial peak. Despite societal expectations that life begins at 60, she disagrees, citing that her life has been going on for decades already. She's taking a more relaxed approach to her career and personal life, prioritizing her own interests and happiness. The author notes that ageism is prevalent in dating, with many men seeking younger partners, but she remains optimistic, having a low-stakes dating scene and a supportive social network.

images.alt_text: Aviva's life assurance algorithm informs me I will reach the age of 93, which means I am now 33 years from death. This seems like a minor eternity, equal in length to the portion of life I lived between 27 and now.

site_title: SPH Q3 gain falls 44% on lower investment income, media sales
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 44.1% drop in Q3 net profit to S$26.2 million, mainly due to lower media income and higher operating expenses. The company's operating profit fell 36.6% to S$29.2 million, while operating revenue declined 1.6% to S$246.1 million. Despite this, the property segment contributed 80% to the group's profits, with revenue growing 21.4% and pre-tax profit rising 15%. The company remains focused on its digital transformation strategy and sees growth opportunities.

site_title: A drinker's cup of tea
summary: Mister Wu, a Singaporean teahouse and bar, combines the worlds of tea and alcohol in its tea-based cocktails, such as the Yuzu Jade Monkey, pairing jasmine tea with citrus notes and whisky. The bar's co-owner, Brendon Au, aims to preserve Chinese tea heritage while making it modern and relevant. Mister Wu sources its tea leaves directly from China and Taiwan, and its menu features traditional brews and less-conventional forms like cold brews and kombucha. The bar's cocktail program is guided by principles such as pairing lighter teas with neutral spirits and heavier teas with bodyful spirits.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow hit record high at open on hopes of rate cut
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Dow indexes rising 0.12% and 0.19% respectively. The gains followed Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's dovish remarks, boosting bets of an interest rate cut this month. The S&P 500 traded above the 3,000 level, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.16%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 51.41 points to 27,139.49.

site_title: Vietnam posts large trade surplus amid US-China trade row
summary: Vietnam recorded a significant trade surplus of $1.59 billion in the first half of 2019, largely due to US-China trade tensions. Exports rose 7.2% to $122.53 billion, with shipments to the US and South Korea increasing 27.4% and 16.8%, respectively. The largest export earner was smartphones, mostly made by Samsung Electronics. However, Vietnam's trade deficit with China continued to grow, prompting US President Trump's threat of tariffs on Vietnamese products.

site_title: Thomas Cook in bailout talks with China's Fosun
summary: Thomas Cook, the world's oldest travel company, is in talks with Chinese conglomerate Fosun for a £750 million bailout, giving Fosun control of the company's package-tour business and a minority interest in its airline business. The deal would significantly dilute existing shareholders and comes as the company faces declining demand, high debt, and a hot summer in Europe. Fosun, which already owns an 18% stake in Thomas Cook, aims to turn around iconic brands and preserve value for stakeholders.

site_title: Warren Buffett's electric cars are here
summary: Warren Buffett's dealership, Vantage Automotive Limited, is set to launch the BYD e6 electric car in Singapore on July 19, priced at S$133,888. The move aims to attract mass-market buyers with its affordability and low running costs. This is the first time the BYD e6 will be sold in Singapore, marking a significant entry for the Shenzhen-based manufacturer backed by Buffett. The launch is part of the growing trend of electric power in the car market.

site_title: Wilmar unit gets China regulator's acceptance of application to list
summary: The China Securities Regulatory Commission has accepted Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings' application to list on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, with Wilmar International retaining a majority stake. The listing is expected to increase market visibility and unlock shareholder value, supporting the growth of Wilmar's China operations. Yihai, a large agribusiness and food processing company, will issue new shares amounting to about 10% of its total pro forma share capital. The IPO is expected to make Yihai one of the largest listed vegetable oil and food ingredient producers by market capitalization.

site_title: How low can GDP numbers go? DPM Heng rebuffs recession fears
summary: Singapore's GDP growth nearly halted in the second quarter, with a 0.1% year-on-year growth rate, the slowest quarterly growth since 2009. Despite this, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said the government does not expect a full-year recession. Economists, however, warn that the possibility of a real recession is "very real" and that the risk of a global slowdown is high. Private economists have trimmed their full-year growth forecasts to as low as zero to 1%, while the Ministry of Trade and Industry has cut its forecast to between 1.5% and 2.5%.

site_title: Refrain from leveraging HK unrest: S'pore wealth managers told
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority has cautioned wealth managers against aggressively marketing services to Hong Kong amid the city's political turmoil. Officials made the request to banks, including DBS and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, to refrain from capitalizing on Hong Kong's instability. The move aims to prevent a flow of assets out of Hong Kong.

site_title: Rumble in Kallang as WWE stars tear the house down
summary: WWE stars performed in a live event at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on June 27, drawing thousands of fans who paid up to S$500 for ringside tickets. The event featured 23 WWE wrestlers, including popular stars like Asuka and Kairi Sane, Shinsuke Nakamura, and Becky Lynch. Despite Nakamura's loss in the main event, the crowd was impressed by his display of strength and athleticism. The event was a success, with fans showing their support through elaborate costumes and merchandise purchases. The WWE's visit to Singapore has been a recurring event, with the company planning to return in the future.

site_title: 35 employees kill themselves. Will their bosses go to jail?
summary: Former top executives of France Télécom are on trial for "moral harassment" after allegedly creating humiliating work conditions that led to the deaths of at least 35 employees. The executives, who were trying to downsize the workforce by thousands, made life unbearable for the workers, who were state employees and therefore protected. If convicted, they face a year in jail and a $16,800 fine. The trial has highlighted the country's strict labor protections and the struggles of workers in France's immobile labor market, with many feeling trapped and betrayed by their employers.

site_title: Why spotting "hidden influencers" at work matters
summary: Spotting "hidden influencers" at work is crucial as they possess considerable informal power and can significantly impact a company. These individuals, often not immediately noticeable, can be found in various roles and departments. Their ability to influence others is a valuable trait, but it comes with great responsibility. Recognizing these individuals can lead to improved communication, collaboration, and decision-making within the organization. By acknowledging their influence, companies can harness their power to drive positive change and achieve their goals. Effective management of these "hidden influencers" can be a key factor in a company's success.

site_title: STI up, despite weak Q2 GDP estimates
summary: Singapore's benchmark index closed at 3,357.34, up 6.89 points or 0.2% on Friday, despite weak Q2 GDP estimates. Investors were reassured by US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments that the Fed's interest-rate outlook remains dovish. The Straits Times Index was driven by gains from local banks and real estate investment trusts, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank closing higher.

site_title: Airbus aims to sell more than 1,000 planes over 15 yrs in Latin America, Caribbean
summary: Airbus plans to sell more than 1,000 new passenger planes in Latin America and the Caribbean over the next 15 years, meeting about half the demand expected in the region. The company already operates over 700 planes in the region and aims to sell Eurofighter Typhoon jets to Colombia to renew its defense air fleet. This represents 7% of Airbus' 64 billion euros in net profit last year, which also came from the sale of helicopters, military transportation, and satellites to countries in the region.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO gives execs dressing down over suits
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing publicly reprimanded London-based executives for ordering expensive suits for themselves on the same day the bank laid off thousands of traders. The suits, worth up to £1,500 each, were seen as out of touch with the bank's values. Sewing also hinted that bonuses may be cut this year despite forecasting a net loss. The bank's massive restructuring, which includes 18,000 job cuts by 2022, aims to refocus on core strengths and traditional clients. Sewing sees the changes as necessary to re-energize the troubled bank.

site_title: South Korea, Japan hold talks as diplomatic row worsens
summary: Japanese and South Korean officials held hours-long talks on a worsening diplomatic row, with no sign of a detente. Japan's restrictions on exports to South Korea, sparked by disputes over wartime forced labor, remain in effect. The US offered to mediate, but no concessions are expected. South Korea's President Moon Jae-in's office called for a third-party investigation, while Japan defended its decision, citing international rules and safety management. Tensions between the two allies are unlikely to ease quickly, with experts predicting further escalation.

site_title: S Korea hits brakes on rapid wage gains as economy sputters
summary: South Korea has slowed down its wage growth plans due to economic concerns. The country's minimum wage will increase by 2.9% to 8,590 won (S$9.91) per hour in 2020, lower than previous hikes of 10.9% and 16.4%. The move aims to stabilize the economy, which is struggling with slumping exports and growing joblessness. This decision reflects the vulnerability of the South Korean economy amidst global trade tensions and follows a series of economic slowdowns in the country.

images.alt_text: South Korea slammed the brakes on ambitious pay raises at the centre of President Moon Jae-in's growth strategy Friday as the vulnerability of an economy struggling with slumping exports and growing joblessness hit home.

site_title: China's June trade softens amid stalemate over tariff talks with Washington
summary: China's trade in June showed a softening, with exports falling 1.3% from a year earlier and imports slumping 7.3%. The decline in exports was attributed to the US implementing new tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, which caused a 0.6% drop in shipments. Despite stimulus measures, domestic demand has yet to pick up, and analysts expect global trade to remain subdued for the rest of 2019. China's trade surplus increased to $50.98 billion, and the country's economy is still in a "proper range," according to a customs spokesperson.

site_title: Labour Secretary Acosta says he is resigning after Epstein furor
summary: US Labour Secretary Alex Acosta is resigning amid heightened scrutiny over his handling of Jeffrey Epstein's sexual misconduct charges. As top federal prosecutor in Florida in 2007 and 2008, Acosta signed off on a lenient plea deal that allowed Epstein to serve only 13 months in jail. Acosta cited it as the "right thing" to do, but was criticized for not offering an apology to Epstein's victims. President Donald Trump had told Acosta not to resign, but Acosta stepped down in a surprise move.

site_title: India-US trade talks end without major progress
summary: US and Indian trade negotiators ended talks in New Delhi without major progress, putting off discussions on tariffs and protectionist measures. Indian Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal is set to visit Washington next month to continue talks. The US sought the rollback of Indian tariffs on agricultural products, while India refused to commit to changes in foreign investment rules for e-commerce firms. The talks marked a step back from a "very big trade deal" agreed upon by US President Donald Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the G20 summit in June.

site_title: US$32m swiped from cryptocurrency exchange in latest hack
summary: A Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, Bitpoint, lost approximately $32 million in a hack that involved Ripple and other cryptocurrencies. The exchange suspended all services after discovering that about 2.5 billion yen (US$32 million) of stolen funds belonged to customers. The hack occurred in a hot wallet containing five cryptocurrencies, but no funds were found missing from cold wallets. This incident follows previous cryptocurrency hacks, including the 2018 hack of Coincheck, which led to Japan's Financial Services Agency ordering cryptocurrency operators to improve internal controls.

site_title: Mercedes Benz B200 AMG: The B's knees
summary: Mercedes-Benz has introduced the B-Class AMG, a compact family vehicle that prioritizes practicality over sporty features. The car is designed for daily use, such as commuting and transporting children, and is marketed as a premium-branded family transport option. The B-Class AMG is not meant for high-performance driving, but rather for those who value comfort and reliability. The brand has emphasized the vehicle's character and character-building qualities, rather than its sporty credentials.

site_title: How are gender lens funds performing?
summary: Gender lens funds, which focus on investing in companies with higher women-in-leadership (WIL) metrics, have performed well in Q1, with all global funds posting positive returns and some outperforming the MSCI World Index. However, despite the sector's growth, women hold only 5% of CEO positions and 20% of board seats globally, and progress remains stagnant. The sector faces challenges in differentiating itself and expanding its market-cap range in a limited investment universe, but the push for gender diversity in investment criteria is gaining traction on Wall Street.

site_title: Aberdeen to manage AIIB's US$500m ESG portfolio of Asian infrastructure bonds
summary: Aberdeen Standard Investments (ASI) has partnered with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) to manage a US$500 million ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) portfolio of Asian infrastructure bonds. ASI's Asian fixed income team will oversee the portfolio, which will comprise mainly Asian infrastructure-related bonds, with ESG factors fully integrated into the investment process. The partnership aims to drive responsible investing in fixed income and build a sustainable ESG ecosystem for investing in Asia's emerging markets, supporting AIIB's mission to improve social and economic outcomes in the region.

site_title: Google says partner leaked classified Dutch data
summary: Google acknowledged a language expert partner leaked classified Dutch audio data, compromising user privacy. The leaked data included over 1,000 recordings in Belgium and the Netherlands, with 153 being accidental. The expert, who reviewed around 0.2% of audio snippets, was found to have violated Google's data security policies. Google is reviewing its safeguards to prevent similar incidents, and users can manage data by choosing to auto-delete it every three or 18 months.

images.alt_text: Internet giant Google acknowledged Thursday that a language expert it partnered with had leaked sensitive Dutch audio data, following a report by the Belgian media group VRT.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 9.81 points to 1,669.45, with losers outnumbering gainers 453 to 401. The index saw a total of 2.9 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion traded.

site_title: Chance of Singapore easing monetary policy rises as economy flatlines: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is likely to ease monetary policy in October to boost the export-reliant economy, which is being affected by the US-China trade war. The economy experienced its slowest expansion in a decade with a 0.1% annual growth rate in the second quarter, prompting economists to expect the MAS to loosen policy. Seven out of 11 economists polled by Reuters predicted a policy change, citing the severe effects of the trade war and the MAS's slow inflation rate.

site_title: Deutsche Bank pays US$197m to settle Vestia bribery case
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $197 million to settle a lawsuit with Dutch affordable-housing provider Stichting Vestia over bribery allegations related to derivatives trades. The settlement, worth 175 million euros, ends a long-running court battle with no admission of liability. Vestia claimed the bank paid fees to a middleman for flawed derivatives transactions, while Deutsche Bank maintained the middleman was a legitimate intermediary. The settlement brings closure to the dispute, with Vestia satisfied with the result. This is part of Deutsche Bank's ongoing legal issues, including a US Department of Justice investigation.

site_title: Sri Lanka's car-free day sparks debate over women's safety
summary: In Sri Lanka, a car-free day in Colombo sparked backlash from women who claim cars offer protection from sexual harassment on the streets and public transport. Dozens of women shared their experiences of being ogled, cat-called, and groped, citing a 2015 survey that found 9 out of 10 women faced sexual harassment on public buses and trains. The Colombo mayor's office acknowledged the issue and vowed to address it, while some critics argued that the plan ignored the realities faced by women commuters.

site_title: China to impose sanctions on US firms in Taiwan arms sale
summary: China plans to impose sanctions on US companies involved in a potential $2.2 billion arms sale to self-ruled Taiwan, citing a violation of international law. The move comes as tensions between the US and China are strained due to their trade war. China views Taiwan as part of its territory and has vowed to seize it by force if necessary, bristling at any diplomatic support for the island. The planned arms sale, which includes battle tanks and anti-aircraft missiles, is the first major transfer of US military gear to Taiwan in decades.

site_title: A*Star, Rolls-Royce pump additional S$8m into joint lab
summary: Rolls-Royce and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) have invested an additional S$8 million into their joint lab, bringing the total investment to S$69 million over five years. The new funds will support a sixth work stream focused on developing advanced maintenance, repair and overhaul technologies for high-value engine components. The joint lab has already started nearly 30 projects and implemented two in Rolls-Royce's Singapore facilities, with plans to develop technology solutions for problem statements from Rolls-Royce and Singapore Aero Engine Services (SAESL).

site_title: Airbus pulls anniversary book over fraud probe concerns
summary: Airbus has halted sales of its 50th anniversary book, "Airbus: The First 50 Years," amid concerns it could hinder its efforts to win a settlement in a US$400 million bribery probe. The book, written by Nicola Clark, was commissioned to present the company's findings to authorities by the end of the year. Airbus cited concerns over its official links to the publication potentially hampering talks with authorities. The move comes as the company has already fired over 100 people in connection with the probe.

site_title: Pine Capital gets letters of demand from HK firm to terminate deal
summary: Pine Capital's planned acquisition of a 51% stake in Hong Kong-based asset management firm Silver Tree Hong Kong for HK$2.55 million (S$440,000) in shares may be terminated due to non-compliance with the extended long-stop date. Silver Tree's sole shareholder, David Sarkis, has sent two letters of demand to Pine Capital's solicitors, seeking to terminate the share purchase agreement and compensation of HK$10 million. The acquisition was to be made in two stages, but Pine Capital is in consultation with its legal advisers and will make further announcements as appropriate.

site_title: SPH Q3 net profit falls 44% to S$26.2m
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 44% drop in Q3 net profit to S$26.2m, primarily due to declining print advertisement and circulation revenue. Operating expenses rose 5.5% and investment income fell 82%. Despite a 1.6% decline in operating revenue, rental revenue from student accommodation and retail assets cushioned the decline. CEO Ng Yat Chung attributed the challenges to trade tensions and a slowing economy, while noting improved recurring income from the property segment.

site_title: Britain replaces warship in Gulf, to maintain continuous presence
summary: Britain has deployed the HMS Duncan warship to the Gulf to replace HMS Montrose, maintaining a continuous maritime security presence amid heightened tensions in the region. The deployment follows the seizure of an Iranian tanker in Gibraltar and HMS Montrose's confrontation with Iranian vessels. The UK aims to ensure freedom of navigation for vessels transiting the Strait of Hormuz, a vital shipping route.

site_title: WBL not involved in sourcing end placees in share sale: UE
summary: United Engineers (UE) has clarified that its subsidiary, WBL Corporation, was not involved in sourcing or selecting end placees in the recent share sale. The shares were sold at the prevailing market price of S$2.58 per share, and were sold to independent, unrelated third parties by UOB Kay Hian Private Limited. This comes after concerns were raised by UE shareholder Oxley about the sale price. UE's managing director, Roy Tan, had previously stated that the decision to sell the shares was a board decision.

site_title: US producer prices increased more than forecast in June
summary: US producer prices increased more than forecast in June, driven by trade services and indicating inflation may be stabilizing. The underlying producer prices rose 2.3% from a year earlier, exceeding the median forecast of 2.1%. The data follows a report showing consumer prices also picked up, potentially complicating the Federal Reserve's decision on interest-rate policy later this month. The stronger figures suggest companies are seeing inflation, which could filter through to the broader economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on a positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.14% to 28,471.62. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, driven by expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve at the end of the month.

site_title: Aberdeen to manage AIIB's US$500m ESG portfolio of Asian infrastructure bonds
summary: Aberdeen Standard Investments (ASI) will manage a $500 million ESG portfolio for the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), comprising mainly Asian infrastructure-related bonds. The portfolio, set up in 2018, will prioritize environmental, social, and governance factors in its investment process. ASI's partnership with AIIB aims to drive responsible investing in fixed income and build a sustainable ESG ecosystem for Asia's emerging markets. The move is seen as crucial in addressing the region's pressing sustainability challenges, with AIIB's mission to improve social and economic outcomes in the region.

site_title: Indonesia president vows to fight EU palm oil rules
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo vowed to fight the European Union's plans to restrict the use of palm oil in biofuels, which he said would harm the livelihoods of 16 million farmers and workers. The EU aims to limit palm oil by 2030, citing environmental concerns. Widodo promised to take bold actions to bolster Indonesia's economy, including lowering corporate taxes, easing labor laws, and lifting foreign ownership restrictions. Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest palm oil producers, have threatened retaliation if the EU's plans are implemented.

site_title: Australian shares end lower on renewed trade war worries; NZ ticks up
summary: Australian shares ended 0.3% lower on Friday, with mining stocks leading the decline due to renewed trade war worries. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 19.6 points to 6,696.5, its biggest weekly drop since May. US President Trump's comments on China's agricultural purchases from American farmers fueled concerns. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index ticked up 0.1% to a fifth consecutive week of gains.

site_title: Singapore not expecting full-year recession at this point, says DPM Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore is not expecting a full-year recession despite its economy slowing to a 10-year low in the second quarter, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The country remains focused on the medium and long-term, with areas of strength in the information and communications sector, construction sector, and sectors such as electronics and precision engineering. Businesses and workers in weakened sectors will receive support to adjust to new realities, with the government working with employers and unions to prepare for all scenarios.

site_title: Trump Tower NYC to hit 37% space available over next 12 months
summary: Trump Tower NYC is facing declining commercial occupancy, with 84% of space currently occupied, down from 100% in 2013.
