This change is expected to increase the number of companies being taken private, with 14 firms undergoing privatization or buyout this year.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks rally on rate cut optimism
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.81% on Thursday, following a global advance, as investors welcomed the expected interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve at the end of the month. The Hang Seng Index rose to 28,431.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.08%. The Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.13%. The positive sentiment was also fueled by a rally in Singapore stocks, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Rock The Boat
summary: Nine Years Theatre, a Singaporean Mandarin theatre company, collaborates with the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre to present the novel production "First Fleet". The play, set in 1787, tells the story of the British Empire's First Fleet, which sailed to establish a penal colony in Australia. Director Nelson Chia's innovative staging places the audience on stage with the actors. The play explores themes of hope, grit, and redemption. "First Fleet" runs at the Singapore Cultural Centre from July 18 to 21.

images.alt_text: First Fleet runs at the Singapore Cultural Centre from July 18 to 21.

site_title: Australian banks, shops hit by telecom outage
summary: Australian banks and retailers experienced chaos due to a telecoms outage affecting electronic payment systems and cash machines. Major banks, including Westpac, National Australia Bank, and Commonwealth Bank, reported issues with transaction-handling machines in stores. Retailers like Woolworths Group manually processed transactions after automated checkouts were shut down. Telstra Corp Ltd, the country's biggest telecom provider, is investigating the issue, which affected large customers nationwide. Internet banking systems remained operational, but the outages were uneven.

site_title: Bitcoin extends losses after Fed chief urges halt to Facebook's crypto project
summary: Bitcoin fell 8% on Thursday, extending losses after US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell called for a halt to Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency project due to concerns over privacy, money laundering, and consumer protection. Powell said existing rules do not fit cryptocurrencies and urged a halt until concerns are addressed. This move follows a 3.8% slide on Wednesday. Other major cryptocurrencies, including Ethereum and XRP, also fell by similar levels.

site_title: Pakistan train collision kills nine, injures 66
summary: A train collision in central Pakistan's Rahim Yar Khan district killed at least nine people and injured 66 others, with three to four passengers in critical condition. The incident occurred when a passenger train collided with a stopped goods train at a crossing. An investigation has been launched to determine the causes of the incident, which is the latest in a series of train accidents in Pakistan plagued by corruption, mismanagement, and lack of investment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on Fed chief's dovish signal
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, driven by expectations of a US rate cut and a positive outlook for Nintendo's new Switch console. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.51% and the Topix Index rose 0.47%. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: US, India trade talks to restart after Trump's tariff tweets
summary: US trade officials will restart talks with Indian counterparts on Friday, amid uncertainty over data localization, retail policies, and recent tariffs imposed by India. US President Donald Trump had criticized India's decision to impose higher tariffs on American goods. US trade officials will discuss bilateral trade with India's additional trade secretary and meet trade minister Piyush Goyal. Talks had stalled earlier over tariffs and revoked trade preferences for India, and the US is also challenging India's retaliatory tariffs at the World Trade Organization.

site_title: E-applications to start for Piermont Grand, 2019's first EC launch
summary: Applications for Piermont Grand, Singapore's first executive condominium (EC) launch in 2019, will start July 12-22, with bookings on July 27. Developed by CDL and TID, the 820-unit project offers 3-5 bedroom units with various amenities, including a 50m lap pool and smart home system. Located near Punggol MRT and bus interchange, the project is set to benefit from the upcoming Punggol Digital District. Pricing has not been disclosed, with marketing agents ERA, Huttons, and others handling bookings.

site_title: Professionals urged to upskill as AI reshapes finance sector: CPA
summary: CPA Australia urges finance professionals to upskill in anticipation of AI's growing impact on the finance sector. The accounting body has published a guide, "Charting the Future of Accountancy with AI," to help professionals navigate the evolving technology and changing roles. The guide highlights the need for data mining, extraction, and faster interpretation of big data, as well as statistical modeling, financial analysis, and planning. The report also found that public accounting staff are too narrowly focused and can acquire corporate-sector competencies to widen industry knowledge.

site_title: ECB's Coeure says markets may be overly pessimistic on inflation
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Executive Board member Benoit Coeure expressed caution about market pessimism on inflation, citing "tentative evidence" that households' predictions aren't as dour as expected. Market-based inflation expectations have plunged this year, but households' inflation expectations remain stable near a six-year high. Coeure's comments suggest the ECB may reconsider its monetary stimulus if the outlook improves, potentially leading to a rate cut by September and a restart of bond-buying. This comes as the European Commission cuts its euro-area growth and inflation forecast for next year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. (SGX RegCo) announced changes to voluntary delisting rules, requiring exit offers to be fair and reasonable, and excluding the offeror and its affiliated parties from shareholder votes. Meanwhile, Hyflux is progressing towards a deal with Utico to invest $400 million in the water treatment firm. Professionals are urged to upskill in AI to grow Singapore's economy. The local stock market gained 0.3% on Thursday, and the US Federal Reserve reaffirmed its dovish stance.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,362.66, up 0.67% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.67% or 22.24 points to 3,362.66 as of 1:09pm. Advancers outnumbered decliners 222 to 130, with banking stocks making gains. DBS, UOB, and OCBC increased by 1.58%, 1.1%, and 0.61% respectively. Other active index securities included Singtel, Ascendas Reit, and CapitaLand Commercial Trust. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks surge as Fed chief boosts rate cut expectations
summary: South Korean stocks surged on Thursday, driven by expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate cut and a potential easing of supply glut in the memory chip market. The Kospi stock index rose 1.06% to 2,080.58, with shares in Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix closing up 1.4% and 3.6%, respectively. The won gained 0.7% against the US dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell. The US central bank's readiness to "act as appropriate" to address the US economy's challenges fueled the rally, with foreigners net buying 362.7 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Mainlanders among Hong Kong protesters, though many stay away
summary: Hong Kong protesters, including Chinese mainlanders, continue to voice their opposition to a proposed extradition bill that could lead to the city's unique freedoms and culture being suppressed. Many mainlanders, like Briony Lin, have joined the protests, while others remain cautious due to the risk of retribution from Chinese authorities. Despite some mainlanders expressing support for the movement, the majority remain indifferent or fearful of expressing their views, with some even viewing the protests as a foreign-funded plot. The situation highlights the complex emotions and tensions between Hong Kongers and mainland Chinese residents living in the city.

site_title: Keppel Land, Vietnamese developer to build residences in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: Keppel Land, a Singaporean developer, has partnered with Vietnamese developer Phu Long Real Estate Corporation to build residences in Ho Chi Minh City. The project, valued at over S$425 million, will see the development of 2,400 premium apartments and commercial spaces on three land parcels in the Nha Be district. The first phase of the project is expected to commence in 2020, with a total development cost exceeding VND7,400 billion. This acquisition adds to Keppel Land's portfolio of properties in Vietnam and is part of its goal to develop around 20,000 homes in the country.

site_title: Indonesia plans to build 7 km sea bridge linking Batam and Bintan
summary: Indonesia plans to build a 7 km sea bridge connecting Batam and Bintan islands near Singapore, aiming to boost growth and trade with the neighboring hub. The $385.5 million bridge is expected to take 3-4 years to complete and will be part of a larger $400 billion infrastructure push by President Joko Widodo. The bridge is seen as an alternative to Singapore for shipping and manufacturing, and will reduce logistics costs, improve connectivity, and boost tourism in the area.

site_title: Hyflux 'progressing' towards Utico deal for S$400m lifeline
summary: Hyflux is progressing towards a deal with UAE utility Utico, which aims to invest S$400 million in the water treatment firm. Utico plans to take an 88% stake through S$300 million in equity and S$100 million in shareholder's loan, providing a S$400 million lifeline. A binding agreement is still pending, after Hyflux first mentioned the potential investment on May 3.

images.alt_text: Hyflux's potential white knight Utico is looking to take an 88 per cent stake in the troubled water treatment firm through S$300 million in equity injection and S$100 million in shareholder's loan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.51% to 28,347.86. The gains followed dovish testimony by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell, boosting hopes for an interest rate cut. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter gaining 0.51%. The positive start comes despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Didi eyes global expansion, battles Uber again in Latin America
summary: Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-hailing giant, launched new financial services in Brazil and Mexico, expanding its presence in Latin America. The company partnered financial institutions to offer drivers a bank card, allowing them to receive income and withdraw cash. This move aims to help unbanked individuals in Brazil become Didi drivers. Didi's expansion in the region is seen as a response to Uber's presence, with the company valuing itself at $56 billion and facilitating 30 million rides daily.

site_title: DBS named World's Best Bank by Euromoney magazine
summary: DBS has been named the World's Best Bank by Euromoney magazine, marking the first time an Asian bank has received the award. Euromoney editor Clive Horwood praised DBS for its efforts to embrace digital disruption, stating that no other institution has worked as hard to lead the change. This is the latest in a series of honors for DBS, following two other awards received last year.

site_title: Nintendo announces smaller, cheaper new Switch console
summary: Nintendo has announced the release of the Switch Lite, a smaller, cheaper version of its popular Switch console. The handheld-only device will sell for $199.99 and is expected to hit shelves on September 20, ahead of the holiday shopping season. The Switch Lite will not be compatible with television sets, offering a more portable gaming experience. This move is seen as an attempt by Nintendo to expand its market reach and appeal to a wider audience.

site_title: India airline Vistara to launch first international flights in August starting with Singapore
summary: India's full-service airline Vistara will launch its first international flights in August, starting with Singapore. The airline will operate one daily flight from Delhi and one from Mumbai to Singapore. This launch is a year later than anticipated and aims to give Vistara greater scale to grow and achieve profitability. The move is part of Vistara's expansion plans, which will enable it to compete with other international carriers.

site_title: First Apple store inside an airport complex to open this Saturday at Jewel Changi Airport
summary: Apple is set to open its first store inside an airport complex, Jewel Changi Airport, in Singapore on Saturday. The two-storey store will employ over 100 staff, offering more than 200 products, including iPhones and iMacs. The store will also feature Apple's signature Today at Apple sessions, including a photography workshop. To celebrate the grand opening, the first 100 customers will receive an exclusive commemorative t-shirt. This marks Apple's second store in Singapore, following the Orchard Road outlet in 2017.

images.alt_text: Apple's second store in Singapore at Jewel Changi Airport opens on Saturday at 10am and shoppers can expect to be greeted by staff who, between them, can speak 11 languages.

site_title: Australian shares edge up on Fed rate signal; NZ hits new peak
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a 6,716.1 point close, driven by a Fed rate signal that may lead to an easing of US monetary policy. The S&P/ASX 200 index advanced, with miners and energy stocks benefiting from higher gold and oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record close, while banks National Australia Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group fell to eight-week and eight-week low, respectively.

site_title: Australia: Shares higher after Powell boosts rate cut bets; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,703, driven by higher odds of a US rate cut this month, while New Zealand's benchmark index firmed 0.3% to a record high. Gold miners soared, and energy stocks advanced following a 4.5% jump in oil prices. However, financials were weighed down by stricter capital requirements for three "Big Four" banks and a crackdown on insurance products.

site_title: Elections Department calls second tender in two months
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has called a second tender for bus transportation services to support election operations, following a similar tender in June. The new tender, closing on August 5, also includes services for printing and delivering documents to election premises. The contract, which will last three years, aims to cover the next general election and any by-elections. The formation of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee is considered a more accurate indicator of an impending general election, with the next election expected to take place by April 2021.

site_title: OCBC, Singapore police automate data retrieval to quicken financial crime detection
summary: OCBC Bank has launched Project Poet, a data retrieval system that automates the process of providing critical banking information to law enforcement agencies in Singapore, reducing the turnaround time from 10 days to three months to just one or two working days. The system uses artificial intelligence and data analytics to monitor and identify suspicious activities, and will improve Singapore's anti-money laundering risk management regime. This collaboration between OCBC and the Singapore Police Force aims to combat financial crime and mitigate money-laundering risks.

site_title: Singapore shares surge higher on Thursday; STI up 0.76% to 3,365.88
summary: Singapore shares surged 0.76% to a record high of 3,365.88, driven by a strong US trading session. The Straits Times Index rose 25.46 points, with gains outnumbering losses 123 to 29. Key gainers included Capital World, Rex International, and Golden Agri-Resources, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw significant gains. The rally was partly fueled by dovish comments from US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, which hinted at potential interest rate cuts.

site_title: South Korea steps up efforts for US help in export row with Japan
summary: South Korea is escalating its efforts to secure US assistance amid a trade dispute with Japan, which imposed export curbs on three crucial materials for smartphone displays and chips. South Korea's foreign minister expressed concerns to US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, calling the restrictions "undesirable" and warning they could disrupt the global supply chain. The US is unlikely to intervene as a mediator, and experts say the dispute may affect South Korea's economic growth. Seoul is seeking to strengthen communication with the US and Japan, while also preparing a supplementary budget to cope with the impact of the restrictions.

site_title: Hyflux 'progressing' towards deal with Utico to invest S$400m for 88% stake
summary: Hyflux is progressing towards a deal with Utico to invest S$400m for an 88% stake in the water treatment firm. Utico will provide S$300m equity and a S$100m shareholder loan, and also offer a 4% stake in the enlarged group plus additional cash to Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shareholders. The parties are working towards a binding agreement, with definitive documents to be finalized and entered into soon, and townhall meetings planned for PNP investors and medium term notes holders. The deal aims to preserve value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Brooklyn beats Manhattan for New York apartment rent increases
summary: Brooklyn saw the largest year-over-year increase in apartment rent, with a 5.9% rise to a median rent of $2,914, surpassing Manhattan's 4.7% increase. New luxury developments in Brooklyn drove the surge, with rents rising 17% in new constructions and 3.9% in existing apartments. Meanwhile, Brooklyn sale prices reached a record high, increasing 4.5% to $815,000, while the number of purchases fell 4.5%. This trend is attributed to would-be homebuyers waiting for sale prices to decline, while landlords benefit from the rental market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.41 points to 1,681.38 at 9am. The market saw 53.51 million lots traded worth RM26.34 million, with gainers beating losers 135 to 42. The rally follows a 5-day streak for Singapore stocks, which are expected to continue ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged higher.

site_title: Asia: Equities rally, dollar extends losses on Federal Reserve rate cut bets
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday following Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments that the case for lower borrowing costs had strengthened due to global trade uncertainty. The dollar extended losses as investors awaited the release of inflation data and Powell's second day of congressional testimony. US equities surged, with the Nasdaq ending at a record high, while Asian markets such as Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul also rose, with Tokyo and Singapore adding 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. Oil prices edged up, and the dollar continued to struggle against other currencies.

site_title: China's tech funding rut shifts power to investors
summary: China's tech funding has slowed, with venture deals down 77% to $9.7 billion in the second quarter. Investors are shifting power, demanding more innovation and profit from startups. They're asking tougher questions, seeking bigger stakes, protective clauses, and options to buy into future growth. This marks a power shift from startups to investors, who can now be more selective in their investments. Key sectors like fresh grocery delivery, cloud computing, and healthcare are expected to benefit from the shift.

site_title: Trump threatens to up sanctions as Iran reportedly tries to seize tanker
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Iran that sanctions would be "increased substantially" as Iranian boats reportedly attempted to seize a British oil tanker in the Gulf waters. The incident occurred amid talks between French President Emmanuel Macron's top diplomat and Iranian President Hassan Rouhani aimed at saving the 2015 nuclear deal. Iran has lost patience with perceived inaction by European countries and has threatened "consequences" for Britain over the detention of one of its oil tankers off Gibraltar.

site_title: US launches investigation into France's planned tax on tech giants
summary: US President Donald Trump has ordered an investigation into France's planned tax on internet services targeting American tech giants, citing unfair trade practices. The proposed 3% tax on total annual revenues of companies providing services to French consumers could lead to punitive tariffs, similar to those imposed on China. The US Trade Representative's office will hold hearings and issue a final report with recommendations. The investigation is part of the Trump administration's efforts to address the international tax system and prevent protectionist taxes on global trade.

site_title: European stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose in early trade on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.2%, and Paris CAC 40 gaining 0.4%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. Meanwhile, US stocks also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. In other news, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Chinese developer Future Land says ex-chairman arrested, operations normal
summary: Chinese developer Future Land Development Holdings' controlling shareholder and former chairman Wang Zhenhua has been arrested for child molestation. The arrest was approved on July 10 and the case is being processed. Despite this, Future Land's operations remain normal, with its controlling shareholder no longer holding any position at the company. A subsidiary, Seazen Holdings, has apologized and will cooperate with authorities. The arrest has not affected Future Land's operations, and the company continues to function as usual.

site_title: Vista raises US$850m for second early-stage software fund: sources
summary: US private equity firm Vista Equity Partners has raised $850 million for its second early-stage software fund, Vista Equity Endeavor Fund II. This follows the $560 million raised for the first Endeavor fund in 2017. The fund focuses on investing in high-growth enterprise software businesses with $10 million to $30 million in annual recurring revenue. Vista aims to partner with founders to scale their businesses, and the fund will be used to deploy capital through seven investments. The fund's success underscores investor appetite for early-stage software businesses.

site_title: US art dealer charged in US$145m smuggling ring
summary: Subhash Kapoor, a 70-year-old former US art dealer, was charged with running a US$145 million smuggling ring that trafficked in thousands of stolen antiquities over 30 years. Kapoor, currently jailed in India, is accused of hiding 39 looted items valued at US$36 million and was involved in a scheme that created false paper trails to sell antiquities globally to collectors, art dealers, and museums. Over 2,600 antiquities valued at US$107 million have been seized from storage locations controlled by Kapoor. He was charged along with seven co-conspirators, most of whom are overseas and will require extradition.

site_title: Majority of US veterans say Afghanistan war 'not worth fighting': poll
summary: A majority of US military veterans, 58%, say the nearly 18-year war in Afghanistan was "not worth fighting", according to a Pew Research Centre poll. This aligns with 59% of the general public. Similar sentiments were expressed regarding the wars in Iraq and Syria. The poll results come as the US and Taleban engage in talks to close the conflict, with Washington aiming to seal a deal ahead of Afghan presidential polls in September.

site_title: Flights resume at Gatwick Airport after 'control systems issue'
summary: Gatwick Airport resumed flights after nearly two hours of closure due to an air traffic control systems issue. The airport restarted landings and take-offs around 7:00pm local time, but advised passengers to check flight information with their airlines. Flights had been suspended just after 5:00pm, with the airport working to rectify the issue. This disruption was expected to last several hours, with a backlog of delayed departures and landings.

site_title: Coal tycoon woos Amazon, Google with India data hubs
summary: Indian coal tycoon Gautam Adani aims to capitalize on India's government-mandated data storage law by building data parks, expecting a multibillion-dollar project. Adani Enterprises Ltd plans to invest $13.89 billion over two decades to build data centers in southern India. The move is seen as a strategic expansion into the data storage services market, with companies like Amazon and Google potentially benefiting from the demand. Adani's conglomerate has a history of investing in infrastructure, including ports, mining, and electricity, and is seen as a key player in India's nation-building efforts.

site_title: Dramatic warming projected in world's major cities by 2050
summary: A new analysis projects dramatic warming in world's major cities by 2050. London will resemble Madrid, Paris will be like Canberra, and Stockholm will be similar to Budapest. Moscow will be like Sofia. Tropical cities like Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta, and Singapore will experience extreme weather events and intense droughts. The study, published in PLOS ONE, relies on optimistic projections and highlights the impact of climate change.

site_title: Deutsche Bank faces justice department probe over 1MDB: WSJ
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating Deutsche Bank AG for potential violations of foreign-corruption and anti-money-laundering laws related to its dealings with Malaysia's 1MDB investment fund, which raised $1.2 billion in 2014. A former Goldman Sachs executive, Tim Leissner, is assisting with the probe. The investigation follows similar probes into other financial institutions and individuals involved in 1MDB's scandals.

site_title: KLW disposing stake in Vietnam factory owner for US$7.02m
summary: KLW Holdings is disposing its entire paid-up capital contribution in Vietnam-based factory owner Key Bay Furniture for US$7.02 million to BTJI Industrial Co. The deal includes a US$990,000 deposit, with the first instalment of US$5.68 million due upon completion and the second of US$350,000 six months later. The disposal will allow KLW to realise the value of the vacant factory, which has unutilised capacity, and use the proceeds for working capital needs. The transaction is conditional on approval from the Binh Duong Province Department of Planning and Investment and listing requirements with the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Australian regulator tells Westpac, ANZ, NAB to set aside another A$500m
summary: Australia's prudential regulator, APRA, has ordered three major banks - Westpac, ANZ, and NAB - to set aside an additional A$500 million each until they strengthen risk management and reimburse customers wrongly charged fees. APRA chair Wayne Byres stated that the banks are well-capitalized but need to improve non-financial risk management. The regulator aims to ensure the banks' financial stability and protect customers.

site_title: Hong Kong watch tycoon raises stake in Cordlife to 28%, prompting jump in share price
summary: Hong Kong watch tycoon Hon Kwok Lung has increased his stake in Cordlife Group to 28.17%, prompting a jump in the company's share price. This follows a surge in the stock on Wednesday, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange. Hon's wife, Lam Suk Ying, also holds a significant stake in the company. The move comes after Hon's net worth dropped off Forbes' Billionaires List this year.

site_title: Japan's Hayabusa2 probe makes second touchdown on asteroid
summary: Japan's Hayabusa2 probe successfully landed on the asteroid Ryugu for a second time, collecting pristine materials from beneath the surface. The probe touched down briefly in an area 20m away from the crater created by an "impactor" fired in April. The successful touchdown was confirmed after the probe resumed communications with the control room, allowing scientists to collect valuable samples that could shed light on the solar system's evolution and the origin of life. The mission is the final major part of Hayabusa2's multi-year mission, with samples expected to return to Earth next year.

site_title: US central bank to study Facebook virtual currency
summary: The US Federal Reserve has formed a working group to study the implications of Facebook's planned virtual currency Libra. Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the cryptocurrency raises "serious" concerns regarding privacy and emphasized the need for a patient and careful review. The review will involve coordination with government agencies and central banks worldwide. The study aims to assess the potential benefits and risks of Libra, which aims to lower transaction costs and bring financial services to those without access to the banking system.

site_title: SGX RegCo requires exit offers to be fair and reasonable, shareholder vote to exclude offeror and concert parties
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. (SGX RegCo) has introduced changes to voluntary delisting rules, requiring exit offers to be both "reasonable" and "fair" and requiring offerors and concert parties to abstain from voting on delisting resolutions. The changes aim to safeguard minority shareholders' interests and address concerns about the existing rules allowing issuers to make low-ball exit offers. The new rules take effect immediately and maintain the 75% approval threshold for delistings, ensuring independent shareholders have a say in the decision-making process.

images.alt_text: The regulatory arm of the Singapore Exchange (SGX RegCo) has announced changes to two aspects of the voluntary delisting rules for listed firms, with immediate effect.

site_title: Door open to US rate cut as Federal Reserve's Powell flags economic uncertainties
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell left the door open to a potential interest rate cut this month amid economic uncertainty, citing rising trade frictions and global growth concerns. Powell stated that the case for lower rates "had strengthened" and that the Fed will deploy all tools to support continued expansion. The comments led investors to signal a clear expectation of a rate cut, and Powell also defied President Donald Trump's criticism, saying he would not step down.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Federal Reserve chief's dovish signal
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on July 11, 2019, following dovish testimony from Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, which suggested looser monetary policy. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 21,568.19, while the Topix Index increased 0.19% to 1,574.34. The rally follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: New Epstein victim goes public as Trump labour secretary defends plea deal
summary: US Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta defended his handling of a secret plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein, who has been charged with sex trafficking of minors. Another woman, Jennifer Araoz, came forward alleging she was raped by Epstein at 15. Acosta said prosecutors agreed to the deal to protect victims and ensure Epstein was registered as a sex offender. The deal has sparked calls for Acosta's resignation, with top Democrats in Congress calling for his resignation.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks hit record high before pension reform vote
summary: Brazil's benchmark Ibovespa index reached a record high of 105,817 after closing at 1.23% higher, driven by optimism over President Jair Bolsonaro's pension reform bill, which is expected to pass its first vote in Congress. The bill aims to introduce a minimum retirement age and increase contributions, generating estimated savings of around 1 trillion reais (S$361 billion) over 10 years. A favourable result would be a boon for Bolsonaro, who faces stiff resistance from trade unions and a hostile Congress.

site_title: Tickled Media snags Series C funding from Fosun, JD.com for expansion, e-commerce
summary: Tickled Media, the parent company behind theAsianparent, has secured an eight-figure Series C funding round from Fosun International and JD.com, with additional backing from ATM Capital, Redbadge Pacific, and existing investors. The startup will use the funds to expand its parenting portal into Nigeria, Kenya, and South Africa, and e-commerce platform in Asia. The total funding amount is between $10 million and $30 million. Tickled Media aims to bring its parenting portal to underserved markets in emerging economies, and e-commerce platform will feature niche products for mothers and babies.

site_title: High net worth wealth reverses 7-year uptrend in 2018
summary: Global wealth held by high net worth individuals (HNWI) declined by $2 trillion in 2018, reversing a 7-year growth trend, primarily due to Asia Pacific and China's economic slowdown. Asia-Pacific wealth decreased by 30% to $20.6 trillion, with China accounting for nearly 53% of this decline. The ultra-HNWI segment was hit hardest, with a 4% decline in population and 6% decline in wealth. Despite this, trust levels in wealth management firms rose globally, but declined in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to acquire 7th warehouse in India for S$42m
summary: Ascendas India Trust plans to acquire a 7th warehouse in western India's Arshiya Free Trade Warehousing Zone for S$42.1 million (around 2.15 billion Indian rupees). The warehouse, to be developed and managed by a subsidiary of Arshiya, will have a total leasable area of 325,503 sq ft. The acquisition is expected to increase the trust's distribution per unit by around 0.03 Singapore cent, with completion anticipated by June 30, 2020.

site_title: UOB prices S$750m 3.58% perpetual securities
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) priced S$750 million of 3.58% additional tier one perpetual capital securities at an initial spread of 1.795% above the seven-year Singapore dollar swap offer rate. The issue price is on par with the principal amount, with interest payments made semi-annually. The securities can be redeemed by UOB on July 17, 2026, or on any distribution payment date thereafter.

site_title: European airline chiefs push back against flight shaming, carbon taxes
summary: European airline chiefs have pushed back against efforts to discourage flying, citing the industry's efforts to cut its carbon footprint. Despite accounting for 2.5% of global emissions, airlines argue they've halved emissions per flight over three decades and are investing in fuel-efficient aircraft. The industry has set a plan to achieve carbon-neutral growth and halve net emissions by 2050. Airlines claim there's no shame in air travel and are sensitive to criticism, with Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary stating the industry pays significant environmental taxes and is committed to a greener future.

site_title: Cordlife's share price surges on married deals
summary: Cordlife Group's share price surged 16.5% on Wednesday, reaching an 11-month high of 60 Singapore cents, following a series of married trades totaling nearly 34 million shares. The Singapore Exchange flagged "unusual price movements" and asked Cordlife to explain the trading activity. The company had recently announced a proposed merger with Global Cord Blood Corporation, which could result in the delisting of GCBC shares from the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: Oil prices jump 4.5% on US crude stocks draw, Gulf of Mexico storm
summary: Oil prices surged 4.5% on Wednesday, reaching their highest level in over a month, after US crude inventories dropped 9.5 million barrels and major oil producers cut nearly a third of Gulf of Mexico production ahead of a storm. Brent crude futures rose to $67.01 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed to $60.43 a barrel. The inventory draw and impending storm contributed to the price increase, with analysts attributing the stronger-than-expected draw to refineries ramping up output.

site_title: Is Putin right that liberalism is obsolete?
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin declared that the "liberal idea has become obsolete" in a recent interview with the Financial Times. This statement is seen as a shift in his image, from an aggressive autocrat to a leading political thinker. Economically, the West is facing slowdowns in growth, aging populations, and budget deficits. These challenges have led to a decline in faith in liberal ideology, which Putin attributes to its inability to address people's concerns about national identities and sovereignty.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record as Federal Reserve chief signals possible rate cut
summary: The Nasdaq reached a record high on July 10, 2019, as the US stocks rallied following Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's dovish commentary that signaled a possible interest rate cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also surged to all-time intraday records, but the Nasdaq held the record, closing at 8,202.53. Powell stated that central bankers believed the case for lower rates had strengthened, but most investors predicted a smaller interest rate cut.

site_title: Ryanair says Boeing eyes Max flights by Oct, cites 2020 growth risk
summary: Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary stated that Boeing may not meet its October target for 737 Max flights due to the need for new deliveries over the winter. Boeing expects the Max to be flying by end-September, but O'Leary believes this target could slip to the end of the year. Ryanair has a deal with Boeing guaranteeing lower prices and is waiting to take delivery of 50 new Max aircraft, with a maximum monthly delivery rate of six to eight planes. Europe's largest budget carrier may need to trim its growth plans if the Max is not flying by November.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Ascendas India Trust, Capital World, NauticAWT, Y Ventures, KLW
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singapore stocks are seeing developments that may impact trading. United Overseas Bank priced S$750 million of perpetual securities at an initial spread of 1.795% above the 7-year SGD swap offer rate. Ascendas India Trust plans to acquire an additional warehouse in western India for S$42.1 million. Jardine Cycle & Carriage appointed a new group managing director, while Capital World is raising S$18 million by issuing new shares. NauticAWT's placement agreements have lapsed, and Y Ventures' CFO has resigned. KLW Holdings is disposing of its paid-up capital contribution in a Vietnamese factory for US$7.02 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as Federal Reserve optimism short-lived; banks outperform
summary: European shares closed lower for a fourth straight session, despite initial optimism over a possible interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, with concerns about trade tensions and a weak global economy prevailing. Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments on trade uncertainties and the global economy weighed on markets, with the pan-European index Stoxx 600 closing 0.2% lower. Despite a surge in crude prices and gains for metals, banks outperformed, while bond proxies and chip stocks declined.

site_title: Fears of higher tax wipe 2.3t rupees off Indian stocks
summary: A higher tax surcharge in India's budget has caused a 2.3 trillion rupee (S$45.67 billion) market value loss in the S&P BSE Sensex since July 9. The tax applies to wealthy Indians and trusts, affecting non-resident and overseas funds that invest in the nation. This realization has spooked investors, leading to a significant decline in Indian stocks.

site_title: India sticks to incremental reforms despite slowdown
summary: India's new finance minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, presented a cautious budget, sticking to the government's borrowing target and cutting the fiscal deficit target to 3.3% of GDP. The budget aims to boost India's GDP to $5 trillion by 2024, requiring 7-8% annual growth and a 4% inflation rate. Key announcements include a $10 billion capital infusion for public sector banks, a push for public sector disinvestment, and a corporate tax rate cut to 25% for small firms. However, the budget did not include significant fiscal stimulus, leaving the future of major economic reforms uncertain.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How family-owned businesses survive in Singapore
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how family-owned businesses in Singapore survive and thrive. The podcast explores strategies such as maintaining a strong company culture, leveraging technology, and adapting to changing market conditions. Experts also highlight the importance of succession planning and maintaining a balance between family and business interests. By sharing their experiences and insights, family business owners in Singapore can learn from each other and develop effective strategies for long-term success. The podcast aims to provide valuable advice and guidance for family-owned businesses in Singapore.

site_title: Foreign unicorns here juicing up market for high-tech skills
summary: Foreign tech unicorns in Singapore are creating highly-skilled jobs, adding vibrancy to the local market. 24 foreign unicorns, including Airbnb, Gojek, and WeWork, employ over 1,000 people in highly-skilled and tech-centric jobs. The entry of these unicorns is expected to add 10,000 new private sector tech-related jobs over the next three years. Experts say the skills involved boost the long-term resilience of the workforce and have a "multiplier effect" on the wider labour market and economy.

site_title: Scale-up SG to groom promising local firms to be world powerhouses
summary: Enterprise Singapore launched Scale-up SG, a 2.5-year invitation-only programme to support high-growth companies in Singapore. 25 pioneering companies, including Jumbo Group and PBA Group, will participate in the programme, which aims to strengthen Singapore's business landscape by grooming companies to become world powerhouses. The programme will provide peer learning, leadership development, and access to networks, with consultancy firms McKinsey & Company and PwC Singapore as anchor partners.

site_title: Reaganism and Clintonism fade away
summary: US President Ronald Reagan's conservative values have largely faded, replaced by a government that prioritizes national interests over international alliances. President Trump's policies diverge from Reagan's, with a focus on "America First" and a mercantilist economic strategy. Trump has also adopted a restrictive immigration policy, abandoning the universal values that characterized Reagan's approach. This shift is part of a broader transformation of the Republican Party, driven by changing economic and political realities. The GOP's shift has been influenced by the Iraq War, the 2008 financial crisis, and the rise of populism, setting the stage for a potential clash between Trumpism and left-leaning populism in the near future.

site_title: France denies Franco-German agreement on Carney for IMF job
summary: France denies a Franco-German agreement to support Bank of England's Mark Carney for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) job, contradicting earlier reports. France is pushing for a European consensus on a candidate to replace IMF chief Christine Lagarde, who was nominated to head the European Central Bank. The French finance ministry emphasized the need for consensus on a European name, rather than backing a specific candidate like Carney.

site_title: Europe should heed this wake-up call regarding 5G
summary: Europe should prioritize a unified approach to 5G technology to mitigate security risks. The ongoing debate over US and European mobile operators purchasing equipment from Chinese telecoms giant Huawei has exposed geopolitics and technological leadership concerns. While most European governments favor excluding Huawei due to espionage concerns, the real vulnerability lies in the fragmented telecoms market and lack of a common cyber defense system. A powerful, integrated cyber security agency and centralized regulatory framework are needed to address these concerns and ensure the continent's cyber security and telecoms champions.

site_title: Singapore condo rents dip again in June, HDB rents edge up: SRX flash data
summary: Singapore condo rents decreased 0.2% in June from May, marking the second consecutive month of decline, according to SRX Property. In contrast, HDB flat rents rose 0.3% in June from May. The data suggests a slowdown in non-landed private property rentals, while HDB rentals continue to edge up.

site_title: It's not debt but how Reits leverage on it that matters
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the 45% leverage ceiling for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits). The current limit was set in 2015 to boost operational flexibility, but S-Reits need to borrow to upgrade assets and deliver stronger rental yields. The MAS considers the 45% limit too low, as other Reit jurisdictions have higher or no leverage limits. Analysts argue that S-Reits can manage higher debt levels if they show financial strength and use debt strategically. A higher leverage limit could make S-Reits more competitive globally, but also increases risk.

images.alt_text: Early this month, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said it was reviewing the 45 per cent leverage ceiling for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits).

site_title: After 18% surge in 2019, Singapore Reits seen as too pricey: analysts
summary: Analysts from Morningstar and CMC Markets Singapore warn that Singapore Reits' rally has reached its peak, with the FTSE Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust Index surging 18% in 2019. Reits are now trading at 1.2 times book value, the most expensive in over six years, with some analysts predicting a sell-off due to high valuations and relatively low dividend yields. Despite some remaining optimism, strategists caution investors to be selective and expect modest returns in the second half.

site_title: Turning reservoirs into 'energy batteries'
summary: Singapore is turning its reservoirs into 'energy batteries' to boost renewable energy, despite limited space for solar farms and low wind speeds. The country has partnered with companies like Sunseap and ING to develop rooftop solar projects, and plans to install one of the world's largest single floating solar photovoltaic systems in a reservoir by 2021. This initiative aims to reduce carbon emissions and position Singapore as a renewable energy hub in the region, attracting industry players and sustainable financing opportunities.

site_title: Japan court rejects move to halt Kyushu Electric reactors
summary: A Japanese high court has rejected a citizens group's claim that Kyushu Electric Power Co. has insufficient measures to protect its reactors from natural disasters. The ruling allows the utility to continue operating its Genkai reactors. Japan's nuclear sector is under scrutiny as regulators consider stricter safety standards, which could boost costs and impact operations. The Nuclear Regulation Authority may ask utilities to reassess earthquake risks, potentially leading to reactor shutdowns.

site_title: US claims fund owner ran US$6m insider-trading ring
summary: A San Diego investment fund owner, Donald Blakstad, 60, was arrested and charged with running a US$6 million insider-trading ring. He allegedly received tips from a former Illumina Inc. accountant, Martha Bustos, and traded on the information from 2016 to 2018. Blakstad faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted of conspiracy, securities fraud, and wire fraud. Bustos, who pleaded guilty, is cooperating with the government in hopes of avoiding prison. The case involves Blakstad's investment firm, Midcontinental Petroleum Inc, and several unidentified co-conspirators.

images.alt_text: A San Diego investment fund owner was arrested and charged with running an insider-trading ring that made more than US$6 million from illegal tips about Illumina Inc.

site_title: Singapore's building sector set to grow but downside risks loom
summary: Singapore's building sector is expected to grow 3.2% in 2019 and 2.3% in 2020, driven by a strong pipeline of residential projects. However, Fitch Solutions Macro Research warns of downside risks, including uncertainty over US-China trade tensions and the possibility of a recession. Private consumption remains subdued, and a drop in demand is anticipated due to property cooling measures. The probability of a US recession has increased, and global implications will affect Singapore's economy, including a trade slowdown and potential impact on the residential building sector.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SATS divests 51% stake in FASSCO, a joint venture specializing in healthcare food and nutrition, to Planet Foods for S$1.02 million. The divestment marks the end of FASSCO's status as a SATS subsidiary. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continue their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with NTT DC Reit's public offer 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Singapore's netballers in for tough ride at World Cup in Liverpool
summary: Singapore's netball team, led by coach Natalie Milicich and captain Charmaine Soh, is preparing for a challenging 2019 Netball World Cup in Liverpool. The team plans to utilize their speed and unique playing style to outmaneuver opponents, who will need to adjust to their unorthodox approach. Despite their small stature, the team is confident in their abilities and looks to make a lasting impression in the competition.

site_title: France to impose green tax on plane tickets
summary: France will impose a green tax on plane tickets, starting from 2020, with a maximum of 18 euros per flight. The tax will only apply to outgoing flights and not incoming ones. The funds generated will be used to create less-polluting transport options, with a projected annual revenue of 180 million euros. The tax will be 1.5 euros for economy-class internal flights, 9 euros for within the EU in business class, and a maximum 18 euros for flights outside the EU in business class.

site_title: Greece's centre-right government bears good news for Europe amid volatile landscape
summary: Greece's centre-right government, led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, has won a landslide election, marking the end of a chapter of economic crisis and extremism. Despite losing a quarter of its economy in the devastating recession, Greece has stabilised itself, rejecting extremist parties and embracing democracy. Mitsotakis, a Harvard- and Stanford-educated former McKinsey man, has promised to cut corporate taxes, deliver digital transformation, and attract investment to spur sustainable growth. The election is seen as a positive sign for Europe, rejecting nationalism and xenophobia, and a reminder that democracy can prevail despite challenges.

site_title: Customise, mentor, engage to capture millennials' interest
summary: A seminar in Singapore focused on engaging millennial customers and colleagues, concluding that this demographic is diverse and defies pigeon-holing. Speakers emphasized the importance of personalizing the job experience, communicating purpose and giving employees a sense of accomplishment. Millennials are expected to be early adopters and spend more on travel, fashion, and technology. Engaging millennial employees can lead to significant increases in earnings, profit, and productivity. The seminar aimed to provide strategies for employers to attract and retain millennial talents and create meaningful connections with customers.

site_title: Chinese technology companies are going for America's top influencers
summary: Chinese technology companies, including Tencent Holdings Ltd, are hosting an exclusive event in California to attract top US influencers, as the country's online video sector faces intense competition. The East-West Forum will bring together executives, celebrities, and online influencers from China and the US to discuss potential collaborations. This move comes as China's technology industry seeks to expand its presence in the US market, where YouTube is blocked, giving Chinese companies an edge.

site_title: Gojek snags investment from biggest Thai bank
summary: Gojek, a Singapore-based ride-hailing giant, has secured an investment from Siam Commercial Bank, Thailand's largest bank, according to people familiar with the matter. The exact amount of the investment is unclear. This deal comes as Gojek continues to expand its presence in Southeast Asia. The partnership with Siam Commercial Bank, which is also the largest shareholder of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, may provide Gojek with access to more resources and expertise in the region.

site_title: Oil jumps on report of falling US stockpiles, Iran tension
summary: US crude inventories plummeted by 8.13 million barrels last week, exceeding market expectations, driving oil prices to a one-week high. The American Petroleum Institute's report sparked concerns about rising tensions in the Middle East, particularly after Iran vowed to respond to Britain's seizure of an Iranian tanker. The US dollar's decline also bolstered oil prices. The news has strengthened the supply outlook, with West Texas Intermediate crude rising 2.3% to $59.18 a barrel, and Brent increasing 1.8% to $65.31 a barrel.

site_title: Seoul pledges to help firms to reduce their reliance on Japanese suppliers
summary: South Korea's president has pledged to help firms reduce their reliance on Japanese suppliers due to ongoing export curbs on key materials used by South Korean tech companies. The restrictions, imposed by Japan citing a dispute over forced labor during World War II, could drag on despite diplomatic efforts. The curbs affect materials used in smartphone displays and chips, impacting companies such as Samsung and LG. Seoul's move aims to mitigate the economic impact of the dispute.

site_title: Property investment sales up 49% in second quarter
summary: Singapore's real estate investment sales surged 49% in the second quarter, reaching S$6.7 billion, driven by big-ticket office deals. Commercial deals accounted for 52% of the total sales, with two office space deals generating nearly S$2 billion.

site_title: 3 Singaporeans jailed for 'front-running' in landmark share trading case
summary: Three Singaporean men, Leong Chee Wai, Toh Chew Leong, and Simon E Seck Peng, were jailed for terms ranging from 20 months to three years for running an illegal share trading scheme called "front-running". The trio pleaded guilty to over 100 charges, netting them more than S$2 million each. The scheme involved profiting from confidential information before it was publicly available. The men's actions were deemed a breach of securities laws, resulting in their convictions and imprisonment.

site_title: Sun Venture granted exclusive due diligence for 71 Robinson Rd
summary: Sun Venture, a property investment group backed by Taiwanese and Singaporean investors, has been granted exclusive due diligence for 71 Robinson Road, a 15-storey office block in Singapore. The property, valued at around S$660 million, features Grade A specifications and is currently fully occupied by tenants including CommerzBank, Visa, and WeWork. The sale would reflect a net yield of about 3.5% based on income from existing leases.

site_title: Singapore-sponsored 8i enters into share exchange agreement with Diginex
summary: 8i Enterprises Acquisition Corp, a Singapore-sponsored blank cheque company, has entered into a share exchange agreement with Hong Kong-based blockchain financial services company Diginex Ltd. Upon completion, Diginex is expected to have an initial enterprise value of US$276 million. Diginex aims to build an ecosystem for the broader adoption of digital assets, leveraging blockchain technology. The deal will see 8i acquire Diginex, with Diginex shareholders receiving 20 million ordinary shares of 8i valued at US$10 per share, and potentially an additional 5 million shares based on performance targets.

site_title: Innovation, technology can help unlock opportunities in APAC real estate
summary: Innovation and technology can help unlock opportunities in the Asia-Pacific real estate market, driven by structural people-driven trends such as ageing populations, labour shortages, and changing consumer preferences. Retailers are adopting omni-channel retailing and automation to provide a superior user experience, while landlords are leveraging big data and technology to optimize customer targeting and delivery of shopping incentives. The region's rapidly ageing population also presents opportunities for retailers to tap into the "silver dollar" demographic, and automation can help occupiers scale up while reducing reliance on scarce human resources.

site_title: Boeing falls behind Airbus in deliveries as 737 MAX crisis bites
summary: Boeing reported 239 commercial plane deliveries at mid-year, trailing Airbus' 389 deliveries, due to the 737 MAX grounding. This marks a 37% decline from the same period last year. Airbus is on track to overtake Boeing in 2019 deliveries. The 737 MAX crisis has significantly impacted Boeing's production and sales, leading to Boeing falling behind its European rival in commercial plane deliveries.

site_title: China factory price inflation slips as trade war pressure grows
summary: China's factory price inflation remains unchanged in June, with the producer price index (PPI) at zero, the weakest since August 2016. This slowdown reflects sluggish demand due to the US trade war, which could lead to a drop in prices globally. Consumer prices, however, rose 2.7% in June, driven by a surge in food prices due to African swine fever and severe weather. Experts warn that deflation could dent corporate profits and drag on the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Factory prices in China were unchanged in June from a year ago, data showed on Wednesday, reviving the prospect of deflation as the US trade war hits the crucial manufacturing sector.

site_title: China sees economic growth continuing in range of 6-6.5%
summary: China's Finance Minister Liu Kun expressed confidence in the country's economic growth, predicting it will remain within a 6-6.5% range. Liu emphasized the importance of multilateral organizations and avoiding protectionism, which could harm global growth. He did not mention the ongoing US-China trade dispute.

site_title: Mahathir weighs proposals for Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the government is studying proposals for Malaysia Airlines Bhd, received from mostly local companies offering to buy a stake or manage the flag carrier. Four proposals were submitted, but the names of the companies were not disclosed. The government will consider the proposals to determine the future of the airline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with a 0.31% gain, reaching 28,204.69, as investors await key congressional testimony from Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.44%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.46%. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Iswaran repeats call for SMEs to go digital
summary: Singapore's SMEs Go Digital scheme has seen a surge in sign-ups since the recent Start Digital effort, with 10,000 companies participating since its launch in 2017, including 6,000 in the past six months. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasizes the need for digital transformation, citing competitive pressure in export-oriented sectors and limited resources in domestic-facing industries. The government aims to match SMEs with digital tools, with a focus on payments solutions and online platforms, to drive economic growth and enhance cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran fingered small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) - especially in domestic-facing sectors - as potential culprits behind the patchy digital adoption by companies here.

site_title: NauticAWT's placement agreements lapse, firm strikes new deal
summary: NauticAWT's placement agreements with Zhongtai International Securities and Soochow CSSD Capital Markets have lapsed, as the company and agents mutually agreed not to proceed. Instead, NauticAWT has struck a new share subscription agreement with Dr. Chirasak Chiyachantana to issue 400 million new shares, worth S$4.5 million. The agreement would see the private investor become a controlling shareholder with a 50.4% stake in the company. The net proceeds will be used for working capital funding and investment.

site_title: Asean countries benefiting from trade war: Maybank Kim Eng
summary: Most Asean countries, except Singapore and Indonesia, are benefiting from the US-China trade war, with Vietnam and Malaysia emerging as top beneficiaries. US and China import substitution has driven trade flows towards Asean, with Vietnam's exports to the US surging 29% in the first four months of 2019. This shift has created opportunities for Asean countries, particularly Vietnam and Malaysia, to diversify their trade and economic growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Suntec Reit's proposed acquisition of 21 Harris Street in Sydney, Australia, is deemed fair and distribution per unit (DPU) accretive, boosting FY2020-21 DPU forecasts by 0.6%. China Aviation Oil's (CAO) share price is maintained as "Buy" despite lower jet fuel prices, driven by steady volume growth and a fixed US dollar per tonne margin. CAO remains cheap compared to regional and global peers, with upside potential from rising aviation passenger traffic and expanding infrastructure.

site_title: Deutsche Bank keeping its UK broking mandates
summary: Deutsche Bank will retain its UK broking mandates despite shutting its global equities business. 27 major London-listed companies, including McCarthy & Stone, Travis Perkins, and Carpetright, have chosen to remain with the bank. The decision comes as the bank prepares to close its global equities business.

site_title: Positive midweek performance for STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,340.42, driven by gains from Thai Beverage, DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. Trading volume was above the daily average, with 1.22 billion securities traded. Advancers outpaced decliners 193-188, with ComfortDelGro closing down 0.7% despite hopes of fare revisions. Market sentiment was mixed, with investors anxious ahead of US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony and measured optimism on US-China trade talks.

site_title: Traders certain the Fed will cut in July, but unsure what's next
summary: US traders remain confident the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in July, but are scaling back expectations for 2019 easing to 64 basis points from 80 basis points. Options traders are still betting on multiple cuts, but the June jobs data and slower economic growth have reduced urgency for action. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony and minutes from the June meeting will be closely watched for guidance on policy. If Powell signals a need for further action, markets may surge, but business confidence could be hurt.

site_title: Blumenthal returns, rethinks, and is raring to go
summary: Celebrity chef Heston Blumenthal, known for his three Michelin-starred restaurant The Fat Duck, has returned after a few years of rethinking his work, business, and life. He is now raring to go with brand new ideas, research, and a mission to redefine people's relationship with food. Blumenthal's restaurants still maintain a strong following for their immersive experiences, and he is set to introduce new concepts this year, including a partnership for the Formula 1 race.

site_title: Monaco rolls out 5G network built by Huawei in European first
summary: Monaco has become the first European country to launch a 5G mobile network based on Huawei technology, marking a significant milestone in the rollout of next-generation wireless networks. The network, which covers the entire principality, is seen as a major opportunity for Huawei despite concerns over security risks. The rollout comes as Europe debates its approach to Chinese tech giant Huawei, with the US viewing it as a security risk. Monaco's decision to work with Huawei is defended by the operator, which claims it has implemented necessary security measures to protect its systems.

site_title: Euro rises from 2-week lows before Powell's testimony
summary: The euro rose to above US$1.12 on July 10, rebounding from two-week lows as bets on aggressive US rate cuts decreased. The US dollar strengthened, with yields on 10-year Treasury bonds reaching three-week highs. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony before Congress may confirm or scale back rate cut expectations. Analysts expect a neutral or hawkish tone from Powell to support the US dollar's rise, but the euro remains within tight ranges.

site_title: Toyota to build new SUV, rather than car at Alabama plant
summary: Toyota will build a new sport utility vehicle at a US$1.6 billion joint venture assembly plant in Alabama, shifting production away from the Corolla car. The decision is due to a growing consumer appetite for light trucks and SUVs. Despite US car sales declining 2.2% in the first half of 2019, Toyota expects to start production in 2021. The company will continue to produce Corolla cars at its Mississippi plant.

site_title: HitecVision, Oman's Petrogas to buy UK oilfields from Total
summary: HitecVision, a UK-based private equity fund, and Petrogas, an Omani oil group, have agreed to buy a portfolio of Total's British North Sea oilfields for $635 million. The deal includes 8 fields that will produce 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with plans to expand production to over 100,000 barrels within two to three years. The acquisition is part of a trend of private equity firms acquiring mature oilfields to extract more barrels before exiting. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Microsoft opens first European store in London's West End
summary: Microsoft has opened its first European retail store in London's West End, featuring technology such as Xbox games, Surface tablets, and augmented reality. The three-floor flagship store is designed to cater to various customers, including gamers, students, and small business users. The store will offer 200,000 hours of free workshops to gain digital skills, reinforcing Microsoft's commitment to digital skills development in the UK. The store is staffed by 45 language speakers, including those fluent in British Sign Language, aiming to create a welcoming environment for all customers.

site_title: Virgin Galactic plans to take space tourism venture public
summary: Virgin Galactic, a space tourism company founded by Richard Branson, plans to become the world's first publicly traded space tourism venture through a merger with Social Capital Hedosophia. The deal values the company at $1.5 billion and is expected to be completed before the end of the year. The merger will provide the necessary capital for Virgin Galactic to sustain its operations until it begins commercial flights and generates its own revenue. The company has raised over $1 billion since its inception, but much of that funding came from Branson's personal fortune.

site_title: Asean investment in human capital and ICT infrastructure critical: OCBC
summary: Asean must invest in human capital and ICT infrastructure to remain competitive in the face of China's growing economy and increasing demand for complex imports. As China shifts towards domestic consumption, Asean's labor-intensive manufacturing industries will struggle to meet this demand. Analysts at OCBC emphasize the need for Asean to shift towards technological know-how and develop secure internet infrastructure to stay ahead of the US-China tech race. This investment will be crucial for the region to maintain its global influence and overcome trade barriers.

site_title: China's PBOC, trading platform signal floor for interbank rates, say sources
summary: China's PBOC and interbank trading platform have introduced trading alerts to prevent short-term rates from falling below 0.72% to support the slowing economy. The move follows a recent plunge in some short-term rates, with the overnight bond repurchase rate trading at 1.82% on Wednesday. The PBOC has also suspended traders at Ping An Bank and China Merchants Bank for involvement in "abnormal" trades, which contributed to the low rates. This effort aims to stabilize market yields and prevent further declines.

site_title: New EU chief nominee hopes Britain will ditch Brexit
summary: EU President-elect Ursula von der Leyen hopes Britain will abandon Brexit, warning London that it must take responsibility for "sorting out" its departure from the bloc. Von der Leyen stated that the EU will not renegotiate the Brexit deal, and she emphasized the importance of a good tone and attitude in future relations between Britain and the EU. The EU has agreed on a divorce deal with Prime Minister Theresa May, but it was rejected by British lawmakers. Von der Leyen's comments come as two men, Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt, vie to replace May.

site_title: Sceptical Deutsche Bank investors to grill Sewing on revamp roadshow
summary: Deutsche Bank shareholders will grill CEO Christian Sewing on his plan to deliver revenue growth targets during a global roadshow. The bank is undergoing a 7.4 billion euro overhaul, including 18,000 job cuts and a 'bad bank' for costly trading positions. Investors doubt these moves will turn around the bank's fortunes, with some calling for more radical changes. Deutsche Bank aims for an 8% return on tangible equity by 2022, but faces significant uncertainty and capital constraints.

site_title: Lab-grown meat at US$10 a patty? Give it 2 years
summary: Lab-grown meat could hit US$10 a patty in two years as European startups scale up production, reducing costs. The technology, which involves growing meat from animal cells, has seen significant investment and growth, with over 20 startups in the market. Producers aim to secure regulatory approval to bring the product to mainstream shelves. While some experts question the environmental sustainability of lab-grown meat, others believe it could become a more environmentally friendly alternative to conventional meat production.

site_title: Thai king endorses new Cabinet weeks after disputed election
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn endorsed a new civilian Cabinet led by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, 108 days after a disputed election. The Cabinet includes former junta members, with Prayuth as defense minister and loyalists as deputy prime ministers. Critics say the lineup shows the military prioritized its interests over cleaning up politics, and the opposition claims the Cabinet is weak and lacks the ability to solve people's problems.

site_title: Deutsche Bank tells fixed income traders that they'll keep jobs
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced plans to cut 18,000 positions across its corporate and investment bank division, but fixed-income traders will keep their jobs, according to the bank's head Ram Nayak. This move is part of a "resize" of debt trading operations to free up capital for more profitable businesses. The bank has earmarked over 20% of its balance sheet for winding down or selling, primarily affecting the equities unit. Fixed-income has been a traditional strength of Deutsche Bank's investment banking activities, generating 5.36 billion euros in revenue last year.

site_title: Singapore's 5G network to get expert security team as cyberthreats widen
summary: Singapore plans to establish a cybersecurity team to secure its 5G network ahead of its rollout next year. The Telecoms Cybersecurity Specialist Team will comprise experts from the public sector, tasked with identifying weaknesses and testing new tools. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized the need for a proactive approach to cybersecurity. The move comes as cyberthreats widen, and Singapore aims to have its 5G network secure from the outset.

site_title: US May wholesale inventories unrevised; sales edge up
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.4% in May, increasing 7.7% year-over-year, driven by a strong increase in the automotive sector. The component of wholesale inventories that goes into GDP calculations gained 0.2% in May. This suggests inventory accumulation may have been a drag on economic growth in the second quarter, supporting views that the pace of accumulation is slowing.

site_title: New Thai leader keeps junta's powers of arbitrary detention
summary: Thailand's new civilian government, led by Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha, will retain the power to arbitrarily detain critics despite easing of junta-era security controls. The government retained over 100 junta-enacted orders, including the right for military detention for seven days on national security grounds. Rights groups warn of enduring "martial law," while analysts say full democracy remains a distant prospect. The government's decision was criticized by political opponents, who slammed the process and questioned Mr. Prayut's legitimacy.

site_title: American Airlines raises unit revenue forecast, shares rise
summary: American Airlines raised its second-quarter unit revenue forecast due to the grounding of Boeing's MAX jets, allowing the carrier to fly fuller planes. The company's shares rose 3% and provided relief to the battered airline sector. However, American Airlines canceled over 7,000 flights, resulting in a pretax profit reduction of approximately $185 million. This move lifted shares of other airlines, including Delta Air Lines, which also offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand.

site_title: Greek PM to submit tax cut plan to parliament in coming weeks
summary: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis plans to submit a tax cut bill to parliament in the coming weeks, following his conservative New Democracy party's election victory. The bill aims to reduce corporate and income tax. The new parliament will be sworn in next week, marking the start of Mitsotakis' term. The tax cuts are part of New Democracy's pledge to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to redevelop flatted-factory cluster at Kallang Way
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust plans to redevelop a flatted-factory cluster at Kallang Way into a high-tech industrial precinct for S$263 million. The project, MIT's largest to date, will feature a build-to-suit facility for a German medical device company and increase the utilised plot ratio from 1.5 to 2.5. The anchor tenant has committed to a 15-year lease, and existing tenants will receive assistance packages, including extended notice periods and relocation support. Construction is expected to start in 2020 and be completed in two years, with the project expected to be accretive to MIT's distribution per unit.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Mapletree Industrial Trust's proposed high-tech industrial precinct at Kallang Way. The build-to-suit facility for the German medical device company is on the left.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.3% ahead of Fed chief's testimony
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 10.96 points or 0.3% to close at 3,340.42 on Wednesday ahead of US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony. The local market closed higher, with Thai Beverage and local banks rising, while ComfortDelGro fell 0.7% and Cordlife Group surged 16.5%. Trading volume reached 1.22 billion securities, and total turnover was 92% of the January-to-June daily average.

site_title: Fed's Powell says trade, global growth concerns continue to weigh on US economy
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated that trade and global growth concerns continue to weigh on the US economy, citing persistently weak inflation, slower growth in other major economies, and uncertainty over the Trump administration's trade war with China. Powell said the Fed is ready to act as appropriate to sustain a decade-long expansion, suggesting a possible interest rate cut later this month. Markets now expect a rate cut of at least a quarter of a percentage point, with some analysts predicting a 50-basis-point cut.

site_title: Think-tank trims Greek 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.8%
summary: Greece's economy is expected to grow at a moderate 1.8% this year, according to the IOBE think-tank, trimming its previous forecast. The country is recovering from a 10-year recession, with the economy growing 1.9% last year after exiting its third bailout program in 2018. Unemployment is predicted to decline, but at a slower pace, to settle below 18% this year, with stronger job growth in export sectors. The forecast is close to the central bank's 1.9% projected rate.

site_title: Y Ventures chief financial officer resigns
summary: Y Ventures' chief financial officer, Joshua Huang Thien En, has resigned, effective July 15, after serving a one-month notice period. The resignation is unrelated to the company's financial reporting or ongoing independent review. Financial controller Goh Lay Lan will assume his role and responsibilities. The move comes after accounting errors were discovered in Y Ventures' H1 2018 financial statements, which revealed the company was loss-making despite reporting profits.

site_title: Germany's Merkel suffers third bout of shaking during ceremony
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel experienced her third bout of shaking during a ceremony in Berlin, prompting concerns over her health. Merkel, 64, was seen trembling briefly alongside Finnish Prime Minister Antti Rinne, but her office says she is "fine" and holding talks as planned. The latest episode raises questions about her ability to perform her duties amid a struggling economy and strained coalition. Merkel has attributed previous shaking episodes to dehydration and psychological effects, but the persistent incidents put pressure on her office to provide fuller transparency about her health situation.

site_title: Leaving no one behind on road to progress
