summary: Singapore companies are adapting to the digital era, transforming lives and bridging the digital divide for vulnerable segments. Companies like Jayajyoti Sengupta's, June Ho's, Kunal Chatterjee's, and Yuen Kuan Moon's, have implemented CSR initiatives to ensure no one is left behind. They focus on three groups: children and youth at risk, the elderly, and transient workers. Programs include digital literacy training, STEM outreach, and volunteering to equip individuals with the skills needed to navigate the digital age. Companies are recognizing the need for digital inclusion and are partnering with government agencies and non-profits to address the issue.

images.alt_text: "...The rules of engagement have changed. Organisations know that they can thrive only if the communities within which they operate also thrive," says Mr Sengupta.
"We devote 10% of our annual partnership profits to charitable causes. We also provide pro bono services to those who otherwise cannot afford legal representation," says Ms Ho.
"Visa is also working with the financial institutions and non-financial institutions to ensure everyone in Singapore can have access to a digital payment card." says Mr Chatterjee.
"Sustainability ... is very much part of our corporate strategy as we believe our reputation and long-term success depend on how we create positive change in our society," says Mr Yuen.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.90 points to 1,678.97, amidst a trading volume of 2.2 billion lots worth RM2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 434 to 329.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Powell's remarks boost rate cut hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, July 10, 2019, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments boosted hopes of an interest rate cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.26%, the S&P 500 gained 0.32%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.51% at the opening bell. Powell's statement that the central bank would "act as appropriate" to sustain record US growth fueled optimism about a potential rate cut later this month.

site_title: Kim Darroch quits as UK Ambassador to US amid Trump's fury
summary: Kim Darroch, the UK Ambassador to the US, resigned amid a diplomatic row sparked by leaked comments criticizing the Trump White House. President Trump froze out Darroch, calling him "inept" and "uniquely dysfunctional," and Boris Johnson declined to back him, making it impossible for Darroch to continue in his role. Darroch cited the situation as making it impossible for him to carry out his duties and will stay on until a new ambassador takes over.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Enterprise Singapore launched the Scale-up SG programme, grooming 25 local companies to become future global powerhouses. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by US President Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, and Thailand's PM hopeful Thaksin is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case.

site_title: Further rate cut by Bank Negara Malaysia expected in Q4 2019: HSBC
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) kept its policy rate at 3% in line with expectations, citing concerns about slower global growth and trade-related risks. Despite this, analysts at HSBC predict a further 25 basis point rate cut in Q4 2019 due to a crucial 2020 budget and domestic demand driving growth. BNM expects headline inflation to rise, but remains optimistic about the economy's growth forecast range of 4.3-4.8%. The central bank believes domestic demand will drive growth, but faces downside risks on the domestic front.

site_title: Downfall of Camsing chairman Lo Ching is parable of the dangers of investing in China
summary: Camsing Healthcare chairman Lo Ching's downfall serves as a cautionary tale of investing in China. Lo, once hailed as a legendary Chinese warrior, was detained by police in Shanghai. Her company, Camsing International, is facing a lawsuit by US-listed asset manager Noah Holdings over a 3.4 billion yuan credit product in danger of default. The product was backed by account receivables from top Chinese retailers JD.com and Suning.com. Camsing International's stock crashed 80.4% after Lo's detainment, with her 62% stake now worth only HK$340 million. China's track record on repaying credit obligations is poor, with only 14.5% of missed bond payments repaid.

site_title: Singapore condo rents dip in June, HDB rents edge up: SRX flash data
summary: Singapore condo rents dipped 0.2% in June from May, marking the second consecutive month of decline, while HDB rents edged up 0.4% for the second month in a row. Year-on-year, private rents rose 1.9%, with all regions seeing increases, while HDB rents rose 1.4%. The number of condos leased fell 4.2% month-on-month and 6.4% year-on-year, but HDB flats leased rose 1.2%. Experts attribute the shift to potential investors seeking safer options in Singapore due to Hong Kong's unrest.

site_title: S&P 500 hits 3,000 as Powell's comment lifts rate cut hopes
summary: The S&P 500 index reached 3,000 points for the first time on July 10, 2019, as investors lifted hopes of an interest rate cut later this month following Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's comments. Powell stated the central bank would "act as appropriate" to sustain record US growth, citing a risk of persistent weak inflation. This lifted expectations for a rate cut in July, despite a strong jobs report. The index closed at 3,027.35, with stocks rallying on the back of Powell's comments.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,346.79, up 0.52% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.52% to 3,346.79, driven by gains in smaller stocks such as Asian Pay Television Trust and FJ Benjamin. The three local banks also advanced, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 0.5%, 1.2%, and 0.8% respectively. The gains followed a US congressional testimony by Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell, which boosted investor confidence. Other Asian markets also rose, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul up 0.4%, 0.6%, and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: L'Occitane inks US$900 million Elemis deal in luxury skincare boom
summary: L'Occitane International SA has agreed to acquire luxury skincare brand Elemis for approximately US$900 million, its largest deal on record. The acquisition aims to bolster L'Occitane's global growth, particularly in the US and UK, where Elemis is popular among millennials and Gen X consumers. The deal is part of a luxury skincare boom and is expected to help L'Occitane reach its 1.7 billion euro sales target in two years.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% to 7,522.16 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 losing 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs. In other news, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day, and eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion.

site_title: Capital World to raise S$18m by issuing shares to 2 private investors
summary: Capital World, a Singapore property firm, plans to raise S$18 million by issuing new shares to two private investors, Yuan Zhiwei and Chng Chor Tong. The issue price is S$0.020 per share, a 13.04% discount from the volume-weighted average price. The proceeds will primarily fund the Capital City Project and partial loan repayments, with the remainder used as working capital. Yuan will hold a 28.11% stake, while Chng will hold 4.84%.

site_title: Jardine C&C appoints new group managing director
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) has appointed Benjamin Birks as its new group managing director, replacing Alex Newbigging who is stepping down after seven years. Birks, 45, previously served as CEO of Jardine International Motors (JIM) and will also oversee Jardine Strategic's investment in Zhongsheng Group. Newbigging will become CEO of JIM on October 1 and will relinquish his role on September 30.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise; Samsung, SK Hynix climb on hopes of chip output cuts
summary: South Korean shares rose on Wednesday, led by gains in Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, as the two companies planned to cut production of NAND chips amid a supply glut and Japan curbs. The KOSPI index closed 0.33% higher at 2,058.78, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix shares up 1% and 4.44%, respectively. This marks the KOSPI's 0.87% gain this year and a 0.4% gain in the previous 30 trading sessions.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI closed 6.75 points, or 0.33 per cent, higher at 2,058.78.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall ahead of Powell testimony
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.15-0.23% on Wednesday, July 10, 2019, ahead of US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's testimony. The Nikkei 225 index lost 31.67 points, and the Topix index lost 3.57 points, as investors took a wait-and-see approach. Market expectations have shifted to a smaller interest rate cut than initially expected, with some analysts predicting no rate cut at all. The Tokyo market was influenced by weak New York shares and slight weakness in Chinese shares.

site_title: Businesses can find part-time staff 'in three hours' with employment agency's app
summary: An employment agency has updated its app to connect businesses with part-time staff in just three hours. The app uses QR code technology, allowing employers to quickly scan a code to alert the agency to their staffing needs, and then connect them to a suitable worker from its database of 98,000 part-timers. This streamlined process is particularly helpful for the food and beverage industry, where businesses often struggle with staff shortages. The agency's part-time staff undergo stringent face-to-face interviews and in-house training, with all costs borne by the agency.

site_title: Federal Reserve chief likely to focus on trade-inspired policy shift in testimony
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to testify that the Fed is likely to cut interest rates at its July 30-31 policy meeting due to the market's strong expectations of action following US President Donald Trump's tweets about imposing tariffs on Mexico. The Fed's decision is a first policy shift triggered by tweets, marking a significant change in monetary policy. Investors have high expectations of a rate reduction, with the probability of a cut at close to 100%.

site_title: Top Thai business groups slash 2019 GDP forecast, urge a rate cut
summary: Thailand's top business groups have slashed their 2019 economic growth forecast to 2.9-3.3%, citing a strengthening baht and softening global demand. They urge the central bank to cut interest rates to slow the baht's gains. The groups expect exports to rise or fall 1% this year, down from the previous 3-5% estimate. They also ask for government measures to contain the baht's gains. The Bank of Thailand has left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1.75% and next reviews policy on August 7.

site_title: Singapore firms not doing enough to upskill workers: Skillsoft poll
summary: Singapore workers feel under-skilled and lack opportunities for upskilling, according to a survey of 750 workers. Most employees believe their employers are not supporting them enough to meet future job requirements. Companies are instead focusing on hiring external talent to fill new roles. The survey highlights the need for organizations to invest in upskilling their current employees to remain competitive in the job market.

site_title: 3 Singaporeans jailed for 'front-running' in landmark insider trading case
summary: Three Singaporean men, Leong Chee Wai, Toh Chew Leong, and Simon E Seck Peng, were jailed for terms ranging from 20 months to three years for their roles in an insider trading scheme known as "front-running". They used advance information to profit from share orders, with gains totaling over S$2 million each. The case marked the first prosecution of front-running as an insider trading offence, with the court citing the need for deterrence to maintain the integrity of the trading system.

site_title: Sembcorp injects 516.9 crore rupees to raise stake in India energy business
summary: Sembcorp Industries has invested 516.9 crore rupees (around $101.6 million) in its Indian energy arm, Sembcorp Energy India Limited, raising its stake to 94.05% from 93.73%. The investment, through subsidiary Sembcorp Utilities, supports the growth of its India renewable energy business, which has a wind and solar power portfolio of over 1,700 megawatts. The transaction is expected to have a minimal impact on the company's earnings and net asset value per share for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2019.

site_title: Cordlife share price climbs 16.5%, prompting another SGX query
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) flagged "unusual price movements" in Cordlife Group's shares, which climbed 16.51% to S$0.60, prompting a query. The query seeks an explanation for the trading activity and compliance with listing rules. This is the second SGX query issued to Cordlife in three months, following a 20% surge in shares on May 3. Cordlife has announced a conditional proposal to merge with Global Cord Blood Corporation and has made changes to its remuneration committee and non-executive director.

site_title: JustCo's Manulife Centre co-working space to open in Q4 2019
summary: JustCo, a co-working space provider, will open its location at Manulife Centre in Singapore's Bras Basah district in the fourth quarter of 2019. The space will occupy over 50,000 sq ft and house more than 1,000 members, bringing JustCo's portfolio to 33 centres across eight Asian cities. The company, which is jointly investing US$177 million in co-working space development across Asia, expects to have over 50 centre locations spanning more than two million sq ft by the end of 2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares supported by central bank rate cut hopes
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.4% as investors anticipated a potential interest rate cut by the central bank to boost weak demand. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,689.80. Financials, particularly the "Big Four" banks, also gained after S&P upgraded their outlook. Meanwhile, data showed consumers turned gloomy, highlighting further economic strain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Wednesday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with slight gains on Wednesday, following two days of losses, as investors await key congressional testimony from Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.46% to 28,245.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.24% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.28%.

site_title: Singapore's buildings sector to grow 3.2% this year but downside risks aplenty: Fitch
summary: Singapore's buildings sector is expected to grow 3.2% in 2019, driven by a strong pipeline of planned projects, particularly in residential buildings, which are forecast to grow 3.2% and 1.5% in 2019 and 2020, respectively. However, Fitch warns of downside risks, including uncertainty over US-China trade tensions, a recession, and property cooling measures, which may slow down demand for residential buildings and non-residential sectors.

site_title: Speedoc to offer Singapore's first ambulance-booking app
summary: Speedoc has partnered with Comfort Ambulance & Services Pte Ltd to offer Singapore's first ambulance-booking app. The updated Speedoc app allows users to book private ambulances for transport to healthcare institutions, including hospitals, nursing homes, and hospices. Charges vary based on timing, location, and day, and additional services such as oxygen therapy and stretchers are listed clearly. The move aims to reduce waiting times and provide more efficient access to private ambulances, particularly for non-emergency cases that require prompt medical attention.

site_title: Scale-up SG to groom promising Singapore firms to be world powerhouses
summary: Enterprise Singapore launched the Scale-up SG programme to groom 25 local companies into future global powerhouses. The 2.5-year programme aims to help high-growth companies scale rapidly and expand abroad. Participating companies, including Jumbo Group and PBA Group, will benefit from peer learning, leadership development, and access to expertise and networks. The programme is the first of its kind, aiming to build a community that contributes to a stronger economy and fosters growth among its members.

site_title: Iswaran calls on SMEs in domestic sector to get help going digital
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran urged small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the domestic sector, particularly in food and beverage and retail, to adopt digital solutions to bridge the gap in digital adoption. The SMEs Go Digital scheme, launched under Budget 2017, has added 6,000 new SMEs in the past six months, with the Start Digital initiative playing a key role in its recent growth. Iswaran emphasized the importance of targeted digital transformation for SMEs, regardless of sector or education background, to stay competitive in the global economy.

site_title: US wants coalition to protect strategic Gulf waters: general
summary: The US aims to form a coalition to protect strategic Gulf waters amid heightened tensions with Iran, where nearly a third of the world's oil is transported. General Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the US would provide maritime domain awareness and surveillance, while nations would escort ships carrying their flags. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo hopes over 20 countries, including the UAE and Saudi Arabia, will participate in building maritime security, with the US not bearing the cost. The initiative aims to ensure freedom of navigation in the Straits of Hormuz and the Bab al-Mandab.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as Federal Reserve's Powell takes centre stage
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by expectations of a dovish stance from the Federal Reserve, led by Jerome Powell, amid concerns over the US economy. Powell's congressional testimony will be closely watched for insights into interest rate plans. Despite data showing a stronger-than-expected US jobs market, analysts expect a 25-basis-point rate cut at the Fed's next meeting. Oil prices surged after a report showed a significant drop in US stockpiles, providing a boost to commodity prices.

site_title: Mahathir weighs proposals to buy or manage Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the government is studying proposals to buy or manage Malaysia Airlines Bhd, following a strategic plan to turn around the troubled airline. The proposals, mostly from local companies, aim to find an experienced partner to help the airline recover. The carrier faces the possibility of being shut down, but Mahathir wants to keep "Malaysia" in its name while avoiding layoffs. The government will consider the proposals to find a solution to save the airline.

site_title: Australian consumer confidence tumbles to 2-year low
summary: Australian consumer confidence plummeted to a two-year low in July, falling 4.1% from June and 9% from last year, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. Despite two interest rate cuts and tax rebates, concerns about the economy's outlook and family finances outweighed near-term support. The survey's measure of economic conditions and family finances also fell, with expectations for the next 12 months and five years dropping sharply. The only positive note was a rise in the index of whether it's a good time to buy a major household item.

site_title: Bank of Japan's focus on yen made Japan Inc complacent, says Abenomics critic
summary: A former state banker, Akira Kondoh, criticizes Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies, stating that the Bank of Japan's focus on keeping the yen weak has made Japanese executives complacent and hurt corporate competitiveness. Despite boosting stock prices, Abenomics has failed to deliver on corporate reforms and deregulation, according to Kondoh. He argues that the policies have made life "too comfortable" for business executives, allowing low-productivity companies to stay afloat, and that the BOJ should not allow yen moves to guide policy.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb, financials lead as Powell remarks eyed; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,705.5, driven by financials and energy stocks, with the "Big Four" banks gaining 0.8-0.9% and oil prices jumping 1%. The S&P/ASX 200 index was boosted by an upgrade to its outlook to "stable" from "negative" by S&P Global Rating. Energy stocks, including Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search, also advanced. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8%, its sharpest gain in three weeks.

site_title: Go-Jek snags investment from Thailand's largest lender
summary: Go-Jek, a ride-hailing giant, has secured an investment from Siam Commercial Bank, Thailand's largest lender. The exact amount is unclear, but the partnership aims to bolster Go-Jek's financial services and Siam Commercial's online growth. This is part of Go-Jek's ongoing series-F round, which has already raised over $1 billion. The move is part of Southeast Asia's trend of banks partnering with tech firms to offer financial services.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Wee Hur, Debao Property, SIIC Environment
summary: Singapore stocks experienced new developments on Wednesday, including SATS divesting its 51% stake in FASSCO for S$1.02 million, Mapletree Industrial Trust planning a S$263 million redevelopment project, and Wee Hur securing a S$39 million construction project. Debao Property Development's AGM and fiscal 2018 financial statements application was rejected by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority. SIIC Environment Holdings signed an agreement with the Weifang City Administrative Bureau in China, covering concession rights on the resumption and upgrade of a wastewater treatment plant project.

site_title: Singapore pushes for mediation role as trade war breeds disputes
summary: Singapore aims to position itself as a hub for business mediation to resolve commercial conflicts amid a US-China trade war. The city-state is set to sign the Singapore Convention on Mediation, with over 10 countries expected to sign on August 7. Law Minister K. Shanmugam believes mediation can be an alternative to litigation or arbitration, particularly for companies affected by the trade tensions. Singapore's reputation as a top arbitration destination in Asia and its judicial system make it an attractive option for mediation, with the city-state expecting significant economic value from its aspirations to be a mediation hub.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of Federal Reserve events
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on July 10, 2019, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's US congressional testimony. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.34% to 21,491.21, while the Topix index dropped 0.60% to 1,565.51. Investors took a cautious stance ahead of the key event, which is expected to shape the US monetary policy landscape.

site_title: Walmart got a US$10b surprise after buying Flipkart
summary: Walmart, the parent company of Flipkart, has received a surprise boost from its digital payments subsidiary PhonePe, which is valued at up to $10 billion. PhonePe, founded in 2015, has grown into one of India's leading digital payments companies, with over 290 million transactions in June. The company is now exploring a $1 billion funding round, which could become independent with a distinct investor base. This unexpected success is a result of the Indian government's demonetization move, which led to a surge in digital transactions, and cheap smartphones and data plans.

site_title: China factory price inflation slips as trade war pressure grows
summary: China's factory prices remained unchanged in June from a year ago, marking the weakest reading since August 2016, amid a slowdown in demand due to the US trade war. The producer price index (PPI) fell short of expectations, indicating potential deflation. Consumer prices, however, rose 2.7% due to increased food prices, largely driven by the African swine fever epidemic and severe weather. The trade war's impact on China's economy continues to grow, with policymakers facing pressure to address slowing growth.

site_title: SATS divests stake in healthcare-food business for S$1m
summary: SATS divested its 51% stake in FASSCO, a healthcare-food business, to Planet Foods for S$1.02 million. FASSCO, a joint venture, will no longer be a subsidiary of SATS Investment following the divestment. The deal focuses on healthcare food and nutrition, remote site catering, and integrated facilities management, primarily based in the UAE.

site_title: OUE C-Reit, H-Trust merger deal 'fair' and 'based on normal commercial terms': IFAs
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (C-Reit) and OUE Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) are set to merge in a deal valued at S$1.49 billion. Under the proposal, OUE C-Reit will acquire OUE H-Trust, offering S$0.04075 in cash plus 1.3583 new OUE C-Reit units for every OUE H-Trust stapled security. The merger is deemed "fair" and "based on normal commercial terms" by independent financial advisers. The merged entity will have seven properties and be one of Singapore's largest Reits.

site_title: Pinterest eyes Asia-Pacific growth with Singapore office launch
summary: Pinterest has launched an office in Singapore to serve South-east Asia and India, as part of its expansion in Asia-Pacific. The office, headed by Ayumi Nakajima, aims to build localised experiences for users and hire more employees in marketing and creator roles. This move follows Pinterest's debut on the New York Stock Exchange and comes as the company sees a 50% rise in users in Asia-Pacific over the past year. Pinterest plans to offer a more relevant experience for its users in the region, connecting them with engaged users when considering purchases.

site_title: Fortress Minerals posts 37% rise in Q1 profit to US$1.1m
summary: Fortress Minerals Limited reported a 37% increase in Q1 profit to US$1.1 million, with earnings per share rising to 0.23 US cents. Revenue reached US$5.8 million, primarily generated from Malaysia steel mills. The company attributed its success to iron ore prices reaching a five-year high due to supply disruptions in major producing countries. Despite generating revenue from Malaysia, China remains Fortress Minerals' primary market, with demand for its high-grade iron ore concentrate expected to remain healthy in the short to medium term.

site_title: Trump threatens veto of House defence bill over spending levels, wall
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration threatened to veto a $733 billion defence bill due to spending levels and policy provisions. The bill, which the House is set to vote on, is $17 billion less than Trump's requested budget. The administration objects to provisions related to border wall construction, nuclear weapons, and restrictions on military detentions. A compromise bill must be passed by both chambers before being sent to Trump for signature or veto. Trump's veto threat may be met with resistance from Republicans and some liberal Democrats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.12 points to 1,682.99. The index saw 92 gainers for every 45 losers, with total volume reaching 55.62 million lots worth RM36.13 million.

site_title: Lady Gaga to launch beauty line on Amazon as retailer targets cosmetics business
summary: Lady Gaga is launching a beauty line, Haus Laboratories, exclusively on Amazon in September for 9 countries, including the US, Germany, and Japan. This move boosts Amazon's cosmetics business, competing with traditional sellers like Ulta Beauty and Sephora's Rihanna-backed brand. Lady Gaga chose Amazon due to its commitment to self-acceptance, stating she won't compromise her values for a partnership. This marks Amazon's push into cosmetics, including a private label skin care brand called Belei.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.53% to 3,347.09
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.53% to 3,347.09 on Wednesday, driven by a 17.63-point gain in the Straits Times Index. Trading volume was 62.6 million shares worth S$88.1 million, with 100 gainers for every 35 losers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: Tax returns show Biden income spiked after leaving office
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's tax returns show he made over $15 million in the two years after leaving the vice presidency, making him the wealthiest major candidate to challenge President Donald Trump. Biden's income spiked to $11 million in 2017, largely from book payments and speaking engagements. This contrasts with Trump, who refused to release his tax returns during his 2016 campaign. Other major Democratic candidates, such as Bernie Sanders and Kamala Harris, listed lower incomes in their tax returns.

site_title: US diplomat gets 40 months in jail over Chinese agent ties
summary: A US diplomat, Candace Marie Claiborne, was sentenced to 40 months in prison for lying to investigators about receiving money from Chinese intelligence agents in exchange for classified US documents. Claiborne, 63, also faces a $40,000 fine. She pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the US and had previously been involved with two Chinese agents in 2007. This case is part of several high-profile cases involving Beijing spies recruiting US officials with access to classified intelligence.

site_title: Binance launches crypto-to-SGD platform, partners 2 Vertex funds in Asia
summary: Binance has launched Binance Singapore, a crypto-to-SGD platform, in partnership with Vertex Ventures China and Vertex Ventures South-east Asia and India. The platform, which soft-launched in April, offers round-the-clock Singapore-dollar deposit and withdrawal functionality. The partnership aims to "grow the Singapore blockchain ecosystem" and follows an undisclosed investment by Vertex Ventures in Binance last year. This move is part of Binance's efforts to expand its presence in Asia and tap into the region's growing demand for cryptocurrency services.

site_title: 'Stranger Things' breaks Netflix viewing records
summary: "Stranger Things" breaks Netflix viewing records with its third season, with 40.7 million accounts watching in its first four days and 18.2 million finishing the entire season. This surpasses previous records set by the film "Bird Box" in December, with some analysts expressing skepticism over the viewing figures due to a lack of independent verification. The record-breaking season marks a significant achievement for Netflix, which faces increasing pressure from deep-pocketed rivals in the streaming market.

site_title: HBO Max set for 2020 streaming launch, nabs 'Friends' from Netflix
summary: WarnerMedia is set to launch its new streaming service, HBO Max, in early 2020, featuring a vast library of shows and films, including all 236 episodes of the popular sitcom "Friends," which was previously licensed to Netflix. The service will compete with existing streaming platforms like Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon. HBO Max will offer 10,000 hours of premium content and will debut with exclusive streaming rights to shows like "The Fresh Prince of Bel Air" and "Pretty Little Liars." Pricing has not been announced.

site_title: China demands US cancel arms sale to Taiwan
summary: China has demanded the US cancel a potential $2.2 billion arms sale to Taiwan, including battle tanks and anti-aircraft missiles, citing the "one-China principle" and interference in its internal affairs. The US has shrugged off China's complaints, stating the equipment will contribute to peace and stability in Asia. The sale, which includes 108 M1A2T Abrams tanks and 250 Stinger missiles, is the first major US military gear transfer to Taiwan in decades and has raised tensions between the two powers.

site_title: Brazil court convicts miner Vale for damages caused by deadly dam rupture
summary: A Brazilian state judge convicted mining company Vale SA for damages caused by the deadly rupture of a tailings dam in January that killed at least 240 people. The court ruled that Vale is responsible for fixing all damages, but did not set a monetary value for compensation. The 11 billion reais in Vale assets already frozen will remain blocked. Vale has committed to fair and quick reparations for damages, including environmental and economic effects.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to start its largest redevelopment project costing S$263m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) plans to redevelop a 346,270 sq ft flatted-factory cluster at Kallang Way into a high-tech industrial precinct worth S$263 million. The project will feature a build-to-suit facility for a German medical device company, with a 15-year lease commitment and annual rental escalations. Construction is expected to start in 2020 and complete in 2022, with the redevelopment increasing the utilised plot ratio and total GFA. The project aims to position the cluster as a high-tech industrial precinct and provide stable income for MIT.

site_title: US-China trade talks resume: US officials
summary: US officials held a phone call with Chinese counterparts to discuss the ongoing trade conflict, the first official contact since President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping agreed to resume talks. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer spoke with Vice Premier Liu He and Minister Zhong Shan to continue negotiations on resolving outstanding trade disputes. The talks aim to end the year-long trade war, but US-China tariffs remain in place, covering over $360 billion in two-way trade.

site_title: Boeing falls behind Airbus in deliveries as 737 Max crisis bites
summary: Airbus is on track to overtake Boeing as the world's largest aircraft maker in 2019, with 389 deliveries through mid-year compared to Boeing's 239, a 37% decline from the same period last year. The 737 Max crisis, following two fatal crashes, has significantly impacted Boeing's deliveries, with no new orders reported in June. Analysts expect Boeing to recover, but deliveries are closely tied to company revenues and stock performance, with shares rising 0.6% after the news. Airbus may replace Boeing as the largest aircraft maker if delivery numbers hold.

site_title: Senior models bridge South Korea's age divide
summary: A growing number of senior models in South Korea are bridging the age divide between generations, with models like 75-year-old Choi Soon Hwa becoming social media and fashion celebrities. Choi, who was forced to work 20 hours a day at a hospital, now walks the runway at Seoul Fashion Week, inspiring a new trend of age diversity in the fashion industry. This movement reflects a growing need for intergenerational connection in a country where the population is aging and social divisions are increasing.

site_title: Sister of Saudi crown prince tried in France over 'beaten workman'
summary: A French court began trial of Hassa bint Salman, sister of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, over allegations of ordering a bodyguard to beat a workman who took a photo inside her Paris apartment in 2016. Hassa denies the allegations and is charged with complicity in armed violence, theft, and holding someone against their will. The workman, Ashraf Eid, claims he was tied up and beaten, with the princess allegedly shouting for his death. The trial follows a separate case by the bodyguard against Eid for defamation.

site_title: Singapore Reits seen as too expensive after 18% surge this year
summary: Singapore's Reits have surged 18% this year, but analysts question their valuation, citing a 1.2 times book value ratio, the most expensive in over six years. This rally may be nearing its end, with strategists from Morningstar to CMC Markets predicting a slowdown in the second half. The FTSE Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust Index has closed at its highest since 2007, raising concerns about the market's sustainability.

site_title: West Africa should decide on common currency by 2020: Ivory Coast
summary: Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara urged Western African countries to decide on a common currency by 2020. The idea, first proposed nearly three decades ago, aims to boost cross-border trade and economic development. Eight ECOWAS countries already use the CFA franc, while the remaining seven have their own currencies. Nigeria's skepticism about the benefits of a currency zone is seen as a major obstacle, with analysts predicting the 2020 target date may not be met.

site_title: Europe: German shares drag stocks lower as BASF profit warning bites
summary: German shares dragged European stocks lower on Tuesday after BASF's profit warning due to trade friction, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 0.5% lower. BASF cited a slowdown in global growth weighing on the agricultural and auto sectors, triggering ratings downgrades and losses in peers. Mining stocks fell 2% and banks, including Deutsche Bank, also suffered losses. However, defensive sectors like real estate and Ocado rose, and investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments for clues on a potential rate cut.

site_title: Johnson refuses to say if he would quit if UK still in EU after Oct 31
summary: Boris Johnson, the UK's favourite to become prime minister, refused to say if he would quit if the UK doesn't leave the EU by October 31, the current Brexit deadline. Johnson stated that envisioning a failure to meet the deadline could encourage the EU to encourage his resignation. This came during a head-to-head TV debate with rival Jeremy Hunt, where Johnson emphasized the importance of delivering Brexit on time.

site_title: IBM closes US$34b deal to buy Red Hat to boost cloud business
summary: IBM has completed its $34 billion acquisition of Red Hat, a software company specializing in Linux operating systems. The deal is aimed at boosting IBM's cloud computing business. Red Hat CEO Jim Whitehurst will remain in place and report to IBM CEO Ginni Rometty. The combined firm will offer a hybrid multicloud platform and maintain Red Hat's headquarters in Raleigh, North Carolina. The acquisition is expected to contribute approximately two points of compound annual revenue growth over a five-year period, with IBM's cloud revenue growing sixfold since 2013.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Feature - review of the Mazda 6
summary: Claressa Monteiro reviews the Mazda 6 in a 6:17-minute podcast. She shares her experience driving the award-winning ride over several days, providing an in-depth review of its features and performance. The Mazda 6 is praised for its handling and overall driving experience. The review offers a personal perspective, giving listeners a sense of the car's capabilities and suitability for various drivers.

site_title: Japan, South Korea raise stakes in dispute over forced labour
summary: Japan and South Korea escalated their dispute over forced labor, with Japan tightening curbs on exports of three materials crucial for advanced electronics, potentially disrupting global supplies of smartphones and chips. South Korea denounced Japanese reports of a sensitive chemical being transferred to North Korea, and the two nations are set to hold talks on Friday. The dispute is rooted in compensation demanded by Seoul for South Koreans forced to work for Japanese firms during WWII, with Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government using the issue as leverage ahead of a parliamentary election.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Datapulse Technology will acquire a 5% stake in Bay Hotel Singapore for approximately S$12.1 million. The acquisition is part of a consortium led by Datapulse's subsidiary, Datapulse Investment Pte Ltd, which purchased the hotel from Fiesta Development Pte Ltd and Bay Hotel & Resort Pte Ltd for S$235 million. The deal is part of a larger hotel acquisition by Datapulse Technology.

site_title: Europe urges Iran to stick to troubled nuclear deal
summary: European powers, including France, Germany, and Britain, have urged Iran to reverse its move to increase uranium enrichment, calling on Tehran to act accordingly by reversing breaches of the landmark 2015 nuclear deal. The move comes as tensions rise between Iran and the West, with the US imposing sanctions on Iran's banking and oil sectors after withdrawing from the deal in 2018. Iran has lost patience with perceived inaction by European countries, with President Hassan Rouhani announcing a plan to roll back commitments under the deal in stages every 60 days.

site_title: BlackRock cutting equity risk, raising cash
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, is reducing its equity exposure and increasing cash reserves ahead of the third quarter due to trade and geopolitical tensions. The company's Investment Institute cited these factors as the primary drivers of the global economy and markets. This shift in strategy reflects BlackRock's more defensive stance, as it seeks to navigate the uncertain economic landscape.

site_title: Geely's profit warning seen as bad omen for other China carmakers
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd, controlled by Volvo Cars owner Li Shufu, issued a profit warning, citing a 40% drop in first-half profit due to a decline in Chinese sales. This triggered a decline in shares of Geely and other Chinese automakers, including Great Wall Motor Co, Guangzhou Automobile Group Co, and Dongfeng Motor Group Co. Analysts warn that this could signal further pain across the sector, as the industry struggles with a stalling market and trade tensions.

site_title: PropertyGuru appoints Tan Tee Khoon as Singapore country manager
summary: PropertyGuru appoints Dr. Tan Tee Khoon as Singapore country manager, replacing Jeremy Williams. Dr. Tan, a former executive at Knight Frank, will lead sales and oversee a team of 50. He cited the power of data-driven decision making and PropertyGuru's focus on technology adoption as reasons for his appointment. Dr. Tan's departure from Knight Frank follows a wave of departures by other key executives, including Alice Tan and Edison Ong.

images.alt_text: Dr Tan believes in the power of data-driven decision making, as data is the currency for success in property.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed ahead of Powell testimony
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Tuesday ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's congressional appearance, awaiting clues on an interest rate cut. Despite futures markets expecting a cut later this month, some analysts suggest the Fed could make no changes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.1% and 0.5%, respectively. The mixed market reaction was partly due to the muted reaction to PepsiCo's earnings report, which beat analyst expectations. The Fed's testimony will provide insight into the likelihood of a rate cut.

site_title: Privatisation of SIAEC is more a possibility than probability
summary: Singapore Airlines' subsidiary SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) saw its share price surge after speculation of a potential privatisation bid by SIA. Analysts believe SIAEC could be delisted due to its cash-rich position and low trading liquidity, with some estimating a potential offer price of S$3.01 per share. However, SIA may not pursue a privatisation due to its stretched balance sheet and concerns that full ownership would have minimal earnings accretion. Instead, SIA may focus on conserving cash to combat headwinds in its operations, including downward yield pressure and climbing oil prices.

site_title: Lower volatility is not the same as lower risk
summary: A current asset price cycle is characterized by fear-driven risk aversion, prioritizing capital preservation over capital gains. Investors seek stable, predictable returns, often at the expense of higher returns. This has led to a reevaluation of asset classes, with some becoming overpriced due to their perceived low volatility. Emerging markets, value stocks, and fixed income in China and Asia are seen as attractive options, despite their higher uncertainty premiums. As the current cycle may be nearing its end, embracing areas with lumpy returns and taking a long-term view could be rewarded.

site_title: The quants are back in their billions
summary: Hedge funds, investment banks, and sovereign wealth funds are actively searching for the next big thing in fixed income, following the advice of quant investor Patrick Houweling's 2014 paper on factor investing. This trend is driven by the growing demand for dollar asset diversification, particularly in Asia. Experts expect retail investors to drive significant growth in exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the region, while markets continue to rise due to various factors, including productivity gains and shifting safe havens.

site_title: Temasek's one-year return tumbles amid softer regional markets
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of 1.49% for the 12 months ended March 31, 2019, down from 12.2% in the previous year. The lower return is attributed to weaker global growth and increased competition for investments. Despite this, Temasek expects its portfolio to outperform the global equity portfolio over the next 20 years. The decline in TSR is part of a "lower for longer" market trend.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings on Tuesday reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of 1.49 per cent for the 12 months ended March 31, 2019.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain "Buy" ratings for Fu Yu Corp and Koufu Group, citing positive growth momentum and expansion plans. Fu Yu Corp is expected to benefit from a stronger US dollar and cost optimization efforts. Koufu Group's joint venture in Indonesia is seen as a key growth driver, with potential to contribute 1-2% to earnings in FY2020. Both companies face risks including economic slowdowns and competition.

site_title: Novena Global goes beyond aesthetics services in merger with China hairdressing firm
summary: Novena Global, a Singapore-based aesthetics chain, merges with China's Xingkeduo in a deal worth US$350 million. The combined entity will offer hairdressing services in China's first- and second-tier cities, leveraging Xingkeduo's technology and e-commerce platform. The merger aims to tap China's market and resources, providing affordable and convenient services to customers. The merged entity will offer customized aesthetic and hairdressing solutions using artificial intelligence, with cross-selling opportunities between brands.

images.alt_text: One of Xingkeduo's outlets in Pudong New District in Shanghai. The four-year-old company also sells its products and services online.

site_title: China's new tech trading board is about to have its busiest day yet
summary: China's new tech trading board is expected to see its busiest day yet, with subscriptions for nine firms opening on Wednesday, surpassing the highest number since June 2015. The first batch of 25 companies will begin trading on July 22, eight months after its launch. Regulators are speeding up initial public offerings (IPOs) to attract top Chinese companies, hoping to boost the board's appeal. The move is part of the government's efforts to promote entrepreneurship and economic growth.

site_title: Monaco rolls out Huawei-built 5G network in European first
summary: Monaco has become the first European country to launch a 5G network built by Huawei, a technology firm seen as a security risk by the US. The 5G network, which offers faster data transfer speeds, is part of a shift away from slower 3G and 4G networks in Europe. This move comes as mobile operators consider their approach to Huawei, a pioneer in 5G technology. The launch marks a significant step forward for 5G adoption in Europe, despite ongoing debates about the firm's security credentials.

site_title: Ex-fisherman finds profit in running whale-watching tours in Hokkaido
summary: MASATO Hasegawa, a 57-year-old ex-fisherman, has found success running whale-watching tours in Hokkaido, Japan, shifting the struggling town of Rausu from fishing to tourism. Despite initial struggles, Hasegawa's business has flourished, attracting nearly 33,500 visitors in 2018 and earning him a steady income. He now has a waiting list and a new boat, and is optimistic about the future, citing the steady job and lifestyle as a better option than fishing, which has declined in the area.

site_title: Dyson owner forks out S$73.8m for Singapore's costliest penthouse
summary: Sir James Dyson, founder of Dyson, and his wife Deirdre, have purchased Singapore's most expensive condo, the triplex super penthouse at Wallich Residence, for S$73.8 million. The 21,108 sq ft unit, which includes a private pool and panoramic views, was previously valued at S$108 million. The deal marks the highest price for a penthouse in Singapore, surpassing the S$60 million paid by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin in 2017. The purchase is seen as a strategic move by Dyson, following the company's decision to relocate its corporate headquarters to Singapore to "future-proof" its business.

site_title: Temasek does not see merger of subsidiaries to sniff down deals
summary: Temasek Holdings' CEO Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara stated that the state investor will not consider consolidating its subsidiaries to address the competitive environment, instead focusing on adding value to these companies. This decision comes as yield-hungry investors continue to look for deals. Sandrasegara emphasized that long-term sustainable trajectories are more important than consolidation, and Temasek International's leadership transition has resulted in a shift in oversight, with Ho Ching focusing on stewardship aspects and new chairman Lee Theng Kiat taking over.

site_title: Euro slides as investors reassess extent of Fed rate cut
summary: The euro fell to a three-week low against the US dollar, dipping below $1.12, as investors reassessed the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cut. The euro's decline was fueled by concerns over the European Central Bank's (ECB) potential easing of monetary policy, following the nomination of Christine Lagarde as the new ECB head. The dollar index rose 0.2% to a three-week high, while expectations of a 50-basis-point Fed cut have fallen to 4.9%.

site_title: Long-term view allows Temasek to be patient with poor performers
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore-based investment firm, remains patient with its investments despite poor performers. The firm's long-term approach allows it to weather market fluctuations, as seen in its investment in Bayer, a German life science giant that has fallen 39% since 2018. Temasek's CEO Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara stated that the company's long-term thesis remains true, and its confidence level is high. The firm also expressed confidence in its unlisted portfolio companies, including rig builders and PSA, which can adapt to changing market conditions and find value in their engineering capabilities.

site_title: Sterling falls towards 2-year lows as economic outlook worsens
summary: The British pound fell to 2-year lows against the dollar, weakening to a 6-month low of 89.95 pence against the euro. Fears of a no-deal Brexit and a worsening economic outlook led to a decline in the pound, prompting the Bank of England to consider a rate cut. Markets are pricing in a 95% chance of eurosceptic Boris Johnson becoming the next UK leader, which could push the pound further down. The pound has lost for 10 consecutive weeks against the euro and is expected to contract in the second quarter.

site_title: Look beyond FAANGs for fresh investment opportunities
summary: Investors are urged to look beyond the well-known "FAANG" tech companies, such as Facebook and Google, for fresh investment opportunities. Instead, focus on digitally-minded businesses that have integrated new technology and challenged the status quo. Companies in emerging 5G technology, such as chip manufacturers and wireless communications infrastructure providers, are seen as promising opportunities. Additionally, businesses providing secure enterprise cloud solutions and those connected to the Internet of Things may also benefit from the increased bandwidth and lower latency offered by 5G.

site_title: Strategies for financial firms amid disruption
summary: Financial firms must adapt to disruption by focusing on the customer. Embracing ecosystem platforms, where banks and insurers collaborate with other companies, is key to retaining the customer relationship. Asia, particularly China, Singapore, and Indonesia, lead in this area, with super-apps offering diverse services. Consumers want integrated services and products, and firms must invest in technology infrastructure, customer analytics, and organizational models to succeed. By doing so, financial firms can remain relevant and competitive in the digital era.

site_title: Higher wages, spiffy outfits fail to shift locals' mindset against F&B, retail jobs
summary: Employers in Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) and retail sectors have offered various incentives, including higher wages, medical insurance, and designer uniforms, to attract local workers amid declining interest. Despite a 24% year-on-year increase in overall local applicants, the proportion of local applicants for F&B and retail openings has shrunk. Employers attribute the lack of interest to factors such as job scope, brand image, and the social nature of F&B and retail positions, with some employees citing stress and loneliness as reasons for quitting.

site_title: SGX invests in Smartkarma to advance investment research on Singapore-listed firms
summary: SGX invests $7-figure sum in Smartkarma, a digital global investment research network, to advance investment research on Singapore-listed firms. The investment provides listed companies with a direct touchpoint with investors and access to Smartkarma's network. This move aims to bolster the financial research ecosystem and follows SGX's existing initiatives, such as the StockFacts Research Programme. The tie-up may yield an attractive return for SGX, as it invests in new models to serve investors and companies, and comes at a time when research houses are trimming staff.

site_title: Chairman's arrest a mystery to Camsing Healthcare's board
summary: Camsing Healthcare's board expressed uncertainty over the reasons behind the arrest of its chairman and executive director Lo Ching in China. The arrest led to a 90% plunge in Camsing International's Hong Kong-listed shares on Monday and a further 27% drop on Tuesday. Despite the chairman's arrest, the board stated that normal business operations and functions remain stable and unaffected.

site_title: Salvors remain busy but revenues disappoint
summary: The International Salvage Union (ISU) has released its annual statistics, showing a mixed picture for the salvage industry. Despite fewer mishaps, revenues dropped to US$409 million in 2018, down from US$456 million in 2017. ISU president Charo Coll attributes the decline to economic pressures and competition, but highlights the industry's value in preventing loss, protecting the environment, and supporting global trade. Salvage operations, including Lloyd's Open Form cases and wreck removal, remain significant sources of income, with 71 operations generating US$208 million in 2018.

site_title: No Facebook, Twitter at Trump's social media summit
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced a "social media summit" at the White House, excluding major social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter. Conservative tech critics and groups, including The Heritage Foundation and Turning Point USA, have confirmed their attendance. The summit aims to discuss the opportunities and challenges of the online environment. Trump has previously accused social media platforms of anti-conservative bias, and the event has raised concerns about potential regulation and censorship.

site_title: Garfield art heads to auction
summary: A series of auctions featuring artwork from the Garfield comic strip will take place at Heritage Auctions, starting on July 9, 2019. The collection, known as "The Jim Davis Collection," includes individual strips, sequences, and artwork from US Acres. The auctions are a result of the downsizing of the headquarters of Paws, the company founded by Jim Davis in 1981 to oversee Garfield licensing. Garfield is the most widely syndicated feature in the world, generating over 20 million page views annually, and Davis has stated that he hopes his legacy and that of Garfield will be to brighten people's days through entertainment and laughter.

site_title: KinderWorld delays IPO until 'more favourable time'
summary: KinderWorld, a Vietnam-based private-school operator, has delayed its initial public offering (IPO) plans until a more favorable time, citing the current market performance and geo-political climate. The company will evaluate the Singapore capital markets to determine the best timing for the IPO.

site_title: Indian billionaire defends controversial coal mine in Australia
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani defended the Carmichael coal mine in Australia, stating it's a viable investment and the coal meets India's power needs. Adani responded to criticism that the low-quality coal won't generate enough revenue and that the world should abandon coal for renewable energy due to climate change concerns. He argued the project's US$2 billion investment will be profitable and that coal remains a necessary fuel source. Adani's comments come as the mine faces opposition from environmental groups and local communities.

site_title: Helping the entrepreneurship spirit to take flight
summary: Entrepreneurship is a skill that can be learned and nurtured, not just inherited. For those who lack family ties to business, education and research are key to understanding the economic landscape and forming successful companies or start-ups. This approach is exemplified by individuals who study business-related subjects and develop their own entrepreneurial spirit. With the right education and mindset, anyone can cultivate the skills and knowledge needed to succeed in the world of entrepreneurship.

site_title: UOB sees building closer ties with partners in its ecosystem key to customer engagement
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is working to strengthen customer engagement by building closer ties with partners in its ecosystem, such as property agents. Since 2017, the bank has created multiple ecosystems for various sectors, including property, cars, and dining. This move aims to reduce friction and improve the overall experience for consumers.

site_title: A 1.5b-euro bet to rebuild Italy's construction sector
summary: Salini Impregilo plans a 1.5 billion euro construction hub, "Progetto Italia," to rebuild Italy's ailing construction sector. The project will combine assets with several ailing Italian builders, including Astaldi. This move aims to address years of recession and bad investments in the sector. Progetto Italia will create a construction hub to boost Italy's construction industry and revitalize the sector.

site_title: Dyson's Singapore electric dream is all about personal cars
summary: Dyson, the UK-based home appliance maker, plans to enter the electric vehicle market with a focus on personal cars, a segment it believes will see the fastest adoption. The company's CEO, James "Jim" Rowan, stated that the market has a £2 billion price tag and will be driven by consumer uptake and industry trends. Dyson has pledged to have its maiden electric car plant operational in Singapore by 2021, and will raise production at its Jurong motor plant and expand its technology hub. The company faces competition from rival electric automakers, but Rowan emphasized the need to differentiate in the market.

images.alt_text: CEO James Rowan at the "Dyson Demo Store" - which showcases its line of hair-styling appliances - in Funan Centre. He says Dyson's headcount here is set to grow, with a focus on software engineering and digital marketing.

site_title: CapitaLand launches S$500,000 fund to support children of NTUC union members
summary: CapitaLand has launched a S$500,000 fund, CapitaLand-U Care Resilience and Enablement Fund, to support children of low-to-medium income NTUC union members impacted by sudden loss of income. The fund aims to assist about 2,500 children with a monthly household income of less than S$5,800. Each child will receive a one-time disbursement of S$250 in NTUC FairPrice vouchers. The two-year fund, launched on July 5, is a partnership between CapitaLand's philanthropic arm and NTUC to provide a safety net for children in need.

site_title: Japan-Korea spat threatens to upend global technology
summary: A dispute between Japan and South Korea threatens to disrupt the global technology supply chain, particularly for chipmakers like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. Japan has imposed export curbs on three classes of materials, including fluorinated polyimide and hydrogen fluoride, needed for semiconductor production. This move could lead to production cuts or stoppages, affecting devices such as iPhones, laptops, and servers. The dispute has sparked concerns about the impact on the global economy and the potential for a shortage of essential components.

site_title: Predictions, prescriptions for the global intellectual property landscape
summary: US-China economic relations are hindered by intellectual property (IP) theft, digital trade, and data flow regulations. Existing WTO law is inadequate to address these issues, leading individual states to establish their own cyber security laws and regulatory regimes. The US and China have different priorities in safeguarding cyber security, with the US focusing on protecting the market-driven technology sector and China prioritizing control over civil society and restriction of foreign influence. The trade war and its implications on global trade and economic issues reflect a broader shift towards fragmented global governance. A more coordinated approach to regulating the international digital economy is needed, with a focus on building trust in existing global institutional structures and momentum for further reform.

site_title: HK leader says extradition bill is 'dead'
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced the extradition bill is "dead" following its suspension in mid-June, but critics accused her of playing with words. The bill, which would have allowed people to face trial in mainland China's courts, sparked massive protests and has plunged the city into turmoil. Lam stated that the government's work on the bill was a "total failure," but protesters remain skeptical, demanding a complete withdrawal of the bill and calling for Lam's resignation.

site_title: Troubled Transcorp in 'advanced' talks with group of investors
summary: Transcorp Holdings, a Singapore-listed firm, is in advanced talks with a group of investors to potentially stave off going-concern issues. The engagement is at an advanced stage, but no agreement has been executed, and no certainty exists on whether funds will be raised. Transcorp will keep shareholders informed on material developments.

site_title: Cisco to buy Acacia Communications for US$2.8b
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. announced its plan to acquire optical component maker Acacia Communications Inc. for US$2.84 billion in cash, representing a 46% premium to Acacia's closing price. The deal is Cisco's largest acquisition since 2017 and is expected to close in the second half of 2020. Acacia, a Cisco supplier, designs high-speed optical components for telecom service providers and data center operators.

site_title: Why Boris's first 100 days could be 'nail biter'
summary: Boris Johnson's path to becoming UK Prime Minister is uncertain, despite a likely landslide victory in the Conservative leadership race. Johnson's fragile hold on power stems from the Conservative Party's lack of a majority in the House of Commons and the threat of a no-confidence vote from some of his own MPs. If a no-confidence vote is approved, a general election could be triggered, potentially before October 31, the UK's departure date from the EU. Johnson's stance on Brexit is also a point of contention, with hard-line Brexiteers and Remain supporters within his own party creating divisions.

site_title: Airbus to ask airlines to check wings of older A380s for cracks
summary: Airbus will issue a service bulletin to airlines operating 25 of its oldest A380 super-jumbo jets to inspect their wings for cracks after reports of occurrences found in certain parts of the wing. The European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) advises ultrasonic testing on these aircraft, built more than 15 years ago, to address the potential unsafe condition. This is not the first time the A380 has experienced wing-crack issues, following a 2012 debacle that cost Airbus millions in repair and service costs. The directive is considered an interim action, with further inspections possible.

site_title: Supplements aren't necessarily nutritious: study
summary: A new review published in the Annals of Internal Medicine found that nutritional supplements and dietary interventions offer little to no protection against cardiovascular disease or death. While some supplements, such as folic acid and omega-3 fatty acids, showed benefits, others, like calcium plus vitamin D, may even increase the risk of stroke. The review analyzed 277 trials involving nearly one million people, calling for further research on the issue. The industry's growing popularity, with nearly three-quarters of US consumers taking supplements, may be due to marketing tactics and biased data.

site_title: Deutsche Bank cuts leave workers in job limbo
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting 18,000 employees globally as part of its massive reorganization, including an exit from the equities sales and trading business. The move will leave thousands of finance employees in job limbo, facing challenges such as automation and new technology replacing workers. While some former Deutsche Bank employees may find opportunities at family offices or boutique firms, many will struggle to locate their next position, with some potentially having to leave the industry altogether.

site_title: NZ plans discounts for cleaner cars, slaps new fee on gas guzzlers
summary: New Zealand plans to offer discounts of up to NZ$8,000 for electric, hybrid, and fuel-efficient vehicles, and a fee of up to NZ$3,000 for gas-guzzling cars emitting over 250 grams of CO2/km. The scheme, starting in 2021, aims to make greener cars more affordable. However, environmentalists criticized the penalty as too low to deter polluting car purchases. The government also sets annual emissions targets for new vehicles, with a goal of 105g CO2/km by 2025, as part of its commitment to net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: CapitaLand lands another S$300m in sustainability-linked loans
summary: CapitaLand has secured a S$300 million sustainability-linked loan from Societe Generale, Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank, and Natixis Bank for five-year multicurrency loans linked to environmental, social, and governance metrics. This is the property developer's second sustainability-linked loan, following a S$300 million loan secured last October. The loan will be used for "green" projects and general corporate purposes, with interest rates potentially reduced based on CapitaLand's ESG achievements.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices down 0.4% in June: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices fell 0.4% in June, snapping a four-month upward trend, according to SRX Property. The decline was mainly due to a decrease in prices in the core central region, with the city fringes seeing no change. Sales volume dropped 20.5% year-over-year, but overall prices were still up 1.6% compared to June 2018. Experts attribute the decline to fewer luxury homes being sold and slower sales activity during the school holidays.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on trade war fallout concerns
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday due to concerns over the impact of the US-China trade spat on company earnings and interest rate expectations. The Dow Jones fell 0.30%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.35%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.46%. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records earlier in the week. The uncertainty surrounding the trade spat weighed on market sentiment, leading to a lower opening.

site_title: Employment terms for older workers need fine-tuning as people live longer
summary: The Singapore government's Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers is set to finalize recommendations on raising retirement and re-employment ages, as well as CPF contribution rates for workers aged 55 and above. The move comes as Singapore has surpassed Japan in life expectancy, with a person born in 2017 expected to live to 84.8 years. Studies suggest that restoring full CPF contribution rates could increase workers' retirement sums by S$31,000 to S$145,000, benefiting around 21,790 workers. The workgroup is likely to propose incremental changes to address employers' concerns about costs and maintain labor market flexibility.

site_title: An oil behemoth that's worth less than its energy reserves in the ground
summary: PetroChina, China's state-run oil and gas champion, is undervalued, with its shares trading at a 14% decline in Hong Kong this year. Despite a 19% gain in crude prices, analysts see the stock as a "noticeable outlier" among global energy companies, with a consensus of 42% growth over the next year. To unlock its potential, analysts suggest a major jolt, such as a breakup of assets or a management mindset shift, is needed. PetroChina's current market value of $169 billion is also significantly lower than its estimated reserve value of $208.7 billion.

site_title: Deliveroo sets up Asia-Pacific performance hub in Singapore
summary: Deliveroo has established a new Asia-Pacific performance hub in Singapore, its regional headquarters, to drive growth in the region. The hub, which began operations in May, is home to 16 employees and includes a business intelligence unit. Deliveroo operates in four Asia-Pacific markets: Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan. The company aims to expand its presence in the region, with Siddharth Shanker stating that Singapore's attractiveness as a business hub has made it an ideal location for the new unit.

site_title: oCap taps AI, machine learning to offer short-term loans to SMEs
summary: oCap Management has launched a new Merchant Cash Advance (MCA) loan solution for Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), utilizing machine learning and artificial intelligence to assess business performance and cash flow. The short-term loan, targeting firms with at least two years of business, will be fully rolled out this year with interest rates ranging from 1-2.5% per month and repayment terms of 3-12 months. The loan solution aims to provide an attractive financing alternative for SMEs struggling to secure funding, with oCap planning to expand to other countries and partner with online trading platforms.

site_title: Europeans take first step to punish Iran over nuclear pact breaches
summary: European Union foreign ministers from Britain, France, and Germany, along with the EU's foreign affairs chief, have triggered the mechanism to resolve breaches in Iran's 2015 nuclear agreement. The move comes after Iran announced steps violating its central commitments, including amassing more enriched uranium. The three European powers are seeking to address compliance issues and convene a joint commission of signatories, which could eventually lead to a "snapback" of international sanctions lifted by the deal. Iran must reverse its activities and return to full compliance without delay, the European countries said.

site_title: Australia to raise bank capital buffers by less than expected
summary: Australia's main financial regulator, APRA, has decided to lower the capital buffer for banks by less than initially proposed. Instead of raising total capital by 4-5 percentage points of risk-weighted assets by 2024, banks will now need to lift their total capital by three percentage points by January 1, 2024. This change will result in banks needing to raise around A$50 billion in new junior tier-two debt, down from the initially proposed A$75 billion. The decision aims to reduce the risk of unintended market consequences and minimize the impact on borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the country's largest lender, also said the ultimate cost of the changes was unknown and estimated about A$13 billion extra capital was needed to meet requirements.

site_title: White House economic advisor says Fed chief's job is safe
summary: White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow stated that Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's job is safe, contradicting President Trump's frequent attacks on Powell's interest rate decisions. Kudlow said there's no effort to remove Powell, but acknowledged the Fed's independence. Trump has explored replacing Powell with a new official who supports his views, but Kudlow believes the Fed should remain independent.

site_title: Empowering staff drives earnings growth for DHL
summary: DHL's Certified International Specialist (CIS) program, led by top managers, has trained over 100,000 staff to adopt a "can-do" attitude, driving earnings growth for the company. Launched in 2010, CIS focuses on technical skills and soft skills, such as dealing with people, fixing problems, and responding to uncertainties. The program has helped DHL return to profitability and has boosted employee engagement, with leadership scores increasing to above 90%. The company aims to equip its workforce with the skills needed to thrive in a digital world, where automation and technological disruptions are on the rise.

site_title: France to impose green tax on plane tickets
summary: France will impose a tax on plane tickets of up to 18 euros per flight starting from 2020, with the funds used to create less-polluting transport options. The tax will vary depending on the route, class, and airline, with higher taxes for international flights. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions from air travel, which at 285 grams of CO2 per kilometer, exceed all other modes of transport. The tax is expected to generate 180 million euros annually, with exemptions for flights to Corsica and overseas departments.

site_title: Acra rejects Debao's bid to extend deadline for AGM, annual results
summary: Debao Property Development's bid to extend its annual general meeting and fiscal 2018 financial statements deadline was rejected by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). Debao had initially received a 60-day extension but then applied for a further 90-day extension, citing its auditors' completion of the FY2018 financial statements audit by end-August. Acra has turned down the request, and Debao plans to convene its AGM and file its audited financial statements "as soon as possible".

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay bonuses if staff deserve them, Sewing says
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing announced the bank will pay bonuses to staff if their performance warrants it, despite posting its fourth annual loss in five years. Sewing emphasized the bank's commitment to rewarding its best employees to retain them, while also cutting costs to overcome financial challenges. The bank has suspended its dividend for two years to fund a 7.4 billion-euro overhaul.

site_title: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic to launch IPO by end of the year
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) by the end of the year, becoming the first space tourism firm to tap public markets. The company will merge with Social Capital Hedosophia Holdings Corp and raise $1.5 billion in funding. Virgin Galactic has collected $80 million in deposits and $120 million in potential revenue from over 300 customers, including Leonardo DiCaprio and Justin Bieber, who have paid or reserved spots for suborbital flights costing $250,000.

site_title: ABB pays US$470m to offload solar inverter business
summary: ABB to pay US$470 million in charges to sell solar inverter business to FIMER SpA, marking the first big move by new CEO Peter Voser since taking over in April. The business, which generated US$290 million in sales in 2018, had become a drag on ABB's electrification division, leading to a significant after-tax non-operational charge of US$430 million. The deal is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: Trump again attacks India, say tariffs 'unacceptable'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized India for unfairly blocking American imports, calling the tariffs "no longer acceptable." This comes as Washington seeks to resolve its year-long trade battle with China. Trump's comments have heated up trade tensions between the two nations, just as the US is trying to negotiate a trade deal with China.

site_title: Inspections ordered on some Airbus A380s after wing cracks found
summary: European regulators ordered inspections on 25 older Airbus A380s after small cracks were detected in the wings. The cracks, found on the outer rear wing spars, could reduce the structural integrity of the wing if not detected and corrected. Airbus confirmed the issue and designed an inspection and repair scheme, which can be carried out during scheduled maintenance visits. No safety concerns were raised, and the repairs must be completed within 15 years of the initial wing box assembly. Several airlines, including Emirates and Singapore Airlines, are conducting checks on their A380s.

site_title: US billionaire Ross Perot, who shook up 1990s presidential politics, dead at 89
summary: Ross Perot, the billionaire businessman and independent presidential candidate who shook up US politics in the 1990s, has died at 89. Perot, who made a fortune in computer services, ran two presidential campaigns, including a notable independent bid in 1992 that saw him lead a Gallup Poll with 39% of the vote. He also founded the Reform Party and spoke out against the North American Free Trade Agreement. Perot's unconventional style and unapologetic views earned him both praise and criticism, but his legacy as a populist outsider continues to be felt in American politics.

site_title: Job openings in US eased in May for a second month
