summary: US job openings unexpectedly cooled in May for a second month, signaling a pause in demand for workers. The number of positions waiting to be filled was 7.32 million, little changed from the revised 7.37 million in April. The quits rate remained at 2.3%, indicating workers' confidence in finding a job. Total vacancies exceeded the number of unemployed Americans by 1.44 million. The positive June hiring report suggests the economy may not be slowing as much as previously thought, reducing pressure for a Federal Reserve rate cut.

site_title: Is the US economy excessively regulated?
summary: A US report by the Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) suggests that many recent regulations, costing $235 billion, do not pass a cost-benefit analysis test, potentially saving US households around $3,100 annually. However, experts express skepticism due to the complexity of estimating costs and benefits, and the report's assumptions. Some argue that the actual savings will be lower, as increased trade tariffs and unincorporated regulatory costs may offset the benefits. The White House's point on excessive regulatory costs remains, but the report's findings are subject to further scrutiny.

site_title: Paris declares 'climate emergency'
summary: Paris has declared a climate emergency, following moves by other cities and national parliaments. The declaration, made by the city's deputy mayor, aims to better educate the public about climate change and adhere to the 2015 Paris agreement's objectives. The move comes ahead of municipal elections and follows similar declarations by Britain's parliament, Ireland's parliament, and New York City. Over 650 local authorities worldwide have now declared a climate emergency, with the US pulling out of the 2015 Paris agreement in 2017.

site_title: Remy Cointreau CEO to leave job after high-end spirits push
summary: Remy Cointreau SA CEO Valerie Chapoulaud-Floquet will step down by the end of the year due to personal reasons. Her strategy focusing on high-end spirits led the company's share price to double since 2014. The company regrets her departure and will continue her job until a successor is appointed. During her tenure, Remy introduced luxury products like Louis XIII and shifted away from low-end brands, achieving its target for profitability one year early. The company's results and strategic vision have allowed it to envision a bright future.

site_title: Wee Hur unit bags S$39m construction project from Tanglin Trust School
summary: Wee Hur Holdings has secured a S$39 million construction project from Tanglin Trust School, involving additions and alterations to a new educational institution block. The project will commence on July 15 and be completed by July 15, 2021. The contract is not expected to impact the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2019 financial year. This follows a quarter of halved earnings and 70% drop in group revenue, attributed to a muted development segment.

site_title: Taiwan set to receive US$2b in US arms
summary: The US has tentatively approved a $2 billion arms sale to Taiwan, including 108 M1A2T Abrams tanks and Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. The move is expected to exacerbate tensions between the US and China, with Beijing opposing the sale. Taiwan's president Tsai Ing-wen is set to visit North America, including the US, amid rising military threats from China. The sale provides Taiwan with greater deterrence capabilities, but US lawmakers have 30 days to object, with opposition unlikely. The approvals come as trade tensions and technology decoupling between the US and China continue to deteriorate.

site_title: Sweden rejects Chinese embezzlement extradition request
summary: Sweden's Supreme Court has refused to extradite Chinese national Qiao Jianjun, who is accused of embezzling over 200 million yuan, due to a "real risk" of persecution and the death penalty in China. Qiao Jianjun contests the accusations, claiming he was targeted for his involvement with the "China Democracy Party." The court cited the European Convention on Human Rights and deemed the risk of persecution too great to justify extradition, despite assurances from Chinese authorities. The decision will be reviewed by the Swedish government, which will consider the US's request for Qiao Jianjun's extradition.

site_title: KinderWorld puts IPO plans on hold, eyes 'more favourable time'
summary: KinderWorld, a Vietnam-based private-school operator, has put its initial public offering (IPO) plans on hold to wait for a more favorable time in the Singapore capital markets. The company had aimed to raise up to $71.4 million and value itself at between $300.5 million and $349.3 million. KinderWorld cited a soft IPO market, with Prime US Reit recently downsizing its offering size, and a need to tap the market at a more favorable time. The company remains confident about its business prospects and has sufficient funds to continue growth.

site_title: NYSE to assist Israel in creating secondary tech stock exchange
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has agreed to assist Israel in setting up a secondary stock exchange for high-tech companies. The move is part of Israel's securities regulator's strategy to create secondary and digital stock markets, following the country's struggling Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE). The NYSE will form a joint team with Israel's Finance Ministry to establish the new exchange, aiming to provide a more favorable regulatory environment for smaller companies. Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon expressed confidence in Israel's economy, while the Israel Securities Authority (ISA) aims to create an innovative and relevant stock exchange.

images.alt_text: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) will work with Israel in setting up a secondary stock exchange for high-tech companies, Israel's Finance Ministry said on Tuesday.

site_title: Lagarde set for October confirmation as next ECB president
summary: Christine Lagarde is set to be confirmed as the next president of the European Central Bank in October after finance ministers signed off on the agreement reached by governments. She will replace Mario Draghi on November 1. The European Union will formally appoint her, and attention turns to who will replace her as head of the International Monetary Fund. French Finance Minister Pierre Gramegna suggests a European candidate with crisis management experience, with Mark Carney being a frontrunner, while Kristalina Georgieva and Nadia Calvino are also considered possibilities.

site_title: Spotify unveils 'Lite' app for slower phones in emerging markets
summary: Spotify has released a new 'Lite' version of its music streaming app for emerging markets, particularly in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America, where data plans and slower networks are prevalent. The app, available in 36 markets, is ad-supported and costs the same as the regular premium version. The move aims to boost growth in these markets, which currently account for 13% of Spotify's users, and offset losses due to high music rights royalties.

site_title: Reits dim as hopes fade of big Fed cut
summary: Singapore's Reits dimmed on Tuesday, with the iEdge S-Reit 20 Index losing 1.7% to 1,445.77, as hopes of a sizeable US Federal Reserve interest rate cut faded. The Straits Times Index (STI) also edged down 0.1% to 3,329.46. Despite some Reits reaching "expensive" valuations, analysts like CGS-CIMB remain "overweight" on the sector, but cautioned investors to be selective. Market observers attributed the decline to cautious sentiment ahead of US Fed chair Jerome Powell's testimony and the release of the Fed's June meeting minutes.

site_title: HDB issues S$600m 10-year bond at 2.27%
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has issued S$600 million worth of 10-year senior unsecured notes at a 2.27% coupon. The notes will mature on July 16, 2029, and are expected to be rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service. The net proceeds will be used to finance development programs and refinance existing borrowings. This deal follows a February affirmation of HDB's Aaa issuer and senior unsecured ratings by Moody's, citing the strong linkage with the Singapore government.

site_title: Dyson CEO shrugs off S'pore factory downturn, bullish on job growth
summary: Dyson CEO James "Jim" Rowan expressed optimism about the company's job growth in Singapore, despite the country's manufacturing slump. Dyson has scooped up workers from the declining disk drive industry and is expanding its workforce, with plans to double its research and development footprint. The company's headcount in Singapore is set to grow, with a focus on software engineering and digital marketing, and an electric car plant expected to roll out vehicles by 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek reported a 1.49% one-year total shareholder return. Singapore condo resale prices declined 0.4% in June, breaking a 4-month uptrend. CapitaLand secured S$300m in sustainability-linked loans. Datapulse acquired the Bay Hotel Singapore for S$12.1m. 800 Super suspended trading after losing its free float and is set to be delisted. PropertyGuru named Tan Tee Khoon as Singapore country manager. Global economic concerns include Vietnam's reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK's shrinking economy.

site_title: South Korea: Shares fall further on pharma stocks
summary: South Korean shares fell further on Tuesday, with the KOSPI index closing down 0.59% at 2,052.03 points. The decline was driven by pharmaceutical stocks, with the market losing over 2.2% in the previous session. This marks the second consecutive day of losses, despite the KOSPI rising 0.54% so far this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer another sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks suffered a sell-off on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.76% to 28,116.28, following a strong US jobs report that dented hopes for a big Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.17%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.21%. The losses were despite US stocks reaching fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Chinese wealth manager alleges 3.4 billion yuan fraud at Camsing
summary: Noah Holdings, a Chinese wealth manager, has accused Camsing International Holding of a 3.4 billion yuan (S$672 million) asset management product default. Noah Holdings has filed a lawsuit and reported Camsing to regulators, citing the product's duration will be extended by up to one year to ensure repayment. The allegations come after Camsing's chairman was detained by police, raising concerns about the company's financial stability and governance.

site_title: Ocado eases investors' fears after blaze at robotic warehouse
summary: Ocado Group Plc shares rose 7.7% after the UK online grocer reassured investors that its strategy is on track despite a fire at one of its automated warehouses. The blaze, which occurred in February, is estimated to cut earnings by 15 million pounds. Despite the incident, Ocado maintained its full-year sales guidance and expects full-year growth of up to 15%. The company has removed decorative parts from robots and taken steps to reduce the risk of a repeat incident. Revenue from licensed technology partners rose by over one-third.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.9%, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.3%. The losses followed overnight declines in Asia and on Wall Street. The decline was partly offset by gains in mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower on banks after new capital requirements
summary: Australia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 0.1% due to new capital requirements for banks. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority raised capital requirements by 3 percentage points, expected to pressure lenders' margins. The "Big Four" banks lost between 0.3% and 0.7%. Investors await US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony for cues on monetary policy.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.1% as hopes fade over big Fed rate cut
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.77 points, or 0.1%, to 3,329.46, amid diminished hopes for a significant interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve. The decline was part of a mixed day for regional markets, with Australia, China, Hong Kong, and South Korea closing lower. Profit-taking activities accelerated due to weak fundamental outlook, particularly in the manufacturing and export sectors. The benchmark index had 17 of its 30 components trading in the red, with Thai Beverage and OCBC Bank being the top gainers.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes marginally higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.14% to close at 21,565.15, driven by a cheaper yen in sluggish trade. The broader Topix index lost 0.22% despite strong US jobs figures and a focus on the Federal Reserve's interest rate stance.

site_title: Bacteria, altered to destroy cancer
summary: Scientists have used genetically reprogrammed bacteria to destroy tumors in mice, a potential method for cancer therapy. The innovative approach, led by Dr. Michael Dougan, aims to treat cancer more precisely without side effects. While success in mice doesn't guarantee human success, the study published in Nature Medicine is a promising development. Researchers are already working to develop a commercial treatment, with Dr. Dougan predicting that programmable bacteria will be used for treatment in the future, citing "too much potential."

site_title: Thailand's minimum wage is set for second increase in two years
summary: Thailand is set to increase its minimum wage for the second consecutive year, amid an aging population and labor shortage. A subcommittee will assess the revision in the next one to two months, based on the state of the economy and industries' competitiveness. The increase, initially promised during the disputed March elections, could be up to 40% or 25%, affecting industries such as construction. The move aims to attract workers and boost the economy, despite concerns about a slowdown in exports and tourism.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.23 points to 1,682.87 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 2.4 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. The market saw 402 gainers and 401 losers.

site_title: Demand for new homes to boost Bovis' annual performance
summary: Bovis Homes Group Plc expects to report a significant improvement in first-half profit due to strong demand for new homes. The company delivered 1,647 completed homes in the six months ended June 30, a 4.5% increase from the previous year. Average selling prices rose 3% to £270,000, despite the UK property market being impacted by Brexit uncertainty. Bovis focuses on cash generation through part exchange deals, and its market fundamentals remain stable, with good demand for new homes across its operating regions.

site_title: Nutritional supplements aren't necessarily nutritious
summary: A new review of 277 trials involving nearly 1 million people found that nutritional supplements and dietary interventions provide little to no protection against cardiovascular disease or death, with some even showing negative effects. The review analyzed 16 supplements and eight dietary interventions, including folic acid supplements and omega-3 fatty acids, which showed some benefits, but none were proven to reduce mortality or cardiovascular outcomes. The only supplement to show signs of a negative impact was calcium plus vitamin D, linked to a greater chance of stroke.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,335.60, up 0.04% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.04% to 3,335.60, driven by gains from Thai Beverage Public Co and Sino Grandness Food Industry Group. Losers outnumbered gainers 159 to 132, with banking stocks DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank experiencing slight gains. The index closed before Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.53% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index weakened 0.3%.

site_title: Hong Kong protest group vows new rallies, rejects city leader's comments on 'dead' bill
summary: A Hong Kong protest group, the Civil Human Rights Forum, has vowed to hold new rallies despite city leader Carrie Lam's claim that the extradition bill is "dead". The group rejected the claim, stating that their five demands remain unmet and they will continue protesting unless their demands are heard. The new protests' details will be released in due course.

site_title: Small countries have role to play in defusing US-China conflict: ESM Goh
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong emphasizes the importance of smaller countries playing a role in defusing the US-China conflict. He notes that the deficit in trust between the two superpowers will take time to rebuild, and the world is at risk of being "shackled by history" if they don't work together. Goh suggests that smaller countries can engage with global powers to understand their ambitions and convey concerns, ultimately shaping a consensus-driven, rules-based international order. He cites Asean's experience as a model for building trust through regular meetings and consensus-building.

images.alt_text: With the United States and China engaged in a strategic rivalry that threatens to change the global geopolitical climate, all countries need to speak up to secure a peaceful and prosperous world and future, Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong told a forum of world leaders here on Tuesday.

site_title: Temasek posts 1.49% one-year return; divestments outpace investments
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a one-year total shareholder return (TSR) of 1.49% for the 12 months ended March 31, 2019, down from 12.2% in the previous year. The firm divested S$28 billion in assets and invested S$24 billion, with net portfolio value growing to S$313 billion. Temasek warned of lower returns expectations due to global growth concerns and volatility. The firm remains optimistic on China's medium-term trajectory, but expects policymakers to implement dovish policies to cushion growth pressure.

site_title: Wumart, Yonghui in final race for German food wholesaler Metro's China unit: sources
summary: Chinese supermarket operator Wumart Stores Inc and an investor group backed by Yonghui Superstores Co are among the suitors in the final round of bidding for Metro AG's China business. The final round includes a consortium of Hillhouse Capital, Tencent Holdings, and Meicai, with a potential deal valuing the business at around $2 billion. Bidders have been invited to submit binding offers in August, amid strong competition for the asset.

site_title: BlackRock plays defense by cutting equity risk, raising cash
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, is taking a more defensive approach to investing, raising cash and reducing equity risk amid global economic uncertainty. The firm's Investment Institute cited trade and geopolitical tensions as the primary drivers of the global economy, favoring government bonds and credit markets. BlackRock's strategists also expect an elongated economic cycle to benefit income-generating assets, but are cautious on stocks. The move is seen as a response to escalating trade tensions and the potential for further market volatility.

site_title: Airbus to ask airlines to check wings of older A380s for cracks
summary: Airbus will ask airlines operating 25 of its oldest A380 super-jumbo jets to inspect their wings for cracks after the EU's Aviation Safety Agency reported occurrences of finding cracks in certain parts of the wing on in-service A380 aeroplanes. If left undetected, the cracks could reduce the wing's structural integrity. The airworthiness directive, issued on July 5, aims to address the potential safety risk and ensure the continued safe operation of the aircraft.

site_title: Christian fund is cautious about Woolworths stock after spinoff
summary: Christian Super Pty, a faith-aligned pension fund, is considering buying back shares in Woolworths Group Ltd. after the company's plan to spin off its gaming and liquor businesses. The fund is cautious about the move, seeking clarity on the size and nature of any investment retained in the spun-off company to determine potential risks to Woolworths' brand and culture. This marks the first time in nine years that Christian Super has considered investing in Woolworths, citing the company's commitment to reducing social harms linked to gambling and alcohol addiction.

site_title: Japan rebuffs Seoul's calls to scrap export curbs
summary: Japan has rebuffed South Korea's calls to scrap export curbs on high-tech materials, escalating a decades-old diplomatic dispute that threatens the global supply of memory chips and smartphones. The curbs, imposed by Japan citing a dispute over forced labor during WWII, have been tightened and may hit tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. Japan's Industry Minister Hiroshige Seko said the curbs are not being withdrawn and do not violate WTO rules, while South Korea plans to complain to the WTO and considers countermeasures.

images.alt_text: Japan's Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko said Tokyo was "not thinking at all" of withdrawing the curbs and they did not violate World Trade Organization rules.

site_title: Hyundai says little hold-up left for long-awaited US pickup
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. expects to enter the US pickup market soon with an American-made vehicle targeting city-dwelling millennials who prefer smaller, more versatile trucks. The company, which first unveiled a truck concept called Santa Cruz 4 1/2 years ago, won't reveal details on specifications or release date. The vehicle is expected to be a crossover-type pickup with a 2-liter turbo diesel engine, featuring a sliding extension tailgate, ideal for tight parking spots. Hyundai aims to create a new class of buyers with this innovative design.

site_title: Spotify offers 'lite' app for slower phones in emerging markets
summary: Spotify has released a 'lite' version of its music streaming app for emerging markets with slower networks and limited data plans. The Spotify Lite app, available in 36 markets, is designed to conserve data and storage, using 10 megabytes of storage compared to 100 megabytes for the main app. The move aims to boost growth in regions such as Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America, where the company faces challenges in paying royalties and expanding its user base.

site_title: Credit Suisse hires Ford's Heyer to lead auto tech banking
summary: Credit Suisse has hired Joe Heyer from Ford Motor Co to lead investment banking in the automotive technology sector, focusing on autonomous vehicles, components, and software. Heyer, a former executive director at Ford, will report to David Wah and partner with the global industrials group. This move reflects the tech-driven shift in the auto industry, with electric car makers and ride-hailing companies changing market dynamics. Heyer will start at Credit Suisse in New York as a managing director next month, bringing expertise from his experience at Ford and Guggenheim Partners.

site_title: Australian shares lower on banks after capital requirements; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,653.6, weighed down by a 0.5-0.9% drop in Big Four banks following a 3% increase in capital requirements. Iron ore miners, however, rose, with Newcrest Mining and BHP Group seeing gains, as S&P raised its iron ore price forecasts due to a prolonged supply hit from the Vale dam disaster. In New Zealand, the benchmark index fell 0.6% to 10,545.02, with banks also under pressure.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on Tuesday with a 0.53% decline, extending losses from the previous day, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,181.16, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.08%.

site_title: Indonesia to send 210 tonnes of garbage back to Australia
summary: Indonesia plans to send over 210 tonnes of garbage, including hazardous materials and household trash, back to Australia after an inspection revealed the contents did not match the intended waste paper. The move aims to protect the public and Indonesian environment from B3 waste, a category of hazardous and toxic materials. This is part of a growing trend in South-east Asia, where nations are pushing back against serving as dumping grounds for foreign trash, following China's 2018 ban on imports of foreign plastic waste.

site_title: UK's arcane land-ownership rules targeted in Labour Party plan
summary: The UK's Labour Party proposes changes to the country's land-ownership rules, aiming to end a system that leaves leaseholders paying rent on the ground beneath their buildings. Under the plan, leaseholders would have the right to buy the land for 1% of the property's value, and ground rent would be capped. The changes would target companies that profit from ground rents, including those that have sold thousands of leasehold homes to investors. The move is seen as a step towards reforming the "feudal system" in England, where leaseholders often face restrictive contract terms and high fees.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares up at Tuesday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.32 points to 1,678.96. The market saw a gain of 78 stocks over 52 losers, with a trading volume of 71.09 million lots worth RM13.25 million.

site_title: OCBC and Ngee Ann Poly create programme to train more data experts
summary: OCBC Bank and Ngee Ann Polytechnic have launched a data certification program to train more data scientists and analysts. The 12-module program, available to the public, is expected to take two to three years to complete and will result in an official certification from Ngee Ann Poly. The program is offered through OCBC's learning and development arm, OCBC Campus.

site_title: Corn finally catches a weather break in the US
summary: US corn fields are recovering from a cold, soggy start to summer after a turn towards warmer weather. Corn futures have cooled off after surging 21% in the second quarter, with US crop ratings rising to 57% good or excellent. Investors are scaling back their bullish bets, with money managers' net-long position dropping 3.3% to 181,648 futures and options. Analysts expect the USDA to trim its outlook for domestic corn and soy production in the upcoming report, but the size of the crop remains uncertain.

site_title: Bitmain crypto-billionaire unveils new Singapore-based startup as bitcoin rises
summary: Bitmain co-founder Wu Jihan has launched a new Singapore-based cryptocurrency financial services startup, Matrixport, as bitcoin rises. The platform offers over-the-counter trading, lending, and custody for digital assets. Wu spun off Matrixport from Bitmain in January, after the mining giant faced a cash crunch. Matrixport aims to capitalize on bitcoin's resurgence and provide a one-stop solution for cryptocurrency financial services.

site_title: US, China to relaunch talks with little changed since deal fell apart
summary: The US and China are set to relaunch trade talks after a two-month hiatus, with US President Donald Trump agreeing to suspend tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports. However, little has changed since the talks fell apart in May, with China not making firm commitments to purchase US agricultural commodities. The US is demanding sweeping policy changes to protect intellectual property, while China is pushing for removal of existing tariffs. The negotiations are expected to be challenging, with a "fairly large gap" in core demands and concerns about the US team's hawkish stance.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says extradition bill is 'dead' after mass protests
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam declared the extradition bill "dead" after mass protests, but protesters remained unsatisfied, demanding a complete withdrawal of the bill. Lam's admission came after she suspended the bill in June, but protesters continue to call for her resignation and an independent investigation into police actions. The bill's fate has plunged Hong Kong into its biggest political crisis in decades, with concerns growing about the erosion of freedoms under Beijing's rule.

site_title: PropertyGuru names industry veteran Tan Tee Khoon as Singapore country manager
summary: PropertyGuru has appointed Tan Tee Khoon as its country manager for Singapore, effective immediately. Tan, a veteran in the industry, was previously executive director at Knight Frank Singapore and CEO of Singapore Accredited Estate Agencies. He will lead sales and oversee a team of 50, reporting to Jeremy Williams, chief business officer. Tan expressed his enthusiasm for PropertyGuru's focus on technology adoption and data-driven decision making, stating he looks forward to working together.

site_title: A waste of good wine? Non! Spitting is essential to tasting
summary: A Paris sommelier, Pierre-Jules Peyrat, emphasizes the importance of spitting while tasting wine, stating that it allows for a more refined and distinguished experience. This practice, often frowned upon in polite society, is considered essential for appreciating the nuances of wine. Peyrat's assertion is supported by his demonstration of the technique, which involves getting a good whiff of the wine before spitting it out.

site_title: Swiss engineering firm ABB pays US$470m to offload solar business
summary: ABB, a Swiss engineering firm, will pay up to $470 million to sell its solar inverter business to FIMER SpA, an Italian company. The business, which generates $290 million in annual sales, was acquired by ABB in 2013 but became a drag on its performance. The deal is expected to be completed in 2020, with ABB taking a $430 million non-operational charge. The move is part of ABB's efforts to refocus its business and increase its operational Ebitda margin.

site_title: US burger joint Five Guys to open at Plaza Singapura this year
summary: Five Guys, a US burger chain known for customisable beef burgers, is set to open its first outlet in Singapore at Plaza Singapura in the last quarter of this year. The outlet will offer the same menu as in the US and Hong Kong, including burgers, hotdogs, sandwiches, hand-cut fries, and milkshakes. This marks the brand's entry into the Asian market, following its debut in Hong Kong last year. The location was chosen for its convenience, accessibility, and high foot traffic, according to Zouk Group's CEO Andrew Li.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare's chairman in Chinese police custody
summary: Camsing Healthcare Ltd's chairman and executive director Lo Ching is being held in criminal custody in China, according to a Singapore Exchange filing. The company stated that normal business operations remain stable despite her arrest, but shares of Hong Kong-listed Camsing International Holding Ltd plummeted 90% after her arrest announcement. Lo's arrest follows an April filing where three former Camsing Healthcare directors cited poor audit and corporate governance practices as reasons for their resignations.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.23% to 3,342.06
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.23% to 3,342.06 at Tuesday's open, driven by banking stocks, which opened slightly stronger despite European shares falling overnight. DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank led gains, while LionGold Corp and Singtel held steady. In Asia, Tokyo stocks opened higher, and in Europe, the pan-European STOXX 600 index declined marginally.

site_title: Singapore-backed AI startup Taiger wins US$25m from investors
summary: Taiger, a Singapore-backed AI startup, has secured US$25 million in funding from investors, including PacificBridge Asset Management and MCM Investment Partners. The company's valuation has reached US$110 million, with plans to expand in South Korea, Japan, Mexico, and the Americas. Taiger's AI solutions use human-like logic to automate information extraction, helping companies reduce costs and optimize processing time. The startup expects to maintain revenue growth momentum and secure new international clients, including in the legal sector.

site_title: Datapulse to take 5% stake in Bay Hotel Singapore for S$12.1m
summary: Datapulse Technology will acquire a 5% stake in Bay Hotel Singapore for about S$12.1 million as part of a S$235 million deal. The deal, valued at S$238 million, will enable Datapulse to "enhance shareholders' returns" through stable income and capital appreciation. The hotel has a good location and potential for room expansion and rebranding. The deal is expected to be completed within five weeks after the announcement.

site_title: West Africa wealth inequalities reaching extreme levels: report
summary: West Africa faces extreme wealth inequalities, with the top 1% owning more than the rest of the region combined, according to a report by Oxfam and Development Finance International. The region, which includes six of Africa's fastest-growing economies, has seen economic growth benefit a small elite, while the majority of West Africans lack basic necessities like quality education, healthcare, and decent jobs. The report calls on governments to address inequality through progressive taxation, social spending, and labor market protection.

images.alt_text: West Africa suffers the most inequalities on the continent but many governments prefer to ignore problems despite economic growth, a report by Oxfam and Development Finance International said on Tuesday.

site_title: Seoul: Stock woes deepen as new trade war with Japan roils market
summary: Seoul's stock market has been hit hard by the escalating trade tensions with Japan, wiping out over $35 billion in value from the Korean equity benchmark in July. Investors are selling shares in semiconductor makers, particularly Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which rely on Japanese materials. The tensions have also raised concerns about boycotts of Japanese products and potential delays in investment or production. The Kospi index slumped over 2% on Monday, its biggest drop in two months, as volatility climbed.

site_title: Vintage fashion: senior models bridge S. Korea's age divide
summary: In South Korea, senior models are bridging the intergenerational divide in the fashion industry. Choi Soon-hwa, a 75-year-old former hospital worker, has become a social media and fashion celebrity. Despite the country's aging population, Choi's unlikely career is a "miracle" to her, highlighting the potential for seniors to pursue careers in fashion. This trend is part of a growing movement in South Korea where seniors are taking on new roles and defying traditional age-based stereotypes.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices down 0.4% in June, break 4-month uptrend: SRX flash data
summary: Singapore condo resale prices declined 0.4% in June, breaking a four-month upward trend, according to SRX Property. Prices in the core central region (CCR) dropped 0.7%, while the rest of central region and city fringes saw smaller declines. Sales volume also decreased 20.5% year-over-year, but condo prices were 1.6% higher than June 2018. Experts attribute the decline to fewer super luxury homes being sold and slower sales during the school holidays.

site_title: Why so many of us don't lose weight when we exercise
summary: A large-scale study found that many people who exercise fail to lose weight due to subtle lifestyle changes, such as increased food consumption or reduced energy expenditure. Despite consuming fewer calories through exercise, participants often experience a minimal weight loss, averaging only 30-40% of expected weight loss. The study suggests that human metabolisms are not as efficient as expected, and other factors, such as changes in eating habits, can offset the benefits of exercise. The study's findings may have implications for those trying to lose weight through exercise alone.

site_title: New Zealand proposes discounts for cleaner cars, slaps new fee on gas guzzlers
summary: New Zealand proposes discounts of up to NZ$8,000 for electric, hybrid, and fuel-efficient vehicles, and a fee of up to NZ$3,000 for polluting cars, starting in 2021. The plan aims to make greener cars more affordable. However, environmentalists criticize the penalty as only applying to new cars and newly imported used cars, and the sums not significant enough to stop New Zealanders from buying polluting cars.

site_title: China iron ore futures approach record-high on supply worries
summary: China's iron ore futures surged over 6% in early trade on July 9, reaching a record-high of 899.5 yuan (S$177.84) a tonne. The price increase is attributed to strong demand and concerns over supply, particularly following a deadly tailings dam collapse in Brazil. Credit ratings agency Standard & Poor's has raised its iron ore price forecasts for 2019, 2020, and 2021. Steel prices also rose for the first time in six sessions, with the most-active October construction steel rebar contract increasing by 2.1%.

site_title: Mitsotakis becomes Greece's new PM on vow to end economic crisis
summary: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has been sworn in after a sweeping election victory, promising to end a decade of economic crisis. With nearly 40% of the vote, Mitsotakis's New Democracy party secured a majority of 158 seats in the 300-member Parliament. The new leader faces a challenge to meet strict public spending commitments and reduce Greece's high public debt, which stands at 180% of its GDP. Mitsotakis has vowed to create jobs and stimulate growth through private investments, exports, and innovation, while his predecessor Alexis Tsipras warned that he would dismantle social spending for vulnerable groups.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by a cheaper yen, despite US-Iran tensions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.29% or 62.61 points to 21,596.96. The US dollar's appreciation against the yen, which fell to 108.76 yen, contributed to the positive market sentiment. Oil sector shares and automakers like Honda and Toyota also edged up. Geopolitical concerns, including Iran's uranium enrichment breach, weighed on the market, but bargain-hunting purchases supported the downside.

site_title: China to investigate state-owned giants Minmetals, ChemChina in new pollution audits
summary: China will investigate state-owned companies China Minmetals and ChemChina in a new round of environmental audits. The audits, led by the ruling Chinese Communist Party, will focus on eight regions and target the companies for past environmental violations. The investigation comes after previous audits criticized Minmetals for being a "big corporate bully" and ChemChina for producing substandard diesel. The outcome of the audits is uncertain, but the companies have stated that the investigations will not impact their operations. This marks the first time the government is specifically targeting state-owned firms in environmental audits.

site_title: Nine firms set prices for their IPOs on China's Nasdaq-style tech board
summary: Nine Chinese companies, including China Railway Signal & Communications and Advanced Micro-Fabrication Equipment, set prices for their initial public offerings (IPOs) on China's Nasdaq-style tech board. The companies will take subscriptions from investors starting July 22. Valuations vary, with AMEC priced at 170.8 times its 2018 earnings and CRSC at 18.18 times. The STAR Market has given the go-ahead for 25 companies to list, with four tech board companies already completed and 21 firms taking subscriptions this week.

site_title: Citi's electronic banking platforms safer with payment outlier detection service
summary: Citi has launched its payment outlier detection solution in 90 countries, including Singapore, to review and approve payments deviating from past patterns. The solution uses advanced analytics, AI, and machine learning to identify outlier payments, allowing clients to review and approve them without needing to opt-in. Developed in Citi's Dublin innovation lab with direct client collaboration, the solution replaces legacy rules-based logic with statistical machine learning algorithms.

site_title: Australia to raise bank capital buffers by less than expected
summary: Australia's main financial regulator, APRA, has decided to lower the capital buffer for banks by less than initially proposed. The target is now 3 percentage points of risk-weighted assets by January 1, 2024, instead of 4-5 percentage points. This decision aims to strengthen banks' loss-absorbing capacity while minimizing unintended market consequences. The move is expected to result in a minor rise in funding costs of less than 5 basis points and increase the banks' total capital by A$50 billion. The decision was made after feedback from the banks and APRA considered market capacity.

site_title: China's war on pollution could boost solar power: study
summary: China's efforts to reduce chronic air pollution could increase its solar power generation by up to 13% by allowing more sunlight to reach the earth, according to a new study. The study found that pollution reduced China's photovoltaic potential by 15% between 1960 and 2015. If China reverts to 1960s radiation levels, it could boost solar power generation by 12-13%, supporting Beijing's efforts to increase solar's contribution to the national grid and reduce costs. This comes as China cuts subsidies for renewable energy providers and aims to make solar power more profitable.

site_title: SGX invests in fintech Smartkarma
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has invested in fintech company Smartkarma, tapping its investment research network to drive growth across multiple asset classes. Smartkarma operates a global investment research network and is expanding into corporate solutions to tap top executives and investor relations. This investment aims to enhance SGX's offerings and compete with Hong Kong, another major financial hub.

site_title: Foreign robots are eating into Thailand's trading business
summary: Thailand's domestic brokerage industry is facing a significant decline in revenues due to the increasing presence of foreign institutional investors, who pay lower trading commissions. The industry saw a 72% slump in first-quarter earnings, with brokerage commissions plummeting. This trend is expected to continue, posing a major threat to the industry. The Federation of Thai Capital Market Organization attributes the decline to foreign programme trading, which offers "extremely low fees" to trade.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine lodges report with CAD following Brazil probe
summary: Sembcorp Marine has lodged a report with the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department following a raid at its Brazil yard and a corruption probe involving former president Martin Cheah Kok Choon. The investigation, which also involves SembMarine's Brazil unit Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz, was sparked by a suspicious transaction report. The company has not commented on the outcome of the probe.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine said that due to the "evolving nature" of the matters in Brazil, the internal investigations being conducted by the company are still ongoing and have not yet been concluded.

site_title: CapitaLand gets S$300m in sustainability-linked loans, Sembcorp to install solar panels on properties
summary: CapitaLand has secured S$300 million in sustainability-linked loans with Societe Generale, Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank, and Natixis Bank. The loans will be used for green projects, including the installation of solar panels on six properties, generating 10,292 megawatt hours of energy annually and avoiding 4.3 million kilogrammes of carbon dioxide emissions. The partnership with Sembcorp Industries will see the installation of solar panels with no installation cost to CapitaLand, making it a "good business case for sustainability".

images.alt_text: Sembcorp will install, own and operate the solar panels at six CapitaLand properties located at Techpoint (picture), 1 Changi Business Park Avenue 1, 9 Changi South Street 3, 2 Senoko South Road, 40 Penjuru Lane, and LogisTech.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip on Deutsche Bank, fading hopes of sharp Fed cut
summary: European shares declined on Monday, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index marginally lower, as Deutsche Bank's stock fell 5% despite a major restructuring move. Hopes of a sharp interest-rate cut by the US Federal Reserve also faded after robust US jobs data. Basic resources stocks helped limit losses, and London's FTSE 100 outperformed due to miners and oil majors. The US Federal Reserve is still expected to cut interest rates, but the timing and magnitude are uncertain.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Girls can kick too!
summary: Singapore Women's Football Team captain Angelyn Pang discusses the development of women's football in Singapore, its growing support, and how fellow Singaporeans can support national athletes. She shares her experiences and insights on the growth of the sport, highlighting the importance of promoting women's football in the country.

site_title: Facebook says not invited to White House social media summit
summary: Facebook says it was not invited to a White House social media summit scheduled for July 11, despite US President Donald Trump's repeated criticism of the company. The White House has declined to reveal the attendees, but several conservatives on social media have confirmed their participation. Facebook's absence comes as Trump has used social media to woo voters and has attacked the company as "biased" in favor of Democrats, without providing evidence. Twitter and Google have also not confirmed their attendance.

site_title: 800 Super suspends trading after loss of free float, set to be delisted
summary: 800 Super Holdings, a Catalist-listed firm, has suspended trading after losing its free float following a successful privatisation offer by the Lee family. The offeror, 8S Capital Holdings, received 96.24% valid acceptances, exceeding the 10% public float requirement. As a result, 800 Super will be delisted, with no plans to restore the public float or lift the trading suspension.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing indicate they may pull out of Canada fighter jet race: sources
summary: Airbus and Boeing may pull out of Canada's fighter jet bidding process due to concerns the contest is unfairly tilted towards Lockheed Martin's F-35 jet. The companies have expressed concerns over specifications favoring the US firm and have formally written to Ottawa expressing their concerns. The Canadian government is set to release the final request for proposals on July 17, with the contract worth between C$15 billion and C$19 billion. Lockheed Martin, Saab AB, and the government are working to address the concerns, but Boeing and Airbus have indicated they may not participate if changes are not made.

site_title: HSBC hires Michael Roberts from Citi to replace US chief
summary: HSBC has hired Michael Roberts, a senior Citigroup banker, to replace US unit head Patrick Burke, who unexpectedly retired. Roberts, with over 30 years of experience, will oversee HSBC's North American unit, which has faced challenges including bad debt charges. The move aims to improve returns for the lender, which has flagged the operation as an area of focus.

site_title: US may exceed debt limit sooner than forecast, forcing Congress' hand
summary: The US may breach its debt limit in early September unless Congress raises the debt ceiling, according to an independent policy group. The Bipartisan Policy Center revised its forecast, predicting a tighter deadline due to lower tax revenue projections. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin had previously warned of a possible default in late summer, and lawmakers have been slow to act on a debt limit solution. A meeting between Pelosi and Mnuchin ended in acrimony, and the House is set to leave Washington for six weeks, reducing Pelosi's leverage to secure spending increases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, CapitaLand, Frasers Property, SembMarine, Datapulse, Lian Beng
summary: Sembcorp Industries and CapitaLand have partnered to install rooftop solar farms at six of CapitaLand's properties, with no installation cost incurred by CapitaLand. Frasers Property will form a new business unit combining its industrial and logistics operations in Australia and Europe, starting in FY2020. SembCorp Industries shares closed down 0.4% and CapitaLand's shares down 1.1% on Monday.

site_title: Sexual assault case against Kevin Spacey on shaky ground
summary: Kevin Spacey's sexual assault case against him may be dropped due to his accuser, William Little, declining to testify. Little's cell phone, containing evidence of the alleged incident, has been compromised and disappeared. Little's mother admitted to deleting potentially embarrassing photos before giving the phone to police. Spacey's defense team claims the case is compromised and should be dismissed. The prosecution has requested a week to decide on the case's fate, with charges carrying up to five years in prison if proven.

site_title: Gig economy hijinks: Uber inspires comedy action movie 'Stuber'
summary: Uber has inspired a comedy action movie titled 'Stuber', which follows a mild-mannered Uber driver who gets drawn into a wild ride involving a Los Angeles detective on the trail of a killer. The film's director, Michael Dowse, stated that Uber was not involved in the movie and that the use of the platform was deemed "fair game" as long as it was not derogatory or inaccurate. The movie stars Dave Bautista and Kumail Nanjiani, and begins its international roll-out on Wednesday.

site_title: US slaps new duties on steel from Mexico and China
summary: The US has imposed new duties on steel from Mexico and China, citing unfair subsidies that harmed domestic producers. The decision comes two months after the US lifted tariffs on steel and aluminum from Canada as part of a revised North American free-trade pact. The Commerce Department found Mexican and Chinese exporters received subsidies of up to 177.43% for fabricated structural steel, which is used in major building projects. The duties will be collected starting Monday, but the funds could be returned if the finding is later reversed.

site_title: Alex Navab, former top KKR dealmaker, dies
summary: Alex Navab, a former top dealmaker at KKR & Co Inc, has died at 53 while on vacation with his family. Navab, who worked at KKR for over two decades, launched his own private equity firm, Navab Capital Partners, earlier this year. Born in Iran, Navab fled to Greece in 1979 and later joined KKR in 1993, rising to head of its Americas private equity business. His death was confirmed by Navab Capital Partners, with KKR co-founders expressing their condolences.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops as Apple falls, Fed eyed
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite dropping 115.98, 14.46, and 63.41 points, respectively. Apple shares fell 2.2% following a broker downgrade, while investors weigh the chances of an aggressive interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve later this month. Despite strong US jobs data, traders temper hopes of a sharp rate cut, and expectations about rate cuts have changed slightly.

site_title: Is there a need for Ardmore Medical to rush out its IPO?
summary: Ardmore Medical Group, an orthopaedic surgery and aesthetics specialist, is planning an IPO on the Catalist board. However, investors should be cautious due to concerns surrounding the death of a patient under the care of founder and CEO Sean Ng, which resulted in a surgical complication. The hospital conducted an internal inquiry, and the medical watchdog is still investigating. The company aims to mitigate risks by hiring a second surgeon and recruiting more doctors. The IPO's timing is uncertain, with Ardmore considering delaying the public share sale until the investigation is closed.

site_title: Minister hints at higher transport fares
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Khaw BoonWan hinted at higher public transport fares to keep subsidies in check, citing a 30% subsidy level and losses incurred by rail companies. Between 2016 and 2017, rail costs increased by S$270 million, with SMRT Trains and SBS Transit's train division losing tens of millions of dollars. The government expects to spend S$4.5 billion on operating subsidies over the next five years, on top of S$25 billion for new lines.

site_title: Hoa Nam Building going for en bloc sale with S$160m asking price
summary: Hoa Nam Building, a freehold mixed-development in Singapore, is being put up for collective sale with an asking price of S$160 million. The site has an existing gross floor area of 85,744 sq ft and can be redeveloped into a new commercial and residential project with a plot ratio of up to 3.0. Another option is to keep the existing building and make alterations and additions. The tender will close on Aug 20, 2019.

site_title: Japanese investors pile into world's biggest covered bond market
summary: Japanese investors are buying Danish covered bonds at a record pace, purchasing 2 billion kroner in May, with total investments reaching 10.3 billion kroner this year. This marks a 1 billion kroner increase from 2017 and is catching up to last year's 13.8 billion kroner. Despite high prepayments, Japanese investors remain committed to the asset class, aware of the risk of prepayments. This surge in demand comes as the market prepares for a record wave of mortgage refinancing, with prepayment notifications rising over 50% in a week.

images.alt_text: According to Nordea Bank Abp, Japanese investors bought about 2 billion kroner (S$408.8 million) in callable bonds in May, bringing total investments in the long-term, fixed-rate securities to 10.3 billion kroner this year.

site_title: Boeing's 737 Max loses first customer as Flyadeal turns to Airbus
summary: Flyadeal, a Saudi Arabian budget carrier, has reversed its commitment to buy Boeing 737 Max jets, becoming the first airline to drop the plane since its grounding following two deadly crashes. Flyadeal will instead operate an entirely Airbus SE fleet, purchasing up to 50 A320neo-family planes. The decision marks a commercial setback for Boeing, which is under pressure to prove the Max is safe. Flyadeal's decision follows similar actions by other carriers, including Virgin Australia and PT Garuda Indonesia, amid uncertainty surrounding the return of the Max to the skies.

site_title: S Korean leader urges Japan to withdraw export restrictions
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in urged Japan to withdraw new export restrictions, calling for a return to free trade principles. The restrictions, imposed last week, have intensified animosity between the two countries. If South Korean companies are harmed, Moon said he would take responsive measures. The dispute began after Japan imposed export restrictions on specialized products, citing national security concerns. The move has led to concerns about a potential trade war and its impact on regional economies.

site_title: Way forward is to grow external wing to beat constraints: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, Chan Chun Sing, proposes growing the country's economy by expanding its external presence and focusing on gross national product (GNP) rather than just gross domestic product (GDP). To achieve this, the government needs a solid base of companies operating abroad that contribute to the local economy. Chan cites PSA, a port operator, as an example of a company that has grown beyond its domestic role. The minister also notes that the US-China trade war and global economic shifts will impact Singapore's economy, but the country's fundamentals are sound, and it has the potential to weather the storm by focusing on new technologies and creating opportunities in the digital economy.

images.alt_text: Mr Chan said companies and workers will be given help to build up capabilities to compete, and local companies should be encouraged to expand overseas.

site_title: Bridging the customer service gap is the need of the hour
summary: Customer experience is crucial for revenue growth, with excellent experience resulting in 54% higher revenue growth than poor experiences. Brands can achieve positive customer interactions through customer relationship management (CRM). Meanwhile, a Singaporean startup aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC targets $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its building up for sale, while a Chinatown Business Association seeks $77,700 from a coffee shop over outdoor area use.

site_title: About 500 buildings required to install critical fire safety features
summary: Singapore plans to require critical fire safety features in approximately 500 older buildings with high occupancy loads, as part of proposed changes to the Fire Safety Act. These buildings, constructed before 1991/2002, will need to install fire safety features to meet the latest Fire Code. The move aims to enhance fire safety for occupants, particularly in high-risk situations.

site_title: Education on cyber-crime risks key in tackling rising complexity of cyber security
summary: Cybercrime poses a significant threat globally, with an estimated $114 billion annual cost, and a disproportionate impact on technologically-sophisticated nations like Singapore. A recent report found that 96% of local organizations have suffered a cyber security breach in the last 12 months. To tackle this rising complexity, businesses must prioritize cyber skills, regular training, and threat assessments. Having a clear plan in place for responding to cyber attacks and sharing knowledge internally and with peers is also crucial. Cyber crime is not different from other crimes, and educating businesses on potential threats and counter-measures can help prepare them to manage cyber risks.

site_title: US approves possible US$2.2b arms sale to Taiwan despite Chinese criticism
summary: The US State Department has approved a possible $2.2 billion arms sale to Taiwan, including M1A2T Abrams tanks and Stinger missiles, despite Chinese criticism. China urged the US to halt the sale, citing harm to bilateral ties. The Pentagon says the sale won't alter the military balance in the region. The US is the main arms supplier to Taiwan, bound by law to help defend the island. The sale is seen as a response to Taiwan's requests for new arms to bolster its defenses amid pressure from China.

images.alt_text: The US State Department has approved the possible sale to Taiwan of M1A2T Abrams tanks, Stinger missiles and related equipment at an estimated value of US$2.2 billion, the Pentagon said on Monday, despite Chinese criticism of the deal.

site_title: Why the UK is in a 'Brexit bind' over Hong Kong
summary: The UK is facing a delicate balancing act in its trade ties with China due to the ongoing Hong Kong protests. The UK's post-Brexit economy is heavily reliant on Asian trade, and its stance on the protests is causing tension with Beijing. Both potential UK prime ministers, Jeremy Hunt and Boris Johnson, have defended the protesters, but the UK's history of strained relations with China, including a 2012 meeting with the Dalai Lama, may impact its ability to maintain a strong relationship with China. This could hinder the UK's economic growth and trade ties.

site_title: Dollar holds 3-week highs as sharp Fed rate cut bets fade
summary: The dollar reached 3-week highs as the US jobs data showed a rebound in June, reducing expectations for a sharp Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The dollar index stood at 97.233, near its 3-week high, while the Turkish lira fell 1.7% after President Erdogan dismissed the central bank governor, sparking concerns about the bank's independence. Despite modest wage gains, analysts still expect a quarter-point rate cut from the Fed, but the dollar is expected to trade on a firmer footing due to diminished downside risks.

site_title: Spidey's latest outing sets some box office records ...
summary: Spider-Man: Far From Home debuted with a US$185 million in North America from 4,636 venues, breaking box office records. This surpasses the US$117 million debut of its predecessor, Spider-Man: Homecoming. The film's strong opening is a welcome boost to the North American box office.

site_title: Julius Baer appoints insider Philipp Rickenbacher as CEO
summary: Julius Baer has appointed Philipp Rickenbacher, a company insider, as its new CEO to drive future growth. This move is part of a trend among Switzerland's wealth managers to preserve and increase assets of rich clients. The appointment comes after Julius Baer's previous CEO's departure, and follows similar leadership changes at other Swiss wealth managers, such as Credit Suisse.

site_title: Oil steadies as demand worries offset Iran's new nuclear threats
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday as tensions over Iran's nuclear program countered concerns about slowing global economic growth. Brent crude futures fell 12 US cents to settle at $64.11 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 15 cents to settle at $57.66 a barrel. Iran threatened to restart deactivated centrifuges and step up uranium enrichment, amid US sanctions and warnings from President Trump. Despite lingering demand worries, oil prices remain under pressure due to global economic growth concerns and Opec output curbs.

site_title: Mitigate risk, even out inequalities as yield curve signals downturn
summary: The US Treasury yield curve has inched closer to an inversion, signaling policymakers to prepare for potential economic downturn. A month-long inversion of 10-year yields below 3-month yields is a warning sign, with one model estimating a 29% chance of recession, the highest since 2008. Policymakers should focus on mitigating socioeconomic inequalities and address pricing bubbles, particularly in the property market. A downturn will also impact Singapore's financial markets, and measures such as loan-to-asset caps and unemployment safety nets are needed to minimize disruption.

site_title: Singapore, Armenia sign pacts to strengthen economic, bilateral ties
summary: Singapore and Armenia signed four memoranda of understanding (MOUs) and one agreement to strengthen economic and bilateral ties. The agreements cover areas such as tourism, cultural cooperation, technical education, and avoidance of double taxation. The pacts aim to boost cross-border trade and investment, with Singaporean companies expressing interest in expanding business ties with Armenia. The move is seen as a significant step in enhancing bilateral relations, with Armenia currently chairing the Eurasian Economic Union.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lian Beng Group's unit, UNITED Tec Construction, secured a S$234.7 million contract to build a fresh food distribution centre for NTUC Fairprice, starting in August 2019 and set to be completed by July 2021. This new contract brings Lian Beng's total order book to S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Startup search engine has ambitious plans
summary: BOogle, a blockchain-based search engine, has launched with a focus on data privacy, storing ranking and search data on a decentralized platform. Users can earn BOO tokens for searching and clicking on ads, while the company aims to block objectionable content and prevent user abuse. With ambitious plans to expand into payment, email, cloud, and messaging services, BOogle aims to become a household name, with CEO Patrick Lee forecasting a break-even point in its fourth year. The company has already attracted a three-million-strong global community and is exploring partnerships with financial institutions.

site_title: Prime US Reit is listing now because 'conditions have stabilised'
summary: Prime US Reit, the third US office Reit to list in Singapore, is now available for listing due to stabilized market conditions. The Reit has priced at US$0.88 per unit, offering a 7.4% distribution yield in 2019 and 7.6% in 2020. The initial portfolio consists of 11 Class A and freehold office properties valued at US$1.2 billion. The manager has secured US$317 million in commitments from nine cornerstone investors, with KBS Real Estate Investment Trust III subscribing for 228.4 million units.

site_title: Boycott Japan: South Korea Instagrammers react to trade spat
summary: South Koreans are reacting to Japan's export restrictions on vital manufacturing materials by boycotting Japanese travel and consumer products. Over 2,400 Instagram posts with the #BoycottJapan hashtag have been shared, urging consumers to avoid Uniqlo, Shiseido, and Asahi products and instead opt for "Korean alternative" brands. The boycott has also led to cancellations of flights to Japan and the halt of sales of Japanese products by a Korean supermarket alliance, with some stores temporarily stopping sales of Asahi beer and Kirin Holdings cigarettes.

site_title: China refiners curb fuel output after massive new plants stoke glut
summary: China's fuel producers are cutting their crude processing output, or throughput, in the third quarter after massive new refineries stoked an already-sizeable glut. The move, led by private refiner Hengli Petrochemical and Zhejiang Petrochemical, is expected to sap their appetite for crude imports, pulling down international oil prices. The cutbacks could also send China's fuel exports surging and pinch Asian refining profits, with some analysts predicting a bearish narrative for the global oil market.

site_title: Robots will help, not replace humans: OCBC CEO
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien says robots will not replace humans, but rather work alongside them in a "hybrid workforce." He notes that jobs will not disappear, but rather tasks can be divided into "brain work" and "labour work," with humans focusing on creative problem-solving and automation handling repetitive tasks. Tsien emphasizes the importance of upskilling and reskilling, and OCBC has committed to investing $20 million over three years to train its 29,000 employees globally.

site_title: China search giant Baidu partners Geely, Toyota in AI
summary: China's search giant Baidu partners with Geely and Toyota to cooperate on artificial intelligence (AI) in areas related to self-driving cars. Baidu will provide Apollo Minibus software to Toyota's e-Palette vehicles and explore autonomous driving technologies. The partnership aims to enhance AI applications such as intelligent connectivity and smart mobility. Chinese cities have previously announced local guidelines for self-driving tests, and Baidu has approval to test self-driving vehicles on some city streets, positioning itself to compete with global leaders like Tesla and Waymo.

site_title: Amsterdam housing market gets help from Dutch govt
summary: The Dutch government has signed a long-term housing deal with the Amsterdam metropolitan area to prevent tenants from being priced out of their neighborhoods. The deal aims to cap rents, increase investments, and tweak laws to address the city's severe housing shortage. The median home price in Amsterdam has risen 80% in the past four years, pushing middle-income residents out of the city. The government will also explore a ban on rentals in newly built homes and propose new regulations for holiday rentals.

site_title: China's venture capital boom shows signs of turning into a bust
summary: China's venture capital market is experiencing a downturn, with venture deals plummeting 77% to $9.4 billion in the second quarter, and the number of deals roughly halving to 692. The decline is attributed to unpredictable trade talks and growing concerns about startup valuations, as well as the impact of the US-China trade war on the country's tech industry. Despite the downturn, valuations have yet to decline, with Chinese startups resisting down rounds and pivoting to alternative business models such as enterprise software.

site_title: Summer crop planting down 27% in India on patchy monsoon rains
summary: India's summer crop planting has decreased by 27% due to patchy monsoon rains, with 23.4 million hectares planted, down from 31.7 million hectares last year. This decline is attributed to the delayed onset of monsoon rains, affecting nearly half of the country's farmlands that lack irrigation.

site_title: OakNorth to sell loan underwriting tech to Asian incumbents
summary: OakNorth, a UK-based fintech backed by GIC, has set up shop in Singapore to sell its data-driven credit underwriting model to Asian financial institutions. The technology has led to a pre-tax profit of $44 million in just three years of lending to British SMEs, with zero defaults and missed payments. OakNorth plans to partner with up to eight Asian financial institutions by the end of the year, offering a comprehensive credit analysis service typically reserved for large corporates. The model also monitors market fluctuations, daily news, and social media postings to provide insights to SMEs.

images.alt_text: Mr Shetty says the monitoring by OakNorth's technology (factoring in market movements and the news) is often overlooked by financial institutions.

site_title: British Airways faces record £183.4m fine over data theft
summary: British Airways is facing a record £183.4m fine under the UK's GDPR for the 2018 data theft of 500,000 customers, exposing poor security arrangements. The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) proposed the fine, equivalent to 1.5% of the airline's 2017 global turnover. British Airways plans to appeal, citing European data protection rules allowing regulators to fine companies up to 4% of global turnover. The airline's chairman and CEO expressed surprise and disappointment, while parent company IAG will make representations to the ICO.

site_title: Unesco adds Frank Lloyd Wright's architecture to World Heritage list
summary: UNESCO has added eight major works designed by Frank Lloyd Wright to the World Heritage list, recognizing his contributions to modern American architecture. The designation includes iconic sites such as Fallingwater, Hollyhock House, and the Solomon R Guggenheim Museum, spanning Wright's career and various landscapes that inspired his designs. The recognition, made in Baku, Azerbaijan, marks the first time Wright's work has been included on the list, which now totals over 1,000 properties of outstanding value to humanity.

site_title: India's economic roadmap a bumpy ride
summary: India's government aims to double the country's economy to $5 trillion by 2025, but internal growth engines have slowed. The Modi government requires a minimum 8% annual growth rate until 2025, but recent growth has been at a five-year low of 6.8%. Private investment is key, but past efforts have been unsuccessful, and uncertainty in policy-making deters investments. The government must ensure a sustained "virtuous cycle" of savings, investment, and exports to achieve its goals, but lacks clarity on how to boost savings and boost exports, which are essential for growth.

site_title: Facebook's Libra faces sceptical govt in Asia's third-largest economy
summary: India expresses skepticism over allowing Facebook's Libra digital currency, citing concerns over the lack of full explanation and the potential for private cryptocurrencies. The Reserve Bank of India has already placed restrictions on cryptocurrencies, and the government is drafting a law with stringent penalties. Despite Facebook's plans for Libra to launch in 2020 or later, regulatory hurdles must be cleared before the digital currency can tap into India's large user base, estimated to double from 310 million to 440 million by 2023.

site_title: Two big UK utilities pledge to adopt all-electric fleets
summary: UK utilities Centrica and SSE pledge to switch their vehicle fleets to electric by 2030, aligning with the UK's goal to reduce net fossil fuel emissions to zero by 2050. The companies, which operate the third- and fourth-largest fleets in the UK, also commit to installing charging points for employees. This move is part of a broader effort to shift towards renewable energy and decarbonize transportation.

site_title: First 100 days seen key as polls indicate Johnson set to win party vote
summary: Boris Johnson is all but certain to become Britain's next prime minister, with 74% of Tory member voters backing him over Jeremy Hunt in a You Gov/Times poll. Johnson's first task will be to achieve a Brexit deal, which he promises to do by renegotiating the key aspect of Theresa May's withdrawal accord, particularly maintaining an open border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. If negotiations fail, Johnson will leave the EU without a deal, potentially triggering a general election. His economic policies will depend on the state of the economy and high borrowings, which are currently around 86% of gross domestic product.

site_title: Are China's relations with Japan entering a new era?
summary: China and Japan are entering a new era of improved relations, with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Premier Shinzo Abe discussing a "new era" in their relationship during talks in Osaka. The two countries agreed to revive understandings from 2007 to develop the East China Sea, a joint development in the zone to be decided through consultation. China also agreed to participate in Japan's infrastructure programmes in third countries, a move that can mitigate Chinese influence. However, issues such as territorial disputes, history, and natural resources remain, and diplomacy is seen as a chance to address these problems.

site_title: HK protesters plan to 'stress test' Bank of China
summary: Hong Kong protesters plan to "stress test" the Bank of China by collectively withdrawing funds on Saturday, aiming to pressure the city's pro-Beijing leaders. The move comes after five people were arrested in clashes with police, with protesters alleging excessive force was used. The protests, sparked by a suspended extradition bill, have morphed into a wider movement demanding democratic reforms and an end to sliding freedoms. The Bank of China's shares have fallen 1% in line with the broader market, as public anger against the government and police continues to escalate.

site_title: Lian Beng unit wins S$235m contract to build fresh food distribution centre for NTUC Fairprice
summary: Lian Beng Group's unit, UNITED Tec Construction, won a S$234.7 million contract to build a fresh food distribution centre for NTUC Fairprice. The 2.8-hectare facility, located in Boon Lay, will be designed by Surbana Jurong and completed by July 2021. The project is expected to support Lian Beng's order book of S$1.5 billion through FY2022. Construction will begin in August.

site_title: BOJ warns of US-China trade war impact on regional Japan
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) warned that the US-China trade war is affecting Japan's regional economies, with two regions showing signs of slowing growth. Despite this, the central bank maintained its economic assessment of all nine areas, citing solid domestic demand as a counterbalance. The BOJ governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, stated that Japan's economy is likely to continue expanding moderately, but may be affected by slowing overseas growth. The bank is ready to ramp up stimulus if the economy loses momentum, but is cautious due to years of aggressive easing and low borrowing costs.

site_title: Lagarde has what it takes to head ECB
summary: Christine Lagarde, IMF managing director and former French finance minister, has been selected to succeed Mario Draghi as European Central Bank (ECB) president in a backroom deal. The decision was part of a broader EU appointment process, with Ursula von der Leyen, the German defence minister, being nominated as European Commission president. The selection process was criticized for being unmerit-based, highlighting the complexities of EU politics. Lagarde's appointment has been met with some controversy, but her qualifications and experience have been seen as sufficient to lead the ECB.

site_title: Bill tabled to consolidate IP disputes in High Court
summary: Singapore is set to consolidate intellectual property (IP) disputes in the High Court, streamlining the process and reducing costs for small- and medium-sized enterprises. The bill will formalize procedures for third parties to challenge patent validity and introduce a lower-cost High Court pathway for IP disputes. Patents will be granted and challenged primarily in the High Court, with exceptions for standalone revocation claims and breach of confidence claims. The move aims to increase the attractiveness of Singapore as a venue for international IP arbitration.

site_title: Brokerages tell HMI investors to take cash option for clean exit
summary: Brokerages recommend HMI investors take the cash offer by management and EQT, calling it a "fair" and clean exit amid low trading liquidity. The offer values HMI at approximately S$611 million, with shareholders entitled to S$0.73 in cash or one new PanAsia Health share. HMI shares jumped 9.1% on Monday morning, trading at S$0.72, with Maybank Kim Eng downgrading its rating to "hold" and CGS-CIMB considering the cash option "fair but not compelling".

site_title: China may follow Fed lead in delivering rate cut
summary: China's central bank may cut its benchmark policy rate for the first time in four years if the US Federal Reserve delivers a rate cut in late July, according to analysts. This move comes as China's economy slows, with GDP growth expected to decline. Strong US job gains tempered expectations of a large rate cut from the Federal Reserve, however. The expected rate cut by the US Fed could influence China's decision to cut its policy rate, potentially supporting the slowing Chinese economy.

site_title: Frasers Property's new unit to combine industrial, logistics ops in Australia, Europe in FY2020
summary: Frasers Property will form a new business unit combining its industrial and logistics operations in Australia and Europe, representing S$5.4 billion in assets. The unit, led by CEO Reini Otter, will work closely with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) and start reporting as a strategic business unit in FY2020. The integration aims to leverage existing connections across Europe, Australia, and South-east Asia, enabling better customer service, faster scaling, and strategic asset management.

site_title: Wimbledon serves vegan cream, katsu curry
summary: Wimbledon serves vegan cream and beetroot quinoa burgers, reflecting the growing trend of incorporating vegan options into British diets. The All England Club aims to cater to the changing tastes of its attendees. This move is part of a broader shift towards more plant-based choices, with an increasing number of people adopting vegan lifestyles.

site_title: Investors feel sting of strong US jobs report
