summary: Asian markets closed lower on July 8, 2019, after the US jobs report exceeded expectations, undercutting investor hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The Singapore Straits Times Index fell 1% to 3,334.23, while other Asian markets also declined due to escalating trade friction between Japan and South Korea. The strong US jobs report suggests the US economy is doing better than expected, but investors are cautious about the prospect of rate cuts from central banks and other factors.

site_title: ECB to act if needed to support euro area, says Bank of France governor
summary: Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau stated that the European Central Bank (ECB) has the determination and capacity to act as needed to support the euro-area economy. He emphasized that quantitative easing would depend on economic data over the next few months, amid a "continuing slowdown" in the economy and significant wage increases. Villeroy also noted that monetary policy cannot do everything, and politicians must take action to reduce uncertainty, with an interest rate cut predicted by economists as soon as this month.

site_title: Deutsche layoffs: impact in Singapore seen as muted
summary: Deutsche Bank has cut about half its equities staff in Asia, with the impact seen as muted in Singapore due to its smaller equity operations. The bank plans to reduce its group by another 25% within a month.

images.alt_text: This is the bank's biggest restructuring in decades, and, according to Bloomberg, the first time since at least 1993 that it will not be paying dividends.

site_title: Philipp who? Julius Baer surprises with insider pick for CEO
summary: Julius Baer Group Ltd appointed internal candidate Philipp Rickenbacher as CEO, replacing Bernhard Hodler. Rickenbacher, 48, has 15 years of experience at the bank, including a stint on the management board. The move is seen as a step back from the bank's aggressive expansion under previous CEO Boris Collardi. The appointment may also disappoint internal frontrunner Yves Robert-Charrue and raises questions about the future of former Credit Suisse head Iqbal Khan.

site_title: Museum starts 'live' restoration of Rembrandt's work
summary: The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam began the largest ever restoration of Rembrandt's The Night Watch on July 8, 2019. A massive glass cage was erected around the 1642 masterpiece, allowing the public to witness the restoration process live. The multi-million-euro project, dubbed "Operation Night Watch," is the largest and most comprehensive research on the painting in history, and will also be streamed online for global viewership.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Tata pays 500b rupees to complete sale of mobile business
summary: Tata Group has paid 500 billion rupees (S$9.9 billion) to complete the sale of its mobile phone services business to Bharti Airtel Ltd. This payment includes 100 billion rupees to the Department of Telecommunications and 400 billion rupees to lenders. The deal, announced in 2017, was part of industry consolidation triggered by Reliance Jio Infocomm's entry in 2016. Tata Teleservices' debt obligations have been repaid as per schedule, completing the sale of its unprofitable businesses.

site_title: Ethiopia to send 50,000 workers to UAE
summary: Ethiopia plans to send 50,000 workers to the UAE in the 2019/2020 fiscal year to reduce unemployment and boost the economy. The workers will receive training and earn higher wages. Discussions are underway for similar agreements with Japan and European nations. This move is part of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's efforts to open Ethiopia to foreign investment and create a skilled workforce. The UAE has pledged to invest $3 billion in aid and investment in Ethiopia, and the Gulf nation hopes to expand its influence in the Horn of Africa.

site_title: Oxley asks UE to explain share sale
summary: United Engineers (UE) sold all its treasury shares for S$56 million to undisclosed third parties, sparking concerns from shareholder Oxley CEO Ching Chiat Kwong about the 18% discount to book value. UE managing director Roy Tan explained that the sale was a board decision and that Oxley was not approached as a potential buyer to avoid an interested-person transaction. UE needs to raise funds for investments and working capital, and the sale was made at a price that allows the company to be conservative in market conditions.

site_title: Police crack down on drunken Danes riding electric scooters
summary: Copenhagen police have cracked down on drunken Danes riding electric scooters, arresting and charging 28 people over the weekend. 24 were caught drunk and 4 were stoned, with fines ranging from 2000-crown (S$408) to 135 euros (S$205). The city council has limited access to the city centre and capped the number of scooters at 3000. Critics say the scooters pose a safety risk, while fans see them as a quick and cheap way to get around. The city is not alone, with Paris also introducing fines and a ban on parking on pavements.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Apple slips, hopes of sharp rate cut fade
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday as Apple shares dropped, and investors scaled back bets on a sharp interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.32% to 26,835.64, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.36% and 0.60%, respectively. A solid June jobs report and the decline of Apple shares led to the reduced expectations of an aggressive interest rate cut.

site_title: BNP takes advantage of Deutsche Bank revamp with equities deal
summary: BNP Paribas has agreed to back up and potentially assume control of electronic trading and prime services for hedge funds now run by Deutsche Bank, following the German lender's decision to cut 18,000 jobs and retreat from equities sales and trading. The deal provides continuity of service to prime finance and electronic equities clients and is subject to approvals. This move allows BNP Paribas to strengthen its position in corporate and investment banking in Europe. The agreement comes as Deutsche Bank seeks to end its foray into trading that lasted three decades.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble after US jobs report
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.54% on Monday after a US jobs report showed better-than-expected numbers, reducing expectations for a significant interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve this month. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,331.69, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The sell-off was part of a broader Asia-wide drop, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: US consumer inflation outlook rises for 1st time in 3 months
summary: US consumers' inflation expectations rose for the first time in three months, increasing to 2.7% for one-year and three-year periods, according to the New York Fed's survey. This shift reduces pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut rates significantly. The US economy has been falling short of the Fed's 2% inflation goal, and policymakers are concerned that slipping consumer expectations of price hikes could lead to reduced spending and slower growth. The Fed is debating whether to cut rates at its July 30-31 meeting amidst uncertainty over a US trade war and tepid inflation.

site_title: US financier Jeffrey Epstein charged with sex trafficking
summary: US financier Jeffrey Epstein, 66, has been charged with sex trafficking of underage girls, including one count of sex trafficking and one count of sex trafficking conspiracy. He was arrested on Saturday and faces up to 45 years in prison if convicted. Epstein had previously avoided similar charges in Florida in a 2007 plea deal, which was later ruled to be in violation of the federal Crime Victims' Rights Act. The US Department of Justice has maintained that the deal should not be canceled.

site_title: Allied Tech swings into net loss following audited accounts
summary: Allied Tech, a precision engineering company, reported a net loss of S$30 million in its audited 2018 financial statements, reversing its initial unaudited full-year profit of S$2.16 million. The loss was primarily due to an impairment loss of S$31.3 million resulting from the write-down of goodwill from acquisitions of Asia Box Office and Activpass Holdings. The company is also investigating missing funds of S$33 million and has taken steps to recover these funds.

site_title: China refiners curb fuel output after massive new plants stoke glut
summary: China's fuel producers are cutting output in the third quarter due to a massive glut caused by new refineries, potentially dragging down crude oil demand and international prices. New plants, including Hengli Petrochemical's 400,000-barrels-per-day plant, have increased supply, while slowing local demand for fuels has led to reduced crude processing. This could lead to higher fuel exports and lower refining profits, reinforcing a bearish narrative for global oil prices.

site_title: World's largest port operator hires banks on $1b bond
summary: DP World, the world's largest port operator, has mandated banks to raise about $1 billion in bonds to finance its acquisition of Topaz Energy & Marine Plc. The Dubai-based firm plans to sell benchmark 10-year Islamic bonds and is considering long-dated conventional bonds. The $1.1 billion acquisition, announced last week, marks DP World's first venture into the oil and gas sector. The company has been on a shopping spree, buying several ports and logistics companies over the past 18 months.

site_title: Frasers Property to combine industrial, logistics operations in Australia and Europe under new unit
summary: Frasers Property is forming a new business unit combining its industrial and logistics operations in Australia and Europe, representing S$5.4 billion in assets under management. The unit, starting to report as a strategic business unit in FY2020, will work closely with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) in asset and property management. Reini Otter will lead the unit as CEO, while Matt Knox will be CFO.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine lodges report with CAD following Brazil scandal
summary: Sembcorp Marine has lodged a report with the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department following a raid at its Brazil yard, which was linked to corruption involving former unit president Martin Cheah Kok Choon. The investigation is ongoing, and SembMarine has submitted a suspicious transaction report. The company's Brazil unit was raided, and Cheah was involved in a corruption probe during his employment with the group.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 1% on Monday as strong US jobs data dims hopes for big Fed rate cut
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1% on Monday, closing at 3,334.23, amid strong US jobs data that undercut hopes for an aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate cut in July. The Asia-Pacific market followed suit, with Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea also closing lower. The local market's 5-day rally was halted by the US jobs report, which dimmed expectations for a rate cut.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall over 2% on reduced bets on steep US rate cuts
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted over 2% on Monday, the largest decline in two months, as strong US jobs data diminished expectations of aggressive rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The KOSPI index fell 46.42 points, its lowest close since May 31, while the KOSDAQ index dropped 3.7%. Continued tensions between the US and South Korea also dampened investor sentiment, despite a 1.13% year-to-date gain for the KOSPI.

site_title: Chinese tech company seeks US$500m to prepare for tough times
summary: Chinese tech company Missfresh, backed by Tencent Holdings, is seeking up to $500 million in new funding to prepare for tougher times amid a slowing economy and market uncertainties. The company, which operates a grocery delivery startup, aims to raise $300-500 million at a valuation of up to $4 billion. Missfresh has raised nearly $900 million from investors and has over 1,500 mini-warehouses and 25 million monthly active users. The company's fundraising plans come as venture deals in China have tumbled 77% in the second quarter.

site_title: British Museum announces return of looted Iraqi and Afghan artefacts
summary: The British Museum has announced the return of looted Iraqi and Afghan artefacts seized in Britain. The museum has been working with law enforcement agencies to return 154 Mesopotamian texts and Gandharan sculptures to their countries of origin. The texts, created between the 6th and 4th centuries BC, were smuggled out of Iraq during conflict, while the Gandharan sculptures were exported to Britain in 2002. The artefacts will be handed over to the Iraq Museum in Baghdad, following appraisal by the British Museum.

site_title: Imperial Brands to revise dividend policy, launches share buyback plan
summary: Imperial Brands, a British tobacco company, has announced plans to buy back up to 200 million pounds worth of shares and revise its dividend policy to make payouts grow annually. The company aims to invest more in its vaping products and shed assets worth 2 billion pounds by 2020. Imperial Brands also reported weaker-than-expected e-cigarette sales in May, citing a slowdown in the US market. The revised capital allocation policy is expected to allow for investment in both organic growth and M&A opportunities.

site_title: Temasek-linked Astrea III PE bonds fully redeemed, with bonus paid
summary: Temasek-linked private equity vehicle Astrea III has fully redeemed its Class A-1 notes, with noteholders receiving a bonus redemption premium of 0.3% of the principal. This marks the first Singapore Exchange-listed private equity bond to be fully redeemed. The move is seen as a positive development for the bond market, with Azalea Investment Management's CEO, Margaret Lui, expressing her "heartening" sentiments on the redemption.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on dampened US rate cut hopes
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% to 6,672.20, the largest one-day drop in five weeks, due to dampened hopes for a US Federal Reserve rate cut this month. Strong US non-farm payrolls data softened expectations for a rate cut, with investors awaiting Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony to Congress for more cues on monetary policy. Mining stocks declined 0.7% due to reduced chances for a Fed rate cut, while the S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand closed little changed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.89 points to 1,677.64. Volume was 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 567 to 268.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% to 7,543.16 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 losing 0.2% each. The decline follows strong US jobs data, reducing pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates sharply. The drop in European markets comes ahead of US-EU trade talks and amid ongoing uncertainty over tariffs.

images.alt_text: European stock markets fell at the open Monday, retreating further following strong US jobs data that reduced pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates sharply.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic outlook is uncertain due to the US-China trade dispute, Brexit risks, and regional economic instability. The US announced new tariffs on Vietnam, affecting the Asian garment industry. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for the global equity index by mid-2026. Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident his daughter will be cleared of ethics charges, while the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row.

site_title: China car sales rise for first time in year, helped by discounts
summary: China's passenger-car sales rose 4.9% to 1.8 million units in June, marking the first increase since May 2018. The recovery is attributed to dealers offering discounts to clear inventory before new emissions rules kicked in. However, a sustained recovery is uncertain, with a decline estimated by LMC Automotive for the full year. Local brands have been hit hard, while market leaders Volkswagen and Toyota have seen sales decline. Dealers' short-term incentives have disrupted the market and may have a negative impact on profitability in the long run.

site_title: Papa John's hires McDonald's veteran as head of restaurant operations
summary: Papa John's International Inc has appointed Jim Norberg, a 30-year veteran of McDonald's, as its chief of restaurant operations. Norberg will focus on growing sales and profit margins, improving customer satisfaction, and simplifying store operations. His appointment comes after the company's founder, John Schnatter, exited following a scandal over a racial slur. Papa John's has also recently named Shaquille O'Neal as a board member, brand ambassador, and investor. The move aims to propel the brand forward and position it for continued success.

site_title: US Fed easing could prompt first China rate cut in four years - analysts
summary: China's central bank may cut its benchmark policy rate for the first time in four years if the US Federal Reserve lowers interest rates in July, analysts say. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has injected liquidity into the financial system, but it has not jumpstarted investment as planned, leaving companies wary of making fresh investments. Analysts believe a system-wide cut in interest rates could offer struggling firms more immediate relief, but a benchmark rate cut could pressure China's yuan currency and add to debt concerns.

site_title: Lagarde successor at IMF should be European: Ministers
summary: European finance ministers have expressed support for a European candidate to succeed Christine Lagarde as International Monetary Fund (IMF) head. France and Spain have stated it's a priority to appoint a European, sparking speculation about potential candidates such as Mark Carney, a Canadian-born British-Irish passport holder, and Kristalina Georgieva, the World Bank's chief executive. The European Union had previously nominated Lagarde to succeed Mario Draghi at the European Central Bank, potentially shifting the tradition of Europe holding the IMF while the US appoints the World Bank head.

images.alt_text: The next head of the International Monetary Fund should be a European, the finance ministers of France and Spain said on Monday as governments started talks on Christine Lagarde's succession.

site_title: Construction company is the first to be punished for operating a drone outdoors without permit
summary: The Singapore branch of construction company LT Sambo was fined S$9,000 for operating a drone outdoors without a proper permit, becoming the first to be punished under the law. The company flew a DJI Phantom 4 drone on November 17, 2017, without a Class 1 activity permit, which is required for activities involving non-recreational or research drones. The fine is a result of the company's guilty plea to an offence under the Air Navigation Order.

site_title: Hoa Nam Building in Jalan Besar area up for collective sale with S$160m asking price
summary: A freehold mixed-development, the Hoa Nam Building, in Singapore's Jalan Besar area is up for collective sale with an asking price of S$160 million. The building has a total of 83 units and a site area of 21,365 sq ft, exceeding the 3.0 plot ratio designated under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2014. The site can be redeveloped into a new commercial and residential project or kept with alterations and additions. The tender closes on Aug 20, 2019, with a potential buyer advised of the possibility of rezoning to full commercial use without additional buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 1.3% at 3,324.51
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 3,324.51 on Monday, following a strong US jobs report that dashed hopes for an aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate cut in July. The decline came as Asian markets reacted to the report, with volume and turnover on track to hit averages for the first five months of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down nearly 1%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell nearly 1% on Monday, tracking Wall Street's losses, as investors cashed in on last week's gains. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,534.35, down 0.98% from the previous week's close. The decline was attributed to profit-taking and concerns over US interest rates, following better-than-expected job data.

site_title: Summer crop planting down 27 per cent in India on patchy monsoon rains
summary: India's summer crop planting has dropped 27% to 23.4 million hectares due to patchy monsoon rains, according to the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare. This is lower than the same period last year, with key crops like rice, corn, and cotton also seeing a decline. Soybean planting is down 64%, while pulses and sugar cane plantings are also lower. The monsoon rains in India were below average for the fifth week in a row, with a 6% deficit in the week ending July 3.

site_title: Two big UK utilities pledge to adopt all-electric fleets
summary: Two major UK utilities, Centrica Plc and SSE Plc, have pledged to switch their entire vehicle fleet to run on electricity by 2030, aiming to reduce net fossil-fuel emissions to zero by 2050. The move follows a cross-party effort backed by the government and is part of the utilities' efforts to shift toward renewables. Centrica operates 15,000 vehicles, while SSE has 3,500 vehicles and plans to install charging points for its employees. This commitment adds momentum to the shift away from traditional engine technology and is seen as a step towards meeting the UK's net zero targets.

site_title: British Airways faces US$230m fine over 2018 data theft
summary: British Airways has been proposed a £183.4 million (S$313 million) fine by the UK Information Commissioner's office for a 2018 data theft that exposed customer data of 380,000 transactions. The hack, which lasted from August 21 to September 5, affected account numbers and personal information from the airline's website and mobile app. British Airways Chairman Alex Cruz described the attack as "sophisticated, malicious and criminal," but stated the airline has found no evidence of fraud and plans to vigorously defend its position.

site_title: Prime US Reit priced unchanged from initial guidance at US$0.88 per unit
summary: Prime US Reit priced unchanged at US$0.88 per unit, offering a 7.4% distribution yield in 2019 and 7.6% in 2020. The real estate investment trust (Reit) is listed on the main board of the Singapore Exchange after its manager registered the final prospectus with the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Times Properties, a unit of Singapore Press Holdings, has entered into a call option agreement to acquire a 20% stake in the manager after listing.

site_title: Trade war, major export markets to determine Singapore's economic outlook: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's economic outlook is uncertain due to the US-China trade conflict and its impact on major export markets. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that prolonged tensions will lower global business and consumer confidence, affecting Singapore's outward-oriented sectors. The country's 2019 growth forecast range has been cut to 1.5-2.5%. Singapore will focus on strengthening fundamentals, creating opportunities, and promoting a conducive global and regional business environment to navigate the challenges.

site_title: Singapore saw 12% rise in worker-senior manager pay gap between 2008 to 2017: Korn Ferry
summary: Singapore saw a 12.1% rise in the pay gap between lower-level employees and senior managers from 2008 to 2017, ranking fourth in the Asia-Pacific region. The country's pay gap increase was lower than the average 15.5% across the region. India saw the largest jump in pay gap, widening by 66%, followed by Malaysia and Indonesia. Experts attribute the widening pay gap to automation and offshoring, leading to a shortage of talent at senior levels, and slower pay increases for lower-level workers.

site_title: Chinese shadow theatre fights against dying of the light
summary: Chinese shadow theatre, a 2,000-year-old tradition, faces declining audiences as young people lose interest. Despite UNESCO's recognition in 2011, performers struggle to keep up with modern entertainment options like video games and TV. A troupe in Beijing, composed of dwarf puppeteers, has managed to survive through online recruitment and regular school performances. However, their masters are nearing retirement, and the troupe's future is uncertain, emphasizing the need for government support to preserve this traditional art form.

site_title: India could raise US$10b from first foreign bond sale
summary: India plans to raise up to $10 billion from its first overseas sovereign bond sale, leveraging the appetite for its debt in the foreign market. This move is seen as a cautious beginning to manage debt and ease pressure on local markets. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced surprise moves to lower the budget deficit and sell bonds overseas, which has rallied sovereign bonds for a second straight session. The sale is expected to not exceed 10-15% of total borrowing, making it approximately $10 billion.

site_title: China steel hub Hebei moves 2019 industrial capacity cutting targets forward
summary: China's top steelmaking province Hebei has moved up the target dates for cutting industrial capacity and relocating plants by two months to the end of October to reduce air pollution, especially PM2.5. Despite this, the province saw no significant decrease in average PM2.5 concentration in the first six months of 2019. The extension of industrial production curbs showed that the province is making progress in reducing pollution.

site_title: Iran tanker detention by Britain was threatening act: Iran defence minister
summary: Iran's Defence Minister Amir Hatami claims Britain's detention of an Iranian tanker was a threatening and incorrect action. The tanker was seized for allegedly trying to deliver oil to Syria in violation of EU sanctions. Iran's downing of an unmanned American drone last month was seen as a message to defend its borders. The incident has raised tensions between Iran and the West, with Iran threatening retaliation against a British ship.

site_title: ECB to act as needed to support euro-area economy: Bank of France governor
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau stated the bank is prepared to act as needed to support the euro-area economy, citing a "continuing slowdown" and significant wage increases. Any potential quantitative easing would depend on economic data over the next few months. Villeroy emphasized the need for pragmatism, suggesting that the ECB will assess data before making a decision.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank (ECB) has the determination and capacity to act as needed to support the euro-area economy, Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.

site_title: South Korea urges Japan to scrap export curbs, pledges help to firms
summary: South Korea urged Japan to scrap export curbs on materials for chip and smartphone displays, imposed amid a diplomatic row over wartime labour. Finance Minister Hong Nam-ki stated that the curbs should be withdrawn to minimize damage to affected South Korean companies. The government pledged to provide assistance to help mitigate the impact of the curbs.

site_title: In jab at US, China vice-president says world cannot shut China out
summary: Chinese Vice-President Wang Qishan said the world cannot shut China out and that China's development cannot be isolated from the rest of the world. In a speech at the World Peace Forum, Wang warned against protectionism and called on major powers to contribute to global peace and stability. He reiterated China's commitment to opening up and said that development is key to resolving issues, despite ongoing trade tensions with the US. Wang's comments come ahead of rescheduled talks between the two nations to resolve their year-long trade war.

site_title: China tech giant Baidu partners with Geely, Toyota on AI and self-driving cars
summary: China's Baidu partners with Geely and Toyota to cooperate on artificial intelligence and self-driving cars. The partnership will see Baidu providing its Apollo Minibus software to Toyota's e-Palette vehicles, and the companies will explore uses of autonomous driving technologies. This move follows China's push for self-driving cars and aims to compete with global leaders like Tesla and Waymo. Experts say it will take years for self-driving systems to be ready for widespread use.

site_title: VW to deepen alliances with battery suppliers for electric push
summary: Volkswagen plans to deepen its alliances with battery suppliers to support its electric vehicle push, with a goal of producing 150 gigawatt hours of battery capacity in Europe and Asia by 2025. The company will create joint ventures and finance battery production to persuade skeptical suppliers to invest in the industry. VW aims to start producing 33 electric cars by mid-2023 and is retooling 16 factories to build electric vehicles, with battery suppliers such as Northvolt, LG Chem, and Samsung SDI identified as strategic partners.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen will create joint ventures and help finance battery production to persuade sceptical cell suppliers to back its aggressive push for mass producing electric vehicles, board member Stefan Sommer told Reuters.

site_title: Rich Indians to the rescue as Chinese tourists shun Thailand
summary: Thailand's struggling tourism industry is finding support from visitors from India, which has seen a significant surge in arrivals, driven by more direct flights, a visa waiver, and increasing wealth. With 10 million Indian visitors forecast for 2028, India is poised to become the new expansion story in Thai tourism, potentially rivaling China's growth. This shift could have implications for other Asian economies as China matures.

site_title: Put off by US, Chinese students eye other universities
summary: Chinese students are reevaluating their study options in the US due to visa delays, safety concerns, and research project restrictions sparked by the US-China trade war. The number of Chinese students in the US dropped by 2% in March, the first decline in a decade. Rival countries like Britain, Australia, and Canada are gaining popularity, with Japan, South Korea, and parts of Europe also seeing an uptick in applications. The US economy loses billions of dollars annually from Chinese student tuition fees and living expenses.

site_title: Tata settles US$7.3b of dues to complete sale of mobile business
summary: Tata Group paid approximately $9.94 billion to settle debts related to the sale of its mobile business to Bharti Airtel Ltd. The deal, announced in 2017, aimed to address the debt burden of Tata Teleservices Ltd. and Tata Teleservices (Maharashtra) Ltd. following the entry of Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd. in 2016, which forced the incumbent carriers to exit or merge with rivals. The disposal marked the completion of Tata's mobile business sale.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest five after new night of clashes
summary: Hong Kong police arrested five protesters after clashes with riot officers in the Mongkok district, marking the latest escalation in the city's ongoing crisis. The protests, sparked by a suspended extradition law, have morphed into a movement demanding democratic reforms and an end to sliding freedoms. Police have used force, including tear gas and rubber bullets, to disperse protesters, leading to public anger and calls for reform. The government remains unchanged, with Carrie Lam refusing to step down despite protests demanding her resignation.

site_title: Gojek nabs investment from Mitsubishi for Series F round
summary: Gojek, a ride-hailing company, has secured investment from Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and Mitsubishi Corporation as part of its Series F funding round, which was previously led by Google, JD.com, and Tencent. The investment allows Mitsubishi to tap into Gojek's expertise in mobility and consumer services in Southeast Asia, while Gojek gains access to Mitsubishi's brand power and financial resources. The partnership is expected to boost growth and create synergies among the three parties.

site_title: Higher fares will be needed in face of rising subsidies for public transport: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan stated that the government is subsidizing over 30% of public transport operations, resulting in rail companies operating at a loss. He cited an increase in operating costs of S$270 million between 2016 and 2017 and losses of S$86 million for SMRT Trains and tens of millions for SBS Transit's train division. To keep subsidies in check, Khaw indicated that higher fares would be necessary.

site_title: Swiss bank Julius Baer appoints Rickenbacher as CEO
summary: Julius Baer has appointed Philipp Rickenbacher as its new CEO, effective September 1. Rickenbacher, a 48-year-old Swiss citizen, is the current head of intermediaries and global custody. He replaces Bernard Hodler, who is retiring. The bank's chairman, Romeo Lacher, praised Rickenbacher's leadership and industry track record, saying the appointment is a "delight" and will help address future challenges. Rickenbacher had previously worked at McKinsey and joined Julius Baer in 2004.

site_title: All drones to be licensed after Changi Airport incursions
summary: Singapore will require all drones to be registered, with stricter enforcement and penalties for those who flout flying rules. A licensing framework for drone pilots will also be introduced. The move follows two illegal drone incursions at Changi Airport in June, which disrupted operations and caused 55 flight delays and eight diversions. Operators will be made aware of their responsibilities and required to conduct activities in a responsible manner. Stricter enforcement and penalties, including fines of up to S$20,000 and jail time, will be implemented to prevent future incidents.

site_title: China's venture capital boom shows signs of turning into a bust
summary: China's venture capital market has experienced a significant downturn, with venture deals plummeting 77% in the second quarter to $9.4 billion, down from $41.3 billion in the same period last year. This marks a reversal of the five-year surge in venture capital investment that fueled the growth of startups like Didi Chuxing and Bytedance Ltd. Investors are pulling back amid unpredictable trade talks and growing concerns about startup valuations, with many questioning the ability of companies like Didi to become profitable. The downturn is seen as a potential "bust" for China's venture market, which has never experienced a widespread downturn like the US did after the dotcom boom.

site_title: US-China tariff conflict not the only dynamic shaping Asia Pacific's trade and investment landscape
summary: The recent ASEAN Leaders' Summit in Bangkok, Thailand, highlighted the region's growing importance in global trade, despite the US-China tariff conflict. ASEAN, comprising 650 million people and a combined GDP of $2.8 trillion, is a key player in regional trade and investment. The summit discussed various global trade issues, including the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a 16-nation free trade agreement that aims to synthesize existing preferential trade agreements. While negotiations have stalled, ASEAN leaders have set a goal to conclude the RCEP agreement by the end of the year, with the potential to impact the global economy.

site_title: Hong Kong stock Camsing plunges 90% after chairwoman detained by Chinese police
summary: Hong Kong stock Camsing International Holding Ltd plummeted 90% after chairwoman Lo Ching was detained by Chinese police. The company stated that it became aware of her detention on July 5 and that business operations had not been affected. Lo is also chairwoman of Jiangsu Boxin Investing & Holdings Co, which fell 10% in Shanghai. Camsing's shares traded at their lowest since 2015, and trading volume was unusually high. This is the second Hong Kong stock to experience a sharp decline after a senior figure was detained by Chinese police.

site_title: Deutsche Bank axes whole teams in Asia-Pacific as 18,000 job cuts begin
summary: Deutsche Bank has begun a major restructuring, laying off 18,000 jobs globally, including 10-15% of its Asia-Pacific staff, as part of a 7.4 billion euro overhaul. The bank is scaling back its investment bank, scrapping its global equities business, and cutting fixed income operations. Job losses started in Europe and the US, but also affected Sydney, Hong Kong, and Singapore, with teams being axed across the board. The bank aims to create a leaner, more profitable, and more innovative entity, with CEO Christian Sewing calling it a "restart".

site_title: Thailand not happy with hot money: central bank chief
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, expressed dissatisfaction with "hot money" flowing into the country, which has driven the baht's 5.7% appreciation against the dollar this year. The strong currency is attributed to a weak dollar, foreign fund inflows, and Thailand's large current account surplus. The Bank of Thailand has taken action to curb excessive moves in the currency, but not for competitive advantage in trade, according to Santiprabhob.

site_title: Asian markets hit as US jobs data dent hopes for big rate cut
summary: Asian markets retreated Monday as a strong US jobs report dashed hopes for a US interest rate cut this month. The Federal Reserve's data showed the US economy created more jobs than expected in June, reducing the chances of a rate cut. The dollar gained against its peers, with Asian markets falling 1.8-2.4% and the dollar up 3% on the Turkish lira. Investors now focus on Fed boss Jerome Powell's congressional testimony and the release of Fed meeting minutes for forward guidance.

site_title: Tritech to raise S$1m via share placement
summary: TRITECH Group is raising S$1 million through a share placement of 34.5 million shares at 2.9 cents apiece. The net proceeds will be used for working capital. Four individuals, including Tan Chin Tuan, will subscribe for shares, with Ng Siew Kee and Goh Jee Mui subscribing for 12.1 million shares each. The exercise will not affect the group's enlarged share capital.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters take their message to Chinese tourists
summary: Hong Kong protesters held another march on Sunday, marking the first major action since a group broke into the legislature last week. The protests, sparked by a contentious extradition bill, have drawn up to 2 million people, with about 230,000 attending Sunday's event. The protests have been mostly peaceful, with some violent confrontations between police and demonstrators. The ongoing unrest continues to raise concerns about the situation in Hong Kong and its implications for the city's relations with China.

site_title: Museum starts 'live' restoration of Rembrandt masterpiece
summary: Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum is launching the largest restoration of Rembrandt's "The Night Watch", a 1642 masterpiece, with a multi-million-euro project dubbed "Operation Night Watch". The painting will be restored live in a glass cage, with the work streamed online for global viewers. The restoration aims to preserve the painting for the future, addressing changes noticed in the painting, including a white haze appearing on parts, especially near knife damage. Experts will use high-resolution photography and computer analysis to determine the best restoration techniques, with the project set to begin on July 8, 2019.

site_title: Gates says Steve Jobs cast 'spells' to keep Apple from dying
summary: Bill Gates described Steve Jobs as singular in his ability to take a company "on a path to die" and turn it into the world's most valuable. Gates said Jobs "cast spells" to mesmerize people and pick talent, but also acknowledged his sometimes abrasive personality. Gates praised Jobs' ability to succeed even when he failed, citing the introduction of NeXT, a computer that "completely failed." Gates also reflected on his own leadership style, admitting to micromanaging at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, but said he's "not pushing quite as insanely" as Jobs.

images.alt_text: "I was like a minor wizard because he would be casting spells, and I would see people mesmerized, but because I'm a minor wizard, the spells don't work on me," said Gates, the world's second-richest person, according to a transcript provided by the network.

site_title: Saudi carrier flyadeal ditches grounded Boeing Max for Airbus
summary: Saudi budget carrier flyadeal has withdrawn its provisional order for Boeing's grounded 737 Max jets, instead opting for an entirely Airbus fleet. The airline will operate 30 A320 NEO aircraft and has options for 20 more. Deliveries will begin in 2021. This marks another setback for Boeing, whose 737 Max fleet has been grounded since mid-March following two crashes. The decision comes as flyadeal's parent company, Saudi Arabian Airlines, also orders 65 A320 neo-type aircraft from Airbus.

images.alt_text: Saudi budget carrier flyadeal has withdrawn a provisional order for Boeing's grounded 737 Max jets, the US plane maker said Sunday, as the airline confirmed it will operate an entirely Airbus fleet.

site_title: Hot stock: HMI shares jump 9.1 per cent on privatisation offer
summary: Health Management International (HMI) shares surged 9.1% on Monday after the company accepted a privatization offer by management and private equity firm EQT. The offer values HMI at approximately S$611 million, with shareholders able to receive S$0.73 in cash or one new ordinary share. Analysts have mixed views on the offer, with Maybank Kim Eng downgrading its rating to "hold" and CGS-CIMB considering it "fair but not compelling".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined at the start of trade on Monday, following a forecast-busting US jobs report that dashed hopes for a steep Federal Reserve interest rate cut this month. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.91% to 28,513.14, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.44% to 2,997.81. The decline was attributed to the US jobs report, which contradicted expectations of a rate cut.

site_title: Japan voters back stricter checks on tech exports to South Korea
summary: Japan's voters support stricter controls on tech exports to South Korea, with 58% approving the government's decision. The controls, which took effect Thursday, require exporters to obtain a separate license for three specialist materials vital to the Japanese tech industry. The move is seen as retaliation against South Korean court rulings holding Japanese companies liable for forced labor during World War II. The stricter checks could damage business ties between the neighbors, with South Korea scrambling to respond to the measures. Japan is also considering removing South Korea from a list of trusted export markets.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CFO lauds German economy as lender focuses on home
summary: Deutsche Bank's CFO, James von Moltke, has expressed a positive view on the German economy, citing stability and signs of growth, particularly in trade and investment. The bank is scaling back its trading businesses, focusing on its core strengths in managing cash and risk, and foreign exchange services for German corporate clients. Despite a slump in revenue, the bank expects to set aside more money for souring loans, but believes its conservative underwriting approach will serve it well. The decision marks a shift back to the bank's roots, prioritizing its home market.

site_title: State Street expands trust services in Singapore
summary: State Street has been granted a trust business licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, allowing it to expand its trustee capabilities in the country. The licence enables the company to act as a trustee for collective investment schemes offered to institutional and accredited investors. With over 250 staff in its Singapore office, State Street aims to support asset managers' growth in the retail, high-net-worth, and institutional segments. The move follows the company's significant expansion in the region, with US$32.6 trillion in assets under custody and administration and US$2.8 trillion in assets under management globally.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS lowers Singtel to 'hold' after share price rally
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its rating for Singtel from "buy" to "hold" due to the telco's recent share price rally losing steam. The analyst raised its 12-month target price to S$3.60, citing improvements in regional associates' valuations. Despite a 23% rally since January, Singtel's holding company discount is close to its five-year average, and dividend yield is below 5%. Potential catalysts for further improvements include mobile tariff hikes in India and the stabilisation of core operations in Singapore.

site_title: Oil tankers avoid Mideast refuelling hub after ship attacks; Singapore seen as possible alternative
summary: Oil tanker owners are avoiding the Middle East's main refuelling hub, Fujairah, due to a spate of attacks on vessels in the past two months, which has ratcheted up tensions and highlighted growing risks of operating in the region. Demand for ship fuel at Fujairah has waned as some tankers stay away, with traders reporting a 15% drop in sales since the May attacks. The root cause of the slump isn't clear, but insurance costs have soared and some owners turned wary of sending their carriers to the Middle East.

site_title: From boomerangs to A-bombs? Australia debates nukes
summary: Australia is considering developing its own nuclear deterrent amid a shifting global security landscape. The country's military strategists weigh the need for a nuclear deterrent due to a wobbly US alliance and increasingly bellicose China. Australia's defense forces have historically relied on a century-old alliance with the US for security guarantees and mineral exports to China for economic stability. The debate raises concerns about Australia's ability to protect its interests in the face of rising tensions with China.

site_title: Morgan Stanley turns bearish on global stocks as challenges grow
summary: Morgan Stanley has downgraded its global equities allocation to the lowest in five years, citing a worsening growth outlook and deteriorating manufacturing health worldwide. The firm expects profit forecasts to be too optimistic and believes a market that is overly optimistic about lower bond yields. Strategists prefer Japanese and European stocks over US and developing markets, and have increased allocations to Japanese government bonds. This move reflects growing concerns about a fragile global economy and the US-China trade war, with global stocks up 16% this year.

site_title: Indonesia issues tsunami warning after 6.9 magnitude quake
summary: Indonesia issued a tsunami warning after a 6.9 magnitude earthquake struck the Molucca Sea, southeast of Manado, between north Sulawesi and north Maluku islands. Residents fled their homes, with some describing panic, but there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The US Geological Survey reported the quake at a depth of 24km. A warning was issued for nearby coastal communities, with officials advising residents to stay away from the beach and rivers.

site_title: Oil extends gains, supported by surprise US jobs report
summary: Crude oil prices rose on Monday, adding to gains from the previous session, driven by a better-than-expected US jobs report. Brent crude futures rose 10 cents, or 0.2%, to $64.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rose 14 cents, or 0.2%, to $57.65 a barrel. However, gains were tempered by concerns over the prolonged Sino-US trade war and its impact on global economic growth and oil demand.

site_title: WeWork looking to raise US$3b to US$4b in debt ahead of IPO: source
summary: WeWork Cos is seeking to raise $3 billion to $4 billion in debt before its IPO, aiming to boost investor confidence. The debt facility could grow to $10 billion over the next few years, potentially surpassing the IPO. This move may help fuel investor confidence in the company, which is set to go public. A WeWork spokesman declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: In Yakutia, Russia digs for diamonds in permafrost
summary: In Yakutia, Russia, diamond mining operations continue in the permanently frozen ground, with the Alrosa group, the world's largest diamond producer, employing most of the region's 35,000 inhabitants. The company faces criticism for alleged environmental damage, including polluting water supplies, but is making efforts to demonstrate its work. The region's extreme climate, with temperatures dropping to -55 degrees Celsius, requires the use of explosives to extract diamonds. The operating mines are expected to remain exploitable until 2041, with the company planning to reopen the abandoned Mirny mine in 2024.

site_title: Guaido says talks with Venezuela government to resume, move to Barbados
summary: Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido has announced that talks with the government of President Nicolas Maduro will resume in Barbados, following a previous breakdown in negotiations in Norway. The talks, which will be the third round since May, aim to find a solution to the country's economic and political crises. Guaido wants the talks to lead to Maduro's departure and the establishment of a transitional government, followed by free elections with international observers. Maduro's government has suggested talks will resume this week, while some opposition lawmakers have criticized dialogue as a means for Maduro to "buy time."

site_title: Brazil pays homage to 'greatest artist' Gilberto
summary: Brazil paid tribute to its "greatest artist," Joao Gilberto, a pioneering bossa nova musician who died July 7, aged 88. Gilberto's haunting rendition of "The Girl From Ipanema" has stood the test of time, with singer Caetano Veloso calling him Brazil's greatest artist. The country's music world, from big names to ordinary citizens, honored Gilberto with heartfelt tributes. Gilberto's legacy continues to be celebrated 60 years after his iconic song was recorded.

site_title: Australia job ads rebound in June, trend still weak
summary: Australian job advertisements rebounded 4.6% in June after a 8.4% decline in May, with total job ads averaging 159,717 per week, 9.1% lower than last year. This partial recovery doesn't indicate a turn in the downward trend, with employment growth still expected to slow and unemployment rising. The Reserve Bank of Australia may lower interest rates again, with financial futures predicting a cash rate of 0.75% by Christmas.

site_title: Alternative risk transfer taking insurance industry by storm
summary: Alternative risk transfer (ART) solutions are gaining popularity in the commercial insurance market, with a 410% growth in available alternative capital over the past decade. ART protects revenue streams rather than physical assets, addressing business interruption losses not covered by traditional insurance. Parametrics, a type of ART, pay out based on predetermined triggers, such as weather conditions, without requiring physical losses. Companies like Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS) are using parametrics to open avenues for insurance to clients and provide revenue protection, making seemingly unviable projects viable. ART accounts for 20% of AGCS' gross written premium and offers investors risk diversification benefits.

site_title: KLW Holdings auditor includes emphasis of matters for fiscal 2019 results
summary: KLW Holdings' independent auditor, Baker Tilly TFW, has included an emphasis of matters in its report on the door-maker's fiscal 2019 results. The auditor highlighted uncertainty over ongoing legal claims and a Singapore investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department. The company's directors believe there are no liabilities to be recognized and the investigation should not impact financial statements. This is not the first time KLW has faced legal issues, with a claim of S$7.8 million filed by an investor in 2023. The company's shares closed flat at 0.4 Singapore cents on Friday.

site_title: After Deutsche Bank cuts, where will the growth be?
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to focus on corporate banking, foreign exchange, deal-making, asset management, and private banking as part of its restructuring plan, aiming to produce 7.4 billion euros in charges from cutting its trading arm. The bank aims to build on its strengths in transaction banking and retain a focus on advising on M&A deals and bond issuances. However, finding steady revenue streams will be challenging due to fierce competition and technological changes. Deutsche plans to invest 13 billion euros in technology by 2022 to update legacy IT systems and keep up with fintech innovation.

site_title: Oil giant Total's chief announces new unit to invest in forests
summary: Total's CEO, Patrick Pouyanne, announced a new unit to invest $100 million annually in forest preservation and reforestation projects. He cited reforestation as a cost-effective method to combat climate change, stating it can capture two-thirds of man-made carbon emissions. Pouyanne emphasized the project's long-term goals, contrasting it with philanthropy, and emphasized the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and leave fossil fuels behind.

site_title: Rapinoe calls for action as equal pay chants greet US World Cup triumph
summary: US women's soccer team wins World Cup, with Megan Rapinoe calling for action on equal pay after chants from fans urging the team to prioritize pay equity. Rapinoe, who scored the opening goal, has been a key figure in the team's fight for equal pay, and her coach Jill Ellis praised her eloquence and leadership. Despite winning the tournament, Rapinoe avoided discussing a potential White House visit and instead emphasized the need for the team to focus on achieving equal pay.

site_title: China's June foreign currency reserves rise to highest since April 2018
summary: China's foreign currency reserves rose to $3.119 trillion in June, the highest level since April 2018, according to the People's Bank of China. This marks the second consecutive month of increase, driven by potential capital inflows and positive valuation effects. Foreign investors bought at least $14.7 billion of Chinese bonds in June, and US long-term Treasury yields dropped, further supporting the valuation effect. Analysts attribute the rise to increased inclusion of A shares in global indices and expanded Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor quotas.

site_title: Japan machinery orders fall most in 8 months in worrying sign for economy
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 7.8% in May, the largest drop in eight months, casting doubt on the economy's prospects. This decline could hurt wage growth and inflation goals, as policymakers rely on domestic demand to offset external pressures from the US-China trade war and slowing global demand. Capital expenditure, a bright spot in the economy, may slow sharply in the coming quarters, with economists warning that resilience is unlikely to last. A sales tax hike in October may further dampen consumer spending.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stocks opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 3.65 points to 1,678.88. The market saw 97.7 million lots traded worth RM32.6 million, with 108 gainers and 95 losers.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open lower on US falls, Iran concerns
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, down 0.35% or 76.43 points at 21,669.95, due to US falls and geopolitical concerns linked to Iran. The US job data was better than expected, but triggered a pullback in Fed rate cut expectations. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index also declined, with shipping firms and Uniqlo operator Fast Retailing among the losers. The dollar fetched 108.44 yen in early Asian trade, while US stocks retreated from records.

site_title: Iran 'better be careful' on nuclear enrichment: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Iran to be cautious as it is set to breach a uranium enrichment cap of 3.67%, which is below the 90% level required for a nuclear warhead. Trump's Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that Iran will face further sanctions in response. The breach is related to the 2015 nuclear deal the US withdrew from last year.

site_title: Brazil win Copa America despite Jesus dismissal
summary: Brazil won the Copa America 3-1 against Peru at the Maracana stadium in Rio de Janeiro, securing their ninth title and first since 2007. Gabriel Jesus was dismissed, but Richarlison scored a winning penalty in the last minute. The victory marked Brazil's first Copa America title on home soil, with Everton scoring the opening goal for the hosts.

site_title: African leaders launch 'operational phase' of free trade accord
summary: African leaders launched the "operational phase" of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA), creating the world's largest free trade area. The agreement, signed by 55 nations, aims to boost intra-African trade by 60% by 2022. The operational phase includes shared rules of origin, digital payments, and trade observatory dashboards. Eritrea, the only non-signatory, has expressed interest in joining. The agreement cuts tariffs between African nations, with Nigeria and Benin's presidents signing on to applause, marking a significant milestone for the initiative.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.36% to 3,354.57
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.36% to 3,354.57, following weaker Asia performance and Wall Street's retreat on Friday. The index was influenced by declines in DBS Group Holdings, Singtel, and CapitaLand Commercial Trust. In contrast, Global Invacom Group rose 3.6% and Tritech Group fell 3.2%. The decline was part of a broader regional trend, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index down 0.35% and the US Dow ending down 0.2% amid better-than-expected US job data.

site_title: Power outage hits Venezuela's largest refinery complex: lawmaker
summary: A power outage hit Venezuela's largest refinery complex, the Amuay and Cardon complex, on Saturday night, according to opposition lawmaker Luis Stefanelli. The blackout resulted in access being closed and the refineries being taken over by the National Guard and intelligence officials. This comes at a time of acute fuel shortages in parts of the crisis-torn oil producer.

site_title: Japan bank targets comeback abroad with South-east Asia foray
summary: Concordia Financial Group Ltd, one of Japan's biggest regional banks, plans to expand in South-east Asia to offer cash management services and infrastructure loans to local entities. The bank aims to double overseas loans to over $5 billion in three years, following Japan's largest banks to make up for negative interest rates and weak loan demand at home. Concordia plans to set up a branch in Singapore as a transaction banking hub for Japanese corporate clients operating in the region, and hire specialists with overseas experience to rebuild the business abroad.

site_title: EU lists 5 fixes before Boeing 737 MAX can fly again
summary: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has outlined five major requirements for Boeing to address before the 737 MAX can return to service. The list includes fixing an autopilot function that can't disengage in some emergencies and other unspecified concerns. The FAA has also received the list, but details are not yet public. Failure to resolve these issues could delay the resumption of service, potentially increasing costs and time.

site_title: UNESCO adds Frank Lloyd Wright's architecture to World Heritage list
summary: UNESCO has added eight major works designed by Frank Lloyd Wright to the World Heritage List, recognizing American modern architecture for the first time. The eight inscribed sites include Fallingwater, Hollyhock House, and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, among others. This recognition marks a milestone for Wright's designs, which span various American landscapes and serve as a testament to his innovative architectural style. The designation was announced at the World Heritage Committee meeting in Baku, Azerbaijan.

images.alt_text: Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater in Mill Run, Pennsylvania. The building is among eight buildings designed by Frank Lloyd Wright that have been added to Unesco's World Heritage List.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Tackling an ageing population & trade relations: Japanese ambassador
summary: Singapore and Japan share 53 years of diplomatic relations, with Japanese Ambassador Jun Yamazaki discussing trade relations and Japan's ageing population on the Money FM podcast. Yamazaki highlighted the importance of bilateral trade and Japan's efforts to address its ageing population. The conversation also touched on the G-20 Osaka Summit, where Yamazaki noted Japan's focus on economic growth and regional stability.

site_title: Venezuela opposition says it will meet Maduro envoys in Norway-mediated talks
summary: Venezuela's opposition, led by Juan Guaido, will meet with Maduro's government envoys in Norway-mediated talks in Barbados. The talks aim to resolve the ongoing crisis, with Guaido stating that any negotiations must lead to a sustained solution and not be used to buy time. The opposition has expressed skepticism about the talks, citing previous failed efforts. The Norway-mediated talks follow a stalemate in the crisis, with the opposition agreeing to hold talks after months of resistance. The outcome of the talks remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Opposition leader Juan Guaido, who has been recognised as Venezuela's rightful leader by more than 50 governments, has said any talks must lead to a sustained solution to the crisis and cannot be used by the Socialist Party to buy time.

site_title: Oil minister Zanganeh says hopeful Iran's oil exports will improve: TV
summary: Iran's oil minister Bijan Zanganeh expressed hope for an improvement in the country's crude exports despite US sanctions, stating that the price of oil is not his main concern. Iran's oil exports dropped to 300,000 barrels per day in June, down from 2.5 million bpd in April 2018. Zanganeh blamed the US for destabilizing the oil market and said cooperation between OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers can stabilize it. Talks with Chinese companies, including Total and CNPC, are ongoing to develop Iran's South Pars gas field, despite US sanctions.

site_title: Jho Low's 1MDB-linked yacht available to rent for US$1.25m a week: paper
summary: A 300-foot yacht previously owned by Malaysia's fugitive financier Jho Low is available for rent at $1.25 million per week. The yacht, called Tranquility, was seized in Indonesian waters and sold to casino company Genting Malaysia Bhd for $126 million in April. The vessel features luxurious amenities, including a gym, massage room, and plunge pool. It arrived at the French Riviera on July 1 from Singapore via Sri Lanka, marking its first time in the area since its sale.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KLW, HMI, Hoe Leong, SIA Engineering, Thai Beverage
summary: KLW Holdings' independent auditor included an emphasis of matters in its report due to ongoing legal claims and an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department. HMI announced a joint bid to privatize the company for approximately S$611 million. HMI shares closed flat at S$0.66 on Friday.

site_title: UK housing prices dip but there are signs of optimism: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell 0.3% in June to £237,110, despite Brexit uncertainty. Demand for housing stabilised, with agreed sales falling for 10th consecutive month, but sentiment on longer-term outlook showed modest recovery. A shortage of homes, record employment, and low borrowing costs are supporting values, putting a floor under prices.

site_title: The house that Jean built - carved out of a rock face in Monaco
summary: Architects Jean-Pierre Lott and Patrick Raymond built a luxury "eco" villa in Monaco, carved out of a rock face, using sustainable materials and technologies. The 220 sqm, six-floor villa, known as "Villa Troglodyte," features three bedrooms, three bathrooms, and a swimming pool. Completed with cork insulation, water recycling, and solar panels, the villa aims to optimize energy and costs. Built inside a 10th-century cliff, it showcases a unique and eco-friendly living space in the luxurious principality of Monaco.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts Q2 loss, launches 7.4b euro overhaul
summary: Deutsche Bank posts a net loss of 2.8 billion euros in Q2, exiting its equities business as part of a 7.4 billion euro overhaul to boost profitability. The lender will cut 18,000 jobs by 2022, reducing capital buffer and shelving dividends this year and next. CEO Christian Sewing aims to address high costs and low revenue, following failed previous turnarounds. The overhaul will also see 74 billion euros of risk-weighted assets become part of a new non-core unit, avoiding shareholder taps.

site_title: EU's Juncker hails Greek conservatives' election win
summary: Outgoing European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker congratulated Greece's conservative opposition leader Kyriakos Mitsotakis on his landslide election win over leftist Alexis Tsipras. Mitsotakis, who opposed austerity measures, will replace Tsipras as Greek prime minister. Juncker, who headed the EU executive during Greece's financial bailout, praised Mitsotakis' victory, which marks a shift towards a more conservative government in Greece.

images.alt_text: Outgoing European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker congratulated Greece's conservative opposition leader Kyriakos Mitsotakis on Sunday for his landslide election win over leftist Alexis Tsipras.

site_title: Trade war to dent US Q2, Q3 growth but potential lies in 'compounders'
summary: The US-China trade war is expected to slow US economic growth by 0.2% in the second and third quarters, according to T. Rowe Price portfolio specialist Julian Cook. The trade tensions, which intensified in May, have already imposed additional tariffs on each other's imports. However, Cook believes the US economy remains resilient, with growth already tipped to be lower in 2019 due to its nearing economic cycle. The US market is expected to take a conservative tone, with most opportunities in healthcare, consumer discretionary, and technology sectors.

site_title: Milan real estate prices surge as funds buy in
summary: Global investors are snapping up prime office buildings in Milan, driving up prices to new highs. The city's lack of development and scarcity of prime real estate in Western Europe are fueling the surge. Billionaire families, investment firms, and sovereign wealth funds are closing deals, including the Rovati family, Amundi SA, and Invesco Real Estate. Monthly rents reached 585 euros per square meter, up 1.7% from last year, while vacancy rates declined by about half a percentage point. The city's prime capital values lag behind Paris, with a 50% discount.

site_title: The need for universal legislation on whistleblowing
summary: Singapore lacks a universal whistleblowing law, leaving many whistleblowers unprotected. Existing legislation only covers specific groups, such as those reporting corruption or workplace safety issues. Whistleblowers on general wrongdoing or harassment are not protected, and anonymity is not guaranteed. A general whistleblowing law is needed to cover various types of improper conduct, provide unified protection, and prevent retaliation. Such a law would encourage good corporate governance and behavior, and protect whistleblowers without fear of reprisal.

site_title: Great time for billionaires to splurge on real estate
summary: US luxury property prices are experiencing a correction, with many billionaires taking advantage of discounts. The decline in prices is partly due to fewer lavishly-spending foreigners, with 64% of buyers this year being American. Brokers report that ultra-rich buyers are looking for refined features, such as turnkey art collections, rather than lavish amenities. This shift is evident in the LA market, where properties are being marketed with lower prices and a focus on finished and polished interiors.

site_title: STI adds to gains; more than 70 acquisitions/disposals filed
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.3% from June 28 to July 4, with a total return of 12.2% for the year. Nine primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, totaling S$10.7 million. Notable transactions include Indofood Agri Resources' acquisition of 64,280,100 shares, and executive director Eric Khua's acquisition of 593,100 shares of Vibrant Group. Other transactions include CNMC Goldmine Holdings' disposal of 4 million shares, and LY Corporation's acquisition of 59,000 shares. The ST Group Food Industries debuted on Catalist with a placement of 30,077,000 shares.

site_title: Fresh clashes in Hong Kong after huge march to China station
summary: Fresh clashes broke out in Hong Kong on Sunday as riot police baton-charged protesters, despite a massive rally earlier in the day aimed at explaining the protest movement to mainland Chinese tourists. Tens of thousands marched to a train station linking the finance hub to mainland China, but clashes erupted when hundreds refused to leave. The extradition bill has been suspended, but public anger continues to grow, with protesters demanding democratic reforms, an end to sliding freedoms, and the resignation of the city's leader.

images.alt_text: Fresh political violence broke out in Hong Kong on Sunday night as riot police baton-charged anti-government protesters seeking to keep the pressure up on the city's pro-Beijing leaders, after a mass rally outside a train station linking the finance hub to mainland China.

site_title: M1's beneficiaries treated to Cirque du Soleil show
summary: M1 Limited, a Singaporean telecommunications company, celebrated its 20-year partnership with Cirque du Soleil by hosting a special show for 650 children from its adopted charities. The children attended a preview of the show "KURIOS - Cabinet of Curiosities" on July 4, 2019, at Bayfront Avenue. M1's gesture was seen as a positive impact on the children's lives, with charities expressing gratitude for the company's support and commitment to the community.

images.alt_text: Cirque du Soleil members with M1's young beneficiaries.

site_title: China's EXIM bank chief urges faster yuan globalisation
summary: China's Export-Import Bank chief, Hu Xiaolian, urges faster yuan globalisation due to rising global protectionism and retaliatory tariffs in the US-China trade war. She warns that external risks could harm the financial sector, which is critical for globalisation. Hu calls for reforms to increase the yuan's competitiveness, modernise financial institutions, and expand financial opening and innovation. The call comes as China's central bank takes steps to make interest rates more market-oriented, and amid concerns about the internationalisation of the yuan, which has been hindered since 2016 due to stricter government controls.

site_title: Germany faces pressure to spend as economic risks grow in Europe
summary: Germany faces pressure to increase spending amid growing economic risks in Europe due to trade tensions and Brexit uncertainty. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire urged Germany to invest in innovation and infrastructure, citing the negative impact of global trade uncertainty on economic growth. A slump in German factory orders and a potential slowdown in Europe's economy have led to concerns at the European Central Bank, which may need to take action before newly nominated head Christine Lagarde takes over in October.

site_title: Investors to digest effects of US job data
summary: US job data beat expectations, with nonfarm payrolls rising 224,000 in June, leading investors to expect a smaller interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Asian equity markets, including Singapore's, will digest this information, as well as US-China trade talks resuming by phone. Singapore's advance GDP figures for the second quarter are also expected, which could reveal the effects of heightened US-China tariffs.

site_title: 'Spider-Man' flies again, leading North America box office
summary: "Spider-Man: Far From Home" took in $93.6 million in North America over the US holiday weekend, passing the half-billion-dollar mark worldwide. The film, made by Sony and Disney-owned Marvel, follows Spider-Man (Tom Holland) and Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) as they confront a world without Iron Man. The six-day total for the Tuesday release was a record $185.1 million, marking a new milestone for the Spider-Man franchise.

site_title: Iran set to breach 2015 uranium enrichment limit
summary: Iran plans to breach the 2015 uranium enrichment limit of 3.67% in the coming hours, a move that could lead to the return of all international sanctions on Tehran. French President Emmanuel Macron and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have condemned the decision, calling for punitive measures. Iran claims it is willing to show flexibility and will keep reducing its commitments every 60 days unless European signatories protect it from US sanctions. The move is seen as a test of European diplomacy and a challenge to Washington, which withdrew from the nuclear deal last year.

site_title: US okays SoftBank's US$2.25b stake in GM's self-driving unit
summary: The US Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) has approved a $2.25 billion investment by Japan's SoftBank in General Motors' self-driving unit, Cruise. The investment, which unlocks a seat on Cruise's board, was made after SoftBank provided assurances that Cruise's technology would be off-limits. The approval comes amid US scrutiny of SoftBank's ties to Chinese firms, particularly its investments in Chinese ride-hailing firm Didi and social media giant Tencent. The deal cements key financing for Cruise and is one of the largest investments in self-driving technology to date.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights a surge in the Capesize market, with the Baltic Dry Index reaching $26,444, a week-on-week increase of $7,084. The Atlantic Basin saw a significant rise, driven by Black Sea iron ore fronthaul cargoes, while the Pacific Basin followed suit, with gains on the West Australia to China C5 route. The forward curve for derivatives indicates market uncertainty, but the Atlantic remains tight on tonnage. Other segments, including Panamax, Supramax/Ultramax, and Handysize, also experienced gains, with the Supramax Index rising due to increased pressure from key areas in the Atlantic.

site_title: Insurers keeping annual bonus rates unchanged
summary: Insurers are maintaining annual bonus rates for traditional life insurance policies despite a poor showing among life funds in 2018. The "smoothing" mechanism shields policyholders from volatility, but life funds themselves are subject to market swings. Six insurers reported negative returns in 2018, with only one, Income, showing a gain. Insurers are adjusting terminal bonuses and maintaining or cutting projected reversionary bonus rates. Prudential and Aviva are adjusting terminal bonuses, while Income is declaring higher-than-expected special bonuses. Insurers aim to encourage long-term commitment to policies.

site_title: New chapter in Singapore banking
summary: Singapore's digital banking landscape is set to expand with the introduction of new licenses. Experts predict that digital banks will bring innovative products and delivery channels, increasing consumer choice and driving competition among traditional banks. To succeed, digital banks must manage risks such as money laundering and terrorist financing, while also providing seamless and secure services. The impact is expected to be positive, creating more consumer choice and driving continuous improvements among banks. However, risks include irresponsible pricing and unsustainable business models. Regulators and banks must work together to address these challenges and ensure a secure and trustworthy digital banking environment.

site_title: Certis partners BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: Singapore's security services provider Certis partners with The Business Times Budding Artists Fund to launch "Community Give-Back", a programme empowering disadvantaged children and youth through arts. Over 12 months, 100 Certis volunteers and 60 youth participants will engage in art and digital technology activities for 150 beneficiaries from four charity organisations. The programme aims to give back to the community through the talents of the youth. Certis presented a S$30,000 cheque to support the initiative.

site_title: Insurer AGCS 'seeing a much-stronger increase in premiums' for 2019
summary: Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS) expects a firmer rise in insurance premiums for 2019, following a marginal increase in 2018. CEO Chris Fischer Hirs attributes this to a benign claims environment, overcapacity in the market, and stiff competition. It will take 2-3 years to restore the risk-reward balance, and some clients will face premium increases of 50-70%. AGCS reported a 24% drop in operating profit in the first quarter, despite a 23% rise in net premiums earned.

site_title: US soybean farmers struggling even as prices recover
summary: US soybean farmers continue to struggle despite soybean prices recovering from China-imposed tariffs. Chicago futures returned above levels of 12 months ago, driven by record rain and recent gains, but remain below pre-trade tensions levels. A disease affecting hogs in China further clouds demand, and a long recovery for growers is expected. The US-China trade tensions began escalating one year ago on July 7, 2019.

site_title: PropNex extends market lead on steady demand
summary: PropNex Ltd., a Singapore-listed real estate services group, has extended its market lead on steady demand.
