summary: Singapore's HDB resale market saw a 8.7% decrease in sales in June, with 1,895 flats sold, compared to 2,076 in May and 1,991 in the same month last year. Resale prices inched up 0.1% in June. The decrease in sales volume was attributed to a 4.8% drop compared to the same month last year.

site_title: Jakarta residents sue Indonesia government over air pollution
summary: Residents of Jakarta, Indonesia's capital, have filed a lawsuit against the government over toxic air pollution that has plagued the city for a month. The lawsuit, filed by 31 concerned residents, seeks to force the government to act on the issue. Air quality readings have recorded high concentrations of PM2.5, making Jakarta the most polluted city in the world for several mornings. The plaintiffs claim the government has neglected people's rights to breathe healthy air, and the lawsuit aims to raise awareness and pressure the government to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Residents of Indonesia's capital on Thursday filed a lawsuit against the government over the toxic levels of air pollution that regularly blanket the city.

site_title: Asia: Markets track record lead from Wall Street, focus on jobs
summary: Asian markets rose on July 4, 2019, tracking a record performance on Wall Street, as investors awaited US jobs data and a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The US stock market closed at all-time highs, with investors seeking central bank support amid weak economic indicators. The yield on 10-year Treasuries fell below 2%, and investors are hopeful for a rate cut, which would disrupt the US consumer and support further rate cuts.

site_title: Weak Australian retail sales, job slowdown point to third RBA rate cut
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.1% in May, below forecasts, and job vacancies fell 1.1% in the same period, indicating a slowdown in the economy. The weak data supports expectations of a third interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia, with markets pricing in a 90% chance of a 0.75% cut before Christmas. The central bank's previous rate cuts were aimed at reviving growth and inflation, but the economy is expected to operate with excess capacity for longer than previously expected.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at over 11-yr peak on rate-cut hopes, NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares reached an 11-year high on Thursday, rising 0.5% to 6,718.0, driven by expectations of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and local banks. The benchmark rose for a fourth consecutive session, with financial stocks leading gains, particularly the big four banks. New Zealand stocks also reached a record close, driven by Australian bank stocks. The rally is attributed to policy easing making government debt less attractive, driving money into higher-yielding assets like equities.

site_title: JPMorgan fund manager says always buy the dip in emerging markets
summary: JPMorgan emerging-market fund manager Leon Eidelman advocates for "buying the dip" strategy, citing dollar weakness and dovish central banks as opportunities to invest in Indian lenders, Chinese insurance companies, and Latin American financial technology firms. He highlights HDFC Bank, AIA Group, and Ping An Insurance Group as potential winners, while MercadoLibre and PagSeguro Digital offer opportunities to bet on technology growth in the region. Eidelman believes businesses need to invest in digital infrastructure, positioning his fund for long-term gains.

site_title: Von der Leyen to present EU 'vision' within fortnight
summary: European Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen plans to present her vision for the EU within two weeks, after being nominated by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Von der Leyen, a 14-year veteran of the German government, must first be approved by the European Parliament in a mid-July vote before taking over from outgoing Commission Chief Jean-Claude Juncker.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.90 points to 1,688.15 at 9am on Thursday, with volume reaching 85.13 million lots worth RM13.81 million. Gainers outpaced losers 118 to 41.

site_title: Top Australian banks join IBM, Scentre in blockchain project
summary: Australia's top three banks, Westpac, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, partnered with IBM and Scentre Group to test blockchain technology for digitizing bank guarantees. The eight-week pilot aims to reduce processing time and fraud risk, with the technology having potential to benefit various sectors. Blockchain is being explored for its ability to automate data sharing, verification, and permanent recording, following its growing traction among mainstream businesses.

images.alt_text: Australia's top three banks said on Thursday they have agreed to partner with IBM and shopping mall owner Scentre Group to test blockchain technology to digitise bank guarantees.

site_title: 'Victims and perpetrators': Rehabilitating Indonesia's child bombers
summary: In Indonesia, a unique rehabilitation program is being implemented to treat children of terror suspects, including those involved in suicide bombings. Nine-year-old Mila, a survivor of a family suicide bombing, is among a small group being treated at a Jakarta safe house with psychological and social care. The program aims to re-socialize the children, teaching them about Indonesia's national heroes and Pancasila ideology, and help them cope with the trauma of their families' extremist actions. Experts say successful rehabilitation requires support in assimilating back into society, but extended families' reluctance to take in the children could trigger a return to extremism.

site_title: Australia: Shares surge to highest since Nov 2007; New Zealand at another peak
summary: Australian shares surged to their highest in over 11 years, reaching 6,729.60, as US economic weakness raised expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.7% with financial stocks leading gains, particularly the Big Four banks. New Zealand shares also reached record highs, with the S&P/NZX 50 index climbing 0.2%. The surge is attributed to US trade deficit data showing a five-month high and services sector slowdown, fueling hopes of a rate cut.

site_title: 34 employees trapped in Canadian potash mine
summary: A total of 34 employees performing maintenance on a Canadian potash mine were trapped for approximately 24 hours after a service shaft breakdown at the Cory mine in Saskatchewan. The workers are safely underground and on stand-down, and a company spokesman says it's not a rescue operation, but rather getting the shafts operating again in a safe and practical manner. Teams on site are working to resolve the issue.

site_title: Trump administration loses bid to lift bar on funds for border wall
summary: A US federal appeals court refused to lift an injunction barring the Trump administration from using $2.5 billion for the fight against illegal narcotics to build a border wall, dealing another setback to President Trump's border wall construction efforts. The court ruled that Congress did not appropriate money for the wall, and it is not for the court to decide otherwise. The decision upholds a lower court ruling that blocked the use of funds for the wall.

site_title: China says African swine fever outbreaks slowing
summary: China has seen a significant drop in fresh outbreaks of African swine fever, with 44 new cases reported in the first six months of 2019, according to Vice-Agriculture Minister Yu Kangzhen. This marks a decline from previous months, with pig production gradually returning to normal. African swine fever is deadly to pigs and has affected China, the world's top pork producer, since August last year, causing significant economic pressure on the country's agricultural sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,376.77, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,376.77, up 0.3% on the day, with the Straits Times Index gaining 8.97 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 128, driven by Addvalue Tech's 17.4% gain and Spackman's 11.1% rise. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats. The STI reached a new high, surpassing the $3,300 mark, as investors stay positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Rich Capital: S$2m advance payment guarantee from associate on hold
summary: Rich Capital, a Catalist-listed property developer, has put on hold a S$2 million advance payment guarantee from associate Rich-Link Construction (RLC) pending "new developments" in RLC's solution to repay the amount owed. This move would render the guarantee unnecessary, addressing concerns raised by auditors regarding the company's going concern issue. The decision aims to alleviate working capital pressures.

site_title: Fixed deposits beat out Singapore Savings Bonds
summary: Retail investors' interest in Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) has declined due to competition from banks offering higher rates for fixed deposits. The total applied amounts for SSBs in May and June were S$274.5 million and S$275.4 million, respectively, down from S$400 million in previous months. Higher fixed-deposit rates from banks, with some offering up to 2% for 12-month deposits, may be a contributing factor. The 1.68% interest rate offered by SSBs is also considered low, and demand may ease further if short-term yields fall below 2%.

site_title: Tornado hits northeast China as more 'extreme' weather strikes
summary: A tornado struck northeast China's Liaoning province on Wednesday, killing six and injuring 190, amid a series of "extreme" weather events linked to climate change. The tornado damaged 3,600 homes and affected 9,900 residents in Kaiyuan. Climate change is being blamed for increased extreme weather events, including record-breaking rainfall and temperatures, with China's weather bureau warning of further heatwaves and droughts in the region.

site_title: Thailand wants to restrain the world's strongest currency
summary: Thailand's central bank is concerned about the baht's surge, which has climbed 8.6% against the dollar in the past year, making it the world's strongest currency. The Bank of Thailand is considering possible measures, including an interest-rate cut, to address the issue. The central bank has already cut its economic growth forecasts and left borrowing costs at 1.75% due to the US-China trade war and the currency's climb, which has dimmed the outlook for the export-reliant nation. Proper timing and data dependence are key factors in the central bank's decision-making process.

site_title: Unstoppable Hong Kong dollar surges to strongest in two years
summary: The Hong Kong dollar surged to its strongest level in two years, reaching 7.7855 against the US dollar, due to tight liquidity and elevated borrowing costs. The currency jumped into the strong half of its trading band for the first time since September, as the one-month interbank rate climbed to the highest in over a decade. The move is seen as undermining a popular trade that had pushed the city's currency to the weak end of its trading band.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering: Able to continue as going concern; shares should not be suspended
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering, a Singapore-listed company providing engineering and plant-related services, has reassured the Singapore Exchange that it can continue as a going concern. Despite net current liabilities of S$20 million, the company's cash-flow projections indicate sufficient liquidity for the next three years. Hiap Seng is actively exploring additional equity funding and expects to secure more projects with better margins in the future, generating enough funds to cover operational needs. Its directors have concluded that its shares should not be suspended from trading.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records ahead of July 4 holiday
summary: US stocks closed at records on July 3, 2019, ahead of the Independence Day holiday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7% to 26,961.52, while the S&P 500 gained 0.8% to 2,995.53, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.8% to 8,170.23. The gains were attributed to mixed US economic data that boosted the odds of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. Markets closed early in anticipation of the holiday and will reopen on Friday.

site_title: Broadcom said to be in talks to buy Symantec
summary: Broadcom is in advanced discussions to acquire Symantec, a cybersecurity software company, for over $15 billion. The deal would be Broadcom's second major acquisition in the software industry, following its $19 billion purchase of CA Technologies last year. The acquisition strategy shift comes after the Trump administration blocked Broadcom's bid to purchase Qualcomm in 2018 due to national security concerns. Broadcom's CEO, Tan Hock Eng, has a history of acquiring mature companies with stable cash flows, and the acquisition would be a significant move to expand Broadcom's presence in the cybersecurity market.

site_title: Biggest tax shake-up in a decade will benefit 10m Australians
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison secured the votes needed to enact the most sweeping tax changes in over a decade, providing A$158 billion in income tax relief to over 10 million workers. The legislation, set to become law, includes immediate rebates of up to A$1,080 for low- and middle-income earners and will phase in new streamlined brackets by 2024-25, ensuring 94% of Australians pay 30% or less income tax. The tax cuts aim to stimulate the slowing economy, with the Reserve Bank of Australia urging stronger policy action to address record household debt and tumbling housing prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Wall Street records
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on July 4, 2019, following record gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.48% to 21,742.39, while the Topix index gained 0.47% to 1,587.03. This positive lead from US markets suggests investors are optimistic about global economic trends.

site_title: Tharman on shortlist as Lagarde departure stirs succession speculation at IMF
summary: Christine Lagarde's expected departure as IMF leader has sparked succession speculation, with European officials nominating her to succeed Mario Draghi at the European Central Bank. The next IMF director will face economic challenges, including slowing global growth and trade tensions. Traditionally, the World Bank leader is American, but there's speculation that the US might break with this practice. Early shortlists include Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Agustín Carstens, Mohamed El-Erian, and Mark Carney, who could face opposition from the US and require international coalition support.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises 3b euros in debut eurobond issue
summary: Saudi Arabia successfully raised 3 billion euros (S$4.6 billion) in its debut euro-denominated bond sale, the finance ministry announced. The move aims to plug a budget deficit, as the petro-state has posted deficits since oil prices crashed in 2014. This marks a shift from previously issuing bonds denominated in dollars, as Saudi Arabia taps new funds to address its budget shortfall.

site_title: Northern Chinese province issues 'red alert' due to heat, corn crop at risk
summary: The northern Chinese province of Hebei has issued a 'red alert' due to extreme heat, with temperatures expected to soar beyond 40°C in major cities, posing a risk to the corn crop. Climate change is exacerbating the situation, with rainfall declining 23.9% in the second quarter of 2019. The heat wave is expected to last until next week, and cities are deploying sprinklers to try to keep temperatures down, putting further pressure on water supplies. Hebei is one of China's biggest producers of corn, and the extreme weather conditions are a concern for the grain's production.

site_title: Australia job vacancies fall 1.1% in May quarter
summary: Australia's job vacancies fell 1.1% in the March-May quarter, the first decline since 2016, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Private sector vacancies dropped 1.6% to 219,400, while public sector vacancies rose 3.8% to 22,100. The decline suggests the country's economy is losing momentum, contradicting the Reserve Bank of Australia's optimism on continued jobs growth sparking wage inflation.

site_title: Trump warns Iran threats will 'come back to bite you'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Iran that its threats could "come back to bite you" after Tehran vowed to exceed the maximum uranium enrichment level allowed by a 2015 nuclear accord. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani said the move was in response to the US's failure to provide relief from crippling sanctions. The enrichment limit, set in the agreement, is sufficient for power generation but far below the level required for a nuclear weapon. Trump's warning comes amid escalating tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Oil prices climb as US equities rally, rig count drops
summary: US oil prices rose ahead of a US holiday, driven by strength in the US equities market and a decline in the number of oil rigs operating for the first time in three weeks. The major US stock indexes closed at record highs, with expectations that the Federal Reserve would take a more dovish stance due to slowing economy data. Opec's decision to extend crude output cuts was seen as a factor in the price increase, but concerns about a global economy slowdown still weighed on oil prices.

site_title: US reviews export requests to Huawei with 'highest scrutiny': US Commerce Dept
summary: The US Commerce Department is reviewing export requests to Huawei under the "highest national security scrutiny" after President Trump's surprise announcement to allow US companies to sell products to the Chinese firm. The department is applying the "presumption of denial" standard, making it unlikely that applications will be approved. Huawei was placed on the Entity List in May due to national security concerns. The review is part of the US government's efforts to assess whether US companies can safely export products to the Chinese company.

site_title: United States makes first-ever rice sale to China: trade group
summary: US private importer Sun Valley Rice sold 40 tonnes of medium-grain rice to China, marking the first-ever US rice sale to the country. The sale comes amid a trade war between the two nations, with China previously buying major US exports like soybeans and pork. The rice deal follows a 544,000-tonne soybean sale confirmed last week, and US officials have agreed to allow Chinese imports of US rice since 2017. The sale may lay groundwork for future US rice exports to China.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1% to 3,371.51
summary: Singapore shares edged higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 3.71 points, or 0.1%, to 3,371.51, driven by a positive US market session. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Indexes all hit new highs overnight. Locally, Addvalue Tech and SunMoonFood were among the top gainers, while ComfortDelGro and ST Group Food also made notable moves. Asian equities followed suit, with modest gains across several markets, as investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision at the end of the month.

site_title: Fashion icon Jean Paul Gaultier says he could go back on fur ban
summary: French fashion designer Jean Paul Gaultier said he could go back to using fur if it's entirely traceable. He initially renounced fur in November, citing concerns over animal treatment, but now says he's open to recycling old furs. Gaultier's first fur-free Paris haute couture show featured feathers and animal prints instead, and he emphasized the need to recycle clothes and reduce waste. He acknowledges fur has a negative image, but believes it can be done responsibly.

images.alt_text: French fashion designer Jean Paul Gaultier said Wednesday he could go back to using fur if he could be sure it was entirely traceable.

site_title: Brexit backers help PM candidate Johnson extend lead in funding battle
summary: Boris Johnson has increased his funding lead over Jeremy Hunt in the UK's Conservative Party leadership race, with the majority of donations coming from hedge funds and financiers who support Brexit. Johnson has raised £502,000 in the last year, mostly from wealthy, white, older men, while Hunt has received no additional donations in the last two weeks. Johnson's campaign has received significant backing from Brexit supporters, but his relations with traditional businesses have been strained, and some warn of a risk profile associated with his tougher stance on Brexit.

site_title: China and Britain wage war of words over Hong Kong
summary: China and Britain are engaged in a diplomatic feud over Hong Kong, with China telling Britain to "refrain from further interference" and London summoning Beijing's ambassador. The tensions have revived concerns about the "one country, two systems" approach adopted 22 years ago, which granted Hong Kong broad freedoms. The protests in Hong Kong have reignited the historic agreement, raising pressure on policymakers. The situation highlights the ongoing challenges in the Sino-British relationship and the complexities of Hong Kong's future under Chinese rule.

site_title: Lightning blamed as 45,000 whiskey barrels torched in US
summary: A lightning strike at a warehouse in Kentucky destroyed 45,000 barrels of Jim Beam whiskey, but no one was injured. The fire, which occurred at a relatively young whiskey batch, is expected to have minimal impact on the company's supply. Beam Suntory, the parent company of Jim Beam, stated that the lost whiskey is a small fraction of its total stock, and the company's supply should remain unaffected. The incident occurred at a warehouse containing 45,000 barrels of young whiskey from the Jim Beam mash bill.

site_title: Challenges ahead for Facebook's Libra
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency faces significant challenges ahead, despite its potential to transform the financial landscape. Critics argue that Libra will be Facebook's private currency, raising concerns about data privacy and regulatory pushback. The cryptocurrency's centralised nature, controlled by traditional financial intermediaries, also undermines its decentralised goals. Regulators, including the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, have expressed skepticism, with some calling for strict regulations or even a moratorium on its development. Libra's success will depend on convincing the public of its commitment to data protection and overcoming regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Singapore has varied sand sources, says MND in response to M'sia export ban
summary: Singapore imports sand from various countries, including Malaysia and India, to ensure a resilient supply due to the Malaysian export ban. The ban, imposed in October 2018, was aimed at curbing illegal sand smuggling and limiting land reclamation in Singapore. Singapore has been reducing its reliance on sand imports, with the government encouraging the industry to use alternative materials. The country's stockpiling of sand may provide a buffer against future supply bottlenecks.

site_title: France returns stolen ancient artifacts to Pakistan
summary: France has returned 445 stolen ancient artifacts to Pakistan, including busts, vases, and goblets dating back to the second and third millennia BC. The artifacts, estimated to be worth 139,000 euros, were seized by French customs officers in 2006 and 2008 after being intercepted at Paris airport. The return is part of French President Emmanuel Macron's effort to repatriate ancient artworks to their countries of origin, following similar returns to Benin, Peru, and Egypt.

site_title: North Korea says US 'hell-bent' on sanctions despite Trump-Kim meeting
summary: North Korea criticized the US for sending a letter urging countries to return North Korean workers, viewing it as an attempt to escalate tensions despite a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un. The letter was sent on June 29, the same day Trump invited Kim to meet. North Korea sees this as a sign the US is "hell-bent" on sanctions, despite promoting dialogue. The letter was signed by the US, Britain, France, and Germany.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CHIP Eng Seng Corporation's subsidiary CES Cambridge has agreed to set up an elementary school in Singapore by early 2020 with The Perse School Cambridge International. Eagle Hospitality Trust has entered a US$341 million interest rate swap agreement with Bank of the West, lowering its borrowing cost to 3.41% per year. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EH-Reit, Addvalue Tech, Chip Eng Seng, Hiap Seng Engineering, Eneco Energy
summary:
Stocks to watch on Thursday included:

- EH-Reit, which entered into a US$341 million interest rate swap agreement with Bank of the West.
- Addvalue Technologies, which secured a minimum of US$1 million worth of its proprietary solution with an Indonesian company.
- Chip Eng Seng Corporation, which agreed to set up an elementary school in Singapore by early 2020.
- Hiap Seng Engineering, which responded to queries on its fiscal 2019 financial results, stating it should be able to continue as a going concern.
- Eneco Energy, which tapped Colin Peter Moran as its new CEO, replacing outgoing chief Aditya Wisnuwardana Seky Soeryadjaya.

site_title: IMF approves US$6b loan for Pakistan
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved a $6 billion, three-year loan for Pakistan to help stabilize its economy. The loan, which includes $1 billion released immediately, aims to support the country's economic reform program and reduce economic vulnerabilities. The IMF also plans to unlock $38 billion from other international partners over the program period, helping to generate sustainable and balanced growth. The loan is intended to support Pakistan's economic reform program and help the country address its economic challenges.

site_title: Temasek's Certis invests in AI security
summary: Temasek-owned Certis Group has launched a new centre for applied research in artificial intelligence (AI) in Singapore. The centre, which opened on July 3, will utilize operational footage and open-source data to develop AI security tools. The centre has around 120 employees and plans to alleviate manpower strain with technology like AI, making people more productive and effective. The move aligns with Singapore's goal of becoming a global AI innovation hub and is part of 20 research projects underway, including collaborations with Zhejiang University and Taiwan's National Chiao Tung University.

site_title: BP says some of its oil 'won't see the light of day'
summary: BP says some of its oil resources, particularly those that are "more complicated to extract" and have high carbon intensity, may not be extracted due to increasing pressure to shorten project durations and reduce costs. The company's head of strategy, Dominic Emery, notes that some resources "won't see the light of day" and may be sold or left in the ground. This shift is driven by climate change and low oil prices, with the industry under pressure to adopt lower-carbon projects.

site_title: The ECB needs new inflation rules
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering a new inflation rule to address its struggles in achieving its inflation target. Despite stabilizing the eurozone during the 2007-08 global financial crisis, the ECB's inflation strategy has been less successful, leading to increased risk-taking, rising inequality, and growing pension gaps. The ECB's current policy framework has been criticized for being too rigid, and a more flexible approach is needed to accommodate policy trade-offs between inflation and financial stability. The ECB's next president should consider replacing its narrow inflation objective with a broader target range, including a medium-term inflation target and a definition of core consumer prices.

site_title: US car industry legend Lee Iacocca dies aged 94
summary: US car industry legend Lee Iacocca, credited with creating the iconic Ford Mustang and saving Chrysler from bankruptcy, has died at 94 due to complications from Parkinson's disease. Iacocca's career spanned decades, including his successful marketing campaigns and his leadership roles at Ford and Chrysler, where he implemented a painful restructuring process to save the company. He left a lasting legacy, known for his work ethic, dedication, and resilience, which continues to drive Chrysler's employees today.

site_title: US, China could reach trade deal by year-end, experts tell ST forum
summary: US and China may reach a trade deal by the end of this year or early next year, according to experts. The rivalry between the two largest economies is expected to persist, with "competition, cooperation, and restrictive engagement" between them. US President Donald Trump is pushing for a deal to boost his re-election campaign, while China is willing to make concessions. A trade deal could lead to a global economic boost, but the US Huawei ban may hinder progress, with experts viewing it as a bargaining chip. China's technology supremacy is seen as crucial to its economic and military power, with the US aware of this gap.

site_title: China launches longest EHV power line
summary: China has launched its longest extra-high voltage (EHV) power transmission line, spanning 3,324km from Xinjiang to Anhui, with a capacity to transmit 66 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity annually. The project aims to meet increasing power demand in eastern regions and reduce waste in western areas, as part of Beijing's anti-pollution campaign. This is China's 19th EHV line, with the country promoting cross-region transmission to increase capacity and reduce losses.

site_title: Tritech discloses variances in figures for bank borrowings after FY19 audit
summary: Tritech Group, a CATALIST-listed engineering firm, has adjusted two figures related to its bank borrowings in its fiscal 2019 financial statements after an audit. The company received S$22.26 million in proceeds from bank borrowings, up 154% from S$8.76 million initially stated, and made S$19.84 million in repayments, up 216% from S$6.27 million initially stated. The variances total S$13.5 million and S$13.57 million, respectively.

site_title: Landscape firms eyeing govt contracts must give workers bonus from 2020
summary: Singapore's government has announced that workers in the landscape maintenance industry will receive bonuses starting from January 1, 2020, and annual wage increments from 2023 to 2025. The move follows recommendations from the Tripartite Cluster for Landscape Industry report, which aims to improve working conditions and benefits for industry workers.

site_title: ST Group Food ends Catalist debut at S$0.28 for first day premium of 7.7%
summary: ST Group Food Industries Holdings, a Singapore-based regional franchisee, listed on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.28 on its first day of trading, up 7.7% from its IPO price of S$0.26. The company raised S$9.6 million through its IPO, which included the placement of 30.1 million shares and the issuance of 6.9 million new shares to cornerstone investors. The company has a network of 101 outlets in Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia, and the UK, with no presence in Singapore.

site_title: UrbanAgents taps AI for 'results-based' home sale commissions
summary: UrbanAgents, an agent referral platform, has introduced "results-based" home sale commissions, allowing property agents to earn more or less commission based on how the sale price differs from an AI-driven value prediction. The platform, UrbanZoom, uses machine learning to predict property values, and UrbanAgents connects sellers with top-performing agents. This approach aims to increase transparency and align the interests of agents and sellers, with funds raised from a $2 million seed round to be used for marketing and team expansion.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths to offload drinks, pubs units
summary: Woolworths Group, Australia's largest supermarket chain, plans to demerge its drinks and pubs units, combining them into a standalone listed operator worth about A$10 billion. This move aims to reduce the company's reliance on slot machine revenue and focus on its core business. The demerger will give investors exposure to a liquor store operator and pub owner, while Woolworths will concentrate on family-focused retail.

site_title: Ohmyhome announces first overseas expansion into Malaysia
summary: Ohmyhome, a Singaporean proptech startup, announces its first overseas expansion into Malaysia, launching services and a mobile application in Greater Kuala Lumpur. Plans are underway to expand into Johor. This marks Ohmyhome's first market outside Singapore.

site_title: ONE Championship founder to share entrepreneur tips, journey at forum
summary: Chatri Sityodtong, ONE Championship founder, will share entrepreneurial tips and his journey at a public forum on July 25. Sityodtong, a Harvard graduate, founded ONE Championship in 2011 and has since grown it into Asia's largest sports media company with a global broadcast to over 2.6 billion potential viewers. He sold his first startup at 30 and became a millionaire, eventually leaving Wall Street to start ONE Championship. The forum, "Cutting Edge," is the third in its series and will feature audience participation, moderated by Vikram Khanna.

site_title: Eva Air cancels hundreds more flights as cabin crew strike drags on
summary: Eva Air has cancelled 550 more flights through mid-July due to a 14-day cabin crew strike. The strike, which began on June 20, has disrupted over 2,000 flights and impacted 405,000 passengers. The airline estimates a revenue loss of NT$1.75 billion. Negotiations between the airline and the union broke down on Tuesday, with the union urging the airline to return to the negotiation table. The strike, the longest in Taiwan's aviation history, has been marked by protests and scuffles between cabin crew and the airline.

site_title: US dollar slips to one-week low against yen
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-week low against the Japanese yen due to steady declines in US Treasury bond yields, fading optimism over the Sino-US trade deal, and potential fresh tariff hostilities with Europe. The Swedish crown briefly jumped to a 2½-month high versus the euro after the central bank signaled policy tightening by early 2020. The yen firmed against the US dollar, while the pound fell. Markets expect a rate cut by the Fed this month, with a 70% probability of a quarter-point cut at the July policy meeting.

site_title: Man douses Baidu CEO in mid-speech
summary: A man doused Baidu CEO Robin Li in water during a speech in Beijing, China, on July 3, 2019. The incident occurred when Li was introducing an AI-powered valet parking service, and the perpetrator, wearing an event pass, jumped onstage and splashed him. Li continued speaking without interruption, asking the perpetrator "What's your problem?" The identity of the prankster remains unknown. This incident follows similar events involving CEOs at Amazon and Kamala Harris, and comes as Baidu faces challenges including a slowing economy and recent losses.

site_title: SembMarine hit by renewed fears over scandal fallout
summary: SembCorp Marine's stock tumbled 8.4% to S$1.41 after its Brazilian yard was raided and its former president was being investigated over potential fines related to the Petrobras corruption scandal. The company's woes come as the offshore and marine industry faces an extended downturn. Despite a recent S$2 billion loan extension from parent SembCorp Industries, concerns over potential fines continue to weigh on the firm.

site_title: A revolution in happiness rooted in collective action
summary: A 2019 article explores the concept of collective happiness, rooted in Socrates' idea that happiness is a universal truth. Hannah Arendt's theory suggests that public happiness, as a shared political experience, can be achieved through collective action and participation in the "public space or marketplace". This concept is reflected in the American Revolution and continues to influence modern movements, such as the Women's March and the March for Our Lives. Arendt argues that the experience of public happiness is discovered when people act together, creating something new and experiencing freedom, making it a tangible and joyful experience unlike individual happiness.

site_title: COEs finish mixed as buyers return to weak market
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices ended mixed in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp rising to S$28,589, while those above 1,600cc or 130bhp fell to S$34,000. Commercial vehicle COEs also dropped to S$25,089. Despite crowds returning to showrooms, market sentiment remains weak, with 7,765 motorists extending the lifespan of their 10-year-old cars in April, a 34% increase from the average monthly figure. Industry watchers attribute the mixed results to the still-weak car market in Singapore.

site_title: June PMI falls to 3-year low; electronics contraction continues
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI fell to a 3-year low of 49.6 in June, contracting for the second straight month. The electronics sector, hit by trade tensions, saw its PMI decline to 49.2, its eighth consecutive contraction. Other indicators, such as new orders, factory output, and employment, also retreated. The manufacturing sector's decline may signal sustained contraction in the second quarter, according to economists. Despite this, some manufacturers are working on future growth plans, and demand conditions have turned challenging due to rising input prices.

site_title: Blockchain accelerator facilitates raising of S$17m
summary: Tribe, a government-backed blockchain accelerator, has opened S$16.8 million in funds for its inaugural cohort of 10 companies. Mighty Jaxx, a designer toy collectibles studio, secured a S$2.15 million pre-Series A round led by Eight Mercatus and co-invested by SGInnovate. The funds will be used to develop a blockchain-powered platform for authenticating collectibles. This move aims to support the growth of startups in the blockchain and deep tech sectors.

site_title: Trump taps two allies as Fed board nominees
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced his intention to nominate two new candidates to the Federal Reserve board, Christopher Waller and Judy Shelton, both economists who share his views on the central bank. Waller, a director at the Fed's St. Louis office, and Shelton, a conservative economist, have expressed support for lowering interest rates. This move comes after previous nominations, Stephen Moore and Herman Cain, faced significant opposition, highlighting the challenges Trump faces in installing loyalists at the Fed.

site_title: Indonesia parliament delays approval for levy on plastic bags
summary: Indonesia's parliament has delayed approval for a levy on plastic bags, despite a government plan to impose an excise duty starting from 30,000 rupiah per kilogram or 200 rupiah per bag. The levy aims to reduce plastic waste and pollution in the oceans, where Indonesia is the world's second-largest contributor. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati expressed optimism that the legislation would be adopted this year, but the delay is due to resistance from both ruling and opposition parties. The levy would hurt the plastic industry, with manufacturers opposing the plan.

site_title: AI: Limited as it is now, we have to make smarter use of it - and use it more responsibly
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) has reached a point where it can learn and apply its capabilities more effectively, but it is still far from achieving human-level intelligence. Current AI is narrow and focused on specific tasks, such as recognizing faces, driving cars, and playing chess. Its applications are vast, including pattern recognition, prediction, and recommendation systems. While AI has the potential to replace some jobs, it also has the power to create new ones, particularly those focused on human-to-human contact. To prepare for the future, governments and individuals must rethink education systems and prioritize critical thinking, communication, and empathy skills.

site_title: Japan whale restaurants cheer hunt resumption
summary: Japan has resumed commercial whaling, with the country setting an annual quota of over 600 whales. Despite concerns from activists, Japanese chefs, such as Mitsuo Tani, argue that whale meat is a healthy alternative to other meats, with lower calorie and fat content. However, critics point to mercury levels found in whale meat sold in Japan and the potential decline in supply. The resumption of whaling has sparked outrage from other countries and campaigners, with Japan defending the practice as a key part of its culinary heritage and tradition.

site_title: STI dips on investor caution
summary: The Singapore stock market ended the day 3 points lower at 3,367.80, with the Straits Times Index (STI) finishing 0.1% lower. Genting Singapore dropped 2.5 cents after JPMorgan downgraded it to "underweight". Meanwhile, real estate investment trusts (Reits) benefited from increased investor interest, with the iEdge S-Reit 20 Index adding 1.1%. Sembcorp Marine's shares fell 8.4% after Brazilian authorities executed a search warrant for its Brazilian subsidiary. The market is awaiting the US jobs report on Friday to assess the impact of the trade war.

site_title: Singapore a capital-raising hotspot for European banks
summary: European banks have turned to Singapore as a capital-raising hotspot, selling almost S$3 billion of debt in the Singapore dollar bond market this year alone. The market's favorable conditions, including a deep market and competitive swap rates, have made it an attractive destination for banks seeking to issue Additional Tier 1 capital instruments. This trend is driven by investor and market diversification, as well as pricing arbitrage, which offers cost savings. The Singapore market has emerged as the fourth largest for AT1 capital globally, and banks are expected to continue issuing debt in the market to meet investors' needs.

site_title: FLT to buy 12 properties for A$645m from Frasers Property
summary: FLT, a Singaporean Reit, plans to acquire 12 freehold logistics properties from Frasers Property for A$644.7 million. The properties, located in Germany and Australia, have a total gross lettable area of 297,000 square meters and 100% occupancy. FLT expects to increase its distribution per unit to 3.58 cents post-acquisition. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of August, subject to unitholder approval, and will strengthen FLT through geographical diversification and a longer weighted average lease expiry.

site_title: Vodafone 5G network opens new front in Britain's wireless wars
summary: Vodafone launches the UK's second 5G wireless network, kicking off a commercial battle with EE. The technology offers faster download speeds and more reliable connections, giving early adopters an opportunity to grab a bigger share of the saturated market. Vodafone's 5G service goes live just a month after EE's, and the company is slightly undercutting EE on prices. The UK's other two mobile networks, Three UK and O2, aim to offer 5G by the end of the year, with the potential to boost smartphone sales and revenue.

site_title: Trump accuses China, Europe of currency manipulation, stimulus
summary: US President Donald Trump accused China and Europe of manipulating their currencies and stimulating their economies to gain a competitive advantage over the US. He called for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy. Trump's comments came amid ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Passion projects
summary: Three Singaporeans pursue their heritage through various means, including photography, cookbook creation, and preserving island history. Corporate professionals also find purpose in painting, with some winning awards and selling their works at auction. The article also features interviews with Anne-Sophie Pic, the only female chef in France with a three Michelin-starred restaurant, and past winners of the Best Female Chef award, discussing gender equality in the kitchen. Additionally, the article touches on various lifestyle topics, including sustainable living, financial literacy, and design solutions for unusual home layouts.

site_title: Raids on ATMs rise in Germany
summary: Raid on ATMs in Germany increased by 38% in 2019, with 369 machines destroyed by explosions, compared to 10 times more than a decade ago. The majority of attacks follow a similar pattern, using electric detonators or fuses to blast open machines, often planned months in advance. Successful attacks can be lucrative, with one recent attack netting 190,000 euros. Data from Europol and the European Association for Secure Transactions (EAST) show that Germany accounts for over a third of ATM attacks across 11 European countries, but other nations have seen a 15% decrease in reported attacks.

site_title: Boeing promises US$100m to help families affected by deadly crashes
summary: Boeing has pledged $100 million to support families affected by the 737 MAX plane crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, which killed 346 people. The funding is independent of lawsuits and will be used for education, hardship assistance, and community programs. Boeing will partner with local governments and non-profit organizations to address the needs of impacted families and communities. This move comes after the company faced significant backlash following the crashes.

site_title: Christine Lagarde tapped to head European Central Bank in surprise move
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has nominated Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), as its new president, a surprise move that marks a shift from a typical economist to a politician and lawyer. Lagarde, 63, would replace Mario Draghi on November 1, taking charge of the ECB amidst a slowing global economy. Investors expect her to continue Draghi's aggressive crisis-fighting policies, but some economists question her ability to implement effective monetary policy, citing the ECB's exhausted toolbox and stagnant eurozone economy.

site_title: Latest state tenders yield mixed bag of results
summary: State tenders for two 99-year leasehold sites in Singapore yielded mixed results. An Executive Condominium (EC) site in Sembawang drew eight bids, with the top bid exceeding expectations, while a private housing site in Clementi attracted only five bids. The top bid for the Clementi site was S$491.3 million, with developers citing the site's proximity to educational institutions and potential for strong demand. In contrast, the Sembawang EC site's top bid was S$233.89 million, reflecting developers' confidence in the EC segment despite a limited supply.

site_title: Jet suppliers go on merger spree to keep up with Boeing, Airbus output
summary: Aerospace suppliers are merging to keep up with record demand for jetliners from Airbus and Boeing. The market for deals has reached an all-time high of $120 billion, with over 40 prospective buyers and sellers meeting at the Paris Air Show. Suppliers are under pressure to accelerate production, with businesses lower down the supply chain considering mergers to meet demand. Consolidation has given suppliers more pricing power, but manufacturers prefer it to stopping programs due to supplier issues. The US remains a focus for transactions, with cross-border demand also strong, particularly for Asian and European suppliers seeking access to Boeing.

site_title: Sunseap completes Vietnam solar farm in string of Asia projects
summary: Sunseap Group has completed a US$150 million Vietnam solar farm project ahead of schedule, generating 168 megawatt-peak of solar energy enough to power 192,000 homes and reducing carbon emissions by 240,000 tonnes annually. The project, jointly developed with InfraCo Asia, was completed by June 30 and will sell electricity at a solar feed-in tariff of 9.35 US cents per kilowatt hour.

site_title: Lagerfeld lives on in Chanel Paris haute couture show
summary: Chanel's Paris haute couture show paid tribute to Karl Lagerfeld's legacy, with Virginie Viard's collection showcasing a sleeker, more restrained, and classically Chanel aesthetic. The show featured nods to Lagerfeld, including starched collars and cuffs, ponytails, and two-tone bowed shoes. Viard put her own mark on the clothes, introducing a purer marriage of street style and couture, while maintaining Chanel's standards of tweeds and embroidery. The collection was met with applause, with Viard briefly acknowledging the audience and saving a traditional finale in favor of pink satin pyjamas and a subtly feathered robe.

site_title: MTI accepts proposals to build a design-minded workforce
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) in Singapore has accepted five recommendations to develop a design-minded workforce. The recommendations include strengthening ties between industry and institutes of higher learning, supporting continuing education and training, and introducing pilot programs to enhance design education and skills. A Design Education Advisory Committee will be formed, and two pilot programs will be launched, including a semester-long credit-bearing module at Singapore Polytechnic and a School of X program for professionals to apply design thinking to real-world issues.

site_title: Australia's big banks get squeezed as cash rate drops to record low
summary: Australia's Big Four banks face squeezed earnings after the Reserve Bank of Australia's record-low cash rate cut to 1% on Tuesday. The move reduces bank margins and interest income, with potential earnings cuts of up to 2.5% for the current financial year. Banks have struggled with weak credit growth and high legal costs, and are now under pressure to pass on the rate cut to mortgage customers. Share prices of the Big Four banks fell 0.73-1.2% in the 24 hours following the rate cut.

site_title: Blackstone nears 1 billion euros sale of Center Parcs resorts
summary: Blackstone Group is in exclusive talks to sell its portfolio of seven Center Parcs Europe holiday resorts to German real-estate company Aroundtown for approximately 1 billion euros. The deal follows Blackstone's purchase of the properties in 2006 for 630 million euros. Aroundtown has a pipeline of 1.5 billion euros in hotel and office acquisitions, with 1 billion euros expected to be completed this year. The sale marks another European holiday park deal by private equity investors, which have cut costs and improved revenues by adding amenities and appealing to a wider audience.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hyphens Pharma's stock is recommended to be initiated at S$0.20 with a target price of S$0.25 by RHB Research Institute. The stock is undervalued at 9.6 times FY19F P/E, offering a 2.8% yield. The market is currently undervaluing the group's potential, making it a buy opportunity.

site_title: Indonesia asks China for special fund under BRI
summary: Indonesia has asked China to set up a special fund under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) for investment in Southeast Asia's largest economy. Indonesia has offered projects worth $91 billion, but insisted on a business-to-business loan model to avoid government exposure in case of default. The special fund is expected to provide low-interest loans for investments in Indonesia, in partnership with local companies. This comes after Indonesia previously offered China involvement in 30 projects worth $91 billion, including a high-speed rail project worth $6 billion.

site_title: Rahul Gandhi resigns as leader of India's opposition Congress
summary: Rahul Gandhi, 49, resigned as leader of India's main opposition Congress party, taking responsibility for the party's second-straight election loss to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's right-wing Hindu nationalist BJP. Gandhi cited accountability for the party's defeat in the April-May national elections, where Congress won only 52 of 543 seats. He launched a critical attack on the BJP's tactics and vowed to protect the country, despite accusations of religious tensions and undermining the country's secular credentials. Gandhi's resignation is expected to throw the party into turmoil, with potential successors including his mother Sonia and sister Priyanka.

site_title: The spectacular fall of India's 'dosa king'
summary: P. Rajagopal, the founder of Saravana Bhavan, is set to begin a life sentence for having his romantic rival murdered. Rajagopal's journey from rags to riches began with his vision for a trail-blazing Indian restaurant chain. However, his downfall was sealed after he allegedly had a romantic rival killed. The incident occurred after receiving "fateful cosmic advice." This event marks the end of Rajagopal's life and career.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI falls further into contraction in June
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI fell to 49.6 in June, marking the second consecutive month of contraction and the lowest reading since August 2016. The sector saw its eighth straight month of contraction, driven by first-time contractions in new orders, factory output, inventory, and employment levels. New exports and imports slowed, but remained in growth territory. The overall PMI reading indicates a worsening manufacturing sentiment in Singapore.

site_title: Europe's new leaders face big tests ahead
summary: European Union leaders have agreed on a new team to lead the bloc into the 2020s, with Ursula von der Leyen as European Commission president and Christine Lagarde as European Central Bank chief. Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel will lead the European Council, and Spanish Foreign Minister Josep Borrell will be EU foreign policy chief. The appointments are seen as crucial in guiding the EU's strategic agenda amid geopolitical turbulence and economic uncertainty, with von der Leyen and Lagarde facing significant pressure to deliver results.

site_title: Ohmyhome expands into Malaysia, offers cross-border property deals
summary: Ohmyhome, a local proptech startup, has expanded into Malaysia, offering cross-border property deals. The company has launched its service in Greater Kuala Lumpur and plans to introduce it in Johor. Ohmyhome provides an end-to-end service model, serving both local and cross-border transactions, with step-by-step guidance for negotiations. Users can access the hybrid platform, which offers a DIY model and agent service, and connect with potential buyers, sellers, and landlords across the border. The company has partnered with major banks and real estate developers, offering housing loans and conveyancing services.

site_title: Hundreds get food poisoning at Imelda Marcos' 90th birthday party
summary: About 260 people fell ill from food poisoning at Imelda Marcos' 90th birthday party in Manila, with hundreds sent to hospitals for vomiting and dizziness. The incident occurred after attendees ate meat stew and eggs. Imelda Marcos' daughter, Imee Marcos, downplayed the incident, saying the food may have been spoiled but the family remains solid. This incident comes amid controversy surrounding the Marcos family's wealth and alleged human rights abuses during their rule.

site_title: Time to take another bite of S-chips
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has faced criticism for its handling of Mainland-operating, Singapore-listed companies (S-chips), which have been marred by scandals. However, recent data suggests that the proportion of S-chips listed on the exchange has declined over the past three years. The SGX has taken steps to improve corporate governance, including requiring companies to hold annual general meetings in Singapore and strengthening supervision and accountability. Despite this, it's unrealistic to expect all S-chips to be "Saint"-chips, and the market should welcome high-quality listing applicants.

site_title: Ford readies for push in electric cars, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Ford is preparing to increase its electric vehicle offerings, according to Morgan Stanley. The company has been investing in electric technology and is discussing a potential partnership with Volkswagen to share development and manufacturing costs. Analysts predict this collaboration could mitigate financial risks and position Ford for long-term success. Ford shares rose 1.7% following the news, and an announcement could be imminent. The move is seen as a strategic shift towards sustainable transportation, which analysts believe will benefit the company's earnings and stock price in the long run.

site_title: Eneco Energy appoints new chief executive officer
summary: Eneco Energy has appointed Colin Peter Moran as its new chief executive officer, replacing Aditya Wisnuwardana Seky Soeryadjaya, who retired on July 3. Soeryadjaya had served as CEO for 11 years, leading the company through a challenging oil and gas industry downturn. The company praised Soeryadjaya's leadership, saying he transformed Eneco Energy into an O&G company despite the industry's difficulties. Moran's appointment ensures a smooth transition for the company.

site_title: Validus to apply for Singapore digital-banking licence
summary: Validus Capital, Singapore's largest peer-to-peer lending platform, plans to apply for a digital banking licence in the country. Backed by Temasek Holdings' Vertex Ventures, Validus aims to join a growing list of non-bank challengers in the space. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will open applications for digital banking licences in August, and Validus expects to apply once this occurs.

site_title: Chaswood Resources' independent auditor issues disclaimer of opinion
summary: MOORE Stephens, the independent auditor of Chaswood Resources Holdings, has issued a disclaimer of opinion on the group's financial statements for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018. The auditor found material uncertainties that may cast significant doubt on the group's ability to continue as a going concern due to various legal proceedings and a statutory demand for payment. The group's management believes it can complete a restructuring exercise to continue as a going concern, but the auditor lacked sufficient audit evidence to support this assumption.

site_title: Eurozone business growth weak in June as factories still stumbling
summary: Eurozone business activity picked up slightly in June, but remained weak, with the services industry offsetting a continued downturn in factory output. The Euro Zone Composite PMI increased to 52.2, slightly higher than May's 51.8, but still below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. Business expectations for the year ahead dropped, and forward-looking indicators didn't point to a bounce back, leading to renewed calls for ECB stimulus. GDP growth is expected to be around 0.2% in the second quarter, weaker than predicted.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Wednesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.95 points to 1,690.05. Volume reached 3 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 456 to 395.

site_title: Landlords big winners as Philippines bets on Chinese gaming boom
summary: The Philippines is experiencing a surge in demand for residential and commercial spaces due to the influx of Chinese nationals working in online gaming companies. Chinese nationals make up nearly half of the country's foreign work permit holders, with the number increasing by nearly quadrupling in two years. This has become a boon for the property market, with office rents in the Manila Bay area rising by as much as 150% and condominium and housing rents increasing by 50%. The growth is attributed to the liberal gaming environment and the insatiable appetite for gambling in China.

site_title: Bank stocks vs Reits may be a false dichotomy
summary: Singapore bank stocks have been selling off amid US-China trade tensions, with some analysts arguing they are undervalued compared to high-yielding Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits). However, banks' profitability may be vulnerable due to a potential rate cut, which would reduce their net interest margin. Unlike Reits, banks can benefit from non-interest income, such as fees from private banking and discretionary portfolio management. Analysts suggest a "lower for longer" rate environment and a focus on complex cash management and intra-Asia network may provide comfort for banks, making the bank-Reit dichotomy a false choice.

site_title: Addvalue bags contract worth at least US$1m from Indonesian firm
summary: Addvalue Technologies has signed a contract worth at least US$1 million with an Indonesian company to provide its very small aperture terminal solution for the next year. The Indonesian partner specializes in satellite communication and IT solutions for the government and military. The agreement is renewable annually, subject to a minimum order commitment, and Addvalue is poised to capitalize on Indonesia's rural banking market, which requires satellite connectivity for 50% of its 12,000 ATMs.

site_title: Elizabeth Taylor's Oscars dress among her items heading to auction
summary: Elizabeth Taylor's iconic 1974 Academy Awards gown, designed by Edith Head, is set to be auctioned off in early December for between $4,000 and $6,000. The pale blue chiffon dress will be sold alongside over 1,200 other items from Taylor's life, including a gold-plated, sterling silver Cartier belt expected to fetch over $40,000. The auction will feature jewelry, wigs, fine art, and household items, with some pieces potentially selling for up to $60,000.

site_title: Eight arrested for suspected Hong Kong police data breaches
summary: Hong Kong police arrested eight people suspected of disclosing officers' private information online and making threats against them. The arrests were made in connection with hundreds of complaints about leaked personal data of police officers. The operation is ongoing, with the possibility of additional arrests. The incidents come amid ongoing protests in Hong Kong against a proposed extradition bill, and criticism of police actions, including the use of rubber bullets and tear gas.

site_title: Higher gearing limits will improve Reits' DPU
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes raising leverage limits for real estate investment trusts (Reits) from 45% to 50% or more, potentially reducing their use of expensive perpetual securities (perps) to finance acquisitions. Analysts expect this move to increase distribution per unit (DPU) and allow for more portfolio growth. Higher gearing limits could also encourage Reits to engage in more acquisition activity, but analysts believe the market will self-regulate and punish Reits that gear up too aggressively with low valuations. Most Reits support the proposal, but some, like Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, prefer a gearing range of the 30s.

site_title: Merger of Ascott Reit, Ascendas Hospitality Trust makes sense
summary: CapitaLand has announced the merger of Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust), resulting in one of Asia's largest diversified real estate players. The combined entity will have over S$123 billion of assets under management, 88 properties, and 16,000 units across 39 cities and 15 countries. The merger is expected to increase the trust's pro forma gross revenue by 37% and gross profit by 36%, with a gearing ratio of 36.9% allowing for greater financial flexibility. The move is seen as a strategic move to increase liquidity and financing capacity, and analysts predict a potential positive re-rating for the merged entity.

site_title: Walmart discussed selling clothing brands Bonobos and Modcloth
summary: Walmart has discussed the potential sale of unprofitable clothing brands Bonobos and Modcloth to buyers, citing inability to turn around the company's economics. Modcloth is expected to be sold this year, while Bonobos will be retained. The move comes after Walmart reported projected losses of over $1 billion for its US e-commerce division in 2019. The retailer has been trying to compete with Amazon and appeal to younger shoppers with its clothing acquisitions.

site_title: US factory orders fall for second straight month
summary: US factory orders fell for a second straight month in May, decreasing 0.7% due to weak demand for transportation equipment. Shipments of core capital goods increased 0.6% in May, while overall shipments of manufactured goods edged up 0.1%. The decline is attributed to ongoing manufacturing struggles, including inventory bloat, trade tensions, and a reduction in Boeing's 737 MAX aircraft production. Economists had forecast a 0.5% decline in May, and the data suggests continued weakness in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng to open elementary school in Singapore
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's subsidiary, CES Cambridge, has entered into an agreement with The Perse School Cambridge International to establish an elementary school in Singapore by early 2020. The school will cater to students aged 6-11 and may extend to a secondary school. The agreement includes mutual exclusivity for 30 years and the right to use The Perse School's trademarks. Chip Eng Seng aims to create a "relatively affordable international school" with a focus on quality education.

site_title: Growth concerns abound, but don't hold breath for monetary easing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is unlikely to ease monetary policy in October due to concerns over inflation and economic growth. Non-oil domestic exports have fallen for the third straight month, and industrial production fell 2.4% year-over-year in May. Some analysts predict a technical recession this year, which could lead to a rise in the probability of monetary easing. OCBC Bank and Maybank Kim Eng see a "not insignificant" chance of monetary policy tightening if economic data continues to deteriorate, despite growing speculation about a potential recession.

site_title: UOL-UIC tie-up places top bid for Clementi Ave 1 site
summary: UOL Group and United Industrial Corporation (UIC) have teamed up to place the top bid of S$491.3 million for a 99-year leasehold private housing site along Clementi Avenue 1, working out to S$788.31 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The second-highest bid came from MCL Land's Vesta SG Residences at S$471 million. UOL Group plans to develop a 40-storey project comprising 640 units, capitalizing on the site's strong demand due to its proximity to educational institutions and nearby establishments.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens at record high on rising rate cut hopes
summary: The S&P 500 index opened at a record high on Wednesday, driven by healthcare stocks and bets of an interest rate cut due to slowing global economy fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.17% to 26,832.32, while the S&P 500 gained 0.17% to 2,978.08. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.25% to 8,129.57. The rally comes amid simmering trade tensions and concerns over a slowing global economy.

site_title: COE prices finish mixed as buyers return to weak market
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mixed in the latest tender, with premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing higher at $28,589. However, those for larger vehicles finished lower at $34,000. Open COE prices, which can be used for bigger cars, closed lower at $36,901. The mixed results were attributed to low prices luring buyers back to a weak car market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with losses, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.07% to 28,855.14, following a previous day's rally. Energy firms were hit due to a decline in oil prices. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.94% and 1.18%, respectively.

site_title: Deutsche Bank restructuring to cost up to US$5.6b
summary: Deutsche Bank is planning a major restructuring costing up to 5 billion euros (S$7.65 billion) to turn the lender around after failing to agree a merger with Commerzbank. The bank aims to cut 15,000-20,000 jobs, or one in five of its 91,500 employees, as part of the transformation to improve sustainable profitability. CEO Christian Sewing previously promised "tough cutbacks" to the investment bank. The bank has declined to comment on the expected cost of the restructuring, stating it will update stakeholders if needed.

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by miners and real estate stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,685.50, driven by gains in mining stocks BHP Group and Rio Tinto, which benefited from stronger commodity prices. Real estate stocks also rose, with Goodman Group and Scentre Group increasing 3.1% and 1.5%, respectively, after the Reserve Bank cut interest rates, pointing to easier property lending conditions.

site_title: US private sector hiring picks up less than expected in June
summary: US private sector hiring fell short of expectations in June, adding 102,000 jobs, down from the projected 140,000. This marks the weakest payroll gain since March 2010. Services-providing jobs grew by 117,000, while goods-producing jobs declined by 15,000. Small businesses reduced payrolls by 23,000, while larger companies added jobs. Economists expect the US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report to show a gain of 160,000 jobs, with the unemployment rate remaining steady at 3.6%. The softening labor market raises concerns about the US economic expansion.

site_title: Australia's big banks get squeezed as cash rate drops to record low
summary: Australia's Big Four banks face squeezed earnings due to the Reserve Bank of Australia's record-low cash rate of 1%. The rate cut reduces bank margins and earnings, with some banks, like Commonwealth Bank, seeing a 2.5% hit. To offset cheaper mortgages, banks struggle to lower deposit rates, impacting interest income. Analysts warn further rate cuts will worsen earnings for banks.

site_title: SGX rejects application from ASA for extension to hold FY18 AGM
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Advanced Systems Automation's (ASA) application for an extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018. ASA had initially sought an extension due to outstanding matters and finalizing accounts, but the SGX has informed the company to hold its AGM as soon as possible, with a target date of July 31.

site_title: US trade deficit hits 5-month high as imports from Mexico soar
summary: The US trade deficit reached a five-month high in May, jumping 8.4% to $55.5 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts. Imports from Mexico soared to a record $33.2 billion, while exports rose 2% to $266.2 billion. The deficit with Mexico is up 35% to $40.4 billion, and with the EU, it's up 7.3% to $72.3 billion. The surge in the trade deficit may weigh on growth forecasts for the second quarter, contradicting President Trump's goal to eliminate the deficit.

site_title: Japan's Abe says a 10% sales tax is enough, at least for 10 years
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that a 10% sales tax is sufficient for the next 10 years, potentially hindering efforts to balance the nation's finances. The sales tax is set to increase from 8% to 10% in October, aimed at reducing Japan's massive debt. Abe's comments raised doubts about the government's commitment to balancing its budget, with economists warning that the long-term fiscal sustainability is a concern.

site_title: Yang Kee to boost logistics operating capabilities after investor raises stake in firm to 35%
summary: AUSTRALIAN logistics firm Logos has increased its stake in Yang Kee Holdings to 35% after raising funds. Yang Kee will use the investment to boost its local and overseas logistics capabilities and develop quality logistics assets in Singapore. The partnership aims to strengthen Yang Kee's logistics capabilities and affirm Logos' confidence in the jointly-owned portfolio. The increased investment marks Logos' first investment in Singapore, following the development of a 66,000 sqm logistics hub in 2018.

site_title: Sri Lanka police chief, ex-defence secretary held on remand over Easter bomb attack failings
summary: Sri Lanka's police chief, Inspector General of Police Pujith Jayasundara, and former defence secretary Hemasiri Fernando were remanded in custody on July 3 over alleged failures to prevent the Easter Day bomb attacks that killed over 250 people. The arrests came after the Criminal Investigation Department launched an investigation into the attacks. The case will be heard in the Colombo magistrates' court on Tuesday. The remand is the latest development in the ongoing probe into the Easter Sunday bombings, which were carried out by the National Thawheed Jamaat (NTJ) and the Islamic State.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CapitaLand is merging Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust to form Asia-Pacific's largest hospitality trust, valued at S$7.6 billion. The move aims to create a global hospitality leader. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacts to the US's surprise tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry prepares for potential higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: BOE issues fresh warning on risk from funds with illiquid assets
summary: The Bank of England has issued a warning about funds investing in illiquid assets, citing a risk to the financial system if the issue spreads. Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe expressed concerns about "contagion" if investors lose confidence in a less liquid asset class, leading to redemption pressures and potential damage to the financial system. This warning comes after recent examples of liquidity risk, including a panic at H2O Asset Management and Star stock picker Neil Woodford's forced withdrawal freeze. The BOE is urging international cooperation to assess these risks and implement structural remedies.

site_title: Singapore-based GoComet raises S$3m in Series A funding led by Leo Capital
summary: Singapore-based freight quote comparison platform GoComet has raised S$3 million in Series A funding led by Leo Capital, alongside SGInnovate and AugustOne. The investment aims to expand the company into other South-east Asian markets. GoComet claims its SaaS platform reduces costs and increases efficiencies for freight procurement processes, processing over 19,680 tonnes of air freight and 84,000 containers with a gross freight value of S$235 million. The funding signifies confidence in the company's efforts to transform the sector, with plans to hire top talent to achieve its expansion goals.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust executes US$341m interest rate swap
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a US$341 million interest rate swap agreement with Bank of the West has been executed, reducing the overall cost of borrowing to 3.41% per year from 3.69% per year. The agreement consists of three swap transactions with 90.7% floating debt hedged, resulting in annual savings of $1.36 million. The interest rate swap represents 67.2% of the trust's borrowings.

site_title: European stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% to 7,572.39 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also gained 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus. Meanwhile, the US stock market edged towards fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.1% on Wednesday
summary: The Singapore market declined 0.1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,367.80 points. Trading volume reached 1.57 billion securities, 31% above the daily average. The local banks were mixed, with DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank down 1.3% and 0.1% respectively, while OCBC Bank rose 0.5%. The manufacturing and semiconductor sector was affected by Japan-Korea tensions, with Venture Corporation and Hi-P International shares dipping 0.3% and 0.7% respectively.

site_title: Saudi private sector growth rises to 18-month high in June: PMI
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector growth reached an 18-month high in June, with the Emirates NBD Saudi Arabia Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 57.4, above the 50 mark indicating expansion. However, output prices and growth fell, with job creation slowing slightly to 50.3 and output growth dropping to 61.1, a three-month low. This rebound is attributed to increased customer demand, despite subdued growth in the private sector last year due to fuel price hikes, tax introductions, and higher hiring costs.

site_title: MTI accepts recommendations for design education
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has accepted five recommendations from a tripartite committee to develop a workforce with design skills, even for those in non-design sectors. A Design Education Advisory Committee will be formed and two pilot programs introduced, including a semester-long design-led creative thinking module and a School of X program. The goal is to enhance design education and training, and promote design thinking across various disciplines, to support innovation and competitiveness in the industry.

site_title: US auto industry legend Lee Iacocca dies age 94
summary: US auto industry legend Lee Iacocca, credited with creating the Ford Mustang and saving Chrysler from bankruptcy, has died at 94 due to complications from Parkinson's disease. Iacocca began his career at Ford in 1946 and later led Chrysler to recovery with a $1.5 billion government loan in 1979. Under his leadership, Chrysler invented the minivan and SUV. Iacocca's legacy is characterized by hard work, dedication, and grit, as remembered by Chrysler.

site_title: Landscaping companies bidding for government contracts must give its workers bonus from 2020
summary: The Ministry of Manpower and the National Parks Board announced that landscaping companies bidding for government contracts must give their workers a mandatory annual bonus from January 1, 2020. The bonus must be at least two weeks of the worker's basic monthly wage and paid at least once but not more than twice a year. Additionally, the minimum annual increment of 3% will be implemented for wage levels from July 1, 2023, to 2025, to ensure sustained wage growth for landscape maintenance employees.

site_title: US retail vacancy rates down marginally in second quarter: Reis
summary: US retail vacancy rates decreased 0.1% to 10.1% in the second quarter, marking the first decline since 2016, according to Reis Inc. Despite store closures, new openings led to strong occupancy growth, with grocery stores and discount clothing stores among the new occupants.
