site_title: Singapore sees jump in M&A value for H1 at US$17.1b; S-E Asia bucks downtrend
summary: Singapore recorded a 154% increase in M&A value for the first half of 2019, reaching US$17.1 billion, bucking the downtrend in the Asia-Pacific ex-Japan region. The largest deal was CapitaLand's US$8.1 billion acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge. South-east Asia's M&A activity slowed, with Indonesia and Malaysia posting increases, while Thailand's activity decreased due to growing political uncertainty. The tech war between the US and China is threatening to disrupt the supply chain, and private equity buyouts and exits are expected to worsen in the near future.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. The US stock market opened lower following Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing the outgoing DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Yanlord nets 1.43b yuan in pre-sales at launch of Yanlord Gardens
summary: Yanlord Land Group achieved 1.43 billion yuan (S$0.28 billion) in pre-sales for its Yanlord Gardens development in Nantong, China, within the first day of its launch. The 357 apartment units were sold at an average price of approximately 28,570 yuan per square meter. Chairman and CEO Zhong Sheng Jian attributed the strong demand to upgrader demand and population growth in first-tier and second-tier cities. The development benefits from the Nantong government's initiatives to develop the area into a model for technology company development and innovation.

site_title: Last month hottest June on record: EU satellite agency
summary: Last month was the hottest June on record, according to EU satellite data, with European temperatures 2C hotter than normal and globally 0.1C hotter than the previous record. A record-breaking heatwave across Western Europe, particularly in France, Germany, northern Spain, and Italy, was capped off by scorching temperatures, with some areas experiencing 10C higher than normal temperatures.

site_title: Australian government poised to secure A$158b tax cut plan
summary: Australia's conservative government is poised to secure A$158 billion in tax cuts, primarily aimed at middle-income earners, after independent lawmakers agreed to support the legislation. The tax cuts, proposed by Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, would boost consumer spending and revive the economy, which is growing at its slowest pace in a decade. The plan, which needs the support of three independents and minor parties, would benefit about 10 million middle- and low-income earners, with a rebate worth up to A$1,080 per person.

site_title: ABB to supply chargers for public electric buses to ST Engg Land Systems, BYD Singapore
summary: ABB will supply charging infrastructure for 40 single-deck electric buses in Singapore, partnering with ST Engineering Land Systems and BYD Singapore. The smart charging products feature a "future-proof" design, safe operation, and remote service management. ABB will provide 20 buses with 4x 450kW chargers and 20 buses with 10x 150kW overnight charging systems. The project aims to promote greener, sustainable public transportation in Singapore, following a S$50 million contract awarded by the Land Transport Authority last year. The charging systems are expected to be operational in early 2020.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end weaker as Japan's export curbs unnerve markets
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index ended down 0.36% at 2,122.03 points on Tuesday, following Japan's export curbs against Seoul and trade uncertainties over Sino-US talks. Automakers slid after posting lean sales in June, while the won and bond yield fell. This marks a reversal from the KOSPI's 3.97% gain so far this year and 3.6% gain in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Rich get richer, everyone else not so much in record US expansion
summary: The US economy has entered its record 121st month of expansion, marked by extreme wealth concentration and widening income inequality. Billionaires in the US have more than doubled in the last decade, with the top 5% holding 88% of the country's wealth. Despite this, lower-income levels struggle with stagnant wages, high food and housing costs, and rising rents. The economic expansion is expected to continue, but policymakers worry about the fragility of gains and the potential for a recession.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Tuesday on profit-taking, growth concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Tuesday, closing 0.04% lower at 3,370.80, due to profit-taking and concerns over global economic growth. The index had gained on Monday following a surprise US-China Osaka meeting outcome. In contrast, markets in Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan closed higher, while China and South Korea ended lower. Trading volume was high, with 1.05 billion securities changing hands, and local banks and manufacturing sectors declined.

site_title: Australian bank shares pare index gains; NZ hits another record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.08% to 6,653.20, but gains were largely offset by a decline in large bank stocks due to stricter lending conditions proposed by the Australian Securities & Investments Commission. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to make further rate cuts to support economic growth. Meanwhile, New Zealand stocks hit a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index rising 0.6% to 10,531.94.

site_title: Returning Singaporean children can apply to take school placement tests from July 3
summary: Singaporean children returning from overseas can apply to take school placement tests from July 3 for admission to Secondary 1-3 and Pre-University 1 in September and November, respectively. The tests, part of the School Placement Exercise for Returning Singaporeans, will determine eligible schools and results will be available in December. Those who cannot return in time can take a Supplementary Placement Exercise in mid-December.

site_title: UK housing market stuck in slow gear as Brexit weighs - Nationwide
summary: The UK housing market experienced a slow growth in June, with house prices increasing by 0.5% compared to the previous year, according to Nationwide. This growth is in line with median forecasts and follows a similar trend to 2018. The Brexit uncertainty continues to weigh on the market, with prices in London falling for an eighth consecutive quarter. Despite this, prices in Northern Ireland and Wales rose by 5.2% and 4.2% annually, respectively. Experts predict little change in price growth and transaction levels over the coming months.

site_title: Carousell adopts Singapore government service MyInfo to combat fraud
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds platform, has adopted the government-developed service MyInfo to combat fraud. Existing users can authenticate their profiles using government-verified personal details, and the verification process allows Carousell to assist with investigations more effectively. The service protects user data privacy by not storing NRIC numbers. This step aims to create a layer of accountability and trust, addressing the industry-wide challenge of fraud and scams.

site_title: Isec CEO, shareholders in advanced talks for stake sale to third party
summary: ISEC Healthcare's CEO and certain shareholders, including executive director and CEO Wong Jun Shyan, are in advanced talks with a third-party purchaser for a potential stake sale. The transaction, if completed, may lead to an offer for Isec's shares. No definitive sale-and-purchase agreement has been entered, and the outcome is uncertain. Isec has warned that any agreement may be conditional and does not guarantee completion or an offer. The company has not disclosed the identity of the potential purchaser or the terms of the potential transaction.

site_title: Dealmakers for the rich face a 'Kodak moment,' UBS banker warns
summary: UBS banker Joe Stadler warns that wealthy clients are bypassing financial institutions for direct deals, citing a trend accelerating since years. Family offices and hedge funds are completing transactions without investment bank advice, driven by growing direct deals among the super-rich. Regulators' suitability tests and paperwork are deterring banks, prompting them to create their own deal platforms. To stay relevant, banks are leveraging their skills to match buyers and sellers, and charging lucrative fees for their services.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes marginally higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.11% to close at 21,754.27, despite a sluggish trading session. The broader Topix index also gained 0.31%. The market was divided on the US-China trade dispute, following a 2% rally on Monday.

site_title: La Scala Opera chooses new leader
summary: La Scala Opera in Milan has chosen Dominique Meyer, the head of Vienna's State Opera, as its new leader starting in 2021. Meyer, 63, will initially work jointly with outgoing artistic director Alexander Pereira, who is leaving amid a scandal over fundraising efforts with the Saudi Arabian government. Meyer has increased revenue at the Vienna State Opera, and his appointment aims to extend La Scala's repertoire to include 18th-century composers from Naples.

site_title: Here to help: get checked for sleep apnea
summary: Sleep apnea affects an estimated 22 million Americans, with most cases going undiagnosed. To get checked, individuals should consult a primary care doctor or sleep medicine specialist, who may schedule a sleep test. There are two methods: a traditional polysomnogram in a sleep lab, which is more accurate but less convenient, or a home sleep test, which is cheaper and simpler but less accurate. A home sleep test captures data on blood oxygen levels, airflow, and bodily movement, and can be done in the comfort of one's own bed.

site_title: 'Hong Kong is not China': Protests pose major test for Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping faces a major test in Hong Kong as protesters stormed the legislature and defaced its walls with a defiant message, "Hong Kong is not China". The protests, which began over a bill allowing extraditions to the mainland, have pushed Beijing's patience to the limit, prompting a statement condemning the "blatant challenge" to the "one country, two systems" principle. Beijing's initial reaction is to call for an investigation into the protesters, while Xi may have limited options to avoid spooking foreign investors in the global financial hub.

site_title: Ivory Coast to eliminate illegal cocoa output to control supply
summary: Ivory Coast plans to eliminate illegal cocoa production from national parks and forest reserves over the next five years to control output and support a new floor price of $2,600 per tonne. The move aims to reduce the structural production surplus that could drag prices down. The government will establish a legal framework, expel illegal farmers, and destroy their plantations, with a goal of eliminating illegally grown cocoa volumes of 300,000 to 500,000 tonnes each season.

site_title: Europe: Shares eke out gains as trade fueled rally fades
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, despite US tariff threats on additional EU goods worth $4 billion. The US government released a list of products, including olives and Scotch whiskey, that could be hit with tariffs. This followed a rally in the previous session, as financials rose 0.4% and shares of HSBC Holdings and Prudential Plc climbed. The US-China trade war truce had previously boosted European shares, but the new threats kept gains in check, with planemaker Airbus dropping 1%.

site_title: Australia cuts interest rates further
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates for the second-straight month, lowering the cost of borrowing to a historic low of 1%. The 25 basis point cut aims to support employment growth and provide confidence in inflation. The move follows a 28-year-run without a recession and comes as central banks worldwide shift to a more accommodative stance amid trade uncertainty.

site_title: AB InBev Asia unit sets terms for US$9.8b Hong Kong IPO
summary: Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, the Asia-Pacific unit of Anheuser-Busch InBev SA, has set terms for a US$9.8 billion Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), surpassing Uber Technologies' US$8.1 billion offering this year. The IPO will offer 1.63 billion shares at HK$40 to HK$47 apiece, with trading expected to begin on July 19. The deal, led by JPMorgan Chase & Co and Morgan Stanley, would value Budweiser at US$54 billion to US$64 billion, making it the world's largest IPO this year.

site_title: Brazil meat giants surge on trade deal, but worries persist
summary: Brazilian meat processing giants BRF and JBS surged on the signing of a historic trade deal with the European Union, opening the EU to South American agricultural products. The deal, after 20 years of talks, marked a major breakthrough for the region. Shares in BRF rose nearly 9% and JBS gained 5.5%, outperforming the benchmark index. The agreement is expected to boost trade between the EU and Mercosur countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday trading at 3,357.57, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,357.57, down 0.4% on Tuesday. The Straits Times Index fell 14.69 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 182 to 136, with about 561.4 million securities changing hands. Notable stocks include Genting Singapore, Singtel, and PSC, which made a mandatory offer. The rally in Singapore stocks is ahead of GDP data and amid global market optimism.

site_title: Credit Suisse International Wealth CEO Khan in surprise exit
summary: Credit Suisse International Wealth CEO Iqbal Khan abruptly left his position, sparking speculation he will join Julius Baer Group Ltd. as its new CEO. Khan's departure coincides with increased competition between Switzerland's lenders for top private bankers. Credit Suisse's wealth-management unit, the second biggest contributor to profit, will be led by CFO Philipp Wehle, who was praised by CEO Tidjane Thiam for his strong leadership and performance culture. Khan's move mirrors that of a recent UBS investment banker who left for Banco Santander SA.

site_title: Asean opportunities for Singapore in additive manufacturing: specialists
summary: Singapore has opportunities to collaborate with Asean neighbours on additive manufacturing (AM), which is expected to generate US$100 billion in value by 2025. Established industries like petrochemicals and testing can aid AM development, while Singapore can export its model for the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster and serve as a test bed. The country can also position itself as a service centre for the region, providing services like product development and research. A Thyssenkrupp event estimated AM could create 3-4 million jobs in Asean by 2030.

site_title: Nike pulls US flag-themed shoe after Kaepernick objection: report
summary: Nike has withdrawn a US flag-themed shoe after Colin Kaepernick objected to its design, citing its association with slavery. The Air Max 1 USA featured an early version of the American flag, known as the Betsy Ross flag, which was unveiled to coincide with the US's July 4 independence day. Nike pulled the shoe following Kaepernick's objections, a Nike endorser who led kneeling protests during NFL games in 2016 to protest racial inequality and social injustice. The move was reportedly made in response to Kaepernick's concerns.

images.alt_text: Nike withdrew a shoe displaying an early version of the American flag after former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick warned the design was associated with slavery, US media reported on Monday.

site_title: Collectibles startup Mighty Jaxx raises S$2.15m in pre-Series A round
summary: Mighty Jaxx, a Singapore-based designer toy collectibles studio, has raised S$2.15 million in a pre-Series A round led by Eight Mercatus and co-invested by SGInnovate. The funds will be used for global expansion and development of its blockchain-powered platform, which issues unique certificates to verify collectible provenance. The platform aims to solidify Mighty Jaxx's position as a global market leader in the collectibles industry. Founded in 2012, Mighty Jaxx has shipped millions of products to over 50 countries and partnered with renowned pop culture artists and brands.

site_title: China to push forward opening up of financial, manufacturing sectors
summary: China plans to ease ownership limits for foreign investors in its financial sector in 2020, a year ahead of schedule, and push forward opening up of its manufacturing sector, including the auto industry. The country will also reduce its negative investment list for foreigners and promote imports of goods and services. The move aims to further open up China's markets to foreign investment, although progress has been slow. The Chinese government will cut the number of sectors subject to foreign investment restrictions to 40 from 48, effective July 30.

site_title: Japan government names Yoshiki Takeuchi as top currency diplomat
summary: Japan's Ministry of Finance has named Yoshiki Takeuchi as vice-finance minister for international affairs, marking the country's most senior foreign exchange diplomat. Takeuchi, currently international bureau chief, will oversee currency market intervention, although Japan has not intervened in years. He will take over on Friday, replacing Masatsugu Asakawa, as part of a routine personnel reshuffle.

site_title: Moon hails Trump-Kim meeting as result of 'astounding imagination'
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In hailed the third meeting between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un as a result of "astounding imagination" and thinking outside the box. The impromptu meeting at the Demilitarized Zone resulted in an agreement to resume working-level talks, which had been deadlocked since the collapse of their second summit in February. Both sides expressed willingness to continue talks to restart stalled nuclear negotiations, marking a "de-facto declaration of an end to hostile relations and the beginning of a full-fledged era of peace."

site_title: Pan Asian Holdings unit sells remaining 25% stake in Tianjin firm for 3.1m yuan
summary: Pan Asian Holdings' unit sold its remaining 25% stake in DWK Valves (Tianjin) Co for 3.1 million yuan, valued at S$625,000. The sale was approved by China's authority and will be paid over three years. The deal is part of Pan Asian's strategy to reduce its reliance on the Tianjin-based firm, which manufactures Duvalco brand valves. The sale's net present value is estimated at S$567,343, with potential penalties for non-compliance.

site_title: Key Apple designer from Ive's team lands at home robotics startup
summary: Rico Zorkendorfer, a key Apple designer, has joined Bumblebee Spaces, a home robotics startup. Zorkendorfer, who left Apple in April, leads design at the San Francisco-based company, which combines smart home products and robotics. Bumblebee Spaces has developed smart furnishings that can be raised into ceilings, increasing apartment space. Zorkendorfer previously worked on Apple devices, including the Apple Watch, under Jony Ive's leadership. This marks one of several high-profile departures from Apple's industrial design team in recent months.

site_title: 3 best-performing office S-Reits returned 28% in year to date: SGX
summary: Singapore's top three office S-Reits, Mapletree Commercial Trust, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, and Frasers Commercial Trust, returned an average of 27.6% in the first half of 2019, outperforming the market. The office market in Singapore is experiencing a recovery, with occupancy rates rebounding to 95.2% in the first quarter. New supply is expected to average 1.36 million square feet per year, 29% below the 10-year average, leading to tighter vacancies and rising rents.

site_title: Australia's Blackmores hires China-focused boss to lead turnaround
summary: Blackmores Ltd, an Australian vitamin maker, hired Alastair Symington as its new CEO, seeking to revive sales growth after a consumer downturn. Symington, 46, brings experience in China and managing similar consumer brands. The company posted a profit plunge last quarter and its share price hovered near a four-year low. Investors welcomed the new appointment, lifting shares 1.9% in early trade. Symington starts his new job on October 1 and aims to drive substantial top-line growth via a greater presence of Blackmores throughout the region.

site_title: Australia: Miners lift shares before RBA decision; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,668.80, led by gains from heavyweight miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto, which reached an over eight-year high and 11-year high respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to deliver a second rate cut, benefiting local miners. New Zealand stocks also reached a record high, driven by gains in utilities and consumer stocks.

site_title: Golden Equator Capital raises US$90m in two private capital funds
summary: Golden Equator Capital has raised US$90 million in two private capital funds for growth capital in the infrastructure, energy, and financial sectors of an undisclosed public-listed company in Southeast Asia. The funds were backed by institutional and accredited investors in Singapore, Japan, and Korea. Managing partner Jacob Jiwon Kim sees Asia's growth potential, driven by infrastructure, energy, finance, and technology, and plans to use Singapore as a base to connect markets in Southeast Asia with the broader Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.74 points to 1,685.36. Volume reached 84.2 million lots worth RM34.82 million, with 105 gainers outpacing 80 losers.

site_title: Japan stocks may be the only outperformers in H2, JPMorgan says
summary: JPMorgan predicts Japan's Topix index may return 6.6% in the second half of 2019, nearly double its 3.8% gain in the first half, making it a potential outperformer globally. Analysts attribute this to Japan's lower valuations and expected sub-trend growth for the world's economies. In contrast, most asset classes are expected to deliver low single-digit returns for the rest of 2019. The prediction comes after a global stock rally following the US-China trade dispute truce, but valuations remain high.

site_title: Morocco hopes to attract US$10b in investment to new tech city
summary: Morocco aims to attract $10 billion in investment and create 100,000 jobs at Tanger Tech Mohammed VI, a high-tech city near Tangier. The city is being developed by BMCE Bank and China Communications Construction Co. (CCCC) after a Chinese company, Haite group, withdrew from the project. Tax incentives will be granted to companies in various industries, and work has begun on connecting the city to infrastructure. The city will be built in three phases, with the first phase covering up to 700 hectares, and will benefit from the Tanger Med port.

site_title: Paris introduces rent controls to cap rises
summary: Paris has reintroduced rent controls to cap rises, following a previous attempt that was struck down in court. The new mechanism sets a reference rent for each area, with apartments not allowed to be rented at more than 20% above this price. This aims to help middle-class families in the city, where rental prices have risen by over 50% in the last 15 years. Similar measures have been introduced in other European cities, such as Berlin, to tackle house price inflation and gentrification.

site_title: Sinopec launches product oil pipeline in central China
summary: Sinopec Group has launched a product oil pipeline in central China's Hubei province, connecting its Jingmen petrochemical plant and Xiangyang oil depot. The 130.4km pipeline has an annual oil transportation capacity of 3.5 million tonnes, aiming to expand market access for refineries in central China and reduce logistics costs.

site_title: Construction firm fined S$54,000 for damaging PUB water mains; highest amount to date
summary: A construction firm, Ground Instrumentation and Engineering, has been fined S$54,000 for damaging PUB's 2.2m diameter water main at Raffles Country Club, the highest fine to date. The company failed to consult PUB on the water main's location and did not submit a plan for soil investigation works. The incident resulted in 890,000 litres of potable water being wasted. This is Ground Instrumentation and Engineering's second offence, having been fined S$40,000 in 2016 for damaging a 30cm diameter water main.

site_title: Electric cars grab almost half of sales in oil-producing Norway
summary: Norway's electric car sales surged to 48.4% of new car sales in the first six months of 2019, surpassing the global average. Tesla's Model 3 was the top-selling vehicle, with California-based Tesla leading the market with 3,760 sales in June. Norway's policy of exempting electric cars from heavy taxes has boosted brands such as Tesla, Nissan, Hyundai, and BMW, while others like Ford and Mercedes-Benz have seen sales drop. The country aims to end diesel and petrol engine sales by the middle of the next decade, solidifying its top ranking in per-capita electric car sales.

site_title: EU leaders try anew to end impasse on top jobs
summary: EU leaders meet for the third consecutive day in Brussels to discuss filling top EU jobs, following a stalemate over a Franco-German compromise. French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel had proposed Dutch Social Democrat Frans Timmermans to head the European Commission and Kristalina Georgieva to become European Council president. However, several centre-right leaders rebelled, and a compromise candidate could replace outgoing diplomatic chief Federica Mogherini. The EU Parliament will debate the candidates in its inaugural session on Tuesday, with a nominee needing 21 of the 28 EU leaders' backing for approval.

site_title: Beijing backs criminal probe after Hong Kong 'illegal actions'
summary: China's central government backs a criminal probe into the "illegal actions" of protesters in Hong Kong who broke into the legislature on the 22nd anniversary of the city's handover to China. The protesters, mostly young and hardline, vandalized the building, hung the colonial-era flag, and left anti-Beijing graffiti. The incident has thrown Hong Kong into crisis amid weeks of demonstrations over a bill allowing extraditions to the Chinese mainland. The Chinese government has condemned the violence and supported the city authorities in investigating the "criminal responsibility of violent offenders."

site_title: Shiseido's beauty app promises perfect skin - at US$92 a month
summary: Shiseido has launched a skincare subscription service called Optune, promising perfect skin for US$92 a month. The service uses a smartphone app and dispenser to analyze skin and provide a personalized serum formula twice a day. The app analyzes factors such as skin conditions, sleep rhythms, and external factors like weather and air pollution to deliver the right mix of serums. Sales started Monday, with the service initially available in Japan and potentially expanded abroad. Analysts expect annual sales of US$67.9 billion.

site_title: Asia: Markets subdued after rally, Hong Kong brushes off protests
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, despite a 2% rally the previous day, as disappointing factory data fueled concerns over the global economic outlook. The US manufacturing index fell to its lowest level in almost three years, while China and Europe also reported contraction in their factory sectors. Hong Kong stocks rose 1.3% as investors brushed off violent protests, while other markets, including Tokyo, Sydney, and Wellington, also gained. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates, and central banks may provide further support to economies.

site_title: Japan Inc's inflation expectations stagnate, keep BOJ under pressure
summary: Japanese companies' inflation expectations stagnated at 0.9% for the next year, unchanged from three months ago, and below the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The survey suggests the BOJ's monetary experiment to boost inflation is failing, with companies and households showing no sign of increasing spending. The BOJ may be forced to ease monetary support as early as this month if the US Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, hurting Japan's exports.

site_title: US semiconductor sales data point to 'signs of life', say analysts
summary: US semiconductor sales data shows stabilization in the industry, with May sales reaching $33 billion, a 7.1% increase from April. This represents a moderation in the 14.5% year-over-year decline in April. Analysts believe the industry is nearing the end of a cycle of weakness and tepid demand, with forecasts cut during a period of negative sentiment. The data suggests upside bias to 2019/2020 numbers, indicating a possible rebound in the industry.

site_title: US proposes tariffs on another US$4b of European Union goods
summary: The US proposed tariffs on an additional $4 billion of European Union goods in response to EU subsidies to Airbus. The proposed tariffs include products such as cherries, meat, cheese, olives, pasta, whiskey, and cast-iron tubes. The US Trade Representative's office said the EU subsidies cause $11 billion in annual economic harm to the US. The move is expected to further strain US-EU ties as negotiations for a trade deal continue. The European Union has its own pending case against Boeing, which the US has also targeted with retaliatory tariffs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.82% in early trade on Tuesday, driven by news that China-US talks were resuming. However, gains were tempered after violent protests hit the city overnight. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 28,776.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index dipped slightly. Despite the protests, investors remained optimistic about the resumption of US-China talks.

site_title: Biolidics calls for trading halt pending revised statement on reimbursement for cancer tests in China
summary: Biolidics, a medical technology firm, has requested a trading halt pending a revised statement on reimbursement for cancer tests in China. The company initially stated that Chinese lab tests for cancer would be reimbursed under the national basic medical insurance program, but clarified that the reimbursement is actually for cancer drug treatments, not the tests. Clinical trials are underway to test a cancer treatment, and successful trials may lead to reimbursement under the insurance program.

site_title: Singapore firms' payment performance worsens in Q2: SCCB
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance worsened in Q2, with prompt payments falling to 49.44% and slow payments rising to 37.1%, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. This marks a decline from the previous quarter and year-on-year. The manufacturing sector saw the largest increase in slow payments, while the retail sector saw the largest decline. The sector's slow payments fell 1.54 percentage points to 36.19%. The worsening payment performance is attributed to weaker performance within the manufacturing sector and deteriorating credit conditions.

site_title: Australian government close to securing enough votes for A$158b tax cut plan
summary: Australia's conservative government is close to securing enough votes to pass a sweeping tax cut plan worth A$158 billion. The proposal, aimed at middle-income earners, needs the support of three independents and minor parties. The plan is seen as a response to a slowing economy, and the government has already implemented A$144 billion in tax cuts last year. The main opposition Labor party has vowed to oppose the legislation in the Senate, but independent lawmakers are poised to strike an agreement with Prime Minister Scott Morrison.

site_title: Joe Biden's son held at gunpoint during crack buy: report
summary: Hunter Biden, son of US presidential candidate Joe Biden, admitted to being held at gunpoint while trying to buy crack cocaine in 2016. According to The New Yorker, Hunter was approached by a homeless man in Los Angeles, who took him to a nearby encampment and pointed a gun to his head. Hunter returned to buy more crack multiple times that week. This incident is part of a period of Hunter's reported struggles with addiction and family tragedy, including his father's loss of his wife and baby daughter in a car crash.

site_title: Trump says US will keep strong intel presence in Afghanistan
summary: President Donald Trump announced that the US will maintain a strong intelligence presence in Afghanistan despite plans to withdraw troops. In an interview, Trump called Afghanistan the "Harvard of terrorists," stating that the US will leave behind a significant intelligence presence. This move aims to counter the country's role as a hub for terrorist training and operations.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.01% to 3,372.48
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.01% to 3,372.48. The gains followed a global rally, with US stocks reaching fresh records after the US and China reached a ceasefire on further trade tariffs. Gainers outnumbered losers 53 to 48, with about 43.3 million securities worth S$53.1 million exchanging hands.

site_title: Credit Suisse wealth management CEO Khan departs; Wehle promoted
summary: Credit Suisse's international wealth management unit will be led by Philipp Wehle, who replaces departing CEO Iqbal Khan. Wehle, who has been CFO of the unit since 2015, will bring a strong performance culture and personal values to the role. CEO Tidjane Thiam praised Wehle's track record of generating revenue growth while driving cost and capital discipline. The move aims to reinforce the team's leadership and performance culture.

site_title: OCBC partners Republic Polytechnic on first PayNow initiative for educational institutions
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered with Republic Polytechnic to introduce the first PayNow initiative for educational institutions in Singapore. Students and their parents can now pay course fees online using PayNow, with the polytechnic utilizing OCBC's API to enable payments from bank accounts with any of the nine participating banks. This marks the first time a Singapore educational institution has adopted the electronic funds transfer service.

site_title: Antarctic sea ice in dizzying decline since 2014: study
summary: Antarctic sea ice cover has plummeted by 2 million square kilometers since 2014, reaching a record low, according to a study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The ice cover, which had expanded from 1979 to 2014, receded rapidly from 2014 to 2017 and has continued to decline since. The cause of this decline remains unknown, with competing theories including ozone layer depletion and shifting ocean currents. Scientists caution against applying findings from the Arctic to the Antarctic due to differences in their oceanic and climatic conditions.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record, up 0.8%, on trade ceasefire
summary: The S&P 500 ended at a record high, 0.8% above, following a US-China trade ceasefire. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached fresh records. Despite the gains, lingering questions about the agreement limited the increase. The S&P 500 closed at 2,964.45, surpassing its prior record by about 10 points.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens marginally lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.05% lower on Tuesday, following a 2% gain in the previous session on a US-China trade truce. The broader Topix index rose 0.11%. The lower opening came as investors took profit after the recent rally.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit issues new units to raise 150m euros; distributes income to existing unitholders
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) issued 326.1 million new units at 46 euro cents each, raising 150 million euros, to finance the purchase of six European office properties. Existing unitholders will receive a distribution of income prior to the issue of new units to ensure fairness. The new units will rank pari passu with existing units, except for those from a cumulative distribution. The distribution policy will resume after the issuance of new units, with semi-annual distributions to be made from July 2 to Dec 31.

site_title: US marketing tech firm Stratacache opens warehouse and logistics centre in Tampines
summary: US-based marketing tech firm Stratacache has opened a 15,000 sq ft warehouse and logistics centre in Tampines, Singapore, to support its Asia-Pacific clients. The facility, located near Stratacache's Singapore office, will enhance the company's global delivery capability and marketing technology solutions. It will coordinate with Stratacache's 250,000 sq ft production facility in Ningbo, China, and serve as a regional service and configuration centre for the 10 Asia-Pacific sales offices. The opening marks the company's growth in Asia and expansion of its infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The opening of the Tampines facility comes after the company had centralised its Asia-Pacific operations at the new Singapore regional headquarters in February.

site_title: Calm falls on Hong Kong after protests erupt into extraordinary violence
summary: Hong Kong experienced extraordinary violence on July 2, 2019, after protesters stormed the legislature to protest against an extradition bill. Police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of protesters, leaving debris and chaos. The city returned to calm after police cleared roads near the financial center. The violence marked a direct challenge to Beijing's authority, highlighting tensions in the Chinese-ruled territory. Normal business operations resumed, but the incident raised concerns about the city's stability.

site_title: US Democratic frontrunner Biden drops in polls after debate
summary: US Democratic frontrunner Joe Biden's support has declined after the presidential candidate debate, with 22% of voters backing him, down from 32% in May. Senator Kamala Harris saw her popularity rise, reaching 17% support and second place, while Senator Elizabeth Warren is in third with 15%. Despite post-debate fluctuations, voters still see Biden as the strongest candidate against President Trump, with 43% believing he can unseat him. Months of campaigning remain before the opening Democratic primary contest in Iowa next February.

site_title: Gold sinks most in a year as trade truce deals blow to bulls
summary: Gold prices tumbled the most in a year after the US and China reached a trade truce, dealing a blow to havens. The agreement, announced by Presidents Trump and Xi Jinping, led to a decline in gold prices below $1,400 an ounce. However, some analysts see this as a temporary setback, as investors now focus on US jobs data and the Federal Reserve's next policy move. This price drop may provide a welcome entry point for gold bulls, according to Ross Norman, CEO of Sharps Pixley Ltd.

images.alt_text: Gold prices fell the most in a year after Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping agreed to resume trade negotiations.

site_title: Italy confirms 2020 deficit target at 2.1% of GDP: government source
summary: Italy confirmed its 2020 budget deficit target at 2.1% of GDP, exceeding previous targets. This comes despite European Commission threats to launch disciplinary action due to unmet debt reduction promises in 2018. In contrast, the 2019 budget target was reduced from 2.4% to 2.04%.

site_title: Amazon plans to create 1,800 jobs in France in 2019
summary: Amazon plans to create 1,800 permanent contract positions in France by the end of 2019, increasing its total staff to 9,300. The move reflects the company's investment of over $2 billion in the French market since 2010. Amazon has 20 sites in France, including six logistics centers, and is expanding its presence with a new site slated to open in Bretigny-Sur-Orge near Paris.

site_title: US urges all sides in Hong Kong to avoid violence
summary: The US has urged all sides in Hong Kong to avoid violence following the ransacking of the territory's parliament on the anniversary of its handover to China. Protesters, mostly masked, broke into the legislature and vandalized it with anti-government graffiti. The US has expressed solidarity with activists who blocked a move to allow extraditions to the Chinese mainland. The US emphasizes Hong Kong's success relies on its rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms, including expression and peaceful assembly.

site_title: US will 'never allow' Iran to develop nuclear weapons: White House
summary: The US White House warned that it will "never allow" Iran to develop nuclear weapons, following Tehran's announcement that it has exceeded a limit on enriched uranium reserves under the 2015 nuclear deal. The US withdrew from the deal last year and has imposed punishing sanctions, leading to deteriorating relations. The White House statement called for the restoration of the nonproliferation standard of no enrichment for Iran, amid tensions over attacks on tanker ships and a downed US surveillance drone.

site_title: 'Multi-bilateral' trade order the way forward - and it's achievable
summary: The G20 summit in Japan has highlighted the danger that the forum may wither away as a key multilateral organ in the face of resurgent bilateralism. China and the US have emerged as strong champions of their respective visions for the future international economic order, with China favoring multilateralism and the US promoting bilateral deals. A potential compromise could be a "multi-bilateral" world order, where loosely coordinated bilateral and regional trade deals replace the current system. If China and the US can reach an ambitious, comprehensive, and sustainable deal to settle their economic tensions, it could catalyze a new multi-bilateral trading order, preventing a potential economic war between the two nations.

site_title: UK police say airline stowaway's body found in London garden
summary: UK police have identified a body found in a London garden as a suspected stowaway who fell from a Kenya Airways plane landing at Heathrow Airport on Sunday. The man is believed to have been hiding in the landing gear compartment. The death is not being treated as suspicious, and an investigation is underway to establish the full circumstances. This is the third reported case of a stowaway's body being found on a plane in recent years, following similar incidents in 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Green Build says deals for columbarium niches, convertible bond have lapsed
summary: Green Build Technology's asset purchase agreement with Yea Eun Columbarium to buy niches in Seoul, South Korea, and a convertible bond agreement with investor Kim Kwang Seun have both lapsed due to unmet conditions. The agreements were initially signed in August 2018 and were set to expire on June 30. Green Build's board stated that the lapsing agreements will not have a material adverse impact on its business operations and financial position. Shares of the company last traded at S$0.11 on April 30.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Prostate cancer: What you need to know
summary: Dr. Daniel Tan, deputy medical director at Concord International Hospital, discusses prostate cancer on the Money FM podcast. He explains the condition, identifies symptoms, and debunks myths surrounding the third most prevalent cancer in Singaporean men. The conversation aims to raise awareness and promote early detection.

site_title: Oil steadies on Opec cuts, but oversupply fears persist
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday after Opec agreed to extend supply cuts until March 2020, despite lingering concerns about oversupply. Brent crude futures rose 32 cents to $65.06, while US crude futures climbed 62 cents to $59.09. The deal, which includes Russia and Saudi Arabia, aims to prop up prices amid a weakening global economy and soaring US production. However, analysts expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of the cuts, citing a long wait for the Opec meeting to conclude and concerns about US production growth.

site_title: Learning how to engage millennials
summary: A seminar by sgsme.sg will discuss engaging millennials as stakeholders and consumers, as they soon surpass baby boomers as the most powerful consumers. The event, on July 9, aims to help organisations reach out to millennials effectively. Organised by business resource portals, the seminar is part of a six-business-empowerment series.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally to near 2-month highs on US-China trade reprieve
summary: European shares surged to near 2-month highs, rising 0.8% on the Stoxx 600 index, driven by a US-China trade reprieve. The agreement includes no new tariffs and reduced restrictions on Huawei, boosting technology stocks. The breakthrough helped the Stoxx 600 index start the second half of the year on a strong note, with stocks across the globe rising. However, analysts warn that the relief rally may be temporary and that a deal is still uncertain, with both parties remaining at odds over significant parts of an agreement.

site_title: Trump move to ease Huawei sanctions sparks anger, confusion
summary: US President Donald Trump's agreement with China to ease sanctions on Huawei has sparked anger and confusion over national security concerns. Despite White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow's statement that Huawei may receive new licenses, some lawmakers, including Senator Marco Rubio and Representative Jim Banks, have expressed opposition, calling for stricter regulations. The deal's impact on Huawei remains unclear, with experts warning it may not provide the necessary relief and could damage the company's smartphone business.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Cromwell E-Reit, Biolidics, Green Build, Raffles United
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include: CapitaLand selling its 24.09% stake in Hong Kong-listed CCRE for HK$2.83 billion, Cromwell E-Reit placing new units at 46 euro cents each via private placement, Memtech International's free float falling under 10% prompting trading suspension, Biolidics requesting trading halt pending revised press release on China reimbursement, New Silkroutes Group's sale and purchase agreement for IEG expiring, Green Build Technology's asset purchase and convertible bond agreements expiring, and Raffles United Holdings receiving a mandatory unconditional cash offer for its shares.

site_title: Fresh bid set to bring Afghans to table for peace deal
summary: US and Taliban officials are set to meet in Qatar starting Sunday, aiming for a peace deal within three months. The Taliban has refused to negotiate with President Ashraf Ghani, but rival Afghans will meet with government officials in Doha for the first time since April. Germany and Qatar have jointly extended invitations for the dialogue, with the US seeking to pull its 14,000 troops from Afghanistan in exchange for the Taliban's assurance that their territory won't be used for foreign attacks. The meeting comes after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo voiced hope for a deal before September 1.

site_title: Trump says US-China trade talks 'already begun'
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that trade talks with China have resumed following a truce with Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 summit. The two nations agreed to hold off on new tariff increases, and Trump offered to relax restrictions on US technology exports to Huawei, sparking backlash from US lawmakers. This development comes after a year-long trade war between the world's top two economies.

site_title: ARA goes global, more than doubles AUM to S$80b
summary: ARA Asset Management has more than doubled its assets under management (AUM) to S$80.1 billion, driven by mergers, acquisitions, and organic expansion. Co-founder John Lim aims to reach S$100 billion and potentially reconsider a public listing. The group has set up country desks in Japan, the US, and Europe and is exploring investments in infrastructure and essential services. Despite challenges in resources and integration, Lim believes a return to normalized interest rates will be beneficial for the market.

site_title: Facebook to broaden effort to root out white nationalist content
summary: Facebook announced new steps to eliminate content promoting white nationalism and white separatism, following an external audit that found its efforts were "too narrow." The audit, led by civil rights attorney Laura Murphy, recommended barring content that would cause "the same harm" as explicit praise or support of these terms. Facebook will broaden its policy to address this gap, aiming to prevent similar harm from remaining on the platform. The changes aim to improve Facebook's response to hate speech and promote a safer online environment.

site_title: Making sense of the platform economy
summary: The platform economy, born from the digital era, has revolutionized the way businesses operate with customers. Since the Internet's inception 30 years ago, this new model has created online marketplaces, facilitating interactions between merchants and buyers. In the Asia-Pacific, 77% of respondents attest to the benefits of online marketplaces, driving the growth of platform-led business models. As the platform economy evolves, businesses must adapt to form lasting relationships and add unique value to the market, with opportunities for growth across traditional sectors.

site_title: HDB resale prices slide 0.2% in Q2
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore dropped 0.2% in Q2, reaching 130.8, compared to the previous quarter. This is the fourth consecutive quarterly decline, but prices have only decreased by 0.7% over the past year. Analysts attribute the decline to increased competition and the upcoming release of more HDB flats. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will offer over 7,800 Build-To-Order flats in August and November, and a Re-Offer of Balance Flats exercise will also take place during this time.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators seek to help victims calculate cartel harm
summary: EU antitrust regulators have released guidelines to help courts calculate cartel harm, making it easier for victims to seek damages. The guidelines apply to customers of cartels, indirect customers, and final consumers, outlining methods and techniques to calculate actual losses, profit loss, and interest. This move aims to deter and punish cartels, with fines of up to 10% of a company's global turnover. The rules will help clarify a complex issue, providing certainty for claimants and defendants.

site_title: Fintech Singapore Life secures US$90m from major Japan insurer
summary: Singapore Life, a fintech with an insurance and wealth focus, has secured a US$90 million investment from Sumitomo Life Insurance, valuing the firm at US$358 million. The investment will help accelerate its "mobile-first ambitions" and expand its staff count to 63 from 20 in 2017. This brings Singapore Life's total funding to US$153 million, following previous investments from Aberdeen Standard Investments and Aflac. The investment is seen as a response to the growing demand for integrated financial products and services in South-east Asia and Singapore.

site_title: AIIB plans to finance projects worth US$10-12b a year
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) plans to finance US$10-12 billion worth of infrastructure projects annually over the next few years, maintaining a prudent approach to investing. The bank, which has 97 members, has financed US$8 billion in projects since its launch in 2016. AIIB Vice-President Joachim von Amsberg emphasized the importance of investing in high-quality projects meeting environmental and social standards, rather than prioritizing quantity. Despite the ongoing China-US trade war, the AIIB remains open to US membership.

site_title: Singapore imposes least burden in VAT, GST compliance: study
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the country with the least burden in VAT and GST compliance, according to a study by UNSW Sydney and KPMG. The study, which assessed 47 jurisdictions, found that Singapore scored a compliance burden index of two, indicating a minimal compliance burden. The research highlights the importance of governments modernizing tax administration to support businesses in efficiently managing VAT compliance costs, with countries such as China and India also recognizing the value in having fewer VAT rates.

site_title: Q2 home prices post surprise rise, but analysts call it an anomaly
summary: Singapore's Q2 home prices rose 1.3% in the second quarter of 2019, the highest since 2014, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate. Analysts consider the increase an anomaly, attributing it to developers pricing in high land costs from the previous land acquisition cycle. Despite this, some experts believe the uptrend is unlikely to persist, citing factors such as rising unsold inventory and downward economic forecasts. The government's cooling measures may also remain in place, as analysts warn of potential further measures if property prices continue to rebound.

site_title: Protesters storm HK legislature, smashing walls, doors amid extradition Bill anger
summary: Protesters stormed Hong Kong's legislature building on its 22nd anniversary of returning to Chinese rule, smashing walls and doors amid anger over a proposed extradition bill that would allow extraditions to China. About 1,000 protesters gathered, using makeshift tools to break through the doors, while the government accused them of deploying "extreme violence." Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam suspended the bill but stopped short of protesters' demands to scrap it, and the protests mark a shift towards more violent action.

site_title: Factory activity lower in June across Europe, Asia
summary: Factory activity declined across Europe and Asia in June, with the US manufacturing sector experiencing its lowest reading in 2.5 years due to the ongoing US-China trade spat. The downturn has led policymakers to pressure for stronger measures to avert a global recession. Analysts doubt the recent US-China agreement will lead to sustained easing of tensions, citing lingering uncertainty and potential for further economic weakness. Key indicators, including the euro zone's manufacturing PMI and China's Caixin/IHS Markit PMI, also pointed to a broad-based downturn.

site_title: Paris widens clampdown on older diesel cars
summary: Paris is expanding its ban on older diesel cars, with vehicles 13 or more years old prohibited from driving in the city during the day, starting Monday. Diesel vehicles over 18 years old and petrol vehicles over 21 years old are also banned in the greater Paris region. Motorists face fines of 68-135 euros, with a two-year "learning period" for offenders in suburban areas. The measures aim to reduce air pollution, which causes 48,000 extra deaths annually in France, and phase out diesel cars by 2024, ahead of the Summer Olympics.

site_title: Social media sales soar in Facebook-friendly Thailand
summary: In Thailand, social media sales have soared, with 334.2 billion baht (US$10.9 billion) in sales in 2017, accounting for 44% of e-commerce in the country. The growth is attributed to the widespread use of Facebook and Instagram, with 38 million people accessing Facebook daily. The success of social commerce in Thailand has also drawn attention from Facebook and Instagram, which are expanding their commerce features. Meanwhile, other countries in Asia, such as Indonesia and India, are also seeing growth in social commerce, with Thailand's market being rivaled only by Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong leader condemns 'extremely violent' storming of parliament
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam condemned the "extremely violent" storming of the parliament, where thousands of masked protesters ransacked the building on the anniversary of the territory's handover to China. The unrest, which began three weeks ago over an unpopular extradition bill, saw protesters clash with police before breaking into the legislature. Lam called for a return to normalcy, while police chief Stephen Lo described the protesters' actions as "violent" and exceeding peaceful expressions of demands. The city's financial hub has been rocked by the demonstrations, with Lam resisting calls to permanently shelve the extradition bill.

site_title: Mumbai airport investor gets court approval to sell stake to 3rd party
summary: Bidvest Group Ltd, a South African investor, has received court approval to sell its 13.5% stake in Mumbai International Airport to a third party. The ruling blocks GVK Power & Infrastructure Ltd's bid to increase its ownership to 74%, as it failed to show preparedness to purchase the shares. Billionaire Gautam Adani's Adani Enterprises Ltd is reportedly eyeing a stake in the airport, amidst India's growing air traffic market expected to become the third-largest in 10 years.

site_title: Democrats have tough task to sway voters
summary: Democrats face a tough task to sway voters, as tilting to the left may alienate moderate voters and the party's moderate base. In contrast to the 2016 Republican presidential primary, where the establishment warned against embracing extremist right-wing positions, Democrats are now being scolded for considering radical leftist ideas. The party's shift to the left is evident in the Democratic presidential debates, where candidates are calling for a major overhaul of America's social-economic system, nationalizing healthcare, and providing free college education. However, this approach may alienate moderate voters and help President Trump secure a second term.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust to buy China mall for 1.37b yuan
summary: Dasin Retail Trust has agreed to purchase Doumen Metro Mall in China for 1.374 billion yuan (S$274.8 million), funded with debt and equity. The acquisition, considered an interested-person transaction, involves the company's chairman and a controlling unitholder, Aqua Wealth Holdings. The mall has a 99.7% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 11.9 years. The deal is subject to unitholder approval and includes a private placement of new units to Aqua Wealth.

site_title: Of comic books and couture at 'Mode et Bande Dessinee'
summary: The "Mode et Bande Dessinee" ("Fashion and Comic Books") exhibition in Angouleme, France, showcases the connection between comic books and graphic novels and the fashion industry. The show, running until January 5, 2020, features 13,000 original plates and 250,000 French-language comics, including works by Yves Saint Laurent and Jean Paul Gaultier, who drew inspiration from comic books. The exhibition highlights the impact of comic books on fashion, with examples of comic book characters influencing designer outfits and vice versa.

site_title: Five key themes in Asia-Pac real estate
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investors face uncertainty amid renewed US-China trade tensions, with China's potential sub-6% growth forecasted to be the biggest drag. Looser monetary conditions will support real estate pricing, but investors should be cautious of a more pronounced divergence in performance due to rising risks. The office sector will focus on cities with resilient fundamentals, while e-commerce penetration may reduce retail demand. The APAC real estate market is becoming more institutionalized, with cross-border investors playing a key role.

site_title: Shareholder makes mandatory offer for Raffles United
summary: A shareholder, Raffles Infinity Holdings, led by Teo Xian-Hui Amanda Marie, has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer for Raffles United Holdings shares at 6.5 Singapore cents per share. Raffles Infinity acquired 82.08% of Raffles United's shares, triggering a mandatory general offer. The offer price represents a 19-27% premium above the last traded price. The offeror aims to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange and has stated that the offer will allow accepting shareholders to realize their investments at a significant premium without incurring trading costs.

site_title: Top culinary destinations Down Under
summary: Australia has emerged as a notable culinary destination, offering a unique fusion of East and West cuisines. The country's chefs have combined fresh, quality produce with innovative techniques, resulting in a culinary explosion. Notable destinations include Lake House, which offers a signature tasting menu and a range of accommodation options, and the Emirates One&Only Wolgan Valley resort, featuring 40 free-standing villas and a range of culinary experiences. Other notable mentions include Cape Lodge in Margaret River and Saffire Freycinet in Tasmania, which offer unique culinary experiences and bespoke service.

site_title: Building a social enterprise from scratch
summary: Lam Shumei, daughter of late entrepreneur Larry Lam, built a chicken farm in Rwanda in 2014, despite numerous challenges. Today, Poultry East Africa Ltd (PEAL) is the largest poultry meat supplier in Rwanda, breaking even in 3 out of 5 years, employing 70 people and reducing chicken prices by 50% since its inception. Azul World, the investment holding company, has also made impact investments in sustainable aquaculture farms and technology. Lam emphasizes the importance of commitment, being on the ground, and understanding the local landscape for successful social impact investing, and encourages investors to pursue their passions and be patient with their returns.

site_title: Japan tightens curbs on tech material exports to South Korea over labour row
summary: Japan has tightened curbs on exports of high-tech materials to South Korea, effective Thursday, amid a dispute over South Koreans forced to work for Japanese firms during World War 2. The move, targeting companies like Samsung Electronics and LG Display, will slow exports by several months. South Korea condemned the decision, while Japan aims to protect its interests. The export controls are the latest escalation in a growing row between the two countries.

site_title: ECB could get first woman president on French suggestion to EU
summary: European Union leaders may consider a Frenchwoman for the first female European Central Bank (ECB) president, following a proposal from France. Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund managing director, is among the potential candidates. French President Emmanuel Macron's party is unlikely to be represented in other key EU posts, giving Macron a chance to claim the ECB job. Luxembourg Prime Minister Xavier Bettel suggested that the next ECB chief should be a woman, potentially reducing resistance to France gaining the leadership for the second time.

site_title: Toy Story 4 continues to rule US box office in its second week
summary: Toy Story 4 continued to dominate the US box office in its second week, earning $58 million and boosting its US total to $237 million. The film is now the fourth-highest grossing movie of the year, surpassing Disney's Aladdin and Avengers: Endgame. New releases Annabelle Comes Home and Yesterday debuted in second and third place, respectively, with $20 million and $17 million in ticket sales. Avengers: Endgame returned to the top 10 after a re-release, and Avatar remains the highest-grossing film of all time with $2.78 billion in global ticket sales.

site_title: Taking charge of the family's wealth
summary: ARA Asset Management co-founder John Lim has entrusted his son Andy to manage the family's wealth through the JL Family Office, a holding company. The family office holds significant assets, including a 20% stake in ARA with assets under management exceeding $80 billion. This decision sets a departure from the typical practice of ultra high net worth family scions taking executive roles in family businesses or corporations. By giving his son autonomy, Lim aims to allow Andy to establish his own place in the family's wealth management.

site_title: APAC banks could see M&As, not so much for Singapore: report
summary: APAC banks face a "perfect storm" of slowing growth, rising capital costs, and digital disruption, prompting potential consolidation through mergers and acquisitions. However, Singapore's banking sector has limited consolidation potential due to the dominance of the four largest banks, which collectively hold 55% of the market share. McKinsey suggests that banks with greater scale and digital capabilities will thrive, but warns that low-cost digital banks could erode incumbents' market share and ROEs, potentially dropping to 6.4% by 2023.

site_title: Asean sees silver lining even as dark clouds gather on the horizon
summary: ASEAN is emerging as a growth engine despite global economic uncertainties, driven by its large and vibrant population, rapid technology adoption, and modernized payment systems. The region's digital economy is expected to flourish with the rollout of 5G, enabling businesses to access new channels and services, and increasing financial inclusion. Trade diversion and supply-chain reconfiguration in favor of ASEAN are also expected to boost economic growth, with potential GDP growth adding 50-70 basis points in the mid- to long term.

site_title: Truce for now, but US-China tensions unlikely to go away anytime soon
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping have agreed to a truce in their trade war, temporarily halting new tariffs on Chinese goods and allowing US companies to do business with Huawei again. However, the truce is unlikely to be permanent, and tensions between the two economic giants are expected to persist. The trade war has already had a significant impact on developing nations, particularly those in South-east Asia, which rely heavily on trade with both the US and China. China is likely to take measures to insulate itself from future vulnerabilities, potentially leading to a shift in the global economic balance of power.

site_title: Amicable Trump-Xi meeting lifts market
summary: US President Donald Trump's meeting with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping resulted in a positive market reaction, boosting the Straits Times Index (STI) by 50.65 points or 1.5% to 3,372.26. The rally follows two months of trade war uncertainty, with investors responding positively to the G-20 meeting's outcome. This lift in equities marks the start of the third quarter with a strong note.

site_title: Opportunities abound in London's private residential market
summary: London's private residential market is experiencing opportunities for investors despite Brexit uncertainty. The city's global influence and resilience in the face of economic shocks, such as the 2007-2008 global financial crisis, make it an attractive destination for long-term investments. London's high-quality human capital, innovative economy, and favorable property prices, including a lower stamp duty rate for non-residents, further support its appeal. With a potential stamp duty surcharge of 9% for non-residents, London remains a more attractive option than Singapore for investors, yielding 6-7% less in stamp duties.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to issue up to five new digital bank licences, including two full bank and three wholesale bank licences, to non-bank players. This move aims to provide financial services and take deposits from retail customers and SMEs. The licences will be issued to support Singapore's digital banking development and enhance financial inclusion.

site_title: Japan land prices up for 4th straight year in 2018
summary: Japan's land prices rose for the fourth consecutive year in 2018, with an average increase of 1.3%, driven by solid demand for office space and tourism. Tokyo's Ginza shopping district maintained its position as the most expensive area, with a record high of 45.6 million yen per square meter. Okinawa experienced the largest increase, with land prices rising 8.3% and a block in Naha increasing 39.2% to 1.03 million yen per square meter. The National Tax Agency assesses land prices annually to calculate inheritance and gift taxes.

site_title: The lure of private credit in Asia-Pacific
summary: Private credit in the Asia-Pacific region is rapidly growing due to investors seeking attractive yields and a non-correlated asset class. Asia is an attractive market for private credit investments due to its high nominal growth rate, secular and cyclical drivers. Key factors driving this growth include the search for yield and the potential for uncorrelated returns, as well as Asia's high growth rate and diverse economy. Neeraj Seth, head of Asian Credit at BlackRock, highlights the potential of private credit in Asia-Pacific as a viable investment option.

site_title: GIC to invest billions in North America, Europe
summary: GIC has announced two mega deals, investing billions in North America and Europe. In the first deal, GIC and Brookfield Infrastructure will acquire US railroad owner Genesee & Wyoming Inc for US$8.4 billion, with the deal expected to close by year-end or early 2020. The second deal involves an 80:20 joint venture with Equinix to acquire and develop six hyperscale data centres in Europe for over US$1 billion, with the transaction expected to close in the third quarter.

site_title: US real estate sector expected to continue growing in H2 of 2019
summary: The US real estate sector is expected to continue growing in the second half of 2019, with residential and industrial Reits being the most popular bets. Office Reits and retail are less attractive due to weak earnings growth and interest rates. Investors are optimistic about Reits' dividend yields and cash flow growth, with predictions of high-single-digit to low-double-digit returns. Despite a recent decline, the sector is still considered a safe-haven investment, with a focus on single-family homes and warehouses used by online retailers.

site_title: Australian home prices find floor as Sydney, Melbourne finally rise
summary: Australian home prices showed early signs of recovery in June, with Sydney and Melbourne experiencing their first monthly rises since 2017. Sydney's prices rose 0.1% and Melbourne's rose 0.2%, despite national values still being down 0.2% from May. Analysts expect a sustained rebound in the housing market if auction clearance rates, monthly home price increases, and mortgage growth continue to improve. The Reserve Bank of Australia's recent interest rate cut is seen as a boost to consumer sentiment and economic demand.

site_title: KinderWorld's offer to raise S$71.4m kicks off bunch of new IPOs on SGX
summary: KinderWorld, a Vietnam-based private-school operator, is set to raise up to S$71.4 million through an IPO on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), valuing the company at between S$300.5 million and S$349.3 million. The company, which operates 15 campuses in Vietnam, aims to use the funds to open more schools and expand its operations. Meanwhile, Russian farm owner Don Agro International and healthcare provider Ardmore Medical Group have also lodged draft prospectuses for initial public offerings on the Catalist board, with plans to use the IPO proceeds for land acquisition and equipment purchases.

site_title: Yuan, dollar gain while safe-haven currencies ease
summary: The US dollar and offshore Chinese yuan rallied on Monday after the US and China agreed to restart their trade talks, contrary to market expectations. Investors sold safe-haven currencies such as the Japanese yen and Swiss franc. The agreement, which had been flagged ahead of a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, was seen as more positive than anticipated. The US dollar and yuan gained ground, while the yen and franc declined.

site_title: US factory activity falls to more than 2-1/2-year low
summary: US factory activity reached a 2-1/2-year low in June, with a measure of new orders dropping to 50.0, according to the Institute for Supply Management. This decline was attributed to growing anxiety over trade tensions between the US and China, as well as an inventory overhang. Despite this, manufacturing employment rose to 54.5, indicating some resilience in the sector. Economic growth slowed in the second quarter, with construction spending unexpectedly falling in May, and the US-China trade truce agreement did little to alleviate concerns.

images.alt_text: US manufacturing activity hit more than a 2-1/2-year low in June, with a measure of new orders received by factories tumbling, amid growing anxiety over the escalation in trade tensions between the United States and China.

site_title: Graft probe on IG Aviation Singapore directors scuppers parent's IPO
summary: Three directors of IG Aviation Singapore Pte Ltd, including the group chairman and CEO, have been charged with bribery and fraud related to their dealings with a Malaysian firm. The investigation, led by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, has thwarted plans by the company's parent, IG Logistics Group, to list on the Singapore Exchange. The charges have scuttled the IPO bid, sparing investors from potential losses. The directors allegedly gave bribes to a former executive director of a Malaysian freighter operator in exchange for favor in a general sales agent contract.

site_title: Avoiding legal pitfalls in charitable giving
summary: Donors in Singapore should carefully plan their charitable giving to avoid legal pitfalls and ensure their donations benefit the intended cause. Key considerations include aligning designated purposes with the charity's mission, avoiding funds for non-charitable purposes, and establishing proper governance and succession mechanisms. Additionally, donors should be aware of tax implications, as donations to Institutions of a Public Character (IPCs) may only qualify for tax deductions if made as outright gifts. Testamentary gifts can also be vulnerable to gaps in the gift, lack of proper governance, and non-qualifying for tax deductions.

site_title: China plans to tighten rules on cash management products
summary: China's banking regulator plans to tighten rules on cash management products (CMPs), aiming to treat them similarly to money-market funds. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) will impose stricter rules on pricing and restrict where and for how long inflows can be invested, potentially dampening investment appeal. CMPs, worth an estimated $2 trillion, will see yields drop and lose comparative advantage over money-market funds, but analysts predict minimal impact on market scale. The moves are part of China's efforts to contain financial risk amidst rising defaults and a slowing economy.

site_title: Democratic field is ambitious, but falls short of presidential
summary: The article discusses the Democratic presidential field's lack of "presidential" qualities, despite their articulate and intelligent demeanor. The author criticizes the candidates for focusing on domestic issues and neglecting foreign policy, which is expected to be a major challenge for the next president. Additionally, the author questions the feasibility of the Democratic candidates' ambitious social policies, citing a projected $1 trillion annual budget deficit and a looming national debt. The article concludes that the field lacks a leader who can persuade and make tough decisions, raising concerns about the country's preparedness for the next presidential term.

site_title: Whaling ships set sail as Japan resumes commercial hunts
summary: Japan resumes commercial whaling after decades, with five vessels setting sail from northern ports to hunt 227 whales, including 52 minke, 150 Bryde's, and 25 sei whales, until late December. The move has sparked global outrage and criticism from conservationists, who claim the practice is cruel and outdated. Japan's decision to withdraw from the International Whaling Commission and resume commercial hunts has been welcomed by local whaling communities, who celebrate the return to a traditional practice.

site_title: China PMI slips into negative for first time in 5 months
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted for the first time in five months, with the Caixin Purchasing Manufacturers' Index falling to 49.4 in June. The official PMI also dipped below the 50-point mark, indicating a slowdown. The decline is attributed to weak international and domestic demand, exacerbated by the ongoing trade war with the US. China has rolled out stimulus measures, but the government faces constraints due to its commitment to reform and debt reduction. Economists predict a renewed slowdown in the economy, with some expecting a decline in GDP growth to 6.5% this year.

site_title: Insufficient cash resources to make exit offer to shareholders: Innopac
summary: INNOPAC Holdings has stated it lacks sufficient cash resources to consider making an exit offer to shareholders. The company made this announcement in a filing to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) following its failure to meet requirements to remove itself from the watch-list over 36 months. As a result, the SGX will proceed with delisting Innopac, marking the end of its presence on the exchange.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower after President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lonza Group will acquire a sterile drug product fill-and-finish facility in Stein, Switzerland from Novartis. The acquisition will provide production capacity for Lonza and its additional customers. Meanwhile, New Silkroutes Group's sale and purchase agreement for International Energy Group to TK Energy has lapsed due to the buyer's failure to disburse loans. Memtech International's shares will be suspended due to the controlling shareholders' offer, and Innopac Holdings faces delisting due to failing to meet listing requirements.

site_title: What lies ahead in H2
summary: US-China trade tensions dampen global growth projections, but central banks' interest rate cuts boost market sentiment. Experts predict a trade deal or truce between the US and China, with stimulus from Chinese authorities and the PBOC.
